title: New Jersey Briefs
description: In the first action of its kind in New Jersey, criminal charges were filed against a Cape May County landfill company that allegedly allowed oil to seep into a Delaware Bay tributary. MarTee Contractors Inc., which operates the landfill in Middle Township, was charged with failing notify the Coast Guard of an oil spill in April, 1973, into Pennsylvania Ponds, a series of lakes that flow into the bay.

title: Joint Space Tests Succeed
description: MOSCOW, March 31 (Reuters)  Soviet space officials said today that testing of coordination of control systems for this summer's SovietAmerican space flight had been completed successfully. The official Tass press agency quoted the officials as saying that the test sessions had shown complete mutual understanding.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Foxboro Company, Foxboro, Mass., announced yesterday that sometime this month it planned to file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with contemplated public sale of about 500,000 shares of its cornmon stock.

title: 1 NURSING HOMES FOUND DEFICIENT
description: State Cites Them for Failing to Provide Adequate Services

title: Elk Hills Is a Source of Controversy
description: WASHINGTON. March 31 The California oil field that President Ford visited today is the center of a political storm that is gathering on Capitol Hill.

title: 25 Refugees Reported Killed by Own Troops
description: ABOARD PIONEER CONTENDER, Off South Vietnam, March 31 (AP)South Vietnamese marines shot and killed 25 people on the fantail of an American evacuation ship during frantic attempts to escape Da Nang, according to crew members. The marines said that they were killing Vietcong susfleets

title: Books of The Times
description: The insider's story is always the one we wait for, the one we pant to hear. Like children, we suspect that big people are sitting behind closed doors conspiring to hide dark truths from usand like children we are usually right. So, one picks up both these books with special anticipation, for George Marek and Jerome Toobin are certified insiders with respect to the Toscanini story, though Mr. Marek knew the conductor for only four years at the end of his life, and Mr. Toobin knew him not at all.

title: Oil Overcharges Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)  Representative Lee Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, reported today that the Federal Energy Administration was investigating an alleged overcharge of $40million for oil and the possibility of another $61million overcharge by the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: SAUDIS WILL PRESS MILITARY BUILDUP
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 31The new Saudi Arabian regime declared tonight that it would continue the buildup of the nation's armed forces so that they would be a force in the defense of the Arab nation and of the Arab cause.

title: Ford Foundation Gently Begins Process of Halving Its Staff
description: There Is an orange folder on the desk of Arthur D. Trottenberg, vice president of the Division of Administration at the Ford Foundation, marked Retrenchment of Management Costs: a Progress Report.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 1, 1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Advertising
description: Just back from 10 days on the West Coast where he was looking at pilots of shows for the fall season, Mike Weinblatt, senior vice president, sales, of the NBCTV Network, said he was frankly pleased with what he saw.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Economists Say Farmers Face Leveling Prices as Costs Rise
description: ITHACA, N. Y.New York State farmers face a generally unfavorable economic outlook in 1975 as they make plans for a new crop year, according to agricultural economists at the State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences here at Cornell University.

title: DEMIREL FORMS TURKISH CABINET
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 31 A new conservative coalition cabinet, led by Suleyman Demirel, the man forced to step down as premier four years ago, was announced today.

title: Radio
Market Summary
description: Monday, March 331, 11975

title: Amnesty Plan Ends With Few Signed Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 President Ford's conditional clemency program for military deserters and draft evaders during the Vietnam war ended today after a controversial six months.

title: TWO SOVIET JEWS GET EXILE TERMS
description: MOSCOW, March 31Two Soviet Jews who joined in a brief demonstration last month on behalf of the right to emigrate were tried and sentenced today to five years exile.

title: State Urged to Curb Eavesdropping by Employers
description: TRENTON, March 31The Democratic majority leadership in the State Assembly called today for an investigation into the possible need for curbing or regulating the growing practice of evesdropping on employe telephone calls by private companies in New Jersey.

title: Vorster's Detente (II)
description: CAPE TOWNJohn Vorster is a confident politician these days. As he looks out on the world from the bottom of Africa he sees good reasons for confidence. Consider.

title: JAMES J. O'MALLY
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 31 (AP)James banking executive and civic leader, died yesterday WilkesBarre General Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Rabbi Gets 3Year Term In $200,000 Fraud Case
description: Louis R. Wolfish, rabbi and disbarred lawyer, was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of three and a half years for a fraudulent scheme to collect $200,000 in life insurance by submitting a fake death certificate to indicate that he had died.

title: OPPOSITION PARTIES SHOW GAIN IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, March 31 (UPI)Leaders of opposition parties many of whose candidates were successful in the firs Greek municipal elections in 11 years, said today that the re suits showed that the Government of Premier Constanting Caramanlis had lost public confidence.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
C.I.A. PANEL GIVEN 2MONTH EXTENSION
description: WASHINGTON', March 31 (AP)President Ford has ordered a twomonth extension of the Rockefeller Commission's investigation of alleged domestic wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency, Vice President Rockefeller anncunced today.

title: 2 Actors Find a Universality in Sizwe
description: Unlike many actors, John Kani and Winston Ntshona, the performers in Sizwe Banzi Is Dead and The Is. land, never dreamed of becoming actors.

title: Pope Tells of Sorrow Over Indochina Fighting
description: ROME, March 31 (UPI) Pope Paul VI made a surprise appearance at his study window overlooking St. Peter's Square at noon today to express his sorrow over the fighting in Indochina.

title: Steel Production Rose in the Week To 2,673,000 Tons
description: Steel production for The week ended March 29 edged ahead of the preceding week, according to figures released yester(thy by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Fisher Hall Acoustician Will Get His Way
description: Philip Johnson is not an architect who is noted for taking a back seat to other professionals. But he freely admits that he and his partner, John Burgee, will be allowing someone else to call some of the shots in their upcoming renovation of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Swimming Mark Set By Aussie
description: LONDON, March 31 (AP) Jenny Turrall of Australia smashed the world record today in the women's 800 meter freestyle at a 14nation swimming meet. Her time was 8 minutes 43.48 seconds.

title: Lisbon and Peking at Odds on Macao
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Portugal's ruling Armed Forces Movement tried to give Macao back to China, knowledgeable Western diplomats said today, but Peking said it did not wish to alter the status of the territory.

title: BARNETT J. NOVA
description: Barnett J. Nova, a former lawyer here, who was a tax commissioner under Mayor Robert F. Wagger and executive deputy secretary of state under Gov. Averell Harriman, died March 20 in Phoenix, Ariz. He was 69 years old and retired to Scottsdale, Ariz., a year ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Indochina: Of Political Euthanasia and a Lost Gamble

title: One Attica Murder Charge Dismissed
description: BUFFALO, March 31Justice Gilbert H. King of State Supreme Court today struck down the murder charge against Charles Joseph Pernasilice, one of two defendants in the Attica trial here, saying that he would, instruct the jury that it could still find Mr. Pernasilice guilty of such lesser crimes as attempted murder, assault and attempted assault.

title: $200MILLION SALE DELAYED BY BANK
description: A $200million sale of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation's securities that had been scheduled this week was postponed yesterday following the Chemical New York Corporation's cancellation of a $100million financing.

title: Kaunda Cracks the Whip
description: By ordering the arrest in Zambia of fifty leaders of the Rhodesian liberation movement known as ZANU (the Zimbabwe African National Union), President Kaunda has signaled his intention so far as possible to remove all obstacles to negotiations for a peaceful settlement in Rhodesia. The closing of the offices in Lusaka of ZANU and two rival groups, which had agreed in December to erge, underscores Mr. Kaunda's determination.

title: SIX LICENSE FEES INCREASED IN CITY
description: Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday six license fee increases that are expected to yield $2.4million for the city's treasury this fiscal year. The increases had been passed by the City Council last week end, added to other fees, are expected to generate $17million for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Corning Glass Net Off 80% in Quarter
description: Corning Glass Works reported yesterday an 80 per cent decline in its firstquarter earnings on a sales drop of 8.6 per cent.

title: Bradley Is Progressing
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31 (UPI)Gen. Omar Bradley was described today as progressing satisfactorily in his recovery from brain surgery following a cerebral stroke on March 16. But a source at U.C.L.A. Medical Center said it was too early to say when the 82yearold general might be returning home. He had been transfered from the intensive care unit to a private room.

title: S.E.C. Acts to Make NewRate Advising By Brokers Easier
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today, a rule exemption that would make it easier for stockbrokers to advise their customers when commission rates go to a competitive basis in May.

title: British Soccer Standings
Market Place
description: A.T. & T. stock warrantsa popular speculative vehicle since they were issued May 15, 1970are still tantalizing although their life is rapidly closing.

title: The Fear, the Numbing Fear
description: BRIGHTWATERS, N. Y.Let me tell you what it's like for one guy to be 52 years old and jobless in America in 1975.

title: FUND SET UP TO AID SLAIN OFFICERS
description: A relief fund for the families of the two Mount Holly police officers killed in a shootout Friday night was established yesterday by the Burlington County Police Wives Association.

title: Baseball Umpires In Pension Accord
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 (AP)Major league baseball umpires and league managements reached an agreement tonight on a revised pension program. Details were not disclosed.

title: For Yanks, Long Ride And Defeat
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 For ballplayers coming up to the major leagues from places like Davenport, Gastonia and Aberdeen, one of the most satisfying features of advancement is traveling by air rather than bus. Air travel represents status and, through speed, a diminishment of boredom.

title: 2MILLION GIVEN TO PRINCETON U.
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 31 Princeton University has, received two grants totaling $2.15million from the International Business Machines Corporation and the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, enabling the university to establish chair honoring Albert Einstein and to appoint additional junior faculty members in the humanities.

title: Colonels Win and Share First Place With Nets
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 31 (UPI)  The Kentucky Colonels moved into a tie with the New York Nets for first place in the Eastern Division of the American Basketball Association with a 10388 victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight: Artis Gilmore scored 36 points for the victors. It was their seventh straight triumph.

title: Government Issues and Corporations Bonds Fall
description: The prospect of heavy Treasury borrowings depressed the fixedincome markets yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Greenfield dismissed murder indictments against two of the five reputed members of the Black Liberation Army who were being retried for the 1971 murders of police officers Joseph A. Piagentini and Waverly M. Jones.

title: Venezuela to Shift Some of Her Trade To Latin Nations
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31 Venezuela plans to shift some of the goods she purchased from the United States and Europe to Latin America, according to the Minister of Planning Gumersindo Rodriguez.

title: DR. JOHN S. KIEFFER
description: BALTIMORE, March 31 (AP) Dr. John S. Kieffer, former president of St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., died Saturday at Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Fischer Expected To Yield His Title
description: Rather than play by somebody else's rules, Bobby Fischer will relinquish his title as the world chess champion by default at midnight tonight to. Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the head of the United States Chess Federation said yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 1, 1975

title: Women Learn to Take a Stand: Meeting Violence With Violence
description: The transformation of Susan Murdock is something to behold. At rest, she is a pert young woman with long light brown hair and dimples when she smiles. But when she gathers her forces for an attackfists clenched, biceps bulging, the veins on her neck protruding, her face contorted in a grimace that erupts into a vicious shriekshe is not a woman likely to evoke aggressive or, for that matter, even tender aproaches from the other sex.

title: TV Study Unit Told State Suffers Split Personality
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 31The Mayor of Camden said today that New Jersey was actually two states, North Jersey and South Jersey, and that no increased television news coverage would alter that situation.

title: AsianPacific Cultural and Technical Interchange Institution Is Facing Major Changes
description: HONOLULU, March 30A major change in status is about to occur for the EastWest Center, the federally funded institution that specializes in Asian and Pacific cultural and technical interchange.

title: State Job for Official's Firm
description: TRENTON, March 31 (AP)Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran today announced his appointment of the Union County Democratic chairman's law firm as special counsel in the insolvency of the Gateway Insurance Company. Christopher Dietz, the chairman, is one of the partners of the firm, Weinberg, Aanoff and Dietz of

title: U.S. DELAY HINTED ON ARMS TO ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States would be reluctant to enter into any new arms commitments to Israel while the current reassessment of American policy in the Middle East was going on.

title: DR. LOUIS MKEEHAN, PHYSICIST AT YALE
description: Dr. Louis W. McKeehan, professor of physics at Yale University from 1927 to 1955, died Friday in Jamestown, R.I., where he lived. He would have been 88 years old yesterday.

title: ATTACK ON SAIGON FEARED; DA NANG REFUGEE SEALIFT IS HALTED BY ROCKET FIRE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 1Fears of North Vietnamese attack on Saigon mounted today after Communist troops swept into South Vietnamese Government enclaves on the central coast and thwarted the American evacuation of tens of thousands of refugees.

title: White House Egg Roll Held Without Fords
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)  A crowd of 10,000 participated today in the annual Easter egg roll at the White House.

title: Western Governors Meet
description: BILLINGS, Mont., March 31 (UPI)The Western Governors conference on agriculture opened today with the theme of Agriculture and energy in the Western United States.

title: Amnesty Plan Ends With Few Signed Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 President Ford's conditional clemency program for military deserters and draft evaders during the Vietnam war ended today after a controversial six months.

title: Pace Gallery Bid for Sculpture In Central Park Barred by City
description: A proposal by the Pace Gallery here for the temporary installation of two abstract sculptures in Central Park has been vetoed by Edwin Weisl Jr., Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Commissioner. The sculptures, by Ernest Trove, were intended to advertise show of the artist's work currently at the gallery, 32 East 57th Street, Commissioner Weisl

title: Leaders of 32 Jewish Groups Seek Backing in U.S. for Israel
description: The heads of 32 national Jewish religious and secular organizations, reinforced by five members of New York's Congressional delegation, yesterday opened a campaign to mobilize American public opinion in support of Israel.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Argento to Write Opera on Poe

title: Exotic Baskets Blossom in U.S.
description: With the current enthusiasm for exotic imported baskets, domestic products tend to be overlooked. Take, for example, the Gullah baskets made in South Carolina by some 300 to 400 weavers in the coastal area north of Charleston.

title: ROCKWELL LAYS OFF 300 AT B1 PLANT
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP)  Rockwell International laid off 300 workers today, telling them the company had nearly completed work on three B1 bombers it is building for the Air Force. The workers were notified with their pay checks Friday.

title: Article 3  No Title
First Rebate Checks Expected in MidMay
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)Americans who filed their income tax returns early will get the first rebate checks by midMay, according to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Financial Board to Study Effect of New Tax Law
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the quasiofficial policy planning arm of the accounting industry, said yesterday it had begun to study the effect of the new tax law on financial accounting and reporting by United States companies.

title: ARTHUR H. MILLIER
description: Arthur H. Miller, art critic of The Los Angeles Times from 1928 to his retirement in 1958, died Sunday in Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital. He was 81 years lold and lived at 125 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack.

title: Decline in Morale Casting Doubt on Saigon Defense
description: The widening demoralization of the South Vietnamese Army has increased pessimism in the Defense Department over the South's ability to hold Saigon against a CommuMilitary nist offensive. The Saigon area is still Analysis regarded as defensible by military sources with experience in Vietnam, but they regard the situation as less promising than it was a week ago in view of reports of panicky retreats, looting and indiscipline.

title: Zoning and the Citizen
description: How far can a community go in shaping the size and the character of its growth? That question, which has plagued thousands of localities ever since the postWorld War II

description: Outsider to Be A. &P. President

title: Decline in Morale Casting Doubt on Saigon Defense
description: The widening demoralization I of the South Vietnamese Army has increased pessimism in the Defense Department over the South's ability to hold Saigon against a Commu. flirt offensive. The Saigon area is still Military Analysis regarded as defensible by military sources with experience in Vietnam, but they regard the situation as less promising than it was a week ago in view of reports of panicky retreats, looting and indiscipline.

title: A SAIGON ANTIRED SAYS WAR IS OVER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31One of South Vietnam's most influential political experts says that he believes that the Communists have won the war.

title: Panic Grips Nha Trang, But Beach Life Goes On
description: NHA TRANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 1  Thousands of refugees are milling about in this seaside city amid reports that North Vietnamese forces are moving rapidly in this direction.

title: Some Markets Closed
description: Foreignexchange operations and major securities and commodities markets in Europe were closed yesterday in observance of the Easter Monday holiday.

title: U.S. Team Takes Motorcycle Crown
description: OULTON PARK, England March 31 (Reuters)  The United States won the TransAtlantic trophy motorcycle competition against Britain today for the first time in five attempts, 278 points to 243.

title: Cambodians Get Less and Less to Eat As Paralysis Grows and Prices Soar
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 31A family of sixmother, father and four childrencan survive in this capital on $45 a month, according to United Nations experts here. That amount puts a roof over their heads, clothes on their backs, some fuel into their stove and a certain minimum of nutrition in their stomachs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: MARIE WAGNER, 92, ATENNIS CHAMPION SixTime Winner of National
description: Indoor Singles Is Dead

title: 2 KOREAN PARTIES AGREE ON MERGER
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 31Former President Yun Po Sun and other opposition leaders here agreed in principle today to fashion a broad coalition to seek revision of the Constitution.

title: NEWARK COUNCIL APPROVES BUDGET
description: NEWARK, March 31The City Council today, by a vote of 5 to 3, approved a $252million budget that includes the highest propertytax rate in the city's history and eliminates nearly 600 jobs.

title: State Workers Postpone Strike After Rift Develops
description: ALBANY, March 31  A threatened strike by state workers was postponed today when union delegates seized control of a meeting from their leaders and repudiated a resolution calling for them to walk off the job at midnight.

title: Cook United Asks Banks for Review Of Terms of Loan
description: Cook United, Inc., of Cleveland, a major operator of discount stores, supermarkets and drugstores, said yesterday that it had asked its banks to review for possible changes the terms of its $16million shorttermloan agreement. Cook said it had taken this action in response to concern expressed by some of its major trade creditors about certain conditions of the loan.

title: Farm Bureau Scores Rebate
description: PARK RIDGE, III. March 31 (UPI)  William J. Kuhfuss, president of the American Farm Bureau, said today that the taxrebate bill signed by President Ford was the height of spendthrift folly.

title: Supreme Court Rejects a Ban On Dumping by Reserve Mining
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The Supreme Court refused toay to reinstate an order that would have prevented the Reserve Mining Company from continuing to dump into Lake Superior taconite waste that has been called a potential hazard to public health.

title: FORD PLAYS GOLF; SEES OIL FACILITY
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 31President Ford broke into a sprint today at the Bakersfield, Calif., airport when a reporter asked him what he was doing about the military losses of the South Vietnam Government.

title: High Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Policeman Explosion
description: City policemen help children cross the street, give you parking tickets, solve homicides, settle family quarrels, deliver babies in taxicabs, write down the names of people who have been robbed, talk the deranged out of jumping from high buildings, take drunks home safely and park in noparking zones without getting ticketed. They are named Captain O'Malley and Officer Mosconi.

title: Byrne Asks Investigation On Award of Sewer Job
description: TRENTON, March 31Governor Byrne this evening ordered the State Attorney General to determine whether former State Senator Ralph C. DeRose was guilty of a conflict of interests as New Jersey's member of the bistate Waterfront Commission when he represented a company that successfully sought a $15million sewer contract in Camden County.

title: Maertens Wins Cycling
description: OOSTENDE, Belgium, March 31 (AP)  Freddy Maertens of Belgium won the second leg of the tour of Belgium cycle race today, strengthening his overall position after winning yesterday's segment of the sixday cycling event.

title: Byrne Orders Investigation Of DeRose on Sewer Deal
description: TRENTON, March 31 Governor Byrne this evening ordered the State Attorney General to determine whether former State Senator Ralph C. DeRose was guilty of a conflict of interests as New Jersey's member of the bistate Waterfront Commission when he represented a company that successfully sought a $15million sewer contract in Camden County.

title: WILLIAM D. CARR
description: William D. Carr, who retired in 1966 as senior vice president in charge of corporate trust for the Chemical Bank here, died Saturday in Aiken, S.C. His age was 73.

title: ROY C. WILCOX
description: MERIDEN, Conn., March 31 (AP)Roy Cornwell Wilcox, former Lieutenant Governor and industrial executive, died yesterday at MeridenWallingford Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Hillary's Kin Killed In Nepal Plane Crash
description: NEW DELHI, March. 31 (Reuters) Lady Louise and Belinda Hillary, wife and daughter of Sir Edmund Hillary, the explorer, died today when their singleengined plane plunged in flames near Katmandu Airport, AllIndia Television reported.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS VOLUME GAINS
description: ,Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell yesterday as volume rose slightly on the Amex from last Thursday's trading.

title: American VW Executives Press German Managers for U.S. Plant
description: BONN, March 31  Exectives of Volkswagen of America are applying strong presure on the parent company's management to decide to shift production for the American market from West Germany to the United States.

title: 2 Go on Trial in Coast Killing With Vow to Boycott Courtroom
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 31Joseph M. Remiro and Russell J. Little went on trial today under heavy security for the murder of Dr. Marcus A. Foster, the Oakland School Superintendent, on Nov. 6, 1973.

title: Suspect Charged in Slaying of 3 On Upper West Side in February
description: A 44 year  old unemployed bartender was arrested last night in the Times Square area and charged with the shooting deaths of a woman and two men in two separate incidents last Feb. 20 on the Upper West Side, the police reported.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES RALLY IN CHICAGO
description: Lack of selling of soybeans and corn by farmers, bad weather in the Midwest over the weekend and the inflationary aspects of the new tax law combined to spur a rally in grain and soybean prices yesterday.

title: UNITED RULED LIABLE IN 72 CHICAGO CRASH
description: CHICAGO, March 31 (UPI)A Cook County circuit judge ruled today that United Airlines was legally responsible for the Dec. 8, 1972, plane crash that killed 45 persons near Midway Airport. The ruling allows 10 damage suits to go to trial without the defendants having to prove negligence on the part of the airline.

title: There's Gold in a Soviet Klondike
description: ALDAN, U.S.S.R.  Our people used to call this, place the Russian Klondike, said Valery F. Anokith, a hefty Siberian mining engineer. The label remains apt, for the Aldan region of Yakutia has been yielding up its gold to the Soviet Government for over half a century.

title: Moscow Had Warm Winter
description: MOSCOW, March 31 (Reuters)Pravda confirmed today what Muscovites have suspected for monthsthat the Soviet capital has had its warmest winter for a century. The newspaper also said that the wet and slushy winter in Leningrad was only the second of its kind in 230 years.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Betting scandals are under investigation at three race tracks in the Northeast, all involving the trifecta or big triple or whatever name each has given this exotic form of wagering. Other scandals have erupted or are simmering at other tracks throughout the country.

title: Beleaguered Prosecutor
description: When Maurice H. Nadjari was named special state prosecutor in 1972 to root out corruption in New York City's system of criminal justice, it instantly became clear that he would have to combat even more vigorous resistance from upholders of the status quo within that system than had the Knapp Commission which initiated the cleanup.

title: Sugar Prices Gain In Most Markets
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Retail sugar prices have dropped substantially in a few world capitals since the first of the year but have continued climbing in most including a 60 per cent increase in London, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Japan's Payments Improve
description: TOKYO, March 30 (Reuters)  Japan had a revised balanceofpayments surplus for February of $254million, in contrast to a $1.2billion deficit in January, the Finance Ministry said today. The improvement was due partly to an inflow of dollars through active foreign portfolio investments in Japanese bonds and stocks and the flotation of external bonds by Japanese companies, the ministry said.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: BUDDHIST IN SAIGON FIGHT MOBILIZATION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31  Leading Buddhist monks have opened a campaign today against a Government mobilization order, and it appeared that a series of antiGovernment demonstrations was planned.

title: Gunfire Breaks Out in Nicosia On TurkishGreek Truce Line
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Tuesday, April 1 (Reuters)Heavy firing broke out before dawn today on the ceasefire line between the Turkish Cypriote and Greek Cypriote communities of Nicosia and continued through the early hours of the morning.

title: ANDREW P. YOUNG
description: Andrew Plimpton Young, lawyer in Chatham, Mass, who had been an officer of several corporations, died Sunday in Hyannis, Mass. He was 58 years old and lived in North Chatham.

title: Panic Grips Nha Trang, But Beach Life Goes On
description: NHA TRANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 1  Thousands of refugees are milling about in this seaside city amid reports that North Vietnamese forces are moving rapidly in this direction.

title: Johnson &Johnson Heir Dies; Drug Overdose Is Hinted
description: Fort LAUDERDALE, Ha., March 31 (UPI)Keith Wold Johnson, 25 years old, an heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical company fortune, was found dead in his apartment yesterday from an apparent drug overdose, the police reported.

title: Lifesaving in Vietnam.
description: The overriding American responsibility of the moment in Vietnam is the rescue of human life. The chaos left by the collapse of all military and civil authority in the northern provinces and along much of the coastline from Hue to Da Nang and below calls for massive humanitarian action.

title: Bridge:
description: A topranked quartet of young experts won the Lancia tournament at the American Hotel here during the weekend, and will provide formidable opposition for the touring team of famous European stars next month.

title: U.C.L.A. Five Beats Kentucky, 9285
description: SAN DIEGO, March 31 The University of California, Los Angeles won the National Collegiate basketball championship tonight for the 10th and last time under the direction of Coach John Wooden.

title: Waldheim in Cautious Plea for Indochina Refugees
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31  Secretary General Waldheim appealed tonight for assistance for the civilian population of Indochina and asked all sides of the fighting to limit the suffering of innocent people.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 1, 1975

title: Plutonium Shipment to City Approved
description: WASHINGTON. March 3The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has licensed the shipment by plane of 290 pounds of Britishmade plutonium into New York City's Kennedy International Airport for use in a reactor owned by the Rochester Gas and Electric Company.

title: Article 1  No Title
Parkchester's Conversion To Condominium Halted
description: The State Attorney General's office refused yesterday to let Harry B. Helmsley carry forward the conversion of Parkchester in the Bronx into condominium.

title: Mitchell, Mardian Barred From High Court Practice
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Supreme Court ordered today former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and his former deputy, Robert C. Mardian, suspended from practice before the Court, and gave them 40 days to show why they should not be permanently disbarred.

title: GRAND JURY SCORED BY BOMBING SUSPECT
description: Patricia E. Swinton, free on $200,000 bail on bombingconspiracy charges, appeared with about 50 supporters in front of the United States Court House at Foley Square here yesterday to protest alleged abuses of the grand jury system

title: Style of Bobby Short Varies In Shift From Saloon to Concert
description: Bobby Short's progression from saloon singer to concert artist has been accompanied by a gradual change of style and a consequent turnaround in the way he approaches a song.

title: Soviet Offering Aid
description: LISBON, March 31 (AP) The Soviet, Union is offering economic aid to Portugal, Labor Minister Jose da Costa Martins said today after weeklong visit to Moscow.

title: STATE STRETCHES AUTO INSPECTIONS
description: The New Jersey Motor Vehicle Division approved yesterday an 11day grace period on automobiles due for inspection in March as waiting times at most inspection stations jumped to three and a half hours or more.

title: Official of Treasury Discloses Need for $41Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 With the big taxreduction bill now signed into law, the Treasury revised upward once again today its estimated borrowing in the sixmonth period ending June 30.

title: Limon Dancers Honor Doris Humphrey
description: There was the wrong kind of drama at the Harkness Theater last night where the Jose Limn Dance Company began a twoweek engagement. The first ballet, Brandenburg Concerto No. 4 was coming to its end when one of the dancers, Jennifer Scanlon, a principal of the company, crumpled and fell in evident agony. The curtain had to be lowered and the work was abandoned.

title: Lisbon and Peking at Odds on Macao
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Portugal's ruling Armed Forces Movement tried to give Macao back to China, knowledgeable Western diplomats said today., but Peking said it did not wish to alter the status of the territory.

title: Israeli Marchers Ask Settling of the West Bank
description: SEBASTYE, Occupied West Bank, March 31About 20,000 Israelis converged here today on the site of Samaria, an ancient Judean capital on the West Bank of the Jordan River, at the end of a twoday protest march to dramatize their call for more Jewish settlements in the occupied region.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: WESTBURY, L.I.

title: Hagler Stops Blair
description: BOSTON, March 31 (AP) Marvin Hagler, the undefeated New England middleweight champion, of Brockton, Mass., knocked out Joey Blair of Akron, Ohio, in the second round of a scheduled 10round bout at Boston Arena tonight. Hagler weighed 160 pounds, Blair 161.

title: Population Milestone
description: Sometime about now, according to the calculations of Dr. L. C. Nehrt of Wichita State University, the world's population will break the fourbillion mark, having doubled in the last 45 years.

title: A's Pitching Has a Void
description: MESA, Ariz., March 31Without Catfish Hunter, everyone agrees, the Oakland A's will have a tough time seeking their fourth straight American League pennant and world championship. How tough? Some cold arithmetic revealed the problem Manager Alvin Dark and his daily telephone consultant, Charley Finley, are wrestling with.

title: Reading's Trustees Urge 2 Northeast Rail Systems
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UPI)The two trustees of the Reading Company recommended today creation of two competitive rail systems from the seven bankrupt Northeast railroads.

title: 2 Investment Firms And 3 Individuals Penalized by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Securities and Exchange Commission imposed administrative penalties today on John P. Chase, a Boston investment adviser, and on two counseling firms for violation of the Investment Advisers Act.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 31. 31st day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins Title
description: The University of California, Los Angeles, won the National Collegiate basketball title for the 10th time in 12 years by defeating the University of Kentucky, 9285, Last night. Page 43.

title: ALLEGHANY REPORTS A RISE IN EARNINGS
description: The Alleghany Corporation, once a railroad holding company, hut today a diversified operating company, reported yesterday net earnings for last year of $43.5million, or $5.35 a share, up from $10.2million, or $1.19 share, in 1973.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CITY EXPECTS RISE IN FILMINGS HERE
description: Movie and television production here this year will be double that of last year, according to an estimate presented at closed meeting yesterday at City Hall to Mayor Beame and his Advisory Council on Motion Pictures and Television.

title: Mets Boosters Slate Dinner on Monday
description: The 10th Welcome Home dinner sponsored by the Greater New York Mets Booster Club will be staged next Monday night at the Americana Hotel.

title: Trawler, Taking on Water, Is Saved by Coast Guard
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 31 (UPI)A 65footlong fishing trawler that had begun to take on water was rescued today by a Coast Guard cutter, which took the disabled vessel under tow.

title: Sierra Club Says State Needs More Pollution Funds and Staff
description: TRENTON, March 31 (AP)The Sierra Club said today that the state needed more money and more staff to stop pollution of its waterways with hazardous waste materials.

title: Music: Rostropovich at His Very Best
description: If you want to get down to essentials, there are actually few indispensable events in any music season. The recitals of Mstislav Rostropovich, however, must be on anyone's must list, no matter how selectively chosen. The versatile cellist and pianist, who only last week was named as the next music director and conductor of Washington's National Symphony Orchestra, showed once again Sunday night just why he is so highly valued.

title: The Cold Heart of John Wooden
description: Dave Anderson

title: Stein Panel, in Parting Shot, Charges Top Political Figures With Negligence
description: The Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy went out of business yesterday with a parting salvo at high Republican and Democratic figures, whom it charged with negligence or impropriety regarding the nursinghome industry.

title: Iraqi Forces, Truce Over, Told to Seize Kurdistan
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 31Iraqi armed forces were ordered today to advance toward control of areas held by Kurdish rebels as a ceasefire ended at midnight.

title: GUILTY PLEA IS MADE BY EXAIDE OF ORVIS
description: Fergus M. Sloan Jr., a former stockbroker and managing partner of Orvis Brothers & Co., pleaded guilty here yesterday to one count of conspiracy to give unlawful credit to customers of the former brokerage house.

title: State Land Use Planning
description: The significance of the New Jersey Supreme Court's decision on local zoning is that it will probably force that state to do what it ought to do in any case: execute a statewide plan for the best possible uses of its land. The court has in effect forbidden communities to use the zoning power deliberately to keep out lowincome and middleincome peopleespecially if they are black. That purpose is unarguable; but there is no way implement it short of an overall plan that will take into account all the factors involvedenvironmental, economic, social and political.

title: People in Sports
description: Hockey Honor Goes To Ranger President

title: Business Records
EXPERTS FEARFUL FOR MARS MISSION
description: Discovery of bacteria in all 24 samples of soil from one of the driest, coldest regions on earth has raised fears that microbes carried to Mars may proliferate there, eliminating any chance of learning whether that planet had any life of its own.

title: U.S. Sugar Extra Dividend
description: Directors of the United States Sugar Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly of 50 cents, both payable June 16 to holders of record May 30. Shareholders also received a 50 cents extra dividend on March 17.

title: Milner Injured as Mets Lose to Pirates, 4 to 0
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31The New York Mets chances of completing spring training with a 500 record were dashed today when the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated them, 40. The loss was the 14th in 21 games for Yogi Berra's team with only five games remaining to be played before the April 8 opener.

title: Chicago, a City That Works, Faces Some Hard Realities
description: CHICAGO; March 31One of Chicago's enduring clichs, a catchphrase. dear to the city's boosters and politicians, is that it is a city that works.

title: The New York Times Bettors lined up at Aqueduct. An exacta is a bet on horses to finish in exact one, two order. A triple is a bet on the one, two, three finish in a race.
Soul Concert Gets An Energetic Lift From Betty Wright
description: There may not be an art to putting on concerts, but there certainly is a technique. And it was lacking On Sunday at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, where a soul music package, the Easter Soul Train of Stars, was featured. When the singer Betty Wright completed her spot, the third In a concert that billed six artists, the proceedings were a mere three hours along. Here was a railroad that wasn't running on time, spent much of it in stations en route and had trouble with the rolling stock.

title: 7 STATE AIDES QUIT AS FUNDS RUN OUT
description: All seven members of the State Council of Environmental Advisers announced their resignation yesterday, one day before the council was to be abolished, after the Government refused to provide further funds.

title: ...Or Asserting Their Rightsand NeedsQuietly
description: The women's movement was a mass act of assertion, Janice Larouche, a feminist, said recently. But when it comes to asserting rights individually, that's another matter. We are still victims of the goodlittlegirl syndrome.

title: F.T.C. Aide Alleges Lettuce Price Fixing
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)A Federal Trade Commission official ruled today that one of the nation's biggest lettuce cooperatives has engaged in illegal price fixing, including a period when prices shot to record levels nearly two years ago.

title: Bobick Clan Is at Home In the Ring
description: We may be the fighlingest family in boxing history, said 25yearold Le Roy Bobick yesterday as he watched his brother, Duane, go through a physical examination at the New York State Athletic Commission offices.

title: Shift in Cambodia
description: The magnitude of the human tragedy in South Vietnam should not divert attention from the need to call a halt to the killing in Cambodia. The departure of President Lon Nol from Phnom Penh today ought to be the signal for the remnants of his faltering Government to reorganize for the only constructive purpose left to the beleaguered capitalto negotiate a political settlement.

title: Saigon Aide Asks Wide Relief Access
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 1Dr. Phan Quang Dan, South Vietnam's Deputy Premier, called on the Communists today to allow the Red Cross and other humanitarian agencies immediate access to Da Nang, and to allow wouldbe refugees there and elsewhere to leave.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins Title
description: The University of Canifornia, Los Angeles, won the National Collegiate basketball title for the 10th time in 12 years by defeating Kentucky, 9285, last night in San Diego. Page 43.

title: C.I.A. Investigated Personal Life of a Top Nixon Adviser During 1968 G.O.P. Presidential Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, March 31A Central Intelligence Agency, operative, posing private detective, investing the personal life of a top aide to Richard M. Nixon during his 1968 campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, according to wellplaced Federal officials.

title: Chess:
description: What is it that destines lastminute replacements for great achievements? More than a year ago, for example, Grandmaster Borislay Ivkov of Yugoslavia was hastily summoned to the Beverwijk international tournament to cover for a defector and wound up sharing first prize.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MINI MET A variety of free, holiday events for schoolchildren this week starts today in the Junior Museum auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum, including a film festival, dance activities, art workshops and lectures. On Saturday, there will be treasure hunts and concert by the Boys Choir of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Percy Alliss, British Golfer, Ryder Cup Player, 78, Dies
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, March 31 (UPI)Percy Alliss, a former Ryder Cup golfer, died in a Bournemouth hospital today. He was 78 years old.

title: TV: The Thin Edge
description: Reviewing public television these days can be hazardous to mental and emotional stability. With a new series called The Thin Edge and the return of Feeling Good, marathon screening sessions have delivered a barrage of information on depression, aggression, old age, alcoholism and heart disease. I was feeling fine beforethe onslaught. Now, I'm not so sure.

title: U.S DELAY HINTED ON ARMS TO ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States would be reluctant to enter into any new arms commitments to Israel while the current reassessment of American policy in the Middle East was going on.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: In Memoriam
Winfield Scott's Home Designated Landmark
description: A 19thcentury townhouse in Greenwich Village that was once the borne of Gen. Winfield Scott and is now an Odyssey House drug rehabilitation residence was designated yesterday as a national historic landmark by the Department of the Interior.

title: Mrs. Eisenhower Improving
description: FORT GORDON, Ga., March 31 (UPI)Mamie Eisenhower is eating a normal diet and continues to make steady improvement, her physicians at Fort Gordon Army Medical Center said today. Mrs. Eisenhower, widow of President Eisenhower, entered the hospital last Tuesday suffering from intestinal bleeding.

title: DelBello Gloomy on Westchester Economic Outlook
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 31Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello warned today in a state of the county message that his government would be under siege if national economic conditions continued to worsen.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, March 31 (UPI)The Israeli Sabras Pronounced themselves today as champion of the fivemember European Professional Basketball League because teams from Belgium and Switzerland refused to come to Israel for the playoffs. The league president, Bob Hecht of Houston, who owns the Sabras, said the two European teams were frightened by the possibility of a new Middle war. The Swiss Alpines and Belgian Lions, which had they would not come to Israel for the playoffs, played Israel earlier this year.

title: EDGAR G. GIBBS
description: Edgar G. Gibbs, retired publisher of the Ed Gibbs News Letter, a weekly periodical for the liquor industry, died here Sunday at the age of 77. He I lived at 445 West 23d Street.

title: Stratojet Study Finds Risk of Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Increased commercial flights in the stratosphere will increase the risk of skin cancer among persons on the ground unless aircraft engines are redesigned, a report released today by the National Research Council said.

title: Pickets Shut Virginia Mines
description: NORTON, Va., March 31 UPI) Pickets shut down a major southwest Virginia coal mining company today in the second week of protests over a proposed Federal strip mine law. Officials of the Wetmoreland Coal.Company said all of the company's 13 mines had been closed by picketing. Independent, nonunion strip, mine operators announced plans last week to picket union mines to protest the proposed rules. A local union leader said union miners had joined the protest, while a company official said the pickets were outside personnel.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (Reuters)Attorney General Edward Levi granted today broad immunity from prosecution under antitrust laws to 16 major United States petroleum companies for their consultations with the International Energy Agency.

title: Notes on People
description: A helicopter carrying David H. Kennerly, President Ford's personal White House photographer, was shot at yesterday at Cam Ranh Bay when evacuated Vietnamese marines tossed hand grenades and fired their rifles at civilians and at their officers. The helicopter was not hit.

title: Chicago, a City That Works, Faces Some Hard Realities
description: CHICAGO, March 31One of Chicago's enduring clichs, a catchphrase dear to the city's boosters and politicians, is that it is a city that works.

title: VERMONT PASSES CURB ON APOWER
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 31 The legislature completed action today on the toughest state nuclear power control measure in the nation and sent it to Gov. Thomas P. Salmon.

title: MERCEDES PRICES INCREASED 3.5%
description: Autos Delivered Overseas Affected, Too, but Not the Cars Now in Inventory

title: A Motive Is Sought in Slaying of 11 in a Family in Ohio
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, March 31 (AP)The police had a suspect today but no motive and little Idea of how 11 family members who gathered for Easter dinner could have been killed without any sign of a struggle.

description: Today, April 1

title: Small Colleges Join Drive To Stress Practical Skills
description: MILWAUKEE  One recent morning six students at Alverno College here embarked on an assignment to test their personal skills. Each was given a different role to play on a committee of Repocrat party members selecting a successor to a deceased state Senator from among three different nominees. They had to resolve their conflicting views and reach consensus.

title: Foolish Pleasure's Excuse For First Loss: A Cut Foot
description: Although he finished a disappointing third in the Florida Derby on Saturday, John Greer's Foolish Pleasure is stilt the horse to contend with in the Kentucky Derby on May 3, according to Jacin to Vazquez, his jockey. Informed that Foolish Pleasure was suffering from an injury to the frog, or middle, of his right front foot, Vasquez said in surprise, That's what it must have been.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: MACAOPedro Adigue, the Philippines, outpointed Yoshitaka Kato, Japan, 10, welterweights.

title: FARM PRICES DROP BY 2% IN MONTH; 5TH DIP IN A ROW
description: WASHINGTON, March 31arm prices declined 2 per cent in the month ended March 15 from the averages of a month earlier, extending the slide of major agricultural commodities for the fifth consecutive month, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Connally Is Going on Trial Today on Charges That He Accepted $10,000 in Illegal Gratuities
description: WASHINGTON, March 31John B. Connally will go on trial here tomorrow on charges that he accepted $10,000 in illegal gratuities from dairy industry lobbyists when he was Secretary of the Treasury in 1971.

title: ParkingRule Change
description: Alternate side  of  thestreet parking regulations will be suspended Wednesday, and Thursday, the final two days of the Jewish holiday of Passover. The suspension affects alternate day, alternateside parking restrictions imposed for purposes of street cleaning. Parkingmeter regulations and all other parking and standing rules will remain in effect, the Traffic Department warned.

title: Regina Weinberg Wed to Allen Titus
description: Regina Pierce Weinberg of New York, widow of Sidney J. Weinberg and travel director for Rockefeller University, was married yesterday to Allen Townsend Titus of Milford, Pa., a realtor there. The civil ceremony was performed in Hamilton, Bermuda, at the home of friends.

title: CAREY PROCEEDS ON TRANSIT PLAN
description: ALBANY, March 31Governor Carey, whose suggestions for increased state control over mass transit got an unenthusiastic reception in the Legislature last week, said today that he was ordering a series of administrative steps to put some of the proposals into effect.

title: THIRD WORLD TOLD TO PUNISH ISRAEL
description: UNITE'D NATIONS, N. Y.,March 31 Members of 17 thirdworld countries have agreed that punitive measures against Israel, including dismissal from the United Nations, should be considered by the more than 70 countries that make up their influential bloc here.

title: ACTION PREDICTED AFTER REGROUPING
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that he expected North Vietnamese forces to launch major actions toward Saigon within the next two months.

title: City Files for Listing As an Area Eligible For U.S. Flood Aid
description: The city applied yesterday for membership in a Federal flood insurance program that would pay 90 per cent of the premiums of any resident who applied for Federal flood insurance.

title: WPIX WILL ACCEPT OUTSIDE DIRECTOR
description: WPIX, Inc., in an agreement end a sixyear challenge to its license to operate on Channel 11 here, announced yesterday that it would accept a member of its opposition on its board of directors.

title: 9 BLACK MUSLIMS WIN A REVERSAL
description: WM ORLEANS, March 31 (AP)The Louisiana Supreme Court overturned today the convictions of nine Black Muslims who were sentenced to 21 years each after being found guilty of inciting a 1972 riot in which five persons died.

title: Lon Nol Leaving Cambodia Today; Cancels Last Talk
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 31President Lon Nol, on the verge of departure, went through a series of tearful farewells today, including a final meeting with the American Ambassador, John Gunther Dean.

title: An Illusion Shattered
description: About a million South Vietnamese are still under Government arms, Saigon still has one of the largest air forces in the world, and there appears to be ample ammunition and equipment to carry on a war, Malcolm Browne of The New York Times reports from South Vietnam. In their flight from the Central Highlands and from the northern provinces of South Vietnam, moreover, Saigon's forces apparently abandoned hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Americanprovided military equipment and supplies, and American military officials in Washington are conceding that it was not for want of guns and ammunition that these forces broke so suddenly and completely.

title: JOHN. D. MWILLIAMS
description: NORWICH, Conn., March 31 (AP)John D. McWilliams, a United States Representative from 1943 to 1945, died yesterday, at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: Johns Hopkins No. 1 CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.,
description: March 31 (UPI)The United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association's major college coaches ranked Johns Hopkins University first today in their weekly poll. Johns Hopkins got all seven firstplace votes.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, April 1  President Lon Nol boarded a military helicopter inside his palace compound early this afternoon and took off on a journey that was expected to carry him into permanent exile.

title: Rich Alabamian Is Guilty Of Bombing Car, in 1972
description: SCOTTSBORO, Ala., March 31 A wealthy landowner whose greatgrandfather founded this Northeast Alabama town was found guilty today of a 1972 car bombing that almost killed an attorney here.

description: Nat'l Hockey League

description: The TwentyFirst Century Foundation was quietly created three years ago as an alternative to objectionable, if wellintentioned, paternalism on the part of white philanthropy.

title: LongThwarted Truce Teams Starting Exodus From Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31Many of the almost 600 members of the International Commission of Control and Supervision are clearing out of South Vietnam as the fighting they were sent to discourage closes in on this capital. Others are packing.

title: Humanities Grants Set Up By Rockefeller Foundation
description: The Rockefeller Fonndation announced yesterday its first 34 humanities fellows in new $600,000 program to illuminate and assess the values of contemporary society.

description: WASHINGTON, March 31Farm prices declined 2 per cent in the month ended March 15 from the averages of a month earlier, extending the slide of major agricultural commodities for the fifth consecutive month, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: West Germany Is Studying Law to Curb Foreign TakeOvers
description: BONN, March 31The West German Government is studying a proposed law to give it power to block foreign takeovers of German concerns not in the national interest, a Bonn Economics Ministry spokesman has confirmed.

title: S.E.C Staff Finds Data About Glomar Misleading
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The Securities and Exchange Commission suggested in an unusual statement today that Global Marine, Inc., which operated the salvage ship that raised part of a sunken Soviet submarine in the Pacific last summer, may have misled investors about its work for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Gladys Busk, Horsewoman, Tied for 74 Amateur Title
description: Gladys Terbell Busk, a horsewoman who ended her competitive career with a tie for the amateur ownerhunter championship last fall at the National Horse Show, died of cancer Sunday in Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. She was 43 years old and lived at 928 Lake Avenue, Greenwich.

title: Building Contracts Fell 23% in February
description: With residential construction still in the doldrums, contracts for future construction in February were down by 23 per cent from February, 1974, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: BIG BOARD EASES IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market moved in a narrow price range yesterday and finished slightly lower in slower trading.

title: Holdup Men Slay Police Aide's Kin In a Bronx Battle
description: The 52yearold brother of civilian police official was shot to death in his Bronx liquor store yesterday afternoon during an exchange of gunfire with two holdup men, one of whom was apparently wounded.

title: DORIS ANNE DEBELLA
description: Doris Anne DeBella, secretary David W. Burke, died Friday of a heart attack near Suffern, N.Y., while driving from Albany on the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to her mother's home in Brooklyn. She was 32 years old.

title: N.B.A. Players Supporting AbdulJabbar on Fine; Several Factors Still Unsettled for N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar, who needs no help on the court, received some yesterday when the officers of the National Basketball Players Association supported him on his right to About speak his mind.

title: Egypt Ties Canal Issue to Sinai Pullback
description: CAIRO, March 31  Egypt will let cargo bound for Israel pass through the Suez Canal only if an agreement is reached leading to a further withdrawal of Israeli forces from positions they now hold 10 to 15 mile from the canal, Egyptian officials said today.

title: Yesterday's Exhibition Baseball Games
description: AT CLEARWATER, FLA.

title: Parkchester's Conversion To Condominium Halted
description: The State Attorney General's office refused yesterday to let Harry B. Helmsley carry forward the conversion of Parkchester in the Bronx into condominium.

title: Columbia Defeats Fordham in 13th
description: Jim Bruno slammed a tworun homer in the 13th inning as Columbia defeated Fordham, 86, at Baker Field yesterday. It was the Lions' third victory in a row. lead on two home runs by Bob Kimutis and one by Bob Murphy, but Fordham scored four in the sixth to tie the game. Rob DiVincenzo and Mike O'Connell batted in two runs apiece in the sixth, when O'Connell hit a tworun homer.

title: Fumes Fell 12 at Plant Here
description: Carbon monoxide fumes from a heater overcame 12 workers in a sportswear manufacturing plant on the Lower East Side yesterday, the police reported. The men were employed at Brothers Togs, Inc., at 195 Chrystie Street. They were treated at Gouverneur and BeekmanDowntown Hospitals and released.

title: Cyprus: Perils of Delay
description: The death of a Canadian officer in the United Nations peace force during gun battles between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes is a sad reminder of the perils attending the delay of negotiations on the island's future. It has been three weeks since the Security Council requested a resumption and intensification of talks between the two Cyprus communities under the personal auspices of Secretary General Waldheim.

title: Southern Council Forced to Reduce Outlays and Staff
description: ATLANTA, April 1 The Southern Regional Council, probably the South's leading civil rights and social welfare research organization, has been forced to halve its expenditures and lay off a third of its staff because of faulty budgeting and declining support from recessionsqueezed philanthropies.

title: People in Sports
description: I really was worried last Sunday when Julius went off to the hospital complaining of an aching back, said the coach, whose club is tied for first place with Kentucky in the Eastern Division of the American Basketball Association.

title: Levich's Sons Leave Soviet
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (UPI)The two sons of the highestranking Jewish scientist to apply to emigrate to Israel flew to Vienna today, ending a threeyear waiting period. Aleksandr Levich, 30 years old, and his brother, Yevgeny, 26, applied to emigrate in March, 1972, together with their father, the electrochemist Benjamin G. Levich.

title: Mental Health Show Reports 3,000 Calls
description: Channel 13 received over 3,000 phone calls Monday night during the station's Helpline to Mental Health show, which offered assistance to viewers with psychological problems.

description: BASKETBALL

title: STOCKS REGISTER ABROAD DECLINE
description: The stock market posted a broad decline yesterday, reflecting continued investor concern over the weakening economy and Vietnam. Trading was very light.

description: Scott Camil, a central figure in the Gainesville Eight trial of antiwar veterans was in fair condition yesterday after being Shot by a Federal narcotics agent on a Gainesville street.

title: Volcano Watch Begun
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash., April 1 (UPI)A team of scientists has installed seismographic devices on the rim of Mount Baker's steaming vents because of speculation that the 10,778foot dormant volcano is heating up.

title: Rockets Set Back Hawks, 113104
description: HOUSTON, April 1 (UPI)Kevin Kunnert and Rudy Tomjanovich combined for 53 points tonight, leading the Houston Rockets to a 113104 victory over the Atlanta Hawks in the National Basketball Association.

Bay Ridge Renews Its Efforts to Bar Housing for Aged
description: Bay Ridge residents, apparently fearful of an influx of newcomers, renewed in Federal Court, in Brooklyn yesterday a fight they had lost more than a year ago against the construction of a $23million housing development.

title: Kunstler Assails State's Case in Attica Summation
description: BUFFALO, April 1For more than five hours today, William M. Kunstler reviewed and assailed the testimony of five prosecution witnesses as he began his summation in the Attica murder trial here.

title: A's Will Field LineUp Stronger Than Rivals'
description: MESA, Ariz., April 1If the Oakland A's have a vulnerable pitching staff, which they do since the departure of Catfish Hunter, on what can they depend to win a fifth straight division title, which is the necessary first step if they are to win a fourth straight World Series? On plenty.

title: Artpark Seeks Funds to Keep '75 Shows
description: ALBANY, April 1Artpark, the theater at the edge of the Niagara Gorge in Lewiston, N. Y., that combines painting and sculpture and such with theatrical performances. will have to give up its entire performing schedule this year unless the state comes up with more money.

title: Wary of Shift to Right
description: VIENNA, April 1Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria, the leader of his country's Socialist Party, is worried about a political shift to the right in Western Europe, one resulting from alarm over Portugal's Communist  dominated Government and over the worldwide combination of high inflation and unemployment.

title: U.S. Lays Pollution to 7 Con Ed Plants
description: The United States Government, in the first such action it has ever taken in the state, charged yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company was violating state and Federal standards for visible smoke emission in seven out of 11 major power plants in the city.

title: JOHN J. WHELAN
description: John J. Whelan, who retired in 1972 as director of purchasing of Bell Laboratories, Whippany, N.J., died Monday in Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx. He was 66 years old and lived at 5430 Netherland Avenue, the Bronx.

title: W. Walton Butterworth Dies; ExAmbassador to Canada, 71
description: W. Walton Butterworth, whose 40year diplomatic career included service as an Assistant Secretary of State and ambassadorships in Sweden and Canada, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Princeton, N. J., since his retirement in 1968.

title: U.N. Cyprus Force Condemns Violation Of CeaseFire Pact
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 1 (Reuters)The United Nations force in Cyprus today termed a twohour gun battle between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes and the Turkish army a serious breach of the ceasefire.

title: Colorado's Coors Beer Finds Many Takers at $13 a Case
description: ROCKAWAY, April 1Any self  respecting quaffer of Bass Ale or Japan's Kirin Beer delights in confiding to friends where such delicacies can be obtained. And then there are those who manage to have cases of Colorado's Coor beer shipped eastward, either for its gustatory or snob appeal.

title: Dangers Of Pessimism
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 You can hardly pick up a paper or magazine these days without being told that the American economy is staggering, the Western world is declining, and that the leaderless drift of the free nations is toward division, disruption, recession, and maybe even war.

title: Judge Rules Citizens Have Right To Their Credit Rating Reports
description: MIAMI, April 1A United States District Court judge today upheld the right of citizens to receive copies of investigative reports of their credit rating.
