DALEY WINS EASILY IN CHICAGO VOTING
description: CHICAGO, April 1  Richard J. Daley easily won an unprecedented sixth fouryear term today as Mayor of this overwhelmingly Democratic city.

title: RELIGIOUS SERVICES
description: JEWISH

title: Atom Plant's Neighbors Oppose Cooling Towers for Indian Point
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., April 1The two cooling towers that the Consolidated Edison Company may have to build at its Indian Point nuclear facility were denounced today at an atomic safety hearing as fine for fish but terrible for people.

title: H.E.W. Study Is Critical of Nursing Home Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Department of Health, Education and Welfare, in what it considers to be the first national study of nursing homes ever undertaken by any agency, published today an interim report that cited what one official called widespread deficiencies in the nation's nursing homes.

title: A Novel Idea in DrumTape Music
description: Although in theory any sound a composer can imagine may be synthesized in an uptodate music center, many electronic pieces continue to sound rather as if they were produced on steel drums, just as in the earliest days of the medium. Composers obviously like those reverberant, disembodied sonorities, and anything else seems suspect as not really electronic music.

title: '72 Earth Satellite To Monitor Impact Of Freon on Ozone
description: An earth satellite launched in 1972 is to be used to monitor the extent, if any, to which freon gases from spray cans and refrigeration, systems threaten the ozone layer that protects the earth against lethal ultraviolet rays from the

title: Jets Sign U.S.C.'s Wood, But Await Word on Davis
description: The Jets announced the signing yesterday of Richard Wood, their thirdround draft choice from Southern California, and cleared the way for tackling Wood's more celebrated teammate, Anthony Davis.

title: Nadjari's Record
description: An appeal, Mr. Dooley, the fictional saloonkeeper once said, is where ye ask wan coort to show its contempt f'r another coort. While lawyers ask appeals courts to overrule lower courts al the time, reversal come relatively in frequently. In New York City, where neither prosecutors nor the appellate courts publish box scores on criminal appeals, the courts generally affirm 80 to 90 per cent of the time.

title: CAMBODIA LOSES KEY MEKONG CITY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, April 2  Neak Luong, the Cambodian Government's last enclave on the lower Mekong River has fallen before a heavy onslaught by Communistled insurgent troops and artillery.

title: Many Americans Quit Vietnam; U.S. Denies Evacuation Orders
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1Americans are streaming out of South Vietnam.

title: RADICAL MAYOR WINS IN MADISON
description: MADISON, Wis., April 1 Mayor Paul R. Soglin, a 29yearold radical, won a second term tonight over his conservative opponent, former Mayor Henry Reynolds, 69.

title: P.U.C. Hears Complaints on Rockland
description: MAHWAHA, April 1  The Board of Public Utility Commissioners opened what was billed as the first of a series of road show consumer hearings tonight to a chorus of complaints over the Rockland Electric Company's request for a 23 per cent rate increase.

title: A VIENNESE FLAVOR IN AMATI'S CONCERT
description: The Amati Quartet's program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night was oriented around three Viennese classics: Mozart's Dissonant Quartet, Berg's Lyric Suite and Schubert's Quartet No. 10 in E flat. The performances had a very Viennese character as well, in the best and worst senses of the word.

title: Bridge:
description: The New York experts who dominated the national scene in the nineteenthirties were a particularly hardy breed, and nearly all of them are still around, and by and large playing as well as ever. Consider the following list, necessarily incomplete, of great players living here who have passed their 70th birthday: Theodore Lightner, Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, Harry Fishbein, S. Garton Churchill, B. Jay Becker, Howard Schenken and Richard L. Frey.

title: Bache Group Sets Dividend
description: The Bache Group, Inc., reporting improved earnings, voted yesterday to pay a dividend of 10 cents a share April 14. It paid two dividends of 5 cents each in the prior fiscal year.

title: Fuel Overcharges Found
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Investigators have uncovered more overcharges for fuel oil sold to electric utilities, bringing the known total to more than $1.2million in only four of the 200 cases under investigation, a Federal official said today. Investigators suspect that a total of $19.7million may have been overcharged on utility fuel.

title: Books of The Times
description: One of the smaller dividends of the bicentennial and likely one more lasting than pageantry and rhetoric is the focus of attention on those minor figures of the Revolutionary period whose names are familiar but whose histories are not. They were on the stage of great events, though seldom front and center; even so they did more than swell a scene or two, they were one with the great happenings that unfolded in their lifetime.

title: Market basket
description: Food prices in New York City retail stores went up slightly last week, 0.3 per cent, about a quarter of the rise three weeks ago, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Chessie, Criticizing New Rates on Coal, Won't Increase Any
description: Chessie System, Inc., has notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that, unless the regulatory agency authorizes the railroads to raise freight rates April 12 on export coal movements, Chessie won't apply a general freight increase of 7 per cent on other commodities. Last month the I.C.C., in approving the 7 per cent rate increase for April 12, exempted export coal from the higher rates.

title: Freedom Train Starts on Bicentennial Tour of Nation
description: STANTON, Del., April 1Bill Benson, a 34yearold accountant whose hobby is rebuilding trains, threw a shovel of coal Into the firebox of the steam locomotive that pulled the 25car Freedom Train from Washington to Stanton, leaned on the shovel and talked about the trip.

title: 5 Transit Police Officials Penalized in Graft Inquiry
description: Five top officials of the Transit Authority police force have been found guilty of accepting free liquor and trips and of falsifying department records, the new chief of the transit police, Sanford D. Garelik, said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Gunter Is Upset by Miss Louie in Opening Round
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1In a stunning surprise, Marcie Louie survived two set points before going on to upset Nancy Gunter, 76, 75, in the opening match of the $150,000 Virginia Slims championship, the biggest jackpot in women's tennis

title: Women Flocking to Veterinary Colleges, in a BacktoEarth Trend
description: ITHACA, N.Y.I decided in the fifth grade that I wanted to he a vet.Karen Reamsnyder of Syracuse.

title: Girls' Bodies Found in River
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (UPI)The bodies of two teenage shooting victims were pulled from the Schuylkill River in southwest Philadelphia today. The victims were Layne Dorothy Spicer, 16 years old, and Mary Ann Lees, 15, both neighbors and students at upper Darby High School in suburban Philadelphia.

title: New Hampshire Jobless Up
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 1 (AP)  Unemployment in New Hampshire climbed to its highest level in 25 years last week, with 23,400 persons out of work, or 6.9 per cent of the state's labor force, the Department of Employment Security said today.

title: Ethiopia Reports 5 Killed
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 1 (Reuters)Five civilians alleged to be involved in a plot against Ethiopia's leftwing Military Council were shot to death in a clash with security forces last month, according to a council statement published here today.

title: Typewriter Plants Of SCAT to Be Shut For 4Week Period
description: CORTLAND, N.Y., April 1 (AP)The SCM Corporation, the Cortland area's largest employer, said today it would suspend its SmithCorona typewriter production and close five manufacturing facilities here for four weeks starting April 14 because of economic conditions.

title: INTEREST OF 53% IN TALCOTT BOUGHT
description: Solomon Eisenrod, a New York lawyer and investor, has purchased the 53 per cent interest in the Talcott National Corporation owned by Fasco, Inc., the personal holding company of Michele Sindona, the Italian financier. The value of the transaction came to $5.6million. Mr. Sindona is being sought by the Italian and Swiss Governments for questioning in regard to the failure of certain banks in those countries.

title: A TeenAgers' Party With MiddleAge Nostalgia
description: It was a strange party, both more than met the eye and less. It was supposed to have been a reunion for children, now 16 and 17, who had first met when they were 3 or 4 at the New Lincoln School. Some had stayed at New Lincoln, but most had gone their separate waysto Collegiate, or Horace Mann; one boy is at Exeter in New Hampshire.

title: At Nha Trang
description: NHA TRANG, South Vietnam, April 1Panic held this city, long an important coastal resort, in its grip today as terrorstricken people, fearing that they would be trapped, fled in scenes of confusion like those that accompanied, the fall of Da Nang two days ago.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Ban on Outdoor Prayer Sessions in Queens Is Sought
description: A delegation of community leaders and politicians from Bayside, Queens, asked Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd yesterday to put a halt to semiweekly outdoor prayer meetings that they say are disrupting their area.

title: Region Development Plan Is Set for Three Counties
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, April 1Hundreds of government officials, corporate executives and leading educators from Middlesex, Somerset and Mercer Counties will gather at the Lawrenceville School tomorrow evening to hear a citizen study group tell why the three counties should plan their development as one region.

title: U.S.I.A. U.S
description: WASHINGTONMen grow old, not gradually like the spilling of sand through an hourglass, but men grow old in inconsistent leaps after long stillnesses. Like watching a frog, there is no way to predict when the next jump will occur or how much distance the jump will cover.

title: A Final Masterpiece By Wooden
description: SAN DIEGO, April 1As Kentucky bulled its way through the first four rounds of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, many coaches began to dread the impact this team of heavyweights would have on the college game if it won the championship. The purists feared a trend toward an uncontrollable physical game, a rush to recruit big players who could slug it out under the boards and serve as football tackles in their spare time.

title: Confusion Reigns on U.S. Move to Stop the Fighting
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The White House and the State Department issued conflicting reports today on whether United States diplomatic efforts were under way to halt the fighting in South Vietnam. The White! House later retracted its version.

title: Inquiry of Congestion Ordered At Bus Terminal in Midtown
description: Following repeated complaints from commuters, the Interstate Commerce Commission has ordered an investigation of the massive congestion at the midtown Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: CORRECTION
Energy and Food Needs Clash in Western States
description: BILLINGS, Mont., April 1A cavalcade of tour buses rumbled through the semiarid sagebrush country yesterday near Colstrip, 100 miles east of here, the center of one of the most extensive strip mining developments in the northern plains.

title: RESERVES DOWN FOR OIL AND GAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Two trade associations said today that the nation's proven reserves of crude oil and natural gas declined again in 1974.

title: For Miss Sills, Met Debut Isn't Apex of Career
description: This is not going to be a pinnacle of my career, Beverly Sills said yesterday, in what would seem to be a dissent from music lovers who are eagerly anticipating her Metropolitan Opera debut next Monday.

title: Interim President Takes Over As Lon Not Flies to Indonesia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 1The five years of rule of Marshal Lon Nol came to a virtual end today and the friends and supporters he left behind in charge of the Government began the task of trying to use his departure to get new aid from the United States or negotiations with the Communistled insurgents.

title: City's Revenues Run Ahead of Last Year But $200Million Shortfall Still Looms
description: In the first eight months of the current fiscal year, the city collected $1.779billion in taxes and fees in its general fundabout $234million more than for the comparable period last year. But because this year's budget is so much larger, a projection indicates that if last year's pattern holds true, the city will end its fiscal year three months from now with a revenue shortfall of about $200  million despite higher taxes.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 1The five years of rule of Marshal Lon Nol came to a virtual end today and the friends and supporters he left behind in charge of the Government began the task of trying to use his departure to get new aid from the United States or negotiations with the Communistled insurgents.

title: ELMER C. NELSON
description: MENDON, Mass., April 1 (AP)  Elmer C. Nelson, former Republican State Committee chairman and campaign manager for three Republican Governors, died at Milford Hospital yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: ISRAEL DISCOUNTS OPENING OF CANAL
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, April 1 (AP)Premier Yitzhak Rabin said today that Egypt's announced intention to reopen the Suez Canal on June 5 contributes nothing of benefit to Israel.

title: Egypt and Chile Get Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Egypt will get 300,000 tons of United States wheat valued at $48million under a new Food for Peace longterm credit agreement and Chile will receive 113,000 tons, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: U.S. COURT IN CHICAGO HALTS ATOMIC PLANT
description: CHICAGO, April 1 (AP)A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ordered today a permanent halt to construction of the Bailly Nuclear Power Station on Lake Michigan, east of Gary, Ind.

title: IncomeTax Accord Is Reached in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 1Governor Byrne and the Democratic majority leaders of the Legislature agreed without reservation today that a state income tax was required to meet New Jersey's fiscal crisis, but they failed to agree on a tax that is guaranteed to pass the State Senate.

description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday reinstated five perjury charges that had been brought by the special anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, against Ross J. DiLorenzo, a retired Civil Court judge.

title: Associated Dry Goods Quarter Net Declines by 15.9%
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which includes Lord & Taylor in its chain of department stores, reported yesterday a decline of 15.9 per cent in earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter and 19.7 per cent for the fiscal year ended Feb. 1. Sales, however, increased 1.5 per cent in the quarter and 4.8 per cent for the year.

title: February Inventory Rise Small
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The sustained and rapid buildup of manufacturers' Inventories all but came to a halt in February, but there was no actual liquidation of unwanted stocks, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP) Pinhas P. Delougaz, director of the Museum of Cultural History at University of California at Los Angeles, died in Iran of a heart attack, university officials learned today.

description: GLENDALE, Calif., April 1 (UPI)Gertrude Niesen, a popular Broadway and Hollywood singer of the nineteenthirties and early forties, died Thursday in Kaiser Permanente Hospital. She was 62 years old.

title: Leftovers Used Creatively

title: 20Month Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: The Treasury sold yesterday $1.5billion of 20month notes for an average return of 7.15 per cent. The Treasury received tenders for $3.8billion.

title: Queens Construction Man Held In Hatchet Slaying of His Wife
description: A 53yearold Queens construction worker, described by the police as a quiet, decent, hardworking guy, was arrested last night shortly after he allegedly killed his wife with a hatchet during a family argument and then wounded his two daughters and a soninlaw.

title: Advertising
description: One of the more challenging jobs in the agency business must be that of creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: Western Electric Drops 84
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 1 (UPI)The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing arm of the Bell Telephone System, has laid off 84 workers in its Oklahoma City plant because of falling demand for switching equipment. The company said additional layoffs may involve around 500 workers by midyear.

title: State Ends Fiscal Year Slightly in Red
description: ALBANY, April 1The state ended its fiscal year yesterday $18.5million in the red, according to the State Budget Director rather like a man with a $9,700ayear salary coming up $18.50 short on New Year's Day.

title: Texas Politician Dead
description: SAN DIEGO, Tex., April 1George B. Parr, political boss of Duval County, Tex., and a former millionaire oilman, banker and deputy sheriff who was facing a prison term for income tax evasion, was found dead today in a pasture of his South Texas ranch with a bullet wound in his head.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 2, 1975

title: Sugar Big Business in Hawaii Despite Urban Sprawl
description: WAIPAHU, Hawaii, March 30Beneath the tall stack and inside the factory, the molasses smell is strong and sweet. A sticky, sugary coating covers every exposed surface. Pounding, throbbing machines are watched over by men with faces from the islands of the Pacific. Outside, the fields of cane stretch toward the mountains. Across the rooftops of Waipahu, the sugar town, is Pearl Harbor.

title: A $20Million Suit Is Filed by Trustee Of Equity Funding
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1 (UPI) Robert Loeffler, courtappointed trustee for the Equity Funding Corporation of America, which went bankrupt in the biggest corporate fraud in United States business history, filed suit yesterday for $20million against the company's former president and other officers.

title: Life Is Hell on Earth
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1Cam Ranh Bay, one of the most picturesquely beautiful places on the South China Sea, has become a hell on earth for the hundred thousand or more refugees who have arrived there from Da Nang and also from the whole central part of the country.

title: Poppy Cannon White, 69, Dead; Writer Was Authority on Food
description: Poppy Cannon White, a widely known authority on food and the widow of Walter White, the longtime secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday in a plunge from the terrace of her apartment at 10 Park Avenue.

title: Kissinger Asks Public Figures for Negotiating Ideas
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Secretary of State Kissinger has asked a group of prominent public figures, most of them former high Government officials, to provide him with ideas on how to advance the Middle East negotiations following the recent breakdown of his own mediation efforts.

description: Recommendations for lower duties on steel were heard here yesterday along with strong appeals for maintaining present duty rates on textiles.

title: BRIDGE AUTHORITY HAD A '74 SURPLUS
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, often described as the M.T.A.'s meal ticket, yesterday reported an operating surplus of nearly $66million in 1974 despite a 5 per cent drop in traffic at its toll facilities. The year before there was a $75million surplus.

title: In Memoriam
description: COHENSam. April 2, 1965. Lovingly, remembered, sadly missed.

description: BOSTON, April 1, (Reuters)The Christian Science Monitor announced today that it would publish a new weekly international edition for distribution in 120 nations, beginning Monday.

description: TAMPA, Fla., April 1 (UPI)  A Miami builder, John Priestes, testified today that he turned over $80,000 in political contributions to a fund raiser for former Senator Edward J. Gurney, in return for Federal Housing Administration commitments.

description: VIENNA, April 1 (UPI)Economic experts from the world's major oil  exporting nations opened talks today on ways to protect their revenue by severing oil's traditional link with the dollar.

title: Article 6  No Title
Coastal Forces Unable To Reach Saigon Sector
description: The development of Communist attacks from the north and east of Saigon and the inability of units from the coastal cities to reach the perimeter around the capital have raised doubts in the Defense Department over prospects of the defense of Saigon. Pentagon sources said they were concerned over the Saigon forces' ability to establish a defensive position along a line from the Parrot's Beak on the Cambodian border to the sea. The line would run east of Bien Hoa, already under artillery fire, and through Long Thanh.

title: Knicks Overcome 76ers, 99 to 95, After Trailing Early by 16 Points
description: The Knicks rallied from a 16point deficit midway through the second period last night and held on for a 9995 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers before a crowd of 17,888 at Madison Square Garden.

title: HERBERT E. BERGER, ADMIRAL, LAWYER, 76
description: Herbert E. Berger, a retired Navy rear admiral and a practicing lawyer, died Monday at his home, 1 Fifth Avenue. He. was 76 years old.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: There are limits beyond which the processors of maraschino cherries may not go, the United States Food and Drug Administration has decided.

title: BacktoSchool Plan Weighed for Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Slowly and gingerly, at the urging of some lawyers and to the outrage of others, courts and bar associations are devising a program to improve the quality of legal services by forcing lawyers to go back to school periodically or give up the practice of law.

title: People and Business
description: The downturn in earnings last year at Honeywell, Inc., which as previously reported amounted to some 20 per cent, was accompanied by some severe reductions in pay for the company's senior executives.

title: Velasquez on 4 Winners, Upstaging Cordero Return
description: Nice to have you back, baby, a railbird called out to Angel Cordero yesterday as New York's hottest jockey appeared in the Aqueduct paddock for his first ride in a week. By day's end, though, Jorge Velasquez was the rider who was getting the red  carpettreatment. Velasquez, a distant second in the jockey standing, rode four winners and cut Cordero's lead to 21.

title: Egypt Formally Seeks Geneva Talks
description: CAIRO, April 1Egypt has formally asked the United States and the Soviet Union to reconvene the Geneva peace conference on the Middle East.

description: DETROIT, April 1  United States auto plants built 489,224 cars last month, a decline of 17 per cent from the 590,015 units built in March, 1974, when output had already slowed down because of the energy crisis.

title: Urban League Head Urges Job Program To Aid Unemployed
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) Vernon Jordan, head of the National Urban League, called today for a massive public works program to help jobless workers  especially blacks cope with inflation.

title: Mail Plane Pilot Killed
description: CULVER, Ind., April 7 (AP)The pilot of a small twinengine, mail plane was killed today when the plane caught fire on. a flight from Indianapolis to South Bend and crashed in a wooded area east of here. The authorities identified the victim as Gary Nickerson, 27 years old, of Akron, Ohio.

F. Hoving, the museum's director, as one of the greatest and most generous donations in its history.

description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., April 1The two cooling towers that the Consolidated Edison Company may have to build at its Indian Point nuclear facility were denounced today at an ??tomic safety hearing as fine for fish but terrible for people.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Corp. Expects Profit Gain for Quarter
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the holding company that owns the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the country's fourth  largest bank, expects to report higher earnings for the first quarter, Gabriel Hauge, chairman, indicated at the annual meeting here yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Roderick M. Hills, husband ssand former law partner of Carla A. Hills, the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, will be appointed counsel to the President, President Ford announced yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif. He will serve as deputy to Philip W. Buchen, who is the chief White House lawyer and has the title of Counselor to the President. Mr. Hills succeeds Phillip Areeda, who resigned to return to the Harvard Law School faculty.

title: U.S. HOUSING AID GIVEN TO NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Apr 1 (UPI)Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that $19.4million in Federal housing and public improvement funds would produce nearly 1,500 jobs in Newark, but that municipal layoffs would still be necessary.

title: Texas AirlineStrike Ends
description: HOUSTON, April 1 (AP)Texas International Airlines officials announced today the end of a fourmonthold strike and said it would begin 80 per cent of its scheduled flights on Friday.

title: A.&E Eustace Haydon Is Dead at 95; Taught Religion at U. of Chicago
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 1 (UPI)A. Eustace Haydon, professor emeritus of comparative religion at the University of Chicago and a leader in teaching of religion in this, country, died today of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital. He was 95 years old.

title: STATE HIGH COURT REVIVES 5 COUNTS AGAINST EXJUDGE
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday reinstated five perjury charges that had been brought by the special anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, against Ross J. DiLorenzo, a retired Civil Court judge.

title: Court Enjoins Cancellations Of Malpractice Insurance Here
description: The Argonaut Insurance Company was barred yesterday from raising its premiums on hospital malpractice policies and from canceling the policies for 35 hospitals throughout the state.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 2, 1975

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Cabot Corporation of Boston says it intends to give up its interest in a $100million liquefiednaturalgas terminal on Staten Island, but a New Jersey utility says the terminal can still be made successful. Richard Volmer, the treasurer of Cabot, said his concern was not going to put any more money into the project beyond the $35million already invested in its Distrigas of New York Corporation subsidiary.

title: The Suez Appeal
description: The announcement by President Sadat that he would open the Suez Canal to international shipping on June is a shrewd diplomatic maneuver further to isolate Israel prior to the Geneva peace talks. Use of the canal is a matter of great economic advantage to Western Europe as well as to Japan, Iran and Saudi Arabia, and of considerable strategic interest to the Soviet Union. Promises of substantial loans by Iran and Japan to prop up the Egyptian economy underscore the canal's high value as a quid pro quo.

title: For Miss Sills, Met Debut Isn't Apex of Career
description: This is not going to be a pinnacle of my career. Beverly. Sills said yesterday, in what would seem to be a dissent from music lovers who are eagerly anticipating her Metropolitan Opera debut next Monday.

title: City Labor Fiasco
description: The report of a state referee that New York City guilty of an unfair labor practice in its dispute with unionized firemen, is a depressing commentary on the capacity of city officials to represent its interests effectively in contract negotiations.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In the first eight months of the current fiscal year, New York City collected $1,778billion in taxes and fees in its general fundabout $234million more than for the comparable period last year.

title: Airline to Fly Orphans From Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)  The airline president who got the last refugee plane in and out of chaotic Da Nang says he will fly nearly 1,500 orphaned Vietnamese infants to the United States and Australia tomorrow for adoption with or without permission from the Governments involved.

title: N.H.L. Battle for Two Playoff Spots
description: N.H.L. Battle for Two Playoff Spots

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, April 1 (UPI)Jewel Klein, Illinois Racing Board attorney, said today she had reasonable grounds to believe a number of different drugs were used on thoroughbred horses at Illinois tracks last year, all in violation board rules. Miss Klein previously charged 18 trainers with allowing a morphine derivative to be injected into their horses before races at three Chicago area tracks last year, but so far that is the only drug the board has found in urine tests.

title: Catholics' TV Station in Chicago Stresses Elementary Education
description: As the jumble of errant lines and fuzzy images rounded into order on the 19inch color television console, Loretta Szpek's seventhgrade class quieted to a hush. It was 8.45 on a recent Wednesday morning and, in the course of the next 20 minutes, the students learned, among other things, that the Eiffel Tower is 295 meters high and the Statue of Liberty 93 meters high.

title: Islanders Rally To Tie Flames
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 1  If the New York Islanders have champagne on ice, they'll have to wait another few days to pop the cork. For the second time this week, the Islanders and the Atlanta Flames played to a 22 tie, although the New York team outclassed its 1972 expansion cousins.

title: Western Governors Plan To Fight Ford on Energy
description: BILLINGS, Mont., April 1Governors of the Western Plains coal states gathered here today to tell the Federal Government that they are going to resist national energy development planslike President Ford's Project Independence blueprintthat they said would disrupt the West's agricultural economy.

title: Islanders Tie Flames With Late Goal, 2 to 2
Institution Dollar Volume 69% of Big Board's Total
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that a new transactions study showed institutions accounted for 69 per cent of the dollar value and 59 per cent of the share volume of public trading on the exchange in the first quarter of last year.

title: Farm Price Tumble
description: Farm prices have declined by 10 per cent in the last five months, promising consumers some surcease from the continuing climb of food costs at retail. Hope for such relief will dim, however, if SenateHouse conferees use the slump in farm income as justification for endorsing the wildly exaggerated price supports for farmersapproved by the Senate just before the Easter recess.

title: SWITZERLAND SETS FRANC PROTECTION
description: BERN, Switzerland, April 1 (UPI)The Swiss Government and the national bank announced today a series of measures to protect the Swiss franc from currency speculation.

title: 6 Women Receive Awards For Achievement in Media
description: The recipients of six Matrix Awards for professional achievement in the media were announced yesterday by the New York Women in Communications.

title: Dollar Shows Drop On Europe Markets; Gold Up in London
description: BRUSSELS, April 1 (UPI)The dollar closed lower on European money markets today, as the Swiss Government moved to protect its currency against speculation and as economic experts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met in Vienna to discuss how to protect oil revenues against reverses in the dollar's value.

title: Vatican Official Puts Investment at Under $120Million
description: ROME, April 1The Vatican's investments throughout the world amount to less than $120million, according to a cardinal concerned with financial affairs.

title: Vietcong Protests Airlift
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 1 (Agence FrancePresse)The Vietcong strongly protested today what they called an illegal airlift of arms from California to Saigon.

title: Trial of Con tally Starts; Jury to Be Seated Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The trial of John B. Connally on bribery charges opened in United States District Court here today, and all but the final phase of jury selection was completed.

title: AGENCIES MOVING TO HELP REFUGEES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1United States authorities and leading private relief agencies moved today to provide daily emergency food for one million South Vietnamese war refugees, but many officials acknowledge that the dimension of needs had yet to be determined.

title: Portugal Denies She Tried To Return Macao to China
description: LISBON, April 1 (AP)The Portuguese Government said today that it had had discussions with China about the future of Macao, but that there were no plans to turn the colony over to Peking.

title: U.S. Lays Pollution To 7 Con Ed Plants
description: The United States Government, in the first such action it has ever taken in the state, charged yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company was violating state and Federal standards for, visible smoke emission in seven out of 11 major Dower Wants in the city.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, may be telephoned to Oxford 55311 until 11 P.M. In Regional offices 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday New Jersey (201) MArket 33900: Westchester Co. and Northern New York State Counties (914) WHite Plains 95300; Nassau, Co. (516) 7370500; Suffolk Co. (516) 6691800: Connecticut (203) 3387767.

title: Texas Inmate Guilty of Murder In Escape Death of a Hostage
description: HOUSTON, April 1 (UPI)A state court jury today found Ignatio Cuevas guilty of capital murder in the death of a woman hostage during an attempted breakout of the Texas state prison masterminded by Fred Gomez Carrasco last summer.

title: Greek Village Guards Two Old Trees
description: SKOLARION, GreeceOn the edge of this Macedonian village stand two giant sycamore trees. In their drooping branches hundreds of herons fisheaters, to the villagers make their nests and raise their young.

title: Cosmos Set Back Toros, 10, in Haiti
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, April 1 (AP)The New York Cosmos defeated the Miami Toros, 10, tonight as 11,000 fans witnessed their first professional soccer game in Haiti's Sylvio Cator National Stadium.

title: Miami Lawyer and Aide Named In Alleged Bribe of Judge Here
description: A Florida lawyer and his assistant were indicted here yesterday for allegedly attempting to bribe a New York judge to lower the bail of a suspect being held on charges of cocaine smuggling.

title: Relief Agencies Helping Vietnamese Are Listed
description: Major assistance programs for Vietnamese civilians are being operated by 68 private United States relief agencies, which accept contributions of funds. Ten of the leading organizations are.

title: DAVE MORRIS JR., BANKER, 74, DEAD
description: Dave Kennen Morris Jr., who retired in 1965 as a senior vice president of the Bank of New York, died yesterday at the New York Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 25 Sutton Place.

title: GOLDMAN INDICTED BY FEDERAL JURY
description: A Federal grand jury returned a 44count indictment yesterday against Irving Goldman, charging him with conspiring to defraud the New York City Transit Authority, the Interborough News Company and the United States Government by filing false corporate incometax returns from 1971 to 1973.

title: 3 NEWSMEN CLEARED OF CONTEMPT CHARGE
description: BUFFALO, April 1The Niagara Gazette and three of its employes were found not guilty today of criminal contempt of court charges filed against them after the newspaper published material contained in a sealed grandjury report.

title: Thieu's Opponents Seek Action but Seem Paralyzed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 2Opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu has grown widespread and vocal over the last two weeks as the impression has gained ground that he no longer controls his nation or even his Government and armed forces.

title: Disaster Areas Declared
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April (AP)President Ford declared today major disasters for Arkansas and Texas as a result of tornadoes in March. His action will clear the way for use of Federal funds for relied and recovery efforts in the two states.

title: Postponing Raises Urged To Cut City Budget Defici
description: The Economic Development Council of New York City proposed yesterday that the city renegotiate its current labor contracts and postpone the payment of salary increases as a means of reducing the 1975.76 budget gap by $420million.

title: For Those Who Flee,
description: NHA TRANG, South Vietnam, April 1Panic held this city, long an important coastal resort, in its grip today as terrorstricken people, fearing that they would be trapped, fled in scenes of confusion like those that accompanied the fall of Da Nang two days ago.

title: GEORGE H. MOFFETT
description: George H. Moffett, a retired textile industry executive, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived at 1344 Midland Avenue, Bronxville.

title: TV: School for Scandal
description: Public television's Theater in America has become astonishingly adept at transposing stage productions to a TV screen. The latest coup, adapted by Michael Bawtree, features the Guthrie Theater Company's bright and lovely version of Richard Brinsley Sheridan's The School for Scandal. Michael Langham, artistic director of the Minneapolis company, has codirected the production with Nick Havinga. It will be shown tonight at 9.

title: ONLY WELLTODO LEAVING CAMBODIA
description: PHNOM PENH, April 1When President Lon Nol was eased out of Cambodia today on the pretext of an official mission to Indonesia, his official party of about 30 persons joined the outbound airlift that is carrying the families of the welltodo and wellpositioned from the besieged capital.

title: DUTTON TAKEOVER BY DUTCH DISCUSSED
description: E. P. Dutton & Co. and the Netherlands publishing house of Elsevier are discussing a possible takeover of the American company by the Dutch publishing giant. It's only a possibility, said John Macrae 3d, president and chief executive officer of Dutton, but we do have a problem that must be resolved.

title: The Stage
description: Theater for me, says Rochelle Owens, is true flesh changed into belief and eaten with bread by the Grand Inquisitor. The merging of body and spirit runs rabidly through her work; Miss Owens is a visceral playwright, filling her plays with bile, blood and spleen while keeping half an eye on the heavens. Her writing can be too fleshydripping with imagery, orgasmic with exclamations, delirious with depravity.

title: TREASRY COUPONS DECLINE IN PRICE
English Cookery From a Cumberland Kitchen
description: When we learned that John Tovey, proprietor of an English hotel, was en route to Manhattan we invited him to visit our kitchen, if for no other reason than because of an article we'd read some time back in The London Times. It was written by Margaret Costa, one of England's most admired food writers, who stated unequivocally that John Tovey is the best British pastry cook I know.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: STOCKS OFF AGAIN ON AIM AND OTC
description: Prices fell again on the American Stock Exchange in slightly stepped up trading as those in the overthecounter market dropped in decreased activity.

title: REALESTATE SUIT CHARGES OIL PLOT
description: A group of 47 realestatel operators, controlling more than 29,000 residential and commercial units in the metropolitan area, has filed a $145million suit against 11 major oil companies, charging them with fixing artificially high prices for fuel oil from 1968 on.

title: Futures in Potatoes Record an Advance On CashQuote Gain
description: Potato futures rallied on the New York Mercantile Exchange, following higher quotations for cash potatoes in Maine, which were issued by the Department of Agriculture. In Chicago, soybeans fell on the Chicago Board of Trade under pressure of increased farmer selling.

title: The Role of the C.I.A.
description: When the Central Intelligence Agency was caught the web of Watergate, a thorough scrutiny of its past and definition of its future mandate became inevitable and essential. Fragmentary disclosures concerning the agency's involvement in highly dubious enterprises abroad and illegal activities at home have raised questions about the very nature of a secret intelligence apparatus in a free society.

title: Uncle Sam And Ivan In Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, IraqWashington is officially represented in Iraq only by a diminutive United States Interests section staffed by American diplomats under the Belgian Embassy. King Baudouin's solemn young face adorns the entry where one might expect a picture of Gerald Ford. Yet, despite this frail diplomatic link, the position of the United States is becoming steadily more important.

title: U.S. MARINES SENT TO AID NAVY SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Defense Department announced today that 700 marines had been sent to assist the four Navy amphibious and cargo vessels in the possible evacuation of refugees from South Vietnam.

title: U.S. Cargo Plane Lands in Saigon, but Whether It Is Start of an Airlift Is Unclear
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1When the telephone rang last Sunday morning, Capt. Don Wiegard was stretching in bed just before taking his daughter Kelly to hunt Easter eggs in downtown Vacaville, Calif.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHAT PRICE VOLTAIRE? Bibliophiles can head for the Plaza Hotel tonight for a sampling of the fourday Antiquarian Book Fair, a biennial mart of rare books, fine bindings, autographed material, graphics, manuscripts and modern firsts, all on sale and ranging in price from $4.50 to $45,000. Tonight's preview, from 7 P.M. to 10 P.M. in the hotel's Baroque and Crystal Suites, has a $6 fee for early shoppers and browsers; admission is $2.50 tomorrow and Friday (1 P.M. to 10 P.M.) and Saturday (11 A.M.6 P.M.). Proceeds of admission will go to the CooperHewitt Museum of Design.

title: Overseas Press Club Gives Photo and Reporting Prizes
description: Robert G. Kaiser of the Washington Post and a freelance photographer, W. Eugene Smith, were named winners yesterday of the top Overseas Press Club awards for 1974.

title: Trout's Opening Day: Early Risers Thrive
description: cluding those of the lsonychia group.

title: Funds City
description: Why, it is asked, is New York City's budget so much bigger per capita than that of other cities?

title: Trout's Opening Day: Early Risers Thrive
description: ROSCOE, N. Y., April 1Perhaps prodded into activity by the formidable array of worms, lures and flies flung at them, the frigid trout (the water temperature was 35 degrees at 7 A.M.) of the Beaverkill and Willowemoc Rivers responded fairly well to an average openingday crowd of anglers.

title: Hunter Hurls 7 Strong Innings;
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1  James Augustus Hunter, whose cost to his employer per inning pitched this season is calculated to be the highest in baseball annals (about $500 an inning), indicated again today he was ready to justify the expense.

title: Bernstein to Return to Met, To Lead Fidelio Revival
description: Leonard Bernstein will return after a twoyear absence to the Metropolitan Opera next season to conduct its revival of Beethoven's Fidelio. The production, created in 1970, was designed by Boris Aronson and staged by Otto Schenk.

title: Red Smith
description: ROSCOE, N. Y., April 1Here in the Catskills icicles festoon the rock walls where Highway 17 slices through the hills. Snow carpets the wooded slopes and there is ice on the ponds. In other words, the weather is normal for opening day of the trout season, an immovable feast also known as All Fools' Day. Things were normal last night, too, in the Antrim Lodge, where the clan assembled for the annual Sullivan County Fishing Conference and Liars' Round Table. This dog of mine was barking out in the woods, Charley Crist of the Middleton TimesHerald Record was saying, a coon hound crossed with beaver. I didn't feel like going out in the cold so I let him bark. He kept it up all night. In the morning he was still at it so I went out to look. What had happened, he had treed a coon and gnawed the tree down and was calling me to come shoot the coon. Truth, as the man says, lay prostrate. So did most of the clan after a while, but not for long.

title: CLOSING ORDER SENT TO 6 NURSING HOMES
description: ALBANY, April 1 (UPI)The State Health Department today ordered the closing of six Westchester County nursing homes and fined another $1,000 for denying entrance to department inspectors last January.

title: Trial of Con tally Starts; Jury to Be Seated Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The trial of John B. Connally on bribery charges opened United States District Court here today, and all but the final phase of jury selection was completed.

title: GOLDMAN INDICTED BY FEDERAL JURY
description: A Federal grand jury returned a 44count indictment yesterday against Irving Goldman, charging him with conspiring to defraud the New York City Transit Authority, the Interborough News Company and the United States Government by filing false corporate incometax returns from 1971 to 1973.

title: BacktoSchool Plan Weighed for Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Slowly and gingerly, at the urging of some lawyers and to the outrage of others, courts and bar associations are devising a program to improve the quality of legal services by forcing lawyers to go back to school periodically or give up the practice of law.

title: Lacrosse Coach Named
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (UPI)  Jim Hinkson, a defenseman, was named today head coach of the Philadelphia Wings of the National Lacrosse League to succeed Bobby Marsh. Marsh resigned last night for personal reasons.

title: CORRECTION
PRICES ARE RAISED BY OIL COMPANIES
description: Petroleum companies have begun passing on to consumers the Federal tax of $1 a barrel on imported oil that President Ford imposed Feb. 1 as a fuels conservation measure. The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday it had raised prices on as grades of gasoline by 1 cent a gallon, noting that the Government allowed it to pass on to consumers the higher costs of raw materials and imported products

title: Islanders: A Night Of Highs and Lows
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 1 The Islanders tonight were not, in the words of Eddie Westfall, masters of our own destiny, and so they must wait, and hope.

title: Shelton Still Gropes, Month After Explosion at Rubber Factory
description: SHELTON, Conn., April 1Beyond the twisted machinery and the fireblackened ruins along the Housatonic River, people here still seem numbed by the bombing a month ago that ripped apart the old sponge  rubber factory that once provided more jobs than any other place in town.

title: Burlington Shuts Fabric Plant
description: Burlington Industries announced yesterday that it would phase out the manufacturing of narrow fabrics and close its South Hill, Va., plant. The plant, part of Burlington's ribbon division, employs 375 people.

title: Cardinal Jaeger, 82, Dies; Archbishop of Paderborn
description: PADERBORN, West Germany, April 1 (AP)Lorenz Cardinal Jaeger, a mechanic's son who became Archbishop of this Westphalian city, died today at the age of 82. It was the 53d anniversary of his ordination as a priest.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The State has announced the ppointment of J. Ferrell Parker to head an experimental program in Newark to provide a broad extension of public health insurance. Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies Ann Klein said that Mr. Parker, previously associate director of health services at the University of Massachusetts. would serve as executive director of the Newark Comprehensive Health Services Plan.

title: MANY AMERICANS LEAVING VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1Americans are streaming out of South Vietnam.

title: Other Carriers Will Fight $89 CoasttoCoast Flight
description: World Airways, which has drawn global attention with its exploits in the Vietnam eyacuation, stirred controversy at home yesterday with a proposal for a rockbottom coasttocoast air fare.

title: U.S. ARMS FOR ISRAEL SAID TO DELAY PEACE
description: CAIRO, April 2, (Reuters)Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy told members of a United States Congressional delegation today that large United States arms deliveries to Israel were making it more difficult to reach a Middle East peace settlement.

title: L.I.R.R. Lifts Price Of Its Drinks to $1.75
description: The price of a drink has gone up 30 per cent for riders on the bar cars of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Distraught Couples: A Matter of Waiting
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI)  Tom Crawford and his wife, Terry, watch television news every night with a nagging fear that the infant Vietnamese boy they intended to adopt may never be brought safely out of Saigon.

title: SIMON ADVOCATES MONETARY BRAK??
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 ?? Secretary of the Treasury W?? ham E. Simon said today th?? he thought the Federal Reser?? System should moderate ?? rate of growth of the mane supply, once the business u?? turn begins. Mr. Simon woul not say what he thought th?? rate of growth should he b?? replied I certainly do whe asked if a rate of S to 10 p?? cent would be much to high.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court ruled in Trenton that the results of a liedetector test administered to an alleged rape victim two years after the attack could be admitted in evidence in court. The Appellate Division of Superior Court granted an appeal by the Camden County Prosecutor's office that sought to admit the results of the lie detector test given to Rosemary Branch, the alleged victim.

title: Quick, Inexpensive Test on Bacteria Detects Chemicals Potentially Dangerous to Man
description: With Americans already exposed to an estimated total of 25,000 synthetic chemicals and with hundreds of new ones introduced each year, scientists in government and industry are turning increasingly to a quick, inexpensive test on bacteria as a way of identifying those chemicals that are potentially hazardous for man.

title: Men Vote, Women Die
description: In a few days 100 men are to decide whether to cause the suffering and death of thousands of American women. Last year the Senate passed such legislation, but fortunately it died in conference committee.

title: N.B.A. East WildCard Battle
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Agreement Signed For Art Exchange By U.S. and Soviet
description: The signing of an agreement on an exchange of art treasures between the Soviet Union and the United States was announced last night by M. Knoedler & Co., Inc., of 21 East 170th Street, the art gallery.

title: Cam Ranh: Long Coveted by Diplomats and Generals
description: Cam Ranh Bay, now apparently passing into North Vietnamese control, is a place of extraordinary beauty and an unhappy past. With one of the greatest natural deepwater ports in the world, and situated on sea routes between Japan and China and the West, it has fascinated diplomats and generals.

title: $7.80 Choice Wins Distaff At Aqueduct
description: A change of tactics proved successful for Something Super, in the $28,325 Distaff Harldibap at Aqueduct yesterday. Coming off the pace in the sevenfurlong test for fillies and mares, Something Super scored by threefourths of a length over Shy Dawn, who had a neck the better of Second Coming in the field of eight.

title: U.S. Rescue Group Loses Contact in Vietnam Interior
description: WESTPORT, Conn., April 2 (UPI)The Save the Children Federation said today that it had lost contact with many staff members and project centers in interior areas of South Vietnam.

title: Unopposed Slate Loses
description: UNIONTOWN, Kan. April 2 (AP)The entire city government of this Bourbon County community of 300 persons ran unopposed for reelection and lost. The mayor and five city councilmen lost yesterday to writein candidates. Councilman Noland Headley was beaten by his brother, Herbert.

title: REP. FRASER IN SEOUL ON A RIGHTS SURVEY
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 2A visiting United States Congressman said today that the United States should make its allies' commitment to democracy a strong condition for giving them foreign aid, especially military aid.

title: Report of Robbery Leads to Indictment For Tax Evasion
description: Joseph Valentine, a Bronx gasoline station owner, filed routine tax returns for the year 1970 through 1972 and reported an income averaging less than $10,000 a year.

title: OneYear Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 6.475 per cent.

title: Rites Set for Poppy Cannon
Excessive Profits On Defense Work Seen by Rickover
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) Adm. Hyman G. Rickover testified today that hundreds of millions of dollars in excessive profits had been made on defense contracts.

title: Oil Companies See U.S. Depletion Ban Cutting Exploration
description: Several top oil companies said yesterday the elimination last week of the oil depletion allowance and changes in the foreign tax credit would result in huge drops in spending for oil exploration and develop. ment.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Nordiques Clinch First
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., April 2 (AP)The Quebec Nordiques clinched first place in the Canadian Division of the World Hockey Association tonight as Marc Tardif and Rejean Houle scored goals in the final 78 seconds to defeat the Minnesota Fighting Saints, 53.

title: 27 Die in French Bus Crash
description: VIZILLE. France, April 2 (UPI)  A bus crowded with Frenchmen on a religious pilgrimage apparently had a brake failure on a hairpin turn and smashed through the stone barrier of a bridge today, plunging 80 feet onto a rocky river embankment. Police officials reported that 27 persons were killed and 16 injured.

title: A FearSwept Saigon Is on Brink of Chaos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2This capital is on the brink of chaos. The streets are humid and eerily silent at night as soldiers cluster on street corners or sprawl on the pavement and sleep beneath tamarind trees.

title: Columbia's Nine Wins 4th in Row
description: Ron Pettinger hit a tworun homer with two out in the ninth inning as Columbia rallied to defeat Rutgers, 1110, at Andy Coakley Field yesterday. The victory was Columbia's fourth in a row.

title: LINDSAY H. WELLING
description: Lindsay H. Welling a retired industrial sales engineer and inspector of materials in the New York Ordnance District in World War II, died Tuesday of pneumonia in Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: Saigon's Desperate Hour
description: The disintegration of the Government forces throughout most of South Vietnam above Saigon's defense perimeter adds military emphasis to the longevident political fact that President Thieu is unable to lead his country either to victory or to a negotiated peace. Mr. Thieu's inherent deficiencies as head of an allegedly democratic regime are now overshadowed by what can only be described as a paralysis of command, resulting in an apparently chaotic breakdown in civilian administration as well as military operations.

title: U.S. DROPS SUBPOENA IN A HEARST INQUIRY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (UPI)The Government has, dropped its subpoena seeking testimony from John J. Scott, father of Jack Scott, allegedly a key figure in the Patricia Hearst investigation, it was disclosed Wednesday.

title: DEMOCRATS REAR CONVENTION BIDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Kansas City and Cleveland made strong bids today to become the site of the Democratic party's Presidential convention next year.

title: NATION'S ENERGY USE FELL BY 2.2.% IN 1974
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) Energy consumption in the United States fell 2.2 per cent in 1974 after climbing steadily for more than two decades, Rogers C. B. Morton, Interior Secretary, reported today.

title: Miss Evert Expecting Fight to Remain No. 1
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2I was No. 1 last year, said Chris Evert assuredly the world's best tennis player in 1974, but I don't consider myself No. 1 right now.

title: Oakland Signs Okker
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 2 (AP)The Golden Gaters addOkker to their World Term Tennis roster today, signing the Dutch star to a multiyear contract. Okker, 31 years old, was one of the top players in W.T.T.'s first season last year. He won 31 of 42 sets while playing with the TorontoBuffalo franchise.

title: The Dance: 2 by Limon
description: Jos Limn's The Moor's Pavane is a dance work we have seen quite a bit of lately. Rudolf Nureyev used it as a vehicle to make his modern dance debut here with the National Ballet of Canada and also appeared in it with his own concert group this winter. The Royal Danish Ballet and at least three major American ballet companies now include the Limn work in their repertories.

title: 27 Die in French Bus Crash
description: VIZILLE, France, April 2 (UPI)  A bus crowded with Frenchmen on a religious pilgrimage apparently had a brake failure on a hairpin turn and smashed through the stone barrier of a bridge today, plunging 80 feet onto a rocky river embankment. Police officials were ported that 27 persons were killed and 16 injured.

title: About the Mets . . .
description: Jon Matlack pitched two innings at the minor league field. It was his second start there since he strained a muscle in the right side nearly three weeks ago, and it was intended to work him into the regular rotation behind Tom Sewer. . . . Tonight is the fifth and final meeting with the Yankees in Fort Lauderdale. Seaver will pitch against Larry Gura, then rest four days and open the season Tuesday against Philadelphia. . . . In tomorrow night's game against Detroit, interest will center on Cleon Jones, who had knee surgery last October and hasn't played one inning yet in Florida. His knee seems fine, said Dr. James Parkes, the team's busy physician. He's been troubled lately by a pulled calf muscle in the same leg.

title: People and Business
description: John Dunlop, the new Secretary of Labor, thinks the tax reduction bill signed by President Ford last week could create about one million new jobs in the course of next year.

title: In Hollywood, Record Corporate Prosperity Coexists With High Unemployment Rates
description: HOLLYWOOD  Booming prosperity and vast unemployment are playing a strange double feature in this collection of movie and television studios that still is the world's major factory of mass entertainment.

title: I.R.S. Names Albany Chief
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 George S. Alberts has been promoted to director of the Albany Internal Revenue Service' District, the I.R.S. announced here yesterday. Mr. Alberts, who has been chief of the audit division in Newark since 1970, succeeds Donald T. Hartley, who retired.

title: Coal Mining Injuries Drop But Fatalities Hold Steady
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) The annual number of serious coal mining injuries declined dramatically in 1974, the Interior Department said today.

title: Rockefeller Perceives Little U.S. Can Do Now
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the next 30 days should determine whether South Vietnam could survive by establishing a defensive line north of Saigon.

title: ALCOA CUTTING BACK OUTPUT OF BAUXITE
description: The Aluminum company or America said yesterday it was cutting back its bauxite production in Jamaica, Surinam and the Dominican Republic in line with reduced production of alumina and aluminum in this country.

title: Waldheim Bars U.N. Plea on Refugees
description: ROME, April 2Secretary General Waldheim said today that the fate of Vietnamese refugees in areas occupied by Communist forces was a very controversial political problem that the United Nations should avoid.

title: Byrne Seeks Repeal of Fair Trade Act
description: TRENTON, April 2Goyermor Byrne announced today that he would submit to the Legislature next Monday a bill repealing New Jersey's 37yearold Fair Trade Act, which authorizes price fixing on most brandname consumer products sold in the state.

title: W. F. SCIIARNIKOW, 68, N.L.R.B. JUDGE, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, April 2William F. Scharnikow, a retired administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board, died today in George Washington Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: GeorgiaPacific Paper Mills To Shut Down for 8 Days
description: WOODLAND, Me., April 2 (AP)The GeorgiaPacific Corporation announced today that its newsprint paper machine and groundwood pulping facilities here will shut down for eight days beginning Sunday.

title: Market Place
description: The new equities market, which has been dormant for some time, may see heavy activity in the foreseeable future. That's what Peter L. Bernstein, a Manhattan consulting economist, thinks, and he offers some persuasive reasons.

title: Texas Coach Takes Lie Test
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 2 (AP)Darrell Royal says he and his University of Texas football coaching assistants have taken liedetector tests on recruiting questions in the last month. He said today he would disclose the results if any other school wanted to compare tests. The Southwest Conference instituted the polygraph test last December. Royal is the first coach since then to say publicly he has taken one.

title: Emphatic White Paper
description: Britain's Labor Governmentor at least the majority bloc of sixteen Europeans in Prime Minister Wilson's divided Cabinethas at last come down emphatically on the side of remaining in the Common Market. The Governnient's White Paper puts the positive case for British membership far more convincingly than Mr. Wilson did in his lackluster report to Parliament after the successful Community summit meeting in Dublin last month.

title: Byrne Says He Offered Job To Figure in Investigation
description: TRENTON, April 2Governor Byrne said today that he had offered a state post to John Nero, a Camden County political figure involved in a state investigation of alleged corruption there. But the Governor said he retracted the offer last spring after a state police inquiry into Mr. Nero's background turned up allegedly damaging evidence against him.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, April 2, 1973

title: 3 Seized in Sale of $2Million In Tickets Stolen From Airlines
description: The police recovered almost $2million in stolen airline tickets and $5,000 in cash last night after seizing three men who were allegedly selling blank airline coupons on the sidewalk at Broadway and 72d Street.

title: Vereen, at the Waldorf, in Blend Of Soul, Country and the Beatles
description: Much of Ben Vereen's oneman show  he opened at the WaldorfAstoria's Empire Room on Tuesdayis standard nightclub fodder, served up with bravura. Mr. Vereen, as expected, reflects on his life and times on Broadway with songs, from Pippin, Hair and Jesus Christ Superstar and covers other musical bases by singing some soul, country and Beatles. Also, as expected, he plugs his latest album and ties up the package with some energetic dancing.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 3. 1975

title: WARD SALES HIGHER THAN MARCH OF '74
description: Montgomery Ward & Co., Inc., Chicago, had 1.5 per cent higher sales in March than in the same 1974 month, with total sales last month reaching $262.4million compared with $258.6million in March, 1974. Ward, a division of Marcor, Inc., became the first national retail chain to report its March sales yesterday. Others such as Sears, Roebuck & Co. and J. C. Penney are expected to announce their results today.

title: A.B.A. East FirstPlace Battle
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Mets List Stone as Disabled
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2The New York Mets placed George Stone on the disabled list today in the first of a series of actions designed to salvage their onceimposing pitching staff.

title: TimeTested Security
description: Thirtyfive years after issuance of the first benefit checks by the Social Security System, critics of this widely and deservedly admired program are doing their utmost to undermine confidence in both its fairness and its actuarial soundness. The criticisms are of a kind Congress rightly rejected at the birth of Social Security, but recessionfed anxieties about every aspect of the economy tend to give them exaggerated credibility now.

title: Business Leaders Propose New Policies on TV
description: The Committe for Economic Development, an organization of business executives, most of whom are chairmen and presidents of major corporations, yesterday issued recommendations for new national policies on electronic communications to make possible the abundance of service promised by cable television and other new technologies.

title: Carey Considering Cuite For a Key Post in Cabinet
description: Governor Carey is considering offering the position of Commissioner of General Services to Thomas J. Cuite, the City. Council majority leader.

title: PEACETALK OFFER
description: PARIS, April 2Vietcong officials issued a series of statements here today calling for an uprising against the Saigon Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu and a negotiated end of the fighting.

title: Democrats Tighten Rules on Selection Of Party Delegates
description: TRENTON, April 2 (AP)The state Democratic organization apparently will have tighter control over the selection of the New Jersey delegation to the next national convention under rules announced today.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge:

title: Nets Trounce Sounds To Stay Tied for First
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 2The New York Nets have decided that nobody is going to win the American Basketball Association East title for them, so they routed the Memphis Sounds, 11997, before a crowd of 7,701 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Kaufman & Broad Posts Loss
description: Kaufman and Broad, Inc., the West Coastbased multinational homebuilder, again suffered a deficit in the first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, it was reported yesterday. The company's operations have been affected severely by high moneys costs and reduced demand for housing.

title: American Maize Expanding
Busing Issue Stirs Disputes Upstate
description: BUFFALOI know these people and I know you'll never see their children bused, Joseph Hillery, a member of the Board of Education, was saying the other day. They just won't let it happenthey'll have another Boston first.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: The stock market finished with a small loss yesterday in slightly heavier trading as late selling pressure erased earlier gains.

title: Wisconsin Ponders a Plan for State to Legislate Desegregation of Four Schools in Milwaukee and Suburbs
description: MILWAUKEE, March 29The villages of Shorewood and Whitefish Bay, just north of Milwaukee along Lake Michigan, are typical of the suburbs that ring most of the big cities of the country.

title: Luna22 in Orbit 10 Months
description: MOSCOW, April 2 (UPI)The Soviet space station Luna 22 completed 10 months in orbit around the moon today, Tas, the official press agency said.

title: Contract Awards
description: A fiveyear contract, valued at about $1billion at present prices, has been signed by Ecol, Ltd., a jointlyowned subsidiary of the Ingram Corporation, New Orleans and Northeast Petroleum Industries, Inc., Boston, with Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil company for a significant portion of Ecol's crude oil requirements. Ecol, Ltd., has a 200,000barreladay refinery now under construction in Garyville, La.

title: Police Specialists Credited as Detroit Murders Decline
description: DETROIT, April 2  Last year, in an attempt to lower the highest bigcity homicide Irate in the country, the Detroit police created two handpicked detachments of detectives, named them Squad 6 and Squad 7, and directed them to concentrate on solving and preventing two particularly malevolent types of murder.

title: Fast Action Is Predicted in Albany to Save 35c Fare
description: ALBANY, April 2Swift action on the $100million transit aid package that is needed to save New York City's 35cent transit fare through 1975 was predicted today on both sides of the politically divided Legislature

title: Support for Wallace
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 2Nebraska's Democratic Governor, J. J. Exon, said in an interview that if Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama won the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination, he would support him.

title: Chess:
description: Taking advice is harder than giving it, and although William Hartston gave himself good advice, he didn't follow it. After the publication of his excellent book The Gruenfeld Defense in 197], the British playertheoretican told me, Of course, I won't be able to play this opening for years now.

title: Winnie the Pooh' in Dramatic Form and Other Fun for Children
Iraqis Complete Seizure Of Kurdish Rebel Area
description: KIRKUK, Iraq, April 2Iraqi armored columns, without encountering resistance, have reoccupied the border areas that were seized by the Kurdish rebels a year ago with Iranian support.

title: AMTRAK SETS ORDER FOR 435 NEW CARS
description: Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation that is responsible for the passenger operation of most of the nation's railroads, announced yesterday it had placed orders for 435 new railroad cars.

title: Western Governors Seek a Greater Role in Agriculture and Energy
description: BILLINGS, Mont., April 2The Governors of eight Westem states, suggesting that they have been left out of Federal decisions affecting their region's economic development, demanded from President Ford today a greater voice in policies on agriculture and energy.

title: SURGES OF ACTIVITY IN CICIERSKA DANCES
description: Peggy Cicierska doesn't so much luxuriate in movement as wallow in it, and the difference creatively is that between artistic decision and selfindulgence. She presented new and repertory works Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 3, 1975

title: Music: Meet Moderns
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia's Meet the Moderns series at the Brooklyn Academy of Mimic took a southoftheborder turn on Tuesday, night with a program devoted to works by Julian Orbon (Cuba), Camargo Guarnieri (Brazil), Alberto Ginastera (Argentina) and Carlos Chavez (Mexico).

title: World Chess Leader To Wait Until Today For Fischer's Reply
description: The president of the International Chess Federation decided yesterday in Amsterdam to wait another day before declaring that Bobby Fischer has surrendered his world chess championship by default to Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union.

title: College, School Results
Lisbon's Left Dominates Election Drive
description: LISBON, April 2  Twelve parties, almost all proclaiming, leftist doctrines, began a threeweek campaign today for a constituent assembly whose power to make a new constitution is limited by the armed forces.

title: The Weather Here Last Month
OPEC Weighs Quota On Oil Production Despite Demand Dip
description: VIENNA, April 2 (UPI)Economic experts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries discussed today the possibility of setting production quotas to keep prices up despite decreased demand, OPEC sources reported.

title: Prices Off Sharply On U.S. Securitie??
description: Fears that an escalating Federal deficit will bring high interest rates and a firmer monetary policy before the e?? of the year shook the Government securities market yeste?? day, sending many prices back to their lev?? of late 1974. Our market was in full treat, one dealer said. Statements made Washington by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon we?? an unsettling factor. Treasury coupon issues were hit ?? onepoint losses, an extraordinarily large decline for ?? marketplace. Trading yesterday was an extension of Tues day's price pullback, but the decline yesterday was sharpe.

title: Trade Commissioner Resigns
description: PALM SPRINGS. Calif., April 2 (UPI)President Ford said today that he had accepted with deep regret the resignation of Mayo J. Thompson as head of the Federal Trade Commission. The resignation takes effect Sept. 1. The White House gave no immediate explanation for the resignation.

title: Advertising
description: According to the grandfather clocks in each corner of the Bulova Watch Company's board room it was 11:30, 9:30, 3:00 and 3.45 yesterday morning as officials of the company and Paramount Pictures began their story about the tiein promotion of a new movie about a timeconscious United States marshal who does things with clockwork precision.

title: Energy Agency Criticized On OctanePosting System
description: A Federal Energy Administration regulation requiring the posting of octane ratings on gasoline pumps is not being enforced, the Public Interest Campaign charged yesterday.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Notes on People
description: Inveighing against Zionist demonstrators against him in London, Aleksandr Shelepin visited Scotland yesterday and then flew to Moscow without ever meeting a British equivalent to his own governmental rank as head of Soviet trade unions.

title: It Is Finished
description: BOSTON, April 2The images from Indochina assail us with their misery and horror. The ones from Phnom Penh are in a way the hardest to bear: Those children are starving because of an American blunderrecent, utterly avoidable and prolonged in the teeth of reason.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Investigation Commission has begun an inquiry into the award of a $896,000 contract in 1973 by the city's Department of Highways for demolition of a part the Third Avenue El in the Bronx. This became known when Howard Shapiro, the commission chairman, obtained a showcause order in State Supreme Court to compel a witness to appear at a private hearing at the commission's office, 270 Broadway. The witness, Louis Tuman of 13439 Blossom Avenue, Flushing, Queens, was not otherwise identified. Justice Alfred M. Ascione set a hearing for next Tuesday.

title: Rarely Heard Music for Organ Played by George ThalbenBall
description: It was a discouragingly small but encouragingly enthusiastic audience that welcomed George ThelbenBall on Tuesday night, at the last of the five solo recitals that have helped christen the new Rodgers electronic organ at Carnegie Hall. Although he had not played in New York since 1956, Dr. ThalbenBall is one of the most esteemed organists in Britain. For more than 50 years he has been organist and choirmaster at Temple Church in London.

title: Time for a Knickerbocker Holiday
description: Washington Irving, who at 192 still gives off more New York humor dead than most people do alive, has a birthday today.

title: 10 FOOD SPOTS CITED BY HEALTH AGENCY
description: The Health Department yesterday announced the names of 10 more restaurants and food stores charged with having violated the Health Code.

title: Whitney Museum Sets FreeAdmission Night
description: Admission to the Whitney Museum of American Art, which normally is $1 on weekdays, will be free on Tuesday evenings from 6 to 10 o'clock, starting April 15.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company offered yesterday through underwriters headed by The First Boston Corporation and Drexel, Burnham & Co., 3 million shares of common stock at $18 a share. Net proceeds from the sale, the utility had said, would be used in part to repay shortterm debt.

title: People in Sports
description: Gene Bartow, whose Memphis State basketball team lost to John Wooden's U.C.L.A. team in the National Collegiate final two years ago, won the job as Wooden's successor yesterday. The 64yearold Wooden retired last Monday after capturing his 10th national crown in the last 12 years at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Byrne Asks Repeal Of FairTrade Law
description: TRENTON, April 2Governor Byrne announced today that he would submit to the Legisl??ture next Monday a bill repealing New Jersey's 37yearold Fair Trade Act, which authorizes price fixing on most brandname consumer products sold in the state.

title: HARRY D. HANCOCK
description: Harry D. Hancock, who retired in 1958 as president of the Cities Service Gas Company and as a director of Cities Service Company, the parent concern, died Tuesday at his home 27 Tunstall Road, Scarsdale, N. Y. He was 84 years old.

title: ELLA BOWLES, WROTE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Ella Shannon Bowles, the author of Let Me Show You New Hampshire and other books about her native state, died Friday at a nursing center in Alexandria, Va.

title: She's on the Varsity Because of Her Bat
description: There has been so much interest surrounding the baseball team at St. Mary's High School in Jersey City that the start of the season this week may seem like an anticlimax. The cause for the unusual preseason attention at the Hudson County school was the appearance on the practice diamond of Ann Cortellino, a junior whose hitting and outfielding talents, bolstered by her deep determination to succeed, earned her a reserve's role on the 20player varsity team.

title: Removal of Yearbook's Editor Spurs Vassar Demonstration
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, April 2The removal of the editor of the Vassar College yearbook and the deletion of photographs and other material deemed offensive resulted in a protest demonstration today by 200 students.

title: Stars Subdue Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 2 (AP)  John Roche of Utah scored 15 fourthquarter points tonight and finished with 29 as the Stard subdued an Indiana rally and beat the Pacers, 119112, in an A.B.A. contest.

title: Staten Island. District Attorney Retiring Dec. 31
description: District Attorney John M. Braisted of Staten Island, who will complete 20 continuous years as the county's chief prosecutor this year, announced yesterday that he would not seek a sixth term this fall.

title: U.S. AND CANADA SET MEATQUOTA EASING
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) United States and Canadian agriculture officials agreed today to reduce restrictions on meat trade between the two nations as soon as possible.

title: Moore Retains OneMeter Title
description: CLEVELAND, April 2 (UPI) Tim Moore of Columbus; Ohio, retained the 1meter springboard title tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor diving championships.

title: N.H.L. Battle for Two Playoff Spots
description: REMAINING GAMES
