title: Mobil Announces Finding Of New Alaskan Oil Field
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday the discovcry of a new oil field at Gwydyr Bay South No. 1, about three miles north of the Prudhoe Bay field on Alaska's North Slope.

title: Estimate Board Votes $102Million Proposal to Aid Communities
description: The final application by the city for $102million in Federal Community Development Act funds was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Danish Bank Rate Cut
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 4The Danish bank rate has been cut to 8 per cent from 9, effective Monday, the central bank said today. The rate had been at 9 per cent since Jan. 14, when it was cut by one percentage point.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Already known for its stric discipline, under which long hair and beards are forbidden the Universidad Autonoma d?? Guadalajara has now decrees that Americans cannot take the United States medical boars examinations until they have completed six, semesters at the school.

title: Housing Policeman Indicted
description: A Housing Authority policeman, Stanley Metz, 30 years old, was indicted yesterday on a charge of offering a bribe to another policeman on behalf of a man who had been arrested on a drug charge, according to Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor. The arrested man was identified as Robert Torres, 35, of 35 Jackson Street.

title: 200 Orphans Flown Out By Australian Air Force
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 4 (Reuters)  Australian planes flew more than 200 South Vietnamese war orphans, most of them only a few weeks old and several crippled, out of Saigon tonight en route to new lives with Australian families.

title: Relief Groups Meet on Vietnam Effort
description: Private United States relief agencies operating in Indochina are ready to resume their assistance to civilians if Communist authorities will permit them to work, spokesmen for leading aid agencies said yesterday.

title: Democrats Decide to Push For StateOperated Bank
description: ALBANY, April 4Formation of a state bank to compete with commercial banksa suggestion that was thought to be no more than a tactical threat when state officials believed that banks were too slow in helping the Urban Development Corporationwill be pressed by Democrats in the Legislature.

title: Bomb Blasts a Building 5 Blocks From Ford
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 (AP)A terrorist bomb exploded on the 15th floor of a Standard Oil Company of California office building tonight as President Ford was speaking at a hotel five blocks away, the police said.

title: Earthquake Vietnam
description: Vietnam now has to be seen as an earthquake, not a battlefield; our moral commitment must be to its victims. In this refocusing of vision, there should be a genuine effort to internationalize aid to the peopleincluding those too poor and too helpless to be evacuated. Linked to ancestral lands in South Vietnam and Cambodia, most of Indochina's people will have to remain and adjust to the rhythm of life under changed regimes as they have for centuries.

title: Crash of Galaxy Is Puzzling to Experts
description: Military and civilian aviation experts were deeply puzzled yesterday over reasons for the crash of a United States Air Force cargo plane near Saigon with 243 Vietnamese orphans aboard.

title: Bolivar Use Increased
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 4Several Latin American nations have started to use the Venezuelan Bolivar as part of their foreign exchange reserves because of its growing strength, Alfred Laffee, governor of Venezuelan Central Bank said today.

title: HAROLD J. STEWART, MEDICAL PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Harold J. Stewart, clinical professor emeritus of medicine at Cornell University Medical College and a consultant in medicine at the New York Hospital, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: American Can to Close Plant; Cummins Engine Plans Layoffs
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4 (UP1) The American Can Company announced plans today to close by the end.of the year its Vernon, Calif., canmaking plant, which employs 714 persons.

title: Market Declines for Fifth Straight Day; Dow Average Drops by 4.93 to 747.26
description: The stock market, confronted with the news of another rise in the unemployment rate, finished lower yesterday for the fifth consecutive session.

title: 2 Bobicks Win Bouts In Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. April 4The battling Bobick brothers, Duane and Rodney, posted two more victories for their family before a sparse crowd of 2,436 tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, but only one gained an undisputed triumph.

title: The Cast
description: PIROSMANI, directed by George Shengelaya; screenplay (Russian with English subtitles) by Mr. Shengelaya and Erlom Akhviediani; director of photography, Konstantin Apryatin; editor, M. Karalashvili; music, V. Kukhianidze; produced by Gruzia Film Studio. Running time: 85 minutes. At the Museum of Modern Art, 53d Street, west of Fifth Avenue.

title: A Deep Bitterness Toward U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4It is nice to see you Americans taking home souvenirs of our country as you leave  china elephants and orphans, a South Vietnamese Army lieutenant remarked bitterly today. Too bad some of them broke today, but we have plenty more.

title: Cecilia Mendez, John C. Wallace Are Wed Here
description: Cecilia Mendez, who expects to graduate in June from the Harvard Law School, was married here yesterday morning to John Campbell Wallace of Jakarta, Indonesia. Msgr. Francis X. Mahoney performed the ceremony in the Our Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. He was assisted by the Rev. Michael Gallagher.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD TALK
description: On one side of the street is a McDonald's, where hamburgers and french fries reign supreme. Across the way, it is a different story. There the Olde Grain Mill holds forth, dispensing health foods with a flair for gourmet fare.

title: Women Wary on Title IX
East Germans in Soviet to Lay Pipeline
description: BERLIN, April 4  Several thousand young East Germans are going east this spring to build a large pipeline for natural gas in the Soviet Union.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He's thinking ahead to winning the Indianapolis 500 for the fourth time, but A. J. Foyt also is thinking about tomorrow's Trentonian 200 because he didn't even qualify for the race at the Trenton International Speedway last year. In his annoyance that day at his car breaking down, he kicked the wall. He really was kicking himself. Anthony Joseph Foyt Jr. doesn't make many mistakes. That's why he has won more different types of auto races on more different tracks in more different cars than any driver in history. But at Trenton last year he made a mistake. Not on the track. In the motel bar the night before. He had checked in around midnight and he joined some friends for a beer. Just one, I told myself, but just one turned out to be five or six. He got to bed about 4 o'clock. He had to get up at 7 o'clock. I got up with a headache, he continued in his Texas twang. I don't usually drink since I had hepatitis, that's why I had the headache. In the qualifying, I wasn't as sharp as I should have been, That's why I kicked the wall. I could have said it was the thermostat or the coldweather tires. But deep down I knew it was A. J. Foyt's fault, period. Some guys blame the tires or the car or a little dirt. But when you start lying to yourself, you're in trouble.

title: Ford Acts to Extend to '77 Aid Plan for Unemployed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 4President Ford, responding to the news that unemployment reached 8.7 per cent of the work force in March, said today that he would recommend an extension until the end of 1976 of the emergency benefits program for the unemployed.

title: U. S. Believes No New Weaponry Has Fallen to the Communists
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Defense Department has concluded that none of the United States military equipment lost, to Communist, forces in the latest offensive in South Vietnam is of a sensitive nature, a spokesman said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In an opinion critical of both the trial judge and the prosecutor, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn reversed the conviction of three men on charges of possession of narcotics and ordered a new trial.

title: Methodist Bishops Will Battle Proposed Outlawing of Abortion
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 4Members of the Council of Bishops of the United Methodist Church voted here today to oppose an amendment to the United States Constitution that would outlaw abortion.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Assemblyman Richard F. Visotcky, Democrat of Bergen County, said that as many as 350,000 children up to age 21 could eventually become eligible for the state's disease screening, treatment and prevention program financed by Medicaid. The potential is as high as 350,000, but only about 70,000 are participating right now, the Assemblyman said at the conclusion of a daylong public hearing.

title: Hangar Flying Relives Old Days
description: KINNELONAn echelon of the Smoke Rise Air Force gathered at Lincoln Park Airport recently fo recall a time three decades ago when C46's strained to deliver vital supplies to warravaged China and flying seemed more adventurous and personal than today.

title: CORRECTION
LABEL KATZ DIES; LED B'NAI B'RITH
description: Label A. Katz, former president of the 500,0O0member B'nai B'rith organization and lifelong activist in Jewish affairs, died Thursday at St. Charles General Hospital in New Orleans, where he lived. He was 56 years old.

title: McGOVERN BACKING PALESTINIAN STATE
description: JERUSALEM, April 4 (AP)Senator George McGovern said today that peace in the Middle East could not be achieved unless there was an independent national homeland for the Palestinians.

title: Terry Rhodes Marries Bonita E. Beigel
description: Bonita Edwards Beigel and Terry Rhodes were married yesterday afternoon in Newark. The Rev. Dr. Lloyd George Schell performed the ceremony in the Old First Presbyterian Church.

title: POLICE FIND BODY OF MISSING GIRL, 11
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., April 4The Hudson County Prosecutor's office today identified the nude body of a girl found by the Hackensack River this morning as that of 11yearold Elsa Hall, who disappeared with her 5yearold brother, Robert, two weeks ago, as they were walking to school in Union City.

title: Tatters of Tragedy in a Paddy Field
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 (AP)The huge transport plane lay broken into four main sections, its debris strewn over an area the size of two football fields.

title: Citibank Prime Rate Unchanged at 7%
description: The First National City Bank yesterday kept unchanged at 7 per cent its prime rate on corporate loans.

title: Semper Fidelis Rostow
description: A vigorous military policy can never be a substitute for proper political and economic policies. In fact, no military policy can succeed without a proper political and economic foundation.

title: Celtics Gain Ton Mark
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP)Dave Cowens, playing most of the final period with five personal fouls, hit a jump shot with four seconds remaining tonight and gave the Boston Celtics a 9594 victory over the Washington Bullets in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Nastase Ends Laver Streak
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 4 (Reuters)  Ilie Nastase of Rumania snapped Rod Laver's 25match winning streak today, defeating the Australian, 63, 36, 62, to advance to the semifinals of the $175,000 American Airlines Tennis Games tournament. John Alexander of Australia beat Arthur Ashe, 67, 64, 62.

title: Article 5  No Title
Hsu Leads China Golf
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 4 (AP)Hsu ChiSan of Taiwan posted a fiveunderpar 67 today for a twoday total of 134 and a twostroke lead after two rounds of the $30,000 China open golf tournament.

title: Dr. King's Family Observes 7th Anniversary of Slaying
description: ATLANTA, April 4 (AP) The widow and four children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. placed azaleas on his crypt today, marking the seventh anniversary of his slaying.

title: Antiques: Music Making
description: About 100 collectors, scholars, museum curators and musicians began the fourth annual meeting of the American Musical Instrument Society yesterday in tours here of three distinguished collections.

title: Secretary Will Fill In As Police Director
description: TRENTON, April 4 (UPI)The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association here had new grievance as it entered the latest round of contract negotiations todaya secretary being named temporary Police Safety Director.

title: French, With Gallic Tact, Arrange Oil Seatings Alphabetically
description: PARIS, April 4French officials organizing a preparatory meeting of oil producers and consumers that opens here Monday said today that representatives of Participating nations would sit in alphabetical order of their names in French to avoid chances of confrontation.

title: Only Tokyo Shop to Print in Arabic Triples Staff and Swells Its Earnings
description: TOKYOFor Japan, heavily dependent on imported oil, the quadrupling of the price of oil by exporting nations was a shock that reverberated through the economy.

title: Paper in Soviet Charges U.S. Steps Up Vietnam Interference
description: MOSCOW, April 4A Soviet paper accused the United States today of increasing interference in South Vietnam in violation of the Paris peace agreement.

title: Lloyd Stearman, 76, Dies; Pioneer Plane Designer
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4 (AP) Lloyd Stearman, first president of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and a pioneer aviation designer whose career spanned the era from barstormer to spacecraft, died at his home in Northridge, a Los Angeles suburb, last night after a long battle with cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: A Mooching Dog Lives to Regret It
description: Nobody knows how it happens that this floppyeared mutt comes to be running around on the streets of Troy, New York. He is part terrier, part beagle, part spaniel and nobody knows what all else, and he is nothing but a stray, and a generally goodfornothing stray, at that. Such a dog is not what one would call High Class.

title: Singh, Bombay Duck Picks In Split Big A Fields Today
description: The Gotham, a $50,000 added event for 3yearolds will have its 23d running today at Aqueduct. With 16 named to the onemile contest, the New York Racing Association put up $30,000 more and decided to present the stakes in two divisions. Each section will have a gross value of $46,050, with a winner's share of $27,630.

title: Robert G. Bennett, 62, Led Petroleum Corp. of America
description: Robert G. Bennett, president and chief executive of the Petroleum Corporation of America, a closedend investment company, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.

title: Thieu Shifts Cabinet And Criticizes U. S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4President Nguyen Van Thieu named a new Premier tonight to head a government of war and national union and said that that Government intended to defend the country's remaining territory against the Communists.

title: Drifter Guilty in Beating
description: MIAMI, April 4 (AP)A drifter accused of beating a British tourist, Helen Evans, nearly to death in a downtown bus station restrom has been found sane by a jury and convicted on three charges stemming from the beating. Glenn Battle, 22 years old of Detroit, was convicted late yesterday by a Circuit Court jury of robbery, assault with intent to commit rape and aggravated battery.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MOVEABLE FEAST Families who won't be making a circus pilgrimage to Madison Square Garden this year can get a free look by heading for Central Park today and what is reportedly the first fullscale circus parade through the area. Plans call for a generous sampling of Ringling Bros, and Barnum & Bailey, with a procession of elephants, caged lions and tigers, camels, horses, acrobats, clowns and showgirls.

title: WITNESSES ASSAIL MENTAL CARE HERE
description: I State legislators investigating the shortcomings of New York's mentalhealthcare system heard testimony yesterday that patients in private, profitmaking neighborhood homes had re ceived inadequate care and disrupted the surrounding communities.

title: Makers of Survival Foods Cater to a Growing National Anxiety
description: ATLANTA  Ronald G. Whipple, founder and president of Dixie Beehive Foods, one of the leading marketers of socalled survival food, does not like to think of himself as a prophet of doom.

title: At Oaklawn Park...
description: Promised City heads the field of 3yearold colts and geldings in 39th running of the $100,000 added Arkansas Derby. The Big I Farms colt will carry top weight of 126 pounds. There are 13 other entries.

title: $220Million Is Offered To Pasco for Oil Land
description: Pasco, Inc., said yesterday it had received an oral offer of $220million in cash for its oilproducing properties in Wyoming. The offer reportedly came, from a major unidentilied United States Corporation. lied United States Corporation.

title: MICHAEL DEFILLIPIS
description: MILFORD, Mass., April 4 (AP)Prof. Michael DeFillipis, who retired in 1957 as chairman of the Romance languages department at the University of California at Berkeley, died yesterday at the home of his sister, Mrs. Michael Colavita. He was 84 years old.

title: High Tides Around New York
Rival Unions Fail to Form Joint Slate For the School Board in District 5
description: An attempt to put together a compromise slate of community school board candidates backed by both the United Federation of Teachers and District Council 37 of the leading municipal workers union here has failed in District 5 in Central Harlem.

title: Teams Here Create TV Playoff Muddle
description: While the Knicks may be playing at Houston, or maybe even Madison Square Garden, the Rangers may be at Pittsburgh, or perhaps Nassau Coliseum, while the Nets are at St. Louis and the Islanders are at Vancouver.

title: Notes on People
description: The Order of the Rising Sun, first class, will be conferred on J. W. Fulbright when he goes to Japan on April 12. The Japanese Government announced yesterday that Mr. Fulbright, former Democratic Senator from Arkansas and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, would be decorated for two reasons: the Fullbright Scholarships, a federally funded academic exchange program he introduced, and his efforts toward the return of Okinawa to Japan.

title: 3 Held in Slayings
Article 2  No Title
description: From 1932 until his retirement in 1961 Dr. Stewart was chief of the division of cardiology in the department of medicine at the college, an attending physician at the New York Hospital and director of its heart station.

title: Chad's President Orders Arrest of Military Officials
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 4 (Agence FrancePresse)President Ngarta Tombalbaye's military adviser and both the commander and deputy commander of the national police have been arrested on the President's orders, it was officially announced here last night.

title: JURY IS IN RECESS ON ATTICA KILLING
description: BUFFALO, April 4The jury in the Attica murder trial receased late tonight after deliberating for a second day without being able to reach a verdict. The jurors were seguestered for th night and asked to resume at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow

title: Park Cautions South Koreans Dissension Invites Aggression
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 4President Park Chung Hee told South Koreans today that political troubles at home might tempt the North Korean Communists to initiate hostilities against the South as they did in 1950.

title: Briton Finds 13 Is Lucky
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4Is number 13 unlucky? Not for Virginia. Wade. With her 12match winning streak trembling in the balance, the Briton took six games running last night and won from Julie Heldman, 67, 62, 75, in the Virginia Slims championship tournament.

title: U.S. Military Men Doubt Saigon Turnaround
description: United States military sources say that the North Vietnamese have almost completed preparations for the final battle in the Saigon area and that they doubt strongly that the Saigon garrison has sufficient troops or weapons to launch a spoiling attack that could seriously interfere with the northerners' operational plans.

title: Minnesota Judges and Lawyers Get Orders on Refresher Study
description: ST. PAUL, April 4The Min nesota Supreme Court issued today an order that will require most of the state's active lawyers and judges to take 45 hours of legal refresher courses every three years.

title: Contract Awards
Tables on the Effects Of New Tax Schedules
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Following are tables illustrating the effect on weekly takehome pay of the new Federal withholding tax rates due to go into effect April 30. The tables presuppose that wage earners take all the withholding allowances to which they are entitled and that persons earning more than $15,000 a year take itemized deductions amounting to 17 per cent of their income.

title: HORIZON SECURITIES PENALIZED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (ReuIters)The Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the brokerdealer registration of Horizon Securities, Inc., of New York.

title: Operator Shortage Curbs Telephone Calls to Saigon
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it could put through only an average of 60 to 80 telephone calls daily to Saigon because of a shortage of operators in the South Vietnamese papital.

title: STATE HALTS BID BY NURSING HOME
description: The State Public Health Council rejected the application for a change of ownership by a Brooklyn nursing home represented by State Senator John J. Marchi.

title: Thieu Shifts Cabinet And Criticizes U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4President Nguyen Van Thieu named a new Premier tonight to head a government of war and national union and said that that Government intended to defend the country's remaining territory against the Communists.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed lower yesterday.

title: In Era of Urban Decline, One City Rises: Phoenix
description: PHOENIXAs cities go, Phoenix has gone far and wide. It has grown in the last 30 years from a modest desert outpost of 17 square miles and 45,000 people into a metropolitan giant of 248 square miles and 750,000 people.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Pacific Lighting Corporation yesterday said it had registered wtih the Securities and Exchange Commissoin 2.5 million common shares for public sale through underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Company. As previously announced by the utility holding company, net proceeds will be used to fund advances and to provide capital contributions to operating subsidiaries.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 8.7% IN MARCH, HIGHTEST SINCE '41
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Unemployment rose substantially in March to 8.7 per cent of the labor force, and the number of discouraged workers who have dropped out of the labor force altogether reached a record of 1.1 million, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Books of The Times
description: Harold Macmillan, the most gifted author to occupy No. 10 Downing Street since Sir Winston's departure, once remarked that as he grew older he found the raw material of historyletters, diaries, dispatchesmore rewarding than the finished product.

title: The Giddiness of FirstTime London
description: ON this Wednesday, Sept. 25, I am a vision in suede. Suedepaneled pantsuit, suede luggage, suede shoes and trenchcoat. It looks like Halston moved in with me two weeks ago to coordinate my trip. The couture traveler. Except that my fly is open and I have forgotten how to tie shoelaces or buckle belts. At the advanced age of 25, I am making my first trip to Europe. So who's nervous?

title: Life in Saigon: A Sudden Sense of Doom
description: SAIGONThe restaurants, pool halls and movie houses are open. The women on Cong Ly still crouch on the pavement and sell dishes of steaming noodles at lunchtime. By dusk, with the air choking and the Lambrettes and trucks packing the streets, the shops begin closing and the tensions of the day seem to absorb the city.

title: Auto Engine Fries Eggs
description: FARMER CITY, Ill (AP)A mechanic who was giving a 1,000mile check to a Germanmade car found a bird's nest complete with two eggs in the engine. The small speckled eggs were thoroughly baked by the engine heat. I just can't imagine how they got there, said Mrs. Larry Lamb, the car's owner.

title: The Bicentennial Guide to the American Revolution
description: The celebration of the nation's Bicentennial, one hopes, will enlarge and enrich the average American citizen's knowledge and understanding of his Revolutionary beginnings. There is no better place to begin than with the sites and scenes that survive. And one would be hard put to find more companionable, entertaining and useful guidebooks than these three attractive volumes, available in both hardcover and paperback editions.

title: Harvard's Eight Wins On Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, April 5 (UPI) Harvard took the gold medal and dethroned the University of Washington in the varsity eightoared event today on Mission Bay. The Crimson's time was 6 minutes 14.6 seconds.

title: Lee Elder Prepares for His First Masters Tourney
description: The one thing on my mind this past rear is the fact of be being at Augusta, something I've wanted quite some time. I think I made it clear, when I first came on the tour, that I would be happy to qualify for the Masters. But I wanted to qualify on my own merit, I didn't want anyone giving me a special invitation.

title: Nastase Acts Up, Defeats Rosewall
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 5The record will show that Ilie Nastase defeated Ken Rosewall, 36, 75, 62, today and moved into the final of the $150,000 American Airlines Tennis Games tomorrow against John Alexander, who upset John Newcombe, 62, 62. They will play for a 530.000 first prize.

title: Puerto Ricans List Priorities
description: TRENTON  The State Board of Education is not the only organization trying to decide what constitutes a thorough and efficient education for New Jersey children. So is the Puerto Rican Congress of New Jersey.

title: JOSEPHINE ANDERSON
description: Josephine David Anderson, a former insurance broker and the mother of David Anderson, a sports columnist for The New York Times, died Friday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 7100 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn.

title: NUCLEAR TEST CITED IN TUMOR OUTBREAK
description: SUVA, Fiji Islands, April 5 (UPI)Since the American hydrogen bomb test of 1954, 16 of 17 children born on the island of Rongelap in the Pacific have had surgery for thyroid tumors, Micronesian delegates to a Pacific nuclear congress have charged.

title: Who's Hair Apparent Is a King
description: Alan L. Emlen, a New Yorker, provides the following 1879 letter to his greatgrandfather, a Quaker of local note in Philadelphia who had the rare distinction of being cleanshaven. Mr. Emlen explains: His greatgreatgrandson, fulsome of beard, is making my life miserable by the disclosure of this letter and I would be happy to have some other fathers share my grief.

title: Peter Wibell Jr. to Marry Joan Cotter
description: Joan Street Cotter, an actress and drama teacher at the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, and Peter Oke V. Wibell Jr., a state disability examiner, plan to marry in July.

title: A LAG IN SURGERY LAID TO RECESSION
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15 (AP)People have begun to postpone surgery because of the recession, and hospitals are now functioning 10 to 20 per cent below their usual levels, according to a survey conducted by a private research organization.

title: BAKER IN WARNING ON BUDGET DEFICIT
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5 A $100million deficit in the Federal budget will create a difficult situation for business next year, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said here today. Congress must exercise restraint, he said, even though an expected increase in the gross national product may ease the situation by creating a broader tax base.

title: Author's Query
description: For a book on the subject of predatory animals I should like to hear from readers who have knowledge of, and opinions about the coyote, wolf, mountain lion, bobcat, bear (polar, grizzly and black) and golden eagle; control programs aimed at these animals; and sports or trophy hunting of them. It would he helpful if respondents would indicate their approximate age, occupation and whether or not they are willing to be quoted. FRANCOIS LEYDET

title: The Day of Decision Arrives for Knicks
description: I never figured it would come down to this, said Walt Frazier. I figured by this time we'd be either in the playoffs or out of them.

title: Pappy Seaman, Now 92, Still Active in Designing
description: Harold L. (Pappy) Seaman shuffled through the papers on his drawing board and whipped out the plans for the Fox. Before there were naval architects, fiberglass boats, even pleasure boats, Pappy Seaman was designing and building the Sea Bright, N. J., fishing skiffs as had all the Seamans since his great grandfather built the first in 1841. At the age of 92, Pappy Seaman, the father of the Jersey speed skiff, is still at the drawing board in his Oceanport, N. J., home. With a swift, steady hand, he works on the precise drawings of a 28foot trailable sailboat, the kind of boat he'd like to be building if he still had a yard.

title: Horse Is Identified by Growths on Its Legs
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, April 5A Colorado man has been given a 90day jail sentence here after pleading guilty to perjury in a horse theft case that, according to Federal Government and private veterinarians, marks the first time that callous growths submitted in evidence were the deciding identifying factor in determining the animal's owner.

title: Program On Housing For Cities Is Assailed
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's Urban  Renewal Assistance Program was charged last week with having failed to initiate new housing in the state's blighted cities and with burdening the cities with large debts by having failed to attract sufficient Federal funds.

title: Hanoi Victories Gained Without Using Air Power
description: North Vietnam's armies have won major victories in the last three weeks, according to United States military analysts, without once employing air power. The Communist offensive, still moving without any air support, expanded yesterday into intensified fighting in the Mekong Delta, where the .North apparently hopes to sever communications between that ricegrowing area and Saigon. Mounting pressure was also reported against the outer defenses of the capital.

title: Music: Monteux Tribute
description: The 100th anniversary of the birth of Pierre Monteux, the French conductor, was commemorated at Carnegie Hall on Friday night by the Hudson Valley Philharmonic, which is led by the late conductor's son, Claude.

title: Article 9  No Title
Article 2  No Title
Dayton Bowlers in Lead
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 5 (UPI)A team from Dayton shook up the American Bowling Congress tournament standings today. Members of the Big O Realty team captured the regular singles lead, the regular doubles lead and the team allevents lead.

title: A Single Finds Suburbs Maligned
description: SELDEN, L. I.It has been more than a year now since I gave up the life of a citydwelling single to become a suburban bachelor here in eastern Long Island.

title: Music Notes: Where Young Opera Singers Get the Works
description: If you're a young singer with an important audition prize or two in your pocket but only a hazy idea of what's really in store for you as a professional opera performer, what do you do? The question is one that frequently bothers conductors, directors and educators, and now three of themone from. each profession, more or less have organized a program that takes the matter in hand. The Berkshire Music Center announces that in the summer of 1976 it will inaugurate an Opera Fellowship Program under the guidance of Nathaniel Merrill, the stage director who currently divides his time between the Metropolitan (Les Troyens, Die Meistersinger) and the Opera du Rhin in Strasbourg, where he is principal producer.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Davis Is Winner In Pro Bowling
description: MILWAUKEE, April 5 (AP) Dave Davis of Atlanta stepped back among the Professional Bowlers Association stars today, defeating Earl Anthony, the tour's leading moneywinner, 206187, in the $80,000 Miller open event.

title: Regina Resnik Is Wed To an ArtistSculptor
description: PAWLING, N.Y., April 5 (UPI)Regina Resnik, the Metropolitan Opera star whose portrait in the role of Carmen was painted by Arbit Blatas, an artistsculptor, was married to him here today in a civil ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The New York Times last Sunday, the pictures accompanying the engagement of Deborah Georgia Belury to Thomas Graham Ridgely Kastendike and the marriage of Susan Mae Hubble to Samuel Humes Ballam 3d were transnosed.

title: Zionist Groups Bid Ford Affirm Support for Israel
description: Leaders of Zionist groups called on the Ford Administration yesterday to reaffirm support of Israel as the only democratic nation in the Middle East.

title: Miss Richards Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Richards of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Andrews Richards, to Daniel Graham McKay, son of Dr. and Mrs. R. James McKay Jr. of Williston, Vt.

title: SAIGON SOLDIERS HIJACK U.S SHIP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5Armed South Vietnamese troops being sent by Saigon authorities to a penal island off the country's coast aboard an American ship mutinied yesterday, hijacked the ship and forced it to proceed to the port of Vung Tau, it was learned tonight from South Vietnamese military sources.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, April 6

title: MRS. PERON SEEKS SUPPORT OF LABOR
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 5President Isabel Martinez de Perlin emerged during the last week from her isolation and began efforts to consolidate support within the Peronist movement.

title: Spring Arrives In the Apartment Window Garden
description: Spring has come to our apartment window garden. For two weeks, our crinum has held flamboyant stage center. A member of the amaryllis family, this prima donna, unlike more common house plants, blooms only once a year and briefly.

title: Pacers Take Playoff Opener
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 5 (AP)Lenny Elmore drilled in 10 points during a fiveminute overtime period tonight to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 122119 victory over the San Antonio Spurs in an American Basketball Association playoff game.

title: Dayle Snyder Wed To Lieutenant Boyd
description: Dayle Smith Snyder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Smith of Brielle, N.J., and Lieut. William L. Boyd, U.S.N, son of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar L. Boyd Jr. of Waynesboro, Va.. were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents by Monmouth County Judge William T. Wichmann.

title: Fantasy in American Art Is Shown
description: Visions and Fantasy in American Painting at the Brooklyn Museum is a rebuttal to all those students of American art pragmatic see our painting as a pragmatic esthetic enterprise. We have in this show more than sufficient evidence that even around the turn of the century American painters were responsible for some wild flights of fancy.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Once again, a somewhat unsettling ambiguity surrounds a photography exhibit at The Museum of Modern Art. Just what are those hauntingly beautiful pictures in the third floor photography gallery supposed to represent?

title: Princeton's Eight Takes Logg Cup
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 5 The Princeton heavyweight crew sprinted past Rutgers near the finish and won the eighth annual Logg Cup competition today on Lake Carnegie.

title: Jersey City Water Is Costly
description: JERSEY CITYThe gray hulk of the rotting rowboat, the battered red brick of the vandalized filtration house and the general downattheheels condition of the two reservoirs on Summit Avenue here help to, explain, as concretely as anything else, why Jersey City is about to increase its water rates by 200 per cent or more.

title: 6 Killed and 40 Hurt In Bomb Explosions In TWQ Belfast Bars
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 5  Six people were killed today, four Protestants and two Roman Catholics, in two bomb explosions in Belfast bars.

title: Elderly Widow Slain in Clinton Hills
description: Perhaps someone thought Fannie Todd Speers was rich, a shipbuilding heiress.

description: ART

title: DoItYourself Carpets
description: Although there are still may home improvement and repair jobs that are beyond the scope of the average doityourselfer, the number of tasks requiring professional help keeps diminishing steadily as homeowners and apartment dwellers gain more and more experience and confidenceand as manufacturers, is recognition of this trend, continue to introduce new products which are specifically designed for doityourselfers.

title: Chiang Kaishek Is Dead in Taipei at 87; Last of Allied Big Four of World War II
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sunday, April 6Chiang Kaishek, the President of Nationalist China and the last survivor of the Big Four Allied leaders of World War II, died of a heart attack here last night. He was 87 years old.

title: A Quarter Of Poetry
description: There is something of the letter, as Emily Dickinson and Thoreau knew, about every book sent out into a silent world. Reading the books of poetry published during one quarter of a given year is like opening the mailbox daily to a flood of letters, impassioned, reticent, wry, awkward, pompous, timid, arrogant, cheerful, touching, gifted, even stunning. It is everyone's Hope to open one of these letters and feel like George Keats in Kentucky getting the ode To Autumn in the mail. Sometimes, in the society of so many books, I feel pressed in on by too many voices, each, like the Ancient Mariner, with strange power of speech, until I recall What a pitifully small fraction of all lived life is written down, how mutely most life goes to the grave. And then these poems seem precious shards, as Adrienne Rich once said in a poem, full of pathosa fragment here, a glimpse there, a breath escaped from the tomb.

title: U.S. Farming School Is Still Flourishing in Greece
description: SALONIKA, GreeceIt is a bit surprising to shop in a Greek store and find eggs labeled American Farm School. At a time when many Greeks would like to throw eggs at Americans, the school remains a flourishing example of cooperation between the United States and Greece.

title: A Lowly Doggy Bag Is Lowly No Longer
description: Mrs. Post isn't kidding. She approves them officially on page 177 of The New Emily Post's Etiquette, which comes out this month. And she approves them advisedly because there are certain limitsyou should not take home meat that's been slopping around in gravy.

title: ILLEGAL TAPPING IN HOUSTON CITED
description: HOUSTON, April 5  The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company assisted the Houston Police Department in tapping telephone conversations, Police Chief Carol Lynn says.

title: SUBWAY RIDERSHIP LOWEST SINCE '18; OFF 20% IN DECADE
description: Subway ridership in the city has plunged to the lowest level since 1918, when the city had 2.5 million fewer residents.

title: Islip Man Named County Realty Chief
description: HAUPPAUGE (UPI)  An assistant town attorney in Islip has been named by County Executive John V. N. Klein to serve as head of the county's new Real Property Department.

description: In the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church here at noon yesterday, Shelby Isabel Schoonmaker, daughter of Mrs. John D. Schoonmaker Jr'f Kingston and Claryvile, N. Y., was married to Charles P. Werner, son of ME and Mrs. Carlton B. Werner of Orange, N. J.

title: Kissinger Has No Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 State Department officials said today that there were no plans for Secretary Kissinger to make a new diplomatic shuttle in the Middle East following the collapse of his efforts to work out a new EgyptianIsraeli accord.

title: Princeton Awaits a Graham Ballet
description: PRINCETON This ivyclad community will become akind of moderndance capital Wednesday night.

title: Goodby to Stony Crick
description: Chicago has not enjoyed a good press since the days of Carl Sandburg. That city has come in for a beating in Wigwam in the City, The Mimosa Tree and now GoodBy to Stony Crick. All three deal with rural families, who come looking for jobs and a better way of life.

title: Frenzied Bluefish Hurt 3 Miami Beach Bathers
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 5 (UPI)Thousands of eightto12pound bluefish swarmed near the beach in a feeding frenzy here today, injuring three persons.

title: Mann Symposium Is Slated at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A symposium on Thomas Mann and his works will be held at Rutgers University Thursday through Saturday. Sponsors of the program are the university's Graduate Division of German and Goethe House of New York.

title: Grow Soybeans For Protein
description: As hunger stalks the world, the lowly soybean offers part of the solution. And, like it or not, this fact is slowly changing our eating habits.

title: Rangers and Islanders:
description: For the New York Rangers, the season's story was not so much a matter of making the National Hockey League playoffs but rather of struggling to be in a high qualifying position once they got there. From the moment the schedule began last October, the Rangers were consigned a firstor secondplace finish in the Patrick Division on the strength of eight consecutive years in at least one round of the Stanley Cup championship series. The only question, most experts figured, was whether or not they could oust the champion Philadelphia Flyers from the top spot.

title: A Rare Look At How People Lived in Medieval Times
description: The new exhibition at The Metropolitan Museum of Art's branch for medieval art in Fort Tryon Park is called The Secular Spirit: Life and Art at the End of the Middle Ages. Shakespeare, slightly edited, supplies the best advice I can give concerning this event: Get thee to The Cloisters, go, and quickly too.

title: FORD MEETS JET FLYING CHILDREN OUT OF VIETNAM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5President Ford boarded a chartered plane that brought 325 South Vietnamese children to the United States tonight and carried an infant girl from the jumbo jet. They were among 900 flown from Saigon by United States planes today.

title: A LAG IN SURGERY LAID TO RECESSION
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15 (AP)People have begun to postpone surgery because of the recession, and hospitals are now functioning 10 to 20 per cent below their usual levels, according to a survey conducted by a private research organization.

title: Nuptials for Lillian Roecker in Queens
description: Lillian Els Roecker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur J. Roecker of Forest Hills, Queens, and. B. Edward Brannon, son of Mrs. Willard Hayes of Santa Ana, Calif., and Bennie B. Brannon of Fullerton, Calif., were Married yesterday morning by the Rev. M. Joseph Farley, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Forest Hills.

title: Susan Rommel Wed to Charles Haire Jr.
description: Susan Evelyn Rommel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Rommel of New Hyde Park, L. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Charles Cusick Haire Jr., son of Mrs. Mary A. Haire of Larchmont and the late Charles Cusick Haire.

title: OFFDUTY DETECTIVE IS WOUNDED IN BRONX
description: An offduty police detective was shot twice early today as he sought to question two men standing outside a liquor store on a busy commercial intersection in the Union Port section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Verona, a city of 175,000 between Milan and Venice, here is this season's schedule of performances at the area: Carmen July 12, 17, 20, 25, 29; Aug. 2, 7, 10, 14, 17; La Forza del Destino July 13, 19, 24, 27, Aug. 1, 5, 9, 13, 16; Turandot July 26, 31, Aug. 3, 8, 12, 15, 22. The ballet will be given on Aug. 23, 24 and 26. Tickets range in price from about $5 to $25.

title: Cambodian Refugees Flee Camps as the War Nears
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 5The refugee camp on Route 5, about five miles north of Phnom Penh, was bustling less than a week ago with more than 10,000 persons. Today it was a ghost town.

title: And a Surplus, Too
description: CHICAGOTo the astonishment of the professional politicians in the Illinois Legislature. Gov. Dan Walker recently admitted publicly that he had made some mistakes during his first two years in office.

title: Central Park to Have Circus Parade at Noon
description: What is heralded as the first fullscale circus parade to be held in Central Park will get under way at noon today at Columbus Circle and 59th Street.

title: Correction
High Drama Downriver: The Whitewater Derbies of the Northeast
description: TWO men emerge from a pickup camper parked along the river and walk up the road. They wear red plastic helmets, orange life jackets, sneakers and black, tightfitting wet suits that cover limbs and torso like suit of chain mail. A 10inchwide black strip of rubber dangies taillike from the rear of one man's upper suit, flopping between his knees as he strides up the road. The men strut. They gesture. They talk loudly of their eagerness to start. But their cockiness is comically altered by their attire; these whitewater racers seem a curious combination of beaver, space and medieval knight.

title: Burlington: History Is Relived
description: BURLINGTON  In 1687, the Quaker proprietors of West Jersey created the Council of Proprietors of the Western Division of New Jersey for the purpose of overseeing the distribution of land to individual colonists.

title: HOW IT REALLY WAS
description: In 1940, fully seven years after the Depression had sounded its greatest depth and when the New Deal had run its course, unemployment in the United States was higherfar higherthan it is today. With war industries already gearing up in support of Western Europe, more than eight million Americans were still out of work, or 14.6 per cent of what was then the civilian labor force. Indeed, in the best year of the Depression decade, the figure was never less than 14.3 per cent, compared with the 8.2 per cent reached this January.

title: U.S. Rulings Will Affect Rents
description: WASHINGTON New Jersey is one of the states significantly affected by new Federal regulations designed to give the Government a greater role in determining the rents charged in possibly tens of thousands of privately owned apartments in various parts of the country.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market finished sharply lower last week as depressing economic and international news flowed in. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 23 points in the week to 747.26.

title: Legislature: Focus on Tax Vote
description: TRENTON  The Legislature will reconvene here tomorrow after a month's recess, and the Democratic majorities in both houses have vowed to vote on an income tax by the end of April.

title: Jumping to Conclusions
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) Raised hands do not necessarily mean a holdup. Police officers saw from outside customers at O'Rourke's bar holding up their hands and rushed in, guns ready. It turned out that they were members of a social club and were swearing in new officers.

title: Wayne State Is Fencing Victor
description: FULLERTON, Calif., April 5 (UPI)With Greg Benko and Uri Rabinovich capturing individual titles, Wayne State of Detroit won the National Collegiate Fencing Championship today with 89 points.

title: Singh, Laramie Trail Score
description: Singh strengthened his status as one of the leading contenders for the Kentucky Derby by winning the second section of the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Cynthia Phipps's colt took the onemile event by 2 lengths over Round Stake, with Mr. Duds third in the field of eight.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The art of mime is the art of dramatic expression freed from both the beautiful tyranny of words and the gorgeous suggestiveness of music. It lacks the specifics and the sustained argument of the theater, and it lacks the musical architecture of dance. What it has is something very pure. It is the silent image of nature distilled into an art form.

title: Princeton Rallies to Help World Hungry
description: PRINCETONResidents of this town, responding to an effort spearheaded by its religious leaders, are paring their diets and holding fund drives in a move designed to help alleviate what is seen as a growing famine in the world's underdeveloped nations.

title: Hanoi Reports Offer of Aid By U.N. to Vietcong Areas
description: TOKYO, Sunday, April 6 (AP)A Hanoi radio broadcast monitored here today said that the United Nations Children's Fund has promised $4million in emergency aid for war victims in areas of South Vietnam captured by the Vietcong.

description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Earthquake Hits Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 5 (UPI)strong earthquake struck a cluster of cities in western Venezuela today, killing two persons and injuring scores of others. The cities of Barquisimeto, Carora and Churuguara were hit by the quake.

title: Zarb Is Planning to Order Some Utilities to Burn Coal
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Th'e Federal Energy Administrator Frank G. Zarb, said today that he planned soon to order some of the nation's electric power plants to burn coal instead of oil.

title: Patricia Moore Wed to C. R. Williams
description: In the Greenville Country Club in Wilmington, Del., yesterday afternoon, Patricia Jean Moore was married to C. Ronald Williams. The Rev. Samuel H. Magill performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Storm Washes Away Mysterious Substance on South Shore Beaches
description: Recent stormy weather has Apparently eliminated most, if not all, of an unidentified brownishblack deposit along several miles of Long Island's South Shore beaches between Coney Island and Long Beach.

title: Northport's Folk Art Put on Display
description: NORTHPORTLast summer the Northport Historical Society was still operating out of paper bags and private homes, according to its president, Henrietta Van Siclen. Today, the 13yearold society has an ivycovered Tudor brick home at 215 Main Street, and a fullfledged historical museum about to open its second exhibition.

title: Judith Watson Is Bride
A Speculative Poet of The Piano
description: My memories of Alfred Brendel date back more than a decade. In the spring of 1964 I was part of an avid audience that filled the Hunter College Recital Hall for a performance by a pianist whose reputation promised an artist of the absolute first water. Playing a program of 19thcentury mastersBeethoven, Schubert and LisztBrendel did not disappoint. His readings revealed a sensibility that wed poetic speculation with the intellectual demands of the scores before him. Shortly thereafter a wonderfully limpid and alert recording of Mozart's Eflat Concerto, K. 271, reinforced one's first impression that Brendel was an artist of uncommon insight.

title: ENGINEERS' GROUP ADDS 86 MEMBERS
description: Eightysix American engineers have been elected to membership in the National Academy of Engineering, a private organization established in 1964 to encourage engineering research and undertake technological studies for the Federal Government.

title: He Solicits Dissident Views, But His Mind Is Not Entirely Open
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.Gerald R. Ford, the accidental President, has had more opportunity than he could wish for in the last few weeks to demonstrate his style in decisionmaking when it counts, under the pressure of major events and issues.

title: Melissa I. Cully, William Mueller Marry on Coast
description: Melissa Iris Cully, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Kendig Brubaker Cully of White River Junction, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. William Kendall Mueller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence William Mueller of Fort Wayne. Ind.

title: An OutofTown Sports Fan's Dilemma: Communications Gap
description: Rooting for an outoftown team like trying to maintain a relationship with a girl friend who's away at college. You see her on occasional visits home, you get letters and you talk on the phone, but it isn't the same.

title: The Great Rain Robbery
description: As a child I would have adored David Levine's cartoons for their vigor and wit, but mostly for what they would have taught me about drawing. I've gone to Levine's book Caricatures many a time to free my mind of a fixed visual perception or learn how to crosshatch a certain facial plane.

title: Notes: All Aboard for Switzerland or Miami
description: THE allbutuniversal dream of running a locomotive is suddenly within reach. Only two problems: You have to go to Switzerland to do it, and the price tag is $1,315. For those content just to ride a train, not run it, there is some good news, too. Amtrak is putting in a $99 roundtrip excursion fare to Florida. The Swiss deal first:

title: Four Minicourses Added by College
description: EDISONThe Division of Continuing Education at Middlesex County College has added four minicourses to its schedule of such studies. The courses have no requirements, and neither grades nor examinations are given. Fees begin at $10.

title: Endpaper
description: While a lot of attention will be paid to the official opening of the baseball season tomorrow, of more than passing interest is the unofficial, but equally important, opening of the baseballcard season. The competitive flipping of baseball cards is a great, honorableand nationalpastime that began simultaneously with the publication of the earliest baseball cardsas nearly as can be ascertained, about 1909with Talk of the Diamond cards. It flourished through the 1915 Crackerjacks series, the nineteenthirties' Goudey and Bowman bubblegum sets, and reached glorious fruition with the bubblegum cards of Fleers and Topps in the forties and fifties. Kidsboth boys and girlsare still flipping today. Baseball cards are flipped not only in metropolitan New Yorkwhere flipping is high artbut in Boston; Chicago and Los Angeles and in the suburbs of America as well. This great American game is pervasive, but also largely unheraldeda situation that this Guide will attempt to remedy. Herewith a brief description of some of the rules, the techniques and the of The Game.

title: Union Official Is Honored
description: Murray H. Finley, the general president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, was honored last night for his activities in behalf of Histadrut, the national committee for Israeli labor. About 1,000 business and union leaders attended the testimonial ??nner in the Commodore Hotel.

title: INVESTING
description: The spectacular price advance scored by stocks in recent months may be signaling something other than a traditional postbearmarket rally. It could reflect the changing nature of the market itself as exemplified by increasingly sharp and rapid movements that occur without warning.

title: Overbee Excels in 2 Relays
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 5Bill Overbee ran the anchor leg on the 440yard event and the opening leg on the 880 today to help the New York Pioneers score a pair of victories in the third Post College Relays.

title: The Guest Word
description: Jim Wellington, otherwise known as The Iron Duke, who came out of the west to run the mile for Harvard and the 1500 meter for the U.S.A. at the Berlin Olympics of 1936; The Kid from Tomkinsville, who lost his pitching arm but came back to be a great outfielder for the Dodgers instead; The Keystone Kids, up from the bush leagues and one of them becoming playermanager of those same Dodgers in his second bigleague season; Don Somethingorother, who coached his team all the way to the finals of the Indiana state basketball tournament in Yea! Wildcats! only to lose.

title: The Last Laugh
description: The writers on the old Sid Caesar show are struggling to come up with an odd occupation for a character. Nothing. Suddenly a resident loudmouth named Mel Brooks erupts: He shouts prayers to crashing pilots.

title: Tax Plan Stirs Hope And a Bit of Dismay
description: Amid some expressions of disappoinment, the building industry across the country welcomed the tax law that went into effect last week as a shortterm boon to buyers of new homes.

title: 3 Take Oral Test for Chief Medical Examiner Here
description: In the first open competitive test for Chief Medical Examiner of the city in almost 60 years, three physicians who passed the written examination in January were tested orally yesterday by a panel of five forsensic pathologists.

title: The Superpower Copout
description: PARISNo nation can pretend to be a superpower when its foreign policy suffers such blows as that of the United States in Southeast and Southwest Asia, when its economy reels, its unemployment zooms, its currency staggers, and when its leadership, symbolized by a Chief Executive who chooses that moment to take time off for golf, faces its crises in paralyzed confusion.

title: ART VIEW
description: Once upon a time there were people who thought nothing of still life. Its role in art seemed to them auxiliary and subordinate. It spoke for lack of ambition, a humdrum turn of mind and a readiness to settle for what was dullest and most inert in the world around them. Real painting had to do with the truths of Christianity, with decisive events in history, with the look of kings and queens and potentates and with that glorious world of fantasy that had come down to us from the Greek and Latin poets.and from their successors in Italy and France. Imagination was all, in such cases, and the painter was by definition a poet. Still life in relation to these activities was no more than simian mimicry.

title: Mary E. Pollin Wed to Officer
description: Mary Elizabeth Pollin, daughter of Col. Jack Murphy Pollin, U.S.A., and Mrs. Polka of West Point, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Robert Wayne Richards, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Glenn Richards of Magnolia, Ark.

title: Drug Centers Form New Organization
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 5Seven of the nation's drug abuse treatment centers organized yesterday in a consortium to prepare for what they foresee as a coming epidemic in drug, use in the face of a decreasing umount of Federal money to cope with the treatment.

title: Sketches by a Roving Artist Record History
description: William R. Johnston, an itinerant New Jersey artist who roams the state carrying a sketchpad, notebook and camera, is busy recording in pen and ink a variety of historic structures selected by the curator of the New Jersey Historical Society. The buildings reflect the history of the Revolutionary War, and Mr. Johnston plans to complete drawings of at least 28 of them. He is a transplanted New Yorker who once sold sketches of trees on Eighth Street in New York. His new interest in the history of New Jersey is mirrored in the four recently completed drawings that appear on this page.

title: CORRECTION
Rain Puts Off Fight
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 5 (UPI)Heavy rain, which produced hazardous conditions at the site of the bout, forced a 48hour postponement of tonight's scheduled World Boxing Association lightheavyweight title fight between the champion, Victor Galindez of Argentina, and Pierre Fourie of South Africa.

title: Second Season Starts
description: It was no miracle that brought the New York Islanders into the playoffs. All season long the 3yearold club had been playing the steady hockey that earned it a shot at the Stanley Cup just two years after it had finished a season with but 12 victories.

title: STAMPS
description: The first clashes of the Revolutiontobe took place on April 19, 1775 between American Minutemen and British troops at Lexington and Concord in Massachusetts. These battles are being commemorated with a single 10cent stamp that continues the observance of the Bicenitennial of the American Revolution.

title: Charleston: Riotous Flowers, Aloof Folk
description: SHE has caught cannonballs in her lap, withstood siege, pestilence, Indian arrows, British and Yankee muskets, pirate cutlasses and slave rebellion, not to mention earthquakes, hurricanes and tornadoes that tore up her palmettos like feather dusters, and still she retains her allure. She is Charleston, South Carolina.

title: California Captures N. C.A.A. Gym Title
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 5 (AP)California won the National Collegiate gymnastics championship today with 437.325 points, edging Louisiana State, with 433.7, and Southern Illinois, with 431.5.

title: Moscow Reports Request
description: MOSCOW, April 4The first public acknowledgement of the Egyptian request for a resumption of the Geneva conference came today in a brief dispatch from Cairo printed in Izvestia, the Government newspaper. The Soviet Union has not made public that it has replied.

title: Retarded Adults Get A FosterHome Plan
description: TRENTONA new, federally subsidized program to find more private homes for mentally retarded adults has been established by the Bureau of Field Services in the state's Division of Mental Retardation.

title: Interest in Guitar on Rise
description: JERSEY CITYThe women fall in love with you if you play like that, said Jose Tomas, who demonstrated his versatility before a class in classical guitar that he taught at Jersey City State College last week.

title: Vegetables Thrive In the Schoolroom
description: HAYWARD, CALIF. The Bidwell School is a lowslung onestory white building on the fringes of the California hills. It was set down here not too many years ago on the edge of the last subdivision and might never have faced anything but a discouraging round of budget cuts and pupil losses if Dan Brown hadn't started buying his fluorescent lights.

title: Leftist Alliance In Genoa Strains Coalition in Rome
description: ROME, April 5Italy's governing coalition is under strain following the entry this week of Communists into the municipal Government of Genoa, the nation's fifth largest city.

title: The Maze
description: Of course there are poetic geniuses who are utterly normal: there are poets who have been married contentedly for many years, who do not cause injury to themselves or others. and who labor to create works of art without obligatory plunges into the abyss of madness or drunkenness or sheer wanton childishness. But our attention is drawn to the others. Possibly fewer in numberthe Byronic personalities outshine the rest. What interest has the normal for us, when the brilliant but outrageous is also a possibility? And so it is the fate of certain poets to be elevated more for their images than their work, and to be victimized by the very traits in their personalities that seem to appeal to their admirerstheir wild, reckless originality, their need for constant experimentation and turbulence, their insatiable and, in a way, almost innocent egotism.

title: The Man Of Only Yesterday
description: The author of Only Yesterday was the first good American writer to move boldly into the territoryscorned by the orthodox practitioners of the one and generally outside the interests or capacities of those or the otherbetween history and journalism. He modestly called his books of that sort not history but retrospective journalism, and from a scholarly point of view the selfdeprecation was in order; for one thing, his back notes (never footnotes) amount to reading guides rather than source identifications, and moreover, the club bores of the history establishment always anathematize him by saying, Why, damn it, the man writes plain English! But how many later writers, including academic historians, were first inspired by Frederick Lewis Allen (18901954) to helpless, lifelong worship of the Muse Clio? For better, that is to say, or for worse?

title: Sheehy Sets Meet Mark For 2Mile
description: Brendan Sheehy of Cathedral Prep, who missed most of the indoor season because of injury and illness, served notice yesterday that he was ready for the outdoor track campaign.

title: U.S. Deflects Inquiries On Vietnamese Orphans
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)The large number of calls regarding South Vietnamese orphans has forced the Agency for International Development to establish a new telephone number.

title: Youths Put Jail Menu in ApplePie Order
description: NEW BRUNSWICKA pair of energetic young graduates of a Middlesex. County vocational school have taken over the culinary chores at the County Jail here, and they appear to be on their way to giving the institution a good name so far as food is concerned.

title: Tributes by Senators
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Informed of the death of President Chiang Kaishek, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota and a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today that the Chinese leader had been a strongwilled leader of his people who had earned the respect of millions of Americans. With his death we may see a struggle for power and some basic changes in relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

title: Miss Feeney Sets Bridal
Letters to the Editor
description: Reducing Noise

title: The Bobicks on Long Island
description: Cookie Wallace is an opponent. When a promoter wants to use a fighter whom he regards as a box office attraction, the manager says, Get me an opponent, meaning somebody who won't make trouble and can be relied on not to stink the joint out, as the euphemism goes. The promoter looks around and finds somebody like Wallace, a heavy weight out of Dallas who loses oftener than he wins. Wallace has been a professional for nine years and can make the moves well enough, so promoters haven't been afraid to put him in with main event performers like George Foreman, Bob Foster, Oscar Bonavena, Mac Foster, Ken Norton and Earnie Shavers, all of whom detached him from his intellect. This qualified him as an accessory to unbeaten Duane Bobick's 26th consecutive victory, a role that he performed with celerity Friday night in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: How It All Began
description: All the hoopla, halfhearted though some of it is, that surrounds the impending American Bicentennial has obscured the fact that another bicentennial is more or less upon us. It was just about two centuries ago that the industrial revolution got under way with some remarkable innovations in textiles, smelting and steam power. Fortunately a celebrant has arrived on the scene in the person of Walt W. Rostow, economic historian and sometime special assistant for national security to the late President Johnson. He means to explain how it all began, although that it is not always dear.

title: LETTERS
description: Tankers

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Among the perils of the deep there is hardly one that strikes more terror in the mariner's heart than the Hatteras Hexagon. His fear cannot be dismissed as seaman's superstition: Within this sixsided polygonal east of the Carolinas, no fewer than a thousand ships have vanished  in modern memory alone.

title: Tabitha Bonner Plans Marriage To Frederick Maddox Johnston
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Bonner of Bedford, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mr. Bonner's daughter, Tabitha Bonner, to Frederick Maddox Johnston, son of Mrs. Wolfe Johnston of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and F. Maddox Johnston of Greensboro, N. C.

title: In Memoriam
description: ADELMANLeon L. April 7, 1974. In everlasting memory of a gentle, kind, compassionate man. A wonderful husband, father, grandfather. Rest in peace, Dad. THE FAMILY.

title: The National Pastime Or, a Little Bit of Luck
description: Setting: The bleachers, Fenway Park, Boston. Opening game, 1975 season. Boston Red Sox vs. Milwaukee Brewers. Characters: Father, a baseball devotee. Son, age 9. Vendors. The Commission on the Review of the National Policy Toward Gambling Chorale has completed the singing of Luck, Be a Lady Tonight. Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder has just thrown out the first ball.

title: Mr. Tennis of Brooklyn Fights to Improve City Courts for the Public
description: In the gathering twilight, a lone figure was on the tennis court. He crouched at the net, looking for something on the ground. When he found it, he straightened up and his hands moved quickly. He was repairing the net with a needle and thread.

title: Signing of Agreement In Lisbon Is Held Up
description: LISBON, April 5The formal signing of an agreement under which Portugal's armed forces have virtually imposed a constitution on the country has been delayed until next week because of suggestions for changes that are considered relatively minor.

title: 8WEEKEND STAY SET BY GOSPEL CARAVAN
description: Black gospel music came outs, of the churches and on to the Broadway stage Friday, when at the RFK Theater the Gospel. Caravan Corporation started eight consecutive weekends devoted to the music. Black gospel, one of the documented sources of rock and soul music, possesses its own professional circuit for groups and singers but is rarely heard on secular ground. Occasionally a group will work in rock clubs giving listeners a tantalizing glimpse of a vital, active piece of Americana, but more often the gospel gets in thinly diluted as soul music.

title: The Nation
description: According to Department of Agriculture figures, farm prices dropped 2 per cent more for the month ending March 15. They have fallen more than 15 per cent during the last year, while the prices farmers have to pay have continued to rise. The result apparently has been a squeeze in profits for some and heavy losses for others.

title: Marina Barone Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Marina Barone was married yesterday afternoon to Robert C. Van Velsor, who is the Bobby Van of Bobby Van's bar and restaurant in Bridgehampton, L. I. The Rev. Robert Battles performed the ceremony in Bridgehampton's Presbyterian Church.

title: Thriving Art Gallery Built by Volunteers
description: PORT WASHINGTONAn artist had the idea of staging a happening by driving a car into the Central Hall Gallery's new home.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: An Exhibit of FlyTiers' Art
description: For the last four years, William Cushner has been assembling the creations of many of the world's best flytiers, both past and present, in tasteful mounts and frames behind glass for all to see.

title: He Will Invest His Prestige in the Right Democrat
description: WASHINGTON  When Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. dined recently at the Cantina D'Italia restaurant, not far from the White House, a woman patron sent him a folded note: Thank youfor being all you were and are. Just one of your American people.

title: A TORTURE VICTIM WINS CAIRO PLEA
description: CAIRO, April 5An Egyptian court has ruled that Gen. Mohammed Abdel Ghany elGamasy, in his position as Minister of War, must pay the equivalent of $75,000 in damages to an Egyptian who was tortured in a military prison during the rule of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, Cairo newspapers reported today.

title: Iraqi Victory Over Kurds Seen as Setback to Soviet
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 5The end of the Kurdish rebellion as an outgrowth of Iraq's improvement of relations with Iran is viewed by diplomats here as a setback for the Soviet Union and a potential major gain for the United States.

title: Kevin Dwyer Fiance Of Suzanne Donnelly
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Donnelly of Manhasset, L. P., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Patricia Donnelly, to Kevin J. Dwyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Dwyer of Syosset, L. I. A June wedding is planned.

title: J. M. Corrells Have Son
North Vietnamese Are Forming. New National Assembly Today
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 5 (Agence FrancePresse)North Vietnam is forming new 425member National Assembly tomorrow afternoon.

title: The Growth in Group Travel
description: Gay people have traveled singly or in couples for years with few if any complications. But it was not until about 1969, the date of a Manhattan street protest usually cited as the start of the gay liberation movement, that gays started going in for group travel. That winter saw the formation of Gypsy Feet (1621 Second Avenue, New York), a club devoted to stretching travel dollars. Membership has grown to 2,000, mostly men in their thirties and forties, who pay $15 annual dues to choose from nearly 500 tour packages and charter flights. Examples of 1974 offerings: $209 for a fourday Thanksgiving weekend in London; $299 for Rio de Janeiro the week after Mardi Gras but before the last hurrah. (To both prices were added 10 per cent tax and service. Also, these costs were based on affinity group air fares: one must be a member for six months to take part.) Slightly older, more affluent gays are served by Hanns Ebensten Travel (55 West 42d Street, New York), a wholesaleretail organization which added just one allmale escorted tour to its regular line in 1973. Now it offers seven such packages with 13 departures. Among them, a Devil's Island (French Guiana) tour which, with some amenities, includes accommodations for 30 men in the prison's adapted guards' quarter, and a week on rubber rafts shooting the rapids of the Snake River in Idaho. This one's popular with a lot of Marlboro Men types, Ebensten says. New this year, and his most ambitious plan to date, will be an allmale twoweek Galapagos Islands cruise aboard a 66passenger private ship leaving Aug. 22.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Coast Guard vessels, the Tamaroa, a 205foot cutter, and hte Firebush, a 180foot buoy tender, stood by yesterday to warn shipping away from the site where a 557foot Liberian tanker broke up in heavy Atlantic seas Friday, leaving one seaman dead. Two sections of the tanker, Spartan Lady, were floating seven and a half miles apart 200 miles south of New York Harbor.

title: Underground Atomic Test
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 5 (AP)A nuclear test with a yield of less than 20 kilotons was conducted underground today at the government's Nevada Test Site 65 miles northwest of here, officials said. A spokesman said the 12:45 p.m. test, the third of the year at this site, was of such a low yieldequivalent to less than 20,000 tonsof TNTthat probably no one off the test site felt any ground motion.

title: Ford Lauds Chiang As Man of Courage, Sees End of an Era
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 5President Ford, expressing sadness today at the death of President Chiang Kaishek, described him as a man of firm integrity, high courage and deep political conviction.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Picture Credits

title: Alfred E. Stacey Jr., a Founder Of Carrier Corp., Is Dead at 90
description: Alfred E. Statey Jr., a pioneer or airconditioning and the last of the seven founders of the Carrier Corporation, died yesterday in Watertown, N. Y. He way 90 years old.

title: Hilary Falk Bride Of William Sivitz
description: Hilary Lynn Falk, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Lewis Davis of Lancaster, Mass., and London, was married yesterday afternoon in Palm Beach, Fla., to William D. Sivitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Sivitz of Dayton, Ohio.

title: Yankees Set Back Phils, 62
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., April 5This day began for the Yankees with breakfast in the dining room of the hotel in Tampa, the Hilton Riverside, while in uniform. That is what the program called for in advance of a bus trip 22 miles to Clearwater to play the Phillies, whom the New York club later beat, 62.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 6, 1975

title: Actors Who Speak Silently
description: The office of David Hays was alive with the excitement of communication one day recently, yet not one word was spoken. Julianna Field, a deaf actress, was conversing in sign language with Mr. Hays, founder and producing director of the widely acclaimed National Theater of the Deaf, which begins an eightperformance run tomorrow at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Marjorie Sookin Fiancee
CHESS
description: The 50th Hastings international tournament was won this year by the favorite, Grandmaster Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia, who lost only to England's George Botterill while tallying seven victories and seven draws. Going into the last round with a halfpoint lead over the field, Hort demolished the Yugoslav grandmaster Albin Planinc to put away first prize.

title: Surgery for Talbert
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)  Diron Talbert, a Washington Redskin defensive tackle, underwrent surgery in Oklahoma City today for removal of cartilage from his right knee, a team spokesman said.

title: Vermont Panel Approves Presidential Primary Bill
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 5 (AP)  The Vermont House Government Operations Committee approved today a bill to create a Presidential primary in Vermont.

title: BACKTALK
description: In his March 23d essay entitled The False Art of the Propaganda Film, Walter Goodman labels as propaganda my film The Other Half of the Sky: A China Memoir, and Haskell Wexler's Introduction to the Enemy and Peter Davis's Hearts and Minds. In doing so, he displays the very deception and distortion that is usually associated with the pejorative meaning of propaganda.

title: Rice University to Sell Houston Hotel
description: HOUSTON, April 5The Rittenhouse Capital Corporation of New York has signed a letter of intent and earnest money contract to buy the Rice Hotel, the first deluxe hotel built in this city, and lease the land it stands on for 50 years from Rice University, present owner of the hotel and land.

title: Article 5  No Title
After Leading 15 Performances, Sixten Ehrling Closes the Ring
description: At 12:20 this morning, Sixten Ehrling ended the last of the 15 performances of Wagner's Ring operas at the Metropolitan Opera this season. He is not sure whether he is glad or sorry.

title: FORD GETS APPEAL ON SAKHAROV'S KIN
description: Senator James L. Buckley announced yesterday that he and 36 other United States senators had called on President Ford to exercise his influence with the leaders of the Soviet Union to obtain permission for relatives of the Soviet physicist and civil libertarian, Andrei D. Sakharov, to accept an invitation to study in the United States.

title: France Appeals for a Peace Process in Vietnam
