description: PARIS, April 5The French Government called today for the carrying cut of a process that would bring a political settlement in Sonth Vietnam and said it intended to contribute actively.

title: One Company's Formula for Fighting Recession
description: Coping with the recession is a different task for most companies. But those in the clothing industry are faced with circumstances making their task especially difficult.

title: A Year After the Tornado, 2 Xenias Live and Rebuild
description: XENIA, Ohio, April 5Howard Camp, 46 years old, and Joseph D. Merriman, 71, are separated by a generation and the geography of their town.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER NEW ENERGY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) A national energy program stressing an oil import quota was proposed today by the Democratic Advisory Council. It is the sixth energy program advanced by the Democrats this year.

title: Poll Finds Jackson Strongest Ford Challenger
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson would be a stronger challanger to President Ford than either Senator Edmund S. Muskie or Gov. George C. Wallace if an election were held now, according to a Gallup poll released yesterday.

title: Witch Doctor's Apprentice
description: At the end of November, 1958, Nicole Maxwellan old jungle hand, a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society of London, and, judging from her mudanddungarees photographs, a lady of considerable natural elegance embarked on a onewoman expedition to collect samples of medicinal plants from the Indians of the western Amazon jungle, a region she knew well. She had managed, with difficulty, to persuade a large American pharmaceutical company to put up a thousand dollars toward the costs of the expedition. The prevailing scientific attitude then was (and still is one of skepticism verging on scorn with regard to the very possibility of Indian medicines (How can they know anything about medicine? They're illiterate! said one botanist) and toward the notion of a white woman going alone into the jungle to get them. But Nicole had firsthand experience of some of those medicineslike the tree sap that stops bleeding of wounds and which, if taken by mouth, can halt massive internal hemorrhageand she had direct and reliable testimony of others, notably a onedose herbal contraceptive that could shut off a woman's fertility for as long as eight years!

title: Getting Foreign Cash
description: The question of possible limitations on foreign investment in the United States has been under discussion in the Congress and in the press. It has, so far, been highlighted by denunciations of the Arab boycott of Israel on the one hand by the B'nai B'rith AntiDefamation League, and on the other by equally fervent appeals by representatives of the New York Stock Exchange for free flows of capital.

title: Medical School Dean Chosen
description: ATLANTA, April 5 (AP) Morehouse College has announced the appointment of Dr. Louis W. Sullivan as dean of the medical school scheduled to open in September, 1977. Sullivan, a native of Atlanta, is a professor of medicine and physiology at Boston University School of Medicine.

title: Soviet Replies to Cairo Bid to Resume Geneva Talks
description: CAIRO, April 5Egypt has received a Soviet reply to her call for a resumption of the Middle East peace conference at Geneva, amid reports that Moscow, like Cairo, feels that thorough preparation is needed before the conference should start

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Astronomers at the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Arizona have put together the first photograph of the face of a star other than the sun.

title: Success for Either Side Depends on a Show of Unity
description: PARIS  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was founded in 1960, but only within the last two years has it achieved its two main goals: to increase petroleum prices and to take control of production away from the major oil companies.

title: In Verona, When They Say Grand Opera They Mean Grandiose
description: THE music of Verdi, Puccini, Bizet e and the like is for the ear, of course, but that doesn't mean looks don't count. In Verona's op openair arenathe best preserved amphitheater in Italysummer opera performances have been going on since 1913, and there is always plenty to see as well as hear. The arena can hold 25.000 spectators, though each performance pulls in only around 18,000, and a visitor can nearly always get a seat.

title: Combating Crime
description: The F.B.I. crime statistics for 1974 contain a message for criminaljustice policy planners. After six years of a Federal openpurse policy, the incidence of crime not only has continued to increase, but has spurted up more sharply than at any time since the bureau started col!acting such statistics 45 years ago.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The U.S. Mint is now accepting orders for the third pair of medals in its historic American Revolution Bicentennial commemorative series of 10 antiquepewter reproductions of America's First Medals. The ordering period will close May 31. The two medals in the current offering (illustrated at right) pay honor to Maj. Henry Lee and Gen. Daniel Morgan.

title: Music: Long on Charm
description: The first half of the program by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night was long on charm. It was charm that never cloyed, however, because the three works involved had their bases in sturdy forms. There was Poulenc's Sonata for Oboe and Piano, with its lovely melancholy last movement; Haydn's Piano Trio No. 9 in B flat, alive with surprising invention, and Michael Colgrass's Variations for Four Drums and Viola.

title: Has the Time Come to Pump It Out?
description: WASHINGTONOn a Saturday morning in September of 1973, the President of the United States, contemplating a potentially serious winter shortage of heating oil, declared that production of crude oil from Naval Petroleum Reserve No. 1 in California was essential to expansion of domestic energy supplies.

title: Article 6  No Title
Lincoln U. Media Awards Given Three Newspapers
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 5 (UPI)The Lincoln University Unity Awards in Media program has given its top awards to newspapers in Chicago, Philadelphia and Kansas City. Mo.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Tomorrow night the Metropolitan Opera unveils its new production of Rossini's The Siege of Corinth, and to most opera fans this event means one thing above all: Beverly Sills's longawaited Met debut. Both New York and Miss Sills have deserved the honor for a number of years now, but when the shouting has died away, it may well be the Rossini opera that will stick in the mind, even in the rather curious version that Thomas Schippers has devised for the Met. While Rossini's comic works are now known quantities through numerous recordings and live performances, his tragic or semiseria style is still largely, unfamiliar to audiences, and The Siege of Corinth will provide a good introduction to this relatively unexplored facet of the composer's personality. Angel's new recording of the opera with the four principals of the Met production should also help adjust the perspective as well as provide a fascinating memento of the occasion itself.

title: April and Floods
description: Man is a braggart, to start with. He boasts that is in control of the earth, this land on which he lives, though he really isn't in control of his own dooryard. A drouth can kill his lawn. An invasion of beetles can kill his shade trees. The spray he used to control weeds can kill or sicken the birds. And each spring sees floods sweep over land the farmers insist is their domain.

title: Man Held in Theft Of Woman's Purse From St. Patrick's
description: A 30yearod Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday following a short chase, after he had allegedly grabbed a purse from Connecticut woman as she knelt in prayer in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: MAN IS CHARGED IN DENTIST THEFTS
description: A 25yearold former convict who allegedly gained entry by deceiving dentists into believing that he needed rootcanal work was arrested late Friday night and charged with the armed robbery of more than 20 dentists in the Bensonhurst and Flatbush sections of Brooklyn.

title: In Bad Times, the Relationship Becomes Strained
description: In good times, the crucial role banks play in government financing receives little public attention. Now, as inflation and recession have cut deeply into state and municipal budgets, the intricate relationship between the banks and local government has become a matter of concern. Here are questions and answers about how it works:

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Indians Form a Restoration Group
description: RAPID. CITY, S. D., April 5 (UPI)Dick Wilson, president of the Oglala Sioux tribe on the Pine Ridge Reservation, has announced the formation of an Indian organization tesigned to counteract the American Indian Movement.

title: Arts Called a Tool to Teach Handicapped
description: Mentally and emotionally handicapped children can relate to the arts, but the potential of the arts in this area has not been tapped, a Fordharn University specialist in teacher training said at a seminar there yesterday for therapists, performers and educators.

title: Karen J. Elliott, Arthur H. House Wed in Capital
description: Karen J. Elliott, energy and food policy correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Wall Street Journal, was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur H. House, an economist on the policy planning staff of the World Bank in Washington.

title: Kathleen Foley to Be Married on Aug. 2
description: Mrs. David C. Mac Nichol of Cumberland, Me., and Frederick J. Foley Jr. of Portland Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Foley, to Brackett B. Denniston 3d of Cambridge, Mass. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Denniston Jr. of Barrington, Ill.

title: Paperbacks
description: A COLLEGE ALBUM, by Oliver Jensen. (Avon/Flare, $3.95.) Campus life from the Age of Grant to the recent past depicted in an annotated album of photographs, most of it betraying an immense concern with the trivial.

title: BRIDGE
description: The most savage feuds in history and literature Guelphs and Ghibelines in medieval Europe, Lancaster and York in 15th Century England, Hatfields and McCoys in 19th Century America, and Montagues and Carpulets in Romeo and Juliethave a bridge equivalent in the Fours and Fives.

title: EXTRA GAS PROFITS SUBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) The Federal Energy Administration has scheduled a public hearing on the controversial question of whether gasoline dealers should keep making an extra threecent profit on every gallon of gasoline they sell.

title: ROUNDUP
description: WASHINGTON  Every fourth Tuesday a small group of bankers, economists and lawyers gathers shortly after 9 A.M. for one of Washington's most secret and most important meetings.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Democratic leaders in the Assembly have confirmed what has been apparent to a growing number of legislators for the last several months: that S. Howard Woodson of Mercer County, the Speaker in the lower house, has relinquished increasing amounts of power to Joseph A. LeFante, the Democratic Majority Leader from Hudson County.

title: Thieu Is Reported Ready to Act On Generals Who Gave Ground
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5President Nguyen Van Thieu is reported planning action against a number of his officers, on the ground that they were personally responsible for the loss of twothirds of the nation's territory in the last few weeks.

title: John A. Burns, Former Governor Of Hawaii, 66, Is Dead of Cancer
description: HONOLULU, April 5John Anthony Burns, who retired as Governor of Hawaii at the end of last year, died today at his home at Kaiwi on Oahu. He was 66 years old and had been ill with cancer.

title: Grumman Planning Wider Use Of Airfield
description: BETHPAGE  The Grumman Aerospace Corporation announced last week that it would open its airport here for limited generalaviation by lightweight corporate and private planes.

title: BEN CUNNINGHAM, ARTIST, DIES AT 71
description: Ben Cunningham, an artist and teacher known for his manipulation of color, died yesterday in a nursing home in Hackensack, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived at 44 Carmine Street.

title: MUSEUM ON COAST HAS ANNIVERSARY
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5Ten years ago, Los Angeles's art museum was in an unimpressive section of the downtown Museum of History. Science and Art, where, in the words of a museum official, visitors arrived at the art works by climbing through a dinosaur's skeleton.

title: Federal Slumlord
description: The fact that housing facilities for migrant workers in Florida are often unfit for human habitation has been amply documented over the past decade. It is less wellknown, however, that some of those scandalous slums are financed by the Department of Agriculture.

title: Fleeing Americans Reach Philippines And Tell of Fears
description: CLARK AIR BASE, Philippines, April 5The first planeloads of Americans from Saigon arrived at this United States base in the central Philippines today. They said they were distressed at what they feared was imminent chaos in South Vietnam.

title: Electronics Bringing a Quiet Revolution in the Nation's Telephone Service
description: In the last 10 years, the Bell System has quietly been carrying out a multibilliondollar electronic revolution in callhandling.

title: Bardin Ruling on Route 18 Shift Awaited
description: NEW BRUNSWICKStrong environmental opposition to a proposed realignment of Route 18 along the south bank of the Raritan River has been renewed here, thus confronting Commissioner David J. Bardin of the State's Department of Environmental Protection with what looms as one of his first major decisions.

title: Ford Hit on Juvenile Crime
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said Thursday that President Ford has responded with indifference to legislation to curb juvenile crime. Referring to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act passed last year Senator Bayh said, The President has not yet bothered to appoint an administrator to coordinate our efforts in this area.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TRENTON, April 5Winds of 30 to 40 miles an hour prevented practice and qualifying today for the Trentonian 200 automobile race, the last event on the United States Auto Club championship trail before the Indianapolis 500 on May 25. The $60,000 race is scheduled to start at the Trenton International Speedway tomorrow at 2 P.M. The 19 drivers will be given 1 hours of practice starting 11 A.M., but the starting grid will be determined by a draw. Among the favorites are A.J. Foyt, who is leading the national driver standing, and Johnny Rutherford, last year's Indianapolis 500 champion. The race will be shown nationally by ABCTV (Channel 7 in New York, 2 P.M.).

title: Student Shift Sought In East Massapequa
description: Five hundred parents of children in the Amityville School District petitioned State Education Commissioner Ewald P. Nyquist last week to dissolve the district and reassign its 4,000 pupils to three adjoining districts.

title: SHARING OF POWER IS LINDSAY THEME
description: CHICAGO, April 5The formet boss of the Big Apple visited the Second City this week to tell a wellheeled audience that the future health of city governments depended upon the sharing of the power, by officials and politicians, a prospect as likely in today's Chicago as the return of nickel beer with a free tavern lunch.

title: Aide Joins Carter Campaign
description: SANTA FE, N. M., April 5Chris Brown, the chief aide to Gov. Jerry Apodaca, said yesterday that he would leave his job to become the New England regional coordinator for former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Brown, who is 26 years old, managed Mr. Apodaca's primary and general election campaigns last year.

title: Article 11  No Title
Staub Joins Mets' List Of Injured
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 5The New York Mets neared the end of their training season tonight with new injuries, a growing disabled list and their worst record in eight years.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 367.2 from 378.7 a week earlier. A year ago it was 405.9.

title: Who Lost the War in Vietnam? Who Lost the Future?
description: WASHINGTON, Apr. 5President Ford has invited the American people to assess the blame for who lost Vietnam, and President Thieu in Saigon has invited us to rush to his aid or be branded as traitors, but maybe we don't need any more divisions than we now have. There is enough blame in this tragedy to cover us all.

title: Mansfield Plans to Ask Full Policy Assessment
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Mike Mansfield, the Senate Majority Leader, who has been apprehensive about recriminations between the White House and the Congress over Indochina, will propose next week a bipartisan reassessment of the nation's foreign policy.

title: The Ballet: Trilogy by John Neumeier in Toronto
description: TORONTO, April 5One of America's bestknown choreographers is still comparatively littleknown in his native United States. He is the Wisconsinborn John Neumeier, who is now director of the Hamburg Ballet. Although his works have been seen in New York, danced by the Harkness Ballet, the National Ballet of Canada and American Ballet Theater, it is still in Europe that his reputation stands highest. Earlier this season he enjoyed an outstanding success with his staging of Romeo and Juliet for the Royal Danish Ballet in Copehagen.

title: Scher Hunters Win At Show in Jersey
description: HOLMDEL, N.J., April 5Greg Scher of Far Hills, N.J., who returned from the Florida Circuit last week, guided his horses to two championships today at the Tricorne Farms Horse Show. He rode Nacerina to the junior working hunter title and Wait Up to the large pony hunter crown.

title: EXPERTS CRITICIZE AREACTOR TEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The test that the Government recently ordered utilities to use in the search for cracks in their nuclear reactors is not reliable, according to experts in the agency that ordered the searches.

title: Fashion
description: Cynthia Benjamin had $250 to buy a summer wardrobe, and she set about doing so in a very organized way. She made a list of what she wanted and stuck to it. She decided that, rather than buying lots of inexpensive things, she would get small, coordinated wardrobe with interchangeable parts. Her list called for a sundress, a skirt, a pair of pants, two Tshirts, a bikini and coverup, a pair of shoes, a hat and a bag.

title: Gladys Anne Rogers Is Betrothed
description: Gladys Anne Rogers and Frederick S. Buck Jr. students at the Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, Pa., have become engaged.

title: Big Drop in Fattening Pigs Bad News for Pork Lovers
description: CHICAGO, April 5For those who delight in eating bacon, ham, or pigs knuckles, the news this week was bad.

title: Nicklaus, Player, Trevino, Miller and Elder Draw Spotlight in Masters Golf
description: The Masters, which Jack Nicklaus has characterized as a monument to everything great in golf, begins next Thursday on the flawlessly prepared Augusta National Golf Club at Augusta, Ga.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Salishan Lodge in Gleneden Beach, Ore., was inadvertently dropped from the list in last week's Travel Notes of hotels, morels and resorts awarded five stars for excellence in the 1975 issue of the Mobil Travel Guide.

title: Changes Urged in City's Purchasing
description: The State Charter Revision Commission for new New York City, charging that the city's purchasing operations have become tangled in red tape, urged yesterday that each city agency be given more leeway to make small purchases.

title: Baseball's Year of the Catfish Opens Tomorrow
description: Baseball camps from Palm Springs to Palm Beach will close today, ending six weeks of training for the 24 teams in the two major leagues and opening six months of performing on a stage still crowded with hockey and basketball. The season No. 100 for the National League and No. 75 for the Americanwill start tomorrow afternoon in Cincinnati with the Reds playing the Los Angeles Dodgers. A few hours later, in three night games, the Kansas City Royals will meet the California Angels at Anaheim, the Montreal Expos will play the Cardinals in St. Louis and the Atlanta Braves will open against the Houston Astros under the only roof in baseball.

title: Christopher O. Carey Marries Bonnie Blum
description: Christopher Owen Carey, Governor Cafey's oldest son, was married yesterday to Bonnie Bresler Blum in a family ceremony at St. Francis deSales Roman Catholic Church in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: Attica Jury Convicts One Of Murder, 2d of Assault
description: BUFFALO, April 5The jury in the trial of two former Attica inmates convicted both defendants here tonightJohn Hill of murder and Charles Joseph Pernasilice of attempted assault for their roles in the death of a prison guard during the September, 1971, rebellion at the prison.

title: Elvera Ellen Mc Lees Is Married
description: Elvera Ellen Mc Lees, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard John Mc Lees of West Brighton, S. I., was married yesterday morning to Charles Cameron Weld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Weld of Rothester and Lubec, Me.

title: Not the Old and Not the New, but Something Useful in Between
description: If all goes well, there will be a new series on the educational television network next fall aimed at curing a peculiarly American intellectual malady that some educators call mathophobiaa dread of mathematics. The programs, called Count Us In, are designed to make numbers both interesting and practical.

title: James and John Stuart Mill
description: The story of John Stuart Mill reads like a work of fictionwhich in many ways it was. From his own account of the celebrated education he received at the hands of his father, we get an unnerving picture of a little homunculus, an artificial child reading Greek at 3, mastering Robertson, Hume and Gibbon at 7, and returning, at age 8, to reread Roman history both in my old favourite, Hooke, and in Ferguson.

title: LIBERAL SHIFT SEEN ON JUVENILE COURT
description: The dean of the Marquette Law School told a seminar for Family Court judges and officers here yesterday that liberals who had provided the support for a separate juvenilecourt system that emphasized rehabilitation and treatment had come full circle, to the position that youthful offenders should be incarcerated and punished.

title: Sleeper in '74 Law May Aid Older Units
description: A sleeper provision in the 1974 Federal housing act may substantially strengthen the financial position of rental apartment buildings that are in sound physical condition.

title: Kenneth Feinberg Fiance of Diane Shaff
description: Diane Shaff and Kenneth R. Feinberg, an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York plan to be married in June.

title: Suffolk Democrats Picking Candidates
description: HUNTINGTONThe 1975 political season has quietly started in Suffolk, with officials and party activists preparing for November's county and town elections.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, April 6

title: Employer Is Indicted Over Illegal Aliens
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5A garment industry manufacturer and his son, a former Stanford football player, have been indioted on Federal charges of unlawfully transporting and concealing illegal aliens.

title: Design
description: Josef Hoffmann, the Austrian genius who helped shape 20thcentury architectural thinking, reached center stage in Vienna at the turn of the century. Within a decade he had built the Palais Stoclet in Brussels, a modern landmark and his greatest achievement, and he had cofounded (with Koloman Moser) the Wiener Werksttte, from which came his furniture, textiles and teapots, whose shape and surface decoration anticipated Art Deco and nineteensixties styling.

title: NEW FRONT IS SEEN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 6North Vietaamese troops increased their probing attacks in the Mekong Delta area yesterday, and Western intelligence officials said it appeared that the Communists might now be trying to open a new front on Saigon's southern flank.

title: A City TakeOver Leads to Surprises
description: Last December the city wrested financial control of 200 violationridden apartment buildings from Jacob A. Fine, their owner.

title: Persian Gardens Subject of Lecture
description: PRINCETONPatticia, Countess Jellicoe, of London will give an illustrated lecture at Princeton University on Thursday on the beauty and symbolism of Persian gardens. Sponsored by the Friends of New Jersey State Museum and the university's Department of Near Eastern Studies, the program will be offered in McCormick Hall, starting at 8 P.M.

title: Article 8  No Title
Home Clinic
description: Q: We have dark oak paneling, pillars, staircase and windows framed in the same dark oak. The wood is getting very dry looking and is in need of treatment of some kind. We do not want to have it varnished although my sister says it was varnished at one time with a satin varnish. We cherish this part of our home and don't want to ruin it. What do you suggest?M. R. Rodgers, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Their Stage Language Is Unique
description: Some good news: the National Theater of the Deaf begins a run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tomorrow night. Some bad news: the company will be around only through next Sunday.

title: Aged Horne Gets Funds To Build
description: Construction of a nursing home in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn has resumed after a twoweek delay caused by the failure of the state to sell notes to finance the project.

title: Bridal in May For Malo Paul
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Alden Paul of Palm Beach, Fla., and Cashiers, N. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Malo Paul of New York, to John Stephen Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas R. Harrison of Wilmette, Ill., and Williams Bay, Wis.

title: INDUSTRY RESISTS CARSAFETY COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The contest between advocates of safer, cleaner automobiles and costconscious, styleconscious manufacturers is entering a new phase. After 10 years on the defensive, Detroit is striking back.unbiased judgments on whether the equipment makes financial sense. Completely different conclusions have been, reached.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Nursery Fights Inflation's Pinch And Seeks Aid
description: NEWARKThe recession is threatening one of the countrys largest daycare centers for ??.

title: Scout Group Fights Sale of Wauwepex
description: WADING RIVERA group of Nassau County scoutmasters is trying to block the sale of Camp Wauwepex, a 530acre Boy Scout campground situated in this rural North Shore area near Riverhead.

title: Article 4  No Title
Suffolk Residents Urge Use of New Federal Funds to Rehabilitate Housing
description: Suffolk residents were asked last week at hearings held in Hauppauge and Riverhead to tell the county how to spend $1.1million it expacts to get in Federal funds this year under the Housing and Community Development act of 1974.

title: Ridership Table
description: Following is a table showing the number of revenue passengers (rounded figures in millions) on the subway and bus lines here over the years:

title: Can These Four Jokers Make It on TV?
description: This Thursday evening at 10:00, ABCTV will present an hourlong comedy special entitled Happy Endingsa quartet of original playlets written by four celebrated writers of humor for the stage and screen: Jules Feiffer (Little Murders, Carnal Knowledge, etc.); Herb Gardner (A Thousand Clowns, Thieves, etc.); Peter Stone (1776. The Taking of Pelham One Two Three. etc.); and Neil Simon (Barefoot in the Park, The Odd Couple, etc., etc., etc.). The show will star Lauren Bacall, Art Carney, James Earl Jones and Robert Preston, along with its producer. comedian Alan King.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: RAISING MONEY is becoming a problem on both the municipal and corporate level... Standard & Poor's, one of the two leading creditrating agencies last week suspended its A rating on New York City bonds, an action that could erode investor confidence. Moody's Investors Service, however, said it would stand by the A rating of city bonds. ... The Treasury Department must raise about $17.5billion In new money by June 30, about $13billion more than expected.... Texaco, Inc. said it would postpone a $300million debenture offering.... Manufacturers Hanover put oft a $200million offering and Chemical New York, a $100million one.

title: The Changing Face of the Oil Crisis
description: LONDONEuropean efforts to cope with the impact of the energy crisis are being hampered by a growing sense that there is no longer a serious crisis.

title: FORD DEFICIT GOAL CALLED UNLIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, April 5President Ford will probably be unable to achieve his goal of holding the budget deficit in the new fiscal year to $60billion even if he succeeds in stopping all new Congressional spending bills, high Administration officials concede.

title: Coast Religious Sect's Life Is Tested by Prosperity
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Like the first rays of dawn, the members of the Brotherhood of the Sun slip over the ridge of the mountains behind Santa Barbara early every morning, and stream into the city and the world of materialism they all renounced.

title: The Region
description: ALBANYIn a capital city filled with costly monuments, State Controller Arthur Levitt has spent 20 years issuing warnings to governmental spendthrifts that have echoed off the marble, largely unheeded. But this year, after Governor Carey's campaign promise to limit autocracy of public authorities, and after the nearcollapse of the Urban Development Corporation, Mr. Levitt's decades of critiques of these same authorities and their borrowing practices are being dusted off reverently.

title: Connecticut Man, Flight Backer, Is in California to Greet Orphans
description: Among the people waiting last night for Vietnamese war orphans to arrive at San Francisco International Airport was Robert C. Macauley of New Canaan, Conn, a businessman largely responsible for making one flight possible.

title: Bel canto Beverly
description: Tomorrow night, Beverly Sills superstar, soprano with the New York City Opera for 20 years, will make her debut at the Metropolitan Opera. Next month, she will be 46 years old.

title: Curbs Urged on Court Seniority System
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Proposals that could bring an infusion of new judicial blood to the United States Court of Appeals by reducing the rule of older judges have been recommended by a Federal commission of judges, lawyers and members of Congress.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Government of Jamaica has purchased the 16story office building at 866 Second Avenue, which is also known as Two Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, for $7.5million.

title: Tennis Results
description: HASTINGS CUP

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: MONTREALA few years ago, when Paul G. Desmarais was first emerging as Quebec's suave young prince of highstakes finance, an interviewer asked him just exactly how he occupied his working hours.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WITH the huge taxreduction bill signed into law a week ago after a relatively swift cruise through the legislative mill, Washington canand must turn now without distraction to the other top priorities on the economic calendar: a reasonablycontrolled Government spending plan, a cohesive and practical energy program and improved economic relations in the international sphere.

title: StockCar Driver Killed
description: AUBURNDALE, Fla., April 5 (AP)James Rodgers of Winter Haven, a 54yearold stockcar driver, was killed today during a test run of his car at the Auburadale Speedway Park, track officials said.

title: CURB ON THERAPY STIRS A DISPUTE
description: SAN DIEGO, April 5A court action brought on behalf of two schizophrenic young women, identified only as Jane and Betty Doe, has touched off a legal and legislative battle over a threemonthold California law intended to protect mental patients against radical medical experiments.

title: Lutherans Plan Walk for Hunger
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Young Lutherans from throughout New Jersey will Walk for Hunger on the Boardwalk here today to help express their concern over the world hunger crisis.

title: 3Million Spent on Nixon White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) For the first time in its 11year history, the Committee for the Preservation of the White House has given a full financial report, saying it spent $3.3million to refurbish the executive mansions during the Nixon Administration.

title: The Life of Chiang Kaishek: A Leader Who Was Thrust Aside by Revolution
description: Twentytwo years after rising to the leadership of China in a bloody coup against the Communists in 1927, Chiang Kaishek lost the mantle he had so dearly gained and so precariously mainlained to a triumphant Communist revolution. Thrust aside at the age of 62 by the convulsion that shook half a billion people and an ancient culture, he spun out his long life on the small island of Taiwan in the East China Sea 110 miles from the mainland.

title: 308 GIVEN GRANTS BY GUGGENHEIM
Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayUnited States Auto Club 200mile race at Trenton N. J.) International Speedway. 2 P.M. Formula Ford race at 3:45 P.M.

title: 6Hour Day Sought in Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, April 5 (UPI) Steel workers in the Pittsburgh area want eight hours pay for a sixhour day. The most logical way to reduce unemployment is to reduce the work day, they said in a resolution passed at a district conference of the United Steel Workers of America that concluded today. They said steel workers productive potential had grown with automation and technological advances to allow the workday reduction, adding that it would take a fourday work week to create more jobs for office and technical employes.

title: Music in Review
description: Piano Skill Shown By Robin McCabe

title: A Wedding in June Set by Alice Allen
description: Mrs. Albert Walker Allen of ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., and Southampton, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alice Allen, to Lewis Motter Smith Jr., son of Mr. Smith of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Virginia Smith Fincke of Santa Fe, N. M.

title: The Nation
description: A renewed struggle between the Ford Administration and the Democratic Congress over economic policy may well have been insured by the latest unemployment figure. The percentage of the labor force out of work in March rose to 8.7 per cent, up from 8.2 per cent in February. Not only are eight million Americans now jobless but there are 1.1 million who have become so discouraged at jobhunting they are not counted in the labor force.

title: Japan Finds Overstocking A Problem Now
description: TOKYOA delegation of three Japanese oil executives slipped quietly back into town a few days ago after having failed to persuade Iraq to cut shipments of crude oil to Japan.

title: BROOKLYN MAN HELD IN ABDUCTION OF BOY
description: A 41yearold man who allegedly abducted a Brooklyn boy last February was returned here by authorities yesterday after his arrest by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents Thursday night in Chicago.

title: Sunday Observer
description: It was in the late nineteenforties that the United States finally succeeded in losing an entire country. In those years it lost China. It was an astounding feat, comparable to losing a bull elephant in a studio apartment.

title: Library Unit In Suffolk Offers Plan
description: A weightedvote reapportionment plan for selecting trustees for the Suffolk Cooperative Library System was submitted to the State Education Department for approval last week in an attempt to reform the controversial system.

title: Katherine P. Burnam Married To Charles B. Flood, an Author
description: Katherine Phelps Burnam and Charles Braceien Flood were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in Richmond, Ky., by the Rev. William Roberts.

title: Weiskopf Is Ahead By 4 Shots at 207
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 5Tom Weiskopf struggled through tricky winds again today, slumped to a 72, but still led by four strokes with a 207 in the $225,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Arts and Stottlemyre
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Year in The Minors
description: The San Jose Bees, a very minor league team, almost won a championship in 1973, providing a semidramatic framework for a determinedly undramatic overview of life on the modern, mechanized baseball farm. No echoes of You Know Me Al here. The Bees tend to be collegeeducated, seriousminded men in their early twenties who will leave professional baseball in a year or two if they aren't promoted to a higher league.

title: A 1China policy
description: TAIPEI. There are various ways to describe Taiwan. It is the unresolved last chapter of China's civil war, or a flagrant example of American interference in China's internal affairs. It is a piece of the Free World, or a valuable piece of real estate. A strategic base, an economic success story, or a victim of neocolonialism. It is a question, an issue, an anachronism, a symbol. Or a chip in the floating threehanded pinochle game Henry Kissinger plays with Peking and Moscow. It is another commitment the United States cannot afford to drop, or the logical candidate, after Indochina. for its next Asian disengagement.

title: Catherine W. Pearson To Be a Bride in May
description: Mrs. William Norman Pearson of Nashville has announced the engagement of her daughter, Catherine Wheeldon Pearson. to James Elmer Woodford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodford of Monterey, Tenn.

title: U. S. Deal for Testimony Against Hoffa Is Alleged
description: FORT WORTH, April 5The former national executive director of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' political unit has charged here that the Federal authorities offered to drop criminal charges against him if he would testify that the union's former president, James R. Hoffa, had signed a false sworn statement.

title: N. Y. Stars Outplayed in Rugby
description: The Rugby AllStars from Pennsylvania defeated the. New York AllStars, 137, at Baker Field yesterday.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: S ited uan dei at dhi organ/Ai uas uiri and it at iiz ... So Enrico Caruso, always a bit it at iiz about his English, interlineated his copy of Arthur Sullivan's The Lost Chord. You can gaze upon Caruso's phonetics, and upon some 450 other items concerning Sullivan, at the Pierpont Morgan Library. The exhibition still has another week to run. You can also hear snatches of the operettas, as well as orchestral and instrumental music. The exhibition has been wired for sound. Snap on an earphone and start walking.

title: Now the Bitterness
description: Under the pressure of a near and almost certain defeat, the 20yearold relationship between the United States and South Vietnam has begun to disintegrate, apparently because neither nation is ready to say publicly and officially what now seems evident: North Vietnam and the Vietcong are in control of events. As a result:

title: The Family That Films Together May Win Oscars Together
description: Los ANGELES. The lady may not be a tramp, but she's certainly a slob. Her hair is a hopeless blonde tangle. Her eyes are as bright with terror as those of a trapped bird. Her shapeless minidress is several years out of date. She is pt to make meaningless gestures, signaling with her thumb like a drunken hitchhiker and then winking, mischievously. She hops and chatters and

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayHillair, Hillaire Circle, White Plains, N. Y. Junior, children's, amateurowner and local working hunters; open jumpers, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: All Madras Is Praying For Rains
description: MADRAS, IndiaBrahman priests immersed in neckdeep water chant holy scriptures, Moslems congregate in thousands to say special prayers. Christians attend special services.

title: A Raft of Upcoming Races
description: Farmington Slalom, April 56, New Boston, Mass., Rt. 8 north out of Waterbury, Conn., intermediate difficulty, top competition, contact: Ethel Kenny, 21 Hutton Ave., West Orange, N.J. 07052 Brandywine Slalom, April 1213, Wilmington, Del., oldest U.S. slalom, beginners to intermediate, contact: Lou Metzger, 986 Anders Rd., Lansdale, Pa., 09446

title: Article 3  No Title
2D ATTICA TRIAL IS READY TO BEGIN
description: BUFFALO, April 5As the jury in the Attica murder trial neared tonight's guilty verdicts in three days of deliberation, preparations were under way for a second major trial stemming fro mthe 1971 rebellion at the State Correctional Facility.

title: Dick Allen Wants to Play
description: PERKASIE, Pa., April 4The cold wind swept across the brown farmland and rattled the doors of the big red and white barn where Dick Allen was spreading fresh hay in a stall for one of his thoroughbred race horses. He had on a dark blue jockey helmet, with the chin strap dangling. He wore dark blue work clothes and black rubber boots. If he were wearing an Atlanta Braves uniform, he would be baseball's highest salaried player with a $250,000 contract. But, as baseball's most controversial and perhaps must gifted player, he chose not to report. With the season about to start, Dick Allen was swinging a pitchfork instead of a hat.

title: L.I.R.R. Rider Total Off
description: Tens of thousands of Long Island Rail Road riders have vanished from the line in the last decade, which was marked by four fare increases and the 50day strike of 197273.

title: Food
description: To the uninitiated palate, sushiraw fish served on riceis one of the gastronomic curiosities of the world. Some people, even those who dote on raw oysters and clams, find the thought of eating raw fish in any form bizarre.

title: Klein Steals a March in Suffolk And the Show From Democrats
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 5At 2:30 this morning nearly 2,000 Democrats were crowded into the ballroom of the Huntington Town House here, dancing and enjoying afterdinner drinks. Moving comfortably among them, a highball in this hand, was the man they all want to defeat this year. John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, who is a Republican.

title: CAPITOL HILL HAS FEUD OVER SPACE
description: WASHINGTON, April 5After Pierre L'Enfant had finished laying out this budding Federal city in 1791, he ran afoul of Daniel Carroll, a signer of the Articles of Confederation and major landholder here, who was building a home directly in the right of way of what the plans showed was to be New Jersey Avenue on Capitol Hill.

title: Miss Thurmond Wed To Carl Baumgardner
description: Martha Susan Thurmond, a publicrelations writer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long lines department, was married here yesterday afternoon to Carl M. Baumgardner, headquarters building engineer for A. T. & T. in Somerset. N.J.

title: DANCES OF INDIA GIVEN AT CUBICULO
description: Maya Kulkarni and Janak Khendry presented a concert of dances from India on Friday night at the Cubiculo, proving again that individuality and a classical form are not contradictory.

title: THE JOAN LITTLE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, N. C.The Beaufort County jail is in the basement of the county courthouse. One enters through a thick, soundproof door. Directly ahead is an office with a wall of video screens on which the jailers can watch the prisoners' every move. Off to one side, at the end of a corridor of cells, there is a twocell section separated from the rest of the block. It was here that Joan Little, black, 20 and sentenced to 7 to 10 years for breaking and entering, spent 81 days as the jail's only female inmate, in virtual solitary confinement, until the early hours of Aug. 27, 1974.

title: CYPRUS TALKS SET IN VIENNA APRIL 28
description: VIENNA, April 5 (UPI)Greek and Turkish Cypriots will hold talks in Vienna under United Nations auspices starting April 28 to find a settlement for the bitterly divided island, an Austrian Foreign Ministry spokesman announced today. Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations will mediate.

title: Malpractice Insurance Bill Hearing Opens Tuesday
description: TRENTON  Legislation designed to resolve the crisis surrounding the availability of malpractice insurance for hospitals and physicians in New Jersey will be the subject at a public hearing here Tuesday morning.

title: Dorothy Campbell Is a Bride Here
description: Dorothy Enos Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Burns Campbell of New York and Greenwich, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to William Richardson Bump, manager of telecommunications for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Nelson Bump of West Brattleboro, Vt.

title: Parent and Child: Milk is a fine food, but many kids and adults have drinking problems.
description: Before the advent of pasteurization, cow's milk was known to be a chancy product. Often contaminated, it produced epidemics of typhoid fever, tuberculosis and other infectious diseases. But pasteurization, which both killed the bacteria in milk and enabled it to be kept longer without spoiling, lent the product, in many countries, an almost mythical quality.

title: The Region
description: New York City's immediate and unusual financial problem, the absence of ready cash despite its huge but not liquid assets, has been solved in a temporary and unusual manner. New York State will borrow the money the city needs and give it to Mayor Beame so he can pay his bills..

title: ENGINEERS' GROUP ADDS 86 MEMBERS
What's Doing in BARCELONA
description: ANOTHER SPAIN  One of the great attractions of Spain is the variety of her regions. No region is more jealous of its own culture and traditions than Catalonia, in the northeast, where Barcelone is situated. Separatist feeling is not as strong there as it used to be, but many Catalonians still think of themselves as Catalan first and Spanish second and express this feeling in their own language, an ancient tongue akin to Provencal. Barcelona itself is not only full of life but has an outward look and cosmopolitanism not found in Madrid. Two universities and a large book publishing industry add a strong intellectual flavor. It is a city fascinated by politics and often in the middle of political and social conflict. A visitor out strolling may wander into a demonstration. That also is part of the city's tradition.

title: Mets: New Faces, Old Problems
description: My anxieties have been eased, Tom Seaver said as he reviewed the anxieties of spring training after his celebrated swoon of 1974. My left hip has felt fine all spring, I do my exercises every day, I get a massage from the trainer maybe six days a week and now I don't even feel any twinges across my back after running.

title: Art: The Chicago School at Trenton
description: TRENTONThe vigorous expressionism and surreal fantasy of the Chicago School of the nineteenfifties are represented in the paintings by Leon Golub and Peter Pasuntino that are now on view at the State Museum.

title: Dr. William Fischer Weds Miss Bartlett
description: Rebecca Bartlett was married here yesterday noon to Dr. William Fischer, an internist and director of the advanceddisease service at Roosevelt Hospital. The Rev. William Newell of the United Church of Christ performed the ceremony in the bridegroom's apartment.

title: Consumers Test Electronic Banking
description: BURBANK, Calif.Richard DeCarlo did his banking the other day at his supermarket.

title: New Yanks Call It Successful Spring
description: Since exhibition wonlost records are as meaningless as a $200 tax rebate for J. Paul Getty, the Yankees can fly north tomorrow satisfied that they have experienced a successful six weeks in spring training.

title: VATICAN IS DEFIED BY OUSTED ABBOT
description: ROME, April 5Ecclesiastical Rome is concerned over the case of a former Benedictine abbot suspended from the ministry, who defied the Vatican by offering an Easter mass and administering sacraments.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Cities are built and unbuilt by the forces of law and economics, supply and demand, cash flow and the bottom line, far more than by the ideals, intentions, talents and visions of architects and planners. Right now, the conventional wisdom about investment constructiontear down the old and put up the new for maximum return on the landis taking a beating. And so are cities, in terms of some of the things that the real estate recession is doing to the urban environment.

title: S.P.C.A. IS INDICTED IN ANIMAL DEATHS
description: DALLAS, April 5 (UPI)A grand jury indicted the Dallas Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals yesterday on charges of animal cruelty for the alleged misuse of a high altitude decompression chamber to destroy unwanted dogs and cats.

title: West Five Triumphs By 11089
description: TULSA, Okla., April 5 (AP)  Led by Gus Williams, a Southern California guard, the West turned a close contest into a rout early in the second half and posted a 11089 triumph over the East today in the Coaches AllStar basketball game.

title: Progress Intruding On Spain
description: ALFAZ DEL PI, SpainSigns daubed crudely on the rocks of this village proclaim El Robo del Siglothe robbery of the century. They are not touting a coming movie; they express local dismay over the Autopista, a toll expressway that Spanish Government concessionaires are pushing along the entire Mediterranean coast through rich almond and orange groves.

title: TV VIEW
description: When it comes to Monty Python's Flying Circus, reactions tend to run to extremes. Huw Weldon, TV managing director of the British Broadcasting Corporation, recently mused about having a deathbed choice between watching Monty Python or Jacob Bronowski or Kenneth Clark or some big program on science. I would definitely choose Monty Python,  he decided. At the other end of the scale, a nearhysterical mother recently called my office to complain that her boychild had been inadvertently exposed to the filth of a Monty Python episode the previous evening. Asked why her boychild was watching TV at 10:30 P.M. on a Sunday, she snarled and hung up.

title: Before Feeding Fido, Read Label for Nutritional Value
description: The clue to purchasing appropriate food for a dog is to read the label, according to researchers at the Quaker Oats Company, manufacturer of KenL Ration dog foods. Labels of commercially canned or packaged dog foods clearly give the nutritional contents, which are based on either biological testing or nutrient requirements.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I am happy to find that I am corrigible. A month or so ago I made a few capricious remarks in this column about three revivals I'd just seen, revivals calculated to discredit our entire theatrical pasts forever, if not forever and a day. In scolding their entrepreneurs for having mounted the precious plays at a sleepy time gait and without the least bit of illumination to help them find their ways home, I seemed to be sayingwas saying, to tell the truththat unless a producer, director, or actor was prepared to show me something new in a play I'd already seen 17 to 37 times, I wanted no part of him, her, or it. Shortly thereafter I was scolded in turn. Letters appeared in this newspaper's mail bag pointing out that no matter how many times I'd seen the plays, a great many people had never seen them at all and were grateful for the opportunity, vitaminenriched or no.

title: Plans for SST's at Kennedy Under Attack
description: Angry members of community planning boards and civic groups in Queens are organizing to face an issue with national and international implicationswhether supersonic planes (SST's) should be allowed to land at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

title: Commitment?
description: What, if anything, do the people and Government of the United States now owe to the people and Government of South Vietnam? This question does not admit of any easy answer, entangled as it is in considerations of ethical responsibility, political commitment, and strategic selfinterest, as well as the ambiguities of a shared history between a very powerful nation and a very weak one.

title: Article 10  No Title
FollowUp on The News
description: July 1, 1946: Operation Crossroads. The United States sets off the fourth atomicbomb explosion in history over Bikini, showering the 2.8squaremile atoll with dangerous radioactivity. Months before the test, 150 inhabitants of the Pacific island were uprooted and moved to Rongerik atoll, 109 miles away.

title: Jobless Pay: Fewer Trips
description: TRENTONIn a move designed to relieve the long lines and waiting at New Jersey's unemployment offices, the state plans to begin tomorrow a system under which persons seeking jobless benefits will be required to report only once a month.

title: Letters
description: Lots of good fish in the sea

title: Answers/Questions
description: CAMELLIAS UP NORTH (March 23) A: Mrs. K.E.B., Chatham, N. J., has been studying northern camellia culture but she is having difficulty finding information and source for hardy northern varieties. Herbert A. Mayer, a Long Island reader, and camellia enthusiast, suggests, Finding hardy camellia varieties at local metropolitan nurseries is hitormiss. The best course of action is to ask a reputable local nursery to obtain particular varieties. Order sizable plants (one gallon container or larger) and plant camellias in the spring so that they get a good start. They must have a wellestablished root system that penetrates below the frost line for the next winter. Locate camellias so that they are protected from excessive winter sun and wind. The Camellia japonica variety Kumasaka var. performed well in many locations on Long Island. Other good japonicas are Berenice Boddy, Blood of China, Chandler Elegans, Glen 40, Grandiflora Rosea and Triphosa.

title: U.S. POLICY SCORED BY CHIEF OF AIRLINE
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 15 (AP)The president of World Airways, Edward J. Daly, who flew more than 50 Vietnamese orphans here from Saigon this week, has accused the United States Army and State Department of failing to cooperate with his airline's offers of more assistance.

title: Chichicastenango Unit Dances In Athletic and Eccentric Style
description: Chichicastenango is the deceptively florid name of Marya Warshaw's company of sixj women who dance her somewhat austere works. The group presented three new pieces Friday evening at Choreoground in the Morelli Dance Center that were pleasantly athletic and slightly eccentric.

title: Louis Broido, 79, Who Headed City Commerce A gency, Is Dead
description: Louis Broido, Commissioner of Commerce and Industrial Development under Mayors Robert Wagner and John V. Lindsay, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 20 Sutton Place South.

title: New&Novel
description: Anne Rider has already been compared with Iris Murdoch, Harold Pinter and E. M. Forster, which may be because Miss Rider offers a dazzling change of pace in each of her novels. This one is an ironic entertainment reminiscent of Graham Greene, and an elegant lightness of touch characterizes her approach even to moral considerations.

title: Green port Artisan Practices Vanishing Craft of Scrimshaw
description: GREENPORTA. Douglas Jacobs is in a quandary. As a conservationist he fully supports efforts to preserve endangered species. But Mr. Jacobs is also a scrimshaw artist, and the laws designed to protect whales may put him out of business after he has used up the stock of teeth and bones he purchased before 1971.

title: CITY GROWTH UNIT WEIGHS PROJECTS
description: The city's Industrial Development Agency, which was created last year to attract businesses to New York through a variety of tax inducements, is in the process of completing work on its first half dozen applications from interested companies. Under the agency's charter from the State Legislature it may issue taxfree bonds to finance projects that would lead to the creation of jobs here. The projects may be undertaken either by an existing company that is expanding or by a new company that is moving in.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Here's a new noun to add to your collection: serial, as in THE ROBESPIERRE SERIAL by Nicholas. Luard (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95). It joins such nouns as operation, transfer, arrangement, allegation, combination, conspiracy, dossier, exchange and code. All mean pretty much the same thing. When you see them in a book title, that means an espionage novel. There may also be something in the fact that they all start with The. As for instance: The Yermakov Transfer, The Rhinemann Exchange, The Peking Switch, The Miernik Dossier, The Brahmin Arrangement. There's a deep, hidden meaning around somewhere.

title: Oldfield's 726 Best In ShotPut
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP)Brian Oldfield put the shot farther than anyone in the world had before and said, I tell you, it felt effortless.

title: Rachel Wolfson, Haifa Student, Will Be Bride of Brent Dibner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rachmony Wolfson of Haifa, Israel, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rachel Wolfson, to Brent Dibner. son of Mr. and Mrs. David Dibner of Wilton, Conn.

title: Freed Rhodesian Nationalist Flies to Tanzania Meeting
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 5 (Reuters)The Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, the African Nationalist leader who was freed from detention yesterday by the Rhodesian Government, left here today for Tanzania to attend a meeting of the Organization of African Unity.

title: The Primary Question
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Apr. 5As the nation approaches its 200th anniversary and its 47th Presidential electionit is still groping for a satisfactory method of choosing its Presidents. For the moment, as illustrated here in Texas, the emphasis seems to have shifted from electoral college reform, which seemed so likely in 1969, to the problem of picking party nominees.

title: Bluegrass, Mostly for Love
description: MORRISTOWN  For the last four years, Don Kissil has maintained an almostunblemished record of financial failure in presenting bluegrass groups in this area. But it was not until this year that his losses bothered him.

title: An Examination of How Key Provisions Were Arrived At
description: WASHINGTONThe Tax Deduction Act of 1975, which President Ford signed with such reluctance last weekend, is the most important legislation passed so far by the new Congress. Some of its provisions, chiefly the partial repeal of the oil depletion allowance, probably could not have been enacted without the reforms of Congressional procedures and changes in Congressional personnel that bave taken place in the past several years.

title: BEAME PLANS BILL ON BUILDING GRAFT
description: Mayor Beame intends to ask the City Council shortly to enact legislation to overcome corruption in the construction industry.

title: Cornell Lacrosse Victor
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5 (AP)Mike French scored five goals and had three assists in leading unbeaten Cornell to a 167 lacrosse victory over Navy today.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: For most owners of 35mm cameras with interchangeable lens capability, the most useful second lens is a long focus lensthat is, one with a focal length that is longer than the normal lens for a 35mm image (the usual normal lens is 50mm).

title: TonyAward Nominee From Queens
description: When the nominations for the American Theater Wing's 1975 Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards were announced recently, with such candidates as Shenandoah, The Wiz and Mack and Mabel for best Broadway musical was The Lieutenanta production conceived, created and first nurtured in Queens.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: GOST CHALLENGED ON NURSING HOME
description: The State Health Department, in a major reversal of policy, has ruled that the Park Crescent Nursing Home overstated its building costs by nearly $2million and has moved to recover $900,000 in alleged Medicaid overpayments to date.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: The Dollar's Down, But Not Out
description: From the Persian Gulf to the English Channel, a broad retreat from the United States dollar appears to be picking up speed.

title: Samuel Shaw, Lawyer, Weds Nancy Bridge
description: Nancy A. Bridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Bridge of Chevy Chase, Md., was married in All Saints Episcopal Church there yesterday morning to Samuel R. Shaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvil Thomas Shaw Jr. of Coldwater, Mich. The Rev. Richard A. Miller performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. M. T. Shaw 3d, brother of the bridegroom.

title: The World
description: The parties involved in the Middle East are reassessing the policies that have produced only repeated warfare for 27 years, following the failure of Secretary of State Kissinger's latest effort at personal mediation. With varying degrees of enthusiasm, the parties are preparing for a Geneva peace conference. But it is evident that in the interim some nations are willing to try again for limited agreements.

title: Workshop to Air Job Assertiveness
description: PARAMUS  Asserting Yourself on the job and in Personal Relationships, an allday workshop in assertiveness training for women, will be held in the Community Room at Paramus Park shopping center next Saturday. The session will be led by Janice LaRouche, a career counselor, and Dr. Penelope Russianoff, a psychologist.

title: Headliners
description: President Ford has nominated Stanley K. Hathaway to be Secretary of the Interior, and the appointment is meeting with considerable opposition. As a twoterm Governor of Wyoming, Mr. Hathaway pursued proindustry policies, and was especially close to stripmine developers. Although Wyoming needed new business investments in 1966, when Mr. Hathaway began serving his first term, environmentalists have been sharply critical of his conduct. Even Mr. Hathaway now admits he may have been a bit overeager. Still, there is some speculation that President Ford, angered by the stripmining bill passed over his veto recently, was using the Hathaway appointment to signal his stillvehement views in favor of the strip miners.

title: Public Hearings Listed By City Council Units
description: The following public hearings of City Council committees will be held this week:

title: Haldeman Is No More Innocent Than I Am
description: Bob Haldeman is innocent. That was the message Haldeman gave some 26 million people who watched the twopart CBS News special Haldeman: The Nixon Years Conversations with Mike Wallace, broadcast by CBS the past two Sundays. Haldeman's protestations of innocence ran throughout the nearly, two hours of conversation and a viewer could conclude from what was shown that Haldeman really believes he is innocent. In truth. Bob Haldeman is no more innocent than I am.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. St. Louis

title: WHITE HOUSE DENIES APPEAL ON REFUGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) The White House has rejected a protest by conservationists against a decision to put three national wildlife refuges under the Bureau of Land Management rather than under the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: 2 Embassies Close in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 5With the insurgents continuing to test the unevenly manned defense perimeter around Phnom Penh today, two more embassies closed their doors and the Americans appeared to be speeding their departure.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON The Revolutionary Congressional. budget reform law enacted last year was hailed by many as a turning point in giving Congress more control over its own propensity to spend.

title: Nancy Jean Steinhardt Married To Stephen Fuzesi Jr., Lawyer
description: Nancy Jean Steinhardt, a psychiatric social worker, was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Fuzesi Jr., a lawyer with the firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell.

title: Births
description: Browne

title: Guest's Horse Victor
description: AINTREE, England, April 5  L'Escargot, old but as graceful as ever, showed improvement for the third straight year today and was finally able to catch and pass Red Rum in the Grand National, the world's premier steeplechase race.

title: Article 7  No Title
Ellen S. Phelps Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Walter Phelps Jr. of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Sheffield Phelps, to the Rev. Donald Joseph Schell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Newton Schell of San Jose, Calif.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Rancocas to Defend Its Forensic Title
description: WEST LONG BRANCHThe Monmouth College Department of Speech Communication and Theater Arts will hold its fourth annual High School Forensic Tournament on April 19. According to Prof. William A. Yaremchuk, tournament founder and director, students from more than 35 high schools throughout New Jersey will participate.

title: Oil or Israel?
description: There is a deep and disturbing counterpoint to Henry Kissinger's flying diplomacy (now grounded) in the Middle East. It is the feeling here at homeand particularly among the Eastern Establishment that the traditional American support for Israel is crumbling and that antiSemitism may be on the rise. Put somewhat differently, in the prospective tradeoff between the need to get along with the oilrich Arabs and sympathy for the Jewish state, the Jews are going to be the losers.

title: Garden State Woes Continue to Mount
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 5  Spitefulness, greed and compromise continued to run one, two, three on the local thoroughbred scene today as onceproud Garden State Park limped through its 21st week of headtohead competition against nearby Keystone Race Track.

title: Bistate Vehicular Traffic Appears Heading for Record High
description: NEWARKVehicular travel between New Jersey and New York City, as measured at the Port Authority's six toll facilitiesthe Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, the George Washington Bridge and three spans to Staten Islandseems to be on the way to a record high.

title: Nancy E. Tressel Is Bride of Irwin Frank
description: Nancy Elizabeth Tressel, editor of the scholarly books division of the McGrawHill Book Company, was married yesterday morning to Irwin Frank, a general executive with The Associated Press. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home by State Supreme Court Justice Leonard Scholnick.

title: Flooding Tries Aging Roselle Park
description: ROSELLE PARK  What can you do? You curse, scream, holler a lot and start the pumps. That is how Dennis Ryan described this Union County borough's principal response to its major problem: flooding of the business district after a storm. Merchants and residents report that the area on Chestnut Street from Warren Avenue to Westfield Avenue is impassable whenever it rains and that no business can be transacted.

title: Chinatown's Leaders Plan to Commemorate Chiang
description: The flag of Nationalist China flutered at half staff yesterday evening outside the Chinese Community Center on Mott Street as Chinatown's civic leaders began to plan special observances next week to honor the memory of President Chiang Kaishek.

title: John Wallace to Wed Catherine Hess
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hess of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Ann Hess, to John Crawford Wallace, son of Mrs. Roy S. Wallace Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Wallace who was vice president of the CIT Corporation here. Mr. Hess is a trust officer at the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONThe regime of South Vietnam was effectively created in the summer of 1954. In the spring of 1975, it is perishing. Its creation as one of two zones of Vietnam by the Geneva conference marked the end of a terrible colonial war. Its impending demise, 10 years after American forces splashed ashore at Da Nang and more than two years after the last American troops departed in the name of the 1973 Paris peace accord, marks the end of a grim civil war.

title: Captain America Takes Show Title
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 5  Kathy Whelen's Captain America won two classes and finished second in another today and captured the limit working hunter championship at the New Canaan Mounted Troop Horse Show.

title: Panel Will Discuss Access to Beaches
description: LINCROFT  A panel discussion on legislation designed to provide the public with greater access to the state's beaches will be held at Brookdale Community College Wednesday night.

title: Plainedge Wins Relay
description: WANTAGH, L. 1., April 5 Plainedge High School captured the 880yard relay today in the Nassau County Scholastic Relay Carnival at the Wantagh field. The Plainsmen clocked 1 minute 33.2 seconds in cold windy weather. Among the other victors were: Calhoun in the sprint medley, Berner in the distance medley and Southside in the fourmile event.

title: Miss Pritchard To Wed May 17
description: Mary Manion Pritchard, a photographer here, and Charles Patrick Durkin Jr., a managing director of Dillon, Read & Co., investment bankers, plan to be married May 17 in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Beebe Of Boston Bank
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Eldridge Beebe of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Lake Placid, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Holloway Beebe, to Kenneth Emerson Knowles 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Knowles Jr. of Oyster Bay.

title: NATO CONSIDERING A SUMMIT MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The 15member North Atlantic Treaty Organization is considering a meeting of heads off government in Brussels at the end of May to reassert principles of Western unity, diplomatic officials reported today.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The road to economic reform has been marked by legendary frauds which have implicated the high and the mighty, toppling governments and leading statesmen. Some of today's frauds such as that of the Equity Funding Corporation, also will become legends, but the people implicated are faceless entrepreneurs whose victims are the investing Public.

title: WristWrestler Bids for Giant Berth
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., April 5Can a wristwrestling champion from Brooklyn, with no college or pro football experience, find a job and happiness in the National Football League?

title: U. of Vermont Raises Tuition
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., April 5 (AP)The University of Vermont's board of trustees raised student tuition today by $150 for Vermont residents and $280 for outofstaters? All increases become effective this fall. The new tuition for Vermonters will be $1,100, up from new tuition will be $2,930, up from $2.650.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Festoon yourself with kisses. Stick a safety pin through each earlobe. Slip a bar of Ivory soap onto your finger. It's not really as bizarre as it sounds. It's just that Noma Copley, a goldsmith known for her witty way of elevating mundane objects, is into something newthe design and manufacture of what she calls multiples. Which means that her amusing ornaments are now available in quantity, at prices comparatively easy on the pocketbook.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: In India when gurus die, it is said, they are reincarnated as elephants. Or is it the other way around? Anyway, here we are at the spectacular bicentennial backstage of the, spectacular bicentennial edition of Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circuswhich just opened a twomonth engagement in our own Madison Square Gardenlooking at a long row of shackled exguitis or gurustobe. One is sucking his trunk. Elephants are too smart, we had been told by Gunther GebelWilliams, the world's greatest animal trainer and star of the show. I think they're at least as smart as dolphins. They have their own system of bosses in the wildthe oldest female runs the herd and the males just stand around and guard everybody. But I'm the boss here, and I have to tell them that every day. Indian elephants aren't so bad: you can push them around. The African elephant is completely different. You have to take things very slow, let them learn at their own pace, and don't ever raise your hand to an African elephant. He'll never forget, and he'll make you feel guilty about it for the rest of your life.

title: Fordham Takes 8Oar Cup Race
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 5  Fordham University's varsity eightoared crew crushed St. John's by seven lengths, with Manhattan College five more lengths astern in the 13th annual Grimaldi Cup regatta today on the Orchard Beach lagoon.

title: 4 HEED IN SEARCH FOR MISS HEARST
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., April 5 (AP)An armed raiding party in search of Patricia Hearst arrested four persons and seized bomb materials and radical writings but did not find the fugitive daughter of Randolph A. Hearst, editor and publisher of The San Franciso Examiner, the authorities said today.

title: Weddings
description: PonvertAvenengo

title: Program Aids Elderly in Their Homes
description: GLEN COVEThe elderly of northeast Nassau County are the focus of a new program based here that combines counseling with health care to help maintain them in their own homes.

title: College Instructors Linked to a Fraud Over V.A. Benefits
description: PHOENIX, April 5Several Arizona Western College instructors apparently illegally obtained Veterans Administration benefits by enrolling themselves in their own classes, a V.A. official says.

title: Indians Sue Michigan Officials, Charging False Imprisonment
description: PETOSKEY, Mich., April 5For the first time, Michigan Indians, using their claim to Federal treaty guaranteedhunting and fishing rights, have taken the legal offensive against state authorities.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The major league season officially opens tomorrow, but New Yorkers will have to wait until Tuesday afternoon when the Mets play the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium. After an open date Wednesday, the Mets will meet the Phillies at Shea Stadium again on Thursday. On Friday, the Yankees will move into Shea against the Detroit Tigers. Single afternoon games are listed for Friday and Saturday, with a doubleheader against the Tigers next Sunday. The Mets start their weekday afternoon games at 2:05, the Yankees at 2 o'clock. The Yankees' Sunday twin bill will begin at 1 P. M.

title: Aiken Is Named Professor At University of Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., April 5 (AP)Former Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, was named a full professor today at the University of Vermont.

title: The AllGay Cruise: Prejudice and Pride
description: TWO speakers the size of steamer trunks blasted rock music off the fantail deck one evening as the Renaissance lay docked in a sleepy Mexican port. Merchant seamen on a nearby Brazilian ship put down their mops and elbowed the rail to get closer look at  olha!  boys dancing with boys. The seamen guffawed, poked each other, waved enticingly; three or four started to dance, but the parody was quickly stared down by their shipmates. Up on the Renaissance bridge, some starchy French officers watched tolerantly at first until finally they were moved to grins and restrained toetapping. Below them on the main deck, 50 boys did The Bump as Labelle sang Voulezvous coucher avec moi, ce soir?her invitation echoing over the village, out across the waters, deep into the jungle dusk.

title: Nets Hoping Paultz Can Play Today
description: The first round of the American Basketball Association playoffs for the New York Nets gets under way this afternoon at 2:35 against the Spirits of St. Louis in the Nassau Coliseum. The key to the Nets repeating as league champions revolves around the health of Billy Paultz, their center.

title: In Geneva, the Third Basket Is a Beginning of Expanded EastWest Contacts
description: GENEVAThe European Security Conference here is reaching its final phase after nearly twoandahalf years of negotiation. The shape is emerging of what the West is probably going to get in the way of improving EastWest human contacts, in return for its endorsement of the territorial status quo created the wake of World War If.

title: Hockey Realignment Makes Fan a Winner
description: In the confusion of hockey's last weekend, in which conference titles, division championships and playoff berths remained undecided, the only certain winner was the fan.
