description: Dr. Deanne Arkus Klein, a musicologist who was former program coordinator for the International Music Council at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris, died yesterday liat her home, 14415 41st Avenue, Flushing, Queens. She was 40 years old.

title: Syracuse Again Seeking a Dean of Law
description: SYRACUSEA familiar rite of spring is taking place at the Syracuse University College of Law. For the fifth time in the last five years a search for a new dean has begun.

title: Union City Students Discuss the Slaying Of 2 Hall Children
description: UNION CITY, April 7The slaying of two classmates dominated the conversations among the students of Thomas A. Edison elementary school, who returned from their Easter vacation this morning.

title: FORD BIDS NATION RESIST SELFDOUBT
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. April 7President Ford ended an, eightday vacation today urging Americans not to give in to selfdoubt or paralysis of willpower.

title: CHIEF PROSECUTOR ON ATTICA ACCUSED OF JURY COYERUP
description: A key member of the Attica special prosecutor's office has resigned and charged the chief prosecutor, Anthony G. Simonetti, with covering up possible crimes by lawenforcement officers who put down the rebellion at Attica prison in Sepember, 1971.

title: Vietcong Ask Aid
description: GENEVA, April 7The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government would like international help to make the airfields that they have taken over at Da Nang and Hue operational again, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: Osteen Joins White Sox
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April (AP)Claude Ostern, a lefthander, was added to the Chicago White Sox pitching staff foray, and Bart Johnson, a righthander, was to be placed on the 21day disabled list with a severe back strain.

title: Joint Chiefs' Head Sparks Confusion Over Vietnam Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Defense Department and its military chief, Gen. George S. Brown, first seemed to reopen and then to foreclose today the possibility that the United States might reintroduce military forces into South Vietnam.

title: List of Persons Who Wrote Rodino Unit to Be Destroyed
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  Computer tapes containing the names and addresses of persons who sent letters disclosing their attitude on the mpeachment of President Nixon to the House Judiciary Committee have been ordered destroyed.

title: TIMES EDITOR PRODS PRESS ON REPORTING
description: BALTIMORE, April 7 (UPI)The greatest problems facing the press in the United States are the unwillingness of publishers and broadcasters to spend the money needed for good reporting, the constant danger of Government distortion of information and judicial encroachments on the First Amendment, according to A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The New York Times.

title: 3 STATIONS CANCEL 64,000 QUESTION
description: The three CBS television stations that bought the syndicated revival of The $64,000 Question, one of the most successful bigmoney quiz shows of the late nineteenfifties, have canceled the agreement.

title: City Sees Chance to Get Voice on Port Authority
description: ALBANY, April 7A bill to give the Mayor of New York City the right to appoint one member to an expanded Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has a good chance of approval, the city's lobbyists here said today.

title: Helicopter Program
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. April 7 (UPI)Mr. Hughes sought to continue the war in Vietnam until he could recover losses in his helicopter program, The Las Vegas Sun reported today.

title: Strip Mine Group to Protest in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 7A convoy of chartered buses and more than 408 coal trucks brought 1,000 strip mine workers and their supporters to Washington tonight to lobby and demonstrate tomorrow against the Federal surface mine control bill now pending in Congress.

title: Chiang Mourned in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 7South Koreans widely expressed sorrow today over the death of General Chiang. President Park Chung Hee yesterday sent separate messages of condolence to Taipei to C. K. Yen, the new President, to Mrs. Chiang and to Premier Chiang Chingkuo.

title: $183,000 Is Raised By Marines School, Averting Shutdown
description: The Mannes College of Music, the 59yearold conservatory on East 74th Street that recently announced it would have to shut down because of financial problems, has been saved. Officials of the school said yesterday that $183,000 had been raised from foundations and private citizens, in cash and in pledges and that $50,000 more would be available in May. The school had reported that unless $200,000 could be raised by yesterday to meet the current budget deficit, the school could not continue to function.

title: Bundy Denies Any Assassination Plots
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 McGeorge, Bundy, President Kennedy's aide for national security affairs, said today that he had told the Rockefeller Commission that he had no recollection of plots to assassinate foreign leaders or of formal discussions of such plans during his White House tenure.

title: FORD BIDS NATION RESIST SELFDOUBT
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. April 7President Ford ended an eightday vacation today urging Americans not to give in to selfdoubt or paralysis of willpower.

title: I.R.S. CHIEF ASKS OUTSIDE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The head of the Internal Revenue Service said today that there was need for an outside investigation of allegations of corruption and improper activities by the tax agency.

title: Grossi, Under Fire in Jersey, Retiring as President of P.U.C
description: TRENTON, April 7 Governor Byrne confirmed today that Anthony J. Grossi was retiring as president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, thus easing the mounting political pressure on the cabinet officer since charges of corruption were lodged against him last October.

title: Communist Gunners Shell at Least 10 District Capitals in the Mekong Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 8 (AP)North Vietnamese gunners shelled at least 10 district capitals in the Mekong Delta yesterday, with most of the fire concentrated on targets within 35 miles of Saigon.

title: CHECKS PROPOSED FROM PASSBOOKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The line between checking and savings accounts became a bit more blurred as the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed today to let banks offer savings depositors the new service of paying their bills from those accounts.

title: TB DRUG DOUBTED ON LEUKEMIA ROLE
description: BETHESDA, Md., April 7Experience involving many thousands of persons in the United States and abroad casts doubt on the hope that the tuberculosis vaccine BCG can protect against human leukemia, according to a report today to a research conference at the National Cancer Institute.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 7yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: BENJAMIN H. BALSER PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Benjamin H. Balser, a neuropsychiatrist and associate clinical professor at Columbia University, died yesterday at his home, 707A River Vale Road, Orangeburg, N. J. He was 69 years old.

title: Gromyko Sees Egyptian
description: MOSCOW, April 7The Soviet Union gave the first public indication today that it was working toward a resumption of the Geneva conference.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, April 7 (AP)Trying to avoid a cheese war with Europe, the United States Government has dropped its insistence that the Common Market abandon all subsidies on the export of cheese to the United States, Common Market officials said today.

title: Syracuse Again Seeking a Dean of Law
description: SYRACUSEA familiar rite of spring is taking place at the Syracuse University College of Law. For the fifth time in the last five years a search for a new dean has begun.

title: In Memoriam
description: LONDONEmanuel, D.D.S. In loving memory of a devoted and gallant spirit. JACOUIE, MAURY and Grandchildren.

title: Limitations Statute Ends On Nixon Drive Donors
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) The statute of limitations ran out today for further Watergate prosecution of donors of the $20million that poured into Richard M. Nixon's reelection committee before a new disclosure law became effective.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 8, 1975

title: Cardenal Passes Test
description: CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) Jose Cardenal, Chicago Cubs outfielder, underwent an eye examination today and was pronounced fit to play on Thursday in the season opener against the Pittsburgh Pirates. Cardenal had complained of blurry vision.

title: Rebels Overrun Outposts Near Phnom Penh Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 7Phnom Penh's defense perimeter shrank again today as insurgents overran some outposts four miles north of Pochentong Airport.

title: The Bases Are F.O.B.
description: TALLAHASSEE, FLA. Opening day at Ebbets Field in 1939 wasn't concerned with capital gains, demands by the players' union, stipulations by the umpires' association, television coverage and its enormous income.

title: H. C. JACOBS DIES; EXAIDE OF H.E.W
description: Haskell Chares Jacobs, a lawyer specializing in social service, died Sunday in Arlington, Va., wher he lived. He was 66 years old.

title: Conflict of Interest By U.F.T.'s Store Charged by Dealer
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that he would ask city school officials to check records of the school system's purchases from a supply store run by the United Federation of Teachers, to determine whether a conflict of interest existed.

title: Students Try Tuition Switch
description: IOWA CITY, April 7 (AP)Some students at the University of Iowa are trying a new ploy to avoid paying outofstate tuition. They say ownership of a cemetery plot in Iowa qualifies them for the lower resident tuition rates. University officials disagree and the students say they may force a court test.

title: Beauty Industry Licensing: It's a Paradoxical System
description: A woman may get her hair cut by a barber, but her husband may not have his long locks trimmed by her hairdresser.

title: KISSINGER WARY OF MIDEAST ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Israel and Egypt have informed the United States of their interests in a new American mediation effort, but so far neither side has shown any readiness for concessions to break the impasse that led to the collapse of Secretary of State Kissinger's last mission.

title: Prof. Michael Doudoroff, 63, Helped Synthesize Sugar
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 7Michael Doudoroff, a molecular biologist who took part in the first laboratory synthesis of sugar, died of cancer Friday in Oakland. He was 63 years old.

title: MGM Net Climbs in Quarter and Half
description: MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., yesterday reported the highest earnings in several years for the quarter and halfyear ended Feb. 28. The increases, of 58.8 per cent for the quarter and 37.6 per cent for the sixmonth period, are primarily from its prospering Grand Hotel operations and the film That's Entertainment.

title: School SitIn Backs Fuentes's Claim to District 1 Post
description: A group of supporters of Luis Fuentes began a sitin at Junior High School 81 on the Lower East Side last night to demonstrate support for his contention that he is the rightful superintendent of Community School District 1.

title: Thieu's Palace Is Attacked By One of Saigon's Planes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 8  A South Vietnamese plane attacked the presidential palace with bombs and machinegun tire this morning in an evident effort to kill President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Bridge:
description: This district final of the grand national team championship at the Essex Bridge Center, West Orange, N.J. during the weekend produced a desperately close finish. A strong sextet headed by Arch McKellar of Millwood, N.Y., squeezed through to victory by two international match points against an equally redoubtable foursome led by Jeff Rubens of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Music: Glorious Moment
description: Hack work is too strong term for it, but like almost all the master composers of the past Beethoven produced a fairly stedy flow of ordinary madetoorder music along with his Eroicas and Emperors. Since ordinary Beethoven can sometimes be more than ordinarily interesting, it is too bad that more isn't made available to us in enthusiastic performances of the sort that Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonia gave to the cantata Der glorreiche Augenblick on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Grossi Is Retiring As Head of P.U.C
description: TRENTON, April 7 Governor Byrne confirmed today that Anthony J. Grossi was retiring as president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, thus easing the mounting political pressure on the cabinet officer since charges of corruption were lodged against him last October.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTOIN  The handgun played a valuable role in helping win the West. But its value on the urban frontier is less clear.

title: EDWIN F. THAYER
description: Edwin F. Thayer, who retired in 1963 as publisher of Industrial Marketing magazine and who was publisher of Tide magazine from 1943 to 1949, died yesterday in Saybrook Convalescent Hospital in Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived at 61 Briarwood Drive in Old Savbrook.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: ROSCOE, N.Y.A snowplow is grinding past, the wind is gusting to 45 miles an hour, the temperature is in the low 20's and it is the third day of the troutfishing season.

title: How About That!!
description: STAMFORD, CONN. Baseball fever is upon us as we eagerly await the renewal of one of America's most venerable traditions, opening day.

title: Beame Is Upbeat Over the Cultural Life of the City
description: Mayor Beame, who will today take the first steps toward a revision of the city's approach to cultural affairs, emphasized yesterday not only what New York can do for the artsat no extra cost but also what the arts do for New York.

title: STOCKS RETREAT IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market incurred its sixth consecutive setback yesterday in the second slowest trading session of the year.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: ROSCOE, N.Y.A snowplow is grinding past, the wind is gusting to 45 miles an hour, the temperature is in the low 20's and it is the third day of the troutfishing season.

title: Business Records
description: Monday, April 7, 1975

title: Newest Nonsmokers Celebrate Nonsmoking
description: Amid the napery and lunchtime chatter of the nosmoking room at Rosoff's restaurant yesterday, a happy group of 16 people who had first met five weeks ago sat down and talked like old friends. There were a lot of kidding requests for cigarettes, accounts of tobaccohaunted dreams and sudden cravings for Milky Way candy bars, and a few pairs of hands that played constantly with cutlery, swizzle sticks and fruit compotes.

title: SOUTH AFRICA OPENS A URANIUM PROJECT
description: CAPETOWN, April 7  A pilot plant for the enrichment of uranium has gone into operation in South Africa. Disclosing this in Parliament today, Prime Minister John Vorster said it would enable the country to proceed with the production of enriched uranium for commercial purposes.

title: Margaret Black Is Wed to C. E. Carney
description: Margaret Chambers Black, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Howard Black Jr. of Harwich, Mass., and Marco Island, Fla., and formerly of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Edward Carney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Carney of Marco Island.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 7 (AP)Victor Galindez of Argentina staged a late comeback to defeat a South African challenger, Pierre Fourie, and retain the World Boxing Association lightheavyweight boxing title tonight.

title: Angels, Ryan, 32 Winners
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April (AP)  Nolan Ryan fired a threehitter, struck out 12, and the California Angels rallied for two runs in the ninth inning to beat Steve Busby and the Kansas City Royals, 32, tonight in the opening game of the American League baseball season.

title: Soviet Has Trade Surplus With West, C.I.A. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Soviet Union's balance of trade with the West swung into surplus last year after years of deficits because of much higher prices for oil, gold and other Soviet exports, a new study by the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded.

title: Ford Back in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  The President returned to Washington tonight, arriving at Andrews Air Force Base at 9:21.

title: Princeton U. Discloses BusinessHousing Plan
description: PRINCETON, April 7Princeton University officials) today unveiled plans for a 1,604acre multipleuse development to be built at the James Forrestal Research Campus in Plainsboro Township.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: DR. AARON SOBEL
description: Dr. Aaron Sobel, retired chief of urology at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., died there Sunday. He was 89 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie.

title: Knicks' Experience Worrying Rockets
description: John Egan, the Houston Rockets' coach, knows the value of experience, and he knows all about backcourt men. He played 10 seasons as a backcourt man in the National Basketball Association with five teams, including two seasons with the Knicks. That's why he has some fears as the teams open a twoofthreegame playoff series tonight in Houston.

title: FED INTEREST RANGE ON FUNDS LOWERED
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee sharply lowered its target range for the key Federal funds interest rate at its meeting of Feb. 19, in order to spur the lagging growth of the nation's money supply, it was disclosed today.

title: Robinson Calm for Debut as Indian Pilot
description: CLEVELAND, April 7He was only 24 hours away from making history as baseball's first black manager, but Frank Robinson had a more pressing problem to worry about todayparking passes for his players for tomorrow's openingday game with the New York Yankees.

title: Charles Hoff, Photographed The Hindenburg Burning
description: Charles Hoff, a newspaper photographer who captured the German dirigible Hindbenburg bursting into flames at Lakehurst, N.J., in 1937, died yesterday of a stroke at his home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 70 years old. e myears,

title: Notes on People
description: Arriving in Hong Kong from Peking, House Speaker Carl Albert said there could be no regular diplomatic relations between the United States and China under the present circumstances but that Chinese leaders showed understanding and patience concerning the American position on Taiwan.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Washington Meeting on Children's Airlift Is Jarred by Charges of Racism and Elitism
description: WASHINGTON, April 7An informal conference organized by a Congressman in the hope of speeding the airlift of South Vietnamese children was jarred soon after it began today by charges of litism and racism.

title: Builder Testifies He Gave Money to Aide of Gurney
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 7 (UPI)A south Florida builder testified today that he made payoffs in 1971 to Senator Edward J. Guerney's fundraiser, Larry Williams, who then introduced him to a Federal Housing Administration director as a great friend of the Republican patty.

title: FRANK PREMACK
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 7 (AP) Frank Premack, chief of The Minneapolis Tribune's special reporting team, died today after suffering a heart attack. he was 42 years old.

title: 4 Are Indicted in Slaying Of Retired Postal Worker
description: A Bronx grand jury indicted four men yesterday for the beating death of an 83yearold retired postal worker on the night of Feb. 22. District Attorney Mario Merola said. The four were arrested March 21 after an intensive police investigation.

title: The Ethnic Turks of Greece: An Island Left Behind by a Receding Empire
description: KOMOTINE, GreeceMost of the ethnic Turkish women of Komotine go out in public in long black dresses and veils that cover everything but a small circle of wellscrubbed face. Only when they are indoors will some of the younger ones doff the traditional costume, revealing modern clothes.

title: TRIBUNE CO. GIVES EARNINGS DETAILS
description: CHICAGO, April 7  The Tribune Company, which publishes The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News, New York, today released a breakdown of its earnings and revenues for the first time. The privately held Chicagobased, company previously reported only overall revenue and profit figures.

title: Seaver to Oppose Phils' Carlton in Opener at Shea
description: Baseball returns to town today after a sixmonth absence when the Mets open their 162  game season against the Philadelphia Phillies and in a broader sense open the new Battle of New York against the revivedYankees.

title: West Files Suit Against Lakers
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 7 (UPI)Jerry West, former Los Angeles Lakers basketball star, today filed a breach of contract suit against the team owner, Jack Kent Cooke, and his corporalion, charging them with reneging on an agreement that would have paid West more than $1million after his retirement.

title: RECESSION AID PLAN TIED TO JOBS RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Legislation to provide multibilliondollar assistance to state and local governments to help cushion the impact of recession was introduced today by two senior Democratic Senators, Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIGH AND GROOVY Tuesday night is bargain night in a midtown penthouse that has professional jazz, reasonably priced drinks and a spectacular view. Once a week from 5:30 P.M. to 8:30 P.M., the New York Art Director's Club, atop the Look Building at 488 Madison Avenue (near 52d Street), opens its doors fcr goodwill jam sessions featuring jazz names and a resident quartet. Last week there were about 60 twilight listeners  couples, singles, office workers heading home or to midtown dinners and shows.

title: Corning Glass Ending Fair Trade Pricing
description: CORNING, N. Y., April (AP)  The Corning Glass Works announced today that it was discontinuing socalled fair trade price fixing arrangements that have come under attack by consumer advocates.

title: P.U.C.Panel for Rate Rise To Jersey Central Power
description: NEWARK, April 7  The State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners has been urged by a panel of its hearing examiners to approve a $28.7million rate increase requested by Jersey Central Power and Light Company, and to establish, for the first time in New Jersey, a summer electricity billing differential for residential customers.

title: Phone Service Back In Afflicted Section, Company Maintains
description: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that except for some special services, disruptions on the Lower. East Side caused by the major switchingcenter fire on Feb. 27 had been cleared up. However, some customers still reported lessthannerfect service.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 8 (AP)The Soviet Union rallied from a onegoal firstperiod deficit today, and heat Czechoslovakia, 52, taking a major step toward its 14th world ice hockey title. In an exciting match of the cofavorites, highlighting the first round of the Group A tournament, the Soviet Union, the defending champion, outskated its rivals in the last two period's with an awesome offensive assault.

title: State Investigation Panel Looks Into Bank's Loans to Monserrat
description: The State Commission of Investigation is looking into personal bank loans made to Joseph Monserrat, a member and former president of the city Board of Education, in connection with its inquiry into the way school contracts are awarded.

title: Zarb Says a Grand Jury Balked Oil Price Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Federal Energy Administrator, Frank G. Zarb, complained in an official letter in February that a grand jury investigation had prevented his enforcement agents from determining whether the Jacksonville Electric Authority was overcharged for fuel oil it bought during the Arab oil embargo.

title: Restless Connors Seeks Match Play
description: Jimmy Connors is impatient to get matchplay competition to sharpen his game and John Newcombe has been beaten twice in two weeks.

title: Cocoa Futures Drop 2c Daily Limit in All Contracts
description: Cocoa futures dropped the daily 2 cents a pound limit in all contracts yesterday, following disclosure of a startling drop in the grinding figures.

title: Jacobsen Admits That He Is Unsure About Some of the Details of Alleged $10,000 Payoff to Connally
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 Jake Jacobsen, the Government's central witness in the bribery trial of John B. Connally, conceded today that he was uncertain of some details of his account of an alleged $10,000 payoff to the former Treasury Secretary in 1971.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AID TO THE MUSE Tonight's variety concert, a benefit for the music division of the Public Library at. Lincoln Center, is not the usual kind of concert mixture held at Avery Fisher Hall or anywhere else. Organized by Andre Watts, the pianist, who will also participate, the performance starting at 8 P.M. is a classicbased potpourri with the help of Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops: Judith Blegen and Sherrill Milnes of the Metropolitan Opera, Benny Goodman, the clarinetist, and Tony Randall, of television's The Odd Couple.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera: Corinth, the Sills Debut at Met
description: Beverly Sills made it to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera exactly at 8:18 Monday night. She made it as a diva should, with a brilliant new production, showstopping arias and the adoration of the multitude that gave her an 18minute solo ovation at the end.

title: Notes on People
description: Seven couples were buffetdinner guests in the White House family quarters last night to celebrate Betty Ford's 57th birthday. Later they sat with Mrs. Ford in the Presidential box for a performance by Pearl Bailey at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. President Ford canceled his own atendance, to work on his foreign policy speech.

title: Humanitarian, Say Some; Easing Guilt, Say Others
description: As the children arrived by the planeload from South Vietnam to face new homes, new families and, in many cases, new names in the United States, interviews in the metropolitan area indicated that opinion on the airlift was as divided among the public as it was among the experts.

title: Case of Successful Play By Declarer Against Odds
description: Spectacularly successful plays by the declarer, apparently against the odds, will sometimes cause a defender to mutter to himself and wonder whether he should be holding his cards more tightly to his chest. If he thinks it over later he will almost invariably find that the declarer has simply made a wellreasoned play.

title: Shots in Angola Hit a South African Jet
description: LUANDA, Angola, April 8A heavily loaded South African Airways 747 jumbo jet was struck by bullets while landing here last night.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: An Imaginative French Chef Delights His Midwestern Patrons
description: WHEELING, IllTo a provincial New Yorker, the discovery of an excelling French restaurant in Chicago might seem a distinct and provocative cultural happening. To discover a restaurant of outstanding merit in a small and otherwise undistinguished village approximately 40 miles north of the Windy City's Loop comes as cosmic revelation. But Le Franais restaurant here would rank on almost any count with the finest French restaurant in America. In some areas it all but outdistances any but those on the top rung of the gastronomic ladder.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 8 (UPI)The Oakland A's, with Vida Blue and Rollie Fingers combining for an eighthitter and Phil Garner driving in two runs, opened the ,season tonight with a 32 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: City Hall Drafting U.S. Measure to Get. Federal Aid
description: The Beame administration is drafting legislation that would amend the Federal Financing Bank Act of 1973 to allow a Federal bank created to coordinate and assist Federal borrowing to purchase city securities.

title: Letters and Statement in Attica Inquiry Dispute
description: Following are the texts of letters by Malcolm H. Bell, a former special assistant assigned to the investigation of possible crimes arising from the Attica prison revolt, and by Robert P. Patterson Jr., an attorney for Mr. Bell, and a statement by Anthony G. Simonetti, a special assistant attorney general who is chief prosecutor in the Attica investigation. The material deleted from Mr. Bell's letter makes reference to particular cases and persons involved in the Attica investigation. The deletions had already been made when the letter was obtained by The New York Times:

title: CORRECTION
Contract Award
8% AD REVENUE RISE IS SEEN FOR PAPERS
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 8 (UPI)The president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, Inc., said here today that if daily newspapers used aggressive salesmanship in 1975 they could expect to increase their advertising revenues by 8 per cent over last year to a total of 88.6billion.

title: Class Aims to Loin Cabbies Proper Speech
description: New York taxi drivers can tell you where to get off, but their diction occasionally leaves something to be desired. That was excuse enough for the taxi speech seminar yesterday.

title: Mets, Behind Seaver, Top Phils By 21 on Single by Torre in 9th
description: With four new players on the field but with the old Tom Seaver on the mound, the New York Mets opened their 14th baseballl season yesterday by defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 21, on a single by Joe Torre in the ninth inning.

title: About New York
description: The showing of The Lost Weekend on television recently provided a reminder of a story known to everyone who has ever lifted a glass at P.J. Clarke's, the landmark saloon at Third Avenue and 55th Street. That is, that the scenes showing Nat's Bar, where the alcoholic Don Birnam, played by Ray Milland, begs Nat, played by Howard Da Silva, for just one more, were filmed there.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Middlesex General Hospital in New Brunswick agreed to operate an aroundtheclock ambulatory healthcare service in southern Middlesex County. It would be the first such service in New Jersey.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Those who have always opposed foreign adoption because they see it depleting nations of their children are angrier than ever. At the same time, some who might defend foreign adoption under other circumstances are saddened and perplexed by what they describe as haste and disorganization in this operation.

title: 8 ON TRIAL IN SPAIN IN BUSINESS SCANDAL
description: MADRID, April 8 (AP)Eight Spanish businessmen went on trial today on charges of involvement in a $150million financial scandal that shook the Government six years ago.

title: Twins Rout Rangers, 114
description: ARLINGTON, Aex. April 8 (UPI)Tony Oliva's threerun homer capped an early attack of Ferguson Jenkins tonight and the Minnesota Twins had 17 hits to give Gert Blyleven an openingnight 114 victory over the Texas Rangers. Jenkins, who went the distance 29 times while winning 25 games in 1974, lasted only 1 innings, giving up six runs and seven hits.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dr. John Esben Kirk, 69, Expert on Aging Process
description: ST. LOUIS, April 8 (Reuters)  Dr. John Esben Kirk, a scientist known for his studies of the aging, died yesterday of muscular dystrophy at his home (here. He was 69 years old.

title: Denmark Grants First Leases For Oil Search Off Greenland
description: COPENHAGEN, April 5The Danish Government today granted the first leases for oil exploration off Greenland. The leases cover 15,000 square miles on the West coast continential shelf.

title: 8 P.B.A. Founders Make Hall of Fame
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 8 (UPI) Eight charter members of the Professional Bowlers Association will be installed in the organization's Hall of Fame next Monday.

title: Article 2  No Title
MANY IN SOVIET DIE IN FIERY RAIL CRASH
description: MOSCOW, April 8 (Reuters) A passenger train rammed a train of gasoline tank cars in Lithuania on Friday and many people were killed in the fire that followed, according to a Lithuanian who said he survived the accident.

title: International Paper Reports a 14% Rise In Sales and Profits
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper producer, achieved a 14 per cent increase in both sales and earnings in the first quarter to set records for the period. J. Stanford Smith, chairman, told shareholders yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Chicago.

title: A Global Bank Tangle And Its Lost Millions
description: PARIS, April 8An indictment was handed up in Israel today charging the country's most prominent financial official, Michael Tzur, with fraud, bribery and a breach of trust. The indictment had been expected, but behind it was a long trail of banking intrigue in Switzerland and Liechtensteinthat allegedly siphoned off million of dollars intended for Israeli development.

title: DELEGATE CEILING SET ON OIL TALKS
description: PARIS, April 8 (Reuters)Major oilconsuming and oilproducing countries set a ceiling of 30 today on the number of nations to lake part in a world energy conference this summer.

title: Attica Bombshell
description: Former Attica prosecutor Malcolm H. Bell has dropped a bombshell into the state's law enforcement machinery that requires a good deal more than the usual we'll look into it response which it has elicited from Governor Carey's office.

title: Premier Fears Boycott By HENRY GINIGER
description: LISBON, April 8  Premier Vasco dos Santos Gongalves warned Portugal today to be prepared for an international economic boycott as a result of her socialist revolution.

title: Dr. Charles Wolf Dies at 87; Dermatologist at Mt. Sinai
description: Dr. Charles Wolf, a derma tologist who had been on the staff of Mount Sinai Hospital for more than 50 years, died Monday at the DeWitt Nursing Home. He was 87 years old.

title: Guilty in Nixon Donation
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 8 (UPI)David G. Livingston, former chairman of the board of the First National Bank, pleaded guilty yesterday to making illegal political contributions to former President Richard M. Nixon, a former New Mexico Governor and three New Mexican Congressmen. Sentencing was set for May 5.

title: Israeli Intransigence
description: The history of the Middle East has been one of missed major opportunities for peace by Israel.

title: STEREOTYPERS SAY PAPERS DRAG FEET
description: John Kennedy, president of Stereotypers Union No 1, said yesterday that his local was eager to negotiate a new agreement with The Daily News and The New York Times, but that the newspapers were dragging their feet in bargaining talks.

title: Postal Rate Increase Now Seen for October
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)The Postal Service has revised its proposed budget estimate downward in anticipation of higher postage rates by Oct. 1 instead of July 1 as originally projected.

title: Need of Bilingual Study Esta Dramatizada Aqui
description: It was a conscious effort to make the audience nervous.

title: Colonels Win, Lead Series, 20
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April (AP)Louie Dampier scored 23 points and Kentucky beat Memphis, 119105, tonight in an American Basketball Association playoff game.

title: Private Efforts Stressed
description: WASHINGTON, April 8President Ford's chief refugee coordinator suggested at a Congressional hearing today that 3,000 to 4,000 more Vietnamese children might be airlifted to the United States.

title: Prosecutor Expects Retrial Of 2 in '73 Inmate's Slaying
description: TRENTON, April 8 (UPI)Two inmates charged with the slaying of a Trenton State Prison inmate will probably be retired, prosecutors said today.

title: Chrysler Recalling 2,400 as Benefits Face Lack of Funds
description: DETROIT, April 8 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation has recalled 2,400 workers from Indefinite layoff, only days before its special unemployment benefit fund for laidoff production workers was expected to be exhausted.

title: Controversy Is Growing
description: The airlift of children from South Vietnam, begun last week with a sense of urgency and compassion, has left in its wake bitter argument over whether taking children from their homeland is an appropriate or necessary way to deal with a crisis.

title: CITY OPERA LISTS NEW PRODUCTIONS
description: The New York City Opera will present five new productions, including one directed by Harold Prince, in its fall and spring seasons at the New York State Theater in 197576.

title: Sellers of Rutgers Voted Top Player Here
description: Phil Sellers, who decided last week to remain at Rutgers for another year of college basketball, and his coach, Tom Young, took two of the top awards last night at the annual Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association dinner.

title: NORTH VIETNAM SAYS U.S. IS A KIDNAPPER
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 8 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese Foreign Ministry charged today that the emigration of South Vietnamese adults and children to the United States constituted kidnapping.

title: Deal on Sterndent Merger Called Off by Dictaphone
description: The Sterndent Corporation, Which fought off a takeover bid by Kuwaiti interests in February, said yesterday that a subsequent merger deal. with the Dictaphone Corporation had been called off, Stern dent, which makes denial equipment and trades in precious metals, reportedly began merger talks with Dictaphone a few days after the, Magus Corporation's takeoverl bid as a means of thwarting it.

title: House Panel Backs 368Billion Budget
description: WASHINGTON; April 8 (AP) A Congressional budget target of $368.2billion was approved today by a sharply divided House Budget Committee.

title: Great Adventure Prepares For Opening of 2d Season
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIPGreat Adventure, the 1,500acre amusement park and wildanimal habitat here that drew 1.3 million visitors and a seasonlong chorus of complaints last year, is rushing to expand and improve its facilities before the May 3 opening of its second season.

title: Pastore Says the C.I.A. Made Discoveries on Sub
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)  Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, chairman of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee, said today that the Central Intelligence Agency made some significant discoveries last year when it raised part of a Soviet submarine from the floor of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Health Foods Tasting Inflation
description: For S. D. Kominsky, an 80yearold artist who walks 10 miles every day, the price that he must pay for pure maple syrup, nuts and currants is an inconsequential matter.

title: Soldiers Seek to Forget Vietnam
description: FORT HOOD, Tex. April 7In the tiny museum of the First Cavalry Division here is a model of a Vietnamese, hootch. A mannequin wearing Army fatigues stands beside it. Above each fatigue chest pocket is a sewn patch. One says Ho Chi Minh. The other says N.V.A. A sign nearby reads:

title: LISBON WARNS U.S. ON AZORES FUELING
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Portuguese Government has informally advised the United States that it could not use an air base in the Azores to resupply Israel in a new Middle East conflict, a State Department official said today.

title: Anker to Appoint District 1 School Chief
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker, stepping into the long and bitter controversy over the designation of an acting superintendent of Community School District I, said after a meeting last night with seven members of the school board that he would appoint a superintendent today.

title: Baseball Strike Averted
description: PITTSBURGH, April 8 (UPI) Ushers and ticket sellers at Three Rivers Stadium signed a new threeyear contract today averting a strike that threatened to mar the Pirates' home opener Friday with the New York Mets. The contract calls for a 25 per cent pay raise over three years pus fringe benefit increases and job retention.

title: IRVING HABER, 66, NIGHTCLUB OWNER
description: Irving Haber, who for many years operated nightclubs here, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 50 Sutton Place South. He was 66 years old.

title: FREIGHT RISE SET FOR EXPORT COAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed today to let the nation's railroads extend the recently approved 7 per cent general freight rate increase to include export coal.

title: 600 at Rites for a Paterson Fire Captain
description: PATERSON, April 8Fred Armona, a Fire Department captain killed in a church blaze here last Saturday, was buried today with full honors rendered by more than 600 firefighters from 50 communities including twothirds of this city's firemen.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Padres Opener Off
description: SAN DIEGO, April 8 (AP) The San Diego Padres' season opener with the San Francisco Giants was rained out today. A Padres' spokesman said Randy Jones and the Giants' Jim Barr, would face each other in tomorrow's regularlyscheduled game. They had been scheduled to start tonight.

title: About the Mets...
description: The Mets, besieged by strained muscles and other ailments, began a program of lockerroom calisthenics for the starting lineup. Seven guys do them, not counting the pitcher and catcher, said Eddie Yost, the coach and drillmaster. Every day I take the extra men outside early for exercises, but the regulars are still getting dressed then. So I lead them in calisthenics inside for five minutes. It was suggested by Mr. Grant [Donald Grant, chairman of the board] to prevent pulled muscles. . . . For Ed Kranepool it was the 14th opening day in a row, the most for a Met. In 1962, he said, I was a senior in James Monroe High School and they invited me to watch. Since then I've been on the team. Still sitting and watching, but I've got a better seat now. . . . For Tom Seaver it was his eighth straight opener on the mound. He has won four, pitched to no decision four times.... I never experienced fan reaction like this before, said Dave Kingman, who played in windy and unpopulated Candlestick Park before joining the Mets. They were yelling on every pitch.

title: Knicks Beaten by Rockets In Playoff Opener, 9984
description: HOUSTON, April 8Never able to generate any effective offense, the New York Knicks got off on the wrong foot in the National Basketball Association playoffs tonight by losing to the Houston Rockets, 9984.

title: Dean Witter Settles Suit
Erving Is Still No. 1 to Spirits
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 8 Before he took his team through a workout at the Nassau Coliseum today, Coach Bob McKinnon was talking about what hurt his Spirits of St. Louis the most in their opening loss in the American Basketball Association playoffs to the New York Nets on Sunday.

title: MARKET BREAKS ITS LOSING STREAK
description: A moderate technical recovery broke the stock market's losing streak yesterday as the trading pace grew slightly.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 9, 1975

title: Young Islanders Take Pressure Well
description: Until last night one factor remained unknown in the equation that will spell out the winner of the RangerIslander playoff seriesthe emotional maturity of the 3yearold Islanders.

title: Hawaii Ouintet Wins
description: KISARAZU, Japan, April 8 (AP)The University basketball team overpowered the AllNipppon Steel team, 11065, today. The Hawaiians, who led 5532 at halftime have a 20 wonlost record on their tour. Their third game is against the AllNippon Kokan team in Niigata on Thursday.

title: Theater of the Deaf Performs Dybbuk
description: The Dybbuk, which began a week's engagement Monday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is both a change of pace and a challenge for the National Theater of the Deaf, which up to now has specialized in work that is light and comic. S. Ansky's classic tale of exorcism is a tragedy dense with mysticism and ornate language.

title: Arthur C. Goerlich Dead at 81; Led College of Insurance Here
description: Arthur C. Goerlich, who retired in 1964 as president of the College of Insurance, a New York educational institution that he helped to found in 1962 with a class of 15 students, died Sunday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: Unemployment Benefit Rolls Show Decline of 42,500
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The Labor Department said today the number of persons receiving unemployment insurance benefits declined during the week ending March 22, but the number of persons receiving extended jobless pay edged up slightly.

title: DIRECTORS OF A.P. REELECT CHAIRMAN
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 8 (AP)  Paul Miller, chairman of the Gannett Company was reelected today as chairman of The Associated Press Board of Directors.

title: T.V.A., a National Asset
description: President Ford is soon to choose a nominee to fill a vacancy on the threemember board which governs the Tennessee Valley Authority. It is one of the more important appointments that a President makes because of the length of the termnine yearsand because of the continuing importance of the T.V.A.

title: SOLAR ENERGY PLAN TO BE ACCELERATED
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Federal energy experts announced plans today to shave as much as two decades off the process of achieving widespread use of solar heating and cooling systems in the United States.

title: Three New Mets and Mr. Seaver
description: The landed gentry of Shea Stadium were at home yesterday to a fairly large and fairly intelligent gathering. The gale count for the Mets' first lawn party of 1975 was only 18,527, but Bill Shea and Abe Beanie were present. Bill is fairly large and Abe is fairly intelligent. Today the Mets will share their playpen with the Vilifies and Yankeesfor workouts, not a doubleheaderand on Friday the Yankees will show up for their homeawayfromhome opening. It has been predicted that the squatters would upstage the original inhabitants this year by displaying exciting newcomers like Catfish Hunter and Bobby Bonds, but it will be a warm day in August before the Orphans of the Bronx delight the ?? more than the new Mets did in their debut.

title: H.E.W. OFFERS PLAN ON SCHOOL FINANCES
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare proPosed today, regulations to reimburse states for the cost of developing and implementing plans for school finance equalization.

title: First Black Manager in Baseball Is Winner in Debut
Cougars Trustee Reeking $751,500
description: CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI)The trustee of the financially troubled Chicago Cougars filed suit in United States District Court today, seeking $751,500 from the World Hockey Association.

title: CHASE TO SELL 12% OF LONDON BANK
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank disclosed yesterday that would proceed to sell its 12 per cent interest in the Standard & Chartered Banking Group, a Londonbased bankholding company with $10.7billion in assets. The investment had been expected to provide the Chase with a prosence in Africa.

title: COMBAT SLACKENS NEAR PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 8Combat slackened on all sides of Phnom Penh's defense perimeter today, but heavy fighting was reported continuing inside the isolated city of Kompong Speu, 32 miles to the southwest.

title: Controversy Is Growing
description: The airlift of children from South Vietnam, begun last week with a sense of urgency and compassion, has left in its wake bitter argument over whether taking children from their homeland is an appropriate or necessary way to deal with a crisis.

title: TWO CYPRIOTE SIDES ACCEPT VIENNA DATE
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 8 (UPI)Turkish and Greek Cypriote leaders confirmed today that they would open political negotiations in Vienna on April. 28.

title: Jacobsen Concedes Uncertainty On Some Details About Connally
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 Jake Jacobsen, the Government's central witness in the bribery trial of John B. Connally, conceded today that he was uncertain of some details of his account of an alleged $10,000 payoff to the former Treasury Secretary in 1971.

title: Fred W. Prender, 46, Dies; Bucknell's Football Coach
description: Fred W. Prender, head football coach at Bucknell University, died yesterday of a heart attack after a tennis game. He was 46 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Blue Cross of New Jersey, the hospital insurance plan, filed with the State Department of Insurance a request for an increase of 29.8 per cent in its premium rates for 1.6 million of its 4.3 million members. The increase would raise the plan's hospital insurance costs for individual and small group members those in groups of fewer than 100 peopleincluding students and the elderly, effective July 1.

title: Article 4  No Title
$135Million Credit Accord Sought by Capital Mortgage
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Capital Mortgage Investments Inc., a real estate investment trust, said today negotiations had begun for a $135million, oneyear revolving credit with several banks, to consolidate outstanding shortterm obligations.

title: Concert: Schoenberg String Quartets
description: There was a time when the string quartets of Arnold Schoenberg were considered forbiddingly difficult. That was before the earstretching (to use the Charles Ives term) process of the last two decades. Anything that could happen did happen. Today, after the music of Stockhausen, Boulez, Cage, and other exponents of complete dissonance and organized (or unorganized) chaos, the music of Schoenberg sounds as historical as Schubert.

title: ExAides of National Tea Being Investigated by U.S.
description: CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI)The National Tea Company said today that several of its former officers and employes were being investigated by the United States Attorney's office here in connection with financial transactions between 1968 and 1973.

title: Class Aims ta Loin Cabbies Proper Speech
description: New York taxi drivers can tell you where to get off, but their diction occasionally leaves something to be desired. That was excuse enough for the taxi speech seminar yesterday.

title: Sadat Plays for Time
description: CAIRO, April 8By deciding to reopen the Suez Canal and by sticking to his policy of trying to negotiate a settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict in spite of the absence of a new disengagement agreement, President Anwar elSadat is gaining time to protect his relatively liberal regime at home.

title: HANOI OPENS DRIVE NEAR DELTA ROAD
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 9Two North Vietnamese divisions launched a series of coordinated ground and shelling attacks in the upper Mekong Delta yesterday in an apparent effort to cut off Saigon from the riceproducing area to the south.

title: Three New U.S. Bishops Appointed by Pope Paul
description: ROME, April 8The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI had appointed new bishops in three United States Dioceses.

title: Train Engineer Dozed Before Yugoslav Crash
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, April 8 (UPI)An engineer and his assistant admitted today that they had been asleep at the controls of an express train that crashed on the approach to the Zagreb railway station last August, killing 153 persons.

title: COUNTY OFFICERS HEAR CAREY PLEA
description: LIBERTY, N.Y., April 8Governor Carey asked county officials tonight to help him win more local aidand more state taxes to provide itfrom the Legislature:

title: Aaron Hitless as Brewer In 52 Defeat by Red Sox
description: BOSTON, April 8 (UPI)Bob Montgomery doubled home two runs and scored a third today in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 52 openingday victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC RAISES EARNINGS
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the holding company that owns the country's 10th largest bank, reported yesterday that firstquarter earnings jumped 35 per cent.

title: Private Efforts Stressed
description: WASHINGTON, April 8President Ford's chief refugee coordinator suggested at a Congressional hearing today that 3,000 to 4,000 more Vietnamese children might be airlifted to the United States.

title: About Education
description: Ever since Charles Eliot broke the rigid classical curriculum at Harvard almost a century ago by introducing the concept of the elective, college educators have not been able to agree among themselves, let alone with their students, on what courses a student should be required, or at least expected, to take in order to merit a bachelor's degree and the reputation of being an educated person.

title: OLD AND GAS MEN OPPOSE SHELF BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The oil and gas industries presented a united front today in opposition to proposed legislation that would require Federal exploration for oil and gas in the frontier areas of the Outer Continental Shelf before the Department of Interior could sell leases in those areas.

title: Theater: A Hedda Gabler in Style
description: Ibsen is in style these days. We have recently had A Doll's House at Lincoln Center, Ghosts at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, and just around the corner we are awaiting the arrival of Glenda Jackson and the Royal Shakespeare Company in Hedda Gabler in Washington. Meanwhile for those who cannot get to Washington, or just cannot wait, an excellent production of Hedda Gabler has now joined the always enterprising C.S.C. Repertory at its handsome home, the Abbey Theater on East 13th Street.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: National League

title: Secret Meeting Reported
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 8 Reports of a secret meeting here between Premier Long Beret and Cambodian insurgent representatives could not be confirmed today.

title: Godfather, Part II Wins 7 Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES, April 8The Godfather, Part 11, the sequel to the Oscarwinning Mafia film of two years ago, The Godfather, continued the family tradition tonight by sweeping seven top honors at the 47th annual Academy Awards presentations.

title: Abramowitz Is Reinstated by Nyquist As Great Neck School Superintendent
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 8Mortimer J. Abramowitz has been fully reinstated as superintendent of the Great Neck school district, following an eightmonth effort by the board's majority to dismiss him in a series of bitter public meetings.

title: $1.5Million Gift for Hungry
description: CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI)A $1.5million contribution, donated by the Roman Catholics of the Chicago Archdiocese, was presented today in behalf of the world's hungry to the directors of Catholic Relief Services by John Cardinal Cody, Archbishop of Chicago. It was raised in a special freedom from hunger collection.

title: U.S. WELFARE COST CUT $62MILLION IN 2D HALF OF '74
description: WASHINGTON, April 8National welfare costs were cut $62million in the last six months of 1974 as part of a Government campaign to remove ineligible recipients from state rolls and reduce payment errors, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare reported today.

title: DALE B. OTTO
description: Dale B. Otto, who retired in 1965 as president of the New Jersey Natural Gas Company, died yesterday in the Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, N. J. He was 64 years old and lived in Middletown, N. J.

title: Helicopter Crash Rips Ranger Field
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 8 (UPI)  A helicopter being used to dry the wet playing field at Arlington Stadium crashed today about four hours before the Texas Rangers were to open their season against the Minnesota Twins tonight.

title: Lafleur Awarded Cup
description: MONTREAL, April 8 (UPI) Guy Lafleur of the Montreal Canadiens was presented with the Molson Cup today as the team's most valuable player for 197475. The trophy is based on the threestar selections, which are made after each of the Canadiens' games during the regular campaign. Lafleur, who set a National Hockey League record for right wings and a team record with 53 goals, picked up $1,000 and the cup as the overall winner.

title: WNET to Devote Special Sunday to Social Security
G.O.P. Criticizes Rise in State's Payroll
description: ALBANY, April 8Republicans here are distributing duplicated copies of two textsGovernor Carey's State of the State message promising an immediate freeze on hiring, and a departmental memorandum showing that the state payroll actually had risen under Mr. Carey.

title: FARM AIDE SCORES FARMLANDS PLAN
description: TRENTON, April 8The constitutionality of a proposal made by a private research group to save a million acres of New Jersey farmland by permitting the trading of development rights on the private realestate market was challenged today by Phillip Alampi, State Secretary of Agriculture.

title: FOOD STAMP PLAN TO PROVIDE MORE
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Food stamp allotments for fourperson families will rise automatically to $162  $8 more a monthon July 1, Agriculture Department figures indicated today.

title: Old S.I. Lighthouse to Be Made a Home
description: A 32yearold Staten Island engineer received permission yesterday from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to convert an abandoned 19th  century lighthouse overlooking Lower New York Bay into a bachelor home for himself.

title: Accused Ohio Killer of 11 Pleads Insanity
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, April 8 (AP)James Ruppert pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity today to an indictment charging him with killing 11 members of his family during a gathering at his mother's home, on Easter.

title: Theodore Giddens, Officer Shot in Holdup of Tavern
description: Theodore Giddens, a Rikers Island Correction Department officer, who was paralyzed by gunshot wounds received when he interrupted a robbery in a Queens bar last Jan. 22 died Monday afternoon in Bellevue Hospital.

title: Norway Plans to Extend Her Industrial Ownership
description: OSLO, Norway, April 8The Norwegian Labor Government plans to extend the Governmentowned industrial sector, mainly in connection with the oil industry, although most industrial production will continue to be based on private ownership, the Government said in a White Paper.

title: Catholics for Abortion Are Denied Communion
description: SAN DIEGO, April 8 (AP)The Roman Catholic Bishop of San Diego has ordered that holy communion be barred to any Catholic who admits publicly to membership in the National Organization for Women or proabortion groups.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
U.S.IS CRITICIZED ON FAMILY COURT
description: The chief judge of the Rhode Island Family Court said yesterday that someone in the bowels of the Justice Department was trying to curb the powers of juvenile courts.

title: People and Business
description: Senator James L. Buckley of New York got a warm response after he told the American Association of Petroleum Geologists in Dallas that he knew of nothing in the antitrust laws to prohibit American business from joining together in some sort of union to prevent what he suggested could be the nationalization of American industry.

title: Soviet Bank Is Raising New Syndicated Loan
description: LONDON, April 8 (Reuters) The Soviet Union's Bank for Foreign Trade is raising its second syndicated loan within five months on the international capital market banking sources said today.

title: ROSE H. TALBERT
description: Rose Hershfield Talbert, a popular variety entertainer in the nineteentwenties and thirties, died Friday at St. Clare's Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived at 300 West 55th Street.

title: Bergen Judge Has Rhyme For Finding of No Crime
description: There was something borrowed and something blue about the ceremonies yesterday in Bergen County Court, but the only thing that was married was language of bawd to verse.

title: NASA Says Soviet Used Older Rocket In Aborted Mission
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The Soviet Union used an old model rocket in the abortive weekend launching of a Soyuz spaceship but a modernized version will launch the Soyuz that is to meet an American Apollo craft in earth orbit in July, the United States space agency reported today.

title: Carey Defers a Decision On Attica Trials Inquiry
description: Governor Carey deferred a decision yesterday on a request that he appoint an independent individual or group to investigate the management and affairs of the state's prosecution of crimes connected with the Attica prison rebellion of September, 1971.

title: Wage Crisis in Britain
description: LONDON, April 8While inflation is simmering down in the United States and on the European continent, it appears to be accelerating in Britainbreeding conditions likely to produce a severe political as well as economic crisis before the year is over.

title: Offer for AstonMartin Accepted by Creditors
description: LONDON, April 8Aston Martin, expects to resume production next month, only four months after it shut down, bankrupt and heavily in debt.

title: Some of Jean Banchet's Specialties
description: 1 small pair sweetbreads, about threequarters pound Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste

title: Mergers Off 34%, to 579 From 878, in First Quarter
description: CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) Merger activity dropped 34 per cent in the first quarter of this year despite falling interest rates and higher stock prices, W. T. Grimm & Co. reported today.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0,8% IN O.E.C.D.
description: PARIS, April 8 (Reuters)Consumer prices in the 24 nalions belonging to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose 0.8 per cent in February, reflecting a general slowdown of inflation rates in the world's major industrialized stales. The international agency attributed the decline mainly to a drop in demand.

title: Market Summary
Mr. Kaunda's Detente
description: Kenneth Kaunda is the man on the spot in black Africa.

title: Seasonal Factors Cut West Germany's Unemployment
description: BONN, April 8The number of unemployed in West Germany, which reached a 17year high in February, fell in March by 69,500 to 1,114,000or 4.9 per cent of the work forcebecause of seasonal causes, the Federal Employment Office in Nuremberg reported today.

title: Perfect Tully Hall Organ Is No Trifle
description: This is the way God intended organs to be built.

title: Discrepancies Cited in Records Of U.S. Arms Sent to Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Major discrepancies between the amounts of United States military equipment supplied to South Vietnam and Vietnamese records of what they have on hand have been found by the General Accounting Office.

title: TV SHOW INSPIRES ART GIFT TO N.Y.U.,
description: An art patron's viewing of Sunrise Semester, the early morning educational TV program sponsored by New York University, has resulted in a new $1million art museum and gallery for the school.

title: Jet Pigeon Is Shut in by Windows
description: The sealed windows of modern New York office buildings are interfering with a novel executive communications program.

title: Lesbian Groups and Militant Feminists Questioned in Search for Fugitives
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and at least three Federal grand juries are intensively questioning members of lesbian communities and the radical women's movement in their search for underground fugitives.

title: Troops Occupy a Seoul Campus After Park Declares Emergency
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 8Armed troops today seized the campus of Korea University, one of the nation's three larp,est schools, following the declaration of a state of emergency by President Park Chung Hee.

title: Natural History Museum Builds A Wing for 600 Tons of Fossils
description: Just west of Central Park, herds of giant bison, caravans of camels as tall as giraffes, a pride of lions from Alaska, relatives of a horse with claws instead of hoovesin short an extraordinary bestiary of fossil mammals has moved into a new home.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CUTS CANNED FOOD PRICES
description: Price reductions were announced yesterday by the Campbell Soup Company and the Emery Air Freight Corporation.

title: The Weekly Market Basket: Sugar, Egg Prices Decline
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 0.6 per cent last week as prices that had been raised because of the PassoverEaster holidays were dropped back to the previous levels.

title: Deputy Commander Of the Saigon Area Is Found Shot Dead
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 9The deputy commander of the South Vietnamese military region that includes Saigon died last night of a selfinflicted wound, authorities here reported today.

title: Justices Facing Housing Bias Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 Having refused to merge city and suburban school districts to achieve desegregation, the Supreme Court is now faced with a dispute over whether a similar metropolitan plan, ex tending beyond city boundaries, can be used to end racial discrimination in housing.

title: Learning From the Past
description: American disengagement in Indochina and the military debacle in South Vietnam and Cambodia have aroused fears that the United States may be entering a new era of isolationism or at least impotence in the world arena. President Ford has even hinted darkly that those who sought the end of this country's military involvement with Saigon were advocating a retreat behind Fortress America.

title: Ford Calls for Youths To Enter Government
description: WASHINGTON, April (AP)President Ford urged a group of highschool students today to get involved in government at all levels.

title: Bicentennial in Smithtown, L. I., Is Plagued by a 200YearOld Problem
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., April 8The men and women who run this growing town in Suffolk County conducted their business today in the attire of their founding fathers and mothers but they discovered that in the intervening 200 years at least one matter had remained unresolved  the problem of wandering pigs on the Village Green.

title: Amex Seat Price Is Off
description: A spokesman for the American Stock Exchange said that a seat had been sold at $34,000, off $4,000 from the previous sale on April 1. Seats are now quoted at $28,000 bid $45,000 offered.

title: JOHN. D. MORRIS, EDITOR, 60, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, April 8John D. Morris, assistant news editor of the Washington Bureau of The New York Times ind a longtime correspondent for Congressional affairs, died tonight in the District of Columbia General Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Islanders Conquer Rangers
description: Savoring the words, the Islanders screamed One more! One more! and danced off the Madison Square Garden ice last night after capturing the first Stanley Cup game they ever played.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLOGMay. In loving memory of a devoted wife, mother and grandmother.

title: RED CROSS APPEALS FOR INDOCHINA FUND
description: The American Red Cross issued an appeal from its headquarters in Washington yesterday for contributions to the nternational relief effort of the Red Cross for Indochina.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The 1975 model cars were introduced amid warning from oil and automobile company executives that 15 to 30 per cent of the new engines, particularly those in General Motors cars, would knock when running on the most widely available brands of unleaded gasoline.

title: A SPECIAL SESSION HINTED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 8  Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak said today that Governor Carey was considering calling a special session of the Legislature if it adjourned without passing some of his propossed taxes and the economy fails to generate needed revenues for state programs.

title: Market Place
description: A few weeks ago, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company sent out proxy material asking both commonand preferredshareholders to vote to eliminate their preemptive rights at the annual meeting April 16.

title: Opera: Computer Love
description: One of the durable myths of modern times is the mechanical monster that turns into a human (not to he confused with the familiar reality of a human turning into a monster). From Dr. Frankenstein's creation down to the computer Hal in 2001: A Space Odyssey the idea has demonstrated its staying power as one of man's longrange worries and sources for comedy.

title: Staten Island Is Official, The Name Dutch Chose
description: Like most Staten Islanders, Borough President Robert T. Connor was always a bit unsettled about the borough's official name, what with their mail often winding up in Richmond Hill (Queens) or in Richmond (California, Indiana or Virginia).

title: MEYNER ASSAILS COVENANT REPEAL
description: HACKENSACK, April 8Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner contended today that the State Legislature had nothing before it but demagoguery last year when it repealed a bond covenant limiting activities of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in mass railtransit.

title: STATE SELLS BONDS WORTH $75MILLION
description: TRENTON, April 8 (AP) The state announced the sale today of $75million in bonds to one bidder at an interest rate of 5.999 per cent.

title: Strip Mine Workers Protest in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 About 2,000 strip mine workers from the Appalachian mountain coalfields staged a peaceful protest here today against environmental legislation pending in Congress that they and their employers said could cost them their jobs and businesses.

title: Malaysian Guerrillas Kill 7
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 8 (UPI)  Communist guerrillas in Malaysia have stepped up a weekod offensive killing seven soldiers and wounding 14 in two ambushes near the border of Thailand, the Government announced today.

title: Perfect Tully Hall Organ Is No Trifle
description: This is the way God intended organs to be built.

title: Scannell Quitting His Post As Transit Authority Chief
description: Daniel T. Scannell, senior executive officer of the financially troubled Transit Authority, said yesterday that he would give up his post April 26 to go into private law practice here.

title: New Books Today
description: FICTION

title: PROF. ROBERT B. HALL
description: Robert Burnett Hall, professor emeritus of geography at the University of Michigan and founder of the institution's Center for Japanese Studies, died Friday at his home in Ann Arbor. He was 78 years old.

title: Bruins Overwhelm Hawks in Opener
description: BOSTON, April 8 (UPJ)Phil Esposito scored three goals tonight, sparking, the Boston Bruins to an 82 rout of the Chicago Black Hawks in the opening game of their two  of  three  game Stanley Cup series.

title: SAVINGS UNITS ASK FOR VARIABLE RATES
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Spokesmen for California's savings and loan industry urged today that Federally chartered institutions be allowed to write mortgages on which the interest would vary with changes in the money market.

title: WEYAND PROPOSES URGENT ARMS AID TO DEFEND SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, has recommended to President Ford that the United States rush additional military aid to reequipSouth Vietnam's regular army and arm its Regional Forces for the defense of Saigon, Admin. istration officials reported today.

title: Accord Seen at U.N. to Extend Mideast Peace Force 3 Months
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8Members of the Security Council have agreed privately to a threemonth extension of the mandate by United Nations peace  keeping forces separating Egyptian and Israeli troops in Sinai, delegation sources said today. A Security Council session on the issue is likely April 16 or 17.

title: Thieu Seems Well in Control Despite Palace Attack
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 9In the aftermath of an air attack one the presidential palace yesterday by a renegade fighter pilot, President Nguyen Van Thieu appeared as much in control as ever, and even his political opponents denounced the assassination attempt.

title: EDITH KING, 91, RAN SCHOOL OF ACTING
description: Edith Lawrence King, who for more than 35 years operated the Children's School of Acting and Design Theater here with Dorothy Colt, died Monday at her home in Southbury, Conn. She was 91 years old.

title: Goodrich to Close 3 Plants 2 Weeks, Laying Off 2,875
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 8 (UPI) The B. F. Goodrich Company announced today it would close three tire plants for two weeks to cut inventories, idling 2,875 workers.

title: House Votes Delay In Some Sections Of Commodity Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Legislation authorizing a 90day delay in some provisions of the law creating a new Commodity Futures Trading Commission was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate.

title: EDGAR R. SEAGLE
Hanoi Seen Overcoming Its Surprise at Saigon Rout
description: United States military analysts believe that the North Vietnamese command has recovered from its surprise over the speed of the southern pullback and that a major effort against Saigon will end the war. South Vietnamese intelligence reports, relayed to Washington, say that a major drive against the capital is imminent. American sources are not so certain. They believe that Hanoi is preparing for either of two situations.

title: Port Agency Will Enforce Regulation on SST Noise
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey assured Governor Carey yesterday that Concorde supersonic airliners would not be allowed to operate at Kennedy International Airport unless they met all legal requirements, including limits on noise.

title: Elder Plays For Present, Not History
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8Lee Elder, the first black golfer to qualify for the Masters, said today he felt he had a chance to win despite the historical odds against firsttime competitors.

title: Indiana. U.C.L.A. to Open
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 8 (AP)Indiana and the University of California, Los Angeles, will meet in next season's opening college basketball game, officials announced today. The Hoosiers, ranked No. 1 most of the past season, will meet the national champion Bruins at St. Louis on Nov. 29.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in slightly increased trading as bullish news continued to be lacking on Wall Street. Nevertheless, prices rose in the OvertheCounter market on higher volume.

title: Judge Is Criticized By Appeals Court On Lakes Hearing
description: ST. LOUIS, Apri 8 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit today criticized United States District Court Judge Miles Lord of Minneapolis for a hearing that he conducted on the Appeal's Court's decision in the Reserve Mining Company case.

title: VIETNAM CHILDREN IN STOPOVER HERE
description: Twentyone Vietnamese children arrived here from San Francisco yesterday, but for all but one it was just another temporary stop on the long, wearying journey from Vietnam to new homes.

title: Mirror, Mirror On the Wall
description: BRUSSELSThe American abroad cannot help but be astounded by indications, as reported in both spoken and written media, of a lack of United States awareness that the free world situation has become rapidly more critical in the wake of our own failures and a simultaneous surge of selfconfidence in the Communist camp.

title: A Power Substation On Coast Is Bombed 2d Time in 12 Days
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 8 (UPI)Bombs ripped a closely guarded Pacific Gas and Electric Company substation today for the second time within 12 days, temporarily stopping service to 22,000 homes and small businesses.

title: Books of The Times
description: I guess Charles L. Mee Jr.'s Meeting at Potsdam has everything you could possibly want in a work of history. It is intensely dramatic; for it brings to stage center the monumental figures of Truman, Churchill and Stalin (with their respective advisersand of course Clement Attlee, who replaced Churchill as British Prime Minister midway through the conference  standing just to the right and left of them), and depicts them forging the postWorld War II world in dialogue so vivid that it seems almost to have been lifted from a work of the imagination (I will obey your orders, says a playful Churchill, agreeing to Truman's proposal that their plenary 4 o'clock instead of 5; If you are in such an obedient mood today, Mr. Prime Minister, chivvies Stalin, I should like to know whether you will share with us the German fleet). It develops a thesis that stunsdemonstrating, as it tries to do, that first, Truman and Stalin cynically divided the postwar world into Soviet and American spheres of influence, while professing to do just the opposite; second, Churchill egged them on at every opportunity, reasoning that the greater the conflict between American and Soviet interests, the greater the opportunity to forge an AngloAmerican alliance; and third, that Truman not only dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki with the cynical purpose of intimidating Stalin, but also that he actually prolonged the war with Japan to do so. A shocking thesis and a dramatic demonstration of its development all rolled into one: how can one possibly complain about this account of the Potsdam conference written by a former editor of Horizon magazine?

title: Sillanouk Issues Denial
description: PEKING, April 8 (Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, head of a Cambodian exile regime, said in a statement here today that no member of our movement had met with Premier Long Boret.

title: Gerulaitis Victor Over Case, 75, 76
description: ST. LOUIS, April 8 (AP)Vitas Gerulaitis edged Ross Case of Australia, 75, 76, in the first round of the $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today. The 20yearold New Yorker took the tiebreaker, 74.

title: Business Briefs
description: DEARBORN, Mich., April 8 (AP)A group of Ford Motor Company executives are in Egypt this week to explore possible joint commercial ventures with the Arab station, the automaker said today. The delegation of 10 executives, headed by William O. Bourke, chairman of Ford of Europe, arrived Sunday and will stay a week to 10 days, the company said.

title: Carey Defers a Decision On Attica Trials Inquiry
description: Governor Carey deferred a decision yesterday on a request that he appoint an independent individual or group to investigate the management and affairs of the state's prosecution of crimes connected with the Attica prison rebellion of September. 1971.

title: A Global Bank Tangle And Its Lost Millions
