description: PARIS, April 8An indictment was handed up in Israel today charging the country's most prominent financial official, Michael Tzur, with fraud, bribery and a breach of trust. The indictment had been expected, but behind it was a long trail of banking intrigue in Switzerland and Liechtenstein that allegedly siphoned off million of dollars intended for Israeli development.

title: Rating Power: The Who and Why
description: Jesse Unruh, State Treasurer of California, was in New York yesterday on a very important mission  raising money.

title: Crabiel Trial Is Delayed By CoDefendant's Illness
description: ELIZABETH, April 8The trial of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel on bidrigging charges in Superior Court here was delayed today to determine whether his chief codefendant is too ill to stand trial.

title: 2 Lost on Mt. Washington Are Found Safe in Shelter
description: PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., April 8 (UPI)A young couple missing for four days in a blizzard on Mount Washington was found safe today in a shelter five miles from the summit.

title: CORRECTION
Prostitution Bill Opposed
description: HARTFORD, April 8  Gov. Ella T. Grasso said at a news conference today that she would oppose the decriminalizat ion of prostitution. The states's Permanent Commission on the Status of Women is sponsoring a hill to remove prostitution from criminal codes. The commission contends that because the men who visit prostitutes are rarely arrested, the law discriminates against women. The General Assembly's Judiciary Committee will conduct a public hearing on the bill Thursday.

title: Three Special Programs Scheduled for Weekend
description: Three special programs involving the new organ inAlice Tully Hall are scheduled for this weekend. On Friday night, the Julliard Orchestra conducted by Sixten Ehrling will perform Hindemith's Organ Concerto (1962) and SaintSans's Organ Symphony with student soloists. On Saturday night, Karl Richter of Germany will play a Bach recital.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. St. Louis

title: Port Agency T ells Carey It Will Uphold Noise Limitation on SST's at Kennedy
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey assured Governor Carey yesterday that Concorde supersonic airliners would not be allowed to operate at Kennedy International Airport unless they met all legal requirements, including limits on noise.

title: Indicted Israeli Faces Charges Of Fraud, Bribery and Larceny
description: TEL AVIV, April 8A prominent Israeli executive was indicted today on charges of fraud, bribery and larceny.

title: A Truck Driver Skids, Falls and Has to Be Rescued
FEW OLDTIMERS Al PEKING'S HELM
description: PEKING, April 8The death of Tung Piwu, the former acting chief of state, at the age of 90 seemed to have a special poignancy here, perhaps because of the reminder that the men who towered over the first quarter century of Communist China may all soon be gone, to he replaced by relatively unknown figures.

title: MRS. CARL L. H. STORCK
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April  Edythe Storck, widow of Carl L.H. Storck, a retired executive of the General Motors Corporation, died Sunday Norwalk, Conn.

title: WINE TALK
description: PAUILLAC, France, April 8On Monday morning, Philippe Cottin picked up his telephone at his office here and called Chateaux Margaux, HautBrion, Latour and Lafite Rothschild.

title: 292Day Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Treasury auctioned 292day bills today at an average yield of 6.560 per cent

title: A MEDICAL EDITOR DISCUSSES ETHICS
description: Medical researchers and ethicists should work more closely with each other in laboratories, hospitals and classrooms to keep to a minimun potential unethical steps in the many experiments on humans that are needed to improve health care, the editor of one of the world's most prestigious medical journals said yesterday.

title: Pause for Reflection
description: Leading participants in the ArabIsraeli deadlock are not behaving quite as had been expected, following the breakdown in Sectetary of State Kissinger's attempt to mediate a new interim agreement between Egypt and Israel. Instead of moving promptly into a Geneva Conference, as even Mr. Kissinger had anticipated, the parties are showing revived interest in less cumbersomeand less explosivediplomacy.

title: 19 Prisoners Serving Time as Collegians in a Coast Experiment
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 8When grades for the quarter came out at the University of California campus here the other day, a group of 19 students who live together learned they had compiled and overall average of 3.7, or nearly A. That would have been good news for most college students, but it was a source of special pride for the 19.

title: WEY AND PROPOSES URGENT ARMS AID TO DEFEND SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, has recommended to President Ford that the United States rush additional military aid to reequipSouth Vietnam's regular army and arm its Regional Forces for the defense of Saigon, Admin. istration officials reported today.

title: LISBON WARNS U.S. ON AZORES FUELING
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Portuguese Government has informally advised the United States that it could not use an air base in the Azores to resupply Israel in a new Middle East conflict, a State Department official said today.

title: ABRAM DENOUNCES FAILURES ON AGED
description: Morris B. Abram, chairman of the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes, yesterday denounced what he called a breakdown in controls and responsibilities over the industry, but ruled out a switch for the industry from the profitmaking to the Philanthropic sector.

title: People in Sports
description: The choice of Johnny Miller as athlete of the year was announced last night. The golfer was honored, along with 10 other athletes, on the Gillette Cavalcade of Champions award program on an NBC television program. They were chosen in a national poll of the public.

title: Wisdom in a Marbled Haul
description: GENEVA, N.Y., April 8The pursuit of knowledge by six male Hobart College students here went too far today when they kidnapped Minerva, the Greek goddess of wisdom, from her lofty sactum in a women's dormitory at nearby Wells College. They stuffed the 800pound, fiveandahalf granite statue into their car, but had to leave a door ajar and were stopped by a state trooper in Aurelius, a town between the two colleges. They were charged with grand larceny and released in their own custody.

title: Disputes Over Resources Hurt IndiaBangladesh Relations
description: NEW DELHI, April 8India's relations with Bangladesh, her closest ally in the subcontinent, are strained by two disputes over resources.

title: BILL RALLY LIFTS CREDIT MARKETS
description: A rally in Treasury bills helped to stabilize a disheartened and nearchaotic market in fixedincome securities yesterday. As a result, prices firmed in the Government securities market and this show of strength spilled over into the corporate and taxexempt sectors. Some observers, noting that the credit markets had been depressed severely by recent selling pressure, thought that the rally may have been technical. I'll take the rally, technical or not, one dealer said.

title: German and French Citizens Join in a Watch on the Rhine Against Pollution
description: WYHL, West Germany An ecological Maginot Line is rising on the Rhine, not erected by France against Germany but by citizens of both nations who want to slop nuclear power plants and polluting industries.

title: Top Court in Manila Halts Military Trial
description: MANILA, April 8The Philippine Supreme Court tonight halted a military court hearing against an opposition leader who has gone on a hunger strike.

title: Cordero Winner After 015 Streak
description: Angel Cordero broke a 15mount losing streak at Aqueduct yesterday by winning the ninth race aboard Resident at $5.60 for $2. The combination of Resident, East of the Sun and Topech returned only $51 in the Triple.

title: LEE WILL CONDUCT AT PHILHARMONIC
description: Everett Lee, music director of the Symphony of the New World, and Lawrence Foster, music director of the Houston Symphony, will make their New York Philharmonic conducting debuts during the 197576 subscription season. Each will conduct for one week.

title: Beware of Greeks Bearing Pills
description: LARISSA, Greece, April 8 (UPI)The president of the local soccer club, Olympos, filed a suit today against one of his players for doping his teammates last Sunday.

title: General Mills Unit Charged With Trade Restraint by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today charging a major snackfood processor, Tom's Foods, Ltd., of Macon, Ga., with conspiring to restrain trade.

title: Senate Panel to Monitor Garment Center Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 8A Senate investigating committee served notice today that it would monitor the prosecution of cases developed by an unusual Federalcity undercover investigation, but the committee acceded to a Justice Department plea that it halt its inquiry into the investigation pending disposition of the cases.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, has recommended that the United States rush additional aid to reequip South Vietnam's regular army and arm its regional forces to defend Saigon, according to Ford administration officials. The general was said to have advised asking Congress for at least $500million in emergency military aid. He told Congressional committees that without additional aid South Vietnam could not survive. Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said he had been reliably informed of secret agreements with South Vietnam envisioning fateful decisions. The State Department referred newsmen to Secretary of State Kissinger's statement on Saturday that the United States had a moral but not a legal commitment to come to South Vietnam's aid. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: CRIME INSURANCE AID IS EXTENDED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) President Ford signed legislation today authorizing the Department of Housing and Urban Development to continue providing federally assisted crime insurance and riot reinsurance programs through the end of April, 1977.

title: Agency Studies Law For Revamping Rail And Airline Systems
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Department of Transportation is considering legislation to restructure the nation's rail and air systems through a series of mergers, William T. Coleman Jr., Transportation Secretary, said today.

title: Ford's Speech Thursday Is Expected To Be Conciliatory Toward Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 8President Ford's foreign policy address on Thursday is expected to be conciliatory toward Congress and more optimistic than his recent appraisals of the World situation, according to officials familiar with the current draft of the speech.

title: Monday's Fights
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaVictor Galindez. 172 pounds, Argentina, outpointed Pierre Fourie, 168, South Africa, 15 rounds; Galindez retained his World Boxing Association lightheavyweight title.

title: Advertising
description: W. R. Simmons & Associates Research has suspended the syndicated audience research study now in the field in order to use its resources to fight the breachofcontract suit brought by Time Inc., Frank Stanton, chairman of Simmons, announced yesterday.

title: New Manager Shows Ease And Grace Under Pressure
description: CLEVELAND, April 8Prank Robinson went through the pregame rituals on his first day as manager of the Cleveland Indians with ease and grace today. His knees did not shake when Commissioner Bowie Kuhn predictably called today a historic day for baseball. Robinson smiled graciously.

title: HOUSE PANEL LAGS IN INQUIRY ON C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The House select committee set up in February to investigate intelligence gathering in Federal agencies will be seven weeks old tomorrow, and so far it has no staff director and no staff.

title: Jackson's Latest Scoop
description: WASHINGTON, April 8I have been reliably informed, Senator Henry M. Jackson of the State of Washington told the Senate of the United States, that there exist between the Governments of the United States and South Vietnam secret agreements which envision fateful American decisions whose very existence has never been acknowledged.

title: Plant Is Experimenting With Changing Work on Line
description: BOLIVAR, Tenn.In a plant three housed in three big leaky quonset huts here, a farreaching and unusual experiment to chance work is evolving.

title: a FAMILY BUDGET UP $1,733 IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The typical urban American family of four requires $14,300 annually to maintain a moderate standard of living, the Labor Department said today. This, after the worst inflation in 28 years, is $1,733 more than in the previous year.

title: Senate Panel to Monitor Garment Center Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 8A Senate investigating committee served notice today that it would monitor the prosecution of cases developed by an unusual Federalcity undercover investigation, but the committee acceded to a Justice Department plea that it halt its inquiry into the investigation pending disposition of the cases.

title: Blue Cross of Jersey Requests 29.8% Increase in Some Rates
description: TRENTON, April 6  Blue Cross of New Jersey, the hospital insurance plan, filed with the State Department of Insurance today a request for an increase of 29.8 per cent in its premium rates for 1.6 million of its 4.3 million members.

title: SAXBE WAS NOT TOLD ABOUT HOOVER FILES
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation director, Clarence M. Kelley, says he did not tell the Attorney General when he learned of J. Edgar Hoover's files of derogatory information on public officials.

title: HANOI OPENS DRIVE NEAR DELTA ROAD
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 9Two North Vietnamese divisions launched a series of coordinated ground and shelling attacks in the upper Mekong Delta yesterday in an apparent effort to cut off Saigon from the riceproducing area to the south.

title: GUAM'S EXGOVERNOR INDICTED OVER FUNDS
description: AGANA, Guam, April 8 (AP) Former Gov. Carlos G. Camacho, former Lieut. Gov. Kurt S. Moylan and nine other former and present officals of the Guam government were indicted today on a variety of charges, most stemming from alleged abuses at the territory's commercial port.

title: Toll in Bombings Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The F.B.I. reported today that there was a sharp increase in the number of deaths and injuries and the amount of damage caused by criminal bombings in the first two months of 1975. Fifteen persons died and 91 were injured in January and February, as against three deaths and 20 injuries in the first two months of 1974, the F.B.I. said.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Phoenix vs. Quebec

title: Vietcong Aide Pledges Fairness For the Children Left by G.I.'s
description: GENEVA, April 9The Vietcong's representative here said today that the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam would treat the children left behind by American soldiers without hatred or discrimination.

title: NOFRILL FLIGHTS WIDENED BY C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board broadened the airline industry's no frill price war to smaller jets yesterday.

title: 58% in Gallup Poll Favor Equal Rights
description: Although prospects for ratification this year of the Equal Rights Amendment have been extinguished, six out of 10 Americans interviewed by the Gallup Poll favor its passage, with a greater proportion of men supporting it than women.

title: WAGE COUNCIL SEES LOW PRICERISE RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (Reuters)The Council on Wage and Price Stability said the consumer Price Index could he rising at an annual rate as low as 6 per cent by the last quarter of this year, if crops are good.

title: Mary Dalrymple Is Wed to Banker
description: Mary Dalrymple of Wayzata, Minn., widow of John S. Dalrymple Jr., was married yesterday afternoon to Clinton Morrison, a Minneapolis banker. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bride's soninlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Wood, in Minneapolis by the Rev. Dr. John McMillian, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in Minneapolis.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BALLAD ROUNDUPComposers and lyricists will perform medleys of their own tonight from such shows as Bye Bye Birdie, Fiddler on the Roof, Fanny, No, No Nanette and Fiorello! and do such popular standards as Swanee, Brother, Can You Spare a Dime and My Silent Love. The performance is at 8 o'clock at the Bowery Lane Theater, 330 Bowery (near Houston Street), where the Jean Cocteau Repertory stages vintage and modern classics. The $25 admission is taxdeductible as a benefit for the company.

title: Worst of Recession Over, Finance Ministers Agree
description: PARIS, April 9The worst of the world's recession is over and no further measures of stimulation are necessary to get an economic recovery under way, finance ministers from major nonCommunist industrial nations agreed today.

title: Cash in Alleged Coverup Traced at Connally Trial
description: WASHINGTON, April 9A $20 bill from the Federal Reserve Bank in Chicago became a central ingredient today in the bribery trial of John B. Connally as Government prosecutors sought to trace the origins of money allegedly used by the former Treasury Secretary to cover a $10,000 payoff.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Companies Seek Big Savings by Cutting Small Costs
description: every multipage document it receives on both sides unless specifically requested to print on one,

title: Mental Health Unit Honors State Aide and The Times
description: The Mental Health Association of New York and Bronx Countieg has announced awards to Barbara Blum, the assistant director of the State Board of Social Welfare, and to The New York Times.

title: Senate Defies Ford, Blocks Bid To Remove Oil Price Controls
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Senate, resuming its running battle with President Ford over energy policy, rejected today several efforts to assure a complete end to regulation of oil prices.

title: NASA Launches Satellite To Explore Earth's Shape
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 9 (AP) GEOS3, a satellite designed to explore the ocean and gain data on the earth's shape and quake behavior, was launched today, a spokesman for the base said.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners.)

title: ELEANOR BERGQUIST BOWS IN LA BOHEME
description: The news item in Tuesday evening's generally effective performance of La Boheme by the New York City Opera was the company debut of Eleanor Bergquist as Musetta.

title: Board Votes Nassau Legislature Plan
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 9The Nassau County Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to set up a 15member county legislature to replace the present system of government, but left to the courts a decision's on which of two redistricting maps to use.

title: Notes on People
description: By a 28 to 22 vote of the Pennsylvania Senate yesterday, Herbert S. Denenberg, a 46yearold consumer advocate, lawyer and former economics professor, lost his seat on the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. Dr. Denenberg had been the state's militant and controversial Insurance Commissioner during the first fouryear term of Gov. Milton J. Shapp but resigned last year before his unsuccessful primary race for the United States Senate. He has been mentioned as the possible choice of Governor Carey for State Insurance Superintendent.

title: 1974 SOVIET TRADE SHIFTED FROM U.S
description: MOSCOW, April 9  The United States fell from second to seventh among Western trading partners of the Soviet Union last year as the Russians increased their trade with other Western nations.

title: Brewers Stop Red Sox
description: BOSTON, April 9 (AP) George Scott and Robin Yount each drove in two runs, helping the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Boston Red Sox today, 74, and gain a split of the twogame series.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Rangers vs. Islanders

title: Suffolk Conservatives And G.O.P. Reach Pact
description: BLUE POINT, L. I., April 9Concerned about an erosion of their strength in this traditionally Republican county, Suffolk G.O.P. leaders have agreed to accept Conservative endorsement of their candidates in this year's local elections in exchange for Republican support next year of the reelection campaign of Senator James L. Buckley, RepublicanConservative of New York.

title: Bengal Back Sued In Injury Case
description: CINCINNATI, April 9 (UPI) The Cincinnati Bengals and their running back, Bobbie Clark, were named as defendants in a $1million lawsuit filed today by a former Denver Broncos' linebacker, Dale Hackbart, who claimed he was injured by malicious and wanton acts by Clark in the opening game of the 1973 season.

title: Local Poverty Officials Angered and Frustrated
description: COLUMBUS, OhioIn the days of President Johnson's Great Society, an antipoverty leader from Columbus was sometimes more welcome in Washington than the Mayor of Columbus.

title: Supplemental Aid for the Jobless Near End for 40,000 at Chrysler
description: DETROIT, April 9The grim word that had been awaited since last fall by tens of thousands of the Chrysler Corporation's laidoff production workers has finally come: After this week, the companypaid supplemental unemployment benefits that have been keeping them from financial calamity will be no more.

title: Adelphi Trustees Elect
description: Leonard Nadel, senior vice president of Abraham & Straus, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of Adelphi University. Mr. Nadel, a resident of Roslyn, L. I., has been a member of the board since 1963. He has been vice chairman and served on the executive committee, as well as having been chairman of the advisory board of Adelphi's School of Social Work.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Vandals with hammers destroyed the granite bust of Harry Houdini over his grave in Machpelah Cemetery, Glendale, Queens. The lifesize memorial to the famed magician, who died 48 years ago, was inscribed Society of American Magicians. Ralph Stollow, superintendent of the cemetery, told the police yesterday that he had received an anonymous phone call last week warning that the Houdini grave had been booby trapped. He dismissed the threat as that of a crank, he said.

title: Israeli Food Show Almost Chickenless
description: At the Israeli Government Food Show, which is attracting retailers here, there are enough soups on display to float the Queen Miriam: mushroom barley, green pea, borsht, potato, vegetable, onion, celery, asparagus, tomato, even a Hebrew AlefBet soup in which the letters float from right to left. But if it's maybe a chicken soup you're looking for, you should look a long time.

title: Full Voting Rights
description: Despite the demonstrated effectiveness of the Voting Rights Act over the past decade, there is little question that the proposed extension of that legislation, now pending in Congress, is urgently needed.

title: Dance: Limon Opts for Varied Casting
description: Modern dance and moderndance companies are changing in many ways. In some respects, the larger moderndance troupes are learning frcim classical ballet one or two tips about long seasons and programing. Perhaps the most important lesson is that of doublecasting in principal roles. The Alvin Ailey and Martha Graham companies have already taken this step, and now, at the Harkness Theater, the Jose Limon Dance Company is showing quite a number of cast changes in its leading roles.

title: U. S.Financed Work for Jobless In City Being Used as Patronage
description: The Beame administration is filling federally financed jobs in the Office of Neighborhood Servicesjobs intended for the longterm unemployed  with political patronage appointees.

title: British Football Results
description: By Reuters

title: TUESDAY NIGHT
description: FIRST PERIOD1, Los Angeles, Berry (1) (Kozak, Wilding) 14:31. 2, Toronto Stoughton (1) (Keon, Hammarstrom) 15:40. PenaltiesFlett, (5:43); Kannegiesser, (17:18); Hammarstrom, (19:39).

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Thursday, April 10, 1975

title: People and Business
description: The exodus from Saigon last weekend of the managers and American staff members of the Bank of America, Chase Manhattan Bank and First National City Bank of New York is causing some United States firms dealing through these banks some serious difficulties, according to the executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce there.

title: Poverty Programs Lag as Slump Intensifies Federal Aid Demand
description: WASHINGTONAt a time of deep national recession, the voice of the nation's chronically poor has been muted in the halls of government by the demands of a multitude of other special interests seeking limited Federal dollars.

title: Article 7  No Title
Arms Expert Warns on Nuclear Spread
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Administration's leading arms control expert said today that transfer of peaceful nuclear technology provides not only the means, but also the cover for a spread or nuclear weapons.

title: Tiriac Boston Coach
description: BOSTON, April 9 (AP)Ion Tiriac. 36yearold Rumanian, will be playercoach of Boston's entry in World Team Tennis, Bob Mades, club president, said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: Freud said that anatomy is destiny: I would say that, in the best women's writing today, anatomy is irony. Reading their books, you feel that they have been stockpiling their wit, like weapons, for the sexual revolution. For years, they have been using the role of sexual object as a cover while they spied out the land.

title: Senate Panel Favors Smaller Cut in Defense Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Senate. Budget Committee tentatively approved late this evening a ceiling on expenditures for the next fiscal year of $366.1billion, $10billion morel than the most recent, unofficial estimate by the Ford Administration, but $1.9billion less than the ceiling approved yesterday by the House Budget Committee.

title: Personal Finance: Other Insurance Is Helpful in Filling Medicare Gap
description: Payments by Medicare, principally for the hospital and medical needs of those 65 and older, are likely to amount to almost $15billion in 1975. Nonetheless, more than half of the 20 millionplus Americans participating in Medicare spend over a halfbillion dollars annually through supplementary private health insurance.

title: Communists Tighten Grip On Approaches to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 10Communist forces tightened their grip on the approaches to Saigon yesterday and today as they penetrated a provincial capital 36 miles to the northeast and temporarily cut a major road 18 miles southwest of here.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Judge Felix Martino of Essex County court has reversed the Municipal Court conviction of 15 people arrested in a United Farm Workers demonstration last October. The state director of the farm workers' union, Charles March, and 14 union volunteers had been found guilty of trespass in South Orange municipal court.

title: Bridge:
description: The most active and successful players this year in New York, and perhaps in North America, are four young experts whose average age is under 30: Peter Weichsel, Alan Sontag, Ron Rubin and Matt Granovetter.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Staff Charges CoverUps By State Correction Panel
description: The State Commission of Correctionthe new independent watchdog group set up by the Legislature with vast powers to remedy prison problemshas been accused by staff members of concealing irregularities and possible crimes by prison authorities.

title: The Woman Who Isn't Slim Desires High Fashion, Too
description: In a society that worships slimness and idolizes size 5 fashion models built like bamboo stalks, the fat woman is often America's forgotten person. The fashions available in her size are often too blah, she laments. The colors, too somber. The underwear, too spartan. And the boots, too small.

title: Xerox Unit Upstate Will Lay Off 585
description: ROCHESTER, April 9 (UPI)Production and maintenance workers at the Xerox Corporation's suburban Webster plant will he laid off indefinitely starting next Tuesday, company officials announced today.

title: Kosygin Assails Saigon's Refugee Policy
description: MOSCOW, April 9Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin asserted today that the Saigon Government was guilty of the new crime of forcing civilians out of areas It had lost in Vietnam.

title: Spirits Finally Defeat Nets and Even Series
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 9 When a team's best shot is a brown sneaker that hits an opponent, then the team is in trouble.

title: Knicks to Meet Rockets In a DoorDie Situation
To Restore Perspective
description: No task is more challenging for the highest leadership of this land than to correct the erroneous impression abroad among America's friends that the United States is in danger of collapsing as a world power.

title: Accused Mount Holly Slayer Is Held in Bail of $250,000
description: MOUNT HOLLY, April 9 (UPI) A 23yearold Mount Holly man who allegedly shot two police officers to death and seriously wounded another in s threehour shootout on March 28 was ordered today held in jail in lieu of $250,000 bail.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice From Virginia
description: BOSTON, April 9I had a telephone call the other day from a man with the deep soft voice of tidewater Virginia.

title: S. E. C. SUIT LINKS A HONDURAS BRIBE TO UNITED BRANDS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the United Brands Company yesterday with having paid a bribe of $1.25million to Government officials of Honduras to obtain favorable tax treatment on banana shipments from that Central American republic. It further charged the company with having agreed to pay another $1.25million.

title: Saudi Prince's Girlfriend Denies That She Is Jewish
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9 (Reuters)Christine Surma, the girlfriend of the accused assassin of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, said here that she was not from a Jewish family and denied that she was part of any Zionist conspiracy against the King.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Outlook for Wheat Mostly Favorable, Crop Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) The United States winter wheat crop grew subnormally during March because of cold weather, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Hawks to Make First Pick
description: Marvin Webster's stock rose sharply yesterday on a coin toss.

title: Staff Charges CoverUps By State Correction Panel
description: The State Commission of Correctionthe new independent watchdog group set up by the Legislature with vast powers to remedy prison problemshas been accused by staff members of concealing irregularities and possible crimes by prison authorities.

title: U.S.Financed Work for Jobless Used as Patronage
description: The Beame administration is filling federally financed jobs in the Office of Neighborhood Servicesjobs intended for the longterm unemployed  with political patronage appointees.

title: 3 Make Shore After Wind Flips Plane in Jamaica Bay
description: Two officials of the city's Department of Marine and Aviation and a pilot swam and waded to shore yesterday after their small amphibian plane was flipped over by the wind in Jamaica Bay a mile south of the Mill Basin Bridge of the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. King's Duo Wins 2 Matches
description: OSAKA, Japan (AP)Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals scored two victories in the $100,000 doubles championship of the women's pro tour today.

title: Judges in Favor of Opening Family Court to Newsmen
description: Family court judges indicated yesterday that they favored opening their proceedings to newsmen, provided mutually agreed upon guidelines were established to protect certain confidences.

title: Beame and Financiers Trade Accusations About City's Tarnished Fiscal Image
description: Mayor Beame traveled a few blocks to the financial district yesterday to charge that some members of the financial community had subjected the city to a corrosive negativism that had tarnished our city's financial image wholly without justification.

title: EightFoot Sailboat Sets Out on Voyage To Cross Atlantic
description: ORLEANS, Mass., April 9Allan Chadburn kissed his wife and two young sons goodby today and set sail for Portugal in his homemade eightfoot sailboat.

title: Legion of Mary Fans Cheer Band's Winning Music
description: About 15 per cent of the Grateful Dead's fan club lives in. New York, and most of it seems to try to get into the Bottom Line whenever Jerry Garcia, head of the now temporarily dormant band, appears there with his latest ensemble.

title: Cards Top Expos, 40, on Forsch 2Hitter
description: ST. LOUIS, April 9 (AP)Bob Forsch faced the minimum of 27 batters today as he pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 40 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Yankees and Mets: 3 Key Men Ailing
description: Somewhere in the mass of players among three teams who worked out all day at Shea Stadium yesterday were three Mets and Yankees whose activity was more significant than that of the 70 others at the busy ball park.

title: DEFAULT CHANCES MIMED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission proposed today regulations to protect consumers from massive repossessions of household goods or attachment of paychecks when they default on personal loans.

title: Antonioni' s Passenger, Quest for Life
ExAttica Inmate on Bail
description: BUFFALO, April 9 (AP)Charles Perdasilice, one of the two former Attica inmates convicted last weekend in the heating death of a guard during the 1971 prison rebellion, was released on $10,000 bail today.

title: MOST INTERNISTS DO WELL ON EXAM
description: More than 3,500 doctors certified as specialists in the practice of internal medicine before 1968 voluntarily took a recertification examination, and the results reported yesterday were a surprise to leaders of the specialty.

title: French Ferment Grows In Wine War With Italy
description: MONTPELLIER, France, April 9They say down in this hotblooded region of rough men and rough wine that even the grannies love a good brawl.

title: Chess
description: The fifth annual Louis D. Statham Tournament, to be held in Lne Pine, Calif., starting Sunday and running to April 24, promises to be the strongest Swiss System competition ever held in the United States.

title: Advertising
description: One of the exciting (if you're easily excited) features of the annual Direct Marketing Day is the panel that delivers 50 Ideas in 45 Minutes. Yesterday, at the New York Hilton, they were delivered in 39 minutes flat.

title: Parties Offer Rival Proposals For State Aid to Local Schools
description: ALBANY, April 9The battle lines on aid to local school districtstraditionally a major annual preoccupation of the state governmentwere drawn today with disclosure of a $197.4million plan by Republican legislative leaders. The Democrats have a $298million plan.

title: Chrysler Reports a Loss From Its British Operation
description: LONDON, April 9 (UPI)The Americanowned Chrysler Corporation lost a staggering $42.72million on its British operation in six months trading, the group said today.

title: Wallace Sees Halting of Some State Primaries as Party Chiefs' Plot Against Him
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 9Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama charged today that the Democratic party's hierarchy was so afraid that he might run again for the Presidency that efforts were being made in several states, including North Carolina, to stack delegateselection procedures against him.

title: Outspoken Lawyer
description: Throughout his career in the law, Malcolm H. Bell has spoken his mind, argued with superiors, stood his ground and, sometimes, suffered the consequences.

title: KISSINCER AGREES TO ALLON MEETING
description: JERUSALEM, April 9In an effort to reverse the recent sharp deterioration in Israel's relations with the United States, Yigal Allon, Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister, will visit the United States next week and meet with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Inclusion of Investors' Funding In Foreclosure Suit Is Sought
description: The CI Mortgage Group, a real  estate investment trust, asked the Federal Court in the Southern District of New York yesterday to allow the bankrupt Investors Funding Corporation to be brought into a foreclosure suit against an unfinished high  rise apartment complex in Fort Lee.

title: New Zoo Babies: Fun for Children
description: Children intrigued by nature will find that springtime is baby time at the Bronx Zoo. Among the newest arrivals are a bushbaby, a bettong, a bog turtle and a boatbilled heron.

title: TV Designates 79 P.M. as Family Time
description: The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters has voted overwhelmingly to adopt an amendment to the Television Code designating the period between 7 and P.M. as family viewing time.

title: U.S. MAY SHELTER SOME VIETNAMESE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 President Ford is considering contingency plans to evacuate thousands of South Vietnamese whose lives might be in jeopardy in the event of a Communist takeover, Government officials said today.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Knicks vs. Houston

title: Guard Major Cites Delay On His Attica Testimony
description: Dr. John Cudmore, a surgeon who as a major serving with the National Guard entered the Attica prison just after the inmate rebellion in September, 1971, was quelled, said yesterday that despite his public disclosure of seeing atrocities committed by guards, he was not questioned by state investigators until nearly two and a half years after the event.

title: O.A.U. OFFICIALS SEEK SOUTH AFRICA POLICY
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 9 (UPI)A deeply divided meeting of black African and Arab ministers tried to formulate a joint policy toward South Africa today, with both moderates and militants claiming majority support.

title: PESTICIDE LINKED TO DEFECTS IN FISH
description: Six years ago, Government scientists noticed that channel catfish growing in fish farms in the South were developing a curious curvature of the spine that, in many cases, broke the fish's back and stunted the animal's growth by up to 30 per cent.

title: In U.S. Embassy, the Strain Is Showing
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 9To those who consider this encircled capital a sinking ship, the most potent symbol is the fact, that every foreign embassy has abandoned it but onethe American.  And now even the Americans seem poised to disembark, having evacuated more than twothirds of their staff.

title: TV Networks to Carry Ford's Speech Tonight
description: President Ford's speech tonight before a joint session of Congress will be telecast live by the three television networks  ABC, CBS and NBC  by the Public Broadcasting System.

title: CAMBODIA AIRPORT IN MORTAR RANGE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 9Continued erosion of Government positions north of Pochentong Airport is putting the installation within range of insurgent mortars, military sources reported today.

title: Market Place
description: As businesses have become overburdened with recordhigh debt, there is increasing pressure on management to tap the equity market for future financings.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH FOOTBALL ASSOCIATION CUP

title: Congress Urged to Act Quickly To Revise Offshore Oil Leasing
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Governor of Massachusetts and a Se??tor from California urged Congress today to act speedily on legislation drastically overhauling procedures for oil and gas exploration and leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf.

title: TENANTS ENJOY FINE DAY IN COURT
description: After sustaining 20 burglaries in 15 months, culminating with six in a single week last January, the residents of a West Side apartment house went to a Housing Court yesterday to demand better security for their building.

title: Sagner Acknowledges Official Offered $25,000 Campaign Gift to Get a Post
description: TRENTON, April 9  The State Transportation Commissioner: Alan Sagner, acnowedged today that John Nero, a Camden County official involved in the state investigation of alleged corruption there, offered the Byrne gubernatorial campaign a $25,000 contribution in 1973 in return for his appointment as executive director of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission.

title: Market Averages
AMEX PRICES RISE IN HIGHER VOLUME
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overtheCounter market advanced yesterday, amid increasing confidence resulting from a rise in the bond market. Volume was higher on both marts.

title: Detective Escapes Death
description: TULLYTOWN, Pa., April 9 (UPI)A Bucks County detective wearing a bulletproof vest escaped injury yesterday when the was shot in the chest during an attempted holdup of a coin shop here. The police said that Itobert Gergal, 35 years old, had been struck during an exH change of shots between two holdup suspects and policemen on stakeout duty at the Levittown Shopping Center.

title: Stock Market Climbs
description: Stocks soared yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.77 points to 767.99, its largest gain since Jan. 27, when it rose 26.05. The rise was attributed to bond price gains. Page 57.

title: Commons Supports Wilson on Market; Laborite Vote Split
description: LONDON, April 9  The House of Commons voted by a large margin tonight in favor of continued British membership in the European Common Market, but Prime. Minister Harold Wilson was deserted on the issue by nearly half the members of his Labor party.

title: Newsmen Are Told Calls Were Tapped In Indian TakeOver
description: SHAWANO, Wis., April 9 (AP)The Shawano County authorities notified more than 80 newsmen today of a wiretap that had intercepted their telephone conversations with Indians holding the Alexian Brothers estate at. Gresham.

title: U.S. Accused by Algeria
description: PARIS, April 9 (Reuters)Algeria today accused the United States and its, industrial allies of threatening to torpedo the talks between oil producers and consumers.

title: In Memoriam
description: CERTNERJoel. In loving ?? of our beloved Joel. Mother, Dad, Naomi, Jerry.

title: The Busiest Yard in Town
description: The busiest corner of New York yesterday may have been the dozenacre plot in Queens known as Shea Stadium. No baseball game was played there, but three of the 24 teams in the major leagues converged on the yard for 90minute workouts with assemblyline precision. The Mets, who are the home team at the moment, arrived at 11 o'clock in the morning to limber up for their second game of the new season this afternoon against the Philadelphia Phillies. The Yankees, who become the home team tomorrow against the Detroit Tigers, filtered onto the scene at 1 P.M. And finally the Phillies replaced them at 2:30 while the groundskeepers stood by anxiously with rakes and hoes.

title: Former Singer Discerns Sweet Music in Judging
description: When Savoyards gather upstate to celebrate the Gilbert and Sullivan centennial this year they will give three cheers and three cheers more for Nellie V. Anderson, who for several years sang the role of Josephine, the daughter of the captain of H.M.S. Pinafore. Mrs. Anderson, who sang with the Albany Light Opera Company, also was Katisha in the Mikado.

title: Worth More Than a Dam
description: Since 1971 the Federal Power Commission has been prevented by a moratorium from allowing utilities companies to dam up the Middle Snake River, flooding a major segment of the magnificent Hells Canyon. The moratorium, which expires this year, was designed to give Congress time to consider prohibiting dams on the Middle Snake altogether by officially including it in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. Now comes welcome word that the House Interior Committee is about to report out a bill to achieve that purpose, with its Senate counterpart due to follow soon.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Sacramento, Calif.  Alvaro (Indian Yaqui) Lopez, 175 pounds, Stockton, Calif., knocked out Lee Mitchell, 180, Phoenix, Ariz., 6 rounds.

title: Business Briefs
description: The New York State Banking Board decided yesterday not toreduce the state's current 8 per cent usury ceiling on home mortgage loans, Eliot N. Vestner, Superintendent of Banks, stated after a meeting of the board.

title: SCHOOLS CRITICAL OF STATEAID PLAN
description: A new Board of Education study charges that inequities in the current stateaidtoeducation formula have cost New York City schools more than $457million this year alone.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: EFFECTIVE MAY 3, 1975 ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER STATE NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Lincoln Center, with an assist from the New York City Transit Authority, has augmented its afterperformance bus service on the midtown Manhattan route, which connects the performing arts center with the Second, First and York Avenue lines.

title: Twyla Tharp Introduces Sue's Leg, a Jazz Dance
description: Twyla Tharp packed the house at Town Hall yesterday in the Interludes series, whichwhile always popularturned out so popular that the overflow crowd at the box office spilled off the sidewalk.

title: Music: Variety on Cello
description: EllenZoe Hassman, a cellist who has played here previously, gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. With Abbott Ruskin at the piano, she offered the FrescobaldiCassado Toccata, Beethoven's Magic Flute Variations, the BrahmsKlengel Sonata in D, Schumann's Fantasy Pieces (Op. 73), a Dvorak Rondo and the ChopinFranchomme Grand Duo Concertant. She also played Crumb's Unaccompanied Sonata and, with three guests, Klengel's Variations for Four Cellos.

title: Nicklaus: Master of Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9In the Masters, a golfing event that is the criterion of immutability, the only thing that changes from one year to the next is Jack Nicklaus's age. For the 39th Masters, which begins tomorrow morning, Nicklaus is 35 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
Lawrence P. Lazore Dies; Mohawk Chief, Educator
description: Lawrence P. Lazore, a Mohawk Indian leader and director of St. Lawrence University's native American teachertraining program and visiting lecturer in education, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Hogansburg, N.Y. He was 47 years old.

title: Catholics May Publish Ecumenical Scriptures
description: ROME, April 9  Roman Catholics may prepare and publish versions of the sacred scriptures in collaboration with the separated brethren, or nonCatholic Christians, a new Vatican decree on ecclesiastical censorship of writings said today.

title: U.S. GROUP REPORTS VIETCONG AMNESTY
description: A group of Americans seeking to end the fighting in South Vietnam reported yesterday that Vietcong representatives in Paris had told them that the Communists were following a policy of general amnesty toward those with antiCommunist connections in areas they now occupy in South Vietnam.

title: SCHOOL VANDALISM CALLED WORSENING
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) A Senate report contended today that violence and vandalism in the nation's schools had reached a crisis level and was worsening rapidly.

title: Reward in Harvard Killing
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 9 (AP)A reward of $5,000 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer of a Harvard Business School, employe was announced yesterday by Harvard University. The March 31 victim was Carol Peterson, 48 years old, administrative assistant to the Harvard dean of administration, Lawrence E. Fouraker.

title: Detroit's Better Idea
description: DETROITHotel operators throughout Florida, trying to figure out why the past winter's tourist season was so good in the midst of a nationwide recession, have come up with the last fling theory: that tourists such as laidoff Detroit auto workers used the last of their savings for one glorious family spree before crashing into poverty.

title: Brooke View on Lisbon
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Senator Edward W. Brooke, who has just returned from three days of talks with Portuguese leaders, said today that he was deeply concerned that the United States might overreact to the movement to the left in Portugal.

title: Economic Worry Underlies Calm in Huey Long's Parish
description: WINNFIELD, La.  When Huey P. Long was assassinated 40 years ago this September, the pine hills he had come from were a model of misery in a nation that was stricken everywhere by depression.

title: 31111 Wins Swim Title at 23
description: CINCINNATI, April 9Nancy Garapick, a 13yearold Canadian whiz kid, and Kim Dunson, a Texan who talks to herself to clear my mind, set surprising American records as the national Amateur Athletic Union shortcourse swimming championships opened tonight.

title: Increase in Equity Is Stimulated by Bond Price Rise
description: Stimulated by an upsurge in bond prices the stock market yesterday registered a strong advance, its best in more than two months, in accelerated trading.

title: Judge to Be Queried
description: Federal Judge Mark A. Costantino of Brooklyn was asked to appear before a meeting of Federal appellate judges here to respond to charges developed by a Federalcity undercover operation in the Garment District. Details, Page 78.

title: Companies Seek Big Savings by Cutting Small Costs
description: The Carrier Corporation in Syracuse, the country's No. 1 producer of airconditioners, is making war on the buzzers, lights, and other devices that the company's telephones spawned in more prosperous times. So far this year, Carrier has eliminated 10 per cent of the devices, saving $3,500 to $4,000 in annual telephone company rental charges.

title: AT OSCAR AWARDS, BACKSTAGE DRAMA
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9 A backstage dispute over a statement read by Frank Sinatra during last night's televised Academy Awards ceremony came to light today.

title: TV Designates 79 P.M. as Family Time
description: The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters has voted overwhelmingly to adopt an amendment to the Television Code designating the period between 7 and 9 P.M. as family viewing time.

title: TELL BERNA, AIDE TO TOOL BUILDERS
description: Tell Berna, who retired as general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders Association in 1956 after 19 years with the group, died of an anleurysm Saturday in Nantucket Cottage Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived on Nantucket Island.

title: Most Active Stocks
description: Wednesday, April 9, 1975

title: Benton's Widow, 73, Dies
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10 (AP)  Rita Piacenza Benton, the 73yearold widow of the artist. Thomas Hart Benton, died tonight of a heart attack, less than three months after her husband's death. He died Jan 19. The Bentons had two children,

title: The Celanese Corp.'s 6% Loan Proposal For Officers Incurs Shareholder Wrath
description: A Celanese Corporation proposal to make unsecured loans of up to $3.5million at 6 per cent interest to the chairman and other key executives for purchasing company stock, incurred the wrath of shareholders at the company's annual meeting yesterday.

title: Carey's Concerns After 100 Days: Taxes and Nadjari
description: Satisfied that he has inched up the learning curve in his first 100 days in office, Governor Carey is now considering such controversial plans as whether the state sales tax can be increased equitably and whether the power of Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari can be reduced easily.

title: Philadelphia Museum to Close 10 Months for Repairs
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 9After 20 years as a guard in this city's Museum of Art, William H. Norfleet has concluded that its greatest assets are not its paintings but the people who come to see them.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: With the Rangers playing the Islanders in the first round of the National Hockey League playoffs, commercial television was caught with its antenna down. As a result, tonight's contest at Nassau Coliseum and tomorrow night's at Madison Square Garden, if necessary, could only be viewed on cable television in the metropolitan area.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: DROP CONTINUES IN COCOA FUTURES
description: The sharp decline in United States cocoa grindings announced earlier in the week continued to depress cocoa futures yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. However the decline did not match Tuesday's 2centapound limit drop.

title: 4 Accused of Taking $25,000 From Doctor Through Sex Plot
description: A 26yearold widow and three men  one a Suffolk County policemanwere arraigned in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that they turned a physician's house call into a sex session that led to demands for a payoff from the physician.

title: Allied Chemical Earnings Drop Despite Sales Gain
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation, a major diversified chemical producer, reported Yesterday a profit decline of 30.3 per cent for this year's first three months. It was the first drop since the final quarter of 1971.

title: Stocks Are Up 18.77 on Dow; Corporate Offerings Sold Out
description: New offerings of corporate bonds were sold out yesterday, as the recently battered credit markets enjoyed higher prices for the second straight day.

title: U.A.W.'S CHIEF URGES U.S. RAIL TAKEOVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, urged the nationalization of the railroads today as one step toward making the nation less dependant on cars.

title: Arnholt Smith Trial Put Off
description: SAN DIEGO, April 9 (UPI) The trial of Financier C. Arnholt Smith on 25 counts of bank fraud has been postponed until June 16. The trial had been scheduled to begin Monday, April 14.

title: Music: Watts Plays in Worthy Cause
description: Avery Fisher Hall was nearly full last night, and that was nice, for the concert was a benefit for the music division of the New York Library. The boxoffice returns were not yet in, but let us hope that Andr Watts and his cohorts, all of whom donated their services, brought in a tidy sum for the beleaguered library.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three men employed by the Bronx District Attorney's office to record the secret hearings of grand juries were arrested in the culmination of a sixmonth investigation into possible leaks of confidential information.

title: Stevens Students Losing Floating Dorm
description: HOBOKEN, April 9Engineering students at Stevens Institute of Technology failed to absorb a lesson in logistics and economics yesterday, resulting in an exercise in stress for the school's president.

title: Action on Firebombing's
description: MELBOURNE, Fla., April 9 (UPI)Chief of Police Bob CoIron has ordered his patrolmen to use shotguns if necessary to iquel an outbreak of firebombing of automobies driving University Avene in South Melbourne at night.

title: NIXON TOLD THIEU U.S. WOULD REACT TO RED OFFENSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The White House said today that President Richard M. Nixon privately assured the Saigon Government in 1973 that the United States would react vigorously to a major Communist violation of the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: Suit Seeks to Shut 3 Zoos in City Parks As Cause of Cruelty
description: The Society for Animal Rights, Inc., filed a suit here yesterday to force the closing of the municipal zoos of Central, Prospect and Flushing Meadows parks and the removal of their animals to the Bronx Zoo, operated by the New York Zoological Society.

title: It's Do or Die for Knicks Here Tonight
description: HOUSTON, April 9For the second time in five days, the New York Knicks will face a must win situation tomorrow night when they play the Houston Rockets at Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock.

title: S. E. C. SUIT LINKS A HONDURAS BRIBE TO UNITED BRANDS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the United Brands Company yesterday with having paid a bribe of $1.25million to Government officials of Honduras to obtain favorable tax treatment on banana shipments from that Central American republic. It further charged the company with having agreed to pay another $1.25million.

title: People in Sports
description: Bill Foster, a 39yearold native of Hemingway, S. C., was named head basketball coach at Clemson yesterday. He replaces Tates Locke, who resigned for personal reasons on March 20, after leading Clemson to a 1711 wonlost record, its best finish in eight years.

title: Commons Supports Wilson on Market; Laborite Vote Split
description: LONDON, April 9  The House of Commons voted by a large margin tonight in favor of continued British membership in the European Common Market, but Prime Minister Harold Wilson was deserted on the issue by nearly half the members of his Labor party.

title: BRITAIN PROPOSES STATE OIL PROJECT
description: LONDON, April 9The British Government proposed today to establish greater control over the nation's petroleum resources through the creation of a British National Oil Corporation.

title: City Seeking $1 Million From Landlord Who Sold 90 Buildings to Avoid Repairs
description: In one of the largest actions of its kind, the city is seeking More than $1million in penalties from a Brooklyn landlord who allegedly sold or gave away 90 violationridden apartment buildings to avoid entering into an agreement with the city to repair them.

title: Bulls Beat Kings, 9589, In Opener of Playoffs
description: CHICAGO, April 9 (UPI)Bob Love scored 38 points tonight and led the Chicago Bulls to a 9589 victory over the Kansas City Kings, the Bulls' first openinggame playoff victory in history.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Phoenix vs. Quebec

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. St. Louis

title: European Soccer Results
description: EUROPEAN CUP

title: Contract Awards
description: A $70million award to design and build a major hydrocracker expansion for the Kuwait National Petroleum Company at Shuaiba, Kuwait, has been received by the Foster Wheeler Energy Corporation, a unit of the Foster Wheeler Corporation.

title: Books of The Times
description: Freud said that anatomy is destiny: I would say that, in the best women's writing today, anatomy is irony. Reading their books, you feel that they have been stockpiling their wit, like weapons, for the sexual revolution. For years, they have been using the role of sexual object as a cover while they spied out the land.

title: Figure in Hearst Inquiry Vows Not to Assist F.B.I.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9Jack Scott, the radical sports figure, and his wife, Micki McGee Scott, a writer, who had been sought for questioning by the Federal authorities in connection with the Patricia Hearst case, appeared at a packed news conference in a church here today and said they would not cooperate with the authorities.

title: Gribetz and Judges to Meet On Attica CoverUp Report
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that his counsel, Judah Gribetz, would meet shortly with senior judicial officials of the state to discuss the alleged coverup of possible crimes by law enforcement officers during and after the Attica prison revolt in September, 1971.

title: Stock Market Climbs
description: Stocks soared yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.77 points to 767.99, its largest gain since Jan. 27, when it rose 26.05. The rise was attributed to bond price gains, Page 57.

title: Morristown's 2Way Stars
description: High school coaches are accustomed to the idea that if boy excels in one sport, he is likely to be useful in another. As an example, Morristown High last fall won the state football championship with one of the most gifted backfields ever assembled in New Jersey. Rick So

title: WITNESS DESCRIBES GURNEY AIDE'S OFFER
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 9 (UP)A former employe of a Californiabased development company testified today that an offer of help in setting up a business in Florida was coupled with a suggestion that he contribute to a political fund for former Senator Edward J. Gurney.

title: Time Yielding Custody Of KennedyDeath Film
description: Time Inc. announced yesterday that it would return the original Zapruder film of the assassination of President Kennedy and all commercial rights to it to the heirs of Abraham Zapruder for the sum of $1.

title: N.Y. Fed Assesses Outlook
description: The growth in retail sales and funds flowing into savings institutions have brightened the economic picture in the United States, according to the Federal Bank of New York. In its April monthly review, the Fed also pointed to the combination of lower prices for materials and reduced demand as other encouraging signs.

title: House, 3962, Backs Summer Program To Feed Children
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The House voted today to authorize $52.7million to continue a lunch program for children this summer.

title: Law Aides Criticize F.E.A. On Florida Fuel Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Federal and Florida lawenforcement officials testified under oath before Congress today that the Federal Energy Administration had refused to cooperate with them in investigations of suspected overcharges by Ven Fuel, a company partly owned by the Government of Venezuela, for fuel oil sold to the Jacksonville Electric Authority.

title: Glasgow Garbagemen End Strike After 13 Weeks
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, April 9 (Reuters)A strike by garbagemen that left Glasgow's streets strewn with hundreds of tons of rotting refuse was called off at a mass meeting here today.

title: Saint Laurent: A Classic Mood, A Comfortable Look
description: PARIS, April 8Yves Saint Laurent fluctuates between iconoclast and classicist. He's in his classic phase now and his clothes are a pleasure to behold.

title: Article 2  No Title
Amnesty Group Charges Abuse Of P.O.W.'s by Israel and Syria
description: LONDON, April 9  Amnesty International said today that both Syria and Israel violated Geneva conventions on the treatment of prisoners of war during the war in October, 1973.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners.)

title: HighVolume Rock By Johnny Winter, Now in a Top Hat
description: Johnny Winter, making his annual New York pilgrimage at the Felt Forum on Tuesday, seemed changed only in appearance. Gone were the flowing caftans; now a top hat, somewhat battered, is the only sartorially bizarre effect. Remaining is the same screechy attack on the bluesrock form that has characterized the Texas musician since he burst charismatically on the music scene in 1968.

title: Nicosia Wins Ruthless, Favored Funalon Next
description: Nicosia of the Mill Ridge Farm demonstrated a liking for the fast track at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the Ruthless Stakes for threeyearold fillies, Nicosia rallied in the stretch to score a three quarterlength triumph over Funalon, with Something regal next in the field of a dozen.

title: $16MILLION LOSS SET BY WADDELL & REED
description: Waddell & Reed, Inc., has disclosed in a proxy statement that it lost $16.2million last year, compared with earnings of $4.3million the year before and $8million in 1972.

title: As Asia Goes, So Goes New York
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.At last it begins to end, suddenly very quickly. rerun of Nationalist China's collapse, but delayed by 25 years of greatpower interventions.

title: Personal Guards Of Sikkim's King Disbanded by India
description: NEW DELHI, April 9 (Reuters)Indian troops have disarmed and disbanded the personal guards of the Chogyal of Sikkim, the Himalayan kingdom recently incorporated into the Indian political system, officials said today.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS HEALTH INSURANCE FOR UNEMPLOYED
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill to extend health insurance benefits to about three million unemployed workers.

title: Helping Hand Paid Back in Alimony
description: Ethelyn Morgan wanted to become a doctor, and Charles Morgan wanted to become a lawyer. When they were married in 1967, she was a sophomore studying biology at Florida State University, and he was a thirdyear prelaw student at the University of North Carolina. They had a lot of ambition, but no money.

title: State Prison Unit Accused of CoverUp
Plan for Only State Stewards Draws Criticism of N.Y.R.A.
description: The New York Racing Association will violently oppose any statute requiring that all track stewards be state appointed, its president said yesterday.

title: 2d Replacement for Fuentes Named in School District 1
description: Rufus B. Shorter was appointed yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker to assume the controversial post of acting superintendent of Community School District 1, and immediately proceeded to the school district office and put an end to a threeday sitin by supporters of Luis Fuentes, who was suspended in August.

title: Dutch Economy Still Low
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 9 (Reuters) Business activity in the Netherlands will continue to remain low this year although demand may show a slight recovery in the second half as a result of stimulatory policies abroad, especially in West Germany, the Dutch Central Planning Agency said in its 1975 Central ecomomic plan.

title: TRIAL OF CRABIEL IS RESET FOR TODAY
description: The trial of J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State, on charges of rigging highway construction bids was reset yesterday to begin today in Superior Court in Elizabeth after a twoday postponement.

title: Yankees And Mets: 3 in Doubt
Gribetz and Judges to Meet On Attica CoverUp Report
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that his counsel, Judah Gribetz, would meet shortly with senior judicial officials of the state to discuss the alleged coverup of possible crimes by law enforcement officers during and after the Attica prison revolt in September, 1971.

title: Vietcong Say Pilot Who Bombed Palace Defected to Them
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (AP)The jet pilot who bombed President Nguyen Van Thieu's palace yesterday later landed at a Vietcongheld airfield, a spokesman for the Vietcong delegation to the Joint Military Commission in Saigon said today.

title: A. Burton Carnes Is Dead at 78; Was Artist and Film Animator
description: A. Burton Carnes, an artist and photographer who had worked in advertising, motion pictures and printing, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 74 Irving Place.

title: U.S. MAY SHELTER SOME VIETNAMESE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 President Ford is considering contingency plans to evacuate thousands of South Vietnamese whose lives might be in jeopardy in the event of a Communist takeover, Government officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Paris in The New York Times yesterday described Tibor Rosenbaum as treasurer, although temporarily inactive of the World Jewish Congress. The congress says that Mr. Rosenbaum was replaced as treasurer of the organization in February by Solomon Ranee of Canada.

title: Worst of Recession Over, Finance Ministers Agree
description: PARIS, April 9The worst of the world's recession is over and no further measures of stimulation are necessary to get an economic recovery under way, finance ministers from major nonCommunist industrial nations agreed today.

title: Market Summary
Thousands of Jersey Jobs Open In Spite of Jobless Rate of 11%
description: NEWARK, April 9Thousands of jobs paying $9,000 to $20,000 yearly are going begging each month in New Jersey, despite the state's estimate that more than 380,000 residents are out of work.

title: Ford Picks Retired General For Energy Agency Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) President Ford said today that he would nominate Gen. Alfred D. Starbird, a retired Army officer, to a key energy post and James G. Watt, an Interior Department official, to be a member of the Federal Power Commission.

title: Stolen Safe FoundEmpty
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., April 9 (AP)A safe stolen last weekend from the Holyoke tax office was back in the city's hands today, minus nearly all of the $28,000 stored inside. The 850pound safe was found in a wooded area of Granby, Conn., on Monday and hauled back to Holyoke.

title: U.S. Judge to Be Queried on Alleged Sentencing Fix
description: Irving R. Kaufman, chief, judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here, asked Federal Judge Mark A. Costantino yesterday to appear before a special meeting of the Federal appellate judges to respond to charges recently made in the press concerning his judicial activities.

title: Louisiana Teamster Chief Gets EightYear Sentence
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., April 9 (AP)Edward Grady Partin, the Baton Rouge Teamster leader whose testimony helped send Jimmy Hoffa to jail, was sentenced today to eight years in prison.

title: 28 More Military Men Arrested As Portuguese Purge Continues
description: LISBON, April 9The armed forces announced the arrest today of 28 more officers and noncommissioned officers on charges of involvement in the attempted military coup on March 11. Three civilians were also reported arrested.

title: CHINA MAY ACCEPT SHORTTERM CREDIT
description: HONG KONG, April 9 (Reuters)China may accept the principle of shortterm credit in the coming year, according to the Bank of America's Asia Office publication, China Spotlight.

title: DR. WILLIAM BLACKWELL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 9Dr. William Blackwell, corporate secretary of the International College of Surgeons, died here yesterday in a diabetic coma. He was 64 years old.

title: Budget Beginning
description: By agreeing, however reluctantly, upon a compromise resolution setting forth anticipated levels of Federal revenue, Federal spending and probable deficit, the House Budget Committee has made a responsible start on the urgent and difficult task of controlling the budget.

title: Iran Again Buys a Share Of Big German Concern
description: BONN, April 9Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi of Iran has widened his industrial holdings in West Germany by buying a 25 per cent share of Deutsche Babcock and Wilcox, A.G., of Oberhausen, which makes power generating machinery.

title: MOBIL WILL RAISE SHARE IN ARMCO
description: The Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) disclosed yesterday in London that the Mobil Oil Corporation would increase its share in that company from 10 to 15 per cent over the next five years.

title: SCHOOL VANDALISM CALLED WORSENING
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) A Senate report contended today that violence and vandalism in the nation's schools had reached a crisis level and was worsening rapidly.

title: Police Security Is Tight as Seoul Hangs 8 Men Convicted of Plot Against Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 9 About 150 policemen surrounded the Seoul Penitentiary this morning as eight men convicted by a military tribunal of having been members of an outlawed party were hanged.

title: Economic Worry Underlies Calm in Huey Long's Parish
description: WINNFIELD, La.  When Huey P. Long was assassinated 4?? years ago this September, the pine hills he had come from were a model of misery in a nation that was stricken everywhere by depression.

title: RIGHTS UNIT BACKS WIDER VOTING ACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that it favored expansion of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to protect the right of Americans of Spanish origin to vote, just as the law has helped to enfranchise black Americans in the last decade.

title: Islanders, Home Tonight, in Catbird Seat
description: If there is such a thing as a catbird seat, the New York Islanders must be perched on one today following their 32 upset victory over the Rangers Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. There are four playoff games tonight in the National Hockey League and the Islanders will be the only team playing at home with a onegame advantage in the twoforthreegame series.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS HEALTH INSURANCE FOR UNEMPLOYED
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill to extend health insurance benefits to about three million unemployed workers.

title: Sarnoff Asks Annual Data On U.S. Arts Organizations
description: The chairman of the Business Committee for the Arts called yesterday for an annual report on the nation's arts organizations to provide precise data on their source of funding.

title: Inmates' Right to Chaplain Subject of an A.C.L.U. Suit
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 9 (AP)The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit in Federal court today charging that the barring of a Catholic chaplain at the Adult Correctional Institution violated the First Amendment.

title: Rockefeller Says Filibuster Role Evoked Attempts at Blackmail
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 9Vice President Rockefeller said today that conservative Republicans had tried to blackmail President Ford to force a change in Mr. Rockefeller's position on the filibuster rule.

title: Eurodollar Requirements Cut
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction from 8 per cent to 4 per cent in bank reserve requirements on Eurodollar borrowings.

title: Main Thrust Against Saigon Expected From North
description: North Vietnamese attacks east and southwest of Saigon may represent the opening of an offensive in the area, according to United States military sources. The attacks at Xuan Loc, 38 miles east of Saigon, and near Tan An, 18 miles to the southwest, were preceded by heavy artillery and rocket preparation.

title: Panel Asks Ford to Speed Study on Colby
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence voted today to ask President Ford to expedite delivery of the Colby report and other top secret documents it has asked for in its investigation of the Government's intelligence apparatus, the committee chairman said.

title: Nazi Slaying of 6 Million Jews Is Termed Purely Desecration
description: Dr. Emil L. Fackenheim, a professor of philosophy at the Uoiversity of Toronto and a survivor of the Sachsenhausen Nazi concentration camp, said last night that the slaying of six million Jews in Nazi Germany was purely desecration for desecration's sake.

title: Arabs Fighting Eviction in Old Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, April 4For 40 of his 41 years, Ayub Hamis Tutungi has lived in a house with an extraordinary view.

title: City Seeks to Learn Location of Potholes
description: The Highways Department has asked the public to report potholes and other street conditions in need of repair to the appropriate borough office by calling one of the following phone numbers:

title: MENTAL CARE PLAN IS URGED FOR STATE
description: CHERRY HILL, April 9After two days of heated debate, with occasional bursts of rancor, New Jersey mentalhealth advocates meeting here agreed that a single, unified system of care was essential if state and county facilities were to emerge from the dark ages into the 20th Century.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Time Denies Harassing Simmons
description: Time Inc. yesterday formally denied any harassment of W. R. Simmons and Associates Research, against which it filed a breachofcontract suit last January.

title: Lacrosse Booms on Island
description: When Bill Ritch became lacrosse coach at Sewanhaka in Floral Park, L. I., 27 years ago, three Nassau County schools fielded varsities and, he recalls, people considered it an oddball sport. Now 45 county schools have teams, and college varsities are wellstocked with Long Islanders. Ritch explains the sport's popularity as follows:

title: For 10,000 on Road to Saigon, an Interrupted Journey
description: GO DEN, South Vietnam, April 9For some Vietnamese, the war just means sitting and waiting in the hot sun.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Paris in The New York Times yesterday described Tibor Rosenbaum as treasurer, although temporarily inactive of the World Jewish Congress. The congress says that Mr. Rosenbaum was replaced as treasurer of the organization in February by Solomon Kanee of Canada.

title: Westchester Unions Accept W.P.A. Jobs
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 9Westchester County's construction unions have agreed, with some misgivings, to the hiring of their unemployed workers for county projects at well below prevailing wages.

title: NIXON TOLD THIEU U.S. WOULD REACT TO RED OFFENSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The White House said today that President Richard M. Nixon privately assured the Saigon Government in 1973 that the United States would react vigorously to a major Communist violation of the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: Publishers Are Disturbed By ProductionCost Rise
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 9 A convention of newspaper publishers these days is a journey between economic optimism and pessimism.

title: Thaw in South Africa?
description: Prime Minister Vorster of South Africa knows that any hope he may have for an enduring peaceful relationship with black Africa requires meaningful changes at home an addition to helping resolve the issues of Rhodesia and Namibia. He has now authorized a modest but significant first step toward change of a kind that would impress South Africa's critics everywhere.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Florida Power and Light Company said yesterday it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission 3 million common shares of the company. The shares are to be publicly offered later through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. Goldman, Sachs & Co.; Salomon Brothers and White, Weld & C??

title: New Bond Issues
Maertens Cycling Victor
description: WEVELGEM, Belgium, April 9Freddy Maertens of Belgium won the GhentWevelgem pro cycling classic today by a wheel in a 10man sprint finish after the riders had battled bitter winds and snow squalls over 156 miles of cobbled roads. Maertens finished in 6 hours 14 minutes. The world champion, Eddy Merckx of Belgium, finished sixth.

title: Communists Tighten Grip On Approaches to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 10Communist forces tightened their grip on the approaches to Saigon yesterday and today as they penetrated a provincial capital 36 miles to the northeast and temporarty cut a major road 18 miles southwest of here.

title: GrandJury Leaks Are Laid to 3 Clerks
