description: Three men who were employed by the Bronx District Attorney's office to record the secret hearings of grand juries were arrested yesterday in the culmination of a sixmonth investigation into possible leaks of confidential information.

title: CANADIAN LEADERS MEET ON ECONOMY
description: OTTAWA, April 9  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau called the premiers of Canada's 10 provinces together here today for a wideranging discussion of energy and the country's worsening economic health.

title: Stars Defeat Nuggets
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April (AP)Moses Malone scored 30 points and hauled down 33 rebounds tonight as the Utah steps downed the Denver Nuggets, 122108, in the third game of their American Basketball series.

title: SHIFTS EXPECTED IN THAI POLICIES
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 9Current developments in Cambodia and South Vietnam can only accelerate shifts in Thailand's foreign policy, according to experienced diplomatic observers here.

title: Judge to Be Queried
description: Federal Judge Mark A. Costantino of Brooklyn was asked to appear before meeting of Federal appellate judges here to respond to charges developed by a Federalcity undercover operation in the Garment District. Details, Page 78.

title: Some Obstetrical Methods Criticized
description: An expert on the problems of birth for the World Health Organization said yesterday that several common American obstetrical practices used in labor and delivery were potendaily dangerous to the health of the baby about to be born.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The White House said President Nixon gave private assurances to Saigon in 1973 that the United States would react vigorously to a major Communist violation of the ceasefire agreement. The statement, in response to Senator Henry M. Jackson's charge of secret agreements, said the private assurances had been substantially the same as what Mr. Nixon and others were saying in public. They lost validity, the White House said, because Congress imposed a ban on American combat activity in Indochina in August, 1973. Senator Jackson clearly felt the statement vindicated the charge he had made. [1:8.]

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Greek Communist Exiles Starting to Return Home
description: ATHENS, April 10After almost 30 years of political exile, Pericles Kalodikis returned to Greece last November. An alert and forceful man of 69, he recently explained why.

title: Turks Accuse Greece in U.N. Over Arming of Aegean Isles
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 10 (Reuters)  Turkey accused Greece today of violating aninternational peace treaty by establishing military installations in the Dodecanese islands in the Aegean Sea.

title: Unhealthy Cure
description: For many jobless workers and their families, no aspect of the recession is harsher than the cutoff of health and hospital insurance that normally accompanies separation from the payroll in unionized industries. But the reality of the problem does not mean that a practical remedy is available through Government action, as is now being made clear by the stumbling efforts in Congress to design one.

title: STATES ASK VOICE IN COASTAL PLANS
description: CHERRY HILL, April 10The MidAtlantic Governors Conference called today for Federal legislation giving coastalstate governors a strong voice in any plans to drill for oil on the outer Continental Shelf.

title: Big John Connally In the Dock
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Watching Big John Connally of Texas in the dock here on charges of bribery, you have to remember him when he was Governor of Texas, Secretary of the Navy, a power in the Democratic party, wounded partner of Jack Kennedy in the Dallas assassination, and finally converted Republican, Secretary of the Treasury and adviser to President Nixon.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The families who've received Vietnamese children to adopt in recent days are a hardy lot. Most of them have had mountains of red tape to wade through, taking perhaps years, and they've had to suffer through the uncertainties of the current crisis.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: ExAttica Prosecutor Says Evidence Was Denied Him
description: Malcolm H. Bell, the fromer Attica prosecutor who has charged his superior with covering up possible crimes by law enforcement officers, told Governor Carey in his confidential report that he had been blocked from obtaining audiotapes and pictures of the assault on the prison in 1971.

title: Inflation Effect Given Blame for Decline
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, still trying to recover from one of its worst years in recent history, reported an 8.4 per cent drop in first quarter 1975 earnings yesterday, compared with the same period in 1974.

title: RETAIL SALES OFF BECAUSE OF CARS
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Retail sales in March declined slightly from the February level, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of preliminary estimates. The drop was attributed mainly to the fall in automobile sales following the end of special price rebates.

title: Big 6 Mayors Criticize State Budget; Ask $680Million More for Education
description: BUFFALO, April 10Mayor Beanie and the other Mayors of the state's Big Six cities attacked the new state budget today as a standstill document and called for an increase of $680million In state aid to localities for education.

title: NEW CAMERAS SOLD BY G.E. AND KODAK
description: The General Electric Company and the Eastman Kodak Company combined forces yesterday to introduce a new line of five pocketsized cameras and a new flashbulb system that combines eight photoflash bulbs in a single thin case. Kodak rose 1 on trading of 117,400 shares on the New York Stock Exchange to close at 94, while G. E. added a point and closed at 47 as 106,600 shares traded hands.

title: Byrne Reported to Weigh Appointing Kelly to S.C.I.
description: TRENTON, April 10Governor Byrne was reported today to be seriously considering appointing the former State Police Superintendent, David B. Kelly, as a member of the State Cornmission of Investigation.

title: Arthur Rosenstock Dies at 72; ExHead of Newspaper Guild
description: Arthur Rosenstock, a former president of the Newspaper Guild, died Wednesday evening at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 72 years old and lived at 1730 Mulford Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Parking Meter Rates Will Rise in Brooklyn
description: The rates for 1,120 parking meters in the downtown Brooklyn shopping and civic areas will be increased beginning Monday, it was announced by the Traffic Department.

title: ExProsecutor Tells of Thwarted Efforts
description: error's spokesman, was, supposed to have been held yesterday but was postponed after Mr. Lefkowitz informed Mr. Carey that he had a doctor's appointment.

title: SIMON BIDS SOVIET NEGOTIATE TRADE
description: MOSCOW, April 10 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told Soviet trade officials today that cooperation in bilateral trade talks here might enable the Ford Administration to offer Congress specific proposals for new trade legislation by the middle of the year.

title: Senate Budget Committee Lowers Ceiling on Spending for Defense
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Senate Budget Committee voted today a small reduction in its proposed ceiling on defense spending and a larger cut in programs aimed at combating the recession.

title: Hospital Evacuated Twice
description: LARGO, Fla., April 10 (AP)A bomb threat and a fire that followed a few hours later twice forced the evacuation of about 200 patients from Largo's Suncoast Hospital today. No patients were injured officials said. We definitely suspect foul play, Ken Whisenand, the hospital administrator said, referring to the possibility of arson.

title: THIEUNIXON NOTES LINKED TO TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Informed State Department officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger did not make public the private exchanges between President Richard M. Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam in 1973 because he felt this would have jeopardized reaching ?? ceasefire agreement in Paris.

title: Dichter's Fluent Fingers Play Music Full of Mercurial Moods
description: In a recital here two years ago, Misha Dichter gave a noteworthy performance of Schumann's Symphonic Etudes. It was another Schumann work, the Davidsbndler Dances, that found that pianist in his best form in his program in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

title: John M. Bailey Dies at 70; Democratic Party Leader
description: HARTFORD, April 10John M. Bailey, Democratic National Chairman during the Presidencies of John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, and Democratic State Chairman in Connecticut for nearly three decades, died this afternoon after a long battle with throat cancer. He was 70 years old.

title: FIGHTING IS HEAVY IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 11  Communist forces, bolstered by tanks and heavy artillery, maintained their pressure on Saigon today with more heavy fighting in and around Xuan Loc, a key provincial city 38 miles northeast of here. Control of the area was uncertain in a fluid battle situation.

title: Issues Reslated as Corporates Sell Out
description: New corporate offerings continued to sell out in the bond market yesterday, and, as a further sign of improvement, several recently postponed issues were rescheduled for sale later this month. Meanwhile, the taxexempt sector displayed a firm tone in its best session of the week, thanks partly to the successful reception of the State of New Jersey's recent $75million bond offering.

title: Lobby by Lobstermen Wins Restudy of Fine
description: TRENTON, April 10 (UPI) Lobstermen persuaded the Legislature today to reconsider a $5 increase in the fine for catching undersized lobsters.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: NEW YORKER AWARD GIVEN TO WALKERS
description: The 100 Club of New York, an organization of local business and professional men, presented its fourthannual Distinguished New Yorker Award last night in honor of Frank Walker, the 38yearold widower who was slain while trying to help a policeman recaptured a deranged prisoner at St. Vincent's Hospital on Jan. 30.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Phoenix vs. Quebec

title: FORD DIVIDEN CUT TO 60C FROM 80C
description: DETROIT, April 10Ford Motor Company directors today cut the quarterly dividend by 20 cents a share in a move that the company said could save $75million on an annual basis to be spent in developing more small, economical American cars.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Rolling Stones will apparently tour the United States this summer, but although rumors are bubbling over everywhere, nobody will formally confirm anything.

title: Senate Vote Backs Citizenship Rights For Robert E. Lee
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Senate voted today to restore full citizenship rights to Robert E. Lee, the Confederate General in the Civil War.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Rangers vs. Islanders

title: 2d Titles To Shaw, Babashoff
description: CINCINNATI, April 10Jenni Franks and Andras Hargitay broke American swimming records tonight, but Tim Shaw and Shirley Babashoff proved they were better than ever.

title: 3 Early Scores Set Stage for 83 Romp
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 10In a contest that saw three playoff game penalty records fall and another equaled, the New York Rangers routed their suburban rivals, 83, on the Islanders' ice tonight.

title: Uncle Sam: No More Mr. Nice Guy
description: WASHINGTON  Wherever one looks the rate of change on the international scene has achieved dizzying proportions, often with ominous overtones for United States interests. What is frequently overlooked, however, is that American behavior may be one of the greatest precipitators of this growing instability.

title: GIBSON IS FOUGHT OVER RESIDENCY
description: NEWARK, April 10 A Federal District Court judge today ordered the administration of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to show cause why it should not be barred from forcing most municipal employes to live in the city.

title: A Bright Night for the Sunshine Boys
description: Two men who rose from a New York slum to costar in a $4million movie about feuding vaudevillians in New York received certificates of appreciation last night from a man who came from the same slum to become Mayor of the city.

title: Cosmos Said to Woo Pele With $1Million
description: The New York Cosmos are negotiating with Pel and are reportedly willing to pay him $1million to nlav for them.

title: For a Solid Recovery
description: The finance ministers of the major nonCommunist nations, meeting in Paris, have proclaimed that the worst of the recession is over. Unquestionably, good grounds exist for concluding that the present slump, the most serious of the postwar period, will not turn into a depression on the order of the nineteenthirties. But confidence on that point scarcely warrants complacency about the forthcoming recovery, much less a conviction that enough has already been done to guarantee it.

title: G.O.P. Says Facts Belie Carey's Claim He Inherited Deficit
description: ALBANY, April 10Republican fiscal experts charged today that an analysis of tax collections by the state for the last fiscal year shows the facts startlingly in contradiction to Governor Carey's contention that he inherited a deficitridden budget.

title: Corn Futures Drop Daily Limit After Soviet Union Complaint
description: Corn prices dropped the 10centabushel daily limit yesterday following news that the Soviet Union had complained about the quality of recent corn shipments.

title: A Happy Admiral and Daughter
description: LANTANA, Fla., April 10 Ladies and gentlemen, my daughter, said the pale, enfeebled old man, turning to the strikingly beautiful young woman at his side.

title: Senate Upholds U.S. Abortion Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Senate refused today to halt the use of Federal funds to finance abortions for the poor.

title: 2 Legislative Units To Examine Charge Of Prison CoverUp
description: The chairmen of two legislative committees yesterday announced investigations into charges that officials of the State Commission of Correction covered up prison irregularities and spied on a critic.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY APRIL 11, 1975

title: Dance: Emperor Jones
description: Probably no choreographer of his generation was more sympathetic toward creating roles for the male dancer than Jose Limn. In the midnineteenfifties he assembled a series of pieces offering juicy lead roles for male dancers, several of which remain in the repertory of today's company. On Wednesday evening Clay Taliaferro relished his opportunity to dance The Emperor Jones as the piece made its first appearance in the twoweek season of the Jos Limn Dance Company at the Harkness Theater.

title: SENATORS BACK FOUR FOR COMMODITY UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)The Senate Agriculture approved President Ford's four nominees for membership on nominees for membership on a new Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Camiel Estate Guarded
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 10 (UPI)The state police have posted a 24hour guard at the Montgomery County estate of Peter J. Camiel, Philadelphia Democratic chief, because of threats made against his family.

title: Controlling Guns
description: Attorney General Levi, rightly concerned about the massive American traffic in handguns, is reportedly getting strong support from President Ford in his effort to develop new guncontrol legislation.

title: Lainie Kazan's Songs Get Sunny and Witty Touches
description: The image that has trailed Lainie Kazan since she replaced Barbra Streisand in Funny Girl eight years ago has been that of a chubby (or saftig, if you prefer) version of Miss Streisand. Now, however, Miss Kazan, who is appearing at the Rainbow Grill, has not only slimmed down attractively, but also eliminated whatever Streisand sounds may have lingered in her sinning.

title: SUMMARIES OF FINALS
description: 200Yard FreeStyle1, ?? Shaw, Long Beach Swim Club, 1 minute 38.357 seconds; 2, Tim McDonnell, U.C.L.A., 1:38.514; 3, Jim Montgomery, Indiana, 1:38.934; 4, John Naber, Southern California, 1:36.983; 5, Bruce Furniss, Long Beach Swim Club, 1:39.036; 6, Steve Nelson, Thurston Olympic, Olympia, Wash., 1:40.061; 7, Mark Greenwood, Southern California, 1:40.175; 8, Kurt Krumpholz, Santa Clara, Calif., 1:40.184.

title: Computerized Chrysler Engine Planned to Save Fuel in '76 Car
description: DETROIT, April 10  The Chrysler Corporation has ordered into production for 1976 cars a radically modified computerized engine that does away with the catalytic converter and improves fuel consumption, company officials said today.

title: Strike Force Asked On Oil Overcharges To Electric Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Senator Henry M. Jackson recommended today that state and city officials work with agents of the Federal Energy Administration in a special utility strike force to search for fuel oil overcharges to electric utilities.

title: Miss Graham Offers Solo Frontier
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April It seems that the Martha Graham Dance Company will not have a proper New York season in the immediate future, although it is rumored that the company will give a New York season in December. However, despite the lack of metropolitan exposure, the Graham company is active enough and at present embarked upon a spring tour.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: THOMAS F. BUCK
description: Thomas Francis Buck, a former assistant to the publisher of Look Magazine and a former advertising director of McCall's magazine, died WedInesday in Georgetown University Hospital, Washington. He was 62 years old and lived in Montrose, Pa.

title: Candidates Spent 74Million in Races For Congress in '74
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Candidates for House and Senate seats used almost $74million in their campaigns last year, Common Cause reported today.

title: Article 6  No Title
People in Sports
description: Admitting that I may have been a little disoriented in the beginning of the season, Marvin Barnes of the Spirits of St. Louis was happy to learn yesterday that he had been named rookie of the year in the American Basketball Association.

title: Saudis Planning Some Decentralization
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, April 7Half a century after Bedouin warriors, called the Ikhwan, united most of the Arabian Peninsula under King Ihn Saud, the Government of King Khalid plans to pass some power back to the farflung provinces, according to wellplaced informants.

title: Mixing of All Children Urged
description: ALBANY, April 10  All handicapped children should not be isolated in special schools and special classes, the New York State Education Commissioner said today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Off
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.2 billion tonmiles, 13.6 per cent below the corresponding week year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 425,232 cars, 15.9 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 24.5 per cent below last year.

title: Life With VietcongA Portrait by Refugees
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 10Refugees who fled from areas of South Vietnam lost by the Saigon Government in the last month report that the Communists have moved quickly to round up all ranking South Vietnamese Army and Government officers. But the refugees add that they know of only a few executions of Government officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: Net Savings Inflow a Record in March

title: Market Place
description: It makes little sense to some in Wall Street: the Ford Motor Company becomes the last of the Big Three auto makers to cut its dividend and the stock market streaks ahead.

title: Manufacturers Bank Gains; Morgan, Chemical Net Up
EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 2 million common shares of the Potomac Electric Power Company, at $10.625 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. and Goldman, Sachs & Co. The utility had said net proceeds would be used to reduce shortterm borrowings.

title: Probable LineUp For Yankee Game
description: DETROIT

title: MICKELSON HEADS U.S. RADIO IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Sig Mickelson, chairman of Northwestern University's journalism department, was appointed president of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty today in a move to consolidate the operations of the two networks.

title: Walker Evans Dies; Artist With Camera
description: Walker Evans, the photographer noted for his bleak, abstinent pictures of. American life, died yesterday of a brain hemorrhage at YaleNew Haven Hospital in Connecticut. He was 71 years old and held the title of professor emeritus of graphic arts at Yale University's School of Art and Architecture.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 10 (AP)The National Football League Players Association and the league's alumni association agreed today to discuss their dispute involving a players' pension fund.

title: Underwood Holds Lead
description: PENINA, Portugal, April 10 (Reuters)Hal Underwood of the United States shot a twounderpar 71 in the third round of the Portuguese open golf tournament today and took a twostroke lead at 216.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Friday, April 11, 1975

title: Notes on People
description: Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court, who was hospitalized until March 19 after suffering a stroke New Year's Eve, has returned to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. A court spokesman said that he would be there for a few days for a checkup and further tests. As a result, the 76yearold Justice may miss some of the final oral arguments of the current court term, which ends after two more weeks.

title: Carey Takes the Cake On Eve of His Birthday
description: ALBANY, April 10No one can ever say this is a halfbaked administration, Governor Carey commented today after he had received two cakes at a surpriseparty birthday celebration.

title: City's Fiscal Crisis: The Guarantees Against Defaulting
description: New York, America's biggest, richest city, which for many years supported a public budget second in size only to the Federal Government's, last week found itself in the humiliating and dangerous position of being unable to sell a note issue equal to less than half the expected yield from its sales tax. An advance of $400million in welfare aid from the state saved the city from having to postpone a payroll or repayment of loans due this month. But the nickintime rescue has raised, with renewed urgency a question that has been in the bark of people's minds ever since the city's fiscal affairs moved to the crisis stage last fall. That question is: Can New York default on its debts and go bankrupt?

title: POLICE BREAK UP FUNERAL IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 10  South Korean policemen today blocked a funeral mass for one of eight men hanged yesterday as a convicted plotter against the Government. The police seized the body and had it cremated without the family's consent.

title: LAYOFFS ARE SET BY PAPER MAKERS
description: The paper industry announced yesterday a series of layoffs, generally because of the weakness in the economy.

title: Retail Sales Advance
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $994million, down 2 per cent from the yearearlier 31.01billion. Total retail store sales were about $10.73billion, up 5 per cent from last year's $10.17billion.

title: Transcript of President's Address Before Congress on the State of the World
description: Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, distinguished guests, my very good friends in the Congress and fellow Americans: I stand before you tonight after many agonizing hours and very solemn prayers for guidance by the Almighty.

title: Stockholder Sues United Brands Co.
description: The troubles of the United Brands Company deepened yesterday with the first of what is expected to be a rash of stockholder suits against the giant food concern.

title: F.B.I. Finds Major Rise In LoanSharking Here
description: The new head of the New York regional office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that there had been a substantial increase in loanshark operations here as a result of the economic recession.

title: China Is Seeking Support Of Aussies in Tennis Bid
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 10China has applied for membership in the International Lawn Tennis Federation and has asked Australia to support its entry.

title: Government Rests in Connally Bribery Trial; Court to Hear Arguments Monday on Motion for Acquittal
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Government rested its case today in the bribery trial of John B. Connally, the former Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Attica's Legal Gadfly
description: When Robert P. Patterson Jr. was a student at the Columbia Law School in the late nineteenforties, he didn't really want to practice law. Only in his last year, when he found that law could mean public service, did he decide to enter the profession. Now a senior partner in Patterson, Belknap & Webb (the Patterson is his late father, who was Secretary of War), Mr. Patterson for years has been devoting the lion's share of his time to publicservice law, most recently in prison reform and the Attica prison case.

title: Con Ed Seen Lacking Way To Cut Rates
description: A management study of the Consolidated Edison Company ordered by the State Public Service Commission has concluded that increased efficiency by the company could not appreciably lower the company's rates.

title: Joyrider Aboard Cabin Cruiser Seized off Bayonne After Chase
description: A new $60,000 cabin cruiser was seized at her slip in Brooklyn early yesterday morning by a 20yearold joyrider who managed to elude pursuing police launches, helicopters and Coast Guard vessels until he steered the cruiserthe Smartalec IIinto a blind channel off Bayone, N.J.

title: Notes on People
description: Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court, who was hospitalized until March 19 after suffering a stroke New Year's Eve, has returned to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. A court spokesman said that he would be there for a few days for a checkup and further tests. As a result, the 76yearold Justice may miss some of the final oral arguments of the current court term, which ends after two more weeks.

title: WESLEY ROBERTS, G.O.P. CHAIRMAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) C. Wesley Roberts, who was Republican National Chairman under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack, in Alexandria, Va. He was 72 years old.

title: Money
description: Thursday, April 10, 1975

title: Subsidies for 3 Cheeses Ended by Common Market
description: BRUSSELS, April 10 (AP)The European Economic Community announced today that it was ending subsides on three types of cheese exported to the United States in its last concession to try to avoid a cheese war.

title: Police Cabs Make The Criminal Pay
description: As Jeremiah O'Connor eased his yellow taxi up to the traffic light at 115th Street and Eighth Avenue, the gleam of a gun barrel in the dim evening light caught his eye.

title: To End Any CoverUp
description: NASHVILLE, April 10Earlier this week, nine inmates at the Tennessee State Prison seized four prison counselors and held them hostage for eight hours, with pipes and makeshift knives for weapons. The rebelling inmates presented prison authorities with a list of eleven grievances but ultimately surrendered themselves and their hostages without anyone having been injured.

title: GLOMAR EXPLORER TO SAIL AGAIN SOON
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10 The Glomar Explorer, the ship that raised part of a Soviet submarine in the Pacific last year, will make another trip into the Pacific shortly, Corbett U. Allen, a vice president of Global Marine, Inc., said today.

title: Italy Is Removing Ban on Exports of Pasta
description: BRUSSELS, April 10 (AP)After a ban of more than a year and a half, Italy will be able to export spaghetti again, the Common Market announced today.

title: Illinois Bank Will Open 3 Unmanned Facilities
description: The Continental Bank announced yesterday that it planned to open three unmanned electronic banking facilities in downtown Chicago, the first by a bank in Illinoisa state that does not permit branch banking.

title: Computerized Chrysler Engine Planned to Save Fuel in '76 Car
description: DETROIT, April 10  The Chrysler Corporation has ordered into production for 1976 cars a radically modified computerized engine that does away with the catolytic converter and improves fuel consumption, company officials said today.

title: GROWTH RATE UP IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: The nation's money supply continued to grow at faster rates, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Elegiac Camera
description: Walker Evans singlehandedly raised American documentary photography to the ranks of art. His pictures, most of them snapped in moments of intuition, captured the naked realities of American society: its drawn Depression sharecroppers, bleak factory windows, desiccated towns and automobile graveyards. Some thought his eye for the failed promises of an abundant life too harsh; yet others rightly discerned an elegiac view of America in his work. There was indeed a statement in Mr. Evans's superb photographs. It was the perishability of material things along with the indomitableness of the human spirit. This humanity is Mr. Evans's testament to photography.

title: MORIARTY PERFORMS AS SINGER AT PIANO
description: Michael Moriarty, the actor a Tony Award winner last year for Find Your Way Home, after an attentiongeting film performance in Bang the Drum Slowlyis trying his wings as a singer and pianist at Michael's Pub, where he tells listeners, I've been ordered by the management, to have fun.

title: Amid Fray, A Tea Break For Troops
description: HUNG LOC, South Vietnam, April 10At a roadside cafe near here, some South Vietnamese airborne soldiers were taking a break today drinking iced tea and eating noodle soup.

Scrap Dealers Are Hurt by Recession And Falling Prices of Used Materials
description: Scrap dealers are among the first to suffer from recessions and the last to benefit from economic upswings. Thus, the National Association of Recycling Industries being its 62d annual convention here today in less than happy circumstances.

title: JOSEPH LANIEL, 85, FRENCH PREMIER
description: PARIS, April 10Joseph Laniel, a former French Premier, died yesterday at his Paris home after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: STATE URBAN FUNDS VOTED FOR 28 CITIES
description: The state Senate passed and Governor Byrne signed into law legislation giving 28 cities in New Jersey $38.9million in urban aid. Mr. Byrne said that the money would be used to maintain and upgrade municipal servces in the cities.

title: 3 Die in Hotel Blaze
description: LANSFORD, Pa., April 10 (AP)Fire heavily damaged the Aquila Hotel early today, killing three persons and injuring two others, one critically. The authorities identified the dead as Samuel Valick, 55 years old, a retired state trooper; Pete Porambo, 85, and John Rock, 65. The cause of the fire is unknown.

description: DEAR DIRECTOR OF INTERNAL REVENUE:

title: FALSE IDENTITIES COSTLY TO NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 10A Federal panel estimated today that the United States economy was losing billions of dollars annually because of illegal use of easily obtained false identity papers.

title: Peruvians Bow. Here In Dances
description: One of the best and most interesting folk dance companies to be seen here in years turned up at the Hunter College Assembly Hall on Wednesday night, when the National Folk Ensemble of Peru made its local debut.

title: Port Authority Increases Tolls at Crossings by 50%
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday raised basic automobile toll rates to $1.50 from $1 a round trip at the George Washington Bridge, Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and three other bridges, effective May 5.

title: Family Court Judges Here Assail Policy on Juveniles
description: New York Family Court udges said yesterday that the raditional methods for dealing with juvenile offenders, partic??lady those who have com??itted violent acts, had failed, ??nd they complained at a sem??ar here that nothing was ??eing done about it because ??o one would admit it.

description: Should New York State step in and begin appointing all the officials for sports events at Madison Square Garden?

title: Standard of Indiana Reduces Heating Oil 3 Cents Per Gallon
description: Price reductions were announced yesterday in the oil and chemical industries.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times of Feb. 26, reporting a Supreme Court deadlock on the issue of reproducing copyrighted written material, stated erroneously that the American Library Association was among the organizations backing unrestricted photocopying. The library association favors limitations on such copying.

title: REACTION IS COOL
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Leading members of Congress reacted quickly and overwhelmingly negatively tonight to President Ford's request for $722million in additional military aid to South Vietnam.

title: SENATE APPROVES CEILING ON PRICES FOR DOMESTIC OIL
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Senate passed today, by a vote of 60 to 25, legislation that would place a price ceiling on all oil produced in the United States.

title: Lisbon Says It Is Dissatisfied With Political Parties
description: LISBON, April 10The Goyernment's official spokesman expressed dissatisfaction today with Portugal's political parties and accused them of being more interested in their own power than in the country's welfare.

title: Bridge:
description: To win a national team championship with pickup teammates is a rare event. To do so as a nonmember of the organization is perhaps unique.

title: Krakatoa Is More Active
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 10 (AP)Krakatoa volcano, in the Sunda Strait between the islands of Sumatra and Java, has shown increasing activity in the last two weks, the department of Geology said today. Every five minutes the 570foot volcano has been belching smoke and causing occasional earthquakes.

title: A New Organ Is Dedicated at Tully Hall
description: The formal dedication Wednesday night of the new organ in Alice Tully Hall gave New York a concert hall equipped with a distinguished pipe organ of extraordinary versatility.

title: Hanoi Said to Aim at Averting Bloodshed
description: The tactical pattern of the heavy fighting in South Vietnam at and near Xuan Loc in the last 48 hours indicates to United States military analysts that the North Vietnamege nigh commana wants to destroy the defending Government divisions in the field and thus prevent them from falling back to offer a streetbystreet defense of Saigon.

description: The chairmen of two legislative committees yesterday announced investigations into charges that officials of the State Commission of Correction covered up prison irregularities and spied on a critic.

Only in his last year, when he found that law could mean public service, did he decide to enter the profession. Now a senior partner in Patterson, Belknap & Webb (the Patterson is his late father, who was Secretary of War), Mr. Patterson for years has been devoting the lion's share of his time to publicservice law, most recently in prison reform and the Attica prison case.

description: The Board of Estimate ratified the designation of Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn as a scenic landmark yesterday after receiving assurance that the action would not jeopardize Federal funds for resurfacing the six  mile  long boulevard, which runs from Prospect Park to Coney Island.

title: Tax Rebates' Mailing Date Is Linked to Appropriations
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (Ap) The first tax rebates and special Social Security payments can be mailed by May if Congress appropriates the necessary funds by May 1, White House spokesman said today. All of the checks could be paid out by no later than June 20, the spokesman said.

description: HORTON, Kan., April 10 (UPI)Members of two Indian tribes occupied a Federal Government office here for 12 hours yesterday and won the immediate ouster of the superintendent of the local United States Bureau of Indian Affairs.

Shinnick, the former Olympic athlete and fourth witness called before a Federal grand jury in recent weeks in connection with the search for Patricia Hearst, invoked the Fifth Amendment's provision against selfincrimination today but said he was innocent of any crime.

description: ALGIERS, April 10Presicient Valry Giscard d'Estaing arrived here today for the first French state visit to the former colony since the war that brought independence to Algeria and nearly brought civil war to France.

title: Article 5  No Title

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 10 (AP)Communistled forces attacked Government troops yesterday, killing 16 and wounding 20, officials said today.

title: Ford Stresses Support Of Intelligence Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, April 10President Ford made an impassioned appeal to Congress tonight not to allow its investigations of the United States intelligence, community to destroy national security or harm the effectiveness of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: ExAttica Prosecutor Says Evidence Was Denied Him
description: Malcolm H. Bell, the former Attica prosecutor who has charged his superior with covering up possible crimes by law enforcement officers, told Governor Carey in his confidential report that he had been blocked from obtaining audiotapes and pictures of the assault on the prison in 1971.

title: Fraud Is Charged To 4 ExOfficers Of Sanitas Services
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed charges of fraud and other violations of Federal securities laws against the Sanitas Services Corporation and four former officers and directors.

title: Long, Unbroken Tenure
description: John Moran Bailey looked like a political boss, talked like a political boss and for more than 25 years operated as one of the most effective political bosses in the country.

title: City Next Week to Mark Met Opera's 90th Year
description: To celebrate the completion of the Metropolitan Opera's 90th anniversary season, Mayor Beame has proclaimed next week Metropolitan Opera Week.

title: FIGHTING IS HEAVY IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 11  Communist forces, bolstered by tanks and heavy artillery, maintained their pressure on Saigon today with more heavy fighting in and around Xuan Loc, a key provincial city 38 miles northeast of here. Control of the area was uncertain in a fluid battle, situation.

title: 3Nation Pact on Gas
description: MOSCOW, April 10 (Reuters) West Germany, Iran and the Soviet Union today signed an agreement under which Soviet natural gas will be piped to West Germany and an equal amount of gas from Iranian fields will be supplied to the Soviet Union in compensation.

title: Hunter Will Face Tigers Here Today
description: Having succumbed to sociobaseball history in their season opener at Cleveland, the Yankees expect to use the newest chapter in their own history today to club the Detroit Tigers into submission in the home opener at Shea Stadium.

description: SAN DIEGO, April 10Faced with rising criticism inside and outside the church, the bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese of San Diego agreed today to a modification of his pastoral letter denying communion to Catholics who are members of proabortion groups such as the National Organization for Women.

title: Official State Rules Are Issued On Court's Education Mandate
description: TRENTON, April 10 (UPI)The state officially announced today what the public schools must do to provide the thorough and efficient education mandated by the State Supreme Court in 1973.

title: Police Cabs Make The Criminal Pay
description: As Jeremiah O'Connor eased his yellow taxi up to the traffic light at 115th Street and Eighth. Avenue, the gleam of a gun barrel in the dim evening light caught his eye.

title: People and Business
description: William Seidman, White House economic adviser, reminded a Washington audience yesterday that with the tax reduction out of the way, President Ford's top priority now was a national energy program.

title: Books of The Times
description: The dominant character in Frederick Exley's first confessional novel, A Fan's Noteswhich was published seven years ago, won a modest amount of critical praise, as well as several literary awards, and is now being reissued in a new edition (385 pages; Random House; hardcover, $10.; paperback, $4.95)was of course Frederick Exley, who, though he suffers throughout the novel a series of disastrous defeats, could nevertheless claim at the end the signal triumph of having written A Fan's Notes. But though Mr. Exley's new book, Pages From a Cold Island, is a sequel A Fan's Notes and involves the selfsame bumbling Exley character with a literary style occasionally suggestive of the mature W. C. Fields, perhaps the most interesting character in the book is a manuscript Pages From a Cold Island. This manuscript is introduced on page 9 of Mr. Exley's book. It is 408 pages of typescript, and though not unpublishable (All I had to do was Xerox it, put it In an envelope and mail it off to my agent.), it didn't at all work at that heady level I desperately yearned for it to work . .. because it was so unrelievedly desolate that despite its humor I was sure the reader couldn't turn back the final page (allowing he got that far) without wondering whence I'd mustered the will to put together its four hundred and eight pages of typescript. So Exley sets forth on a series of quixotic adventures, presumably to relieve it of its desolation.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Yoshi's, an attractive new restaurant at 52 West 55th Street, calls its cuisine Japanese continental, with steaks, roast beef, roast chicken, grilled pork, beef Stroganoff, salmon steak, sea food au gratin and french fries representing the mysterious West on a dinner menu dominated by such familiar orientalia as teriyaki, sukiyaki, tempura, sushi and sashimi. Connoisseurs of Japanese food will miss the more elaborate dishes available at larger, more purely Japanese restaurants, but everything we tried at Yoshi's was excellently prepared, beautifully presented, and true enough to Japanese tradition.

title: Embassy in Saigon Told To Begin Staff Reduction
description: WASHINGTON, April 10President Ford asked Congress tonight to clear authority to use American troops for the possible evacuation from Saigon of American citizens and tens of thousands of South Vietnamese.

title: REYNOLDS IN A DEAL ON JAMAICA BAUXITE
description: The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday the creation of a partnership with the Jamaican Government to carry on its bauxite mining operations there.

title: Braves Vanquish Bullets for a 10 Lead
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 10 The Buffalo Braves, the team Jack Ramsay calls the best I've ever coached, folowed a seasonlong formula and toppled the Washington Bullets, 113102, tonight before an unbelieving crowd of 17,140 at Capital Centre.

title: FRED VANT HULL
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 (AP) Fred Vant Hull, former University of Minnesota football star who also played professionally for the Green Bay Packers, died today at a Minneapolis hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: Rangers Rout Islanders, Even Series: Knick Win 10696, Tie Playoff at 11
description: After 69 days, the Jim Barnett trade finally helped the Knicks.

description: BASEBALL

title: About New York

Roosevelt Drive and 90th and 91st Streets.

title: JOHN J. O'BRIEN
description: QUINCY, Mass., April 10 (AP)  John J. O'Brien, who headed the International News Service bureau in New York after World War I, died Tuesday in Florida, where he moved after his retirement in 1963. He was 86 years old.

title: NEW PHASE IS READY FOR ALASKA PIPLINE
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 10 (AP)The transAlaska oil pipeline is slated to be put into place without fanfare this week, the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company has announced.

title: Apartment Referral Companies Are Target of an Inquiry Here
description: Last September, Stephen Jasper, a 23yearold bookkeeper looking for a new apartment, went to an apartment referral firm after seeing its advertisement.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Bob Oliver, playing first base, will be another making his Yankee home debut today. . . . Not one but six ceremonial first balls will be thrown out before the opener. The tossers will he the six Jackson Heights children who were orphaned when their father, Frank Walker, was killed trying to help a police officer last January. The children are Raymond, 13; Linda, 12; Frank, 10; Theresa, 8; Daniel, Kelly, 4. . . . As part of the pregame ceremonies, the Yankees will honor the United States Marine Corps on its 200th anniversary. . . In attendance will be 4,000 city school children who earned free admission by their scholastic performances.

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill For MiddleIncome Housing
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs approved legislation today that would subsidize interest costs on mortgages to help middleincome families buy homes.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
VIETCONG AIDE PUTS POLITICAL AIM FIRST
description: PARIS, April 10 (AP)The foreign minister of the Communists' Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam said today that the Vietcong were trying to obtain their ob. jectives if possible by calm than military means.

title: Subway Rider Fatally Shot On IND Train in Harlem
description: An unidentified middleaged man was fatally shot on a subway train in Manhattan last night during an apparent argument with a younger man as the train pulled into a Harlem station

title: Polite Applause for the Man in Green
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10In about 20 minutes Lee Elder would be teeing off in the Masters as that tournament's first descendant of the slaves who before the Civil War worked the nursery where the Augusta National Golf Club now sprawls among pines and dogwood. In the white clubhouse that contributes to the plantation atmosphere, he was sipping a 7Up as a misty rain dampened the famous course. Are you going to wear a rainsuit? somebody asked. And mess up this pretty green, Lee Elder replied. He was wearing green slacks and a green sweater over a green shirt. None of the greens matched perfectly but the significance of the color was obvious. The winner of the Masters each year is awarded a green jacket, symbolic of membership in the club. Three shades, he said, holding a green match book that he had taken from the bar. That way, I was sure I'd match this shade.

title: Crabiel Trial Judge Separates Katz as Too Sick to Face Court
description: ELIZABETH, April 10Judge John A. Ackerman today separated George Katz from the bidrigging conspiracy trial of J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State, saying Mr. Katz was too ill to stand trial.

title: Hawks Sink Bruins in Overtime
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (AP)Ivan Boldirev's goal after 7 minutes 33 seconds of overtime gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 43 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a firstround game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COLE CHAMPAGNE There's good news for Cole Porter fans, with his rarely revived CanCan opening tonight in a production by the All Souls Players at the All Souls Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. Five songs, trimmed from the 1953 original, are being restored with the cooperation of the composer's estate, which also lent a hand to The Pirate revival last season. Jeffery K. Neill is again director and, choreographer, with a cast of 26 singers and dancers. The company also reports helpful encouragement from Lilo, now a retired New Yorker; who introduced I Love Paris that durable souvenir from the show, along with a new dancing redhead named Gwen Verdon.

title: Life Under Vietcong: A Portrait by Refugees
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 10Refugees who fled from areas of South Vietnam lost by the Saigon Government in the last month report that the Communists have moved quickly to round up all ranking South Vietnamese Army and Government officers. But the refugees add that they know of only a few executions of Government officials.

title: EARLY VOTE URGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 10President Ford appealed to Congress tonight to approve without delay nearly a billion dollars in military and humanitarian aid for Saigon to give South Vietnam a chance to save itself as a country and make possible a largecale evacuation of Americans and South Vietnamese should the worst come to pass.

title: 3 GUILTY IN DEATH OF 2 POLICEMEN
description: Three reputed members of the Black Liberation Army were found guilty yesterday of murdering two New York City policemen, Joseph A. Piagentini and Waverly MoJones, nearly four years ago.

title: Walker Evans Dies
description: Walker Evans, the photographer noted for his bleak portraits of American life, died yesterday. He was 71 years old. Page 90.

title: Sikkim Acts to Become an Indian State
description: NEW DELHI, India, April 10 (AP)The legislature in the Himalayan kingdom of Sikkim voted today to abolish the monarchy and seek full statehood in India. A referendum on the two actions was set for Monday.

title: 7,000 Attend Rites For 2 Children Slain In Jersey Abduction
description: UNION CITY, N.J., April 10Seven thousand mourners, mostly Cubans who fled their homeland after Fidel Castro came to power, crowded into dusty Roosevelt Stadium today to pray for 11yearold Esli Hall and her brother, Robert, 6, who were murdered after being kidnapped.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY APRIL 11, 1975

title: Advertising
description: With its May issue, Essence, the service magazine for black women, begins its sixth year as one of the few publications in this country showing advertising page gains over last year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Proposed increases in license and inspection fees that would generate almost $6million more a year in revenue for the city were attacked by both the taxi and electrical industries.

title: Saudi Loan to Syria Set
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 10 (Reuters)Saudi Arabia will lend Syria $220million to build a factory for smelting scrap iron, a fertilizer plant and a plant to make steel pipes, under an accord signed here today. Saudi Arabia will pay the loan over three years and Syria will repay interest free, over 13 years beginning in 1983, it was said.

title: UNICEF Official Cites Hanoi Pledge On Aid to Children
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10Vietcong authorities have told the United Nations Children's Fund that assistance for children will be given high priority because Vietnam has lost so many men in 20 years and because children are the future.

title: Marjorie Main, Actress, Dies; Ma Kettle of Movies Was 85
description: Marjorie Main, a stage actress who topped her triumph as the mother in Broadway's Dead End in 1935 with more than 100 roles in Hollywood films, died yesterday in Los Angeles. She was 85 years old.

title: U.S. TO INVESTIGATE PATRONAGE IN CITY
description: The United States Department of Labor yesterday ofdered an investigation into the Beame administration's use of Federal publicservice job money to hire Democratic district leaders and others with political connections to work in city neighborhoods.

title: Phnom Penh Defense Weakens; Rebels Within 3 Miles of Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 10The weary and thinly stretched army defending this encircled city fell back at several points today, leaving large gaps in its defense.

title: 7,000 Attend Funeral Of Abducted Children
description: UNION CITY, N.J., April 10Seven thousand mourners, mostly Cubans who fled their homeland after Fidel Castro came to power, crowded into dusty Roosevelt Stadium today to pray for 11yearold Esli Hall and her brother, Robert, 6, who were murdered after being kidnapped.

title: Rockwell Net Falls 39.1% Despite 22% Sales Rise
New Jersey Briefs
description: Assistant State Treasurer Clifford Goldman has reported that revenues this year are coming in somewhat higher than the state's original gloomy forecasts. Mr. Goldman said at Trenton yesterday that at the current rate about $21million more would be coming in than forecast in the Byrne administration's budget. He said the extra money would allow reinstatement of some programs cut earlier this year because of the projected budget deficit, especially construction projects that would help the state economy.

title: White House Is Said to Support Political Figure for Cuban Post
description: MIAMI, April 10  White House aides are urging the. Department of Health, Education and Welfare to appoint a Cuban political figure in this country as director of the Cuban Refugee Program, according to. Cubans who work for the assistance agency. Previously the post has been held by nonpolitical specialists.

title: ACREAGE RAISED 15% FOR WHEAT SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz announced today a 15 per cent increase in the amount of wheat acreage eligible for Federal price support protection in 1976.

title: SENATE APPROVES CEILING ON PRICES FOR DOMESTIC OIL
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Senate passed today, by a vote of 60 to 25, legislation that would place a price ceiling on all oil produced in the United States.

title: Article 4  No Title
Bid for Oil Agenda Continuing in Paris
description: PARIS, April 10  A group of oilexporting and consuming nations struggled here today to bridge gaps between developed and developing nations over an agenda for a fullscale conference this summer.

title: Giants Take Opener, 20
description: SAN DIEGO, April 10 (UPI) Gary Matthews doubled home Bobby Murcer in the 10th inning and later scored on an infield out as the San Francisco Giants defeated the San Diego Padres, 20, in the opening game for both teams tonight.

title: Labor Against Itself
description: The House of Commons has mustered a robust majority of 226 for continued British membership in the European Common Market, but in circumstances acutely embarrassing to Prime Minister Wilson and ominous for the Labor Government's future. Eleven more Labor party members voted against the Government than supported it, and another 37 were absent or abstained.

title: PROTEST IS MADE ON THE BILLY ROSE
description: A group of theatrical figures said yesterday that they feared that the Billy Rose Theater at 208 West 41st Street was being allowed to drop into decay and could be destroyed.

title: Pirates 84 Victors
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (AP)Willie Stargell's second home run of the game broke a tie in the eighth inning and helped the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 84 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The game was the season's opener for both teams.

title: About the Mets
description: The Mets announced they had verbally signed Jesus Alou as a replacement for Cleon Jones, now on the disabled list with a damaged left knee. Alou, one of three brothers who have played in the major leagues, is 32 years old and has been an outfielder with San Francisco, Houston and Oakland with a .280 career batting average. The A's released him 10 days ago and he went home to the Dominican Republic. . . . He'll join us maybe Saturday in Pittsburgh, Yogi Berra said. He can pinchhit for us and, when Cleon comes back, we'll decide then what to do with Alou. . . . Tug McGraw threw for 10 minutes before the game, about onequarter of my full heat but it felt great. The former Met pitcher underwent surgery last month for a knot below the left shoulder blade and may pitch for Philadelphia around May 1. . . . Joe Torre saved the Mets some grief with a diving stop of a line drive in the seventh inning with two Phillies on base. Torre sprawled on the ground, jumped up and beat Jim Lonborg to third base for a forceout. . . . Next for the Mets: two games in Pittsburgh, two in Philadelphia, two in St. Louis.

title: EARLY VOTE URGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 10President Ford appealed to Congress tonight to approve nearly a billion dollars in military and humanitarian aid for Saigon to give South Vietnam a chance to save itself as a country and make possible a largescale evacuation of Americans and South Vietnamese should the worst come to pass.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER GAIN
description: Increasing confidence in the economy sent prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market higher yesterday in steppedup volume.

title: Stewart in London Debut
description: LONDON, April 10 (AP) James Stewart, 65 years old, made his London stage debut last night to cries of Bravo and six curtain calls. Appearing in Harvey, Mr. Stewart also won rave reviews from British critics even though they were cool to Mary Coyle Chase's 30yearold play.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, April 10, 1975

title: Initial Rezoning Step Approved For Arab Island Off S. Carolina
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., April 10 The Charleston County Council all but cleared the way today for a controversial resort planned by the Kuwaiti owners of a virtually undeveloped barrier island 22 miles south of here.

title: Phnom Penh Defense Weakens; Rebels Within 3 Miles of Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 10The weary and thinly stretched army defending this encircled city fell back at several points today, leaving large gaps in its defense.

title: REACTION IS COOL
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Leading members of Congress reacted quickly and overwhelmingly negatively tonight to President Ford's request for $722million in additional military aid to South Vietnam.

title: Reds Top Dodgers, 76, Sweep 3Game Series
description: CINCINNATI, April 10, (AP) Charlie Hough, in relief, hit two batters in succession, setting up Tony Perez's tiebreaking double in the eighth inning that gave the Cincinnati Reds a 76 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Dodgers. The victory gave the Reds a sweep of their threegame series with the defending National League champions.

title: Transportation Unit Stages Train Crash
description: PUEBLO, Colo., April 10It is two minutes and counting, an electronically amplified voice boomed over the blowing sand and tumbleweeds of the Colorado Desert yesterday.

title: Equity Aide Sentenced
description: WAUKEGAN, Ill., April 10 (UPI)Fred Levin, vice president of the defunct Equity Funding Corp., pleaded guilty today to state charges of forgery and fraud and was sentenced to two to eight years in prison.

title: I.B.M.'s Earnings Advance Only 1.4%; Westinghouse Shows an 8.4% Drop
description: Citing a sharp decline in computer sales, the International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday a profit rise of only 1.4 per cent for the first quarter. Analysts see little hope for substantial earnings improvement before late this year.

title: SPOUSE OF FORD AIDE IS APPARENT SUICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) James W. Howe, the husband of Betty Ford's personal secretary, died tonight of a gunshot wound. The police said it was selfinflicted.

title: Regional Presidential Primary Elections Sought in Three Sections of the Country
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Efforts to establish regional Presidential primaries, which could radically alter the process of selecting nominees in 1976, have begun in three sections of the nation.

title: Valentino Revives Elegance For a Chilly April in Paris
description: PARIS, April 10Anyone around here remember elegance? It's a quality once honored in fashion circles. It was, in fact, once the vortex. It took Valentino, a foreigner, to revive it the other night, and not everyone was delirious.

title: Extent of AntiCatholicism Is Debated; Issue Linked to Abortion and School Aid
description: After Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin was convicted in Boston last February of manslaughter in an abortion operation, a spokesman for the American Roman Catholic hierarchy said that much of the news coverage of the event had been marked by innuendo and unfounded accusation directed against the Catholic community.

title: Article 3  No Title
New Honors for Painter on Union Sq.
description: Isabel Bishop is very taken with Union Square. With a painter's eye, she has watched it for 41 years from the winow of her studio at 16th Street and Broadway, observing the ebb and flow of human traffic.

title: Phils Defeat Mets in 11th
description: The New York Mets, who won their opening game in the ninth inning Tuesday, lost their second game in the 11th yesterday and then took the act on the road while the Yankees edged onto the stage with Catfish Hunter.

title: Music: A Brass Quintet
description: Music for brass quintet can be a problem. The repertory consists mostly of anachronisticsounding works from the Baroque, bland presentday efforts and more or less appropriate transcriptions. And the sound of such an ensemble, even at its best, can too easily lapse into an elephantine smoothness, bereft of variety or spunk.

title: 67 by Nichols Leads Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10The rain, which falls on the just and unjust alike, also fell today, for good measure, on the opening day of the Masters golf tournament. The result was a slow track with soft greens, a combination that yielded no fewer than 14 subpar rounds.

title: NonOrphans Reported Among Airlifted Children
description: A California Congressman's aide and a representative of the American Friends Service Committs said yesterday that they had found a dozen nonorphans among the hundreds of children who had been airlifted from Vietnam and were being processed this week by adoption agencies at a military installation in San Francisco.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: SLAIN BOY'S MOTHER CONTRADICTS POLICE
description: The mother of a 10yearold black youngster slain, in Jamaica, Queens, in 1973 denied at a Police Department hearing yesterday that she had made statements that became the basis for a new inquiry into the dismissal of two white policemen in the killing.

title: Chenault Sentence Upheld
description: ATLANTA, April 10 (AP) The Georgia Supreme Court has upheld the death sentence of Marcus Wayne Chenault, a black man: from Dayton, Ohio convicted in the shooting death of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., mother of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Brazilian Opposition Set Back In Campaign on Human Rights
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 10 The Congressional apposition, defying veiled warnings from rightwing elements of the military Government, today sought to summon the Minister of Justice before Congress for questioning on the treatment of political prisoners.

title: PIERRE R. VIGNERON
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) Pierre R. Vigneron, professor emeritus and former chairman of the Universiy of Chicago's department of Romance languages and Literature, died Tuesday. He was 78 years old.

title: Ornithological Phone Line Is for the Bird Watchers
description: Twelve Eastern bluebirds, two piping plovers, one little blue heron, one black phase gyrfalcon but no paaartriidge in a pear tree.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times of Feb. 26, reporting a Supreme Court deadlock on the issue of reproducing copyrighted written material, stated erroneously that the American Library Association was among the organizations backing unrestricted photocopying. The library association favors limitations on such copying.

title: F.C.C. Urged to Extend Ad Codes for Children's TV
description: The Council on Children, Media and Merchandising, a consumeradvocacy group based in Washington, yesterday petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to adopt rules that would protect children from advertising abuses, not only on Saturday and Sunday mornings but in evening time as well.

title: 18 Welfare Centers Abandon Innovation Of Saturday Hours
description: Starting tomorrow, the city's Department of Social Services will suspend Saturday business hours at 18 welfare centers that had for the last six months opened their doors an extra day to accommodate their clients.

title: Carey and Beame Skip Work for Yankees
description: Mayor Beame and Governor Carey were conferringnot about state aid or politics, but about Catfish Hunter.

title: Tombstone Salesman Held on Bribery Charge
description: To get Woodlawn Cemetery's daily list of burials a day ahead of its official release, Alfio Spina, a 39yearold Bronx tombstone salesman, was allegedly willing to pay the cemetery's night watchman $40 a week. But, afoul of the law, he upped the ante, the police said, and deepened his legal problems.

title: Spirits Beat Nets; Lead Series
Elder, Cut on 152, Accepts It Calmly
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11With a sixoverpar 78 in the second round for a 36hole total of 152, Lee Elder, the first black golfer to compete in the Masters tournament, failed to qualify today for the final two rounds. But the 40yearold touring pro, had no excuses and didn't appear overly disappointed.

title: Watchdog Unit Says That It Will Correct Inaccuracies in Ads
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Accuracy in Media, Inc., a selfstyled press watchdog, consented in an agreement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission to correct its own inaccuracies in newspaper advertisements seeking stockholder support for resolutions calling for more accurate and fairer coverage by the news on TV.

title: CHARTER FLIGHT AID PROPOSED BY C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)Expressing fear that its earlier proposals would be too costly and too restrictive, the Civil Aeronautics Board proposed new rules today to make charter flights more attractive and less costly to travelers.

title: Cotton Industry Fighting to Avert Losses On Defaults by Textile Mills in Far East
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The United States cotton industry, already hard hit by the recession, faces severe losses unless diplomatic efforts now under way can reverse largescale defaults  equaling nearly onefourth of this year's total expected shipments of cottonon contracts by textile mills in four Far Eastern countries.

title: Jacques G. Bernier Weds Ruth Chase
description: Ruth Mikkels Chase, daughter of Robert Willard Chase, United States Consul General in Alexandria, Egypt, and Mrs. Chase, was married Wednesday in Alexandria to Jacques Gerard Bernier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Bernier of. CarletonsurMer, Quebec. The Rev. Robert Orr performed the ceremony in All Saints Anglican. Church.

title: A Novelist's Eye in Isabel Bishop Art
description: One of the great standard pleasures of life is the sight of free human beings walking around in a defined but open space. This pleasure was fundamental to ancient Athens. It was common form in Rome until the invention of the automobile. All the great European cities have allowed for it.

title: Islanders Eliminate Rangers At 11 Seconds of Overtime, 43
description: Sudden death came to the New York Rangers last night more suddenly than any other time in Stanley Cup history.

title: G.M. BENEFIT FUND NEAR EXHAUSTION
description: DETROIT, April 11The General Motors Corporation said today that its supplemental unemployment benefits fund to pay jobless benefits to laidoff workers would be exhausted the first week of May.

title: For the Rangers, a Humiliating Finish
description: The circle was completed last night at Madison Square Garden. Joining the New York Mets, who rose to outshine the Yankees in baseball; the Nerd York Jets, who outclassed the venerable Giants in football, and the New York Nets, who upstaged the Knicks in basketball, the New York Jets Islanders became No. 1 in the New York hockey scene, displacing the stunned Rangers.

title: Article 9  No Title
N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Rangers vs. Islanders

title: Berkey Photo to Market Russian Camera in U.S.
description: Berkey Photo, Inc., said yesterday it would market a Russianmade camera nationally in the United States.

title: Onassis Said to Have Planned Divorce, Provided $3Million for Widow in Will
description: Under the will of her late husband, Jacqueline Onassis receives $3million, a bequest far less than published reports indicated she would receive, according to friends of the Onassis family.

title: English Comedy
description: ???A Private Enterprise," the ???st feature film to be di???ted by Peter K. Smith, a year-old Englishman, is a ???mpathetic comedy about ???nebody whose values are ??? rate.Shiv (Salmaan P???), its hero, is a young Indian engineer who works in Birmingham as a laborer but dreams of making his fortune manufacturing and selling plastic toy elephants.Shiv is less naive than madly hopeful. The elephants he wants to market are of a vulgarity that reduces shop???girls to helpless giggles. When a snobbish English girl picks him up on the train, he ???s the last one to realize that to her he is just another ???exotic ornament, a higher???-class version of one of his ???elephants."A Private Enterprise" has ???he shape of comedy but its ???one, ultimately, is sorrowful, ???ot unlike the Anglo-Indian comedies of James Ivory and ???smail Merchant. Shiv is not ??? tragic character. He's a ???efuddled one, trying unsuccessfully to fit into a society ???hat doesn't want him.The film is small, precise ???nd, at crucial moments, ???eautifully funny, as when a ???adical Indian friend quotes Chairman Mao to the back-???liding Shiv. "A Private Enterprise" was shown at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday in the New Directors/???ew Films series. It will be ???iven a second screening here tonight at 8:30.??? Comedy

title: Slain Correction Officer Eulogized in Harlem Rite
description: The dazed widow of Theodore Giddens slowly climbed the steps of St. Charles Roman Catholic Church in Harlem yesterday with the help of her daughter and brother as 200 correction officers saluted in a farewell tribute to Mr. Giddens, a fellow officer who died trying to stop a robbery while off duty.

title: D'ELBERT KEENAN
description: D'Elbert Keenan, who retired as associate professor of French at the Washington Square College of New York University in 1969 after 42 years in the French department, died of cancer Thursday evening at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 11 Fifth Avenue.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: ROSCOE, N. Y.  Here on the fabled streams of the Catskills, where fly fishing for trout in the United States was born, the early season angler approaches his sport much as he would woo a passionate lady of many moods.

title: Young Poet's Haiku Displayed With Those of Masters
description: Cathy Toscano of Avenue J, Brooklyn, will join Basho, Hokushi, Buson and other classical masters of the Japanese haiku when her winning haiku is displayed, with theirs as part of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's celebration of the 60th anniversary of its Japanese HillandPond Garden.

title: PanAmerican Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) President Ford today proclaimed next week PanAmerican Week and Monday, April 14, as PanAmerican Day, in observance of 85 years of cooperation among the countries of the Western hemisphere.

title: Ford Selects Two To Direct Agency On Fire Prevention
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) President Ford announced today that he would nominate John L. Petersen, a lawyer of Aurora, Ill., to head the new National Fire Prevention and Control Administration.

title: For Augusta, The Masters Crowd Means People Who Spend Money
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11games Lester, owner and manager of the Discotheque GoGo Lounge on Broad Street, Augusta's main thoroughfare, was delighted. He had a house full of happy, wellbehaved customers, they were all spending money, and his headliner, Miss Sandy O'Hare, the Improper Bostonian, recognizable even with her clothes back on, was sitting in his office after receiving an enthusiastic welcome beneath the flickering red and blue lights.

title: LAST AMERICANS LEAVE CAMBODIA; EMBASSY CLOSED
Keeping Secrets
description: Few would dissent from President Ford's belief in the value of an effective intelligence system. Nor is it open to dispute that officials in all branches of Government charged with intelligence responsibilities have special obligations to protect the secrecy of vital information, sources and procedures.

title: Market Place
description: The story, a familiar one in Wall Street these days, has its origins in the bull market in the late nineteen sixties.

title: Decoy Used in Robberies of Elderly
description: A young woman, telling elderly people in the Bronx that she has mistakenly received their mail, has been tricking them into opening their apart ment doors so that her two male companions can rush in and mug them, the police said yesterday.

title: Market summary
description: Friday, April 11, 1975

title: Give me your tired, your poor...
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.Last Sunday evening, with an unseasonal April wind storm chilling frail bodies and blowing out candles, several hundred Vietnamesemostly women and childrengathered on the sidewalk in front of the White House for a prayer vigil. They prayed that Americans would help save their families left behind in Vietnam.

title: Israelis Report Quiet Visit By Soviet Representatives
description: JERUSALEM, April 11Two representatives of the Soviet Union visited Israel secretly last week and conferred with Premier Yitzhak Rabin and other Israeli leaders during their twoday stay, Israeli Government officials said here today.

title: Central Park Opening A RollerSkating Area
description: Roller skating comes to Central Park today with an area set aside for use from noon to 6 P.M.

title: Connecticut Town Shuts Schools in Fund Shortage
description: HARTFORD, April 11 All 12 public schools in East Haven were closed indefinitely, today because school funds have been exhausted, affecting 5,700 pupils and leaving 300 teachers temporarily out of work.

title: 1,900 Accept Plan Offered by I. B. M. On Early Retiring
description: ARMONK, N.Y., April 11 (UPI)About 1,900 of the 8,000 employes of the International Business Machines Corporation with 25 years service or more have accepted a company offer for early retirement with what amounts to a bonus of two years' salary in addition to their pensions.

title: Suit Filed to Bar Congregations From Meeting in Public Schools
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 11 A trial date of June 4 was set today for a civil suit challenging the practice of the East Windsor Township Board of Education in allowing religious congregations to use its school buildings for services and meetings.

title: G.E. PROFIT FALLS 39% FOR QUARTER
description: Although revenues rose slightly, the General Electric Company, the nation's leading electrical products maker, reported a 39 per cent drop in its earnings for the first quarter of this year compared with the same period a year ago.

title: BENJAMIN SOLOMON
description: Benjamin Solomon, a founder and director of Vanguard Records, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 410 West 24th Street.

title: Gerulaitis Triumphs, Gains Semifinals
description: ST. LOUIS, April 11 (UPI) Vitas Gerulaitis of New York, the youngest player in the $60,000 St. Louis tennis classic, advanced to the semifinal round today by defeating Jeff Borowiak, 76, 16, 63.

title: SOVIET SIGNS PACT FOR LOAN IN WEST
description: MOSCOW, April 11The Soviet Union signed an agreement today to borrow $250million from a group of Western banks.

title: R. D. MATHEWSON OF U.N. PUBLICATIONS
description: Richard D. Mathewson, chief of special publications of the United Nations from 1950 to 1966, died Wednesday in Hyannis, Mass. He was 69 years old and formerly had lived for many years in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Stocks Up 4th Day; Dow Rises by 8.21
description: The stock market yesterday Finished higher for the fourth consecutive session with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its highest level in night months.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: ART WHIRL Local creativity, professional and nonprofessional, can turn up in surprising places and from unexpected sources, from Wall Street to the uptown Hudson River shore and across town to a large hospital complex. Even the Metropolitan Museum holds quiet surprises.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Wednesday incor??ectly identified the Geneve Corporation as having been ormed to serve investment nterests in Kuwait. The venure capital company was esablished in 1971 by members of the Rosenwald family and ??ncludes American banks, inurance companies and pri??ate interests among its in??estors. The Kuwait invest??ent Company invested $1million, or less than 7 per cent of Geneve's capital.

title: Sohio to Raise Gas Prices At Stations by 1c a Gallon
description: The Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced yesterday in Cleveland that it was raising gasoline prices at its companyoperated stations by 1 cent a gallon, effective today.

title: Conte, Actor, Critically Ill
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 (AP) Richard Conte, the actor, remained in critical condition today at U.C.L.A. Medical Center after suffering a heart attack a week ago. Mr. Conte, 61 years old, who often played smooth gangsters, has not responded to treatment in the coronary care unit, a Medical Center spokesman said.

title: The Toughest Job in the West
description: CASTEAU, BelgiumIt Is arguable that the most difficult position in today's worried and uncertain world is held by Gen. Alexander Haig, commander of all military forces in NATO Europe. For, amid faltering United States leadership and relentlessly rising Soviet power, his task is to hold together and revivify an alliance that shows some signs of coming apart at the seams.

title: 2 Lives, One Fact: Terminal Cancer
description: Lois Jaffe has a good marriage, four children of whom she is very proud, a nice house, a job as associate professor at the University of Pittsburgh and enviable energy. She is 47 years old, and two years ago yesterday she was told that she had acute leukemia and less than a year and a half to live.

title: The Catfish Opens for Business
description: When Dave Kingman of the Mets slugged Catfish Hunter for a monstrous home run during spring training, the expensive pitcher shrugged it off, I've given them up before, she said, and I'll give them up again. Jim Hunter is a man of truth.
