Before 26,212 customers and one white leghorn hen assembled in Shea Stadium to witness the start of his multimilliondollar career as a Yankee, he gave up a couple of them yesterday. Willie Horton, the third Detroit employe to face him with a stick in his hands, smashed one good for two runs when the match was one putout old. Then in the sixth inning after the Yankees had gone ahead, Nate Colbert whacked one worth three runs and the ball game, 53.

title: More Hispanic Teachers Urged By 2 Puerto Rican Groups Here
description: Two leaders of Puerto Rican organizations called yesterday for the hiring of more Hispanic teachers to enhance the effectiveness of the school system's bilingual education program, which is to begin on a citywide basis next September.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Had No Objection
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 A high State Department official said the United States Government was informed of the secret Soviet visit to Israel after it happened.

title: A Vein of Bias Exposed in Vancouver by Immigration From India
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 7Like many Canadians, the residents of this gentle Pacific seaport are accustomed to thinking of themselves as a tolerant people, generally free of the racial bias that they believe afflicts their American neighbors.

title: CONCESSIONS SET ON ENERGY AGENDA
description: PARIS, April 11Delegates at a preparatory meeting on energy said today concessions were being made in a procedural dispute that should pave the way for successful conclusion of the talks tonight or tomorrow and a fullscale conference on world economic problems this summer.

title: The Whys Behind Ford's Speech
description: WASHINGTON, April 11President Ford stepped before Congress last night and asked for $722million in emergency military aid for the Saigon Government and Congress responded with opposition. By al?? accounts, he expected just abou?? that. Why, then did he do it? The answer goes to the mind of the President. He decided to stand with his five predecessors and do what he could to prevent a Communist takeover of South Vietnam.

title: DICK WELLSTOOD PLAYS AT COOKERY
description: Dick Wellstood, the jazz pianist, who has been accused of having three hands, is playing a twomonth stand at the Cookery, Eighth Street at University Place. He says he prefers to play without a bassist, and he has none. He also says he likes a drummer, but because the Cookery does not have a cabaret license, he cannot have one.

title: Fords Express Sympathy to the Howes
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) President and Mrs. Ford expressed their deepest sympathy to the family of James W. Howe, husband of Betty Ford's, personal assistant. Mr. Howe died yesterday of a gunshot wound that the police said was selfinflicted.

title: Polygamist's Wife Tells Why
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 11 (AP)  Judy Joseph says she has found real happiness sharing her husband with 11 other women.

title: EXPANSION URGED IN COLLEGE BOARD
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, Chan cellor of the City University, has come out in favor of a controversial proposal to increase the size of the 10member Board of Higher Education, the governing body of the giant municipal university.

title: Cadillac's New Seville To Carry $12,479 Price
description: DETROIT, April 11The Cadillac Division of the General Motors Corporation announced today that its new small Seville luxury car would carry a basic price $12,479 when it goes on sale May 1.

title: Do Robes Make a Judge? Bench Debates Question
description: To robe or disrobe?

title: Art: Max Beckmann Stands Out
description: This year marks the 25th anniversary of the death of Max Beckmann, one of the towering figures of modern European painting, and it will be interesting to see what, if anything, the occasion brings in the way of new attention to his powerful oeuvre.

title: Marian Ombres Wed To Sidney E. Frank
description: Marian Elinor Ombres, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Severn Richard Ombres of Palm Beach, Fla., was married here yesterday afternoon to Sidney Edward Frank of New Rochelle, N.Y.; Antigua, West Indies, and Palm Beach. Justice Irving H. Saypol of the New York Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sarnoff.

title: Knicks Play Must Game Again Today
French Group in Accord To Build 4 Soviet Hotels
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (UPI)A French hotel group has signed a $180million contract to construct four hotels in the Soviet Union, including Moscow's first fivestar, luxuryclass hostelry.

title: CITY UNIT AGREES TO FREEZE HIRING
description: The United States Department of Labor asked the city's Office of Neighborhood Service's yesterday to postpone further hiring until it has completed an investigation into whether the agency has filed federally financed publicservice jobs with political appointees.

title: Nicklaus Leads By 5 on 67135
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11Golf tournament? What tournament? The event that began yesterday as the 39th Masters abruptly changed to a oneman benefit today as Jack Nioldaus shot a 67 to take a fivestroke lead after 36 holes.

title: Saigon Describes Ford's Speech as Encouraging
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 11The Saigon Government today described President Ford's speech to Congress as encouraging for South Vietnam.

title: SAIGON SAYS REDS YIELD IN KEY CITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 12South Vietnamese soldiers, militiamen and fighter  bombers reportedly pushed Communist troops out of Xuan Loc yesterday.

title: Egyptian to Visit Moscow
description: CAIRO, April 11 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy will visit Moscow on April 19 for discussions on the Middle East and the Geneva peace conference, Egyptian officials said today.

title: MAX KATZ
description: Max Katz, who founded M. Katz & Son, a manufacturer of billiard cues, in 1907 and was its president since, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived at 305 West End Avenue.

title: Notes on People
description: I wish I had never heard of the White. House, E. Howard Hunt Jr. said yesterday after a Federal judge ordered. him back to prison April. 25 to complete his sentence for his role in the Watergate burglary. The former operative of the Central Intelligence Agency had served 11 months when he was freed, in January last year; while appealing his sentence of 2, to 8 years. But the UnitedStates Court of Appeals in Washington turned him down on Feb. 25.

title: Students Find College Honor Codes Losing Favor
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 11A group of college students who met here for three days this week to discuss and examine college honor codes found that changing attitudes and academic pressures had made the codes all but outmoded on many campuses.

title: Oak Bluffs Stays Oak Bluffs
description: OAK BLUFFS, Mass., April 11 (AP)Voters at the town meeting decided not to change the name of this Martha's Vineyard town back to Cottage City. The town, largely a summer community at the time, was called Cottage City from 1880 to 1907, and no one seems to remember why it was changed to Oak Bluffs.

title: Rutgers Invites Visitors To Observe Anniversary
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 11Rutgers University, which is holding a monthlong, statewide celebration of its 30th anniversary as a statesupported school, invited the neighbors in this weekend to an open house on the campus here.

title: 17 MORE THAIS SLAIN BY REBELS IN NORTH
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 11 (AP)  Communist insurgents opened fire on Thai helicopters bringing reinforcements to a battle in northern Thailand now in its third day and killed 17 more soldiers, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: PATRICIA BOWERS
description: Patricia Bowers, a principal editor of the fifth edition of Foundation Directory, a listing of private grant makers, to be published this month by the Foundation Center, died Thursday in New York Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived at 20 West 84th Street.

title: Jamaica Will Pay Reynolds $24Million for 51% Stake
description: The Jamaican Government said yesterday it would be paya 51 per cent interest for a 51 per cent interest in the bauxitemining and land and cattle operations of the Reynolds Metals Company in that country. An agreement was signed on Thursday in Kingston between the Government and Reynolds.

title: 'Wedding Trough'
description: Wedding ???Trough ???is a movie??? about a young man ???who lives on a farm. Since Wedding Trough" is ???supposed to be an avant-garde ???movie, the young man has no ???ame and very little expres???on in his face. He does, ???owever, have some chick???ns, some ducks, some tur-??? eys and a large cheerful ???w who goes "oink, oink" ???s she forages for food and ???e soundtrack plays ???Monte???erdi.When we first see the young man he is trying to fit the head of a doll over the head of a pigeon. The pigeon will have none of it. The young man sets the pigeon free. Later the young man chops off the head of a chicken. The chicken runs around without it for a while, then collapses. Still later the young man has sex with the ???sow while she continues her search for food. The sow knows it isn't love, even before the young man hangs ???their three piglets, murders her and becomes hugely preoccupied with his own excrement."Wedding Trough," which was screened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art in its New Directors/New Films series, will be repeated there Monday.It is experimental film-making of the most ordinary, unstimulating sort. It's the first feature by a 24-year-old Belgian director whose pseudonym is Thierry Zeno and whose idol, apparently, is Pier Paolo Pasolini at his worst. "Wedding Trough" ???may be about things other than those events shown on the screen but I doubt it.

title: Airlift of Children Assailed By Catholic Relief Agency
description: ROME, April 11A spokesman for an international Roman Catholic relief organization today denounced the evacuation of orphans and other small children from South Vietnam as a mistake.

title: Article 2  No Title
PROFIT INCREASED BY FIRST CHICAGO
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the holding company that owns Chicago's largest bank, reported yesterday that firstquarter earnings rose 21 per cent to a record of $28.9million.

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, April 11 (UPI)Chile, Peru, Zaire and Zambia, the world's major copper exporting countries, decided today to reduce copper production by 5 per cent in addition to the 10 per dent decided upon last year.

title: TEXACO DEFENDS PLANNED OFFICES
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., April 11A Texaco executive testified At an environmental hearing today that an office complex his company planned to build in Harrison would have a minimal impact on air quality despite the additional 1,600 vehicles it will attract each day.

title: Hungary Rejects Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Hungarian Government ha decided not to try to negotiate a trade agreement with the United States leading to lower tariffs on both sides as long as American trade law sets political conditions, a Hungarian official disclosed here today.

title: A Few of the Guilty
description: All this talk to the effect that we should not start pinning the blame on the people responsible for the Vietnam fiasco is nonsense. Pinning the blame is as American as a Saturdaynight shooting, and anyone who expects us to forgo its pleasures in the Vietnam business is out of touch with the spirit of America.

title: The Nixon Foundation Is Officially Dissolved
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 (AP)The Richard Nixon Foundation has been officially dissolved.

title: S.B.A. Official Held On Bribery Charge; Four Others Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 11A highranking official of the Small Business Administration and former Michigan Republican leader has been arrested here and accused of conspiracy, interstate racketeering and accepting an $18,000 bribe from two Cleveland contractors.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 12, 1975

title: QUEENS PRISONER IS FREED IN MIXUP
description: A prisoner being held without bail on armedrobbery and attemptedmurder charges strolled out of the Queens House of Detention for Men yesterday in place of another inmate whohaving completed a fourday term for disorderly conductwas sleeping in his cell at the time of his scheduled release.

title: Indochina's Children
description: Wellmeaning governments and individuals seeking ways to channel their funds, supplies and sympathies to the orphans and refugees caught in the Indochina maelstrom must, first of all, come to terms with reality. The purpose of the relief should be to alleviate human suffering, not to salve consciences.

title: 6 Major Parties in Lisbon Accede to Rule by Military
description: LISBON, April 11Six major political parties today signed away almost all their power to make a constitution for Portugal, accommodating themselves to several years of tight military rule.

title: Young Musketeers Lunge Parry and Thrust
description: Anybody who doesn't like it is a gazodp, said Henry P. Davison 2d. (He's 13 and wants to be called Harry.)

title: Events Today
description: MUSIC

title: Books of The Times
description: Intellectual appraisals of movies have long suffered from time lag because the cinema is mass entertainment and the masses knew it was a major art form long before cliques of intellectuals gave it the label. As mass entertainment, this medium is, of necessity, a marriage between creativity and commercialism, a condition that often causes complications for purists.

title: JOHN F. SIMMS, 58, EXGOVERNOR, DIES
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 11 (UPI)John F. Simms, former Governor of New Mexico and a longtime leader in the Democratic party, died today of a stomach ailment. He was 58 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. Farouk Akhdar, a Saudi Arabian planning official, said here yesterday that his country's own development plan and aid to developing countries would leave little or no surplus oil earnings for Saudi investment in the United States.

title: John K. Mallory Jr. Dies; Trial, Antitrust Lawyer
description: John K. Mallory Jr., a trial and antitrust lawyer who practiced here and in Washington, died Thursday of a heart attack in Paris, where he was attending meetings of the International Energy Agency. He was 55 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Hope A. Leather Becomes Bride Of T. C. Thurlby
description: Hope Alexie Leather, daughter of Sir Edwin Cameron Hartley Leather, Governor of Bermuda, and Lady Leather, was married yesterday to T. Christopher Thurlby of Bailey's Bay, Bermuda.

title: U.S.Pilot Killed at Airport Of Embattled Phnom Penh
description: The following dispatch was written several hours before the evacuation of Americans from Phnom Penh.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Reaction Against Youth Crime Decried
description: Most juvenile offenders are more annoying than dangerous, but the common attitude is that they are dangerous and should be locked up, Milton Luger, director of the New York State Division for Youth, said yesterday.

title: Of Men and Wopersons
description: Just when television wags had supposedly squeezed the last drop of fun out of the mayhem that women's liberation is inflicting on the language, along comes Government to show what deadpan comedy can do. The Labor Department's Manpower Administration (sic) has announced that 3,500 jobs will be renamed in Its revised dictionary of job titles in order to achieve some degree of neutrality and sexlessness.

title: CHANGE IS PRESSED ON NURSING HOMES
description: Battle lines were drawn yesterday over whether to expand or limit the role of profitmaking companies in Governmentsubsidized health cars.

title: BAN ON CRUEL ARMS ADOPTED AT GENEVA
description: GENEVA, April 11 (Reuters) An international conference on bringing the Geneva war conventions up to date has agreed to ban weapons that cause unnecessary suffering or that permanently harm the environment, a conference cornmuniqu said today.

title: Throngs in an Algerian Town Cheer Giscard and Boumediene
description: SKIKDA, Algeria, April 11Most of the people here and in nearby Constantine turned out today to acclaim the President of France, Valdry Giscard d'Estaing, the first French chief of state to visit Algeria since the nation won its war of independence.

title: ASTON MARTIN TAKES INADEQUATE OFFER
description: LONDON, April 11The board of Aston Martin, the ailing British sports car company, reluctantly accepted today a $2.5million takeover bid

title: 2 LAWYERS ASKED TO QUIT DEFENSE
description: NEWARK, April 11Essex County prosecutors asked two lawyers representing defendants in an Orange police corruption scandal to withdraw from the case today on the ground of an apparent conflict of interest.

title: JOHN E. ROBERTSON
description: John E. Robertson, vice president and manager of the West Coast program production office for Compton Advertising, Inc., died last Saturday of a coronary attack at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 62 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE MAY GET JOB EQUALITY POST
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The leading candidate to be chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is Lowell W. Perry, an executive with the Chrysler Corporation in Detroit, according to sources here.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Harry M. Stevens, Inc., has been awarded the concession contract at the sports complex being built in the Hackensack Meadows by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The authority voted Thursday to pick Stevens over six other bidders, but officials said the final terms of the contract were still being negotiated.

title: Text of Ford Statement on Evacuation
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday April 12 (AP]Following is the text of the statement by President Ford regarding the evacuation from Phnom Penh:

title: Article 7  No Title
CONNALLY LAWYER URGES ACQUITTAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) John B. Connally's lawyer asked today that the former Treasury Secretary's bribery trial be halted by judicial order because he said, the Government testimony on the uncorroborated testimony of a single witness who is an admitted perjurer.

title: FORD IS EXPECTED TO VETO FARM BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said today that he had been told by White House officials that President Ford would veto whatever version of the emergency rural farm pricesupport legislation came out of Congress.

title: Saigon's Gains Seen As Limited
description: Stubborn and successful fighting, on a limited front, by South Vietnamese GOvernment troops should not be taken as an indication that Saigon is in a position to reverse the present military situation United States mili tary source warned today.

title: Rockefeller, at Party for Buckley, Denies Attendance Means Endorsement
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Vice President Rockefeller caused a tremor of excitement when he appeared last night at a wellattended Republican campaign fundraising party for Senator James L. Buckley of New York. Did it mean, everyone was asking, that he was endorsing the ConservativeRepublican for reelection next year?

title: Vietnam Priority
description: It is difficult to believe that President Fordor anyone elsecan really think that the appropriation of threequarters of a billion dollars for military aid to Saigon within the next few days could enable the South Vietnamese to stem the onrushing aggression, to stabilize the military situation [or] permit the chance of a negotiated political settlement, as the President suggested in his address to Congress.

title: Students Urged to Vote
description: TRENTON, April 11 (AP)Governor Byrne today urged high school authorities to encourage voter registration next week among students who were over 18 years of age. At the 36th annual meeting of the youth legislature of the Young Men's Christian Association in the State House, Mr. Byrne signed a proclamation declaring next week High School Registration Week.

title: E.P.A. Hints Big Losses In Sewerage Plant Grants
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had turned up evidence of mismanagement, faulty construction and misrepresentation of costs in at least 41 Federal sewerage plant construction grants around the country.

title: More Stockholders Suing United Brands on Bribery
description: The number of suits against the United Brands Company for concealing bribery continued to grow yesterday.

title: MORE STATE HELP SOUGHT FOR U.D.C.
description: ALBANY, April 11More aid for the Urban Development Corporation$88.1million in new money and the removal of restrictions on the use of state funds previously advancedwill be asked of the Legislature next week.

title: Surface Storage of Atom Waste Is Delayed by Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Energy Research and Development Administration is putting aside its plans to build surface storage facilities for waste from the nation's nuclear power plants, a spokesman for the agency said last night.

title: President of Cambodia In Hawaii for Therapy
description: HONOLULU, April 11 (AP) President Lon Nol of Cambodia arrived here last night following 10 days on the island of Bali in Indonesia.

title: Down in Ham Country, the Smokehouses Boom and Bustle
description: SMITHFIELD, Va.There is a legend here in the Tidewater cbuntry that the first English settlers at Jamestown, 20 miles up the James River, were saved from starvation by a friendly Indian bearing a Smithfield ham.

title: White House Asks Anyone Charging Secret Pacts to Give Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, April 11A White House spokesman said today that President Ford knew of no secret commitments made to South Vietnam and that anyone who charged there were such agreements should back it up with evidence.

title: F.E.A. Denies Trying to Block Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Responding to accusations that the Federal Energy Administration had tried to block an investigation by a Federal grand jury, the agency's general counsel, Robert E. Montgomery Jr., told a Congressional subcommittee today that everything we had we gave to the United States Attorney everything.

title: AIR FORCE IMPOSES CURBS ON C5 USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Air Force imposed a series of restrictions today on the use of the giant C5 cargo transports pending results of an accident investigation.

title: PATERSONDETECTIVE GETS 364DAY TERM
description: Capt. Joseph M. Esposito, Paterson's suspended chief of detectives, was sentenced by a Morris County Court judge to 364 days in jail on his conviction of protecting the illegal numbers operation of a Paterson bookmaker. He also was fined $2.000.

title: Julia Cohn Algase, 73, Is Dead; Stage and Labor Lawyer Here
description: Julia Cohn Algase, a lawyer for 50 years, specializing in labor and theater law, died of a heart attack Thursday in University Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived at 151 Central Park West.

title: Argentine Local Elections to Test Peronists
description: POSADAS, Argentina, April 8Several thousand leftwing Peronists, most of them young farmhands bussed in from the countryside, assembled in the main square to the deep, rhythmic beating of drums and the chanting of the Peronist hymn, Pern, Pern, how great you are.

title: AIRLIFT OF CHILDREN RESUMES IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, April 11 (UPI)  Nearly 300 Vietnamese children were airlifted out of Saigon today.

title: Blast Sinks Ship at California Dock; Caller Warns Against Sale to Arab
description: SAN PEDRO, Calif., April 11 (UPI)A terroristic explosion sank a 125foct excursion ship at her dock last night. An anonymous caller said that it had been a warning to the vessel's owners not to sell a ship to an Arab buyer.

title: 24 Arrested on Drug Sales
description: WOONSOCKET, R.I., April 11 (AP)  Twentyfour persons were arrested today in early morning raids in Woonsocket on charges of selling drugs, the police reported. The police said the 24 persons.

title: The Ballet: Summer
description: BOSTON, April 11It is perfectly conceivable that Agnes de Mille is the cleverest woman ever to step into a ballet studio with creative intent in her heart. This is both her blessing and her liability.

title: Cross Burned at School
description: HOUSTON, April 11 (UPI)An eightfoot cross was burned on the front lawn of Aldine High School to protest the slaying of a white student by a black. The authorities said J. Edwin Threadgill, Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan of America, Inc., took responsibility for the cross burning.

title: A Gloomy Spring time in Trenton
description: TRENTON, April 11  The first days of spring at the State House here each year have invariably carried with them the promise of political rejuvenation, the hope of reversing things gone wrong. But the last few days have failed to dispel the pervasive sense of frustration and defeat that has gripped the Byrne administration and the Lesgislature.

title: 40% of Commuter Drivers Affected by Toll Tripling
description: The new rates for the six toll crossings between the city and. New Jersey call for a tripling of the tolls for nearly 40 per cent of the automobile drivers unless they form car pools.

title: MANAGEMENT OF VW SCORED BY SCHMIDT
description: DORTMUND, West Germany, April 11 (Reuters)Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today attacked management mistakes at the Volkswagen Company, which lost more than $200million last year.

title: East Africa Fossils Suggest That Man Is a Million Years Older Than He Thinks
description: Fossil remains of early man discovered over the last two years in East Africa are causing a major upheaval in the study of human evolution by suggesting that man's origins lie more than twice as far into the past as had been supposed from earlier evidence.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Wednesday incorrectly identified the Geneve Corporation as having been formed to serve investment interests in Kuwait. The venture capital company was established in 1971 by members of the Rosenwald family and includes American banks, insurance companies and private interests among its investors. The Kuwait Investment Company invested $1million, or less than 7 per cent of Geneve's capital.

title: EDWARD EMERSON
description: Edward Emerson, a stage, screen and television actor and writer, died yesterday of cancer at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 65 years old and lived at 415 Central Park West.

title: Senate Panel Approves a $3 65Billion Spending Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Senate Budget Committee, partly reversing some of ifs earlier decisions, gave final approval today to a proposed ceiling of $365billion on Government spending for next year.

title: SENATE UNIT PASSES BILL ON SECURITIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee today approved an omnibus bill that one sponsor says would result in sweeping reforms in the securities exchanges and securites industry.

title: Report on Alleged Attica CoverUp Cites Possible Murder Charges Against Law Enforcement Officers
description: The confidential report to Governor Carey on the alleged coverup by the chief Attica prosecutor, Anthony G. Simonetti, cited at least two cases in which murder charges might have been brought against law enforcement officers.

title: A Newspaper Photo Of Party Volunteers Yields Arrest of One
description: A newspaper photograph published last week to illustrate an article on an exconvict who gives parties to cheer retarded youths has led to the arrest of a suspect in a $60,000 jewel robbery.

title: Article 1  No Title
Veterans in Kansas Town Cool to Ford Pleal
description: CLIFTON, Kan., April 11Vietnam is a long way from Clifton, a town of 800 people nestled among the corn and wheat fields 110 miles northwest of Topeka. And somehow it seems to be growing more distant every day.

title: Damages Awarded By Appeals Court In ChrisCraft Suit
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday awarded damages of $25.8million to ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., in a case first instituted in 1969 by ChrisCraft against the Bangor Punta Corporation, First Boston and certain members of the Piper family of Lockhaven Pennsylvania.

title: The Fat Envelope
description: NEW HAVENThousands of American high school seniors will learn today which of the Ivy League universities will accept them to the class of 1979. This experience reveals the fears, conflicts and aspirations of the late adolescents.

title: Elsevier Reaches Dutton Merger Accord
description: An agreement in principle has been reached by Elsevier Publishing. Company, N.V., Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and E. P. Dutton & Co., Inc., here for the acquisition of the privately held American publishing concern. A spokesman for Dutton said that it was, too early, in the negotiations to give the price that would be paid for the company. However, it has sales of $12million annually.

title: NESSEN REVISES NEWS SUMMARY
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Under orders from Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, the news summary that is prepared daily for President Ford has undergone some dramatic changes in recent days.

title: Linden Mayor Pleads Not Guilty On LandBuying Fraud Charges
description: ELIZABETH, April 11 (UPI) Assemblyman John T. Gregorio, Democrat of Linden, and four codefendants pleaded not guilty today in Superior Court to charges of conspiracy, fraud and perjury in connection with a land purchase from the Elizabethtown Gas Company.

title: Conflict of Interest Investigation Holds Up Funds for Soul City
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) A Commerce Department official said yesterday that the department would not spend any more money on Soul City pending an investigation of possible conflicts of interest in development of the North Carolina new town.

title: New Tolls Triple the Fee For Commuter Motorists
description: The new rates for the six toll crossings between the city and New Jersey call for a tripling of the tolls for nearly 40 per cent of the automobile drivers unless they form car pools.

title: Salat Reported to Plan A Cabinet Shuffle Soon
description: CAIRO, Saturday, April 12 (Reuters) President Anwar elSadat will shuffle his Cabinet within the next few days, Cairo newspapers said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 12, 1975

title: ARTHUR SETTEL, 63, U.S. CUSTOMS AIDE
description: Arthur Settel, first publicinformation officer of the United States Customs Service, who organized its network of publicinformation offices, died yesterday in Miami after heart surgery. He was 63 years old and lived in North Miami.

title: P.S.C. Staff Urges Rate Rise Sought by Con Ed Be Denied
description: ALBANY, April 11Consolidated Edison's application for a $202million interim rise in electricity rates should be denied without a hearing, the staff of the Public Service Commission said today.

title: For the Islanders, a Big Dream
description: Al Arbour, the coach, sat in a room by himself and lit a cigarette with trembling hands. Roy Boe, the owner, was speechless and hugged eyeryone in sight. The publib relations man was reduced to tears. And the New York Islanders themselves screamed and laughed, shook their heads and screamed some more.

title: Hawks Put Bruins Out Of Playoff
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)Tony Esposito, the Chicago goalie, atoned for an opening game humiliation with a spectacular performance tonight as the Black Hawks defeated Boston 64 and eliminated the Bruins in the preliminary round of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: MISS KRUPSAK BACKS JOB TRAINING PLAN
description: A bill to redirect public spending from welfare into job training programs conducted by nonprofit communitybased organizations was supported yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak and members of the State Legislature.

title: Miss Morey Sets Mark in A.A.U. Swim
description: CINCINNATI, April 11Marcia Morey, who gets her kicks beating the boys on the Millikin University swim team, turned her finishing touch into an American record in the women's 200yard breaststroke tonight.

title: State Department Text
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)Following is the text of the statement issued by the State Department tonight regarding evacuation of American citizens from Phnom Penh:

title: 3 Are Found Not Guilty Of Looting Pension Fund
description: CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) Three men charged with looting a pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters of. $1.4million have been found not guilty by a Federal jury.

title: LAST AMERICANS LEAVE CAMBODIA; EMBASSY CLOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, April 12The United States announced last night that because of the seriously deteriorating military situation it was closing its embassy in Phnom Penh and evacuating several hundred Americans and Cambodians from the encircled Cambodian capital.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Article 8  No Title
DR. JAMES DWINELLE
description: Dr. James Howard Dwinelle, a dermatologist, died Thursday at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N. Y. He was 74 years old and lived and practiced in Rye, N. Y.

title: 4 Arrested in Labor Strife
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 11 (AP)  Four persons were arrested after more than 100 riotequipped policemen were summoned to control a disturbance involving union strikers and nonunion workers it the Washburn Wire Company.

title: Camera a Training Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 11A camera system that was patented this week can let the viewer watch open heart surgery just as if he were the surgeon performing the operation. Films produced with the camera enable the trainees to see machinery, tools and even moving fingers exactly as they would on the actual job. Patent 3,877,041 was granted this week to Vera Jean Graeter of West New York, N. J., and her late husband, George Ralph Graeter.

title: LTV Corp. to Pay Dividends And Arrears on Preferred
description: The LTV Corporation, an integrated steel producer, announced yesterday in Dallas that it would pay all arrears and the current dividends on its $5 series A cumulative pre??erred stock and all stock dividend arrears on its special Class AA stock.

title: Congress Resists U.S. Aid In Evacuating Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Congressional resistance developed today against President Ford's request for authority to use American troops, if necessary, to protect the evacuation of South Vietnamese citizens.

title: New Books
description: ??frican Music: A People's Art, by Francis Bebey, translated by Josephine Bennett (Lawrence Hill, $10; paperbound, $5.95). Copiously illustrated sociological study.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Electric Car at Toyota

title: Sales Lag at Bergdorf's Suburban Branch
description: Last October, Bergdorf Goodman, probably the most prestigious woman's apparel store in the country, opened with great fanfare the first branch store in its 73year historyin affluent White Plains, N.Y.

title: State Tells 26 School Districts To Submit Desegregation Plans
description: TRENTON, April 11 (UPI)Twentysix major school districts have received orders to submit desegregation plans to the state by next month, the State Education Department said today.

title: PRICES UNCHANGED IN GRAIN FUTURES
description: Grain and soybean prices were virtually unchanged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Ford on Turkish Arms
description: There are circumstances under which Congress should end the ban on American military aid to Turkey; but in his State of the World address, President Ford rested his plea for that action on questionable premises. His appeal was further weakened by his failure to note that in demanding the embargo Congress was primarily motivated by concern for enforcing existing law governing the use of military aid.

title: Small, BatteryPowered Automobile Recently Completed by Toyota Motors
description: TOKYO, April 11Toyota, Japan's leading auto manufacturer, has recently completed a small prototype electric car powered by highcapacity batteries for urban and suburban use. The company said it was, not yet ready to predict when the auto would go on the market or at what price.

title: University Presses Being Transformed Into a Profitable, BestSeller Venture
description: A few weeks ago, the Columbia University Press took a fullpage advertisement in a national book review to promote a memoir by a living writer who is not an academic. The book, The Witness and I by O. Edmund Clubb, was the press's first such venture in its 82year history.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 28yearold shoe salesman, described by Federal officials as a bumbling bank robber who once asked a teller for all his tens, twenties and thirties, was sentenced in United States District Court in Brooklyn to eight years in jail. The salesman, Mark Ira Lippman of 8670 Francis Lewis Boulevard, in Hollis, Queens, pleaded guilty last Sept. 23 to robbing a First National City Bank branch at 10229 Queens Boulevard, in Forest Hills, of $1,680 on Dec. 31, 1973. In the subsequent nine months, Mr. Lippman was charged with committing eight additional bank robberies which netted him about $8,500. Last April 18, when Mr. Lippman was carrying out a robbery at the First National City Bank branch at 6010 Queens Boulevard in Woodside, he handed a teller a note asking for your tens, twenties and thirties. The teller shoved $970 across the counter and the bandit walked out. As he left, a bank officer followed on foot and observed Mr. Lippman walk into a motel a block away. When police arrived, they were led to the motel where they arrested Mr. Lippman. At his sentencing, Mr. Lippman told Judge John R. Bartels that he had a gambling problem and asked that he be sent to a prison that had a chapter of Gamblers Anonymous.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesAlberto Davila, 118 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Jose del Rio, 117, Mexico City, 5 rounds.

title: East Africa Fossils Suggest That Man Is a Million Years Older Than He Thinks
Open Interest
description: Friday, April 11, 1975

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: Bowlers on all levels, up to an including the, intermediate range, look with awe (admiration probably is the better word) on the professional and his ability to convert spares consistently. What the loweraverage bowler fails to realize is that the pros sometimes miss; it's because they don't often shoot at spares and the ones they do shoot at are usually onepin spares. And those, of course, are relatively easier than multiplepin spares.

title: Ceausescu, in Manila, Signs Cultural, Economic Pacts
description: MANILA, April 12President Ferdinand E. Marcos and the visiting Rumanian leader, President Nicolde Ceausescu, concluded today a spate of cultural, technical and economic agreements.

title: Pullout: Anxiety, False Starts and Safety
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. OKINAWA IN THE GULF OF SIAM, April 12The first word that the American evacuation of Phnom Penh was coming not In a matter of days but a matter of hours reached the Hotel Le Phnom at breakfast time, shortly after 7 A.M.

title: 3 Harvard Lightweight Crews And M.I.T. Vanquish Columbia
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 12In separate but equal races, the women from Princeton, Yale and M.I.T., and the men from Columbia, Harvard, and M.I.T., staged 12 races today on the Charles River under near perfect rowing conditions.

title: Announcements
description: Births

title: FollowUP on The News
description: The headline said 28 Hurt in Crash of Chartered Bus, and one of the victims of that Westchester accident last Aug. 17 was a Bronx woman whose right leg was severed. Surgeons at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains were reported to be attempting to restore the leg after the state police recovered it and rushed it to the hospital minutes after the accident.

title: IMMUNIZATION LAG IS LAID TO SCHOOLS
description: A state report expected to be released this week charged that, contrary to publichealth law, about 35,000 childrenmore than onethird of the youngsters entering city public schools each yearare not immunized against a number of serious diseases.

title: Bomb in Pub Kills at Least Five In a Catholic Section in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 12 (UPI)  A bomb exploded without warning tonight in a crowded pub in a Roman Catholic district of East Belfast, killing at least five persons.

title: Capitalist squash
description: In an early round of the U.S. Squash Racquets Singles Championships in February, a clutch of spectators sat freezing in the steep stone amphitheatergallery of New York's University Club. Down in the bright, white box below, two men attacked a small, darkgreen, hardrubber ball with skinny racquets and sent it flying, at times at blurring speed, at other times in soft floating arcs, off the front wall and ricocheting off the side walls and the back wall.

title: Billy Martin Tries To Eject Umpire
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 12 (AP)Manager Billy Martin of the Texas Rangers continued his feud with Umpire Ron Luciano today. I'm not out to get him fined, said Martin. I'm out to get him fired.

title: Arson Increasing Rapidly; Recession Called a Factor
description: DETROIT, April 12Seattle bans topless dancing in gogo bars, the clientele drops off, and immediately some of the bars burn downsuspiciously so in some cases, according to the fire department.

title: Outlook for Vacationing Students on Bright Side
description: HACKENSACKAs bleak as the New Jersey employment picture is it apparently is not too bad for 14to18yearolds and vacationing college students.

title: Beethoven's Big Nine The Japanese Love It
description: TOKYO When Leonard Bernstein once stated that Japanese audiences for Western classical music are among the world's top four, he was speaking of the performer. As a member of the audience in Tokyo I find the concert experience daunting if not disconcerting. No one coughs, although this is the flu season; no one rustles his program once the music starts; and no one ever seems to cross his legs or drop anything.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about todays television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Coin Week Starts April 20
description: National Coin Week, sponsored by the American Numismatic Association, starts next weekend and runs through the following weekend (the official dates are Sunday, April 20, through Saturday, April 26, but participants in past years have often used both days of both weekends). The theme selected for the week this year is Monuments in Miniature, which emphasizes the medallicthe artistic and historicaspects of coinage.

title: Tigers 7Run 7th Downs Yanks, 72
description: About the pitching that was supposed to be the Yankees' strength this season maybe in the next 159 games. Certainly not in the first three. Not with George Medich opening day in Cleveland, not with Catfish Hunter opening day in New York, not with Pat Dobson yesterday. Rudy May, the fourth starter, gets his chance today.

title: Pamela Andrea Krusen Is Married
description: Pamela Andrea Krusen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Andrew Krusen of Tampa, Fla., was married early last evening to William Young Boyd, 2d. of Panama City, Panama, beard chairman of Boyd Brothers, Inc., and the Boyd Steamship and Ocean Trucking Corporations.

title: Sauna: Done to a Turn in Finland
description: I HAD roasted baked, broiled and fried myself so thoroughly that by the end of my visit to Helsinki, I was beginning to think I was edible. But it was in a worthy cause. I was in quest of the perfect Finnish sauna.

title: Champion Tomato Grower
description: Leopold Klein of Valley Stream has been named America's champion tomato grower by the National Garden Bureau because he can harvest up to 100 pounds of tomatoes from plants growing in a single hole in the ground or in a wooden box on wheels.

title: Widening Additional Sections of the Garden State Parkway Is Being Considered
description: WOODBRIDGE  Further expansion, in the form of additional lanes, may be in store for the Garden State Parkway. The New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the 173milelong toll road, reports that it has several widening studies under way.

title: L. P. Hall 3d, Robin B. Adam Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Adam of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their, daughter, Robin B. Adam, to Leonard Parke Hall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Jr., also of Buffalo.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market advanced sharply last week in active trading as the list was stimulated by considerably improved sentiment in the bond market.

title: Year Delay Urged On Sprinkler Law For Buildings Here
description: A proposal by the Administration of Mayor Beame to exf tend for one year the deadline for installation of sprinklers in highrise commercial buildings, was taken under advisement last week by the City Council's Housing and Building Committee.

title: College Schedules An Industrial Fair
description: BRANCHBURG  A threeday fair featuring displays by industries and professional organizations from the Somerset Hunterdon area will be staged at Somerset County College May 20, 21 and 22.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor (and John Dean):

title: Newark Schedules Anticrime Meeting
description: NEWARKIn a move designed to encourage more citizen involvement in curbing here, a twoday anticrime workshop will be held April 26 and 27.

title: PAF Is Offering Tickets to Jobless
description: HUNTINGTON STATIONThe Performing Arts Foundation is offering reducedprice tickets to the unemployed, a spokesman for the theater has announced.

title: Building Law Aids Handicapped But Gives New Mexico a Problem
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 12A new law prohibiting state agencies from renting space in buildings not accessible to physically handicapped persons has state administrators in a., quandary because office structures free of architectural barriers are all but nonexistent.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: In the beginningour beginning, anywaywas Maria Callas. It was she who, by force of personality as much as by force of voice, brought back bel canto opera after World War II, and showed that those old operas by Rossini, Donizetti and Bellini were more than faded mementoes of the past. Then there was Joan Sutherland. Coloratura sopranos were not supposed to have such big voice, but Joan of the golden throat. demonstrated that great volume and great flexibility were not incompatible. Then came the third soprano, Beverly SillsBeverly of the New York City Opera, Beverly of La Scala and the Teatro Colon, and Beverly, as of last Monday, of the Metropolitan Opera. She finally made her debut there, in the new production of Rossini's The Siege of Corinth.

title: Bank Cleaning Man Picks Up $41,000 And Gives It Back
description: Stavros Zoumboulis, a 32yearold cleaning man at a Queens branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank, might have been on his way to Rio with $41,000 yesterday. Instead, he had the luxury of a clear conscience.

title: An Older and Wiser Laver Appraises Tennis Scene
description: ST. LOUIS, April 12Rodney George Laver, at the age of 36, is only four years younger than Ken Rosewall, whose tennis victories these days are hailed as miraculous, because of his advanced years. But Laver, going through one of the more successful stretches of his successladen career, looks so natural doing it that no one speaks of him as a geriatric marvel.

title: 1,043 Men and,Women SO Employed in 3 States Can't Be All Bad
description: My father is a lobbyist, the young girl responded to the teacher's request that her pupils tell about their fathers' occupations. Isn't that illegal? piped up another youngster.

title: Adelphi Chairman
description: GARDEN CITY  Leonard Nadel, senior vice president of Abraham & Straus and a resident of Roslyn, has been elected chairman of the Board of Trustees of Adelphi University.

title: Since the Kissinger Failure, the Kremlin's Role Has Expanded
description: MOSCOWWhen Secretary of State Kissinger's latest attempt to negotiate a partial Middle East settlement failed last month, Pravda did not gloat, but there was a distinot smirk in the Communist party paper's comment that Mr. Kissinger's quiet diplomacy tactics had been proved hopeless. The paper also said that the Geneva conference on the Middle East should be resumed at an earliest date. This was in tune with official propaganda.

title: I.R.S. IS ACCUSED OF RECENT SPYING
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 The Internal Revenue Service continued a form of political surveillance as long as 17 months after the agency officially ended such activities, according to court documents here.

title: High Score Awards Association Is Back on HorseShow Scene
description: The Long Island High Score Awards Association, which in recent years has become an important factor on the metropolitan horseshow scene, will be in operation again this year, its 16th year.

title: Hong Kong's Bank of Many Faces
description: HONG KONGThere are 74 banks in Hong Kong. One of them has more than half the deposits of the colony and prints 85 per cent of its currency. It also has a branch in Shanghai, on the mainland.

title: Nine Die in Alabama Fire; Father of 5 Victims Is Held
description: BEULAH, Ala., April 12 (UPI) Nine children were killed last night in a fire that destroyed a frame home and the authorities today charged the father of five of the victims with murder and arson.

title: Nadine Gordimer's Mehring would leave the world alone
description: Interviewed a few months ago London, Nadine Gordimer said: Lib. eral is a dirty word to me. I am radical. She is one of the few: Most other African writers have opted to become Ph.D. fodder and scholargentry, they shunt back and forth on the American college lecture circuit, having cut themselves loose from countries in which the illiteracy rateaccording to the latest UNESCO figureshas risen sharply in the past few years. One wonders who speaks for the African. It is certainly not the Hitlerian general Idi Amin Dada or any other African politician. Of the novelists, the Nigerian Chinua Achebe has been able to depict African cultural confusionbut the poor fellow lives in Massachusetts. Really, Miss Gordimer's vision of Africa is the most complete one we have, and in time to come, when we want to know everything there is to know about a newly independent black African country, it is to this white South African woman and her Guest of Honor (1970) that we will turn.

title: PUERTO RICAN LAG IN INCOME NOTED
description: Socially and economically, Puerto Ricans living in New York State lag considerably behind Puerto Ricans who were born on the mainland and live outside the state, according to a new study based on census data.

title: Ma Bell's Children's Stories
description: Ma Bell, whose voluminous skirts already infold Diala Joke and DialaRecipe, is about to join with the Queens library system to offer a similar service for children.

title: Plans Bridal
description: Mrs. Hilary H. Holmes of Riverdale, the Bronx, and East Hampton, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Margaret Swearingen Holmes, to Paul vonRyll Gryska, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul F. Gryska of Weston, Mass. A wedding in July is planned.

title: Spurs Win In Playoff, Trail, 31
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 12 (AP)George Gervin's basket with five seconds remaining gave San Antonio a 110109 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight, giving the Spurs their first victory after three losses in the fouroutofsevengame American Basketball Association West Division playoff series.

title: Giants: Schedule Conflict
description: The New York Giants will play at least two games on Saturday afternoons rather than Sunday at Shea Stadium next season, according to the National Football League schedule released yesterday: The Saturday dates, which will put the Giants into competition with local high school and college events, were necessary to fit those two games into the crowded calendar for Shea, also the home of the Jets and baseball's Mets and Yankees.

title: Pupils Offering Music Man
description: MONTCLAIRThe Music Man is coming to town again, this time in a production by the pupils at Mount Hebron School. Fifth and sixthgraders sing in the chorus, seventh and eighthgraders are playing the leads and several teachers, including the principal, will be seen in minor roles.

title: BRIDGE
description: Everyone has heard about Baron Munchausen, the celebrated German teller of tall tales. But not everyone knows that he was a bridge player. Some of his bridge stories strain credulity to the utmost: How he bid and made a slam missing four aces and the king of trumps; how all four aces appeared on one trick; how he made a slam when the opponents. held ten trumps headed by the queenjack; and how he won the first trump trick with the fivespot, over the two, three and four, when defending a slam.

title: A DIFFERENT KIND OF ART
description: Americans too young to remember Joseph Welch can remember the time when photography, like professional football or sex, was an activity that almost everyone enjoyed, and almost no one analyzed in public, excepting only tiny bands of esoteric specialists. Doubtless an unreconstructed minority still exist who believe that this was all for the best, but theirs seems a lost cause, even if just. After 135 years, the question of what photographs really mean is being considered along a fairly broad, if shallow, intellectual front. Having become a public issue, the question is unlikely simply to go away, unless it finally proves too difficult for the analytical tools that we manage to devise.

title: Dubcek: J'Accuse
description: Alexander Dubcek, First Secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party during the 1968 liberalization period, last Oct. 28 sent a long letter of protest to the Federal Assembly and the Slovak National Council, or parliament, supporters abroad say.

title: Gerulaitis Stuns Layer, 46, 63, 64
description: ST. LOUIS, April 12 Fourthseeded Vitas Gerulaitis scored a stunning upset in the semifinals of the $60,000 World Championship Tennis St. Louis tennis tournament tonight as he defeated topseeded Rod Laver, 46, 63, 64.

title: Endpaper
description: Frances Knight, for a generation in charge of deciding who is worthy enough to receive a United States passport and who not (I was not for several interminable years), has now conceived an awesome idea. She proposes that every American be required to carry a card of identity. It would be issued, inevitably, by the Federal Government, which owes every American citizen a true, recorded national identity to protect him from criminal impersonations, Miss Knight says.

title: The gimmick is credible authority, the market is inexhaustible
description: The genre is selfhelp; the inducement is easy answers to common personal problems. It is suggested, or asserted, that the reader will be pointed along the true course toward happiness, achievement, serenity, selfassurance, getting along with others, improved health, a good sex life, whatever. The formula is a consistent winner, as the bestseller lists demonstrate; the criterion of success is a good gimmick, presented with the trappings of credible authority; the market is inexhaustible.

title: Alvin Alley's Dance Tribute To the Duke
description: For at least the next few years, when people mention Alvin Ailey, they're going to have to mention Duke Ellington, too, The artistic director of The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater is devoting his considerable energies to building Ellington a monument in movementa monument that Ailey intends to culminate in an Ellington Celebration for the United States Bicentennial.

title: Spring Breeds Art Shows
description: MORRISTOWNTwo New Jersey synagogues and the Y.M.Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey are welcoming the spring with art exhibitions.

title: FOUL PLAY FEARED IN DISAPPEARANCE
Mets Have Confidence Baldwin Will Make It
description: PITTSBURGH, April 12 Jesus Alou joined the Mets today, adding a seasoned bat to New York's catchyourbreath hitting attack.

title: The influence of fame
description: That brand of oblique noto riety that touches the family of a famous person is a variorum of celebrity that manages, oddly enough, to satisfy the same hunger for gossip and need for human interest which celebrities are meant to provide. The media manages, in its sly way, to bellow into existence a desirewhich it then immediately gratifiesto know the little particulars concerning the relatives of the great (vide Lynda Bird Johnson's husband's sister.) Obviously it's a position fraught with potential for scorn and misinterpretation  famous people are veritable teething biscuits for our furious collective gums. But this kind of readymade famebeing an established character on stage in the public imaginationalso provides the befamedone with an arena in which to work out her troubles or shoot off her mouth.

title: Preservationists Lose Virginia Strip Mine Ruling
description: LOUISA, Va., April 12Historic preservationists, who won an environmental struggle here a year ago in blocking the construction of a state prison facility in the scenic Green Springs section of central Virginia, have suffered a setback in another dispute that may open the way for strip mining in a region of rich farmland near Charlottesville.

title: Many Top U.S. Yachts In TransAtlantic Race
description: The New York Yacht Club, the cosponsor with the Royal Thames Y.C. of England, expects an entry of at least 30 yachts for the race across the Atlantic Ocean that will start from Newport, R. I. on June 29. One of the entries is Carina, owned by Richard S. Nye of Greenwich, Conn., which won the last transAtlantic race in 1972. Nye won two others before that.

title: Aeros Win, 53, And Lead by 20
description: HOUSTON, April 12 (AP)Houston's Murray Hall scored two goals and Mark Howe added an emptynet goal at 19:28 of the final period to subdue a Cleveland Crusaders rally and gain the Aeros a 53 victory tonight in the World Hockey Association playoffs.

title: Friday's Fights
description: Melbourne, AustraliaRocky Mattioli, 147 pounds, Australia, knocked out Billy Backus, 146, Syracuse, N. Y., 5 rounds.

title: Republicans Gain Strong Ally for Suffolk Election
description: The RepublicanConservative alliance that was put together in Suffolk County last week will give County Executive John V. N. Klein and other Republican candidates down to the town level a major boost in their effort to avoid a repeat of last year's Democratic successes in the county.

title: Knicks Ousted From Playoffs As Rockets Post 11886 Victory
description: HOUSTON, April 12Just 16 hours after their corporate cousins, the New York Rangers, got themselves eliminated from the National Hockey playoffs, the New York Knicks followed them into competitive oblivion today by losing to the Houston Rockets, 11886, in full view of a national television audience and 10,218 ecstatic rooters in the Hofheinz Pavilion here.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Phoenix vs. Quebec

title: A Student in South Korea Kills Himself in a Protest Against Repression
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 12A senior at South Korea's leading university died today after disembowling himself in protest against President Park Chung Hee's political repression.

title: Centers to Collect Aid for Vietnamese
description: MINEOLA  Seven large shopping centers in Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties were the sites last week of the start of a drive to obtain money, clothing and other items on behalf of the Long Island chapter of the Friends of the Children of Vietnam.

title: William Shakespeare
description: S. Schoenbaum in his last book, Shakespeare's Lives, succeeded beyond expectation, and indeed almost beyond precedent, in making the triumphs and follies of Shakespearean biography through the ages matters of amused public concern. Now, I suppose inevitably, he adds his own Life to the long list. One imagines that the spirits of a hundred forgotten scholars, still smarting from his goodnatured correction, will crowd round this large handsome book in search of revenge.

title: A Dead Whale Is Found Off Bayonne
description: A 20,000pound dead whale found floating in Newark Bay Channel off Bayonne, N.J., yesterday posed a problem for the Coast Guard, but the Smithsonian Institution treated the carcass like a treasure.

title: Corrections
description: A story in the March 30 issue of The Week in Review, based on information from various sources, said that black enrollment in the nation's colleges is falling. A Census Bureau survey issued in February, however, indicated an upward trend, giving these figures: 814,000 in 1974, 684,000 in 1973, 727,000 in 1972. The report said blacks constituted 7 per cent of all college students in 1970 and 9 per cent in 1974.

title: How One Man, Atypical, Gets His Job Done
description: The image of the fasttalking, buttonholing, freespending lobbyist is belied by Michael A. Abelson, a New York University doctoral candidate. and the lobbyist for the student associations of the State University of New York. Mr. Abelson is paid $5,200 a year, considerably less than many lobbyists, to represent 250,000 students on state university campuses from Stony Brook to Plattsburg to Buffalo.

title: Tennessee Reporter Wins Award of Sigma Delta Chi
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (AP)Frank Sutherland, educational news editor for the Tennessean of Nashville, won the Sigma Delta Chi distinguished service award for general reporting in 1974, the socity of professional journalists announced today.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The steppedup pace of Bicentennial coin and medal production and the seemingly inexhaustible requirements for circulation coinage have combined to thwart the U.S. Mint's efforts to accommodate collectors of regularissue American coins. After months of trying to avoid it the Mint has reluctantly issued the following announcement: There will be no 1975 dating on quarters, halfdollars and dollars. The cent, nickel and dime will be the only 1975dated coins.

title: Vanishing Shield?
description: So varied and numerous in recent years have been the warnings of hazards from environmental contaminationan ice age caused by air pollution, cancer from substances in wide use, and the likethat one tends to become Inured. A new threat, however, represents a special problem. It concerns a phenomenon remote from our direct ken, essential to our lives, yet strangely fragile.

title: Future Social Events
description: Leonard Bernsteins to Be Hosts

title: A Daisy With Distinction For Sunny Sites
description: Shasta Daisies are hybrids of wild flowers found near the Pyrenees. They were hybridized by the great Luther Burbank who named them for Mt. Shasta which was near his California growing fields.

title: Archbishop Tapes Appeal for Funds
description: NEWARK  The Archdiocese of Newark has entered the electronic age to start Lifeline '75, a $6million fund drive that is designed not only to keep current projects moving but also to whittle down some of the $24million debt that Archbishop Peter L. Gerety inherited when he took over his post last June.

title: Income Tax Preparer Curb
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Legislation to license commercial income tax preparers and weed out incompetents has been introduced by Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut.

title: Greatest Agony f or Vietnam Families: Deciding Who Flees and Who Stays
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12Some people here are ready to sacrifice themselves to save loved ones. Others, in a paroxysm of fear, have cast away even wives and children to save themselves.

title: Display on World Of Gertrude Stein
description: GREENVALE  Gertrude gein is one of the most fascinating personalities of the 26th century. A massive Buddha of a woman with an acute mind and a trenchantly witty tongue, the American expatriate turned ber Parisian home into a salon that attracted the most celebrated literati, painters and poets of the early nineteenhundreds. Her prowess for collecting art works is considered legendary by now, as is her piercing insight into what she collected.

title: A F.B.I. INFORMER ASSERTS SHE SPIED ON ATTICA DEFENSE
description: A 26yearold Buffalb woman said yesterday that, she had infiltrated the Attica defense camp and reported back to the Federal Bureau of Investigation on legal strategy surrounding the trials of former inmates under indictment for crimes stemming from the 1971 prison rebellion.

title: Hearing Tomorrow on The Controversial Plan to Rezone Brooklyn High Schools
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker's recently announced plan to rezone Brooklyn high schools came under attack last week on a number of fronts, setting the stage for a hearing tomorrow by a special Board of Education zoning ?? panel.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON Governor Byrne attempted to dissuade him. So did the State Treasurer, Richard C. Leone; S. Howard Woodson, the Assembly Speaker, and Assemblyman Joseph A. LeFante, the Majority Leader in the lower house, among others.

title: NEW FILM STIRS SOVIET AUDIENCE:'Mirror' by Tarkovsky Is Unorthodox and Popular
description: MOSCOW, April 12"Mirror," a new film by Andrei Tarkovsky, the controversial and unorthodox Soviet director, is delighting, puzzling, disaping serious Muscovite movie enthusiasts.The film began showing in two theaters here this week and instantly became the talk of moviegoing intellectuals because, they say, nothing quite like "Mirror" has ever been made before by a Soviet director. Scores of people have been clamoring for tickets in the last few days.Some Muscovites who have seen the film predict that it is sure to be attacked for its unorthodoxy by the ideologically oriented critics of the official press. But in the first round of published reviews, in which some of Mr. Tarkovsky's fellow film makers evaluated his new work, there is much praise, tempered with criticism of some parts of the film.Unconcerned With AbuseIn the way he has created "Mirror"using techniques familiar to viewers of Federico Fellini and Ingmar Bergman pictures, but not to many Soviet moviegoersMr. Tarkovsky seems to make it clear that he is unconcerned with the abuse he has taken for some of his earlier films. "Andrei Rublev," the grim, realistic story of the 15th-century Russian monk and icon painter, was banned in this country for several years, although it won a Cannes Film Festival prize in 1970. Mr. Tarkovsky's science-fiction film, "Solyaris," was criticized a few years ago as being too arcane and whimsical for the average audience to understand."Mirror," a Mosfilm production, is not at all easy to understand, in the sense that it does not have the traditionally recognizable plot structure that is rarely tampered with by Soviet directors. There are flashbacks, slow-motion dream scenes, newsreels and a mixture of color for some sequences and black and white for others.The camera work of Georgi Rerberg on hazy countryside scenes and prolonged still-life shots of, for example, spilled milk or a spot of moisture evaporating on a shiny wood table fascinated viewers who saw the picture the first night it was shown here. Several Russians discussing the film later in the evening argued for various, interpretations of various scenes, but all agreed that parts of the movie produced a shock of self-recognition.Soul of One ManAs far as it can be summarized, the movie follows the course of the soul of one man, who narrates but is rarely seen on the screen. His relationship with his wife, his mother and his children and the society around him develops in events connected in his mind. How this connection is translated to the screen is what puzzles or delights the viewer, as he watches the hero's wife doubling in his mind as his mother.There are symbolic birds and fires and winds and rainfalls, and newsreels of a bullfight in Spain, Chinese agitators taunting Soviet soldiers at the border and Soviet soldiers tramping through mud. Stalin peers for a split-second from a poster into a print shop where a mistake might have been made. The hero's wife seems to long for him, but she kills him metaphorically by beheading a large white rooster."Mirror," according to the criticism of several of Mr. Tarkovsky's fellow directors, will narrow his audience in the Soviet Union. It could increase his audience and his prestige in the West, if the Soviet authorities permit the film to be shown abroad.

She lacks a really strong top and the brilliance of color and coloratura agility for the Jewel Song. In addition, her dictionso important in French opera particularly  sounded mushy.

title: Court Upholds Prisoner
description: RICHMOND, April 12 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has ruled 4 to 3 that a prisoner left naked in solitary confinement in a primitive cell was subjected to cruel and unusual punishment and therefore deprived of his constitutional rights. The court ruled yesterday that Milton McCray, an inmate in the Maryland Penitentiary, had been deprived of his Eighth Amendment rights. The decision reversed a dismissal of the prisoner's complaint by the United States District Court in Baltimore.

title: W. D. Yaffa Fiance Of Patricia Gilbert
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Gilbert of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Susan Gilbert, to William D. Yaffa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Yaffa of New Canaan. Conn.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Dennis V. Shea of Bethesda. Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ce cella Shea, to Thomas Pedder Bispham, assistant manager of the Chemical Bank's petroleum and minerals division here. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Bispham of Haverford. Pa.

title: Oystermen to Test New Gear
description: PORT NORRISIn a move designed to increase the profit margin for South Jersey's sagging oyster industry, vacuumtype harvesting equipment is being installed on a vessel here.

title: Data Inadequacy
description: A technical problem which the Federal Reserve System must continually confront in implementing its monetary policy is the shortrun inadequacy, of its monetary data. In recent years, difficulties probably attributable to the procedures for gathering reports from nonmember banks have produced recurrent data errors and subsequent revisions.

title: The P.T. Barnum Pairing
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12The only golfers to have worn the Masters green jacket four times played together today in the third round, as if P. T. Barnum had become the Augusta National Golf Club's newest chairman of the pairings committee. The twosome of Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer was made in Heaven for the gallery here and for the television gallery elsewhere, but it was made in Hell for the two golfers. Nicklaus shot a oneoverpar 73 and Palmer shot a threeoverpar 75, hardly the stuff of which legends are made. While they concentrated on competing against each other instead of competing against the famous course itself, Nicklaus lost the fivestroke lead he had held after 36 holes and Palmer lost his status as a threat. Nicklaus dropped into second place by a stroke as Tom Weiskopf sculptured a sixunderpar 66 for 207 after 54 holes. In third place at 211 was Johnny Miller with a 65 that included two Masters recordssix consecutive birdies and a 30 for the front nine.

title: Butz Says That Court Dispute May Delay New Standards for Beef
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, contradicting one of his department's lawyers, said today that new standards for grading beef would not be implemented Monday, as planned, unless an injunction issued in Nebraska was overturned.

title: DISPUTE OVER LAND IN NEW MEXICO ENDS
description: ESPANOLA, N.M., April 12A longstanding title dispute over ownership of 1,044 acres in the Carson National Forest area ended this week when 75 residents received deeds to the land. Much of the land has been occupied by their families since the early seventeen hundreds.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Bluegrass Is what most people mean when they talk about hillbilly music. It is a genre quite distinct from that homogenized, cornfed version of pop that is called country down in Nashville. Bluegrass has maintained its identity by preserving a characteristically intricate string ensemble style, a direct heir of the reels and country dance music the English and Scots brought with them to the Southern Appalachian highlands. In addition, of course, bluegrass has its own stars who are followed by their own passionate fans, its own fiddlers, conventions and festivals, and its own permanent center of activitywhich Is not Nashville, but Washington. D.C.

Where the devil do you relieve yourself, then?) Laurence Meynell works this and other turnofthecentury surprises into a delightful reconstruction of life among the bon ton, circa 1910. The action is minor, on the scale of an enclave of seven houses enclosing a private park in Brightsea, a seaside town. But it is as buoying as the light Madeira that everyone favors. The humdrum routine of the Square is invigorated when Number 5 is taken by the dashing Mrs. DillonStuart, who has two exhusbands to her credit and wellcut trousers.

title: Bullets Square Series With Braves
description: BUFFALO, April 12With Wes Unseld making a cornplete turnabout from his flat performance in the opening game, the Washington Bullets tonight evened their fourofsevengame National Basketball Association Eastern semifinal series with the Buffalo Braves at 11 by scoring an impressive 120106 victory at Memorial Auditorium.

title: THE SHELTERED LIFE
description: To most people, the Federal income tax is a complex system designed to extract large sums from their pocketbooksabout $150billion, or more than half the Government's total income. Few realize, however, that while collecting these taxes from individuals and corporations, the Government is simultaneously paying between $80and $90billion to some of them. It does this by simply not collecting any or all the taxes it might on certain types of activitiesthose that, because of their claimed value to society, are permitted special tax benefits. If the Government were first to collect this $80 to $90billion in the regular incometax sweep and then to disburse it again for these benefited activities, we would refer to the process as a subsidy. Indeed, this often overlooked form of Government spending through the tax system amounts to nearly twice the total of all other Federal subsidies. And it can be argued that it is more wasteful and less fair than almost other subsidy.

title: Goldin Study Group Seeks a Feasible Way to Sell City Bonds and Notes Directly to the General Public
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin Is committed to offering city bonds and notes to city, employes and the general public, and has established a study group in his office to come up with a workable plan for the offering, a spokesman for the controller said this week.

Va., at a cost of more than $50million with an annual capacity of 1.5million tons of metallurgical coal by 1982.... The New York State Public Service Commission has recommended rejection without hearing an application by the Consolidated Edison Company for an 8.8 per cent rate hike on electric rates.

title: In Memoriam
description: BERLIANTEdward. April 16, 1974. Death is a heartache no one can heal. Memories are keepsakes no one can steal. Beautiful memories of you are all I have left, of a wonderful husband I will never forget. No one will take your place.

title: Con Edison Acknowledges Rescinding Officer Pay Cuts
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, which recently asked the State Public Service Commission for a 21.7 per cent electric rate increase, acknowledged yesterday that it had quietly rescinded the pay cuts its top executives took amid some publicity around the end of 1973.

title: I Write What Makes Me Laugh
description: Bernard Slade, author of the runaway hit comedy Same Time, Next Year, came to Broadway as that rara avis, the unknown playwright. Well, Slade may have lacked Broadway credentials, but he Is a long way from being a stranger to comedy writing and the world of theater. He is also a far cry from the traditional picture of the struggling young author. It turns out that the man who took Broadway by storm  a typical accolade was Clive Barnes's an enchanting evening, and even the qualified verdict of Walter Kerr conceded that Slade had been thoroughly conscientious, about getting a laugh every 40 to 60 seconds  is an actorturnedwriter with a long string of successes in television. Indeed, the man who gave Broadway theatergoers what Barnes called a devilishly brilliant comedy about two married people who meet for an adulterous weekend once a year for 25 years, is the same man who gave the nation's TV watchers one of the sillier sitcoms of the late sixties, a little number called The Flying Nun.

title: 40 School Buildings to Shut Here
description: Prompted by declining enrollments and a need to cut costs, the Board of Education is planning to close as many as 40 school buildings by June, 1976, and take other measures to use its buildings more efficiently.

title: COAST POLICE UNIT PURGES ITS FILES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12The Los Angeles Police Department, in a move to reform its intelligencegathering activities, says it has destroyed nearly two million secret files it kept on Los Angeles citizens and organizations over the last 50 years.

title: A HEARST WITNESS RESISTS TESTIFYING

Hearst, editor and publisher of The San Francisco Examiner, could be disrupted by the reluctance of a key witness to testify.
