title: Why are there two u's in Equus?
description: It dawned on me, Peter Shaffer said, that when people talked about the air of mystery in the mask scenes of The Royal Hunt of the Sun for them it was all taking place in some remote past. It was about a dead civilization, and with those striking costumes it had the feeling of a historical pageant. Very often, I realized, audiences relate to a historical play at a specific level, as though it had nothing to do with them today, as though it were some sort of...outing.

title: What's Doing on the FRENCH RIVIERA
description: SETTING THE SCENEIn its broadest sense the Cote d'Azur, or. French Riviera, might be said to extend eastward along the Mediterranean from Marseilles or Hyares to Menton, just short of the Italian border. But tourists are most likely to be curious about that part of it that includes St. Tropez, Ste. Maxime, St. Raphael and the famous and occasionally fading resorts on the 36mile stretch from Cannes to Monte Carlo, a stretch that includes JuanlesPins, Antibes, Nice, Villefranche, Beaulieu and Eze. The scenery is varied, often breathtaking. At Cannes there are long sandy beaches backed by resort hotels. On the Esterel drive between St. Raphael and La Napoule there are coves below red  rock cliffs. At Antibes there are crowded beaches along railroad tracks; at Cap Ferrat, posh villas; at Nice, a central business district fronting on pebble beach. Three winding roads between Nice and Menton provide access to much of the best scenery. They are the seaside Corniche Inferieure, the mediumheight Moyenne Corniche and the dizzying

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Living Quarters
description: Charles du Chaudrun was once her lover, when he was down on his luck and eating at the Automat, before he knew anything about her, before she inherited several million dollars, before his success as a television film producer. Then he married her. He loved her as he had never loved anyone else. And she loved him. She depended on him. He was her entire life. There was nothing else. He was also aware that he could leave at any time and that her life would not change substantially. She'd continue to do whatever she'd been doing when he left. She had no power to alter her own course. She was an object in space.

title: A Real Mental aid Becomes A Movie Cuckoo's Nest
description: SALEM, ORE. Sometimes it's a clutch of grade school teachers being led on a tour by that fool Public Relation man who's always clapping his wet hands together and saying how overjoyed he is that mental hospitals have eliminated all that oldfashioned cruelty. What a cheery atmosphere, don't you agree?

title: Joseph H. Given, 53, Dead; WNEW Radio News Writer
description: Joseph H. Given, a news writer wand broadcaster for Radio Station WNEW, died yeatkday of cancer in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 43 years old and lived in Englewood Cliffs; N. J.

title: 4Day Antiques Fair Set in Morristown
description: MORRISTOWNThe sixth annual Morristown Antiques Fair and Sale will be held at the National Guard Armory on Western Avenue for four days, starting April 24. About 100 major dealers from Maine, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Florida, Rhode Island, Delaware, New York and New Jersey are expected to be on hand.

title: Buffalo Lark Wins In Florida
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 12 (AP)Buffalo Lark passed Duke Tom at the head of the stretch, to win the $140,200 Pan American Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: FirstAid Equipment to Treat Humans Proposed as Requirement for Dog Shows
description: When Bart Kollar fell in the ring, apparently the victim of a heart attack, at the recent Bionx show, Dr. Bernard McGivern, judging in an adjoining ring, and two nurses, who were spectators were at his side within seconds.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Knicks Eliminated

title: Brooklyn Landmark Battle
description: A downtown Brooklyn landmark, the old fire headquarters on Jay Street, has become the focus of a tugofwar between City Hall and a perennial antagonist, former Assemblyman Vito P. Battista.

title: Aid on the Medical Front
description: Another fringe benefit just for top executives that is gaining ground is reimbursement for all medical and dental expenses not covered by companywide programs.

title: Stephany L. Hitchcock Plans to Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jacob L. Webb of Ocean Ridge, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Webb's daughter, Stephany Louise Hitchcock of New York, to Franois Roger CapronManieux, also of New York, a son of Mrs. Phillippe Manieux of Beaune, France.

title: Nassau Rent hoard To Fill Vacated Seat
description: MINEOLAThe counsel to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors said last week that he expected the board to nominate a tenant representative to the Nassau Rent Guidelines Board by, the end of this month to replace a member who resigned, effective last week, in opposition to a set of rent guidelines adopted by the ninemember board.

title: Tyler G. Hicks, Science Editor, Is Fiance of Mary T. Shanley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Shanley of East Rockaway, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary T. Shanley, to Tyler G. Hicks of Hicksville, L.I., editor In chief for engineering, science and management at the McGrawHill Book Company.

title: The Big Mac in Piccadilly Circus?
description: LONDONGolden arches on the European horizon? A cheeseburger and tea? Le big mac on the Champs Elvsee?

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, April 13, 1975

title: Carol Sue York Wed to Michael K. Diana
description: Carol Sue York and Michael Keelan Diana, who received M.B.A. degrees from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in December, were married in New Orleans last evening. The Rev. Hunter Hargen performed the ceremony in the chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Jennifer E. Lively Is Engaged To John Bradbury Judkins 3d
description: Elizabeth Mears Lively of Manhattan and Michael E. Lively of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Elizabeth Lively, to John Bradbury Judkins 3d, son of Mr, and Mrs. Judkins Jr. of Lake Forest. Ill.

title: Drug Center Seeks a Home
description: A Queensbased, drugfree youth program is continuing its increasingly desperate search for a new home this weekend after residents of Coronawhere the counseling center was to have relocated  charged that their community had been duped by officials of the group and the city.

title: Man Saved in Chicago Fire
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (UPI)Firemen made a seventhfloor aerial rescue early today of a man trapped in a burning building. The flames from the fire rose high over the downtown Loop and temporarily disrupted elevated rail service on one transit line. More than 25 pieces of equipment were used to fight the fivealarm blaze in an eightstory building that caused an estimated $100,000 damage.

title: Bergen Aids Own Youths Who Need Mental Help
description: DUMONT  An ongoing program at the Community Center for Mental Heigth here is designed to treat and counsel troubled adolescents in their own environment. And, as could be expected, the project, which, is still a few months shy of being a year old, already has encountered its share of successes  and disappointments.

title: Senator Now Favors TeachingHospital Plan
description: LAWRENCE  Supporters of a proposal by Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center to build a teaching hospital here received an unexpected boost last week from State Senator Karen S. Burstein, who reversed an earlier position and announced that she would make as strong a fight as I can on behalf of a hospital.

title: Facts on Fertilizer
description: This year more homeowners then ever will be using fertilizers for the first time in their first home vegetable gardens. One reason is to reduce the family food costs.

title: Volunteer Bicycle Troop Patrols the Park in Style
description: Policing the 840 acres of Central Park is a little less of a problem these days, thanks to 40 civilian volunteers who patrol the park on bicycles with firstaid kits, twoway radios and sirens.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: 2 Relay Races Taken By Loughlin Trackmen
description: NANUET, N. Y., April 12Luis Ostolozaga, a junior at Bishop Loughlin, led the Brooklyn team to two impressive victories today in the eighth annual Nanuet Relays.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Borden, Inc., International, a division of Borden, Inc., a leading food, dairy and chemical company, has leased 38,700 square feet on the 18th floor of the Graybar Building, 520 Lexington Avenue, at 43d Street The 10year lease calls for an aggregate rent of more than $2.5million.

title: Dance: Offbeat Concert
description: Two dancers and choreographers, Lee Connor and Lorn MacDougal, offered an offbeat concert Friday night at New York University's School of the Arts with a program that took in other choreographers as well.

title: Public Symposium on Food Crisis Set
description: NEW BRUNSWICK World Hunger and its Implications for Us, a public symposium on the food crisis, will be held Thursday evening at Douglass College.

title: Boys will be boys, girls will be girls, or will they?
description: Male and female traditionally have been seen as opposites so basic that they symbolize and encompass all sorts of other differenceslight and dark, hard and soft, strong and weak, sacred and profane. Certain antithetical psychological qualities are routinely paired off sexually. Men are said to be active, aggressive, analytical, autonomous; women to be passive, peaceful, intuitive and social. The two main schools of thought on how they got that way might be called intuitive and agnostic. The intuitives, often mothers, school teachers or others who have had the opportunity to observe small children, say, We know boys and girls are different; anyone can tell just by watching them. The agnostics, often feminists bent on heading off arguments that might be used to rationalize the inferior position of women. say, We don't know which differences if any are innate, and we never will know until boys and girls are raised in precisely the same way.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MILAN, April 12 (Reuters)Pele, the Brazilian soccer star, said today he was considering offers to return to the sport, playing for the New York Cosmos in the North American Soccer League. He told reporters here he was negotiating with the Cosmos. I have asked $6million for a two year contract and the Cosmos have offered me the same figure, but for three years. Next Monday we must meet to see if we can reach agreement, said Pele who is on a world tour.

title: Inquiry Clears Kleindienst In Drugs Trial Testimony
description: SAN DIEGO, April 12 (AP)A Federal investigation has concluded that former. United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst testified honestly during, a narcotics trial here two years ago.

title: OIL DRILLING PLAN STIRS NEW DISPUTE
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12A new confrontation has developed between the Department of the Interior and one of the major coastal areas involved in the Ford Administration's proposed offshore oil leasing program.

title: Party in a Store, Crashed by the Customers
description: George Balanchine was enjoying himself. He was flanked by a bevy of women, and his eyes skipped from them to an array of New Guinea art perched on a recessed wall system.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Clark to Rome

title: Law and order in Chile
description: SANTIAGO. I had come to Chile not long ago an admitted opponent of the military junta that unseated Marxist President Salvador Allende Gossens on Sept. 11, 1973, in one of the bloodiest military takeovers in Latin America's history. I would find that the military junta's policies have crippled the country's longstanding democratic institutions in ways that go far beyond the damage already suffered during Allende's three years office.

title: Puerto Rican Family Week Ends With Health Fair and Free Tests
description: Puerto Rican Family Week concluded yesterday with an allday health fair, at which more than 150 people of all ages were given free diagnostic tests.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 13, 1975

title: New York Joins Fight to Cut Sandy Hook Sludge
description: TRENTON  Alarmed by deteriorating water quality and the increasing threat of damage to beaches, a New Jersey legislator is helping to promote a bistate drive that is designed to reduce the buildup of sludge off Sandy Hook.

title: Soaring: Ecstasy In the Alps
description: THE sky is endless around me as I rest on a motionless wind that fills by, head with whistling wonders. Below me is a tapestry: lush fields of green, orange and yellow dotted with brightly colored villages, threaded with shining blue rivers.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Navy to Honor Frenchman
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Navy has announced that it will name a new destroyer for a French admiral who helped to bring about American victory in the Revolutionary War siege of Yorktown. The admiral is Franois de Grasse, who commanded the French fleet at Yorktown in 1781.

title: The Theater: Woyzeck
description: Georg Bchner is the most remarkable of contemporary playwrights, if only because he died nearly 140 years ago at the tender age of 23. Yet in the handful of plays he has left us, he has demonstrated time and again that he was the precursor of the modern theater. It is virtually imposible to think of Woyzeck as anything but a play of our century.

title: Newark Exhibits a Saga of Whaling
description: NEWARK  The excitement, dangers and rewards of oldtime whaling are vividly evoked in a new exhibition at the Newark Museum, thanks to the aid of precious scrimshaw, a 28 foot  long whaling boat and a 50footlong felt whale.

title: Blood on his hand, not custard on his face
description: Len Deighton's success as a writer of spy thrillers has always rested on his recognition of the humorous possibilities of the form. Like its near cousin the murder mystery, the novel of espionage rests on a set of conventions that bring it closer to comedy than to any other literary genre. The readers' fascination for it, Deighton knows, is a function of our nostalgia for action or, put another way, for the child's world of moral clarity and guiltless intrigue. Plot dominated, the thriller deals with stock characters and a degree of happenstance and coincidence that with a twist here and a turn there could easily degenerate into buffoonery. Even the most credulous of readers has a great deal of disbelief to suspend; most important of all is that one knows from the start that although the hero may emerge with blood on his hands rather than custard cream on his face, he will remain fundamentally unscathed, springing back from near disaster like a Joe Palooka punching bag.

title: Lawyer for Jane Alpert Denies She Informed on Other Radical Fugitives
description: Since she surrendered last November, Jane Alpert has been strongly attacked by militant feminists who believe she informed on Pat Swinton and other fugitives and fear that she will testify against Miss Swinton before a grand jury here believed to be investigating the harboring of radical fugitives.

title: Notes: The ABC's Of the APEX Fare
description: NOW that people are starting to sign up for the, airlines' latest moneysaving schemethe new transAtlantic Advance Purchase Excursion fare, known as APEX, which was approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board two weeks ago and became effective April 1many prospective passengers are questioning the wisdom of committing themselves to travel, plans they cannot easily change.

title: Private School in East Orange Is in a Class by Itself
description: EAST ORANGEFiftyfive boys and girls are attending a high school here in which the students set up the curriculum, help to hire teachers and decide whether or not to attend classes.

title: The World
description: With the Geneva conference on the Middle East unlikely to resume before summer, some movement toward new bilateral negotiations between the belligerents is under way.

title: Finley Claims Dave Johnson
description: Charles O. Finley, the Oakland A's owner, said yesterday he was going to claim Dave Johnson and insisted that the Atlanta Braves' sale of the second baseman to Japanese baseball was illegal.

title: CHESS
description: People were saying Bobby Fischer had to play. They said that no champion could shrug off his title. They said that his insistence on certain conditions for playing were only tactics leading up to a dramatic lastminute acceptance of the match with Anatoly Karpov. But they were wrong.

title: Europe and the Resource Revolution
description: LONDON  Is Europe on the verge of a fresh upsurge of economic growth? Or have the economic and social forces that propelled it through the most dynamic boom in its historyone that lasted from postwar reconstruction until the skyrocketing of oil prices  now spent themselves?

title: Income Tax? People Seem Resigned to It
description: PASSAICThe people of NeW Jersey appear to be uncertain of the need for a state income tax.

title: Pennsylvania Poor Cool To Fuel Aid Experiment
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 11When the Federal Government started helping poor people here pay their, heating bills last winter, nobody thought it would be a problem to get rid of the $180,000 allocated to the program.

title: An Unplanned Economic Experiment
description: WASHINGTONThe United States economy is about to undergo an unusual and somewhat hairraising experiment. What is to be tested is whether a Government budget deficit, which until now has been a normal and accepted stimulus for the economy in time of recession, can become so huge as to be counterproductive and even stifle economic recovery.

title: Yachtsmen Join to Battle Big Brotherism
description: The growing intervention of government in pleasure boating has spurred the United States (formerly North American) Yacht Racing Union to join the National Boating Federation. The federation, an alliance of boating organizations representing a million boating families, officially will admit the Union at its annual meeting next Saturday in New Orleans. The Union and its 4,000member organization will add 250,000 sailors to the N.B.F.

title: FLORIDA RAINSFORCE EVACUATION OF 1,500
description: BONIFAY, Fla., April 12 (UPI) The Choctawahatchee River, swollen by three days of rain, swept through two towns today and left 1,500 persons homeless in the Florida panhandle.

title: Many Refugees Have Had Years of Practice
description: SAIGONFor Nguyen Xuan Ngon, the decision to gather his family, abandon his property and flee from his home in the northern areas of this wartorn nation the other day was just about the easiest decision of his life.

title: Paperbacks
description: ESCAPE FROM CHILDHOOD, by John Holt. (Ballantine $1.75.) One of the nineteen sixties' most outspoken educational reformers (Why Children Fail, etc.) here argues that childhood Is largely an artificial thing, invented to exploit the young, and urges that children be extended the same rights as adults.

title: The Sweater Girl Returns to Reminisce
description: LOS ANGELES Lana Turner, fabulous sweater girl of the forties, sultry pinup of World War 11, glittering star of some of MGM's glossiest extravaganzasnot to mention a sizzling offscreen drama or twowill be back in the spotlight tonight in A Tribute to Lana Turner at Town Hall. Miss Turner, whose career has spanned more than 30 years since that day she was discovered sipping a soda in Schwab's Drug Store, will be on hand to answer questions from the audience after the showing of scenes from a number of her movies.

title: Medicaid Funds Called Lost on Wrong Care for Aged
description: A study by city physicians estimates that Medicaid ?? wasting $126million a year by keeping patients in the wrong kind of nursing home here.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The coercive power of the Federal purse... From the age of Franklin Roosevelt to that of Lyndon Johnson, such warning phrases were the hallmark of the political right this country. But the phrase was used the other day by a figure with authentic liberal credentials: Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University. He warned against use of the leverage of the government dollar to achieve social aims.

title: U.S. Aides in Saigon Fear Disorder May Hamper Exit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. April 12There is widespread concern here that in an evacuation many Americans and almost all Vietnamese who have worked for Americans will be trapped in Saigon.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Can you please tell me how to refinish a rosewood table which has stains on it from wet glasses? The stains hays been on for quite some time.J.R., Brooklyn. N.Y.

title: Reds Warn of Uprising If Thieu Does Not Leave
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12A Vietcong delegation exuding confidence and good humor warned today that an uprising in Saigonpresumably meaning a big Communist guerrilla operationwas imminent, unless President Nguyen Van Thieu stepped down immediately and the Americans left.

title: Sarah W. Adams to Be Married
description: Annoucement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Adams of Washington of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Woodbury Adams, to Denis Howard Hector, son of Louis J. Hector of Coconut Grove, Fla., and the late Mrs. Hector. A July wedding is planned.

title: LOTTERY NUMBER
description: Saturday, April 12, 1975

title: A Dozen Newsmen Remain in Cambodia After Evacuations
description: More than a dozen foreign newsmen are staying behind in the embattled Cambodian capital, Pnom Penh, some by their own choice and others because they missed the evacuation helicopters.

title: Exhibition Soccer Listed by Hartford
description: HARTFORD, April 12 (AP) Hartford of the North American Soccer League will play four international exhibition games before opening its season April 25 in Miami against the Toros.

title: Expanded Soccer League Has High Hopes For the New Season Starting Friday
description: The North American Soccer League will open its eighth season Friday with 20 franchises, five more than last year and 11 more than two years ago. But despite its expansion the league, now the nation's third largest professional organization in number of teams, still is out of the television picture on a regular basis.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city of Milford, Conn., has come to the financial aid of the Milford Academy, a private, coeducational preparatory school that had asked its 25member faculty and staff to work without pay. Several thousand dollars were earmarked by the city to pay teaching and maintenance personnel through June at the 200student school, Mayor Joel R. Baldwin said. Milford Academy is a fixture in our city, and I could not sit idly by and watch it go down the financial drain.

title: RICH INDIAN AREA LOSES RICE CROPS
description: PONVILAINTHAKALATHUR, IndiaLiterally translated, the name of this village 40 miles southwest of Madras means the Yield That Grew Gold.

title: 18 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: CLINES CORNERS, N. M., April 12 (UPI)A Continental Trailways bus on a Los AngelestoNew York run slid off icy Interstate 40 near here early today and overturned on its side in a ditch. Eighteen persons were injured, none seriously.

title: ENERGY MEETING IN PARIS STALLED
description: PARIS, April 12  Despite concessions by both developed and developing countries, a preparatory meeting for a world energy conference remained deadlocked in its sixth day today, but delegates were continuing to try to reach an agreement.

title: LETTERS
description: Oil Allowance

title: Communist Rule Is at Least Uncertain; Napalm Is Not
description: PHNOM PENHThe spectacle of the Americans being evacuated front Cambodiawith helicopters dropping from the skies and stonyfaced Marines armed to the teeth protecting the Embassy evacuees from nothing, with curious crowds of Cambodians watching another American spectacle they did not understand and with Embassy homes being ransacked by military police immediately after the officials' departureis perhaps a fair epitaph for American policy Indochina, or at least in Cambodia.

title: SAIGON REPORTING GAINS AT XUAN LOC AND ON A KEY ROAD
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 13The Saigon Government said last night that its forces had fought off Communist troops at Xuan Loc, 38 miles northeast of here, and on a key road 21 miles southwest of the capital.

title: SCHOOL MAY REQUIRE CLEARWRITING TEST
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., April 12Students at Michigan State University will have to prove they can write clearly before they can get a diploma, if a writing competency exam is approved here.

title: David F. Dietz Fiance Of Katherine W. Wies
description: Dr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Wies of Branford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Wilbour Wies, to David Fianklin Dietz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Dietz of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 7.

title: Legislators: Offices at Home
description: EAST BRUNSWICKLater this spring, Assemblyman James W. Bornheimer will move his district legislative office from the cellar of his home here to a local office building: He chose the new location because it is situated on a main thoroughfare and is easy for the majority of his constituents to reach.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Johnny Miller learns the price of success: It used to be that if I finished fourth or fifth, they'd come up to me and say, Nice going. Now when I come in fourth or fifth in a tournament, they ask, What happened?

title: Hearings This Week On SST's At Kennedy
description: Federal hearings are to open in Washington tomorrow and in Queens later, in the week on the explosive, emotional issue of whether the 1,350mileanhour BritishFrench Concorde supersonic jetliner should be allowed to land at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Nancy Topf Offers Five Dance Pieces At Hoff man Studio
description: The choreographer Nancy Topf presented a program of five pieces at the Byrd Hoffman Studio on Friday night. All dealt imaginatively with bodies in simple motion.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Though the idea behind Walter Wager's TELEFON (Macmillan, $6.95) is not newBrian Garfield had previously explored the concept in his Deep Cover of 1971Wager develops it in a gorgeous manner and has come up with a doozie of a thriller. The idea: the presence of a large number of special Soviet agents in the United States, all under deep hypnosis, all here for many years, all good, Godfearing American citizensuntil the trigger word sends them off.

title: Big Banks in City Expanding
description: The three largest banks in the city are sharply expanding their office facilities here.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Chiquita Banana has met an unexpected masterthe Securities Act of 1933. Last Wednesday the Securities and Exchange Commission cited the United Brands Companythe Chiquita Banana people, formerly United Fruitfor a $1.25million bribe to an unidentified high official of the Government Honduras, and for another $750,000 of payoffs to officials of a foreign government in Europe.

title: Alfred Starr Hamilton, Poet
description: Once upon a time I used to know an honest, yet humble, advertising executive in Buckhead, Ga., by the name of James Dickey. He was surely the only man in the Peach State who could talk about F. S. Flint, R. E. F. Larsson, Mina LoyI mean poets, whether they were minor ones or major ones and all that. He would get that wild good light in his eyes. Well, that was 17 years ago. Mr. Dickey, having run through the Poetry World like green corn through a cow, now masquerades as Sheriff SuperJock, of Deliverance County, Jawja.

title: The Region
description: The state's chief Attica prosecutor has been accused by his former deputy of covering up possible crimes committed by law enforcement officers in their violent suppression of the prison uprising in 1971. The charge raises serious questions about New York's investigation of the rebellion and also, indirectly, about former Governor Nelson Rockefeller's role in alloWing the assault to take place.

title: Step Nicely Takes Excelsior, Monetary Principle Is Second
description: Step Nicely made his customary way to the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday. The Hobeau Farm's 5yearold won the 1mile Excelsior Handicap, as most of the 32,825 spectators expected he would.

title: New California Governor Stuns the Liberals, Too
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12The iconoclasm of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. is sending shock waves through liberals and conservatives in the nation's most populous state.

title: Lobbyist Ordered to Prison
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) A Federal Judge has ordered Cyrus T. Anderson, a lobbyist to report to prison on May 12 to begin a sentence of up to 18 months for his 1972 conviction of bribing a former Democratic Senator of Maryland, Daniel B. Brewster. Mr. Brewster's conviction for accepting $14,500 from Mr. Anderson to influence his vote on pending postage rate legislation was overturned last August, but Mr. Anderson's conviction was upheld. A retrial of Mr. Brewster is scheduled for May 19.

title: Manila Reviewing Status of U.S. Bases
description: MANILA, April 12The Philippine Government has begun a review of how useful the American bases here are to this country.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Twenty years ago the idea of the Jos Limn Dance Company without Jos Limn would have been as unthinkable as Hamlet without the Prince of Denmark. Partly this was because at that time no one thought in such termsit was almost as unthinkable to have Martha Graham leading her company as a choreographer rather than choreographer/dancerbut also because so many of the company's roles created both by Doris Humphrey and Limn himself seemed to be impregnated with Limn's spirit and personality. Of course, to some extent this was true of the creations Graham made for herself, but in all the Graham works the strength and lasting quality of the actual choreography was always evident. With Limn and Humphrey such durability seemed somehow less certain.

title: Senate to Get Bill T is Week to Protect Privacy of Citizens
description: TRENTON  Legislation that would require state and local governments, and private industry to protect the privacy of citizens, and which would create a com mission to enforce that protection, will be introduced in the Senate this week.

title: Food News
description: PRINCETONA demanding clientele was responsible for the initial growth of their business, say Carl and Virginia Andersen, owners of the modern, glass  walled Bon Appetit shop at the edge of the Princeton Shopping Center. And a matching demand of their own for the most sophisticated gourmet foods, the Andersens add, may explain the remarkable growth of the store, whose size has tripled in four years.

title: More People Deduct the Office at Home
description: When the returns are in this week, eagleeyed agents of the Internal Revenue Service may note an increase in the number of inhome offices.

title: Mr. Ford's. Strange Ploy
description: For reasons only he and Secretary of State Kissinger can know fully, President Ford has made two extraordinary demands on Congress to complete what he perceives as the American responsibility in Indochina.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Many recent discussions of monetary policy conclude that the Federal Reserve System should act quickly and vigorously to reduce shortterm interest rates further. The wisest policy for the next several months would be to maintain shortterm yields at or only modestly below their current levels.

title: FIRST CHOICE,TRIO, SINGS AT GOOGIE'S
description: First Choice, a young female soul trio from Philadelphia that returned to New York for a twonight engagement at Barney Google's beginning Friday, made a not entirely convincing impression.

title: Baseball: What It's All About
description: Baseball men agree with the philosopher that perfectionwhich means a pennant to themis attainable only through a proper combination of opposites. A team equally strong in attack and in defense, wellproportioned as a unit, with, of course, those intangibles morale, enthusiasm, and directionthat is the story of success in baseball.

title: Smith Pole Vaults 184, Snaps His World Mark
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April l2 (AP)After clearing 18 feet 4 inches for a professional pole vault record, Steve Smith took a look at 19 feet and liked what he saw.

title: Laos Is Worried by Indochina Setbacks
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 12The kingdom of Laos, which last year set up a coalition of neutralists, rightists and proCommunist Pathet Lao, is in the grip of anxiety and confusion because of the deteriorating situation in Cambodia and South Vietnam.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: After a threeyear silence, Judy Collins has returned to recording. Her new album, entitled Judith, not only broadens her repertoire to include the standard popular classics but takes a headlong plunge into Rolling Stones rock. The kind of versatility that Judy Collins cultivates is rare in pop music. It distinguishes her 16year career as vocalist, composer, lyricist, arranger, producer, guitarist, concert pianist, writer, actress, social activist and filmmaker.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It's only April but Hal Ashby's Shampoo, which opened in February, remains the American film comedy of the year to datea witty, furtively revolutionary, foulmouthed comedyofmanners cast in the fairly conventional frame of a story about the comeuppance of a smalltown Casanova.

title: President Asks Authority On Reorganization Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)President Ford has asked Congress to extend for four years authority for the executive branch to propose Government reorganization plans to improve management and increase efficiency.

title: Strife Growing in Angola as Date for SelfRule Draws Closer
description: LUANDA. Angola, April 8Divisions and hatreds among Angola's black liberation movements have deepened as independence draws closer, bringing a threat of civil war Or even partition to this vast and rich territory in southwest Africa.

title: Design
description: It's too bad the archeologists of the future won't be able to dig up our corporate reception areas. They probably tell more about us than the giant buildings that contain them. Ostensibly, these waystops to the inner sanctums of big business are for direction of traffic flow. Actually. they are indicators of the psychodrama of the business world, from the uses of power to the institutional putdown.

title: Sarah Elizabeth Hall Married To John Parker Hansel Jr.
description: Sarah Elizabeth Hall and John Parker Hansel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hansel of Hanisville N H., were married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Amnesty Center Is Closed; Processed 5,492 Deserters
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 12 (AP) A total of 5,492 military deserters were processed during the 5months conditional amnesty program at the Joint Clemency Processing Center at Fort Benjamin Harrison here, military officials say.

title: Solzhenitsyn Speaks Out on Paris TV
description: PARIS, April 12Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn said last night in a television interview that if he had not been imprisoned for his dissident views, I would have perhaps become a writer in the Soviet Union, but I do not believe that I could have ever really appreciated or understood my true tasks.

title: Crops Wilting Along the Euphrates, and Iraq Says a Syrian Dam Is to Blame for the Low Water Level
description: KORSH, Iraq, April 5By the waters of Babylon, Odeh Abed, an Iraqi peasant, said he wept at night for the little tomato and pepper plants that are wilting in his garden beside the Euphrates River for lack of irrigation.

title: Two U.S. Dogs Top Groups
description: MONTREAL, April 12An English springer spaniel, a Scottish deerhound and a Great Dane took group honors tonight in the richest dog show ever held in North America, the United Kennel Club's 81st Montreal fixture, which drew 1,358 entries.

title: SUPERTRAMP BOWS WITH BRITISH COOL
description: Supertramp, a British rock band that appeared for the first time in New York on Friday night at the Beacon Theater, seems oddly misnamed. One expects some new extreme of glittering outrage, all sequins and ambivalent sexuality and raunchy bluesrock in the New York Dolls mode. Instead, one gets cooly rehearsed, top40 progressive rock.

title: Radio

title: Scuba: Fear and Joy in Bermuda
description: I AM halfway across the island of Bermuda on my rented motorbike when the shower begins, the kind of shower you usually take naked with a bar of soap. The road acquires a rainslick, my glasses are a sheet of water, and I begin to shiver with cold and an attack of nerves, but there is, no turning back. I have an appointment at 10:15 with a tank of compressed air and a pair of flippers; I intend to keep it.

title: Is That You, Miss Blue?
description: Hilarious and sad and crazy and unbelievablethat's how Flanders, the 15yearold narrator, describes the little world she has been living in for three months, and the description is totally apt for the novel as well. M. E. Kerr has used the familiar microcosm of boarding school to make several points which apply at large, and to make them with so much grace, charm and poignancy that one closes the book with the feeling, this is the way life really is. And the way life really is, as even the youngest of us find out soon enough, is unjust and unkind in direct proportion to one's vulnerability.

title: The Making of an Art Detente
description: From the Lands of the Scythians, the exhibition of ancient art from the Eurasian Steppe that opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art next Saturday, represents among other things a triumph of artpolitic. Three weeks later, 100 paintings from the Metropolitan will go on view in the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad. (The paintings will appear subsequently at the Pushkin Museum in Moscow, while the Scythian show travels to the Los Angeles County Museum and then to the Louvre.) Behind this first largescale fine arts exchange between the United States and the Soviet Union lies a tortuous trail of negotiations that led at one point to the political summit, and to hear Tom Hoving talk there is no question whose side came out on top.

title: Food

We were delighted to read in an interview recently that she shares our passion for chicken wings. First off, she declared that she is not a gourmet but a gourmand (infinitely preferable in our books). My favorite dish is chicken wings, she declared. It's the most refined part of the creature. We can only add brava and contribute two refined uses for that part of the creature. One is for curried chicken wings, the other for chicken wings chasseur made with tomatoes and mushrooms.

title: The Strange Case of Alfred Hitchcock
description: Academic or serious film criticism stands apart from its journalistic neighbor at least by virtue of its exhaustiveness. The word can suggest a number of things, including the effect of such criticism on its readers, but in the case of Raymond Durgnat, who has published a score of books on the movies, it should indicate some happy traits in the author: care, range of information and, above all, Ins prodigious output. Reading these two books has convinced me that Durgnat is that rare creature, a critic of solid intelligence whose style is completely undistinguished. Though he writes with penetration and admirable common sense, one is apt to be thinking at every point: yes, but how oft thought, how off better expressed.

As a sports buff, he loves it, the fervor of the crowds, the showbusiness atmosphere and above all the Nets. I love them, he concedes. That Julius Erving. He's made of rubber, does the most fantastic things.

title: The poet as Oedipus
description: For the production, study and enjoyment of literature there are central assumptions that rarely get examined, not always for want of critical energy, but for what seem to be commonsense reasons. Consider Milton as an example. He is the author of Paradise Lost; the textof that poem exists, it is read, it has been written about, and is itself about great events on earth, in heaven and hell. Readers of Milton assume that the text they read as by Milton is what is immovably before them on the page. Milton's date,s of birth and death, the textual history of his poetry; his fame and position in literature, even the meaning of his epic: all these are ascertainable by interpretive methods, perfected in the course of Western culture, that depend on the writer's presence in the culture. The whole enterprise of literature, and consequently of literary criticism, is to fix authors like Milton and his text ever more securely in the culture: the author and his text have sources, the author and his text have an influence on subsequent poets, but always we assume the abiding presence of a great author who has produced the great work.

title: Encounter: I've Never Believed in Voodoo. I Still Don't. But...
description: OUR ten days in Haiti were almost over. My husband and I had strolled through PortauPrince's. Iron Market, pursued by small boys who yelled; Bonjour, Monsieur Blanc, you want to buy real chip? and had acquired a graceful candelabra made of old tin cans for $2. We had explored the Centre d'Art headquarters for the best of Haiti's hundreds of talented painters, and had dickered with art dealers, who purveyed kitsch and high quality with impartial enthusiasm. We had nightclubbed like jetsetters: the musicians and dancers in the floor shows exuded an exoticism more exciting, and genuine than anything we'd ever seen in New York.

title: And a Story Goes With It

Six weeks ago the 2yearold champion of 1974 was the only undefeated winner of the Flamingo Stakes in the 47 years that race has been run at Hialeah. Today he is no longer unbeaten, having gouged the soles of both forefeet running in the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park, where John Galbreath's entry of Prince Thou Art and Sylvan Place beat him back to third. In spite of that, the Reno Turf Book still makes him 5 to 2 for the big one in Louisville, with Prince Thou Art 4 to 1, Singh 6, Master Derby 10, Laramie Trail 15 and Lefty 20. Singh, Laramie Trail and Lefty are expected to try Foolish Pleasure in the Wood.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: At the same time that Joseph Papp is talking about raising $3million or so to remodel the troublesome Vivian Beaumont at Lincoln Center into a regulation, oldfashioned, prosceniumarch house, he is busy playing host, at his downtown Public Theater, to an environmental production of Ibsen's Ghosts that not only dispenses with a proscenium arch but that makes it virtually impossible to locate the actors anywhere. There is no particular irony in the situationafter all, a man may use two different houses for two different purposesbut there may be something to be learned from it.

title: Used Car Inquiry Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission has announced an investigation of the used car business, particularly into how well dealers live up to service contracts and guarantees. The investigation, announced Thursday, was prompted by a recent Federal law upgrading warranties.

title: Indoor Gardening
description: On several occasions I have told publisher friends of mine that after thinking it over I have reached the conclusion that publishers don't know Much about the publishing business; and on each occasion the response has been a startled question as to what could ever have given me the idea that they do. Books that should sell don't, and books that shouldn't, do. But there must be some rational connection demand and supply in the case of hooks on amateur gardening, especially indoor gardening, since they continue to flow from the presses in quantities exceeded only by cookbooks.

title: Ford Golfs in Maryland
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  President Ford played golf today at Burning Tree Country Club in nearby Maryland. His playing partners were William Whyte, vice president of United States Steel; Rod Markley, vice president of government relations for the Ford Motor Company, and former Representative John Byrnes of Wisconsin.

title: 7 STATES BORROW TO PAY JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Seven states and Puerto Rico have now been forced to borrow from the Feleral Government to pay unemployment insurance benefits. Government officials say trust funds in several other states are nearly depleted.

title: New Yorkers Shut Their Stuff All Year
description: WHATEVER the time of year, the state of pocketbook, the weather a footsore visitor, to New York City can pause in his peregrinations and watch the natives do the walking. There are dozens of parades of every description, many of them reflectiohs of the ethnic melting pot that is New York.

title: Tennessee Evolution Law Is Voided by Appeals Court
description: CINCINNATI, April 12 (UPI) A Tennessee law minimizing the theory of evolution in biology textbooks is similar to the 1925 law that produced the famous Scopes monkey trial and therefore is unconstitutional, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Schoolgirl Sets Record
description: PINE PLAIN, N. Y., April 12Christine Helbock, a 17yearold senior at Haldane Central High School in Cold Spring, N. Y., set a New York State record of 40 feet 9 inches in the Spound shotput at a Duchess County track meet today. Miss Helbock's shot surpassed the previous record of 377 set. by Gail Dusekas of Watertown last June.

title: Package Tour of Mainland China
description: I HAD 11 children. Nine of them starved to death in front of me, and there was nothing I could do. I carried the bamboo pole from sunup to sundown for the landlord and my only payments were meager amounts of millet that did not last through the winter. Now my family has a sewing machine and two bicycles. I have a job arid I am helping to raise my weekold granddaughter. In new China we have a future.

title: G.A.O. FINDS TAX LAG FOR FARM WORKERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Thousands of hired farm workers apparently are not paying their full share of Federal income taxes because most employers do not deduct those taxes from wages, government investigators say.

title: Sea Oats Anchor Sand
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP)  Sea oats, a three to four foot tall grass common to Southern and Gulf shores, help anchor the shifting sand dunes.

title: Jane Regan Bride of A. B. Houghton
description: Jane Nagle Regan and, A. Bradley Houghton, both of South Orange, N. J., were married yesterday morning by the Rev. Aloysius Nagle, a cousin of the bride, in Our Lady, of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange. The nuptial mass was concelebrated by Msgr. George W. Shea, the Rev. Daniel A. Danik and the Rev. Daniel A. Hare.

title: New Lunar Flight Planned by NASA
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has invited scientists to propose experiments for a new, unmanned Moonorbiting spacecraft, the rirst American moon mission since the end of the Apollo project in 1972.

title: Expert Says a New Dehydration Treatment May Eliminate Severe Diarrhea
description: A simple treatment for the dehydration that accompanies severe diarrhea has proved so successful that it promises to eliminate cholera as a major killer and perhaps mitigate the effects for tourists and babies of other such disorders, according to a specialist in diseases of the internal tract.

title: U.S. Embassy Staff Is Evacuated From Phnom Penh Under Guard of U.S. Marines
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 12The American Embassy pulled out of Cambodia today in a sudden morning evacuation in which fully armed marines who flew in to provide security were shelled by the insurgents as they prepared to board the last helicopters.

title: Shop Talk
description: HAWTHORNEJacob Van Beuzekom, C.K.D., has been in business here for 35 years.

title: Joan Chuda Bride of Robert Pierce
description: Joan Diane Chuda and Robert King Pierce were married yesterday, morning in St. Thomas Episcopal Church. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: Lessons of Depression Fail to Help Elderly Poor Residents of Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH  All their lives they worked hard, these aged survivors of the Great Depression. They came here to a frugal pocket of sunshine to finish their days on Social Security or pension or both, benefits that they helped win in the political and economic struggles of the nineteenthirties.

title: Why Lots of Money Didn't End Lots of Crime
description: WASHINGTON  On Feb. 6, 1967, President Johnson sent the Safe Streets and Crime Control Act to Congress. The very name of the act, Safe Streets, and Mr. Johnson's accompanying message contained the notion that large transfusions of Federal money could help defeat violent crime in this country. The act, after considerable refinement by Congress, created a new Government agency in 1968, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, to pump money into the nation's criminal justice system. And the agency has been pumping money ever since, $4.2billion to be exact.

title: STAMPS
description: Paul Laurence Dunbar, the first nationally known black poet in the United States, appears on the second commemorative in this year's American Arts series.

title: MISS MOORE OPENS AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: Melba Moore begins her per forrnance at the Bottom Line very quietly  just her unaccompanied voice. But Miss Moore is a singer with a voice that moves from whisper to scream in no time at all, and at the end of the song she is in full throttle, comfortably outdistancing the large backup band.

title: Blacks Are Hoping To Make a Splash
description: CINCINNATI, April 12In his book, The 50Meter Jungle, Sherm Chavoor held out hope of training a black swimmer who could duplicate the Olympic feats of Chavoor's star pupil, Mark Spitz.

title: Susan Metzenbaum to Be Wed To Joel Zylberberg of Yale Law
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Metzenbaum of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lynn Metzenbaum, to Joel H. Zylberberg, son of Mr. and Mrs David Zylberberg of University Heights, Cleveland. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Suzanne Ekkers To Be Wed in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Ekkers of Manhasset, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Marie Ekkers, to George Andrew Doyle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle, also of Manhasset.

title: Nassau Votes Legislature
description: MINEOLANassau County's Board of Supervisors approved a charterrevision measure last week that wouldif it is acceptable to the courts and then approved in a referendum set for June 10  replace the present board with a 15member county legislature.

title: Epilogue
description: Citizen Robert E. Lee

title: TV VIEW
description: Now that we have all watched both hours of the Sunday night Bob and Mike Show on CBS, it is time to sermonize on the problem of checkbook journalism: (I am reminded of an article in a recent issue of the British journal, Nature. The article argued that the increase in the number of American tornadoes during the past 40 years might plausibly be blamed on the fact that Americans drive on the right side of the road, thus conspiring with oncoming cars at a counterclockwise vortex of air motion which, in this hemisphere anyway, encourages tornadoes. Some problems are more momentous thanothers. But lhoie of us who drive our typewriters on the right side of any problem can still whip, up a lot of wind.)

title: Exodus
description: The evacuation from Phnom Penh of Americans and of as many... Cambodians who have been associated with us as circumstances permit brings to an inglorious if inevitable conclusion this phase of the United States illconceived involvement in Indochina. It is also the probable precursor to a similar withdrawal from Saigon, following the collapse of the South Vietnamese Government's military forces in the face of the Communist offensive from the north.

title: Assembly Backing DeathPenalty Bill
description: TRENTONThe State Assembly is poised to approve a measure that would restore the death penalty in New Jersey.

title: Elderly In Nassau Feel Bite Of Inflation
description: CARLE PLACEFor many of the elderly in Nassau County who are living on fixed incomes, inflation has created problems in getting adequate housing, nutrition and health care, according to a survey conducted by the Nassau Department of Senior Citizen Affairs.

title: Police Wound 4 in India Riot
description: NEW DELHI, April 12 (Reuters)  Four persons were wounded in Ahmadabad today when the police opened fire after a crowd of 2,000 attacked them, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Great Neck: Tensions Remain
description: GREAT NECK  Even though Mortimer J. Abramowitz has been fully reinstated as School Superintendent, there is little evidence that Great Neck is entering a new era of peace and understanding.

title: Workshop PIanned On County Reforms
description: NEW BRUNSWICKNew Jersey Common Cause, in conjunction with the Eagleton Institute of Politics, is sponsoring a workshop on county party reform. It will be held next Saturday at Douglass College.

title: DELAWARE PAPER SUES OVER LOAN
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The Delaware State News is suing the Farmers Bank of the State of Delaware, Inc., for more than $100,000, charging that the batik canceled a loan in retaliation for unfavorable news articles and editorials about the bank.

title: The Little Evergreens Are showy Yearround
description: Before We discovered the littlest evergreens, our karden was always at a low point in late wider and early spring. Except for an occasional bulb blooming in some protected spot, there was nothing to see, everything was still underground. Evergreens changed all that. Now no matter how early in the year, we can walk about and be greeted by mounds tuffets and hummocks of greenery.

title: Carey Orders Naming of Aide to Evaluate State's Inquiry on Attica
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that a special deputy attorney general would be appointed shortly to evaluate the conduct of the state's threeyear investigation and prosecution of alleged crimes arising from the Attica prison revolt.

title: More Of the Same
description: The most dismaying thing about President Ford's foreign policy speech was not his call for $722 million in military aid for South Vietnam, since there is little chance Congress will provide anything like that sum. Rather, it was what the entire speech suggested about the man himself, his view of the world, his brand of national leadership.

title: NEW LAW TANGLES VOTE IN ANN ARBOR
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 12 Six days after an experiment with preferential voting, residents of this university city of 100,000 still aren't sure whop won the election for Mayor. In the end, the courts may decide.

title: Letter
description: Sttrretching it out

title: Fringe Benefits at the Top
description: The pain and privilege of high corporate office seem to be intensified in trying times like these.

title: Cholera Kills 33
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 12 (Reuters)Thirtythree people have died of cholera in Majalengka, Java, the last three months, Anatara, the Indonesian press agency reported today.

title: GERRY RAFFLES DIES; BRITISH PRODUCER, 53
description: LONDON, April 12 (AP)Gerry Raffles, a major figure in British theater since World War II, has died in Lyons, France, friends said last night. He was 53 years old.

title: Buzzers and Phones And TV, Too, Add To Building Security
description: As the cost of aroundtheclock doormen for an apartment building approaches $50,000 a year and the supply of qualified personnel diminishes, owners and managers are discovering a wide range of electronic substitutes.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: NEW HAVEN. It is pearpicking time in England's provincial Black Country. Seasonal laborers strap canvas baskets to their necks and pluck ripe fruit from trees. The pickers are mostly locals, whose Birmingham accents are as thick as clotted milk. David Rudkin's Afore Night. Come (at the Long Wharf Theater) begins quietly and deceptively, like David Storey's The Contractor (with fruitpicking, not tenterecting, the apparent subject), but Rudkin has something startlingly different in mind.

title: 15.3% Jobless in Michigan
description: DETROIT, April 12 (UPI)Unemployment in Michigan decreased for the first time in six months during March, but Gov. William Milliken says that the 15.3 per cent unemployment rate still is totally unacceptable. Officials credited the revived auto industry with reducing the March unemployment figures a 1.3 per cent decrease from the 15.5 per cent rate in February. The rate was 9.6 per cent in March of 1974.

title: Nan Gardner Grimm to Wed in June
description: Nan Gardner Grimm, manager of the Ben Kahn fur salon at Cartier's, plans to be married this June in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church to John Hunnewell Moorhead, an account officer with the First National City Bank of New York.

title: Pamela Wescott, R.B. Keighley Jr. Are Married Here
description: Pamela Anna Wescott, manager of the men's department at Macy's White Plains, was married yesterday morning to Richard B. Keigley Jr., a special agent for the Northwestern Mutual Insurance Corporation in Greenwich Conn.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: OAKLAND, Calif. World Airways, an obscure charter airline that became rich hauling soldiers and weapons to the Vietnam War, has suddenly shed its obscurity by the act of hauling refugees away from the war.

title: Barnes Problem For Nets
description: ST. LOUIS, April 12 We're up against it now, no question about it, said Rod Thorne, assistant coach of the New York Nets after their 113108 loss to St. Louisa last night had put them behind, two games to one, in the American Basketball Association playoffs. But that's when you find out what kind of people you are, right? How you react to adversity?

title: 3 Astronauts in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 13 (UPI)The three United States backup astronauts for July's joint SovietAmerican space flight arrived in Moscow today for additional training, The backup crew of Ronald E. Evans, Jack R. Lousma and Alan L. Bean Will be joined Tuesday by the Trime crew of Thomas P. Stafford, Donald K. Slayton and Vance D. Brand.

title: PAPER SAYS SCHOOL SEEKS NIXON PAPERS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) The president of the University of Southern California has met with former President Richard M. Nixon about the possibility that Mr. Nixon would donate his personal papers to the school, The Los Angeles Times reported in today's editions.

title: Suspect Charged, in Fire Fatal to a Bronx Man
description: A 43  year old Bronx man was arrested on charges of homicide and arson early today for allegedly setting a fatal fire in his apartment following a night of drinking with two friends, the police said.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Monday, April 14, 1975

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A study by the Regional Plan Association of 31 counties in the metropolitan area predicts continuing decline for the area unless urbanization of open space is curbed and more Federal funds are put into downtowns. The study, covering the area from Trenton to New Haven, said that median family income there had dropped from $10,900 in 1969 to $10,400 in 1973 and that factory jobs had declined 15 per cent between 1967 and 1972.

title: ABUSE OF AIRLIFT BY SAIGON IS SEEN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (UPI)Some of the Vietnamese children airlifted to the United States are sons and daughters of political and military officials, an official of a United States adoption agency said today.

description: The Byrne administration has introduced a bill that could save consumers millions of dollars in utility bills.

title: Article 4  No Title
Portugal's Bishops Differ With Military on Voting
description: LISBON, April, 13Tension mounted here today as reports circulated of a possible new attempt at a military coup and as the country's two strongest institutions, the armed forces and the Roman Catholic Church, disagreed over what voters should do in their first free election in close to half a century.

description: Communist Forces Press Drive to Capture Xuan Loc as the Fighting Intensifies

description: BLOOMSBURG, Pa., April 13 (AP)An order denying communion to members of NOW and other proabortion groups has been criticized by a national Catholic lay organization.

description: CAIRO, April 13President Anwar elSadat today accepted the resignation of Premier Abdel Aziz Hegazi.

title: Goldin Sees Budget Gap Greater Than Beame's
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that the deficit in the current expense budget would be considerably larger than the $120million that Mayor Beame anticipates will exist after his nearly six months of economies and curtailed city borrowing.

title: THIEU SAID TO TRY TO SEND OUT GOLD
description: South Vietnamese officials tried to ship $73million worth of gold bullion apparently belonging to President Nguyen Van Thieu and to Lon, Nol, the President of Cambodia  to Switzerland, Time magazine says in its current issue, which goes on sale today.

title: U.S. Setto Ban Cape Cod Nude Bathing
description: SOUTH WELLFLEET, Mass., April 13An end to nude bathing on all Cape Cod national seashore beaches appeared likely today.

title: Lobster Farming Called Answer to Short Supply
description: CEDAR BEACH, LI., April 13Early each day, Prof. Orville W. Terry secludes himself in a small laboratory in this lovely, isolated section of Long Island's North Fork and devises ways to feed lobsters more nutritiously so that they can multiply healthily in captivity.

title: Hardhat Realism
description: With the possible exception of auto manufacture, no industry has been as hardhit by the recession as construction. Yet, in the face of astronomic levels of unemployment among building tradesmen, unions in many areas have been pressing for wage increases so large that they act as jobkillers.

title: Unveilings
description: Jossen, Frank

title: League of Women Renews Battle for State Income Tax
description: MORRISTOWN, April 13The League of Women Voters debated at its state convention today a resolution opposing reinstitution of the death penalty in New Jersey.

title: Newcombe Pulls Out of Net Tourney
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. April 13 (UPI)John Newcombe withdrew today from the World Championship of Tennis tournament at Denver to ensure he would not meet Jimmy Connors before their $250,000 challenge match scheduled for April 26. The Denver tournament begins tomorrow.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: The Ecology Business
description: When Earth Day was first celebrated five years ago this month, the concepts of ecology burst upon the consciousness of the general public although they had long been familiar to specialists. Congress responded to this awakened public concern by passage of the National Environmental Policy Act, the Clean Air Act, the Water Pollution Act, and many lesser pieces of legislation.

title: Marilyn Smith Wed To Jerry Grossman
description: Marilyn Smith and Jerry Grossman were married yesterday evening at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle, N. Y. Rabbi Samuel Silver and the Rev. Peter Jacobs, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the nondenominational ceremoney.

title: Blacks and Jews Viewed As Drawing Closer Again
description: The declining economy and continued tension in the Middle East, have served in recent months to strengthen ties between blacks and Jews in the United States, according to community leaders.

title: ExMinister in India Ends WeekLong Fast
description: NEW DELHI, April 13 (AP) Former deputy Prime Minister Morarji Desai ended a weekold fast today after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi reluctantly agreed to his demand for early elections in his home state of Gujarat.

title: Kings Beat Bulls, Tie Series at 11
description: KANSAS CITY, April 13 (UPI)Larry McNeill, hitting all of 12 of his shots from the field, scored 28 points today and led the Kansas CityOmaha Kings to a 10295 victory over the Chicago Bulls, evening their fourofsevengame National. Basketball Association playoff series. The Western Conference semifinals is tied at 11.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1975

title: Andre Brassard's 'Once Upon a Time...'
description: Lise Pacquette, a waitress in Montreal's seedy East End, is very young, pretty and pregnant, but with no man in sight. When she tries to borrow money from the loan company to pay for an abortion, she explains that she wants a new stereo. Her application is turned down.Pierrette is older but equally unhappy. Her man has left her for a younger woman, so she drinks too much. Old Mme. Lauzon receives word that she has won a million trading stamps. At first she is skeptical and cross. Then she becomes almost unhinged with excitement.Hosanna, an aging transvestite who never successfully hides a five o'clock shadow, spends all day preparing for a drag ball where he'll appear as Cleopatra. Cuirette, Hosanna's roommate who fancies leather and chains, makes fun of Hosanna unmercifully.Everybody in "Once Upon a Time in the East" (II Etait une Fois Dans l'Est) dreams an impossible dream that is bound to come to no good end.More to the point of the film, everybody has a big scene, one of those front-and-center moments when he or she can attempt the movie equivalent of stopping the show. But movies, being movies, don't stop. Thus, would-be show-stopping moments tend to collect, to bunch up, like too many people trying to attract the attention of a single taxi on a rainy night.You've never seen as much acting as goes on from the start to the finish of Andr Brassard's French-Canadian film, which was screened Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, as part of the New Directors/New Films series, and will be screened there again tonight at 8:30."Once Upon a Time in the East," based on a screenplay by Michel Tremblay and Mr. Brassard, has its origins in plays written by Mr. Tremblay and staged with great success in Canada by Mr. Brassard. An English translation of one episode of this film was done on Broadway last fall under the title "Hosanna."Mr. Brassard and Mr. Tremblay have tried very hard to make a coherent film of all these actors doing what they do so well, but I, for one, could never forget that everyone was simply acting."Once Upon a Time in the East" has more busy moments than affecting ones. The characters all seem to be related to one another or, at least, to know one another, but there is very little sense of community in the movie. It's like a Broadway tribute of some sort, composed entirely of big moments from other shows.

title: 100,000 March Here Support of Soviet Jewry
description: Waving banners that read Let My People Go and Their Fight is our Fight, a crowd estimated by the police at 100,000 paraded yesterday and raised their voices here in a fourhour demonstration in support of Soviet Jews.

description: The second game of the National Hockey League playoff between the Islanders and Penguins tomorrow night will be telecast by WOR, Channel 9, at 8 P.M.

title: Woman Loses Grip On Rescuer in Fire And Falls to Death
description: A 61yearold woman fell to her death yesterday morning as she tried to escape from a burning fourstory Harlem apartment building by holding onto a fireman who was descending on a rope.

title: One High Spot Near Philadelphia Stands Out in State's Melting Ski Scene
description: PINE HILL, April 13New Jersey's multimilliondollar ski Industry did a booming business this past season in only one placea sandy South Jersey hill here within sight of the Philadelphia skyline.

title: Thieu Announces His New Cabinet; Pledges Offensive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Monday April 14President Nguyen Van Thieu named a new Cabinet today and said he planned an eventual counterattack to retake the twothirds of the country lost to the Communists.

title: Article 5  No Title
First TwinHeart Patient Dies Four Months After Operation
description: CAPE TOWN, April 13 (UPI) The world's first twinheart patient has died a little more than four months after Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard put the. second organ into his chest cavity, the South African radio said today.

title: President of Chad Is Killed During a Military TakeOver
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 13 Agence FrancePresse)  Soldiers stormed the Presidential Palace in Chad early today and killed the President in a coup d'tat.

description: The declining economy and continued tension in the Middle East have served in recent months to strengthen ties between blacks and Jews in the United States, according to community leaders.

description: The worldwide arms buildup, particularly in the Middle East, has brought boom times for United States exporters of arms.

title: The Cast
description: DON'T CRY WITH YOUR MOUTH FULL (Pleure Pas la Bouche Pleine), directed by Pascal Thomas; screenplay (French with English subtitles) by Mr. Thomas, Roland Duval and Suzanne Schiffman; director of photography, Christian Bachmann; executive producer, Claude Berri; editor, Helene Plernianikov; music, Michel Choquet; produced by Renn Productions and Les Films du CheflieuO.R.T.F.; released by New Yorker Films. Running time: 116 minutes. This film has not been classified. At the Paris Theater, 58th Street west of Fifth Avenue.

title: 5 Years of Vigils Rile Some in Bayside
description: With 75 policemen standing py, 150 followers of a woman who says she has had visions of the Virgin Mary gathered inside a Bayside Hills, Queens, church yesterday while 200 residents of the area met outside to discuss what they called the disruptive effects of the religious group's semiweekly vigils.

title: Utilities' Compliance With CleanAir Standards Proceeds Slowly
description: Athough Federal and state air quality standards, requiring reduced pollution at many of the nation's coalfired utility plants, have been in existence for nearly three years, fewer than half of the 100 power units on the Environmental Protection Agency's target list have taken major steps toward compliance.

title: Synagogue Torah Stolen
description: A Torah, bound in blue with gold engravings and valued at $1,000, was apparently stolen late Saturday from the Young Israel of the Rockaways Synagogue, 5204 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Arverne, Queens. Detectives investigated the apparent burglary yesterday, although the police said there were no signs of a forced entry.

title: Secret NonCommitment
description: Whether technically a commitment or technically secret, the assurances which former President Nixon gave Saigon as the Paris Vietnam accords were being concluded obviously misled President Thieu into expecting more military support than the Administration could deliver. The shiftiness of the transaction is underscored by the Administration's subsequent reticence on the subject even as Congress was unwittingly voiding those assurances seven months later.

title: Canadiens Victors Over Canucks 62
description: MONTREAL, April 13 (UPI)Guy LaPointe and Guy LaFleur each knocked in two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens took the opening game of their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series from the Vancouver Canucks, 62.

title: RITA STREICH SINGS FOR THE NEW WORLD
description: It was a coup for the Symphony of the New World to snare Rita Streich as soloist for yesterday afternoon's Viennese program at Avery Fisher Hall. The popular soprano of the Vienna Staatsoper made her American debut 18 years ago, but she has sung here very seldom of late. It was nice to have her. back, even if only for a pair of Mozart arias and three short operetta tunes.

title: McDonnell Douglas Pact Is Accepted by Machinists
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 (UPI)Machinists voted 2 to yesterday to accept a threeyear contract with McDonnell Douglas, ending a twomonth strike that affected employes in California and Florida.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 14Communist forces renewed their assault on Xuan Loc, a key provincial capital east of Saigon, yesterday while others shelled the Mekong Delta city of Can Tho in the heaviest fighting since the North Vietnamese offensive of 1972.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Wearers of Joy perfume have always been a sort of exclusive club. When one devotee meets another and goes through the cheekbrushing, kissintheair ritual, there's that delighted You're wearing Joy recognition of kindred souls. And since the house of Patou advertises the perfume as the costliest in the world, Its status goes beyond the fact that it smells good.

title: DOROTHY PATTEN, STAGE ACTRESS, 70
description: Dorothy Patten, an actress who appeared in 30 Broadway plays, several motion pictures and more than a dozen daytime television shows, died Friday at her home in Westhampton, L.I. Her age was 70.

description: Oscar Siffert, retired secretarytreasurer of the New York exportimport firm of Guiterman & Co., died yesterday at Somers N.Y. He was 88 years old.

description: Records of a federally financed program to train employes for privately owned nursing homes and hospitals here, have been seized by the office of Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor looking, into the nursinghome situation.

title: Children's Showboat May Float on City Waters by Year's End
description: By Christmas, David Hays expects a children's theater to float down the East River and to sail from borough to borough, making children laugh, stare, giggle and dream.

title: Lana Turner Stars at Town Hall In Films and Onstage Interview
description: Lana Turner was clearly nervous at Town Hall last night, undergoing a stage interview and later answering audience questions sent backstage earlier during a long, two  hour film compilation from her durable Hollywood career. Her fans just as obviously did not mind, having packed the house (with 35 balcony standees) for the first sellout of the inperson Legendary Ladies series produced by John Springer, who moderated the program on stage, seated alongside the actress.

title: 2 Charged With Arson
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP)Two men were charged today with arson in connection with a weekend fire near St. Luke's and Children's Medical Center that forced the evacuation of about 220 patients. The police said Eugene Williams, 67 years old, and Roy Martin, 63, had been using a cutting torch to remove steel rods from a vacant fourstory warehouse when sparks set something afire.

title: A Kidnapped Jeweler is Released in Rome
description: ROME, Monday, April 14 (AP)  Gianni Bulgari, an international jeweler who was kidnapped last month in Rome, was freed today, the police reported.

title: It Might Have Been
description: Following is the text of President Ford's address to a joint session of Congress, as recorded in an optimist's imagination:

title: The Cast
description: ALMA, directed by Zelito Wane; screenplay (Portuguese with English subtitles) by Mr. Viana, Eduardo Coutinho and Antonio Carlos de Birto, based on the novel Os Condenados by Oswald de Andrade; director of photography, Dib Luftl; editor, Eduardo Escorel; music, John Luciano Neschling; produced by Fadito Val Quintans and Alma Freire for Mane Films, Ltd. Running time: 90 minutes. At the Museum of Moden Art, 53d Street west of Fifth Avenue.

title: G.O.P. Gets Overtures On Buckley
description: As part of their bargaining with Republican leaders over bipartisan endorsements of local candidates this year, Conservative party leaders are drumming up support and even commitments among Republican county leaders to back Senator James L Buckley for nomination as a Republican as well as a Conservative next year.

title: Books of The Times
description: SNEAKY PEOPLE. By Thomas Berger. 315 pages: Simon and Schuster. $8.95.

title: U.S. Arms Exports Boom, Particularly to the Mideast
description: The worldwide arms buildup, particularly in the Middle East has brought boom times for United States exporters of arms.

title: Oil Talks
description: The preparatory meeting in Paris for a world conference of oilproducing and oilconsuming nations appears to have foundered on the fundamental issue that had divided the participants for a whole week.

title: Three Are Killed as an Auto Plunges Off Riverside Drive
description: An automobile traveling south on Riverside Drive went out of control last night darted across the northbonnd lane, plunged through a guard rail and fell 50 feet to a street below, killing the driver and two passengers, the police reported.

title: Savings Banks Are Pleased But Cautious on Big Inflow
description: Money is pouring Into the nation's savings banks and savings and loan associations in a record flooda development that pleases the bankers but leaves them cautious.

title: Garden to Pay for Knick and Ranger Failures
description: The fans on long lines at Madison Square Garden today will be getting money back, rather than paying it out.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
MENTAL HOSPITALS FOR CRIMINAL ONLY URGED BY MEROLA
description: The establishment of forensic hospitals for the segregation and treatment of mentally ill criminals and defendants in a secure setting was urged yesterday by. Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola, to correct a state system that he called a charade.

title: 4 Die of Smoke Inhalation In Montana Home for Aged
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., April 13 (AP)Fire officials said that four residents of a retirement home died last night in a fire that may have been touched off by a cigarette dropped into an overstuffed lounge chair.

title: Gerulaitis Wins First Tour Event
description: ST. LOUIS, April 13 (UPI) Vitas Gerulaitis, 20 years old, the youngest member of the World Championship Tennis blue group, won his first W.C.T. event today by beating Roscoe Tanner, 26, 62, 63, in the $60,000 St. Louis tournament.

title: Canadiens' Scoring
description: First. Period1, Montreal, Lapointe 1 (Risebrough), 9:02. 2, Montreal, Lapointe 2 (MahovIich, Lafleur), 12:17. 3, Vancouver, Bordeleau 1 (Oddleltson, Gould), 15:40. 4,. Vancouver, O'Flaherty 1 (Murray, Dailey), 17:26. PenaltiesRisebrough, Mtl, 2:09; Dailey, Van, 2:35; Grisdale, Van, 5:14; Grisdale, Van, 9:07; Vancouver bench, served by Boddy, 11:13; Lemaire, Mtl, 11:13; Grisdale, Van, 12:09; Oddleifson, Van, 16.15; Robinson, Mtl, 16:15.

title: MOYNIHAN CLARIFIES VIEWS ON LIBERALS
description: Daniel P. Moynihan, former Ambassador to India, said yesterday that he had not assailed the role of liberals in general in a Freedom House lecture reported in The New York Times yesterday. He said to the contrary it is that which was and is liberal in our foreign policy which most commands my regard.

title: Lady Lucy Russell Kills Self by Fire In a Churchyard
