description: Can a state that already imposes the highest combination of state and local taxes in the nation add another $850 million to the tax burden on its citizens in this recession year without driving more business away and thus further undermining its fiscal foundations?

title: No Success In Hunt For 4 Youths Lost In L.I.Boat Mishap
description: A daylong search for four Long Island teenagers who failed to return from a Sunday clamming expedition on the Great. South Bay ended in failure last night after search units found the battered remains of the youths' outboard motorboat washed ashore on Fire Island yesterday morning.

title: Stock Exchange Reform
description: Senate and House committees have moved with commendable speed to prepare the legislative underpinning for the most comprehensive reform of the nation's stock exchanges since the 1930's.

title: Gold Prices Drop As Dollar Gains In World Markets
description: BRUSSELS, April 14 (UPI)The price of gold dropped dramatically in Zurich and London today as the dollar continued to rise on most world money markets.

title: Dubcek: J'Accuse
description: To disregard the differences between countries endangers the party and the development of Socialism and the fate of the whole Socialist revolution. Underestimating or ignoring internal differences in the activity of the Communist party as the leading force in society after the victory of the working class leads inevitably to a gradual weakening of the party's influence on the masses, to a decline in initiative and initial enthusiasm, and mainly to a gradual loss of the voluntary spirit with which the masses launched the revolution and the building of Socialism.

title: COURT UNIT HEARS COSTANTINO CASE
description: Charges of wrongdoing were vehemently denied yesterday by Federal District Judge Mark A. Costantino at a special meeting of an administrative council of Federal judges here.

title: 60 Are Dispersed In ProRebel Rally After Clash Here
description: About 60 persons demonstrating in Times Square in sympathy with insurgents in Cambodia and South Vietnam were dispersed by the police last evening after scuffling broke out between the pickets and passersby, the police said.

title: NoFrills Service on Airlines Is Initiated, With Frills
description: MIAMI, April 14  At an altitude of 32,000 feet, they launched the Brown Bag Special today.

title: ARMY ACTS TO EASE MISSISSIPPI FLOOD
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 14The Army Corps of Engineers today began opening a giant relief gate upstream to reduce the Mississippi River's flood threat to this low delta city.

title: SAIGON AIDE ALLEGES KISSINGER ARMS VOW
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14 (AP)South Vietnam's Foreign Minister at the time of the 1973 Paris peace agreements says President Nguyen Van Thieu's Government agreed to sign only after Henry A. Kissinger promised that any North Vietnamese attack would be met by American military action.

title: 2 School Buses Collide
description: ST. LOUIS, April 14 (UPI)Two school buses collided on rainslicked streets in North St. Louis County today, injuring 56. persons. The authorities said the two bus drivers and children on both buses were hospitalized but none of the injuries appeared to be serious.

title: Memorial Service Held For the Titanic Victims
description: A memorial service for the 1,500 persons who died in the sinking of the Titanic was held yesterdaythe 63d anniversary of the disasteroff Grand Banks, Nfld., the site of the tragedy, aboard the Coast Guard cutter Evergreen.

title: Revenues Also Gain
Wood, Field and Stream: On Survival
description: At the risk of seeming callous oward the plight of certain endangered species, which I am not, I would like to suggest that in some of his efforts to protect these creatures man is ignoring the facts of life.

title: Unbeaten Ruffian Returns $2.20 For Triumphant Return to Races
description: The 19,575 fans at Aqueduct yesterday were treated to a splendid performance by the Locust Hill Farm's Ruffian, the champion filly who was making her first start of the year. The the winner of all five of her races as a 2  year  old last season, Ruffian continued unbeaten with a 4length success in the sixfurlong feature.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A bill permitting reinspection of motor vehicles at approved service stations was passed in the Assembly today. The vole was 48 to 17. The measure now goes to the Senate. It was proposed as a way of cutting down lines at the state's 38 motor vehicle stations, built to handle about three million of the 4.5 million vehicles they are handling now

title: Derailed M.T.A.
description: The desperate plight of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which cannot meet its bills, demands urgent action in Albany to reconcile divisions between Governor Carey and the Legislature and among the legislators themselves over the size and nature of new state transit operating assistance.

title: House Unit Opens Hearings on Draft Amnesty
description: WASHINGTON, April 14A House Judiciary subcommittee began hearings today on possible clemency for the remaining Vietnam war era draft evaders and deserters who did not participate in President Ford's conditional amnesty program that ended last month.

title: Notes on People
description: Pointing to stacks of telegrams and letters, San Diego's Roman Catholic Bishop, the Most Rev. Leo T. Maher, predicted yesterday that other Bishops and even Protestant church leaders would follow him in denying communion to members of the National Organization for Women and other proabortion groups.

title: Clyde Tolson, Former FBI. Official, Is Dead at 74
description: Clyde A. Tolson, former associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and, for more than 30 years the closest friend and associate of its director, J. Edgar Hoover, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital in Washington.

title: Sears Is Cutting Outlays
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest retail merchandiser, said yesterday in Chicago that its capital expenditures in 1975 would be in excess of $350million, compared with $411million in 1974. The company said it planned to open 36 new stores this year, including 18 in new markets. Last year, Sears opened 30 new stores.

title: William W. Garth Jr. Dies; Headed Graphic Arts Group
description: William W. Garth Jr., chairman of Compugraphic Corporation, makers of photocomposition a machines and other typesetting equipment in Wilmington, Mass., died Friday of cancer in a i nursing home in Concord, Mass. He was 59 years and lived in Concord.

title: MeatFree Meals for $1 Planned in Bryant Park
description: Four completely meatfree meals will be served at $1 each in Bryant Park from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. Thursday in keeping with a principle of helping the hungry and to encourage a reduction in the consumption of grainfed meat.

title: NURSING HOMES FACE PROFIT CURB
description: The State Health Department has decided to eliminate a practice that critics have charged permitted owners of nursing homes to collect millions of dollars a year in unjustified profits on real estate.

title: Swiss Confirm a Refusal To Fly Gold From Saigon
description: BASEL, Switzerland, April 14 (Reuters)The Swiss charter airline company Balair confirmed today that it had refused to fly 16 tons of gold out of Saigon.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday, April 14, 1975

title: NursingHome Runaway, 102, Backs Living Alone
description: When you get old, you can still live alone and like it in this city, even if you are 102 years old, are handicapped by cataracts in the eyes and have only $228 a month with which to pay your bills, Henry Jones testified yesterday.

title: WINNERS NAMED FOR BOOK PRIZES
description: The winners of the 26th National Book awards were announced at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday afternoon. Two of the prizes, Arts and Letters and Fiction, were given to two books each.

title: Photos Give a New Life to the Old West
description: BUFFALO, April 14History is a wonderful provider. In every generation, it yields up new heroes and new scenarios to meet the needs and aspirations of a new cuitural situation. In the visual arts, it even turns up new, or at least newly discovered, objects to satisfy a newly defined taste. It seems, at times, an inexhaustible cornucopia.

title: Market Place
description: It isn't easy for a businessman to get his point across. He has vested interests. When he expresses his point of view, he sounds like a businessman trying to preserve and even add to the interests he already has.

title: Peace Main Thing to Cambodians Here
description: Last Sunday was the first day of the New Year in Cambodia and the first day in six years that there was no official American presence there. For Prem Rudee, a 31yearold Cambodian student of political science at the New York Institute of Technology, who lives in Jackson Heights, it was a day of mixed emotions.

title: ThickSkinned Tomato Symbol of Consumer Discontent
description: Over the last few years the tomato has become a symbol for consumer groups of everything they find wrong with the American food supply. Today's supermarket tomato is a thickskinned mutant of its former juicy self, designed to be mass grown, mass shipped and mass marketed.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, April 14, 1975

title: FISCHER ACCEPTS OFFER BY KARPOV
description: Bobby Fischer, who gave up his world chess crown earlier this month because he could not get organized chess to change a rule, yesterday accepted an offer by his Russian successor, Anatoly Karpov, to meet and discuss the terms of a match between them.

title: NEW SOVIET OPERA DRAMATIZES WAR
description: MOSCOW, April 14  The Dawns, Are Quiet Here, a new opera with book and music by Kirill Molchanov, is an attempt to dramatize World War II in a way that is neither maudlin nor excessively patriotic and that has not already been tried a hundred times here, where the victory over Nazi Germany was a much more emotional event than it was in the United States.

title: Dow Up by 17.45 to 806.95; Increase Is Fifth Gain in Row
description: Increasing signs that the recession may be ending set off another sharp advance in stock prices yesterday.

title: Ashe Wins In S. Africa By 64, 61
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14 (AP)Arthur Ashe breezed to a 64, 61 victory over Derek Schroder of South Africa in the second round of a World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today. Prize money totals $60,000.

title: In Memoriam
description: LORBER Sallie and Adolf

title: 120mm.Cigarette Contest Grows
description: Last week, R.J. Reynolds announced it would go national yesterday with its More 120mm. Wand. Yesterday, Philip Morris announced it was going national yesterday with its competing Saratoga brand.

title: TREASURY ISSUES CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Prices of fixedinterest securities continued to improve yesterday in all sectors of the market. However, bond dealers said that trading was less spirited than late last week, when the latest rally started. Dealers in Treasury paper marked up prices of bills by about 12 basis points in anticipation of much lower yields on the weekly auctions held yesterday afternoon. A basis point is one onehundredth of a point.

title: Big Board Seat Price Off
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: FORD WILL STUDY FARM PRICE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 14President Ford promised today to give serious consideration before deciding whether to accept or reject a farm bill now nearing completion in a SenateHouse conference after reports that he had threatened a veto, Congressional Republican farm leaders said after a White House meeting.

title: Ban Sought on Concorde Flights Here
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Congressional opponents of the Concorde supersonic airliner told a Government hearing today they would assiduously seek passage of legislation to ban the plane from this country.

title: CURB ON ABORTION VOTED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, April 14  A highly controversial measure banning state Medicaid payments for abortions unless the life of the mother is in danger cleared the Legislature this evening with passage by the Assembly by a vote of 46 to 18.

title: NEW READING TEST FOR 680,000 TODAY
description: A new reading test will be given today to 680,000 city pupils amid tight security measures that are intended to prevent a recurrence of the irregularities that forced the Board of Education to abandon the previous test.

title: Democrats Here Diminish Power Over Judgeships
description: Democratic political leaders who once designated judges with little or no independent consultation are increasingly putting some reins on their own power by appointing independent panels to screen prospective judges.

title: Setback in Effort To Curb Malaria Brings a Warning
description: GENEVA, April 14 (AP)The World Health Organization said today that malaria, the largest single cause of death and debilitation was raging last year in several countries where eradication seemed imminent a few years ago. The organization warned that a further spread was likely.

title: About New York
description: When Arthur Ashe played Kenny Lindner in an exhibition match at Tennisport in Long Island City, Queens, last week, many spectators asked themselves and one another, Who is Kenny Lindner and why is Arthur Ashe playing him?

title: A BID BY HALDEMAN TO SIRICA REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) H. R. Haldeman's attorney sounded out United States District Court Judge John J. Sirica during the Watergate coverup trial about the possibility that the former White House aide might plead guilty, it was learned today.

title: Jean Morel, Conductor, 72, Dies; A Former Teacher at Juilliard
description: Jean Morel, a conductor who specialized in French music and who headed the Juilliard School's orchestral conducting department from 1949 to 1971, died Monday at his home, 515 East 89th Street, after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Daisianna Caffrey du Chaudrun, the heroine of Vincent Canby's novel, is one of those passively destructive females who are the darker, obverse side of the archetype of woman as creator and nurturer of life. She is a negligent Hedda Gabler, a negative magnetic pole who attracts, then harms. Her innocence exfoliates a poisonous fruit that men find alluring; she is rich, pretty, fey, and the men involved with her all end up badly. She incarnates the vapidity of evil, but evil is too strong a term for a woman with limbo for a soul. She is also psychotic; not certifiably so, just periodically, whenever the apparition she calls the Little Lord Jesus appears to tell her to do destructive things. Once when the Little Lord Jesus came he told Daisianna to throw chunks of concrete at Brooks Brothers' windows; another time, he told her to shoot a prowler, who turned out to be Charles, her husband. Her psychiatrist, Dr. Jack Mandelbaum, advised Charles that she was nutty as a fruitcake, yet manageable with ups and downs from his medical kit and with a sanctum to retreat to when the madness welled up. Jack Mandelbaum is the dedicated, chain smoking healer who runs Hickory Hollow, a rural funny farm; he likes Daisianna: She's gentle, sweet and fragile ... one of God's blessed creatures. He too is drawn into Daisianna's destructive ambit.

title: AMEX PRICE INDEX SHOWS GAIN AGAIN
description: The stock price index managed to eke out its sixth consecutive gain yesterday in active trading on the American Stock Exchange. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: President's Group Gets $569,000
description: Funds have been approved for the formation of The President's Commission on Olympic Sports, and a White House announcement on the subject may be issued by the end of the week, it was learned yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the photograph with yesterday's television schedule in The New York Times, Shirley MacLaine was shown with Mrs. Chou Enlai, wife of the Premier of China, not with the wife of Mao Tsetung.

title: Rat Elected by Students
description: EL PASO, April 15 (AP)University of TexasEl Paso students have elected a ham.ster to a Student Senate seat. The hamster, named Stripers, was run under the slogan the only candidate honest enough to admit he's a rat.

title: B.B.B. Unit Faults 10 Advertisers
description: An unusually high percentage of advertisers were found at fault in March by the National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, which faulted 10 of the 14 cases that came before it.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Advocates for the Arts, a national citizens' action group for the arts, yesterday filed suit in the United States District Court in Concord, N. H., to enjoin and restrain the Governor and Executive Council of the state from interfering with a $750 grant previously made to Granite, a literary magazine, after approval of the grant by the New Hampshire Commission the Arts.

title: Suit Against Steel Concern By Paralyzed Boy Opens
description: Newark, April 15 (UPI)A New York steel company and a Brooklyn truck driver went on traial today in a $6million civil case brought by a 9yearold boy, paralyzed two years ago when a steel Ibeam was dropped from a truck on top of him.

title: Frustrations of Oil Conference
description: The first conference in Paris of oilexporting and oilimporting countries, which was supposed to have set the agenda and improved the atmosphere for a world energy conference next summer, has got nowhere. Instead, by over running its intended time limits it was well into its second week when it adjourned yesterdayand by polarizing the differences among participants, it has served to dramatize the radical conflicts (hat exist within the nonCommunist world over two critical issues:

title: Indonesian Authorities Free Head of Asian Press Group
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 15 (AP)Mochtar Lubis, president of the Press Foundation of Asia, who was arrested in February on charges of subversion, was released from detention today after authorities failed to link him with anti Government riots in January, 1974.

title: VW SETS CUTBACK OF 25,000 PERSONS
description: NECKARSULM, West Germany, April 15West Germany's giant Volkswagen auto company announced today it would, cut the number of its employes by 25.000 to a total of 107,000 during the next 18 months, including 4,700 workers in this small industrial town 40 miles north of Stuttgart.

title: SSSSSsssssssssst
description: WASHINGTON It is perhaps to be expected that the United States Federal Aviation Administration's proposal that the BritishFrench supersonic Concorde enter limited commercial service early next year at New York and Washington should have attracted criticism.

title: Kennedy Center Sets 10 American Plays
description: WASHINGTON, April 15A series of 10 American plays, mostly classics, will be presented at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here during the 197576 season through the sponsorship of the Xerox Corporation, Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the center, announced today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Winfield Anderson of Camden was indicted by a Camden County grand jury for firstdegree murder in the death of twin fetuses and for shooting their mother in the abdomen during a robbery at her house. The mother, Nicki Spearman, was more than seven months' pregnant. About an hour after the shooting, the twins were delivered by Cesaerean section at Cooper Hospital. Both died within hours after delivery. The mother recovered.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A jaguarundi, a llama, a kinkajou and a bobcat were among 90 surplus animals from the city's three zoos put on the auction block. Neither the animals nor the bidders attended the auction. Instead, 45 formal bids came in sealed envelopes from zoos, kennels and pet shops.

title: SADAT ANNOUNCES A NEW GOVERNMENT
description: CAIRO, Wednesday, April 16 (AP)President Anwar elSadat formed a new Government early today and in a surprise move, lie chose Air Marshal Husni Mubarak to he Vice President.

title: DEATHS NEAR 100 IN BEIRUT BATTLE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15Gunfire, rockets and bombs took a deadly toll here today as Palestinian guerrillas battled for the third day with the rightwing Phalangist party's armed militia.

title: Connally Admits Memory Flaw; Case May Co to the Jury Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The defense rested its case today in the bribery trial of John B. Connally after the former Secretary of the Treasury conceded that his memory was flawed, but insisted that he had never accepted a $10,000 payoff.

title: 2,500 Historians Gather For 68th Annual Parley
description: BOSTON, April 15  More than 2,500 college and university teachers of United States history gathered here today for the 68th annual meeting of the Organization bf American Historians, which opens tomorrow and lasts through Saturday.

title: In Novel S.I. Program, Learning Doesn't End
description: Michael Mack is a senior at a Catholic high school who for the last two years has been taking courses for credit at Staten Island Community College. His mother, a licensed practical nurse, has from time to time brushed shoulders with him on the bustling campus on her way to night courses that she is taking toward a registerednurse degree.

title: Reluctant Miss Evert Is Wooed by W.T.T.
description: World Team Tennis, which has scored many aces, except where they count most (at the box office), is convinced that Chris Evert Will end her ??dout and join the league after she defends her Wimbledon title early in July. If Ohris sings, will Jimmy Connors be far behind?

title: No TaxDeadline Panic
description: NEWARK, April 15 (UPI)There were a few frantic calls for help from the 5,000 New Jersey residents who had waited for the last day to file tax returns, but crowds were generally light today at Intrenal Revenue Service offices in the state.

title: TV Review
description: The IrishAmerican past and the AsianAmerican present are explored in two dramas this evening. The Unwanted, being presented on WNEW/Channel 5 at 7:30, deals with an attempt in the eighteenforties to smuggle destitute Irish immigrants from Canada into the United States. The Year of the Dragon, on Channel 13 at 9, goes into the emotionally charged apartment of a family living in San Francisco's Chinatown.

title: BELL ISSUE GIVEN STRONG RECEPTION
description: The $300million offering of South Central Bell Telephone, rated tripleA and serving as this week's keynote new issue in the corporate bona market, moved out successfully to buyers yesterday. Underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch reported that both the $100million of eight  year notes and the $200million of 35year debentures were at least 95 per cent sold.

title: Old Opera House Played Many Parts
description: It opened tumultuously Dec. 3, 1906, as the Manhattan Opera Housean Oscar Hammerstein creation that he hoped would do something that he could look on with pride and that would compete with the Metropolitan Opera.

title: ... For People in Need
description: America's sincerity in providing humanitarian relief to Indochina's war victims can best be conveyed by assuring that aid is available to persons in need, regardless of the political jurisdiction in which they have been cast. Food and medical care will be as essential in the areas of South Vietnam controlled by the Provisional Revolutionary Government as in the Saigon area and Mekong Delta still under. President Thieu's authority.

title: National Assembly Dissolved in Laos; Election in Doubt
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 15 (Reuters) King Savang Vatthana has signed a decree dissolving the predominantly rightwing National Assembly as of April 10, the national radio announced today.

title: Airline Head Assails End Of His Cambodia Race Lift
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Edward J. Daly, the controversial president of World Airways, is in a dispute again with the United States Government this time over termination of his contract to fly relief missions in Indochina.

title: About New York
description: When Arthur Ashe played Kenny Lindner in an exhibition match at Tennisport in Long Island City, Queens, last week, many spectators asked themselves and one another, Who is Kenny Lindner and why is Arthur Ashe playing him?

title: Cambodia and Vietnam...
description: When Premier Long Boret rejected the invitation of the departing Americans to fly with them to safety, he proudly stated that he would rather starve to death with his Cambodian countrymen than leave his country. Since then, continuing to display an admirable sense of duty, the head of the embattled nation that has shrunk to the mere enclave of Phnom Penh itself, has offered resign in return for nothing more than the prior assurance of a ceasefire and negotiations. The only response for the United States and other nations is to do everything possibleif anything is still possibleto encourage a negotiated end to the bloodshed in Cambodia.

title: Things Are Tough All Over, Yogi
description: Why did the Mets trade Tug McGraw away? one fan asked, posing a question which that lefthanded deity asked himself last December. Before anybody else could answer, another fan spoke up: To make us forget that they traded Nolan Ryan away. The resentment in his tone seemed unusually sharp for this early in the season. Ordinarily it takes more than five games to erode the optimism built up between seasons, even when four of the five games are lost. Evidently the clients are finding this year's defeats especially hard to take because the games have been lost in the late innings, calling attention to the poverty in Yogi Berra's bull pen. To be sure, McGraw hasn't yet thrown a ball on behalf of the Phillies and couldn't have given the Mets more than moral support, but if he were still wearing New York regimentals the fans could tell themselves that things would be better as soon as the Tugger got back. Now there seems to be a widespread feeling that trying to improve a fifthplace team by disposing of the star relief pitcher is like shooting a dog to rid him of fleas.

title: Cops, Crime and Fashion: Unended Tale of Intrigue
description: In the next few days, before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan, a onetime Brooklyn insurance broker named Herman Goldfarb is expected to unfold the story of Project Cleveland one of the most imaginative, expensive and dangerous criminal investigations ever mounted in New York City.

title: ... Action on Tolls
description: Ironically, one of the most promising steps toward sane transportation system for New York has just been taken by the Port Authority independently of the Federal Government's clean air enforcement orders. The authority's decision to raise bridge and tunnel tolls carries out a proposal that was included in the original Transportation Control Plan but which was dropped some time ago at the insistence of state officials.

title: For the Architect, New York Is Home
description: Somehow, in spite of the fact that the building business is in a genuine depression in New York, none of the New Yorkbased architecture firms seem to have given a thought to moving away. Many of them are doing most of their buildings elsewhere, of course I. M. Pei, for example, has done more work in Boston than in New York for years nowbut this remains the city in which most architects want to be based, even if it means putting up with inordinate amounts of time on airplanes going to and from the places where their buildings are actually going up.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EAST IN WEST As spring burgeons, so do local activities of traditional Oriental Culture, rooted in soil, theater and art. Starting this afternoon, a fourday festival will highlight the 60yearold Japanese Garden's seasonal reopening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington AVenue, at 1:30 o'clock by Nobuyuki Nakashima, Consul General of Japan in New York. A commemorative program of music and dance (admission $1) will follow at 2 P.M., with awards presented to Brooklyn high school students who entered a writing contest in haiku poetry. A general display of the classical haiku will also be set up along garden paths. Starting at 2 P.M. tomorrow, four films on Japanese gardening will be shown in the auditorium (admission $1). A free program of haiku poetry reading is scheduled for 5 P.M. On Friday, beginning at 10:30 A.M., demonstrations will be given in tree care and flower arranging ($1 admission to each program). Free guided tours of the garden will leave on the halfhour on Saturday. The garden entrance fee is 10 cents. For further information: 6224433.

title: Coast Murder Trial Opens For Two Members of S.L.A.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 15 (AP)Robert Blackburn, the prosecution's only witness to the slaying of Marcus Foster, the Oakland School Superintendent, took the stand today in the murder trial of two members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army, but was unable to say who the attackers were.

title: Quarter Sales Up 1%
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that its net income fell 45.7 per cent in the first quarter of 1975 from the 1974 level.

title: PROFITS UP 21% AT BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterday that firstquarter earnings increased a substantial 21 per cent, typical of gains at large moneycenter banking concerns for the first three months of this year.

title: RAYMOND V. BOVETT, TENNIS OFFICIAL, 54
description: Raymond V. Bovett, executive director of the United States Professional Tennis Association, died here Monday night at the age of 54.

title: MORE TV TIME SET FOR JERSEY NEWS
description: TRENTON, April 15  The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting announced today that it had withdrawn its challenges to the license renewals of four New York television stations after getting pledges that they would improve their news and publicaffairs coverage of the state and to devote more air time to it.

title: Students Assume Leadership of Seminar on Economy
description: Bring together 78 high school sophomores from around the country for a week of seminars in New York and before long leaders emerge and the group begins to mold itself into a selfgoverning unit.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Mets Obtain Reds' Hall For Relief
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 With their bull pen awash under flood waters and Manager Yogi Berra clutching at the roof of the barn, the Mets made a deal today with the Cincinnati Reds in an effort to obtain relief. The Mets acquired the services of Tom Hall, a skinny lefthanded relief pitcher, in a straight player transaction for Mac Scarce, who had pitched one inning for the Mets this season.

title: Just As It Was Back in 1900 Sausage Without Additives
description: We first heard of Faicco's pork store in Greenwich Village about 2 years ago.

title: TV License Challenges Are Withdrawn On Promises of More Jersey Coverage
description: TRENTON, April 15  The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting announced today that it had withdrawn its challenges to the license renewals of tour New York television stations after getting pledges that they would improve their news and publicaffairs coverage of the state and to devote more air time to it.

title: Dow Average Climbs 8.13 As Traders See Recovery
description: The stock market kept its latest rally going yesterday as prices advanced again in heavier trading.

title: Brazilian City Growing, but in Scale
description: CURITIBA, BrazilA few years ago this rapidly expanding city was faced with the prospect of becoming a metropolis, with all the problems of urban growth slums, pollution, traffic jams and the extinction of green areas.

title: For Urges Congress and the People to Join in a Vow to Keep the Nation Strong
description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Ford urged Congress and the American people today to join him in a pledge to prevent the world military balance from shifting against the United States, saying, Our survival as a nation could well depend on it.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Seoul Regime Is Urged to Avoid a War Crisis Mood
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 15The leader of South Korea's main Opposition party, Kim Young Sam, urged the Government today not to create a wartime crisis mood as a means of suppressing domestic political dissent.

title: BOOK CRITICS PLAN 4 ANNUAL AWARDS
description: After sharp debate, the National Book Critics Circle, at its first annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday afternoon, confirmed by hand vote the decision of its advisory board Nov. 15 to establish four annual literary awards: for fiction, poetry, general nonfiction and criticism. The awards will be made in January for books published the previous year.

title: CAREY WELCOMES U.S. ROLE ON ATTICA
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he would welcome the participation of United States Attorney General Edward H. Levi in the investigation of the Attica prosecution.

title: Authority Delays Action On Battery Park Housing
description: ALBANY, April 15The Battery Park City Authority, which is charged with building a vast complex of housing, offices and civic facilities on the southwestern shore of Manhattan, has been forced to rethink plans to borrow $80million for its first housing package, officials said today.

title: Effect Will Be Delayed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 16A United States Embassy spokesman here said today that it would be at least three or four days before the effect was felt from the order to reduce the number of Americans in South Vietnam to 1,000.

title: ANCHOR HOCKING SEEKING AMEROCK
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that the Stanley Works, a producer of hardware in New Britain, Conn., had asked for permission to sell its Amerock subsidiary to the Anchor Hocking Corporation; for $32  million. Stanley Works has been under and F.T.C. order since 1973 to divest itself of Amerock.

title: HOUSE APPROVES 5BILLION FOR IDLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The House approved today catchall $12billion supplemental appropriations bill that includes $5billion for jobless workers receiving Federal and state unemployment compensation.

title: Thousands Mob Funeral of Josephine Baker in Paris
description: PARIS, April 15  Thousands of admirers mobbed the funeral here today for Josephine Baker, the Americanborn entertainer who captivated France 50 years ago. She died of a stroke Saturday at the age of 68 after a triumphant musichall comeback here.

title: SICILIAN IS FREED FOR HIGH RANSOM
description: ROME, April 15  Sicilian kidnapers today released a 23yearold wine expert after holding him for ransom for more than seven months.

title: Clean Air Mandate ...
description: After nearly two years of obstruction by city and state officials and procrastination in Washington, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has finally moved fulfill its mandate to help clean up New York City's a polluted air.

title: Two Men Accused Of Failing to Report $2.4Million Income
description: NEWARK, April 15  Two businessmen were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of failing to report $2,439,525 in personal income that they allegedly had diverted from a preciousmetals company.

title: FORD VOWS TO WIN PRESIDENCY IN '76
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 President Ford told a Republican fundraising dinner tonight that he does not see an unbeatable Democrat among the men who hope to run against him next year.

title: SIHANOUK PLEDGES DEMOCRATIC RULE
description: PEKING, April 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian leader, said here today that the government that would be installed in Phnom Penh after victory of the insurgents would be nonaligned, democratic and progressive, not Communist.

title: Iran's Exports of Crude Oil Showed a Decline in March
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 15 iAP) Iranian eiports of crude oil dropped by half a million barrels a day in Marci because of reduced demand, the National Iranian Oil Company announcad today.

title: FORD PRESS AIDE CHOSEN IN SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The White House press office was shuffled today with the announcement that William I. Greener, a veteran Govemment public information officer, has been appointed deputy press secretary to the President.

title: ICI America Is Expanding
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Ajril 15 (UPI)  ICI America, Inc., a subsidiary of Britain's Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., said today it would build a $70milion plant at Bayport, Tex., to make paraquat herbicides for the farming industry. The M.W. Kellogg division of Pullman, Inc., will be the general contractor.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Cambodian insurgents, closing in on Phnom Penh from most directions, reached the southern edge of the city. Heavy fighting was in progress as Government forces were brought back from the outer perimeter. The American Embassy pullout was apparently the signal for the, new insurgent drive. Refugees poured into the capital. The Government was still vowing to fight to the last man but its defenses appeared to be falling apart. [Page 1, Columns 58.]

title: Fur Flies at Chrysler Annual Meeting
description: CENTER LINE, Mich., April 15The top executives of the Chrysler Corporation faced unrelenting questioning about their policies and abilities from the 610 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: Cops, Crime and Fashion: Unended Tale of Intrigue
description: In the next few days, before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan, a onetime Brooklyn insurance broker named Herman Goldfarb is expected to unfold the story of Project Cleveland one of the most imaginative, expensive and dangerous criminal investigations ever mounted in New York City.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLIMB IN CHICAGO
description: Continued withholding by farmers of soybeans from the market pushed bean futures prices up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: JUSTICES VOID LAW ON MAJORITY AGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Supreme Court served notice today that it would strike down as unconstitutional any state law that treats men and women differently unless the Justices can find some rational basis for the distinction.

title: INQUIRY POSTPONED IN HEARST HUNT CASE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 15 (UPI)A Federal grand jury investigation into the possible harboring of Patricia Hearst in a Pennsylvania farmhouse was postponed indefinitely today.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Phoenix vs. Quebec

title: A Base for African Negotiations
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 15Efforts by whiteruled South Africa and a few black African states to promote a peaceful settlement of the Rhodesian problem and other southern African issues are still far from success, but have laid a valuable preparatory base. Last week the pragmatic black nations in the front line won a mandate from the rest of black Africa to continue the effort  and to continue limited contact with South Africa.

title: Bridge:
description: When a deal presents no particular problems in play, it is usually easy to inspect a pair of partnership hands and discover the most desirable contract. But usually is not always, as the diagramed deal suggests. What contract would you select, looking only at the NorthSouth hands?

title: Concert
description: One of the first Bicentennial music projects has originated not with a musical organization but with the J. C. Penney Company, the store chain. Under the guidance of professional musicians, the company has packaged 35 scores100 minutes in playing timefor presentation to 30,000 schools throughout the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: CITY BUDGET CUT 100MILLION MORE; NEW LAYOFFS DUE
description: Mayor Beame and Budget Director Melvin N. Lechner have sheared more than $100million from what they had projected as an $883.9million deficit for the 197576 expense budget. They have also made tentative plans, for more layoffs of city workers, perhaps as many as 10,000, officials in the administration said yesterday.

title: Minority Hiring Here Checked by U.S.
description: Department of Labor inspectors have begun unannounced visits to about 90 federally financed construction sites here to determine if contractors are abiding by Federal regulations requiring the hiring of minorities in construction trades.

title: Contract Award
description: Braniff International, Inc., which owns all the stock Braniff Airways, said yesterday it had purchased eight Boeing 727200 jet airplanes from the Boeing Company with widebody interiors for delivery in 1976 and 1977.

title: Four Children Drowned Fishing With Parents
description: GENEVA, N.Y., April 15. (UPI)Four young children drowned in Seneca Lake this afternoon as they were out fishing with their parents in a rowboat.

title: NET UP BY 3282% Al MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., the parent company of the nation's largest brokerage house, reported yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter were 328.2 per cent above the 1974 level.

title: Republic Steel Earnings Soared By 56.7% for the First Quarter
description: The Republic Steel Corporation got off to a fast start this year with net income soaring 56.7 per cent over the first quarter of 1974. Sales were up 15 per cent.

title: Scenes as U.S. Embassy In Phnom Penh Closed
description: These pictures of United States marines evacuating Americans from Phnom Penh last Saturday were sent out of the beleaguered city by Sydney H. Schanberg, New York Times correspondent who remained behind. The pictures, by Dith Prang New York Times Cambodian reporter and photographer, and Ennio Iacobucci, a freelance photographer, came out aboard, the last plane to leave the city.

title: Food Day Activities
description: Tomorrow is Food Day, a national day of action and education on food problems ranging from world hunger to local supermarket prices. Sponsored by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a nonprofit organization based in Washington, Food Day will be marked by lectures and teachins by feasts and fasts.

title: BIEN HOA IS TARGET
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 16Communist gunners shelled South Vietnam's largest fighter base at Bien Hoa, 15 miles from Saigon, with longrange artillery yesterday amid indications that the North Vietnamese were moving three more divisions into the battle for Saigon.

title: Daly Reads His Message
description: TOKYO, April 15 (UPI)Edward J. Daly, president of World Airways, read today a telegram he said he had drafted to President Ford urging him to cut red tape and help people escape Saigon. The message read:

title: Fragments Studied By Police and F.B.I. In Rembrandt Theft
description: BOSTON, April 15 (AP)The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation studied four fragments of a frame and some other evidence today in their investigation into the theft at gunpoint yesterday of a Rembrandt painting valued at $500,000 from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Donovan, at Knicks' Helm, Looking for Hawks' Trade
description: An hour after the Knicks had officially announced that Eddie Donovan was their new general manager, he walked into his hurriedly prepared office and picked up the telephone.

title: Wage Law Violations Are Found to Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 15(UPI)The Labor Department has reported that enforcement of wage and hour and antidiscrimination standards indicated that 350,540 workers were cheated out of nearly $82million during the nine months that ended March 31.

title: EAST HAVEN SCHOOLS ORDERED TO REOPEN
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15 A Superior Court judge today ordered the East Haven Board of Education to reopen the town's public schools tomorrow, and directed the town government to borrow funds to cover a protected 333,036 deficit.

title: State Use of Energy Seen Still Falling
description: A state forecast estimated yesterday that the total energy use in the state would decline this year almost to 1968 levels, mostly because of the continuing economic recession but also in part because of consumer conservation and resistance to higher costs.

title: Notes on People
description: Despite a flareup of controversy, the annual Israel Prize will be awarded to Golda Meir todayon the nation's independence dayfor her lifetime work.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Wednesday, April 16. 1975

title: Pullout of 5,000 to Leave 1,000 Americans in Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States Embassy in Saigon had been ordered to reduce the number of Americans remaining in South Vietnam to a mini mum level. Administration and Congressional sources said the objective was to reduce the number, which until recently had totaled more than 6,000, to 1,000 or less within two weeks.

title: Prosecutor at the Connally Trial
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The prosecution does not rest at the bribery trial of John B. Connally. It seems instead to fret.

title: Richard Conte, Actor, 59, Dies; Played Gangster and Hero Roles
description: Richard Conte, who attained Hollywood stardom portraying gangsters and worldweary heroes, died yesterday in Los Angeles as the result of a heart attack and paralyzing stroke. He was 59 years old and had been in intensive care for 13 days at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center.

title: CAREY REQUESTED TO BACK A $2 TOLL
description: Robert N. Rickles, executive director of the Institute for Public Transportation, urged Governor Carey yesterday to insist on automobile tolls of $2 a round trip at the six bridges and tunnels operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: People in Sports
description: Two assistants to Bobby Knight of Indiana, College basketball coach of the year, were named to head coaching assignments yesterday. They are Michael Krzyzewski, who goes to Army, and Dave Bliss, who will guide Oklahoma. Krzyzewski, 28 years old, succeeds Dan Dougherty, and Bliss, 31, takes over from Joe Ramsey. The new Army mentor was captain of the 196869 Cadets, who placed fourth in the National Invitation Tournament. In making the announcement of Krzyzewski's appointment, Col. Jack Schuder, director of athletics, said, We are very pleased that Mike has accepted the position and we are looking forward to a resurgence of Army basketball under his leadership.

title: Pullout of 5,000 to Leave 1,000 Americans in Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States Embassy in Saigon had been ordered to reduce the number of Americans remaining in South Vietnam to a minimum level. Administration and Congressional sources said the objective was to reduce the number, which until recently had totaled more than 6,000, to 1,000 or less within two weeks.

title: WINE ACCORD BRINGS VIOLENCE IN FRANCE
description: NARBONNE, France, April 15 (AP)French farmers, enraged at a Common Market agreement in the wine dispute between France and Italy, blocked all major road and rail routes in the South of the wintry today, seized an airport and set fire to tax offices.

title: Paterson Mayor Cleared Of ElectionFund Charge
description: TRENTON, April 15Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson was cleared today by the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission of charges that he had illegally diverted about $9,000 in campaign contributions to two City Council candidates to avoid exceeding the state ceiling on campaign expenses.

title: Concert: 18thCentury Entertainments
description: The 20th century can claim to be advanced in certain respects, but it is difficult to be condescending to the 18th century in the matter of dinner music. Where we have the pipedin tranquilizer known as mood music, the diners of the 18th century had Mozart's divertimentosor some did, anyway.

title: Rockefeller in Taiwan Avoids Mention of Security Treaty
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 15Vice President Rockefeller was noticeably restrained in expressing American support for the Chinese Nationalist Government today as he arrived here to attend the funeral of President Chiang Kaishek.

title: For Urges Congress and the People to Join in a Vow to Keep the Nation Strong
description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Ford urged Congress, and the American people today, to join him in a pledge to prevent the world military balance from shifting against the United States, saying, Our survival as a nation could well depend on it.

title: W.F.L. Luring Namath
description: The World Football League, which wound up its first season last year almost $10million in debt, has offered Joe Namath a longterm, $4million contract to join the Chicago entry for the 1975 season.

title: XEROX EARNINGS UP 5.4% TO RECORD
Nets Are Eliminated
description: The New York Nets, defending American Basketball Association champions, lost their fourth of five playoff games to the Spirits of St. Louis, 108107, last night and were eliminated in the quarterfinal round. Page 47.

title: Students at Brown U. Strike Over Budget
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 15Students at Brown University began a strike this morning to protest proposed budget cuts and university budgetmaking policies.

title: Majority at Hearing in Chicago Urges Congress to Ban Pistols
description: CHICAGO, April 15Sheriffs doctors, businessmen, politicians, judges and representatives of civil rights and citizens groups urged a Congressional subcommittee yesterday and today to pass legislation banning the manufacture, sale and possession or pistols by civilians.

title: Penguins Defeat Islanders
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15 Denis Potvin clasped his hands as though he were holding the handle of a switchblade. Its just like taking a knife right here, he said, touching the imaginary point to the inside of his left knee, and slicing up the leg to here. He stopped at the top of his thigh.

title: The Realists
description: Maybe we expect too much of April. It has a green sound to it, and sunlight in its vowels. It has at least a hint of early morning birdsong in the soft rippling of its name. We don't want to be shivering in April.

title: APRIL 110 SALES OF CARS OFF 29%
description: DETROIT, April 15Domestic newcar sales during April 110 were down 29.2 per cent from the yearearlier level and were the lowest for the period in 14 years.

title: Lucille Miner, 65, Is Dead; L.I. Hospital Administrator
description: Lucille L'Ecuyer Miner, administrator of the Manhasset Medical Center Hospital, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital, Port Washington, L. I., of injuries received Monday evening in an automobile accident in Roslyn, L. I. She was 65 years old.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: New national beefgrading standards, temporarily delayed because of a court suit in Omaha brought by eight consumer groups, have been widely attacked because they include some beef formerly graded as Good in the higher and more expensive Choice grade.

title: Theater: 2 by Shepard
description: Sam Shepard is a playwright of the apocalypse. So often in his plays something terrible has happened, or is about to happen. So often his characters are mythic figures, be they rock stars, cowboys or navigators, in a cold landscape of death, or merely locked in lunar belt just off the contemporary world. As one of the characters says in his new double bill, which opened at the American Place Theater last night, this is a world of no sound, no time, just a cold space.

title: A Libretto by Fry For Paradise Lost
description: Christopher Fry is writing a libretto based on Milton's Parodist Lose for the opera Krzysztof Penderecki is composing for the Chicago Lyric Opera. The work is to be given its premiere during the company's 1976 season.

title: Britain Increases Taxes, Assails Unions' Demands
description: LONDON, April 15The British Government announced broadly distributed tax increases today and promised future spending cuts in a strenuous effort to curb Britain's inflation and revive her prosperity.

title: OnceQuiet Saudi Port on Red Sea Now Bustles With Foreign Workers
description: JIDDA, Saudi Atabia, April 9Everything was hushed, strained, even furtive, T.E. Lawrence, the British adventurer, known as Lawrence of Arabia, wrote after a tour of this sultry Red Sea port more than 40 years ago. The doors of houses shut softly as we passed; there were few wayfarers of any kind.

title: Marjorie Stinson Is Dead at 79; Flier Held Pilot's License No. 9
description: Marjorie Stinson, one of the country's first aviators, who was issued pilot's' license No. 9 in 1914, died yesterday in Rogers Memorial Hospital, Washington. She was 79 years old.

title: Witness Links Crabiel To BidRigging on Roads
description: ELIZABETH, April 15The vice president of a building materials and construction company testified in Superior Court here today that as late as 1967 he had participated in a bidrigging and pricefixing conspiracy that included the New Jersey Secretary of State, J. Edward Crabiel.

title: Mary Ure's Death Ruled An Accidental Overdose
description: LONDON, April 15 (AP)Mary Ure, the British actress who was found dead April 3 after opening in a play called The Exorcism, died accidentally from a mixture of drink and drugs, a coroner's court ruled today.

title: PARIS TALKS FAIL ON ENERGY AGENDA
description: PARIS, April 15  A preparatory meeting for an international energy conference this summer broke down on its ninth day today when 10 delegations from developed and developing countries decided they could not agree on the agenda and other terms for the proposed Conference.

title: SARAH H. SWIFT, 85, DOG BREEDER, DIES
description: Sarah Howard Swift, a breeder of Dandie Dinmont terriers and a former social worker, died yesterday in her home in Bedford Village, N.Y. She was 85 years old.

title: IDS Realty Lowers Earnings Forecast
description: IDS Realty Trust, whose investment adviser is IDS Realty Services, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the Minneapolisbased mutual fund and insurance underwriting concern, announced yesterday that it appears likely that its audited results for the fiscal year to Jan. 31, 1975, will reflect an approximate breakeven level of operations loss.

title: This Song and Dance Routine Is Really a Class in Anatomy
description: His father Is Herbert Burstein, a prominent labor relations lawyer. His mother is Beatrice Burstein, a judge of the New York State Supreme Court. His sister is Karen Burstein, a State Senator from Nassau County.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The U.S. and South Vietnam: After President Ford's Address

title: State House Cafeteria Fined for Sanitation
description: TRENTON, April 15 (AP) The State House Cafeteria, probably the most popular lunchtime eating place in downtown Trenton, has been fined $400 by the state for unsanitary conditions.

title: NEW OFFICE VOTED FOR THE RETARDED
description: ALBANY, April 15The Assembly today gave final legislative passage to a bill that strips the Department of Mental Hygiene of the care of the mentally retarded and sets up a special Office for Mental Retardation in the executive branch.

title: MORGAN R. SEIFFERT, JERSEY LAWYER, 72
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N, J., April 15Morgan R. Seiffert, lawyer, who was credited with being largely responsible for preserving the Delaware and Raritan Canal from destruction and achieving its designation as a historical landmark, died yesterday in Princeton Medical Center. He was 72 years old.

title: Strike Shuts Paris Papers
description: PARIS, April 15There were no newspapers today in Paris as a result of a 24hour printers' strike. The printers were protesting threatened layoffs of 800 men at two Paris masscirculation dailies, Le Parisien Libr and FranceSoir, and of 380 at two major printing plants.

title: 2 AGENCIES SCAN CAREY 1974 FUND
description: ALBANY, April 15  The State Board of Elections and the St. Lawrence County District Attorney have begun a joint investigation into charges that funds of the CareyforGovernor campaign were used to finance underhanded campaign tactics against Governor Malcolm Wilson.

title: Dynamite Seller Says He Gave Tip on School Blasts
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 15  A man who unwittingly supplied explosives to protesters accused of conspiring to bomb schools in a dispute over textbooks here testified today that he had notified the authorities when he learned of the scheme.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 16, 1975

title: City Auctions 90 Surplus Zoo Animals
description: A jaguarundi, a llama, a kinkajou and a bobcat were among 90 surplus animals from the city's three zoos put on the auction block yesterday.

title: Idabo Town Charmed By Movie Company
description: MYRTLE, Idaho  Benny Gibbs hasn't been getting much of a picture on his TV set lately. The large aerial usually atop his simple farmhouse near the banks of the Clearwater River here was lying on the ground so it wouldn't show up in scenes of a Charles Bronson Western filmed near his property.

title: GOLD PRICES SLIDE; DOLLAR ALSO DROPS
description: BRUSSELS, April 15 (UPI)the price of gold hit today its lowest levels in almost six months in London and Zurich. The dollar also dropped on most world money markets.

title: DEATHS NEAR 100 IN BEIRUT BATTLE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15Gunfire, rockets and bombs tool a deadly toll here today as Palestinian guerrillas battled for the third day wit the rightwing Phalangist party's armed militia.

title: Concert: Isaac Stern
description: At the beginning of George Rochberg's new Violin Concerto there is a dissonant clash that sounds almost like a cluster. Perhaps that is the composer's way of letting us know that he can be as contemporary as anybody else. But once having established his credentials, Mr. Rochberg seems content. The remainder of his long Concerto (five movements, 37 minutes) looks back rather than forward. Mr. Rochberg has composed a romantic work very much in line with the neoromanticism that has been entering the avantgarde in recent years.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (UPI)Mayor Richard J. Daley Said today if the Chicago Bears moved to suburban Arlington Heights, the city would take court action to take Chicago out of their name.

title: The Price Of Palestine Peace
description: ATHENSThe creation of an independent Israel is a romantic, dreamfulfilling event. In the sense of providing a free haven for refugees from fear, it compares with the creation of the United States two centuries ago.

title: U.S. to Honor Pacts, Schlesinger Says
description: Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger reasserted tonight that the United States was prepared to fulfill its defense obligations in Asia and Europe.

title: S.E.C. URGES RULES ON FUND VALUATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today rules were needed for money market mutual funds to determine the value of the funds for the purpose of investors.

title: Huge Losses Are Taken As Thousands Set Flight
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15As hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese prepare for the mass flight they feel is imminent, they are selling off houses, cars and expensive applances at huge losses to buy gold, dollars, preserved food suitable for traveling, and oceangoing junks.

title: Business Briefs
description: TEHRAN Iran, April 15 (AP)  Iran took a further step today toward active participation in oil operations, announcing plans to form a joint venture between the National Iranian Oil Company and the British Petroleum Tanker Company, spokesmen for the companies said today.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Pittsburgh

title: CLEANAIR ORDERS ISSUED FOR CITY
description: The Federal Government issued an elaborate timetable yesterday that in effect orders the city and the state of New York to adhere to a stepbystep program to substantially clean the city's air over the next two years.

title: Rhodesia's Dolce Vita
description: Rhodesia hardly looks the part of a country that has been an outcast among the nations for nearly a decade a land afflicted by guerrilla war and supposedly under economic siege.

title: Flyers Beat Leafs, 30, and Gain 20 Series Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15Two down, 10 to go. By posting a 30 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, their second straight at the Spectrum, the Philadelphia Flyers kept to their simplified formula for retaining the Stanley Cup: 10 more playoff triumphs and it's theirs again.

title: Connally Admits Memory Flaw; Case May Go to the Jury Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The defense rested its case today in the bribery trial of John B. Connally after the former Secretary of the Treasury conceded that his memory was flawed, but insisted that he had never accepted a $10,000 payoff.

title: Concorde Safety at Kennedy Is Argued
description: WASHINGTON, April 15A Government hearing was told today that many airline pilots were worried about the safety of a lowaltitude turn that the Concorde supersonic airliner would make just after takeoff to meet noise rules at Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: Enforcing Laws
description: After a hundred days in the job, Governor Carey has found abundant reason for concern over the reputation of the lawenforcement process in this state. In that time, he has had to appoint a special prosecutor and a Moreland Act Commission to look into the nursing home industry; he has had to seek a special assistant attorney general to look into Attica coverup charges; he has had to worry about the jurisdiction of the anticorruption prosecutor in New York City; and he is watching a legislative committee begin an investigation of alleged wrongdoing and coverup in the Corrections Department. In short, an ad hoc parallel law enforcement system is beginning to develop because the formal system of enforcing the laws in this state has broken down so regularly.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Reinhardt Rasmussen is packing in the crowds at Rosenthal StudioHaus these days. The Danish glass cutter will be plying his trade at the Fifth Avenue store through Tuesday, April 22, as part of The Great Danes at Rosenthal celebration to honor the 150th anniversary of Holmegaard of Copenhagen. There is no charge for the initials or dales he engraves on Holmegaard glasses purchased during his stay nor for the leaves, birds and flowers he often adds.

title: About Education
description: Should chairmen of college departments be considered representatives of their faculty colleagues primus inter pares, first among their peersor agents of management?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Traffic Department postponed plans establish an experimenstal twoandahalfmile express bus lane along Queens Boulevard after 100 medallion cab drivers blocked the lane Monday night to protest their exclusion from it. A departmental spokesman said the project had been postponed until further notice so that meetings could be held with the Community Planning board, the Chamber of Commerce, the tax industry and local organizations. Under the planned twoweek experiment, express buses would have been allowed to travel east along a normally westbound lane, away from the Queensbound rushhour crush, beginning at 5 P.M. each weekday.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, April 15, 1975

title: Bien Hoa a Key Base For Operations, Supply
description: The sprawling Bien Hoa air base is the largest air force installation in South Vietnam and perhaps the most important since it is not only a center for combat operations but also houses the bulk of the air force's spare parts and maintenance facilities.

title: Charles Cardinal Journet Of Switzerland Dies at 84
description: FRIBOURG, Switzerland, April 15 (AP) Charles Cardinal Journet of Switzerland died today. He was 84 years old.

title: Equal Employment Guideline on Layoffs Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission postponed final action today on guidelines aimed at protecting minorities and women from bearing a disproportionate burden in the layoffs caused by the recession.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the photograph with yesterday's television schedule in The New York Times, Shirley MacLaine was shown with Mrs. Chou Enlai, wife of the Premier of China, not with the wife of Mao Tsetung.

title: PRICE CUTS PLANNED BY JEWEL COMPANIES
description: The Jewel Companies, the largest supermarket chain in the Chicago area, announced yesterday that it was reducing prices on more than 3,300 basic food and household items an average of 10 to 12 per cent.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. St. Louis

title: Anniversaries
description: ABRAMS. Lorel. To my sweetheart. This is No. 8. Fortytwo more In go together. Your loving husband, Hy and our dearest children, Rose, Mitchel and Missy.

title: Farm Bill Conferees Back Lower Subsidy Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Senate conferees yielded to the House on every major point today to produce a farm bill tailored to avert a Presidential veto. The compromise measure will increase subsidy and pricesupport provisions of the present agricultural law but not to the degree called for in the Senate version of the bill.

title: AIR CARGO THEFTS PUT AT 16MILLION
description: Cargo thefts at the three metropolitan airports were estimated to be running at a rate of $16million a year, in a report made public yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. The report said that more cargo might be stolen here than throughout the rest of the United States.

title: Advertising
description: For a retired stickball player and Glenn Miller fan, it was a pretty heady morningbreakfast at the Plaza with William Talbert of the United States Lawn Tennis Association and a midmorning meeting with Schuyler Chapin, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Forest Service Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The House passed today an amendment that adds $21million to the Forest Service budget, including over $5million to combat fires and insect infestations. The sponsor, Representative Robert Duncan, Democrat of Oregon, said the funds could save some of the six million hoard feet of timber lost annually to fires and insects.

title: CoverUp at Attica: Often Charged but Never Investigated
description: Charges that the Office or the special state prosecutor covered up crimes allegedly committed by law enforcement officers during the Attica prison uprising have been made with regularity almost since the criminal News investigation of Analysis Attica crimes began three days after the disorders were quelled on Sept. 13, 1971.

title: Sikkim Votes to End Monarchy, Merge With India
description: NEW DELHI, April 15 (AP)Citizens of the Himalayan kingmingly today in favor of abolishing their 300yearold monarchy and merging the country with India.

title: Great Neck Board to Appeal State Ruling on School Chief
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 15The Great Neck school board voted, 3 to 2, last night to appeal to the State Supreme Court in Albany a ruling by Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner, who cleared Mortimer J. AbramoWitz, the Superintendent of Schools, of charges of insurbordination, incompetence and neglect of duty.

title: BOOK CRITICS PLAN 4 ANNUAL AWARDS
description: After sharp debate, the National Book Critics Circle, at its first annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday afternoon, confirmed by hand vote, the decision of its advisory board Nov. 15 to establish four annual literary awards: for fiction, poetry, general nonfiction and criticism. The awards will be made in January for books published the previous year.

title: William McGaffin, Reporter For Chicago Daily News, 64
description: William McGaffin, deputy chief of the Washington bureau of The Chicago Daily News, died Monday of cancer in Doctors Hospital, Washington. He was 64 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: BIEN HOA IS TARGET
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 16Communist gunners shelled South Vietnam's largest fighter base at Bien Hoa, 15 miles from Saigon, with longrange artillery yesterday amid indications that the North Vietnamese were moving three more divisions into the battle for Saigon.

title: CLEANAIR ORDERS ISSUED FOR CITY
description: The Federal Government issued an elaborate timetable yesterday that in effect orders the city and the state of New York to adhere to a stepbystep program to substantially clean the city's air over the next two years.

title: DR. JAMES BAKER, VETERINARIAN, 64
description: Dr. James A. Baker, a veterinarian and professor of virology at the New York State Veterinary College at Cornell University, died Monday at Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Sindona Appears in Public To Address College Group
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 Michele Sindona, the beleagured Italian banker, real estate man and industrialist, made today his first public appearance since his business empire was plunged into trouble last year.

title: Farm Bill Conferees Back Lower Subsidy Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Senate conferees yielded to the House on every major point today to produce a farm bill tailored to avert a Presidential veto. The compromise measure will increase subsidy, and pricesupport provisions of the present agricultural law but not to the degree called for in the Senate version of the bill.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: CONTROL DATA SETS HONEYWELL ACCORD
description: Honeywell, Inc., and the Control Data Corporation said Yesterday that they had agreed to establish a company to design, develop and manfacture computer mass memory products.

title: CAMBODIA WINDUP
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, April 16The insurgents, closing in on Phnom Penh from almost all sides, reached the southern edge of the city after dark yesterday, and heavy fighting was under way.

title: Michael Flanders Is Dead at 53; HumoristStar of Drop of a Hat
description: Michael Flanders, the British lyricist, humorist and actor who performed from a wheelchair because of the effects of polio, collapsed and died Monday night while on vacation in Wales. Mr. Flanders, who was 53 years old, was best known for his 13year partnership with Donald Swann, the composer and comedian, in their twoman At the Drop of a Hat shows in London and on Broadway.

title: Palmer in Spanish Golf
description: LA MANGA, Spain, April 15 (Reuters) Arnold Palmer, fresh from a strong performance in the Masters, makes his first appearance in the Spanish open golf championship, which starts tomorrow. The 45yearold Palmer heads a field of 150 professionals and six amateurs in the $72,000 event.

title: STAATS SUES FORD ON IMPOUNDMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Controller General Elmer B. Staats, acting on behalf of Congress, took President Ford to court today on the issue of impoundment of funds for a subsidized housing program.

title: I.B.M. Is Introducing A HighSpeed Printer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday a new highspeed computer printer that operates at speeds nearly six times faster than the company's present printers.

title: Revenues Rise Slightly
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's largest independent telephone company, reported yesterday a 13.6 per cent decline in its consolidated net income for the first three months of the year compared with the 1974 period.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Houston

title: Panel Says Finances Will Force 1 Campus in 10 to Merge or Shut
description: BERKELEY, Calif.A panel of educational leaders forecast yesterday that financial pressure would probably compel one of every 10 colleges and universities in the United States to merge, consolidate or close ?? entirely within the next five years.

title: CITY BUDGET CUT 100MILLION MORE; NEW LAYOFFS DUE
description: Mayor Beame and Budget Director Melvin N. Lechner have sheared more than $100million from what they had projected as an $883.9million deficit for the 197576 expense budget. They have also made tentative plans, for more layoffs of city workers, perhaps as many as 10,000, officials in the administration said yesterday.

title: Red Sox Top Yanks' Hunter, 53
description: Despite the services of Catfish Hunter, a threerun lead after three innings and a porous Red Sox infield, the Yankees lost again yesterday.

title: Injured Singh Out of Wood; ABC Will Televise the Race
description: A training injury has knocked Singh out of next Saturday's Wood Memorial and probably out of the Kentucky Derby two weeks later.

title: Market Summary
description: Tuesday, April 15, 1975

title: Spirits Erase 16Point Deficit, Oust Nets in 5 Games, 108107
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 15Improbably, but irresistibly, the Spirits of St. Louis completed their upset of the defending American Basketball Association champions tonight as Freddie Lewis's jumpshot basket sent the New York Nets to a 108107 defeat.

title: Market Place
description: The pension law of 1974 adds a new level of responsibility for managers of pensionfund assets that could lead to major new disruptions in the stock market.

title: Memorial Services
description: ADAMPeter John Canaday. Memorial servire to he held at 12 noon Saturday, April 19th at the New Canaan Presbyterian Church, Denote Ridge Road, New Canaan, CI.

title: Concert: 18thCentury Entertainments
description: The 20th century can claim to be advanced in certain respects, but it is difficult to be condescending to the 18th century in the matter of dinner music. Where we have the pipedin tranquilizer known as mood music, the diners of the 18th century had Mozart's divertimentosor some did, anyway.

title: Former Agent Says I.R.S. School Was Amateurish
description: WASHINGTON, April 15A former special intelligence agent for the Internal Revenue Service said today he had attended the agency's secret undercover school and found it extremely amateurish.

title: Teaching Children Facts About Worldwide Hunger
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 How do you get the average wellfed community interested In doing something about hunger in the world?

title: Smith, Lutz Advance in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, April 15 (Reuters) Stan Smith of the United States easily defeated Yuji Tezuka of Japan, 61, 62, in the first round or a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Monday's Fights
description: Auckland, New ZealandYoung Sekona, Tonga, knocked out George Jerome, Canada, 4 rounds, heavyweights.

title: Ballet Theater Buys Manhattan Center
description: American Ballet Theater, a major company that has been unable to find a home base in its 35 years of existence, announced yesterday that it had signed a contract to buy the Manhattan Center, a former opera house, for $3million and planned to spend $7million for renovation.

title: Rally Held for Grand Central to Be a Landmark Again
description: More than a dozen stage, screen, radio and television personalities performed outside Grand Central Terminal at midday yesterday in an effort to rally support to have the structure restored to landmark status.

title: PARIS TALKS FAIL ON ENERGY AGENDA
description: PARIS, April 15  A preparatory meeting for an international energy conference this summer broke down on its ninth day today when 10 delegations from developed and developing countries decided they could not agree on the agenda and other terms for the proposed Conference.

title: UNITED BRANDS SETS DIVIDEND OMISSIONS
description: The United Brands Company, which lost almost $44million last year, said yesterday it would omit its quarterly dividend on three classes of preferred stock for the third consecutive period.

title: Colorado Town Lures Youths With Sun, Scenery and Bagels
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.Call it an Upper West Side with ski lifts. Or an Aspen that hasn't yet grown up. Or simply a mountain haven of extraordinary beauty in a state where ordinary beauty abounds. However you describe Telluride, it is a special place to the new young residents who have wandered into this Southwestern Colorado box canyon in search of sun, snow, scenery, good vibes and good bagels. scribe Telluride, it is a special place to the new young residents who have wandered into this Southwestern Colorado box canyon in search of sun, snow, scenery, good vibes and good bagels.

title: White House Gives Secret C.I.A. Data To Senate Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (Reuters)The Ford Administration has handed over a secret report on the Central Intelligence Agency and other highly classified information to the Senate committee investigating United States intelligence operations, the White House announced today.

title: Cargo Thefts Put at $16Million At the 3 Metropolitan Airports
description: Cargo thefts at the three metropolitan airports were estimated to be running at a rate of $16million a year, in a report made public yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. The report said that more cargo might be stolen here than throughout the rest of the United States.

title: People and Business
description: William N. Walker, a lawyer and Yeutter Clayton, an agricultural economist, have been nominated by President Ford to join Frederick B. Dent, recently sworn in as Special Representative to the President for Trade Negotiations. If confirmed, Mr. Walker who is 37 years old, will became deputy special trade representativeGeneva, and Mr. Clayton, 45, will be deputy special trade representativedomestic.

title: Saigon Defense: Air Power Vital
description: Successful strikes by the South Vietnamese Air Force on Communist heavy artillery and tanks are essential to defense of the Saigon sector in the critical seven days ahead, according to United States military sources. The weight of the South's counteroffensive may be restricted, the sources believed, by continued North Vietnamese shelling of the major air base at Bien Hoa. One report received in Washington said that a large part of the F5 and A37 fighterbombers based there had been immobilized by the shelling.

title: Where Are Henry's Friends?
description: WASHINGTON, April 15In America's opening to China and its policy of dtente with the Soviet Unionthe two most publicized foreign policy developments of the last decadethese three nations recognized their special responsibility to avoid interference in the internal affairs of other states and to work together for peace.

title: The Clunker Label: For Women Only?
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)  Health insurance companies call women clunkers, losers and bad risks for coverage, said a study released today by organized labor supporters of national health insurance.

title: Sutton Stops Reds On OneHitter, 31
description: LOS ANGELES, April 15 (AP)Don Sutton held Cincinnati hitless for 62/3 innings tonight. Then Johnny Bench homered and Sutton had to settle for the fourth onehitter of his career as the Los Angeles Dodgers posted a 31 triumph over the Reds.

title: Working Women Protest Increases in Bride Tolls
