description: A group of 15 working women from Teaneck, angered at the proposed toll rate increase for six crossings between New York City and New Jersey, took time off yesterday to express their ire for the benefit of motorists at the toll booths on the George Washington Bridge.

title: Colonels Delay Play
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 15 (UPI)The Kentucky Colonels announced today that their first game in the Eastern Division final playoff series would be delayed until next Monday night against the Spirits of St. Louis.

title: Edith Vanocur Dead at 51; Washington Food Columnist
description: Edith Pick Vanocur, a food columnist for The Washington Post and the wife of Sander Vanocur, the newsman, died Monday of cancer at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. She was 51 years old.

title: Market Basket
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped fractionally last week, 0.4 per cent, but price analysts saw many indications that food prices are going to rise in the weeks ahead.

title: Colorado Town Lures Youths With Sun, Scenery and Bagels
description: TELI URIDE, Colo.Call it an Upper West Side with ski lifts. Or an Aspen that hasn't yet grown up. Or simply a mountain haven of extraordinary beauty in a state where ordinary beauty abounds. However you describe Telluride, it is a special place to the new young residents who have wandered into this Southwestern Colorado box ?? in search of sun, snow, scenery, good vibes and good bagels.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: WINE TALK
description: BORDEAUX, France, April 15Burdened by rivers of unsold and apparently unsalable wine, battered by staggering interest rates and confronted by an unexpected downturn in consumption in important markets, the Bordeaux wines trade is undergoing some of the most drastic changes in its long history.

title: Canucks Set Back Montreal
description: MONTREAL, April 15 (UPI) Garry Monahan scored at the 13:46 mark of the final period tonight as the Vancouver Canucks gained the first victory in their history over. Montreal, 21, and evened their fourofsevengame Stanley Cup quarterfinal series at a game ??piece.

title: Dip Eased in Mach In Industrial Output
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The steep decline in industrial production tapered off in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: CAMBODIA WINDUP
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, April 16The in surgents, closing in on Phnom Penh from almost all sides, reached the southern edge of the city after dark yesterday, and heavy fighting was under way.

title: F.T.C. ACCEPTS NEW XEROX PACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters)The Federal Trade Commission announced today a renegotiated and stiffened settlement of a consent order with the Xerox Corporation that would require the copying machine manufacturer to license its more than 1,700 patents.

title: A. M. C. EXPECTING SUBSTANTIAL LOSS
description: DETROIT, April 16 (AP)The American Motors Corporation says it will incur a substantial, loss this year, including a pretax deficit of more than $10million in the JanuaryMarch quarter.

title: Apollo Devices Detect Lunar Dust Storms at Sunrise and Sunset
description: Dust storms have been observed on the moon. They are detected, every sunrise and sunset, by instruments left by the Apollo 17 astronauts in the mountainous Taurus  Littrow area.

title: Venue Change Won in Nixon Tax Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The two men charged with assisting in the preparation of false tax returns for former President Richard M. Nixon and Mrs. Nixon won the right today to be tried separately in their home towns rather than together in Washington, as the special Watergate prosecutor had wished.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly reported the dividend rate on shares of Reynolds Securities, Inc., after a 3for2 stock split. The stock will carry an annual dividend rate of 40 cents plus onethird of any earnings above 40 cents a share

title: EXTRA TAX SOUGHT TO AID DOWNTOWN
description: The DowntownLower Manhattan Association, an influential organization of businessmen and civic leaders, has approved a city plan for a special real estate tax in lower Manhattan to pay for such urban amenities as pedestrian malls and park areas and to raise planning funds for new projects, such as the nowstalled Manhattan Landing.

title: Saigon's Need for Shorter Lines
description: The survival of the South Vietnamese Army as a credible defensive force now appears to United States military sources to depend on an early disengagement from its present positions and a retirement to lines closer to the capital. The most critical aspect of a swiftly deteriorating military situation is an acute shortage of reserve units to plug holes in the defense perimeter. The command in Saigon is forced to weaken one critical but inactive sector to strengthen others under attack.

title: DR. ERIK VESELY, 70, SOVIET UNION EXPERT
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Dr. Erik Vesely, an expert on the Soviet Union, died at Georgetown Hospital in Washington on Monday. He was 70 years old.

title: Sales in the Quarter Show Gain of 25.8%
description: Firstquarter reports from metals companies yesterday reflected a mixed trend, with steel companies showing soaring earnings on moderate sales gains.

title: Early Profit Taking Fails To Stem Stocks' Advance
description: Early Profit Taking Fails To Stem Stocks' Advance

title: City Planning Unit Moving to Create Hunan Open Space at Skyscrapers
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday approved major revisions in zoning rules governing the design of open space among Manhattan skyscrapers, in an effort to increase the amount of light, air and breathing space in the city's most densely developed precincts.

title: Bridge: 2 OutofTown Experts Win Chicago Qualifying Tourney
description: The four Lancia qualifying tournaments around the country, which entitle the winners to play against the stars of the Italian Blue Team next month and perhaps win themselves Lancia cars, are open to all comers.

title: Equal Rights Loses In North Carolina, Dooming It for '75
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 16 (UPI)  The North Carolina House today dimmed nationwide hopes for the Equal Rights Amendment in 1975, killing it by five votes.

title: NASA Reversing Plan on Scrapping Surplus Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)The space agency has changed its mind and will keep $900million worth of surplus Apollo rockets, spaceships and a Skylab space station instead of scrapping them as planned, it was disclosed today.

title: Wary Citizens at Lexington and Concord Await Battle Bicentennial
description: CONCORD, Mass., April 16 Fresh white paint glistens on the historic houses and fences near the village green. Bunting and Revolutionary War flags hang everywhere.

title: New Hampshire Is Pushing Election Suit
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 16 (AP)New Hampshire's Governor and Executive Council moved toward a legal confrontation with the United States Senate today, ordering the state attorney general to file a suit in the United States Supreme Court to resolve the fivemonth, dispute over who will be state's junior Senator.

title: Service Held in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) A memorial service, attended by such notables as W. Averell Harriman and the Rev. Billy Graham was held at the Washington National Cathedral today for General Chiang.

title: U.S. Is Seeking to Admit 980 Cambodians
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Ford Administration is expected to announce tomorrow that 980 Cambodian political refugees will be admitted to the United States as temporary residents under a dispensation by the Justice Department, high State Department officials said.

title: SILVER FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: A late rally sent silver futures up sha??ply on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, with the April delivery moving un to $4.21 1/10 an ounce from $4.07 8/10.

title: Political Row Stirs Atlanta Racial Calm
description: The leading white politician, Wyche Fowler, president of the City Council, and the leading black politician, Mayor Maynard Jackson, publicly accused each other of polarizing the city's black and white communities in the running dispute over whether the Safety Commissioner Reginald Eaves, should resign.

title: Advertising
description: W. R. Simmons & Associates Research filed a countersuit yesterday against Time Inc. seeking more than $10million in damages and charging the publisher with seeking to destroy its business and attempting to, persuade other companies not to pay for past work by Simmons or sign up for future work.

title: Objections By Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16Brazil has firmly refused to allow Portuguese intervention in the Lisbon branch of the Bank of Brazil, touching off what could be a diplomatic crisis.

title: Dance: Spring Gala Day
description: Dance is about to burst over New York like a small tidal wave. Leading the assault is the Alvin Ailey City renter Dance Theater, which opened its City Center 55th Street Theater spring season Tuesday night with a gala and a premiere.

title: Tough Handgun Bill Dies
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)  A restrictive handgun bill that would take pistols away from everyone in this state except policemen and soldiers is dead for the year. The measure, backed by an array of civil liberties groups, was defeated in the Massachusetts Senate on a 315 roll call vote.

title: Nets' Demise in Playoffs Deemed Matter of Spirit
description: There was something Buddhalike about Don Adams, perhaps the American Basketball Association's only potbellied forward, as he smiled and stuffed a dollar bill in his pocket.

title: The Stage: Inside Lulu
description: Inside Lulu is a quick cavort through Frank Wedekind's turnofthecentury trilogy of plays about an archetypal woman Lulu is anything you want her to be. In the case of the new Section Ten production, conceived and directed by Andrea Balis and written by Ron Cowen, she suffers from a split personality.

title: Subdued Israeli's Mark Independence Day
description: JERUSALEM, April 16Israelis celebrated the 27th anniversary of their independence today in a subdued, lowkey fashion that reflected the sober national mood.

title: New Books
description: Heinrich von Kleist: The Major Works, a study by Robert E. Helbling (New Directions, $13.50; paperbound, $3.75).

title: CBS NET UP 16.2% ON 7% SALES GAIN
description: CBS, Inc. realized a 15.2 per cent increase in firstquarter earnings on a 7 per cent gain in sales, William S. Paley, chairman, told some 300 shareholders attending yesterday's annual meeting here.

title: FRANCIS I. NALLY
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 16Francis I. Nally, who was president of the National Council of Catholic Men in 195253, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: Senate May Call Bribery Hearings On United Brands
description: The Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on multinational corporations, said yesterday it might call hearings witHin three weeks to inquire further into the bribes the United Brands Company has acknowledged paying to foreign officials to get business favors. President Oswaldo. Lopez Arellano of Honduras is reported to be directly implicated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We feel completely abandoned.Premier. Long Boret of Cambodia. [18:1.]

title: Mayors Urge RevenueSharing Renewal
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The mayors of several cities called on Congress today to renew revenuesharing legislation as a minimum step in helping to relieve cities of their shortage of operating funds. They made their plea in a hearing before the Senate Finance Committee's Subcommittee on Revenue Sharing.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Pittsburgh

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Houston

title: 1,154Count Complaint Filed Against Doctor for Fraud
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)The Federal Government filed a 1,151count civil complaint against Dr. Pablo K. Chan in Federal court today charging him with Medicare fraud and asking $2.3million in damages.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, April 1.6 (UPI)Sweden poured in 11 goals in the last two periods today and defeated a deflated United States team, 123, in the world ice hockey championships. It was the Americans ninth straight loss, the third time they had allowed 10 or more goals and their second defeat by Sweden.

title: Raleigh Smith, 52, Headed Hospital Funding Concern
description: Raleigh L. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Will, Folsom & Smith, Inc., a fundraising concern in the hospital field, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, at his home Tuesday. He was 52 years old and lived at 825 West End Avenue.

title: State Investigates Reports Of Medicaid Profiteering
description: TRENTON, April 16  The State Attorney General's office disclosed today that it was investigating reports of profiteering by hundreds of physicians, dentists, pharmacists and others under the state's $446million Medicaid program.

title: PeopleMover Faces Reprieve At Campus of West Virginia U.
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Government officials who considered dynamiting a controversial and costly peoplemover in West Virginia after investing more than $57million in the test rapidtransit system now expect to salvage it by spending at least $61million more to make it operational.

title: HEILEMAN BREWING SEEKING C. SCHMIDT
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company of La Crosse, Wis., said yesterday it was negoliating to acquire C. Schmidt & Sons, Inc., a privately owned Philadelphia brewer.

title: Screen: Cold Efficiency of 'Capone':Boldness of Gazarra in Lead Risks Giggles 20's Gang Wars Make for Bloody Tableaus
description: "Capone" reduces the gangster film to its single essential, the gun fight.This gun fight goes on more or less nonstop after the title character is established as a poor but ambitious Brooklyn boy, at the beginning of the film, until just before the end when we leave the syphilitic Scarface Al (Ben Gazarra), nutty as a fruitcake by his Florida swimming pool, ranting about the Bolsheviks. The weapons and the combatants change but everything remains basically the same. As old friends, such as Big Jim Colosimo (Frank Campanella), are mowed down, new ones, such as Frank Nitti (Sylvester Stallone), take their place. The movie requires a certain prior knowledge of the Chicago gang wars of the nineteen-twenties, which really aren't dramatized. Rather they are illustrated in a series of bloody tableaus, sometimes by anonymously driven vintage cars that pursue one another through Hollywood studio streets like robots possessed."Capone" which opened at Loews State 2 and Cine Theaters yesterday, was produced by today's King of the B's, Roger Corman, and written by Howard Browne, the two men who earlier collaborated on "The St. Valentine's Day Massacre," which covered pretty much the same turf.This one, however, was directed by Steve Carver, who deals with the subject energetically, directly and completely without sentimentality, which is one of this unpretentious movie's small but remarkable virtues.Some of the other virtues are the performancesby Mr. Gazarra, who plays Al with the kind of boldness that risks giggles; Harry Guardino, as the gentle-natured gangster, Johnny Torrio, and Sylvester Stallone, as a new-style gangster who succeeds Al when the latter is nabbed on income tax evasion. John Cassavetes makes a token appearance as a New York mobster early in the film."Capone" is not great but it moves with cold efficiency, which is its style whether you like it or not.

title: Both Sides Tell Connally Jurors in Final Arguments That They Must Decide Whom to Believe
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Government accused John B. Connally today of lying, and the defense belittled the credibility of the key prosecution witness as both sides presented final arguments to the jury in the bribery trial of the former Secretary of the Treasury.

title: REPORT IS ON RADIO
description: The Cambodian Government surrendered to insurgent forces today, the Cambodian radio announced. The Phnom Penh Government ordered all its troops to stop firing and lay down their arms.

title: Chess
description: Mark Diesen, a 17yearold United States master, finished far down in the Hastings international tournament, but Col. Edmund B. Edmondson, executive director of the United States Chess Federation, said:

title: Exhibitions
description: ART EXHIBITION, including paintings, drawings and pesters by children 10 years old and older, Involved in the Education Action Program of the Harlem Teams for SelfHelp, in the Junior Museum restaurant, Metropolitan Museum of Art, through May 3.

title: Cambodian Diplomat Is Bitter About Way the U.S. Used Us
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Abdulgaffar PeangMeth sat solemnly in the cool, sparsely furnished drawing room of the Cambodian Embassy today, far from the gummy heat and crashing shells of Phnom Penh.

title: FORD ASSERTS U.S. HAS FAILED SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Ford said today that the failure of the United States to meet its commitments to Saigon had created this present tragic situation in South Vietnam.

title: Scythian Gold at Met Brightens Detente
description: In a happy atmosphere of dtente yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum, Vladimir I. Popov, Soviet Deputy Minister of Culture, declared that a new exhibition of Scythian gold, largely lent to the. Met by Soviet institutions, was not only of esthetic but also of political significance.

title: Foolish Pleasure May Lose Jockey
description: Jacinto Vasquez's status as Foolish Pleasure's jockey in Saturday's running of the $100,000 added Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, was placed in some jeopardy yesterday when the Penamanian rider was involved in ninthrace disqualification. Vasquez found himself in traffic difficulties during the running of the sevenfurlong contest while guiding Gerard Robin's 20to1 Throne. He brought his charge home third. After viewing the films however, the stewards dropped Throne to last place.

title: S.E.C. Says Northrop Kept $30Million Secret Fund
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today accusing the Northrop Corporation of maintaining a secret fund of $30million for political and other purposes, at least some of them illegal.

title: Republicans Offer a Plan To Bar New School Taxes
description: ALBANY, April 16A proposal to temporarily cut in half the contributions that local school districts are required to make to the state teachers pension. Systemthus freeing $200million for the districtsis being advanced by the Senate Republicans as a possible alternative to higher taxes for increased local school aid this year.

title: Conviction of Freeholder In Road Deaths Reinstated
description: TRENTON, April 16 (UPI)A State Appeals Court today reinstated the conviction in two highway deaths of Freeholder Robert J. Halpin of Cumberland County, but ordered a hearing on a new trial.

title: FORD ASSERTS U.S. HAS FAILED SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Ford said today that the failure of the United States to meet its commitments to Saigon had created this present tragic situation in South Vietnam.

title: FAMILY FOOD COST PUT AT $40 A WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) A Government survey released today indicates that the average American family spends $40.05 a week on food at the grocery store and dining out.

title: 13 INDICTED IN BRONX IN TWO GANG RAPES
description: Thirteen young men have been indicted in the Bronx in the gang rape of two women last February, Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola announced yesterday.

title: Food Day
description: Food Day brings to the forefront of public consciousness a jumble of troubling issues, ranging from unhealthy nutritional practices to the elimination of dangerous foods from the country's supermarkets. By far the most important function of the observance, however, is to refocus attention on the enormity of mankind's foodpopulation problem.

title: State Finds $2Million Misspent In Minority Program at City U.
description: A state audit of the City University program for disadvantaged students found that an estimated total of $2.2million in state aid was improperly expended, according to a report released yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: A Responsible Congress
description: BOSTON, April 16A common complaint against Congress, when it acts on foreign affairs, is that it seeks power without responsibility. It snipes at the President's foreign policy, the critics say, and legislates restrictions; but it does not offeror take responsibility fora genuine alternative policy.

title: Dartmouth Slashes Budget
description: HANOVER, N.H., April 16 (AP)The trustees of Dartmouth College have approved a budget of $57.1million for the 19751976 fiscal year, Dartmouth's president, John Kemeny, said today. The budget reflects a $743,000 cut and will eliminate the school's current operating deficit, Mr. Kemeny said.

title: Film: Illustrations of National Blight
description: As illustrations of a national blight, Methadone: An American Way of Dealing and Susan: April to June, the documentaries that arrived yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, evolve as professional and provocative inspections of a terrible problem. But in presenting bleak facts and avoiding panaceas for the addicted or superficial notions about a dopedriven prostitute, they manage to shed light and a tiny ray of hope into the dark corners of our malignant drug scene.

title: Cheap Public Colleges and Career Training in Demand
description: A sour national economy and bad job market for young people appears to be pushing an increasing number of high school graduates into lowcost public colleges and college graduates into post  graduate career training programs across the country.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly reported the dividend rate on shares of Reynolds Securities, Inc., after a 3for2 stock split. The stock will carry an annual dividend rate of 40 cents plus onethird of any earnings above 40 cents a share.

title: Ship in C.I.A.Hughes Case Leaves Berth in California
description: LOS ANGELES, April 16The Glomar Explorer, which reportedly recovered a portion of a Soviet submarine from the Pacific Ocean last year on a secret Central Intelligence Agency mission, left her Long Beach berth early today for what was described as a test cruise off the coast of California. No further information on the voyage was given by the corporation.

title: JEANNE GREENS, 69 STAGE ACTRESS, DIES
description: Jeanne Greene, a stage ac tress of the nineteentwenties and thirties, died Monday of cancer at New York Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Bangor Punta Plans Appeal Of an Award to ChrisCraft
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation said yesterday that It plans to take to the United State Supreme Court an Appeals Court decision that awarded ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., $35.5million.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, April 16, 1975

title: Miscellaneous
description: CHILDREN'S BIRTHDAY PARTIES may be arranged through the education department of the Museum of the City of New York, to be held in the museum at Fifth Avenue at 103d Street for children from 5 to 12 years old on Tuesdays through Fridays from 3 to 4:30 P.M. at $10 per child, for a minimum of 10 and a maximum of 15. Party Includes cake with candles, ice cream, candy, games and prizes. 3541672, extension 23.

title: BANKS' RESERVES ARE AIDED BY FEE
description: The Federal Reserve stepped into the money market yesterday to supply both permanent and temporary reserves to the banking system. This move was aimed at offsetting drains from the network as a result of increases in the Treasury's cash balance at the Fed as incometax receipts flow into Government coffers. This inflow takes away funds from the banking system.

title: In Memoriam
description: KOCH, Louise M. April 17th, 1974 In treasured memory

title: A Focus on State Officials In Attica Inquiry Is Urged
description: In a letter to Governor Carey, the lawyer who served as general counsel of the state's Special Commission on Attica has urged that the new investigation of the Attica prosecution focus on identifying state offivials who established and condoned the priority of prosecuting inmates ahead of law enforcement officers.

title: $340,000 Ski Suit Award
description: AUBURN, Calif., April 16 (UPI)A 16yearold girl has won a $345,000 settlement for a skiing injury that resulted in the amputation of her left leg. Superior Court Judge Ronald Cameron authorized the settlement for Rebecca Hutson of Mahoon, Ill. Defendants in the case, were the. Boreal Ridge Corporation and Dr. James F. Black, who treated the injury.

title: A Captain Tells of Flight From Xuan Loc
description: TRANG BOM, South Vietnam, April 16There was nothing we could do, a South Vietnamese Army captain said here today as he sat by the side of the road.

title: Roundup: Cub's Flying High
description: The Chicago Cubs, who spend. most of the National League baseball season looking up to, their superiors, are enjoying the dizzy height of first place in the Eastern Division standings.

title: A SCHOOL OFFICIAL DROPPED IN BRONX
description: Robert L. Green, business officer of troubled Community School District 9 in the. Bronx, was suspended from his post last night on charges of neglect of duty and unbecoming conduct.

title: ExPolice Chief Penalized
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)The former police chief of New Hope, Pa., has been placed on 23 months' probation and barred from further law enforcement work for taking $5 in parking fines. George W. Lair, 46 years old, was also ordered by Bucks County Court yesterday to resign and forfeit pay from Feb. 6, the date of his arrest on theft charges.

title: Former Rival of Brezhnev Aleksandr Nikolayevich Shelepin
description: MOSCOW, April 16  Aleksandr Nikolayevich Shelepin was a model Soviet politician.

title: EXTRA TAX SOUGHT TO AID DOWNTOWN
description: The DowntownLower Manhattan Association, an influential organization of businessmen and civic leaders, has approved a city plan for a special real estate tax in lower Manhattan to pay for such urban amenities as pedestrian malls and park areas and to raise planning funds for new projects, such as the nowstalled Manhattan Landing.

title: Insurers Offer a Joint Malpractice Plan
description: ALBANY, April 16Major insurance companies in the state today proposed that they form a joint underwriting association that would offer medicalmalpractice insurance at rates double those now being paid by physicians but much lower than those asked by the present insurer.

title: Quake Jars Greenland Area
description: GOLDEN, Colo., April 16 (AP) An earthquake hit a remote area of the Arctic Ocean about. 300 miles east of Greenland last night, but no damage was expected from the tremor, the National Earthquake Information Service said today. The quake was recorded at 10:27 P.M. Eastern daylight time and was measured at 6.5 on the Richter scale on seismographs here.

title: U.S. Explosives Experts Testify In West Virginia Textbook Case
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 16Federal explosives experts testified today in the school bombing trial of two religious Fundamentalists, one of them a preacher. The defendants are accused on four counts of violating laws on explosives, including the dynamiting of two school buildings and conspiring to bomb others.

title: Legislators See a Breach of Faith In Plan to Drop Safety Inspectors
description: ALBANY, April 16  While relatives and well wishers milled about the Capitol today waiting for Governor Carey to swear in some high state officials, the Senate confirmed four gubernatorial nominations after a delay in which leaders accused the administration of a breach of faith.

title: Beame and the Budget
description: Mayor Beame, clad in a long black gown and with an academic mortarboard perched atop his head, was seen at yesterday morning's dedication of a new library at the New York Law School, holding tightly to the necktie of Borough President Donald Manes, of Queens, tugging at it, talking and gesturfing, forcing Mr. Manes to listen. Later, Mr. Manes was asked what the Mayor had been so animated about. The budget, he said, what else?

title: Personal Finance: Cost of CreditCard Use Abroad
description: Hans Randolph Reinisch, a New York consumer advocate, rented a car in Europe and paid his bill with a credit card. When he received his monthly statement after returning to the United States the dollar amount listed was more than the equivalent amount in German marks on the date he signed the charge slip.

title: Article 6  No Title
NBC Radio's News Syndicate To Commence Service June 18
description: Three allnews radio stations will be in competition here and in Washington, and probably in Los Angeles as well, when NBC Radio's syndicated National News and Information Service begins June 18.

title: Increase in Revenues of 8.9% Reported
description: The Monsanto Company and the Stauffer Chemical Company reported yesterday gains in sales and revenues for the first quarter. This was in marked contrast to the report on Monday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., which disclosed its worst quarterly earnings since 1945.

title: Fighting Dogs Seized in Raids In California, 25 Suspects Held
description: LOS ANGELES, April 16Sheriff's deputies seized at least 82 fightingpit bulldogs today and arrested at least 25 persons in simultaneous raids in four southern California counties.

title: 2 Women Produce 31 Champions
description: When Mrs. Kathleen Kolbert started with Yorkshire terriers she started in a big way, making a champion of her first. Not that it was any great achievement on my part, said the Oxford, Conn., breeder. You see Windemere Dolly Dew. drop had both majors when I bought her. That was in 1964. But the next year, Mrs. Kolbert purchased a pup and showed him all the way to his title. He was Lord Pickwick of Oxford and he became her foundation stud.

title: Soviet Politburo Drops Shelepin, Formerly a Contender for Power
description: MOSCOW, April 16Aleksandr N. Shelepin, who once figured as a prominent contender for the authority assumed by Leonid 1. Brezhnev, was removed from the Communist party's ruling Politburo today.

title: 28 CAMBODIANS LACK PAPERS FOR ADOPTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Immigration and Naturalization Service is investigating the airlift of 28 Cambodian children who arrived here Monday with documents showing that their adoptions had been authorized.

title: VIETCONG DEMAND FULL U.S. PULLOUT
description: PARIS, April 16The representativeof the Vietcongs Provisional Revolutionary Government issued a call here today for immediate and permanent withdrawal of what he said were 25,000 American military personnel disguised as civilians in South Vietnam.

title: FORD ACTS TO BAR RAILROAD STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) President Ford invoked emergency action today to avert a nationwide railroad strike threatened Friday by the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks.

title: U.S. Considers Corridor To Evacuate Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, told a Senate committee today that the Pentagon was considering establishing a corridor from Saigon to the sea to evacuate tens of thousands of Vietnamese.

title: Article 2  No Title
The Circus
description: RINGLING BROS. AND BARNUM & BAILEY CIRCUS at Madis o Square Garden, through May 26 (except for five Mondays, April 21 and 28, and May 5, 12 and 191. Tickets, $3.30 in $8.50. For admission about hours, dates for halfrate admission for children, and a folder, call 5644400.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Rutherford Borough Council voted, 4 to 2, to deny a liquor license application for a student pub at the Fairleigh Dickinson University campus. College students crowded the Council chambers for the 31Ahour meeting, but there was little vocal protest after the Council rejected the application.

title: VIETCONG DEMAND FULL U.S. PULLOUT
description: PARIS, April 16The representative of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government issued a call here today for immediate and permanent withdrawal of what he said were 25,000 American military personnel disguised as civilians in South Vietnam.

title: HIGH COURT EASES POLLUTION RULE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Supreme Court ruled today that states may exempt some violators from compliance with air pollution requirements without Federal approval as long as the states achieve and maintain national standards for atmospheric quality.

title: Death Penalty Law Upheld
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 16 (AP)  The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals upheld the state's new death penalty law today. The law was passed in 1973 after the United States Supreme Court struck down the old capital punishment law. The Texas court ruled that the new law was constitutional and valid under the latest Supreme Court ruling.

title: Jailed Kahane Is Allowed Out 7 Hours a Day to Pray and Eat
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, head of the militant Jewish Defense League, who was sentenced this year to serve 12 months in Federal prison, has been staying here in a halfway house with permission to leave it for seven hours a day to attend religious services and eat in kosher restaurants.

title: I.R.S. DATA SYSTEM MAY HAVE STRAYED
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service published documents today showing that its controversial information gathering and retrieval system may have contained nontaxrelated information about individuals.

title: DIM FUTURE HELD ON LEVITT PROFIT
description: Levitt & Sons, Inc., the giant housing developer responsible for building such Long Island communities as Levittown, faces unprofitable and capital absorbing operations for the indefinite future, according to a report by a courtappointed trustee, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: CHAD JUNTA NAMES A CHIEF OF STATE
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 16 A 42yearold brigadier general who was arrested 21 months ago on charges of trying to take over the country was named chief of state today.

title: Business Leaders Assert Recession Nears a Low Point
description: Even as the nation suffers from some of the grimmest economic conditions since the nineteenforties, a number of industrialists and businessmen across the country say they are convinced that the current recession is reaching its low point.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Thursday, April 17, 1975

title: DUBCEK INFORMED HE CAN PACK BAGS
description: PRAGUE, April 16 (Reuters) Alexander Dubcek, the former Czechoslovak Communist party leader whose reformist regime was ended by the 1968 Sovietled invasion by Warsaw Pacts forces, was told today that he could pack his bags tomorrow and move to the West.

title: SCHOOL VIOLENCE SPLITS EDUCATORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The rival heads of the two largest teachers' organizations; clashed at a Senate hearing today over the root causes of and potential solutions to rapidly increasing violence in the nation's public schools.

title: Walton Defends Opinions
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 16 (UPI)Bill Walton said today his controversial views about the Government should not be detrimental to his professional basketball career because he had not said anything harmful about anyone on the team.

title: AMEX IN REBOUND FOR MIXED CLOSE
description: After being lower most of the day, prices on the American Stock Exchange staged a comeback in the afternoon and closed mixed in slow trading. Prices finished higher in the overthecounter market in decreased trading.

title: New Delhi Continues Criticism of U. S.; Acts on Sikkim State
description: NEW DELHI, April 16India criticized the United States today and, in a separate development, moved rapidly to make Sikkim a full state within the Indian union.

title: CLERICS IN SEOUL PROTEST HANGINGS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 16A group of American missionaries staged a silent demonstration in the United States Embassy compound today, urging Washington to make a stronger protest to the South Korean Government over the hanging last week of eight men convicted of being Communists.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The collection of contemporary Guatemalan weavings on display and for sale in the print shop at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for another month gives a good idea of the traditional national dress worn by descendants of the ancient Maya.

title: Widening Chasm on Oil
description: PARIS, April 16The collapse of the preparatory talks here on a world energy conference amounted to a major diplomatic setback, according to some exhausted officials early this morning. Tile divisions showing, through the nineday meeting, which broke down late, yesterday, have widened gaps between France her western European partners as well as the United States.

title: Warriors Down Sonics
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 (AP)  Fred Brown came off the bench to score 26 points, including 12 in the final quarter, and led the Seattle SuperSonics to a 10099 victory over Golden State tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: As scores of police officers lined nearby roofs and blocked off traffic in what officials described as the heaviest security ever imposed at the State Supreme Court Building in the Bronx, eight Rikers Island inmates were brought to the courthouse, 831 Grand Concourse, and arraigned on charges of attempting an escape last Feb. 16. The eight, all but two of whom are reputed members of the socalled Black Liberation Army, included Herbert Bell and Albert Washington, both recently convicted of murdering Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini.

title: Homo Sapiens Has His Hour as Connecticut's State Animal
description: HARTFORD, April 16The Connecticut State Senate, in a frolicsome mood, voted today to designate Homo sapienshapless, taxridden man as the state animal.

title: Nordic Ship's Visit Stirs Ripple of Hope for Port
description: The Royal Viking Sea, one of the new maritime breed whose only destination is pleasure, yesterday struck up a nodding acquaintance that could become a lifelong attachment to the Port of New York.

title: Fun in the Land of the Bong Tree
description: Animals have always been a rich source for the plots of children's stories and The Owl and the Pussycat, with original music appealingly incorporated into the play, based on Edward Lear's 19thcentury poem, is no exception.

title: G.T.E Sees Gains Ahead
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 16 Telephone rate increases allowed by Federal and state regulatory agencies, healing of the nation's economic woes and the increases in the investment tax credit to 10 per cent from 4 per cent will combine during the latter half of this year to improve the growth possibilities and earnings of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, its shareholders were told today at their annual meeting here.

title: Films
description: WORLD WITHOUT SUN (1964; 93 minutes) by JacquesYves Cousteau, 12:30 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at Films for Children Program. Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. 9657078.

title: Giscard d'Estaing Will Not Take Part In a NATO Summit
description: PARIS, April 6The French Government said today that if a meeting of President Ford and other leaders of Atlantic alliance countries was held next month, as has been proposed, it would send Foreign Minister Jean Sauvagnaraues.

title: Appeals Court Rules Out Race As Sole Bar to Private Schools
description: RICHMOND, April 16 (AP)A black applicant who meets all requirements cannot be rejected for admission to a private school if race is the only basis for rejection, a Federal Appeals Court ruled today.

title: Workers Give Union Power To Strike Amex on May 1
description: Clerical workers of the American Stock Exchange have voted to strike on May 1, Local 205 of the United Financial Employes Union said yesterday, if they are unable to negotiate a new contract.

title: CommunistLed Rebel Force Combines Diverse Groups
description: The insurgent force that is taking control of Cambodia was forged from several disparate groups, with opposition to American intervention as one of their central rallying points.

title: PHILADELPHIA AIDE CITED IN EXTORTION
description: PHILADELPHA, April 16 (UPI)The city's Managing Director, Hillel Levinson, was indicted yesterday on charges of extortion, illegally demanding political contributions, perjury and violation of provisions of the Philadelphia Home Pule Charter, which forbids solicitation of political contributions.

title: People and Business
description: Walter Frey, general director of the Swiss Bank Corporation, said yesterday that he expected Arab and other oilexporting countries to start putting some of their surplus petrodollars into gold.

title: GROSSI IS CALLED KICKBACK SEEKER
description: ELIZABETH, April 16Anthony J. Grossly president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, was identified today by a witness at the bidrigging conspiracy trial of J. Edward Crabiel as a caller who asked a construction company executive 10 or 12 years ago to give a 10 per cent kickback envelope to a messenger known as G.I. Jimmy.

title: The Peace Must Be Vietnamized
description: PARISHistory, we are told, never repeats Itself. Yet we can remember as yesterday the end of Kuomintang China on the mainland; we have just witnessed the end of Lon Nol's republican regime in Cambodia, and tomorrow will see the end of nationalist South Vietnam.

title: PSYCHIATRIST NAMED IN FRAUD INDICTMENT
description: MORRISTOWN, April 16A Morris County grand jury investigating the operation of the state's Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital today indicted a former staff psychiatrist, Dr. Romeo Perugganan of Clifton, on 12 counts of Medicaid fraud for alleged filing of $7,674 in false claims.

title: A.T.&T's Earnings Down 10%; PoliticalFund Inquiry Ordered
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 16John D. de Butts, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, reported today that the company's earnings in the first quarter of this yearearlier period. The earn$1.19 a share from $1.32 in the year earlier period. The earnings were up slightly from the $1.15 a share of 1974's final quarter.

title: Radhakrishnan of India, Philosopher, Dead at 86
description: MADRAS, India Thursday, April 17 (AP)Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, philosopher and statesman who was President of India from 1962 to 1967, died here today of heart failure in a nursing home. He was 86 Years old.

title: J. Anthony Panuch Dies at 75; Was Adviser to U.S. and City
description: J. Anthony Panuch, an expert on business and government reorganization, died Tuesday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 75 years old and lived in the District of Columbia.

title: Oneupmanship in Rails
description: In the last few years railroad labor and management have come a long way from the dependent relationships that made a mockery of the peacemaking procedures of the Railway Labor Act and forced Congress to enact one emergency law after another to prevent paralyzing strikes. Collective bargaining has been made to work through mutual recognition of the depressed state of the industry.

title: Don Newcombe a Hit With 78 TeenAgers At Economy Parley
description: Don Newcombe, the former Dodger pitcher, yesterday received the warmest reception anyone has gotten yet at this week's youth seminar on the economy when he graphically told 78 high school sophomores about his conquest of alcoholism.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN POSTS RISE IN NET
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that first  quarter earnings climbed nearly 72 per cent, the largest gain among the nation's 10 most profitable banks.

title: Youth, 17 Holds a Woman, Hostage on Subway Train
description: A woman subway passenger was held hostage at knifepoint for nearly an hour yesterday by a. youth who pleaded guilty three days ago to two subway robberies committed last year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 17, 1975

title: Market Place
description: It almost seems as if the cautious investor can't make money these days.

title: S.E.C.Says Northrop Kept $30Million Secret Fund
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today accusing the Northrop Corporation of maintaining a secret fund of $30million for political and other purposes, at least some of them illegal.

title: Bank Declines Comment
description: A spokesman for the Irving Trust Company in New York cited the confidentiality of bankerclient relationships in declining comment on any aspect of the report of a message from a Cambodian bank.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, April 16 (UPI)Sweden poured in 11 goals in the last two periods today and defeated a deflated United States team, 123, in the world ice hockey championships. It was the Americans' ninth straight loss, the third time they had allowed 10 or more goals and their second defeat by Sweden.

title: Nets' Demise in Playoffs Deemed a Matter of Spirit
description: to themselves. With the Knicks' elimination from the N.B.A. playoffs even some N.B.A. diehards might have gone to the Coliseum to watch the Nets or perhaps read about them in the newspapers.

title: Sadat Swears In New Cabinet; Names General Vice President
description: CAIRO, April 16President Anwar elSadat swore in a new Cibinet toddy under Premier Mamdouh Salein, the former Minister of Interior and Police official.

title: American Airlines Loss Grows To $22Million in the Quarter
description: American Airlines reported yesterday a $22million loss for the quarter to March 31, more than twice as large as the yearearlier $10.5million loss. Passenger traffic fell 4.7 per cent.

title: Byrne Formally Proposes $1.1Billion Tax Program
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 16  Governor Byrne formally proposed today a $1.1billion tax program that includes a graduated state income tax and promises $300million in local property tax relief.

title: House Defies Ford, Adds Billion to First Fund Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 16In what may be the forerunner of fiscal battles between the White House and Congress, the House of Representatives passed today its first regular appropriations bill for the fiscal year 1976 with $1billion more than President Ford had sought.

title: WOUNDED OFFICER KILLS A SUSPECT
description: A young robbery suspect was shot and killed in the lobby of a Bronx apartment building last night, moments after he allegedly pulled a gun stolen from a policeman five years ago and shot a police officer in the neck.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In its effort to make Joe Namath an offer he can't refuse, the new World Football League (not to be confused with the old W.F.L. that was in the hands of the receivers rather than the quarterbacks) yesterday introduced Godfather III, alias Eugene Pullano, a Chicago millionaire who apparently enjoys the image he realizes he projects. As the spokesman for the Chicago franchise that hopes to steal Joe Namath from the New York Jets for $4million, 44yearold Eugene Pullano was wearing a gray tweed suit with a gray tweed vest, gray shoes and a diamond ring only slightly smaller than the WaldorfAstoria Hotel chandelier above. He was holding a Bloody Mary and a cigarette one hand and he used his other hand to display a telegram that vouched for $1,209,250 in franchise money. My friends, he said easily, were dropping $75,000 checks on my desk all Friday morning. His black hair curled fashionably and when he was asked his profession, he replied, Bookmaker. He laughed, then explained that he is in insurance and real estate, but that's really just another form of taking bets. He looks as if he should be sitting in a dark corner of Bachelors III with a white telephone on his private table. He hasn't had a meeting with Joe Namath yet but when he does, the Jets can begin counting on Al Woodall as their quarterback. Eugene Pullano is Joe Namath's kind of people, with or without an offer the quarterback can't refuse.

title: At Union, There Is Strength
description: Emphasizing the fact that he must work with at least some new material each year, Gordon LeMatty should have been caught by time and the law of averages. But this is LeMatty's 17th year as coach of the Union High School baseball team, and he still hasn't had a losing season. His teams have won 330 games and lost 108 over that span, and since his latest team opened the season with five straight victories, the pattern hasn't changed.

title: Camp Safety
description: Although eight million children attend summer camps, barely half of the states have any minimum standards for camp operations and not all of those provide any inspection or enforcement. Most parents are more in the dark than they realize when they select summer camps that may operate hazardous equipment, employ unqualified bus drivers and expose children to preventable risks.

title: Notes on People
description: San Antonio staked its claim yesterday as the first of the country's 10 largest cities to elect a woman Mayor following the victory of Councilwoman Lila Cockrell in a runoff election Tuesday. In the city's first direct balloting for Mayor in 25 years, the 53yearold veteran council member defeated John Monfrey, a beer wholesaler, by more than 12,000 Votes. The city's planning commission said populationgrowth estimates showed San Antonio with 775,000 residents, making it the ninth largest city.

title: Price of Fuel Oil Cut by $1 a Barrel By Indonesia Unit
description: Pertamina, the Indonesian stateowned oil company, has Cut its price for lowsulphur heavy fuel by $1 a barrel to $13.20, the Far East Oil Trading Company of Japan reported yesterday from Tokyo.

title: U.S. Considers Corridor To Evacuate Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, told a Senate committee today that the Pentagon was considering establishing a corridor from Saigon to the sea to evacuate tens of thousands of Vietnamese.

title: Chiang Kaishek Interred In Country Villa He Loved
description: TAOYUAN, Taiwan, April 16  President Chiang Kaishek, the last of the allied leaders of World War II, was interred here today beside a mountain lake.

title: A Live Ford Interview Set Monday by C.B.S.
description: CBS News will broadcast a onehour live interview with President Ford on television Monday at 10 P.M. Called A Conversation with the President, the interview will take place in the Blue Room of the White House with the CBS News correspondents Walter Cronkite, Eric Sevareid and Bob Schieffer asking the questions.

title: Fraud Studied in Sale of Bulbs to Help Disabled
description: NEWARK, April 16A Federal grand jury here is investigating a number of complaints that some companies allegedly sold light bulbs and other products at exorbitant prices by falsely stating that they were aiding the handicapped.

title: Nets to Make Refunds by Mail
description: Refunds on New York Nets tickets for home playoff games No. 4 and No. 5 will be made starting May 1.

description: When Digger Phelps walked into the gymnasium at the MosholuMontefiore Community Center the other night, everybody turned and stared. Though coaches from many other colleges were there to Watch the center's postseason basketball: tournament, the Notre Dame coach caused the greatest stir.

title: 14 County Executives Cite Crisis in Welfare Funds
description: Declaring that New York City was not alone in its money problems, 14 County Executives told their tales of fiscal woe yesterday in a bid for more state aid.

description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)Marching to the Bicentennial drummer, the Boston Public Library has proclaimed freedom from fines for all overdue material returned between today and May 31. The library said it sent cards announcing the program in anticipation of the Bicentennial celebration to all residents of the state who have overdue material.

description: The New York Islanders, who knocked wood whenever mention was made of their relatively injuryfree season, are now knocking at the office door of their team doctor.

description: Thomas G. Weaver, a judge of the Criminal Court, died Tuesday evening in San Juan, P. R., where he was attending a meeting of the United Church of Christ's Board for Homeland Ministries, of which he was president. He was 57 years old and lived here at 100 LaSalle Street.

title: BIEN HOA POUNDED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 17  Government units holding the approaches to the devastated city of Xuan Loc, 38 miles northeast of here, were falling back yesterday as the military, situation for Saigon appeared to worsen.

description: Three New York Times reporters won awards yesterday for excellence in news coverage. They were among winners of 15 Medallion Awards announced by the Silurians, an organization of journalists. The winners are to be honored at the group's annual dinner on May 7.

Mr. Wald man is a great one for searching out important but littleplayed music by major composers, and through the years his programs have been an importanteven a majorsupplement to the more orthodox programs offered by the big symphonic organizations.

And it is worth seeing, despite the score's feebleness and the implausibility of the story, one of those kitschy affairs that fed the Viennese taste for sentimentality and decadence between the World Wars.

description: Margaux Hemingway was afraid she'd be late, so she arranged for a helicopter from the airport. She hoped it would land in Central Park, but the nearest she could get was the East River. The trip crosstown took her so long, she was late anyway, but she performed her modeling stint alone, after the show was over.

description: A gang of five teenagers and a 13yearold boy have been arrested and charged with the murders of three impoverished elderly men in the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn in the first three months of this year.

description: Yankee pitchers have given up so many home runs this young season that fans are wondering if, when the catcher gives the signs, he flashes one finger for a fastball, two fingers for a curveball and three for a homerun ball.

Today, at the age of 66, the cartoonist who has chronicled events in Dogpatch, U.S.A., for 90 million readers, will see his work, on canvas, hang in a museum.

Marcos said today that defense and economic agreements between the Philippines and the United States must be urgently updated for reasons of survival because the balance of power in Asia has been disturbed by current developments in Indochina.

title: Bullets Whip Braves, 11196, Go Up, 21
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 16 Phil Chenier, who played only nine minutes in the first half because Coach K. C. Jones thought he was missing wideopen shots, struck for 18 points in the third period tonight to spark the Washington Bullets to a 11196 victory over the Buffalo Braves before a capacity crowd of 19,035 at Capital Centre.

title: 2 Indian Leaders' Acquittal Is Upheld by Appeals Court
description: ST. LOUIS, April 16 (UPI)A Federal Court dismissed today the Justice Department's appeal of the acquittal of two American Indian Movement leaders, Russell Means and Dennis Banks, for their part in the 71day occupation of Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1973.

description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)president Richard M. Nixon's chief disarmament negotiator called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to eliminate their landbased missile defenses.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FAR AFIELD While Columbia University's culture festival is spread over its campus, another spring celebration is also under way in the same neighborhood, although on a smaller scale. It is the eighth annual Folk Festival of the Balkan Arts Center (2220550), which has headquarters at 514 West 110th Street and is sponsoring a series of lectures, workshops, concerts and parties into midMay.

title: Books of The Times
description: Not being a snowplow operator, a damkeeper, or a picnicgoer, I have never much worried about the weather. To me, it's what nobody's ever been able to do anything about (except maybe those people who sprinkle silveriodide on clouds to make, rain) but what everybody talks about when he can't think of anything else to say. Rain, sunshine; it's never mattered. Which is a pretty dumb attitude, I've now discovered from reading The Weather Machine: How Our Weather Works and Why It Is Changing, by Nigel Calder, the English science popularizer. After all, Mr. Calder explains half in earnest, it was because of. the atrociously wet summer in Switzerland in 1816 that Mary Shelley's mood turned gloomy and produced Frankenstein. After all, he explains more seriously, in northern France in 1788 May, June and July were excessively hot and the grain shriveled. On 13 July, just at harvest time, a severe hailstorm added to the losses of many farmers. From that bad harvest of 1788 came the bread riots of 1789, Marie Antoinette's alleged remark let them eat cake, and the storming of the Bastille. That's the sort of thing the weatherworriers are finding out these days. Mr. Calder doesn't mention why the herring left the Baltic Sea in the 17th century and thus helped to break up the Hanseatic League, but I'll bet the weather Was involved. It really matters.

title: U.S. Reports on Home Starts and Income Indicates Business Downturn Is Slowing
description: WASHINGTON, April 16New figures on homebuilding and on individual incomes, made public by the Commerce Department today, gave further evidence that the pace of the business downturn is slowing but disclosed no real sign of an upturn yet.

title: Arts Complex Dedicated by Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 16Rutgers University dedicated a $6million arts center on the Douglass College campus today.

title: Mr. Ford's Illusion
description: In a desperate effort to shore up his request for a massive new dose of military aid to Saigon, President Ford has now told the world that the debacle in Vietnam was caused by the fact that the Soviet Union and Communist China honored their commitments, while the United States failed to do so. It is as incredible as it inaccurate for the President of the United States to justify a bankrupt policy by portraying the two Communist superpowers as more trustworthy than the United States.

title: Thai Government Orders Evacuees Out Within 30 Days
description: BANGKOK; Thailand, April 16Thailand's Foreign Minister, in a further indication of this country's shifting foreign policies, announced today that all Cambodian refugees flown here by the United States in recent days must leave Thailand in 30 days.

title: White Flag
description: Cambodia's weary leadership has raised the white flag of surrender. Five years of bloody, futile warfare have ended. The fate of Cambodia's people, of the countless frightened refugees huddled in their fallen capital, now hangs on the readiness of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and other insurgent leaders to demonstrate that they can be responsible in victory.

title: Times Man in Cambodia Lauded by State Senate
description: ALBANY, April 16  Sydney H. Schanherg, the correspondent of The New York Times who voluntarily remained in Phnom Penh to cover the fighting there, was honored by the State Senate today.

title: Business Leaders Assert Recession Nears a Low Point

title: Text of Phnom Penh's CeaseFire Offer
description: PEKING, April 16 (Agence FrancePresse)Following, in translation, is the text of the Phnom Perth Government's offer of a ceasefire and a transfer of power to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, as relayed by Roger E. Gallopin, president of the Executive Committee of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva, and released here today by the Prince's Cabinet. The offer, signed by Lieut., Gen. Saksut Sakhan, head of the military Governmerit, was introduced and concluded by a message from the Red Cross official.

title: Truce Was Sought
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Thursday, April 17 The Cambodian military Government asked yesterday for an immediate ceasefire from the Cambodian insurgents, who were attacking Phnom Penh from all sides. The Government said it would turn over power to them.

title: W.F.L. Is Replaced by League Called NEW W.F.L.

Christopher Hemmeter, the 35yearold businessman from Honolulu who has been the architect of the reorganization over the last four months, announced the plans here yesterday for the league, which concluded its first season almost $10million in debt.

title: Advertising
description: Despite torrents of negative news stories, a corporation can quickly rebuild its image if it is willing to spend the money for good deeds and the advertising to let the world know about them.

title: 5YEAR WAR ENDS
description: The Cambodian Communists swiftly set up headquarters yesterday in Phnom Penh a few hours after the Cambodian capital was surrendered to them.

title: Magazines' Readership Explored
description: The stability of magazine audiences is a myth, said Timothy Joyce, who had already shown the graphs that proved his point.

title: U.S. News From Cambodia Ends As Communication Lines Are Cut
description: Dispatches from American news sources in Phnom Penh ended early yesterday when communications lines were broken a few hours after the surrender of the Cambodian Government.

title: British Regiment Is Recreated in Massachusetts
description: CHELMSFORD, Mass. What would the battles of Concord and Lexington be without the British?

title: El Shafei Tops Laver By 76, 75
description: DENVER, April 17 (AP)Ismail El Shafei of Egypt continued to bedevil Rod Laver, beating the topseeded Australian, 76, 75 tonight in a World Championship of Tennis Blue Group tournament match.

title: T.W.A. and United in the Red; National Airlines Posts a Profit
description: The nation's two largest air carriers, United and T.W.A., yesterday reported deep deficits for the three months ended Marh 31. National, the No. 10 airline from the standpoint of revenue passenger miles flown, reported a $6.3million profit however.

title: Old Patrician Le Phnom Gets New Plebeian Role
description: PHNOM PENH. Cambodia, April 17After dark tonight, before the Government surrendered to the Cambodian Communists, a few hundred refugees gathered at the gates of the Hotel Le Phnom, which the Red Cross has established as a neutral zone.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Cambodian Communists swiftly set up headquarters in Phnom Penh following its surrender. According to a broadcast monitored in Bangkok, Thailand, they invited ministers and generals in the military Government who have not run away to join in formulating measures to restore order. The streets were reported quiet some hours after thousands were said to have stood mi the sidewalk waving to the entering Communist troops, [Page 1, Columns 58.]

title: Airlift of Young Vietnamese to Resume
description: WASHINGTON, April 17An official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that the airlift of children from South Vietnam, which had been halted, would resume in a day or two and that no evidence of any illegality had been found in their evacuation.

title: Mrs. Abzug Wins Points Meant Initially for Carey
description: WASHINGTON, April 17One measure of how serious Representative Bella S. Abvug appears to he about running for the United States Senate next year is that with less then 24 hours notice she agreed to be the principal speaker at the $15aplate Chemung County Democratic dinner in Elmira last Sunday after Governor Carey canceled his appearance.

title: Donald Elliott Will Head The Urban Coalition Here
description: Donald H. Elliott, former chairman of the City Planning Commission here, was named yesterday to succeed Herbert B. Woodman as chairman of, the New York Urban Coalition. Mr. Elliott, a lawyer, will take over the post on June 1, when Mr. Woodman, who is 70 years old retires.

title: A Tragic Tradition
description: Mr. Speaker, a recent article in The New York Times reports on the design of a special rifle to commemorate the Bicentennial. The rifle, to be produced in only 200 copies, will be priced at $5,800$7,250 each. The gunmaker stated: The gun is not only weapon, it's a tradition.

title: Red Smith
description: If Muhammad Ali can get $1.6million for making faces at Chuck Wepner and $5million for that entertainment with George Foreman in Zaire, then Tony Perez is right in line with the market when he demands $20million from All for badmouthing him and another $20million from American Broadcasting Company for letting Ali do it on the air. Inflation isn't whipped yet. The things the heavyweight champion said about the referee of his last bout were crueler than any punches thrown by Foreman or Wepner, although, of course, it is for judges and juries to decide whether Perez has been damaged and how much. Tony is charging libel, but it says here that Ali's real offense is ingratitude. When he should have been thanking the referee from the bottom of his heart, he threw a tantrum and called Perez a dirty dog.

title: Overdue African Caller
description: If the United States is as anxious to improve relations with black Africa as Secretary of State Kissinger insists, the next two days will offer the best possible opportunity to make a fresh start. President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, one of two key figures in a new effort to achieve peaceful solutions for the remaining blackwhite problems in southern Africa, arrives in Washington today for an overdue White House visit.

title: Thailand Seals Border
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 17 (UPI)Thailand sealed her border with Cambodia today after the surrender of Phnom Penh, but refugees managed to fly into the country on Cambodian aircraft.

title: Berio Concert Provides A View of a Challenge
description: Luciano Berio is one of several European avantgardist composers whose work has challenged the reigning orthodoxy of the postWorld War II period: the belief, that is, that the serial techniques and general esthetic approach of Webern were the only valid directions to be taken in modern music. If that orthodoxy seems to have broken down, the Italian composer's work might be regarded as a kind of wrecker's ball by the old believersor as a crystal ball showing the future by those who believe postWebernism has had its day.

title: Bronx Girl, 14, Slain; School Aide Held
description: A 14yearold Bronx girl was slain last night near High Bridge Park in upper ManhatStan, and shortly afterward a 26yearold man identified as a narcotics counselor at het school was arrested for the crime.

title: SENATE APPROVES FARM LEGISLATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (NPI)  Chalenging a threatened Presidential veto, the Sente passed today an emergency farm support bill that backers said would provide insurance against a farm depression without raising retail food prices.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: While visiting with Dan North of CrotononHudson, N.Y., and his family recently, my host, whose interests are as varied as his spirit is large, dragged forth a sheaf of notes he had made concerning the derivations of the common names of birds.

title: Ousted Officials in Chad Await Army's Decision on Their Fate
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 17 Scores of former government officials are waiting in their homes here to be told by the new military Government whether, as one put it, we will go back to work or to jail.

title: Merrick Acquires Fall Creek Rights
description: David Merrick has paid $250,000 for movie rights to The Massacre at Fall Creek, the novel by Jessamyn West published this month by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. The books based on the murder of nine Indians and the subsequent trial of four white suspects at Fall Creek, Ind., in 1824.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A measure that would repeal New Jersey's 37yearold fair trade law, which authorizes minimumprice fixing by manufacturers on brandname consumer products, was approved unanimously yesterday in the Assembly.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.Dale Hernandez, 136 pounds, Omaha, Neb., knocked out Rod Centreras, 136, Los Angeles, 5 rounds.

title: Fair Trade Laws' Repeal Wins Final Albany Passage
description: ALBANY, April 17Repeal of New York's 35yearold fair trade lawswhich permit manufacturers to set a floor under priceswas given final legislative approval by the Senate today. It was sent For certain signature to Governor Carey, who had recommended it.

title: Splashing Debut for First Polar Bear Born in Bronx
description: The first polar bear to be born at the Bronx zoo went on public display yesterday for the first time amid delighted Oohh's! and Aaah's! and the furious clicking of cameras.

title: NARCOTICS SCHEME TRACED TO PRISM
description: Five men were indicted here yesterday on charges of smuggling heroin into the United States in a major narcotics conspiracy that was allegedly planned and organized in a Federal prison.

title: Aeros Eliminate Crusaders
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (AP)Firstperiod goals by Gordie Howe and Larry Lund helped the Houston Aeros defeat Cleveland, 31, tonight, and eliminate the Crusaders from the World Hockey Association playoffs.

title: Saigon Apparently Braces For a Direct Thrust by Foe
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 18  Government troops were reported holding yesterday at Xuan Loc, 38 miles to the northeast, and making sonic gains nearby, but here in the capital fears grew that. Saigon itself was about to conie under heavy attack.

title: Palmer Trails by 3 In Spanish Golf
description: LA MANGA, Spain, April 17 (UPI)  Arnold Palmer posted a threeunderpar 69 today to move within three shots of John O'Leary of Ireland at the halfway stage of the $67,000 Spanish open golf championship. O'Leary, a streak player on the British circuit, took La Manga's 6,780yard course apart with a sevenunderpar 65 for a 36hole total of 138. Palmer is at 141.

title: Miss Onassis Denies Her Father Planned Divorce
description: PARIS, April 17 (AP)Christina Onassis, daughter of the late Aristotle Onassis and principal heir to his shipping fortune, denied today that her father had planned to divorce Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: Fair Trade Laws' Repeal Wins Final Albany Passage
description: ALBANY, April 17Repeal of New York's 35yearold fair trade lawswhich permit manufacturers to set a floor under priceswas given final legislative approval by the Senate today. It was sent for certain signature to Governor Carey, who had recommended it.

title: W. T. Grant Given A Loan Extension By 27 Main Banks
description: The W. T. Grant Company said yesterday that its 27 major hanks had extended their loan agreements to March 31, 1976. These banks account for over $540million of Grant's $600million shortterm bank debt maturing June 2, 1975.

title: U.S. BONDS SHOW A PRICE DECLINE
description: Prices sank in the Government securities market yesterday as a spell of sudden nervousness affected dealers and investors. This pullback, in contrast to the firm tone prevailing in recent days, affected the corporate sector, where bonds showed fractional losses. However, all corporate offerings were well received in a busy session for new bond issues.

title: Senate Backs a Bill On National Market
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)The Senate approved today legislation directing the Securities and Exchange Commission to set up a national market system. The bill was approved by voice vote and sent to the House of Representatives.

title: Lone Pine Small Talk: Bf8+... Kc7... Nc16+
description: LONE PINE, Calif., April 17The last time anyone lield a regular sporting event in Lone Pine the participants were a bull and a bear Chained together in a pit, cheered in their fight to the death by the roughneck miners and ranchers who formed this community at the turn of the century.

title: After 110 Years, a President Goes to Ford's Theater
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)  President Ford broke historic precedent tonight, becoming the first President to attend a performance at Ford's Theater in the 110 years since Abraham Lincoln was assassinated there.

title: LOAN RATE DATA WILL BE RELEASER
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Federal Reserve Board has agreed to make public information on bank interest rates that could help consumers shop for the most competitive interest on loans.

title: Carey Seeks to Strengthen State's Role on Land Use
description: ALBANY, April 17Governor Carey, declaring that protection of the environment is not a luxury which can be put off until a happier time, submitted to the Legislature today a series of environmentalconservation bills that would strengthen the state's hand in determining or influencing the use of land now under local control.

title: The Evacuation Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 17There is a growing suspicion among members of Congress that the Administration's words about a moral obligation to supply military aid to Saigon are really a charade; that the real object underlying the rhetoric is to gain time to rescue Americans still in Saigon. Neither the White House nor Congress can openly admit that what they are discussing is not how best to aid Saigon but how best to insure the safe withdrawal of the Americans.

title: Soviet Sextet Captures World Title
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, April 17 (AP)The Soviet Union won its 14th world ice hockey championship by defeating Czechoslovakia, 41, for the title today in a tightchecking game that was broken open in the final minutes when Victor Shalimov scored two goals. Until Shalimov connected, the Soviet team was protecting a 21 edge built on Vladimir Petrov's powerplay goal in the final minute of the first period and a goal by Vladimir Lutchenko, a defenseman, in the opening minute of the second period.

title: For Caramanlis, Loyalty but Not Votes
description: CORFU, Greece, April 13We're with the opposition, said a liquor importer here the other day, but we support Caramanlis 100 per cent. He's handled all the issues in a very manly way.

title: 2,000 in Hotel Refuge
description: GENEVA, April 17The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that about 2,000 people were being sheltered in Phnom Penh in the hospital and safety zone it had established in the Hotel Le Phnom there.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 8%
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Department of Commerce reported today that departmen?? mated sales last week were esti mated at $1.02billion, down 10 per cent from the yearear lier $1.13billion. Total retai?? store sales were about $10.92 billion, up 8 per cent from last year's $10.14billion.

title: U.N. Aide Says Environment Suffers for ShortTerm Gains
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 17Despite a vast increase in national programs around the world to protect the environment, there is a strong tendency to make major inroads into our irreplaceable environmental capital in pursuit of shortterm economic benefit, the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program said today.

title: Grip on Industry Lost By Old German Elite
description: DUSSELDORF, West GermanyThe wealthy elite of this industrial capital of the Rhine gather in the cafes and restaurants along the ??nigsallee to watch each other and to talk about their private art collections, private hunting reserves and villas

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE (Volume 3,502,175 shares)

title: Boy Crippled by a Falling Beam Wins $1Million Damage Award
description: NEWARK, April 17A 9yearold boy who was permanently paralyzed when he was struck by a 480pound steel beam being unloaded from a truck near his home nearly two years ago today was awarded $1million and lifetime medical care that might cost up to $500,000.

title: Hayden, Long a Peace Activist, Never Thought War Would End
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 17After years of seemingly futile protest, pilgrimages to Hanoi, arrests and trials, some leaders of the antiwar movement find it a little hard to believe that the end in Indochina is developing so swiftly.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: SHOCKLEY DEBATES THEORIES AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 17A year after disruptive protesters prevented a similar event, Wil liam Rusher, the publisher of National Review, and William B. Shockley, professor of engineering science at Stanford University whose genetic theories have aroused considerable controversy, faced each other on the Yale campus tonight in a debate on those theories.

title: For U.S. Envoy in Saigon, It's Business as Usual Amid Military Setbacks
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 As Saigon's military situation has continued to decline, Ambassador Graham A. Martin has astonished a number of officials here by running a business as usual operation at the American Embassy in Saigon.

title: Of Defeat and Victory
description: Ten years ago, on April 17, 1965, 25,000 people marched in Washington against the war in Vietnam. It was then two months after Lyndon Johnson had sealed his own fate as well as the fates of several nations by launching a massive invasion of Vietnam; it was only days after the marines had landed in Santo Domingo, toppling the democratic Government and adding that intervention to the long list of crimes against Latin America. The next decade would see hundreds of demonstrations involving millions of people, but April, 1965, was the first national demonstration against the

title: Highs and Lows
description: NEW HIGHS320

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Television executives have children on their minds these days. New policies instigated by pressure groups have already resulted in a reduced number of commercials permitted on weekend mornings.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Off
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.7 billion tonmiles, 9.4 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago, which included the Good Friday holiday for some railroads. Carloadings in the same period totaled 442,276 cars, 11.2 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 18.9 per cent below last year.

title: New Yorker Wins Magazine Award
description: The New Yorker has won the 1975 National Magazine Award for reporting excellence for its Supertankers series by Noel Mostert, and Consumer Reports has won the publicservice prize for an article on inferior local water supplies.

title: 50% Pay Increase To $60,000 Urged For U. S. Judges
description: Owen McGivern, the former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court for the First Department, urged yesterday an immediate 50 per cent increase in pay for Federal judges, saying that their present $40,000ayear salaries were forcing them into lives of honorable poverty.

title: S.E.C. Secret Fund Suit Against Northrop Settled
