description: WASHINGTON, April 17the Securities and Exchange Commission formally announced today the settlement of its suit against the Northrop Corporation and its board chairman, Thomas V. Jones, and a former vice president, James Allen.

title: Revue: Bette Midler
description: Bette Midler, the tackiest girl in town, has come home to roast at the tackiest theater on Broadway, the Minskoff. She opened last night with her Clams on the Half Shell Revue, and proved that it's oysters that produce pearls not clams.

title: Assembly Unit Votes Death Penalty And Easing of the Law on Marijuana
description: TRENTON, April 17Legislation that would abolish criminal penalties for the use of marijuana and restore the death penalty in New Jersey was approved by the Assembly's Judiciary Committee today.

title: LibbeyOwens Dividend Cut
description: The Libbey  Owens  Ford Company announced yesterday that it was cutting its quarterly dividend on common stock to 20 cents a share from 40 cents. The dividend is payable June 14 to shareholders of record May 16.

title: U.N. ACTS TO EXTEND SINAI PEACE FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17The Security Council voted today to extend for three months the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force separating Egyptian and Israeli troops in Sinai.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Citizens' Role in Revenue Sharing Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Congress was urged today to strengthen the protection for minorities and women in general revenuesharing legislation and to provide for more influence for citizens in decisions about the use of funds under the Federal program.

title: Cambodian Reds, in Paris, Pledge Neutrality Policy
description: PARIS, April 37The representatives here of the Cambodian Communists, in a triumphant news conference, said today that their new government would follow a policy of neutrality and nonalignment.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Diane Von Furstenberg, who no longer uses her title, Princess, in her business affairs, surveyed the crowd of 500 or so filling the chairs and lining the walls of the Hotel Pierre's Cotillion Room.

title: China Formally Seeks Olympic Reinstatement
description: China has applied to rejoin the Olympic sports movement, the International Olympic Committee announced yesterday.

title: SAFEWAY'S EARNING AND SALES ADVANCE
description: Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's largest grocery chain in terms of sales, yesterday reported sharp rises in sales and earnings for its latest fiscal quarter.

title: Miss Palmer Leads by Stroke
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 17Making her best start ever at the Mission Hills Club, cheery Sandra Palmer led the field with a twounderpar 70, facing a blustering wind down the stretch as scores skyrocketed in the opening round of the fourth annual ColgateDinah Shore golf tournament today.

title: Article 2  No Title
Some in India Deplore Action on Sikkim
description: NEW DELHI, April 17Criticism of the Government's decision to merge Sikkim with India grew today and questions arose about the future of the Chogyal, or King.

title: Notes on People
description: The International League for the Rights of Man will honor Mstislav Rostropovich and Galina Vishnevskaya tonight at a reception in the Central Park West home of Leonard and Felioia Bernstein. The Soviet cellist and his wife, the operatic soprano, who left the Soviet Union last year will receive the league's Human Rights Award for their courageous stand for artistic freedom. They have vowed not to return until such freedom is fully restored.

title: The Broadcast Picture
description: We are in a great haste to construct a magnetic telegraph from Maine to Texas, Thoreau wrote in 1854, and then added, but Maine and Texas, it may be, have nothing important to communicate.

title: Cambodian Reds, in Paris, Pledge Neutrality Policy
description: PARIS, April 17The representatives here of the Cambodian Communists, in a triumphant news conference, said today that their new government would follow a policy of neutrality and nonalignment.

title: Warriors Beat Sonics, Go Up, 21
description: SEATTLE, April 17 (AP)Rick Barry scored 33 points tonight and the Golden State Warriors went on to defeat the Seattle Supersonics, 10596, in their third National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoff game. The Warriors hold a 21 lead.

title: EXJUDGE TO HEAD INQUIRY ON ATTICA
description: Bernard S. Meyer, a former State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County, was named yesterday to head the independent inquiry into the charge that the chief Attica prosecutor covered up possible crimes by law enforcement officers.

title: Bribery Laid to 2 Lindenwold Officials
description: TRENTON, April 17  A statewide grand jury today indieted the Mayor and a former Mayor of Lindenwold in Camden County on bribery and misconduct charges in connection with the awarding of an engineering contract and the approval of sewerline connections.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: The sounds of musket fire, marching men and fifes and drums in scores of communities in the metropolitan area and throughout the nation will mark the effective opening this weekend of America's Bicentennial.

title: A Cambodian Leader
description: It was characteristic of the early confusion surrounding the insurgency against President Lon Nol's new Cambodian Government in 1970 that there were strong doubts whether one of the reported leaders of the movement, Khieu Samphan, was even alive.

title: Saigon Offers to Negotiate
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  In a private conversation with Senator John Sparkman of Alabama, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the Foreign Minister of South Vietnam, Vuong Van Bac, stated today that Saigon was prepared to negotiate a political and military settlement of the war with the North Vietnamese in Paris.

title: Dodgers Beat Reds And Sweep Series
description: Jimmy Wynn, who scored the deciding run yesterday that gave the, Los Angeles Dodgers a sweep of their fourgame series against the Cincinnati Reds, said, There is no way we can let down now. Man for man, we're better than the Reds. That's all there is to it.

title: Foreign Stock Index
description: fFinancial Times IIl Sole. dDow Jones. sSwiss Bank Corporation. n Tokyo new.

title: Market Place
description: It is already clear that on May 1, when stockbrokers' commission charges are to become fully competitive, one element in the picture will be confusion.

title: Nordiques Oust Roadrunners
description: QUEBEC, April 17 (AP) Marc Tardif, a left wing, scored the tiebreaking goal at 14:20 of the third period and the Quebec Nordiques went on to a 42 victory over Phoenix, eliminating the Roadrunners from the W.H.A. playoffs tonight.

title: U.S. OUTPUT FELL BY PEAK 10% RATE IN FIRST QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The nation's total output dropped at an annual rate of 10.4 per cent in the first quarter of this year, a record decline. It followed a 9 per cent decline in the final quarter of 1974.

title: Stern's Opens Fifth Store in State, in the Essex Green Shopping Center
description: WEST ORANGE, April 17Shoppers, most of them housewives, thronged Stern's today as the retail chain opened its fifth store in this state, in the Essex Green shopping center here. Stern's, which left New York City in 1969, is offering job opportunities to people in the Essex area, but the management personnel are mostly from within the Stern's operation.

title: WALDHEIM ENVOY IN HANOI FOR TALK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 Secretary General, Waldheim has sent a representative to Hanoi who is conducting talks with North Vietnamese and Vietcong authorities.

title: CityRand Consultant Institute Ending Because of Tight Budget, Beame Says
description: The New York CityRand Institute, the nonprofit management consultant organization set up in 1969 in the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay, will be dissolved on June 30, Mayor Beame said yesterday, because of the city's budget problems.

title: Dow Also Better
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday firstquarter net income rose 26.4 per cent to $115.7million, or $1.89 a share, from the $91.5million, or $'1.50 a share, in the first three months of 1974, while sales rose 27.3 per cent to $1.4billion from $1.1billion.

title: Indochina Food Aid Set
description: ROME, April 17 (Reuters)The World Food Program announced plans today to send $6million worth of highprotein food to Indochina at the request of Secretary General Waldheim of the U.N. it was announced here.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Mario's Villa d'Este, at 58 East 56th Street, is having its 30th birthday this year, but what can you give a restaurant that has everything? Here's a good professional kitchen, an unusually attractive dining room, a corps of excellent waiters to serve as liaison between the two, and a fan club that fills the tables even on Monday nights.

title: Japanese Comic Theater Gives 3 Rustic Sketches
description: Kyogen and Noll are contrasting forms of Japanese theater. The first is broadly comic, the latter poetic and tragic. Traditionally they share the same stage. In its 1971 visit to Carnegie Hall, Kyogen acted as a curtainraiser to Noh. For its brief New York engagement ending last night, also at Carnegie Hall (part of a tour to North, Central and South America), Kyogen was a curtain raiser to itself. No Nob followed, which made for a onenote evening.

title: Education Uncertainty
description: At the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in Manhattan, recent decisions about the college's reason for being have led to the termination of a mathematics degree program begun only last year. At the State University College at Buffalo, newly contructed but unfilled dormitories have been leased to Erie County for the last three years for housing for elderly persons.

title: Slayer of Wanaque Judge Is Sentenced to 28 Years
description: PATERSON, April 17A 20yearold youth who was convicted of seconddegree murder in the shooting of a Wanaque magistrate was sentenced today to a maximum penalty of 28 to 30 years in prison.

title: Physician Shot to Death In a Health Center Here
description: A 44yearold physician in charge of a municipal healthservice station in Brooklyn was shot to death yesterday afternoon by an unknown assailant as the physician sat in his office.

title: People in Sports
description: Juan Marichal announced his retirement from baseball yesterday and then showed up in the Los Angeles Dodgers dugout and talked with newsmen about his reasons. The 36yearold righthander, a San Francisco Giants star from 196073, was picked up by the Dodgers in spring training as a free agent after spending last season in the American League with the Boston Sox.

title: CLARA E. SIPPRELL, PHOTOGRAPHER, 89
description: Clara E. Sipprell, a photographer for 65 years who was well known for her portraits of the famous, died Tuesday in Bennington (Vt.) Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived in Manchester, Vt.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, April 17 (Reuters)The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today the House of Lords reduced the amount of damages payable by its British subsidiary to the General Tire Company following litigation over General Tire's rubber patents to the equivalent of $737,000, including interest, from about $3.29million.

title: Convicted in Castration
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI)A state court jury today convicted Kerry Andrus Crocker of castrating his 14yearold son by exposing him to radiation. The defense argued that Mr. Andrus had placed cesium capsules in the boy's couch bed.

title: Environmental Boldness
description: Governor Carey has submitted to the State Legislature an environmental protection program which far surpasses any of those ever drawn up by his predecessors.

title: New Rochelle Discloses $40Million Housing Plan
description: NEW ROCHELLE, April 17Plans for a major residential and entertainment complex that could change the face of downtown New Rochelle were disclosed today by city officials.

title: Books of The Times
description: It would not be unreasonable to say that a good short story is one of the most extreme expressions of what is going on in this country right now. And while the 18 selections in Prize Stories 1975: The O. Henry Awards are not all good, I think one can still base certain generalizations on the book. My first response to these stories is that there is little in most of them to get elated about. Then I would add that 2 of the 18 stories are extraordinaryperhaps not wholly satisfactory but capable of surprising us, surprising us radically, of altering our habits of perception. I will those for last.

title: POVERTY UNIT HEAD BEING INVESTIGATED
description: The city's Department of Investigation is inquiring Into reports that Henry Ramos, a leader of the Puerto Rican group of the District 1 Community School Board, misappropriated some $17,000 from a Lower East Side poverty agency he heads.

title: TV: Rachel Jackson Begins First Ladies Diaries'
description: What happens when the afternoon soapopera gang tries to get a bit more ambitious. One example can be found today at 1:30 on NBC. The 90minute specimen is First Ladies' Diaries: Rachel Jackson, the first in a planned series of three specials about the wives of American Presidents. What happens is painfully clear: soap opera in period costume.

title: A SPECIAL OFFICE WILL GIVE PERMITS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17The Saigon Government agreed today to speed the departure of the Vietnamese wives and children of Americans here, a move that is considered a breakthrough in the Vietnam evacuation effort.

title: Radhakrishnan Cremated With State Rites in Madras
description: NEW DELHI, April 17 (Reuters)  Sir Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, the philosopher and second President of India who died today, was cremated with full state honors in his home town of Madras tonight.

title: Connally Acquitted of Bribery Charge; Hints He May Resume Political Career
description: WASHINGTON, April 17John B. Connally was acquitted today of bribery charges in United States District Court.

title: CITY BAR GROUP CRITICIZES BREITEL
description: In a report highly critical of the state's chief judge, Charles D. Breitel, and his too aides, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York called yesterday for the immediate retransfer of Judge Bruce McM. Wright back to the Criminal Court.

title: Chase Realty Trust Posts Quarter Loss Totaling 82Million
description: The Chase Manhattan Mort gage and Realty Trust, the na tion's largest real estate invest ment trust, reported yesterday that its losses during the third quarter ended Feb. 28 amounted to $82.4million, including a $14.4million loss on operations and a special addition to its reserve fund to cover losses on loans of $68million.

title: Concert Put On Ice
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. April 17John Denver, who said he was a hockey fan, agreed tonight to cancel his soldout performance at the Nassau Coliseum on Sunday so the Islanders and Penguins could stage the fourth game of their playoff series over network television.

title: Manila Asks Talks Of 5Nation Group In Southeast Asia
description: MANILA, April 17In the face of the collapse of nonCommunist forces in Cambodia, the Philippine Government today proposed a meeting of the five members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

title: Snipers Mar Truce in Beirut Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17Security forces killed at least two snipers here today as unidentified armed men apparently tried to disrupt a ceasefire reached yesterday between Palestinian guerrillas and the rightwing Phalangist party militia.

title: In Memoriam
description: KERNHenry Charles. Your 43d birthday. Forever in our hearts. MOM and DAD, DOROTHE and JOE, SUSAN and DEBBI.

title: Islanders Lose and Trail, 30
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 17 The New York Islanders failed to solve the mystery tonight as the Pittsburgh Penguins ran through the plot for the third time, beating the Islanders, 64, and claiming their third consecutive victory in the fourof sevengame National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff series. The fourth game is slated for Sunday at 3:30 P.M. at Nassau Coliseum.

title: ALLWOMAN GROUP PLAYS SPIRITED JAZZ
description: Aside from a few singers and pianists, jazz would seem to be a no woman's land, judging by the exclusively male cast of most jazz groups. But the fact that there really are women instrumentalists in jazz was pointed up Wednesday evening in a program called  what else?Women in Jazz at the Executive Sweet in the Hotel Alden, at Central Park West and 82d Street, at which all the musicians were women.

title: Some of Last Messages From Encircled Capital
description: The following messages are among the last received by the Associated Press bureau in Hong Kong from Phnom Penh before communication lines went down a few hours after the surrender of the Cambodian Government yesterday.

title: Colleagues Consider Koch As Most Effective Member
description: The rain pelts the early morning rushhour passengers as they scurry down the subway steps at Lexington Avenue and 77th Street, clutching their newspapers and their closed umbrellas. They descend by the thousands, and at the first landing, partially protected from the rain, they see a familiar figure whose barker's spiel coaxes smiles from their faces.

title: Open Heart Surgery Reduction Suggested by a New Procedure
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 17A medical procedure performed this month for the first time Ion a human may eliminate the need for open heart surgery to correct certain heart defects in children.

title: Odds Are Long Against South Vietnam; Manpower and Weapons Insufficient
description: After more than four weeks. of fighting, the Vietnam campaign appears to United States: military sources to be entering a final phase in which Saigon's hopes for preventing a defeat are minimal. The North Vietnamese divisions closing in around the capital retain the tactical initiative they seized at Ban Me Thuot in the middle or March, in this View, and the South Vietnamese have neither the manpower nor the weapons to reverse the situation.

title: City Seeking to Centralize Lab Testing for Medicaid
description: The city is inviting bids on a new laboratory system that the Human Resources Administration said yesterday aimed to centralize Medicaid laboratory tests for each borough and to cut substantially costs that last year ran to about $12million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Hugo von Mendelssohn, 81, Composer's GreatGrandson
description: BASEL, Switzerland, April 17 (AP)Hugo von Mendelssohn Bartholdy, the last surviving greatgrandson of the German composer Felix Mendelssohn, died today. He was 81 years old.

title: Genetic Mutations Called Minor Evolutionary Factor
description: Two molecular biologists have challenged the conventional belief that mutations that alter the structure of individual genes are responsible for the major anatomical and behavioral differences between the various animal species.

title: DEPUTIES IN ITALY BACK NUCLEAR CURB
description: ROME, April 17  Italy's Chamber of Deputies today endorsed the 1968 treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons. Italy signed the treaty in 1969 but hesitated to ratify it.

title: Ford Prods Congress on Energy Action
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The White House made explicit today the threat that members of Congress, especially those drafting energy legislation, have been expecting for days.

title: Poll Finds a Reagan Race Could Spoil Ford Chance
description: If former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California ran on an independent Presidential ticket in 1976, he could spoil President Ford's chances Of winning, the Harris Poll reported yesterday.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Friday, April 18, 1975

title: U.S. OUTPUT FELL BY PEAK 10% RATE IN FIRST QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The nation's total output dropped at an annual rate of 10.4 per cent in the first quarter of this year, a record decline. It followed a 9 per cent decline in the final quarter of 1974.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KISSINGER CALLS AID DEBATE OVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Vietnam debate was over and that the Ford Administration would accept the verdict of Congress on its latest billiondollar aid request without recrimination or vindictiveness.

title: Atlanta Mayor Refuses to Oust Black
description: ATLANTA, April 17Spurn??ng loud demands from the minority white community, Atlanta's first black Mayor refused today to dismiss the city's first black Public Safety Commissioner.

title: Indiana Gets a Malpractice Law Designed to Stabilize Premiums
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 17Gov. Otis Bowen signed into law today a medical malpractice insurance bill intended to stabilize premium rates for such insurance and encourage reasonable outofcourt settlements of lawsuits most frequently brought by patients against physicians and surgeons.

title: 3 ExDetectives Are Convicted In Shakedown of Drug Dealers
description: Three former detectives of the Police Department's elite Special Investigations Unit were found guilty yesterday of having shaken down narcotics dealers for nearly $100,000.

title: Flyers Win, 20, and Lead, 30
description: TORONTO, April 17Home was anything but sweet for the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. Beaten twice in Philadelphia and shut out in the second game of their quarterfinal playoff, Toronto received more of the same here tonight as the Flyers won, 20, and took a 30 advantage in the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup series.

title: Sales Decline 12%
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday that firstquarter net income fell 30.6 per cent on a 12.1 per cent drop in sales and operating revenues. However, John D. Harper, chairman of the company, pointed out at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh that recent increases in order activity indicated that customer inventories of aluminum were dropping.

title: COCOA FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Cocoa futures dropped sharply yesterday following a report earlier in the week that cocoa grindings for chocolate making in France were off 17 per cent in the first quarter of 1975 from the year ago period. Grindings for the same period were down 28 per cent in Britain and 34 per cent in the United States.

title: Honduras Panel Concedes Signs of Banana Bribery
description: An investigating commission in Honduras conceded yesterday that there was some validity to charges that top Government officials had taken bribes from the United Brands Company.

title: Jury in Case of School Bombing Recesses After Last Arguments
description: CHARLESTON, W. VA., April 17The Federal jury trying a selfordained preacher and a former coal miner accused of conspiring to bomb schools in a dispute over textbooks was sent home for the night today without having deliberated on a verdict.

title: R. J. Reynolds Profit Up 2.8% to Record
Foolish Pleasure Is Sharp; Vasquez Escapes Penalty
description: Foolish Pleasure turned in an impressive workout yesterday demonstrating that he is in excellent shape for the $100,000 added Wood Memorial at Aqueduct tomorrow. Carrying 128 pounds with his regular jockey, Jacinto Vasquez, on his back, Foolish Pleasure stepped a halfmile at the Belmont Park training track in 0:46 1/5. Then, John Greer's colt eased up and turned in 0:58 4/5 for five furlongs.

title: 4 U.S. Ships Ready for Evacuation Role
description: At least four American cargo ships under charter to the Defense Department are off South Vietnam or on the way there with orders to stand by for possible evacuation of refugees, shipping executives said yesterday.

title: Ford Tells Congressmen He Opposes Bill for Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 17President Ford announced today his opposition to legislation pending in Congress the last six years that would establish a Federal consumer protection agency.

title: About Real Estate
description: Bit by inexorable bit, government is paying a higher price for the financial problems of privately owned rental housing, problems traceable mainly to the leap in fuel prices.

title: Modern Museum Names 3 Trustees
description: An architect, a publishing executive and the president of a brokerage concern have been elected trustees of the Museum of Modern Art, it was announced yesterday by William S. Paley, board chairman. They are Gordon Bun shaft, partner in the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; Paul Gottlieb, president of the American Heritage Publishing Cornpany, and Donald B. Marron, president of Mitchell, Hutchins, Inc.

title: EDITORS' PARLEY HEARS CRITICISM
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The nation's newspaper, editors were accused today, in effect, of being snobs, unable to see the world as 90 per cent of Americans experience it.

title: Article 1  No Title
More Texas Oil Output Set
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 17 (UPI) The Texas Railroad Commission, noting a reduction in oil imports, authorized today another month of maximum crude oil production in May. The threemember commission has authorized 100 per cent allowable production continuously since April, 1972, for all but a few Texas oil fields.

title: Food Day: Soyburgers for Some
description: Yesterday the soup du jour was bean. The peanut butter on whole wheat was highly recommended, along with the soyburger in pita bread. Or better stillthe empty plate.

title: Koch Given High Grades By State Representatives
description: The rain pelts the early morning rushhour passengers as they scurry down the subway steps at Lexington Avenue and 77th Street, clutching their newspapers and their closed umbrellas. They descend by the thousands, and at the first landing, partially protected from the rain, they see a familiar figure whose barker's spiel coaxes smiles from their faces.

title: People and Business
description: The line of succession as chief executive officer at the Gillette Company, a subject of much public attention last summer, was quietly resolved yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Andover, Mass., when Vincent C. Ziegler, chairman and chief executive officer, stepped down from the latter post and was succeeded by Colman M. Mockler Jr.

title: DEFEAT FOR FORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Senate Armed Services Committee dealt a serious blow to President Ford's Vietnam policy today by rejecting additional military assistance for the Saigon Government.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Kentucky vs. St. Louis

title: About New York
description: The Treasury Rooms at the Hermitage are traditional European, Stuart Silver was saying. Flattopped glass cases with three times as many objects in each case as we are showing here, old red velvet backgrounds, lighting only soso. Even so when I went to Leningrad, I was struck by the way that the stuff jumps out at you, it's so great.

title: Kissinger Weighs Effect Of a Communist Portugal
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Secretary of State Kissinger is saying he believes that by next year Portugal will be a Communist nation or a neutralist nation under heavy Communist influence.

title: TEXACO LIFTS PRICE OF WHOLESALE GAS
description: Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday that it had raised wholesale prices of all grades of gasoline by one cent a gallon. At the same time, Texaco increased its price of liquefied petroleum gas by 2.5 cents a gallon.

title: DEFEAT FOR FORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Senate Armed Services Committee dealt a serious blow to President Ford's Vietnam policy today by rejecting additional military assistance for the Saigon Government.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The Radio City Music Hall will depart from its firstrun, film policy next Thursday when it starts a monthlong series of weekly showings of MetroGoldwynMayer hits of the past. The first week's attraction will be Gone With the Wind, which has been reissued many times since its original release in December, 1939. The subsequent revivals are: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968), Singing in the Rain (1952), and Dr. Zhivago (1965). The accompanying stage show, It's in Your Stars, will be presented throughout the month.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Egypt Says Libya Threatens To Cut Relations in New Rift
description: CAIRO, April 17Libya has threatened to break diplomatic relations with Egypt in protest over recent remarks by President Anwar elSadat about Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, according to an Egyptian Government communiqu.

title: British Scientists Report Discovering New Type of Star
description: LONDON, April 17 (UPI)British scientists said today they had discovered a new type of pulsating Xray star almost by accident while using the British Xray astronomy satellite, Ariel5, launched last year.

title: CITY BAR GROUP CRITICIZES BREITEL
description: In a report highly critical of the state's chief judge, Charles D. Breitel, and his top aides, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York called yesterday for the immediate retransfer of Judge Bruce McM. Wright back to the Criminal Court.

title: U.S. Family of 3 Captured, A Letter From Saigon Says
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, April 17 (AP)A letter from Saigon reports that a 5yearold girl and her missionary parents, from Pennsylvania, are among those previously listed as missing who have been captured by the Vietcong.

title: They Shoe Horses, Don't They?
description: ITHACA, N. Y.The smallest school on the campus of Cornell University here will graduate a class of two students this weekits entire student body. They are entering a booming old professionhorseshoeing.

title: Fonteyn, Nureyev to Join Martha Graham in Benefit
description: Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, classical ballet's most celebrated team, wills join forces with a once rival camp June 19, when they appear here for the first time in a work created for them by Martha Graham, the pioneer of American modern dance.

title: Cuban Communists to Hold First Congress in December
description: HAVANA, April 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Cuban Communist party will hold its first congress in December, it was officially announced here.

title: U. S., RUSSIA REACH LOBSTER AGREEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) The Commerce Department said today that the Soviet Union had agreed to new controls to protect American lobster fishermen from interference by Russian trawlers.

title: SENATE SUPPORTS NEW F.D.A. POWER
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Senate passed today by an 88to5 vote a bill to give the Government, for the first time, strong power to insure the safety and effectiveness of medical devices such as heart pacemakers, heart valves and kidney machines.

title: EXJUDGE TO HEAD INQUIRY ON ATTICA
description: Bernard S. Meyer, a former State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County, was named yesterday to head the independent inquiry into the charge that the chief Attica prosecutor covered up possible crimes by law enforcement officers.

title: Met Shows Scythian Art With Skill
description: I would rather spend the morning in the Hermitage in Leningrad than in any other single place in the inhabited world. First the collections, then the stupendous building itself and finally the views from the windows add up to an experience that never stales. Throw in the oldfashioned fine manners of the staff, and the enthusiast has in the Hermitage a second home to which he cannot return too often.

title: N. F. L. Says Rozelle Rule Is Still Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)The National Football League Management Council, the owners' agent, told the players' union today that all issues must be bargained, including the socalled Rozelle compensation rule, if an agreement on a new contract is to be reached. The players had said they wished to sever sideration of the Rozelle rule from contract negotiations.

title: After Phnom Penh
description: Must the futile battle of Phnom Penh now be duplicated, at far greater cost in lives, in a fight to the finish in Saigon?

title: 5 Americans Advance
description: TOKYO, April 17 (AP) John Alexander of Australia led seven seeded players, including five Americans, into the quarter final round today of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis Red Group tournament.

title: Mets Get 13 its, Win, 147
description: ST. LOUIS, April 17If we could just get some runs, Manager Yogi Berra of the New York Mets groaned plaintively before today's skirmish with the Cardinals. Six games, and never more than three runs.

title: The Pop Life
description: Sometimes simple musical forms strike one as basic and honest, and sometimes they just sound a little simpleminded. Or at least so it seemed listening to Luther Allison at the Bottom Line on Wednesday night (Mr. Allison closed a threenight run at the club yesterday).

title: Turkey Devalues Lira 1%
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 17 (Reuters)  Turkey devalued her lira against the dollar today by about 1 per cent to 14 lires to the dollar from 13.85, the official gazette said. The readjustment was prompted by a strengthening of the dollar in international money markets, it said.

title: 50% Pay Increase To $60,000 Urged For U. S. Judges
description: Owen McGivern, the ?? presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court for the First Department, urged yesterday an immediate 50 per cent increase in pay for Federal judges, saying that their present $40,000ayear salaries were forcing them into lives of honorable poverty.

title: Ford Prods Congress on Energy Action
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The White House made explicit today the threat that members of Congress, especially those drafting energy legislation, have been expecting for days.

title: Schuman Heads Music Fund
description: William Schuman has been named chairman of the board of the new Norlin Foundation, whose initial focus will be in the world of music. Mr. Schuman, the composer, is president emeritus of the Juilliard School and Lincoln Center. The foundation is supported by grants from the Norlin Corporation, a musical instrument company.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, April 17, 1975

title: House Unit Moves to Add Areas To Voting Rights Act Coverage
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) A House subcommittee voted today to add Texas and Alaska to six Southern states wholly covered by the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Saigon Apparently Braces Fora Direct Thrust by Foe
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 18  Government troops were reported holding yesterday at Xuan Loc, 38 miles to the northeast, and making some gains nearby, but here in the capital fears grew that Saigon itself was about to come under heavy attack.

title: Russian Sees Gains in Technology Pacts
description: A top economic official of the Soviet Union said here yesterday that, despite obstacles to trade with the United States, his country was rapidly increasing technological exchange agreements with American companies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 1,500 teachers, assistant teachers, family counselors and cooks who work at city daycare centers ringed City Hall to protest what they called the inequity of the city's limiting a wage increase to 5 per cent, after nearly five months of negotiations.

title: Krzyzewski to Stress Defense In the Knight Manner at Army
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 17Army's new basketball coach, Mike Krzyzewski, indicates in many ways how strongly he has been influenced by Bobby Knight, the college coach of the year last season. However, Krzyzewski also clearly displays the influence of four years as a cadet at the United States Military Academy

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Houston

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Phoenix vs. Quebec

title: Crabiel Trial Told of Dealings on Bids
description: ELIZABETH, April 17 Prosetution witnesses testified in State Superior Court today that several North Jersey construction and road paving companies, including the Franklin Contracting Company of Little Falls, headed by J. Edward Crabiel, met frequently from 1966 to 1968 to prearrange bidis and divide up public contraets.

title: Demand for Business Loans Up At Banks Here and in Chicago
Business Loans Rise
description: Demand for business loans from New York and Chicago banks showed a little strength this week  an unusual occurrence in the money market this year. Page 47.

title: One More Spring
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 17Spring has come to North Carolina in the annual riot of color. Along the highways and in the welltended front yards of towns and cities, dogwood, azaleas and redbud are blooming brilliantly against the green backdrop of pine trees. No state is more beautiful in the season of renewal although here as elsewhere rejuvenation seems more the property of Mother Earth than of her human creatures.

title: Officer Kilts Brother In Shooting Accident
description: A Port Authority police officer fatally shot his younger brother last night when his revolver accidentally discharged as he was removing it from his holster at their home at 656 Union Street in Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: CAR MAKERS CITE RECOVERY SIGNS
description: DETROIT, April 17  The presidents of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation said today that the industry was beginning to recover from the worst recession in their industry since World War II.

title: Bridge
description: Leading your partner's suit against notrump is a routine move, but there are occasions when a strong suit in the opening leader's hand may offer a tempting alternative.

title: Stoeks Up for 8th Day as Volume Soars
description: Although discouraging economic news trimmed many earlier advances, the stock market managed to register its eighth consecutive gain yesterday in the third heaviest trading in exchange history.

title: Memorial to Vietnam
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa. (AP)A 250pound steel memorial, cast from more than 7,000 Prisoner of War and Missing in Action bracelets from every state, has been dedicated at the Freedoms Foundation here. The memorial was designed by Harold Balazs Jr. a sculptor from Spokane, Wash.

title: PRICES MOVE UP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: In steppedup trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday as traders appeared to be discounting bearish news.

title: Foreign Physicians' English Is Doctored
description: For foreignborn physicians practicing in the United States, there is nothing mysterious about such terms as thrombosis or biopsy. But tummy ache or charley horse are another matter.

title: It's Shakespeare Night at McCarter
description: PRINCETON, April 17In a program certain to appeal to romantics of all ages, and perhaps the less romantically inclined as well, Ian Richardson, a member of the Royal Shakespeare Company, will interpret Shakespeare's insights on love in a onenight appearance at the McCarter Theater here tomorrow.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Levi Strause to Introduce Boys' FireResistant Pants
description: Levi Strauss & Co., the world's largest apparel manufacturer, will introdnce a line of flameresistant pants for boys this year.

title: Music: Schumann Mania
description: The Schumann Cello Concerto, played last night at the New York Philharmonic concert, was responsible for a double ego trip. Mstislav Rostropovich was the cellist, Leonard Bernstein the conductor, and between them they not only wrung the old concerto dry but also in the process extracted some hitherto unknown juices from it.

title: State Is Told It Can Limit Clinics To Performing Early Abortions
description: TRENTON, April 17  The State Attorney General's office said today that the state's Health Department could legally limit the performance, of abortions in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy to licensed hospitals. This would prevent them from being performed in abortion clinics.

title: Chrysler and A.M.C. Set Plant Closings; G. M. Plans Recalls
description: DETROIT, April 17  The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation announced today new plant closings for next weeks, but the General Motors Corporation said it was recalling some workers.

title: Study Says Attitudes of Jurors Hurt U.S. in Its Political Trials
description: WASHINGTON. April 18The attitudes of jurors, not disruptive tactics of defense lawyers, were the major reason the Government lost a series of socalled political trials over the last seven years, the Justice Department had concluded.

title: Friends and Critics Debate Future of Connally as Political Figure
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 John B. Connally, acquitted here of a bribery charge yesterday, has survived too much bizarre fortune, with too boldly unconventional a personality intact, to invite guesses about his future. Yet numero?? friends, rivals and uncommitted political observers shared today a vaguely awed sense that the 58yearold former Texas Governor, former Democrat, and former Treasury Secretary could be as powerful again after his near brush with scandal.

title: Abroad Since 1970, They Found What They Were Seeking
description: In 1970, The New York Times reported on the increase of Americans pulling up stakes and seeking a better life abroad. Some left to get away from crime and the fear of crime; some left to escape filth and pollution; some left to seek better jobs or out of religious zeal.

title: Stock Decline Halts 8 Sessions of Gains
description: The stock market did what most Wall Streeters expected yesterdayit closed lower in much slower trading.

title: REP. HANSEN GETS 60DAY SENTENCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, was sentenced in Federal court today to serve two months in prison for two campaign finance violations.

title: U.S. Admonishes Environment Session
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 18The United States said today that the new United Nations Environment Program was intruding into economic, political and other questions not related to protecting the human environment and was spreading its efforts too thinly.

title: Existencea Common Stake
description: ATHENSA curious phenomenon of American Presidential campaigns began in 1960 when leading Aspirants for the nominations started to concentrate attention on foreign policy, devoting much time to trips abroad, partly to learn what others think and partly to air their own views on overseas soundingboards.

title: Coup 34: Chad
description: For fifteen years, the uncommonly agile Francois Tombalbaye of Chad managed to ride the crest of the turbulenceracial, religious, regional, politicalthat afflicted his central African country from the moment it achieved independence from France.

title: DESMOND T. BARRY, TRIAL LAWYER HERE
description: Desmond T. Barry, a New York lawyer specializing in trial work, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived at 15 Beech Tree Lane, Bronxville, and in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: 800 Paraprofessionals Honored By U.F.T. for Earning Degrees
description: Eight hundred paraprofessionals, many of them working mothers, were guests of honor of the United Federation of Teachers last night at a salute following their completion of the requirements for a twoyear or fouryear college degree.

title: Landmarks Commission Survives A Decade, but Road Ahead Is Rocky
description: When we started, an official of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission said last week, the realestate industry told us we would last six months before the courts put us out of business. Now, 10 years after Mayor Wagner signed legislation on April 19, 1965, establishing the commission, it has designated 447 landmarks and 26 historic districts, bringing a total of more than 10,000 buildings under its protection. The 11member commission has 25 employes and is generally considered the most accomplished such agency in the nation. At a time when, moreover, historic preservation has become part of city planning gospel, the New York commission should be riding higher than ever.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Cut in Chrysler Deficit Forecast by Townsend
description: DETROIT, April 18Lynn Townsend, chairman of Chrysler Corporation, said in an interview today that Chrysler's loss for the first quarter this year would be considerably less than the pretax loss in the fourth quarter of 1974, which totaled $168million.

title: You're Wrong. I'm Right. Absolutely. 102%.
description: If there is a certainty in our society it is that nothing is certain. It is also a certainty that those who are certain are sometimes apt to be wrong.

title: 31 U.S. AREAS JOIN 6% JOBLESS ROLL
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Labor Department added 31 communities today to its list of major labor areas with substantial unemployment.

title: Concord Is Sealed Off As Thousands Pour In
description: CONCORD, Mass., April 18 As tens of thousands of; youths poured into this small town on the eve of the beginning of the Bicentennial celebration, local officials sealed off much of the town.

title: Carey and Byrne Confer on Toll Rises
description: Governors Carey and Byrne met yesterday to discuss proposed increases in the Budson River bridge and tunnel tolls, among other subjects, as aides of the Governors said that both men had been informed in advance of the toll increases and had approved themat least in principle.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 19, 1975

title: The Dance: After Eden
description: Since its creation for the Harkness Ballet about nine years ago, John Butler's sinuous duet After Eden has appeared in a number of other repertories. Thursday night it was given its first performance by the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater at the City Center, 55th Street. The Ailey company has over the years become a special repository for what might be called moderndance classics, and Mr. Ailey himself is clearly anxious to build a broadbased repertory that includes works by many choreographers.

title: Black Agencies Charge Injustice In Placing of Vietnam Children
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Three black social service agencies contended today that the international adoption agencies that were placing Vietnamese children in American homes were bypassing qualified black families who want to adopt the children of black American servicemen.

title: City, State and U.S. Study Abuses in Medicaid Here
description: Federal, state and city agencies are investigating Medicaid practices that are costing taxpayers tens of millions of dollars a year in overcharges, city health officials reported yesterday. The officials said that fraudusually involving billing at least twice for the same service or billing for services not givenaccounts for substantial sums. But they said the major cause of the overcharges was duplicated and unnecessary services.

title: Five Asian Nations Recognize Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 18The Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the five countries geographically closest to the turmoil in Indochina, jointly recognized the new Government of Cambodia today.

title: Amy Shuard, Soprano, Dies; Noted for Turandot Role
description: LONDON, April 18Amy Shuard, one of the leading English lyric and later dramatic sopranos of the postwar era, died today at the age of 50.

title: Rise in Tuition Approved For State Medical School
description: TRENTON, April 18 (UPI)The State Board of Higher Education today approved increases in tuition for students at the College of Medicine and Dentistry and other institutions.

title: Indian Head Agrees In Principle to Buy Polymer Materials
description: Indian Head, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to purchase Polymer Materials, Inc., a supplier of specialty raw materials to the plastic industry. The purchase price is approximately $20million cash, or about $16 a share for the 1,067,341 shares outstanding. Indian Head, which is more than 90 per cent owned by ThyssenBornemiza of the Netherlands, is a diversified company making containers, information technology and automotive products and specialty textiles.

title: CHICAGO MAN SLAYS FOUR, THEN HIMSELF
description: CHICAGO, April 18 (UPI)A man who had gathered 12 relatives in his apartment for a meal tonight suddenly turned on the group with three handguns, killing four persons and wounding four others before killing himself, the police said.

title: Moscow Expects No Attack on Saigon
description: MOSCOW, April 18Soviet diplomats analyzing the fighting in South Vietnam have told wellplaced sources here that they do not expect the Communist forces to try to capture Saigon and win the war in the current offensive.

title: USE OF CREDIT LINE IS CITED BY A.M.C.
description: DETROIT, April 18John C. Secrest, the group vice president of staff and of the international division of the American Motors Corporation, disclosed today that A.M.C., which has been heavily hit by low sales and profits, had used $100million of its credit lines since last September.

title: A Minor Operation With Vast Effects
description: The British raid from Boston on Lexington and Concord was a relatively minor operation that had significant tactical and strategic consequences.

title: RockStrewn Delaware River Shortens 9 Scouts' Raft Outing
description: SPARROW BUSH, N.Y., April 18 (UPI)Nine New Jersey Boy Scouts, their efforts frustrated by rockstrewn waters, ended their Huckleberry Finn adventure on the Delaware River tonight 127 miles short of their 200mile goal.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 19, 1975

title: Books of The Times
description: It is scarely news that one of America's most enduring success stories has been the Mafia, or Cosa Nostra or whatever new brand name authors and detectives apply to organized crime. Through economic boom or bust, the MafiaCosa Nostra has possessed sufficient acumen and muscle to remain a solid growth industry.

title: MaBell Opoly
description: WASHINGTONThe Justice Department antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is the most important step ever taken by the Government to restore competition to the American marketplace and protect our freeenterprise system. If it is successful, the message will be clear that no matter how big and powerful a company may be, monopoly will not be tolerated.

title: K.G.B. Said to Arrest Two in Soviet Amnesty Group
description: MOSCOW, April 18  The Soviet security police moved today against Tour members of the small Soviet chapter of Amnesty International, apparently arresting two and searching the apartments of the two others at length.

title: People and Business
description: Inventory investment, in the view of the economist Arthur M. Okun, is in the spotlight as the big current villain of the recession drama. Mr. Okun, who is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Johnson Administration, says in a guarded assessment: My own personal bet is that, as a result ?? inventory liquidations, the recession will keep going during the spring months but that an upturn will be registered during the summer.

title: The Theater: Meri Mini's Looice
description: LOOICE, book and lyrics by Benjamin Goldstein; music by Philip Namnaworth; edited by Meriden Stein; musical direction, Matthew Koplowitz; costumes by Patricia Krait; settine by Kathy Kunkel, Denise Weber; directed by Meridee, Stein Presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater; producer, Joseph Pape, the Meri Mini Players. At the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Evacuation
description: The greatest danger now facing the United States in Vietnam would be the necessity of a military operation to evacuate the thousands of Americans who have inexplicably been allowed to remain in Saigon.

title: Mayer Beats Gerulaitis at Denver Net
description: DENVER, April 18Fourthseeded Vitas Gerulaitis of New York and eighthseeded Jaime Fillol of Chile were eliminated tonight in a World Tennis Championship tournament.

title: Communists Accused of Atrocities in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)United States officials say they are receiving reports of atrocities allegedly committed by Communists in captured areas of South Vietnam. But the reports have not been verified, and most accounts were described by only one source.

title: ZAMBIAN PRESIDENT IS IN U.S. FOR TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia arrived here today for two days of talks with United States Government officials and Congressmen about the situation in southern Africa.

title: Braves Victors, Tie Series, 22
description: BUFFALO, April 18The Buffalo Braves seemed on the verge of their third straight National Basketball Association playoff loss to the Washington Bullets tonight, then raced to a 108102 victory on the strength of a strong thirdquarter rally and a superb 50point performance from Bob McAdoo.

title: Saudis Seek Balance in Riyadh Between Minarets and HighRises
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Elderly former slaves now collect something ike social security. Skilled Teletype operators greet, operators in distant Arab cities as dear brother. And the gleaming new oilIndustry headquarters is already being patched up by pious workmen who stop now and then to pray.

title: 4 Soviet Task Forces in Pacific, Part of Global Naval Exercises
description: The Soviet Union has deployed four naval task forces in the western Pacific as part of a worldwide exercise that United States naval authorities believe may be the largest the Russians have ever staged.

title: Final Fatal Blow
description: TOKYO, April 18The North Koreans here, who always explain their Government's policy faithfully, said today that President Kim II Sung was expected to ask Chairman Mao Tsetung and Premier Chou Enlai to give a final fatal blow to the Americans after the Indochina debacle.

title: Saigon Accuses B.B.C.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 19 (Reuters)The Saigon Government accused the British Broadcasting Corporation today of biased reporting that helped the Cemmunis?? The official Vietnam Press Agency said the B.B.C. had reported that roads around Da Nang had been cut, causing panic among the population and leading to the city's fall.

title: U.N. Says Cambodians Hampered Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18  The former Cambodian Government compelled United Nations authorities to pay costly airfreight charges to fly powdered milk into the country aboard the Governmentowned airline rather than permit the relief supplies to be flown in free, officials here said today.

title: SOVIET REPORTS ECONOMIC GAINS
description: MOSCOW, April 18The Soviet Union reported today economic gains for the first quarter of the year and issued figures indicating that the Government was fulfilling its plans to devote less attention to the production of consumer goods.

title: NEW PLAN DRAWN TO COVER DOCTORS FOR MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, April 18A new malpracticeinsurance proposal, under which a pool of 300 private insurance companies instead of the State Insurance Fund would write all medicalmalpractice insurance in the state, has been accepted by Governor Carey's office and key legislators of both parties and will be ready for legislative action early next week.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MEATY MENU There is a decided variety of entertainment diversions this weekend, starting with three infrequently performed musical productionsone of the most popular of all operettas, a children's version of a lovely opera and a Mary Rodgers show.

title: 3 Weeks After Fall, Da Nang Seems a Calm City
description: The following dispatch was written for Agence FrancePresse by RolandPierre Paringaux, the only nonCommunist Western journalist allowed to fly to Da Nang, South Vietnam, aboard a French aid flight yesterday.

title: Laotian Says Reds Captured Position Near Key Routes
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 18 (Reuters)  Defense Minister Sisouk na Champassak said today that Communist troops had driven Government forces from a position near a strategie crossroads north of here.

title: Fashion World Hops on the Bicentennial Bandwagon
description: The fashion industry, which hasn't had too many things to crow about lately, was celebrated in film and clothes at the WaldorfAstoria yesterday.

title: Some Cambodians in U.S.
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 18 (AP)Immigration officials say they will take no immedite action to eject 94 Cambodian military officers sent to this country for training. The Cambodians are studying English at the Department of Defense's language school at Lackland Air Force Base here. There are 20 Cambodians at the naval International Officer Candidate School at Newport, R. I.

title: PRICES IN BRITAIN RISE RECORD 21.2%
description: LONDON, April 18Retail prices, in Britain climbed a record of 21.2 per cent in the 12 months through March, the Government said today in a report that appeared to confirm that the nation would experience the highest inflation in the industrialized world in coming months.

title: Arthur Huckle, Publisher, Led Southern Newspapers
description: ROCK HILL, S. C., April 18 (AP)  Arthur W. Huckle, publisher of The Concord (N. C.) Tribune and president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association in 194041, died last night after a long illness. His age was not disclosed.

title: Queens Tenants Showing Willingness to Do Battle
description: In Queens Borough Hall, in Kew Gardens, tenant and landlord representatives from an apartment development in Astoria faced one another across a table recently, with Borough President Donald R. Manes as mediator.

title: Big Board Backs Rate Move
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday its members had approved the repeal of all references to fixed public commission rates from its constitution by a vote of 534 to 214. About 54.8 per cent of the members voted, the exchange said.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rises to 201.6 From 199.9
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 201.6 from 199.9 last week.

title: Reds Said to Tell Civilians In Phnom Penh to Leave
description: Thousands of Cambodian civilians were reported yesterday to be leaving Phnom Penh under orders from the victorious Communists.

title: CALM IS REPORTED IN STATE PRISONS
description: ALBANY, April 18The conditions that led to the Attica uprising do not exist in New York prisons today, according for the State Commissioner of Correctional Services.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor, said a final medical examiner's report indicated that Berel Weinstein, a 28yearold Fort Lee millionaire, had taken his own life or had died of an accidental overdose of a prescription pain killer. The report said it was highly improbable that this kind of drug could be administered in a fatal dose without the knowledge of the deceased, ruling out the possibility of homicide. Mr. Weinstein, who made his fortune from various medical gadget inventions, was found dead in his penthouse apartment Feb. 21. Initial reports indicated the death resulted from a heart attack, but the death became controversial when members of his family, who are Orthodox Jews, protested his widow's plans to have the body cremated.

title: Battles, Rides Start Today
description: The opening engagements of the American Revolution were the Battles of Lexington and Concord and a number of events are scheduled to be held in those towns today and in Boston to celebrate the start of the nation's Bicentennial observance.

title: Manila Will Consider Status of U.S. Bases
description: MANILA, April 18The first complete reexamination of the defense pacts between the United States and the Philippines and of the huge strategic naval and air bases that are the keystone of America's Pacific defenses has begun here,

title: Handball's Dawn After the Dark Ages
description: During the decade when he was the world's best handball player, Jim Jacobs, a collector of boxing films by profession, was accompanying Cus D'Amato, a collector of boxers by profession, aboard the ocean liner America to England, where one of D'Amato's tigers would be baring his chest. For exercise and for mischief during the sixday voyage, Jim Jacobs signed up for handball lessons along with two dozen others. Each day Jim Jacob's game improved, steadily and carefully. On the final day he challonged the instructor. He even had a $5 bet with the instructor, as well as a $1 bet with each of the other pupils. Jim Jacobs won, to a the surprise of the instructor and the other pupils but not to the surprise of the national fourwall champion whom nobody had recognized. Now that's an identity problem. To soothe it, Jim Jacobs collected all the bets he had won.

title: Beirut Truce Taking Effect Amid Scattered Shooting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 18 (AP)  Scattered machinegun and bazooka fire was heard through the night and a shop was blown up, but feuding Palestinian guerrillas and the rightwing Phalangist party said today that a ceasefire in their conflict was generally being observed.

title: Garden State Track Closed by Strike
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 18Thoroughbred racing was canceled today at Garden State Park after striking security guards and maintenance workers set up picket lines around the track.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City Councilman Robert Steingut yesterday charged the Board of Education with neglecting students with poor vision and with wasting remedialreading funds. His statement followed disclosure of studies that showed that a quarter of 3,000 pupils in special reading classes here had poor vision.

title: Byrne and Carey Confer on Toll Rises
description: Governors Carey and Byrne met yesterday to discuss proposed increases in the Hudson River bridge and tunnel tolls, among other subjects, as aides of the Governors said that both men had been informed in advance of the toll increases and had approved them  at least in principle.

title: Jury Questions L. I. Councilman On Report of Kickbacks to Party
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 18 Leo McGinity, a member of the Hempstead Town Council, appeared today before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that is investigating allegations of kickbacks to the Republican party.

title: Castle & Cooke Holders Told Bribes Weren't Paid
description: D. J. Kirchhoff, president of Castle & Cooke, Inc., the diversified food company, told stockholders at the company's annual meeting in Honolulu yesterday that this company has never paid bribes to any foreign Government or its officials.

title: And in Israel, Exactly What I Dreamed About
description: TEL AVIV, April 18 Lawrence and Sarah Behar's dream of raising Arab horses in Israel has materialized. At their halfacre farmstead in Sdeh Warburg in the Sharon Plain, they own three horses waiting to foal and a filly. They also operate a citrus tree nursery on leased land elsewhere in the village and raise vegetables and poultry for their family table. They planted 15 assorted fruit trees.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, April 18 (UPI)Poland dealt the United States the final blow in the world ice hockey championships today with a 52 victory that kept the Americans without a triumph in the tournament. The Polish victory on top of its 53 firstround triumph in Munich, meant that the United States will be relegated from the AAA group of the championship unless, as is widely expectedthe rules are changed to expand the group to eight teams.

title: Article 1  No Title
Peking Congratulates Sihanouk, Victorious Cambodian Forces
description: PEKING, April 18The Chinese leaders have conveyed their warmest congratulations and highest esteem to Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the new Cambodian leaders on their victory.

title: CAMP SAFETY RULES APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)The House has passed and sent to the Senate a bill to set Federal safety standards for summer youth camps and to establish a Federal office to regulate them.

title: NORTH REINFORCES LINE AT XUAN LOC
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 19  Heavy North Vietnamese reinforcements moved yesterday into the battle for Xuan Loc, 38 miles northeast of here, as other Communist troops staged a series of smallscale attacks closer to Saigon.

title: Memorial Services
description: SULLIVANGrace Brinkley. An Anniversary MASS will be offered at the Chanel of Saints Faith Bone and Charily at 9 A.M. an Saturday April 19 in memory at Graco Brinkley Sullivan, who died April 19, 1940.

title: Rhodesia Invites Leaders of Blacks To Resume Talks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 18Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has invited black leaders to resume talks next week on Rhodesia's constitutional future, a Government spokesman said today.

title: SCHOOLS ATTACKED ON VISION TESTING
description: City Councilman Robert Steingut yesterday charged the Board of Education with neglecting students with poor vision and with wasting remedialreading funds. His statement followed disclosure of studies that showed that a quarter of 3,000 pupils in special reading classes here had Door vision.

title: Now, It's the Midday Ride of Dino Di Carlo
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., April 18As Voltaire noted a long, long time ago, those who make history seldom realize it.

title: Islanders Have Bad Luck, Bad Breaks, Bad Excuses
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 18 The sign in Glenn Resch's locker reads, You've got a mouthuse it. The sign is a redundancy. He might as well be reminded to breathe.

title: Russian Orthodox Group Said to Plan Israel Visit
description: JERUSALEM, April 18 (Reuters)An official delegation from the Russian Orthodox Church in Moscow is to visit Israel at the end of this month, sources in the Ministry for Religious Affairs said today.

title: Bonds, Blomberg Crack Homers As Yanks Trounce Tigers, 113
description: DETROIT, April 18  Having teased the rest of the league long enough, the Yankees quit fooling around tonight and started playing the way a team that had added Bobby Bonds and Catfish Hunter should play.

title: FORD TESTS WINDS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N. H., April 18Without saying so, President Ford opened his active campaign for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination today.

title: Battles, Rides Start Today
description: The opening engagements of the American Revolution were the. Battles of Lexington and Concord and a number of events are scheduled to be held in those towns today and in Boston to celebrate the start of the nation's Bicentennial observance.

title: Coast Architecture Revisited
description: There is only One thing in publishing more to be welcomed than a significant new book, and that is the reappearance of a significant old book. Esther McCoy's Five California Architects was first published (was it really so long ago?) in 1960. The book brought to the public eye five almostforgotten architects who have since been given major roles in 20thcentury American architectural history. But although the book itself was largely responsible for the rescue of their reputations, it quickly fell out of print.

title: Report of Contacts With Patricia Hearst Published on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 (AP)Patricia. Hearst and two fellow fugitives of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army have rejected terrorism but would shoot back if agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation used force to try to capture them, The San Francisco Examiner reported today.

title: Composers' Group Plays Seven Pieces In Carnegie Debut
description: The Composers Ensemble, consisting of composerperformers who banded together in 1972 to play their own works, made a New York debut at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, playing pieces by six members and one written by Charles Wuorinen.

title: In Deadlines, the Alum Troupe Offers a Choreographic Smile
description: Images of dark mystery from unfamiliar places and moods of quiet and not so quiet desperation are frequently conjured up by Manuel Alum. At times, however, he manages a choreographic smile in a piece like Deadlines, which was included in his selection of repertory works at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's LePercq Space on Thursday evening. The Alum programs will close the academy's experimental dance series.

title: Iverson's 66 For 133 Best In Pensacola
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 18 (AP)  Don Iverson birdied four of the last five holes today and surged into a twoshot lead at the halfway mark of the $125,000 Pensacola open golf tournament. He shot a 66 over the par71 Pensacola Country Club course for a 133 total.

title: Burger Takes Case for Higher Salaries to Editors
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Chief Justice Warren E. Burger took before the nation's newspaper editors tonight his case for more Federal court manpower and higher judicial salaries.

title: Ford, on Bicentennial Trip, Bids U.S. Heed Old Values
description: BOSTON, April 18President Ford, visiting New England as the celebration of the American Revolution Bicentennial is getting under way, called today for a reversal of what he said was the longterm movement toward big government and a return to the basic American virtues.

title: W.T.GRANT SHOWS NET LOSS FOR YEAR
description: The W, T. Grant Company, the financially troubled retail chain, suffered a net loss of $134.2million, after a tax credit of $74.2million, in the 13 weeks ended Jan. 30. This brought the total net loss for the 52 weeks ended Jan. 30 to $177.3million after a tax credit of $117.5million, according to its annual report issued yesterday.

title: In Picasso Show From Many Lenders, His Inspiration in 1920's Stands Out
description: In the case of Posterity vs. Pablo Picasso the jury has barely been picked yet, and pleadings for and against are likely to continue well into the next century. Between works of supreme genius on the one hand and dogged replays on the other there is a great deal of room for maneuver; we are likely to be in the next world (upstairs or downstairs) before either side rests its case.

title: Brazil and Portugal Resolve Dispute Over a Branch Bank
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18A bank dispute between Brazil and Portugal, which threatened to turn into a diplomatic crisis, was resolved today.

title: After the Flood
description: The news that the entire United States Senate has undergone sexchangesurgery has apparently shocked no one. Few persons seem even mildly interested. The news has been so grotesque for so long that people are surprised by nothing any more.

title: Nixon Shows Strain But Remains Vital, A Clergyman Says
description: MADISON, Wis. (AP)Richard Nixon's mind is lightning fast, but his face is very worn and shows strain. says a clergyman who met privately with the former President in San Clemente last Tuesday.

title: Electronic Way Devised For Composing of Songs
description: WASHINGTON, April 18A composer and author has invented an electronic system for composing a variety of different songs from fractional recordings. Mack David of Palm Springs, Calif., Pawas granted Patent 3,877,338 this week. As described in the patent, the system includes playback units and stored records of lyrics and melodies. The operator selects words and music that fit together and records the combination as the finished product.

title: Bill on Foreign Publications Introduced in Canada
description: OTTAWA, April 18  The, Canadian Government introduced longexpected legislation in the House of Commons today to end tax concessions on advertising that benefit American and other foreignowned publications and television stations in the United States whose programs are seen by large Canadian audiences.

title: Jobless Workers Picket In Favor of Tocks Project
description: WALPACK CENTER, April 18The New Jersey Citizens Advisory, Board on the Tocks Island Project was met by 60 angry pickets today, who blocked the group's bus as it arrived here for a luncheon meeting.

title: Lonrho's Chief Courts Arab Investments and Ignores His Critics
description: LONDON, April 18Attracting capital from Arab investors is the preoccupation of countless businessmen all over the worid these days, but few have achieved the success of Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland, a secretive and controversial British entrepreneur with many friends in the Middle East and Africa.

title: Antioch Chancellor Dismissed As President Defies the Trustees
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, April 18Dr. James T. Dixon Jr. today dismissed the chancellor of the school's Yellow Springs campus, Dr. Francis X. Shea, and refused instructions from the college's hoard of trustees to reinstate Dr. Shea.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Employes Get Eased Job Rules
description: Mayor Beame put into effect yesterday a series of basic procedural changes in the municipal Civil Service system, giving heads of departments greater control over promotions and job assignments for 330,000 city workers.

title: ...and for New York City
description: The rigorous austerity message the Labor Government has just delivered to Britons foreshadows the kind of grim news that New Yorkers can expect next week when Britishborn Mayor Beame outlines his new expense budget proposals.

title: JAMES H. SHELDON, CHURCH AIDE, DIES
description: Dr. James H. Sheldon, a leading New York ecumenist and supporter of humanitarian causes, died Wednesday of a heart attack while addressing the United Nations Association of the United States. He was 67 years old and lived at 309 West, 57th Street.

title: Kissinger Gives Reason On Cloaked Attribution
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)Secretary of State Kissinger was asked yesterday what purpose it served to insist on attributing informadon that obviously came from him to a high administration official or some other cloaked source.

title: Deficit Is Reported By Burlington Line
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., reported yesterday its extensive rail systemmore than 23,100 miles of linehad a $1.8million operating loss in the first quarter this year.

title: Indicted Commissioner Splits Police in Orange
description: ORANGE, April 18 (UPI)The steadfast refusal of the Orange Police Commissioner, Quincy Lucarello, to resign following his indictment on corruption charges has led to a bitter division within the 106man Police Department.

title: Vietnam Refugees: Road's End on Route 1
description: TRANG BOM, South Vietnam, April 18A ranger lieu tenant gestured up the road toward a stand of rubber trees and said, Sure we'll hold them; why not? You have to hold somewhere.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: In a statement prompted by the opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art of From the Lands of the Scythians, the exhibition of ancient treasures drawn primarily from the Hermitage in Leningrad, Leonid I. Brezhnev praised the Hermitage and other Soviet museums as well as the Met for trying to make regular exchanges of art exhibitions an inseparable part of the cultural exchange between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Compensation to G.M. Officials Reduced by 68.3% Last Year
description: DETROIT, April 18The total compensation to top executives of the General Motors Corporation, traditionally among the highest paid in American industry, was reduced last year by 68.3 per cent because of the 60 per cent decline in the company's profits.

title: Compensation to G.M. Officials Reduced by 68.3% Last Year
description: DETROIT, April 18The total compensation to top executives of the General Motors Corporation, traditionally among the highest paid in American industry, was reduced last year by 68.3 per cent because of the 60 per cent decline in the company's profits.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Maj. Gen. William Hamlin, Led Army Signal School
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 18 (AP)Maj. Gem William D. Hamlin, retired, former commandant of the Army Signal School, died of a heart attack yesterday at the age of 70.

title: HUMANITARIAN AID TO SOUTH VIETNAM GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved legislation today authorizing $200million in emergency aid for humanitarian relief and evacuation programs in South Vietnam.

title: Brown U. Strike Unresolved
description: PROVIDENCE, April 18 (AP) Brown University officials and striking students met for two hours today without resolving any of the differences that touched off the fivedayold student strike.

title: Douglas to Get Therapy at Rusk Institute
description: Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas is expected to enter the Institute for Rehabilitation Medicine at New York University next week for intensive therapy to help restore the use of his left arm and leg.

title: HUMANITARIAN AID TO SOUTH VIETNAM GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved legislation today authorizing $200million in emergency aid for humanitarian relief and evacuation programs in South Vietnam.

title: On Black Mayors
description: WASHINGTONCertainly one of the most impressive signs of the progress blacks have made as a consequence of the civil rights movement of the last decade has to be the rise in the number of black elected officials across the country. In the last year alone, the number of black mayors rose from 83 to 108an increase of 30 per cent.

title: KRUPP TO GUARANTEE ESSEN BANK ASSETS
description: ESSEN, West Germany, April 18 (Reuters)A private bank, Carl, Gossenberg & Co., will cease trading but will remain open for customers to withdraw deposits and make other

title: Move to Get Safe District For Rodino Is Foundering
description: TRENTON, April 18A legislative attempt here by the state leadership of the Democratic party to create a predominantly white Congressional district for Representative Peter W. Rodin?? Jr. of Newark showed signs of foundering today.

title: May Bats In 7 Runs As Orioles Win, 97
description: It's been likened to shooting fish in a barrelBoston's cozy Fenway Park and its even cozier leftfield wall, a green concrete barrier 315 feet away and 37 feet high, mooed by a 23foot screen.

title: On Art: Well Worth the Ride
description: BOSTON, April 18We do not usually think of Boston in the era of the American Revolution as a center of mercantile taste and affluence, with everything this implies in the way of conspicuous consumption and the appetite for ostentatious elegance. The mystique of revolution has acquired quite different associations in the 200 years since Paul Revere made his legendary ride to Concord and Lexington. To the modern mind, the very idea of revolution suggests a reolt against extravagant esthetic embellishment, which is felt to be incompatible with radical ideals.

title: SOME SOFT DRINKS CUT IN PRICE HERE
