description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York, Inc., said yesterday that it was reducing prices of its sugarbased soft drinksCocaCola, Dr. Pepper, Welch's sparkling grape soda, Sprite and Fanta principally because of the recent decline in the price of sugar. The New York company said it believed its price cut was the first by any major bottling company in this region since sugar prices began soaring.

title: For Montana Rancher, Strip Mining Has Lost the Allure of 1968
description: BILLINGS, Mont.In 1916, Leo Farley's mother dug out, with a pick and shovel, the first lumps of coal from the Rosebud County section of, the rich, massive Fort Union Coal formation that lies just underneath a good part of eastern Montana, eastern Wyoming and western North Dakota. She and her homesteading brothers used it to heat their log cabin.

title: Japanese Tanker Seized
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 18 (AP)United States marshals) have seized a Japanese oil tanker pending the outcome of a $105million suit against her owners by two Liberian shipping companies. The 350,000ton Volga Marti was seized earlier this month, a spokesman for the Marshals Office here said today.

title: The Rich Get Richer
description: MASERU, Lesoth (AP)King Moshoeshoe II's annual government grant has been increased by $6,220 to $38,610 by the National Assembly.

title: NEW PUN DRAWN TO COVER DOCTORS FOR MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, April 18A new malpracticeinsurance proposal, under which a pool of 300 private insurance companies instead of the State Insurance Fund would write all medicalmalpractice insurance in they state, has been accepted by Governor Carey's office and key legislators of both parties and will be ready for legislative action early next week.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SILVER DECLINE
description: After two sessions of sharply rising prices, silver futures on the Commodity Exchange declined yesterday by more than 5 cents an ounce to $4.33 4/10, from 4.039 1/10.

title: Hard Cheese for Britain ...
description: With a budget remarkable for its bitter mixture of tax increases, spending cuts and tough rhetoric, Denis Healey, the Chancellor of the Exchequer of Britain's Labor Government, has gone far toward confronting British unions with the need to curb their pay demands, slow the present 20 per cent rate of inflation and prevent a looming disaster to Britain's balance of payments. Indeed, judging from the hostile reaction of many members of his own party, of the Conservative opposition and of union leaders, Mr. Healey may have gone further than was politically prudent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Transit Authority's plan to save $8million this year by increasing the time between buses on some routes goes into effect on Sunday for its own routes and on May 11 for those of the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority. The Transit Authority said the changes affected less than 30 per cent of its routes in the day and evening, and that most of the changes during those periods involved an increase of only one or two minutes between buses.

title: NEWS AWARD IS WON BY TIMES REPORTER
description: John L. Hess, a New York Times reporter was selected Thursday as the winner of the New York Press Club's 1975 Gold Typewriter Award for public service in journalism for his articles outlining nursing home abuses.

title: ARAMCO'S OUTPUT OF OIL UP IN 1974
description: The Arabian American Oil Company said in its annual report yesterday that its crude oil production in Saudi Arabia increased by more than 300 million barrels in 1974.

title: Some Plants Bar Autos With Catalytic Converters
description: HOUSTON, April 18 (AP)Eight oil refineries and chemical plants on the Texas coast have banned automobiles with catalytic converters from their property because of reports that temperatures of the pollution control devices can skyrocket when engines are malfunctioning.

title: Saudi Is Lobbying in U.S. Against Israel
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum, has been here for three days trying to persuade Congress and the press that the United States should put more pressure on Israel to withdraw to the borders that prevailed before the 1967 war with Egypt, Syria and Jordan.

title: 2 Found Guilty in Dynamiting Schools in Protest on Textbooks
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 18A Federal jury today found a selfordained Fundamentalist minister and a young coal miner guilty in connection with the dynamiting of public schools here last fall at the height of the Kanawha County protest over school textbooks.

title: ROCKEFELLER CITES FEARS ON DEFICIT
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., April 18  Vice President Rockefeller told a group of young business executives today that Congress was beginning to get worried about possibly increasing the Federal deficit too much.

title: McQuaid Relay Team Is Victor
description: Archbishop McQuaid High School of Rochester, which has been competing in track for 20 years, won its first major relay championship yesterday.

title: BROOKLYN SNIPER COMMITS SUICIDE
description: A man with a shotgun who the police said was distraught fired repeatedly at scores of police officers from his fifthfloor apartment in Brooklyn last night, before finally committing suicide. One police officer was slightly injured in the sniping.

title: PUBLIC TV DROPS SERIES ON CRIME
description: Production of a controversial public television series on criminal justice in the United States, funded by a grant of $1.2million from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, has ceased after six episodes, and the project has been terminated.

title: Quake Felt in California
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 18 (AP)East Bay areas, where thousands of San Franciscans took refuge from the 1906 earthquake and fire, were rattled by a moderate temblor yesterdaythe eve of the great quake's 69th anniversary. Yesterday's quake measured 5.6 on the Richter scale. The San Francisco earthquake on April 18, 1906, registered 8.3.

title: TEXTRON'S PROFIT DOWN IN QUARTER
2 ARE FOUND SLAIN ON UPPER WEST SIDE
description: The bodies of a man and a woman who had each been shot several times were found last night in a ransacked, onebedroom apartment in a small, sevenstory apartment house at 2785 Broadway, near 107th Street.

title: Students Protest at Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (UPI)Some 150 University of Pennsylvania students staged a protest yesterday, charging they were not consulted in the selection of President Ford as their commencement speaker.

title: May Meeting of NATO To Be Summit Parley
description: BRUSSELS, April 18 (AP) The North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today to transform its regular spring meeting next month into a fullscale conference attended by President Ford and other government chiefs, a NATO spokesman announced.

title: PRINCETON STUDENTS PROTEST RISE IN FEE
description: PRINCETON, April 8 (UPI)More than 350 Princeton University students demonstrated today against a $625ayear tuition rise and called upon the administration to open all financial records and finance meetings to the public.

title: Amnesty Concerned
description: LONDON, April 18A spokesman for Amnesty International said tonight it was gravely concerned about the reported arrest of Mr. Tverdokhlebov and the searches in the homes of other members of its Moscow chapter.

title: Market Place
description: The persistent strength of the stock market despite considerable distressing news on the economic front has led some observers to conclude that unusual market factors are at work.

title: Ford, on Bicentennial Trip, Bids U.S. Heed Old Values
description: BOSTON, April 18President Ford, visiting New England as the celebration of the American Revolution Bicentennial is getting under way, called today for a reversal of what he said was the longterm movement toward big government and a return to the basic American virtues.

title: In Mississippi Delta, the Word Is Soybeans
description: William H. Houston 3d, who might be described as a gentleman farmer, looked at the sky to gauge the chances of rain. What we don't need, he said is a threeinch rainfall, A heavy downpour would only complicate our problem.

title: STATUS OF YOUTHS IN COURT AT ISSUE
description: The key to reducing the rate of violent juvenile crime in the community is not punishment upstate after the act, but prevention in the community before the act, a representative of the Citizens Committee for Children told two legislative committees yesterday.

title: Students Protest at Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (UPI)Some 150 University of Pennsylvania students staged a protest yesterday, charging they were not consulted in the selection of President Ford as their commencement speaker.

title: Skin Rashes From Sandals
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that many Americans develop skin rashes from sandals made of water buffalo hides, perhaps because animal urine is used in the curing process. The commission advised consumers to soak the sandals in hot water before wearing them.

title: Antiques: In Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  We've always tried to be fancier here, Robert Hutchinson remarked as he flipped open the tambour top on a superbly crafetd late 18thcentury English desk that he is willing to part with for $3,500.

title: Notes on People
description: One of America's most durable politicians, Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago, began yesterday his 21st year and sixth terminoffice. The jovial mood of the 72year and sixth termin office. trasted with his often fiery outbursts to the press during the election campaign, which he won with 78 per cent of the vote April 1.

title: Reds Said to Tell Civilians In Phnom Penh to Leave
description: Thousands of Cambodian civilians were reported yesterday to be leaving Phnom Penh under orders from the victorious Communists.

title: Study Finds Chemical Pollution Of Drinking Water in 79 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Environmental Protection Agency has found the drinking water of 79 American cities polluted with traces of organic chemicals, including some that are suspected of being causes of cancer.

title: Oil Exporters Increasing Foreign Aid
description: PARIS, April 18Oilexporting countries accounted for a sixth of official development aid from rich to poor countries last year, Western aid officials reported today.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, ??

title: WILLIAM H. BURKE
description: HATFIELD, Mass., April 18 (AP)William H. Burke, former Democratic state chairman and collector of the Port of Boston, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 69 years old.

title: A Reputed Loanshark Acquitted in Tax Case
description: NEWARK, April 18 (UPI) A reputed loanshark, Vincent M. Morris of Hackensack, was acquitted by a jury today on two counts of Federal incometax evasion.

title: Army Major Guilty of Taking Draft Evasion Bribes
description: An Army major in Selective Service headquarters here was convicted yesterday of accepting $50,000 in bribes over A threeyear period to help hundreds of young men escape the draft during the war in Vietnam.

title: Lexington and Concord Battles Spelled the Death of a Second England
description: On April 19, 1775, something fell apart that could never be put together again.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF AS TRADING DROPS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed lower yesterday as trading decreased.

title: 5 Councilmen Air Complaints On Jersey City Bus Terminal
description: Five of Jersey City's nine Councilmen toured the Journal Square area yesterday, and asked for a meeting with Mayor Paul T. Jordan to discuss complaints by merchants and commuters about the design of the new bus terminal of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Business Briefs
description: The First National City Bank yesterday kept unchanged at 7 per cent its prime interest rate on corporate loans.

title: Dance: Meehan Troupe
description: In Grapes and Stones, a firstrate premiere, Nancy Meehan has created the moderndance equivalent of Agon, George Balanchine's enduring and still avantgarde ballet.

title: Study Finds Chemical Pollution Of Drinking Water in 79 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Environmental Protection Agency has found the drinking water of 79 American cities polluted with traces of organic chemicals, including some that are suspected of being causes of cancer.

title: Chad Appoints 4 Groups to Run Nation
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 18 Chad's ruling military council today appointed the members of the four national commissions that are to supervise the functions of the Government.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Shell Loses $290Million In Joint Nuclear Venture
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group lost about $290million in 1974 on its nuclear joint venture with the Gulf Oil Corporation, according to the annual report of the Shell Transport and Trading Company which was released yesterday. The report also said that the company plans to spend about $7.2billion on North Sea oil projects between now and 1980.

title: Apodaca Rejoins Mets; Webb Sent to Minors
description: The New York Mets added an arm to their besieged bull pen yesterday when they restored Bob Apodaca to the active list as the Chicago Cubs reached town with the best record in baseball.

title: Foolish Pleasure on Outside As Wood Draws 15 Horses
description: A surprising field of 15 has been entered for today's Wood Memorial. If all go, the 51st running of the 1mile test for 3yearolds will be worth a gross of $121,400, with a winner's the share of $72,840. However, Kenny Noe, the racing secretary and handicapper for the New York Racing Association, believes there may be one or two scratches, particularly if it rains.

title: Bridge:
description: When former teammates find themselves in opposition, the rivalry is usually intense, and the district final of the Grand National Team Championship, to be played here tomorrow, will be no exception. Play will be at the Card School, 575 Park Avenue, beginning at noon, with restricted admission for spectators.

title: FISCHER AND SOVIET EXCHANGE MESSAGES
description: Bobby Fischer of South Pasadena, Calif., and the Soviet Chess Federation in Moscow exchanged messages through an intermediary in the Philippines yesterday, but there was no evident progress toward setting up a match between the former world champion and his Russian successor, Anatoly Karpov.

title: Two Fined $300 Over Fire At Crusading Newspaper
description: WHITESBURG, Ky., April 18 (AP)Two men have been fined $300 plus court costs after pleading guilty to charges stemming from the burning of the offices of a crusading weekly newspaper, The Mountain Eagle.

title: House Panel Approves 3c Rise In Gasoline Tax Next January
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Voting informally in the absence of a quorum, the House Ways and Means committee gave preliminary approval today to a proposal to add 3 cents a gallon to the Federal gasoline tax next January, with the possibility of an additional rise of 20 cents in 1977 or later.

title: In France, Our Lives Are . . . More Pleasant
description: PARIS, April 18Fourandahalf years ago, Stuart Troup, then a 36yearold widower with two young children, decided to become an expatriate. He set off for Rome after selling his house in Huntington, L. I., his Lincoln Continental and most of his possessions. His goal: Something a little more humane in his life.

title: Decision by Exchange
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange, which planned to move its San Francisco operations to its Los Angeles trading floor so that it could use the San Francisco space to start a new stock options program, decided yesterday to leave its two trading floors unchanged for the present. Its new options trading program, slated to begin before the end of the year, will start in other space near present operations in San Francisco.

title: State Law Urged to Define Death as Stoppage of Brain
description: City medical and lawenforcement officials agreed yesterday to press for a new definition of death in New York State to include stoppage of brain function. They said the move would greatly increase the number of organs available for transplant.

title: City, State and U.S. Study Abuses in Medicaid Here
description: Federal, state and city agencies are investigating Medicaid practices that are costing taxpayers tens of millions of dollars a year in overcharges, city health officials reported yesterday. The officials said that fraudusually involving billing at least twice for the same service or billing for services not givenaccounts for substantial sums. But they said the major cause of the overcharges was duplicated and unnecessary services.

title: NORTH REINFORCES LINE AT XUAN LOC
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 19  Heavy North Vietnamese reinforcements moved yesterday into the battle for Xuan Loc, 38 miles northeast of here, as other Communist troops staged a series of smallscale attacks closer to Saigon.

title: Now, It's the Midday Ride of Dino Di Carlo
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., April 18As Voltaire noted a long, long time ago, those who make history seldom realize it.

title: Kibbee Urges Board to Ask A College Head to Resign
description: The Chancellor of the City University, Dr. Robert 3. Kibbee, has recommended to the Board of Higher Education that it ask for the resignation of Dr. Edgar D. Draper, president of the longtroubled Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Illnesses Among Volunteers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 (AP)Diarrhea, rashes or bacterial infections have hit about 300 volunteers who cared for nearly 1,000 Vietnamese children airlifted to the United States in recent weeks, health officials say.

title: Celebration at City Hall Piazza
description: For five hours yesterday, the French Renaissance facade of City Hall, bedecked with banners and garlands of laurel, was transformed into what the Italian Consul General, Vieri Traxler, called an Italian palazzo.

title: Kings Beat Bulls and Tie Series
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18 (UPI)  Jimmy Walker scored 8 of his 30 points in overtime, spurring the Kansas CityOmaha Kings to a 104100 victory tonight over the Chicago Bulls. The victory evened the National Basketball Association playoff series at two games apiece.

title: Automobile Layoffs To Show Increase; Some Are Recalled
description: DETROIT, April 18The total number of United States auto workers laid off will climb slightly next week but some are being recalled from Indefinite layoff rolls.

title: BOMBS DESTROY OFFICES IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Saturday, April 19 Bombs exploded early today in Tokyo and in the city of Amagasaki in central Japan.

title: EXPORT OF URANIUM TO SOVIET APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)  The Nuclear Regulatory Agency approved today the export of 1.1 million pounds of nautral uranium for processing in Birtain and the Soviet Union.

title: 70 Keeps Miss Palmer A Stroke Ahead at 140
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 18Sandra Palmer, a 5footinch slip of a woman who belts the ball tremendous distances, shot another 70 today to go four under par at 140 and keep a stroke ahead of Jocelyne Bourassa at the halfway stage of the $200,000 ColgateDinah Shore golf tournament.

title: People in Sports
description: Lee Calhoun, the former Olympic gold medal winner who has been an assistant track coach at Yale for the past five years, is the Elis' new head coach. He succeeds Bob Giegengack, who will retire July 1 after 29 years in the post.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: L.I. ANTIGRAFT AIDE INDICTED AS BRIBER
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., April 18 The man who was appointed by Suffolk County to insure that its transactions with realestate dealers were free of corruption was indicted here today on charges of soliciting and receiving $200,000 in bribes from a developer for whom he had allegedly obtained lucrative contracts.

title: L.I. ANTIGRAFT AIDE INDICTED AS BRIER
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., April 18 The man who was appointed by Suffolk County to insure that its transactions with realestate dealers were free of corruption was indicted here today on charges of soliciting and receiving $200,000 in bribes from a developer for whom he had allegedly obtained lucrative contracts.

title: Reid Opposes Concorde Flights Here
description: Chances that the Concorde supersonic transport would be allowed even limited flights here were lessened yesterday by testimony of a key state official at Federal hearings.

title: Breath Test for Students
description: COATESVILLE, Pa., April 18 (UPI)The Superintendent of the Coatesville School District said today that the Board of Education had unanimously voted to allow the use of a breathtester to determine if students were coming to school drunk.

title: Attica Accountability
description: When Attica inmates rebelled three and a half years ago, they began a process that ultimately threw the question of state government accountability onto a substantially larger canvas than they could ever have foreseen. All the inmates wanted was to make correction authorities accountable for neglect of their needs and rights. The passage of time, the pattern of indictments flowing from those turbulent days and the charges of a former state prosecutor have raised the stake considerably. The question now facing Bernard S. Meyer, the newly appointed special Attica investigator, is whether New York State has attempted to place its own governmental actions above and beyond the law.

title: Brooklyn Man Cited In Bilking Families Of 1.2Million Here
description: Andrew Montero, of 3626 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, was indicted by a special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having bilked about 400 families of $1.2million in the sale of cosmetics and flashlightbattery distributorships.

title: Elizabeth Rita Culligan Is Married
description: In St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Rock, N.J., yesterday morning, Elizabeth Rita Culligan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Culligan of Glen Rock, became the bride of Frederick Carl Hoefer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoefer of Wabash, Ind.

title: OPEC Riches, Even Revised, Bespeak Power
description: WASHINGTON  Oilexporting nations are not going to become as rich as many once thought. This is the principal conclusion of the World Bunk's latest report on the repercussions of the oil price rise, now being circulated, confidentially to the United States Administration and other member governments.

title: Maclver's LuminousArt at Montclair
description: MONTCLALRVisitors to the Montclair Art Museum's Loren MacIver exhibition, which opens today, will step out of the matteroffact world into one of whimsy and poetry.

title: Olga Davidson Affianced to Classicist
description: Olga Merck Davidson, who will graduate next month from Boston University, and Gregory BoszormenyiNagy of Baltimore, professor of classics at Johns Hopkins University, plan to be married in

title: Temperature Surges In Warm Front Here
description: A warm front from the Southwest descended upon the city yesterday morning, boosting, the temperature 10 degrees in one hourfrom 60 degrees at 10 A.M. to 70 at 11and catching those who shed their coats with the blustery rains that followed.

title: COOP CLAIMS CASH IN CONNALLY TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The milk producers cooperative has claimed $10,000 of the cash that was introduced as evidence in the bribery trial of John B. Connally Jr., the former Treasury Secretary.

title: Art School for Handicapped.
description: MONTCLAIR  Stanley Obritski Jr. arrives at the Yard School of Art every Wednesday, arranges his materials and sets out to create a floral, landscape or stilllife painting in watercolors. His picturesbursts of color and intricate brush strokes  are exhibited throughout the United States.

title: DALEY MAKES BID FOR MORE POWER
description: CHICAGO, April 19In one of the oldest of political games, Mayor Richard J. Daley tried this week to pick up two more Congressional seats for his Cook County Democratic machine and at the same time reduce the voting influence of Republicandominated suburbs surrounding Chicago.

title: Englewood Hospital To Dedicate Wing
description: ENGLEWOODEnglewood Hospital's new Dean Street Wing, built to alleviate overcrowding and serious delays in admissions, will be officially dedicated on May 18.

title: Article 8  No Title
Special Class at Medical School Concentrates on Human relations in Newark
description: NEWARK  Fourteen casually attired men and women are seated before a classroom blackboard that is covered with physiology formulas, equations and graphs. Soon, three of the group are erasing the medical data and replacing it with chalk marks.

title: 2 Groups Seek to Improve City's Image Nationwide
description: Two new groups are working to improve the selfimage of New Yorkers and the city's reputation around the country.

title: TUESDAY
description: 7:40 A.M. The President, accompanied by two Secret Service men and a valet carrying the brown suitcase, arrives from the residence. He is dressed today in a flashy suit of bold vertical stripes of shades of gray; he looks a bit drawn this morning. It is raining again.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: Ford at Ford's
description: A pleasant punctuation mark was placed on Ford's Theater the other night when President. Ford attended a performance there of Give Em Hell, Harry, a play about President Truman. It was the first time that any President had spent an evening there since the fateful performance of Our American Cousin on another April in 1865.

title: 6 Die in Turkish Floods
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 19 (AP)  Heavy spring rains caused flash floods in four Turkish provinces today, killing six persons and leaving scores homeless, officials said.

title: REVISIONS SEEN IN LOBBYING LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Another report was issued today documenting the inadequacy of the Federal lobbying control law and lobbyists here are predicting a Congressional crackdown on their activities.

title: TV Notes: Family Hour Won't Be Bambi Time
description: The television networks are bracing for the controversy that is bound to arise from their selection of programs for the new family viewing hour next fall. This is because family to some minds suggests childoriented, which was not what the networks had in mind earlier this year when, under pressure from the Federal Communications Commission, they pledged to cleanse the P.M. hour each night of programs too sexually explicit or too violent for children.

title: St. James Hospital Marks Its 75th Year
description: NEWARKSt. James Hospital is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year and its role as a key facility in this city's Ironbound district.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Muscles, Shades of Charles Atlas and Bernarr Macfadden! A book on the art and sport of bodybuilding with a firm grip on the best seller list! Pumping Iron is a pioneering foray into that world where men are obsessed by a strange desire  to turn their naturaly gargantuan physiques into Hellenistic statues so that they may compete for such titles as Mr. America, Mr. Olympia and Mr. Universe.

title: Jeannette Diehl Bride of John Breazeale
description: Jeannette Louise Diehl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lester Diehl of Yonkers, was married yesterday afternoon to John Nicholls Breazeala, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hopkins Payne Breazeale Jr. of Baton Rouge, La.

title: For Brooklyn's Chelsea Theater, Manhattan Is a Profitable Sideshow
description: It's as if we're a church with gambling in the basement  Diamond Studs is our bingo game.

title: Scouting University Training: readers
description: MENDHAM  Seventeen times a year, 30 to 35 men and an occasional woman check in at the Schiff Scout Reservation near this Morris County village. Twentyfour days later, after a tram course in the programs and administrative methods of the Boy Scouts of America, they scatter to all parts of the country.

title: Auction to Benefit Plainfield Center
description: PLAINFIELD  The Jewish Community Center, 403 West Seventh Street, will be the site of a country auction from noon to 4 P.M. today.

title: Church Will Present German Requiem
description: MONTCLAIR  Brahms's German Requiem, considered by most authorities as the composer's greatest choral work, will be presented next Sunday afternoon at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 73 South Fullerton Avenue.

title: Grand Jury Urges a New Jail for Ocean County
description: TOMS RIVERAn Ocean County grand jury has recommended, following a sixmonth investigation, the construction of a new county jail and the removal of guards from Civil Service jurisdiction.

title: Nadia N. Eckstein Is Married on L.I.
description: Nadia Nanette Eckstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guido Lchow Eckstein of Lloyd Harbor, L. I., and Christopher A. Bohlman, son of Eleanor R. Bohlman of Lloyd Harbor and John W. Bohlman of Huntington, L. I., were married yesterday afternoon in Huntington in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Emanual Gorden.

title: QLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Merry I. White Bride at M.I.T.
description: Merry Isaacs White and Lewis David Wurgaft, assistant professor of history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel at M.I.T. by Nancy Richardson, a member of the United Ministry of Harvard University and M.I.T.

title: Vietcong Say They Found 2 Members of Truce Team
description: HONG KONG, April 19 (Reuters)The Viet Cong have located two members of the International Control Commission who had been missing since the fall of the Central Highlands town of Ban Me Thuot last month, the North Vietnam press agency reported today.

title: Marijuana Bill Proposed
description: WASHINTON, April 19 (UPI)Four Senators and a Congressman have proposed legislation to reduce the private possession of an ounce or less of marijuana to a civil violation subject to a Federal fine of no more than $100. Senators Alan Cranston, Democrat of California; Taylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin; Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts; Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, sponsored the bill.

title: Power First In Relay on Weaver Leg
City Cites Progress On Ocean Parkway
description: With most of the controversy over the repaving of Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn resolved, construction on the sixmile treelined boulevard is expected to begin before the end of the year, Commissioner of Highways Anthony R. Ameruso told community leaders last week.

title: Cook College Lists Program for Young
description: NEW BRUNSWICKTours for 1,500 scienceminded high school students, specialinterest talks, exhibits, a chicken barbecue and contests pitting undergraduates against faculty members are among the events to be held at the 14th annual Spring Program at Cook College Friday and Saturday.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Avisitor from Europe asked me recently what's new in American photography, and I spoke of Benno Friedman. But then I asked myself, are Benno Friedman's photographs really so new? Certainly they make the classic modernism of Edward Weston, which still dominates so much critical thinking about photography, look passThey even go beyond all but the most advanced work of the snapshot esthetic photographers. And yet, despite their impeccably uptodate look, they are, in a way, a reversion to the oldfashioned Pictorialism of the turnofthecentury photographic Salons.

title: Paperbacks
description: COLETTE, by Margaret. Crosland. (Dell/Laurel, 81.25.) The best biography yet of the prolific. enormously talented, now legendary French writer.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS FEAR CRACKDOWN
description: MOSCOW, April 19Soviet dissidents expressed general fear today that the future of the small chapter here of Amnesty International was in jeopardy following the arrests yesterday of two members and the seizure of publications from the apartments of two other members.

title: Lawyer Is Fiance Of Lucia Bosqui, Finance Analyst
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Bosqui of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Lucia Bosqui, to Joseph Welles Henderson 3d, son of J. Welles Henderson of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late Helen Lipscomb Jennings.

title: Gardening From An Armchair Has Its Rewards
description: When I was an active plant doctor, I looked down a bit on armchair gardeners who gave advice more from books than practical experience. Four years ago, when a virus disease left me permanently somewhat disabled, I became quite literally an armchair gardener. I can walk a little but I can't stand very long and I don't dare get down on my knees.

title: The Stage: Bluebeard
LETTERS
description: Ecology

title: Sneaky People By Thomas Berger. 315 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $8.95.
description: What you do, see, is go out and buy Sneaky People. Period. No questicins asked. Strip off the dust jacket right there, in your local bookstore. Take it from me, you don't want any hint of the splendid, gaudy surprises beforehand. Come at this novel with the same delightful ignorance that Thomas Berger's characters have as their only stock in trade. When did you ever believe a publisher's blurb, anyway? Also, forget the cheap, putdown title. Sneaky People is funny, wise and very significant. What more do you need to know?

title: After the Fall: Nets Should Rebound Before Knicks
description: The Knicks and Nets finished their seasons on similar notes, each shocked at being quickly eliminated from the playoffs, each facing fundamental questions about the future that had been evaded through niost of the season. Now, with the shock wearing off, their managements must separate the immediate. causes of playoff failure from underlying problems before the future can be plotted intelligently.

title: Point of View
description: There has probably never been such a concerted effort as there is now to cope with the whole fire problem. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 has won Congressional passage and given birth to the National Fire Prevention and Control Administration the first agency with the potential to coordinate, unify and encourage the country's diverse fireprevention activities.

title: Best Sellers
U.S. Ruling on Rent Faces Tenant Fight
description: TRENTONAn organization representing New Jersey apartment dwellers has begun a campaign to rescind a temporary regulation that exempts from local rent controls any housing supported by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Stamp Marks 1775 Bathe
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., April 19 (UPI)The official Bicentennial stamp depicting the Battle of Lexington, the first armed clash between Minutemen and the British 200 years ago, was issued today. The 10cent stamp was based on a painting by Henry Sandham titled Birth of Liberty, which hangs in the Cary Memorial Building here.

title: COMMUNISTS TAKE KEY COAST TOWN IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 20Communist forces overran the last Governmentheld enclave on the central coast today and elsewhere North Vietnamese gunners rendered the nation's most important fighter base largely unusable.

title: Nassau Police Mark Jubilee
description: MINEOLAA crosssection of history spanning the flapperera antics, terrorism of the Black Hand and an invasion by a Nazi UBoat may be be recalled by many oldtimers as the Nassau County police force prepares to observe its 50th anniversary.

title: Handle With Care 4th In Her First '75 Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 19 Handle With Care, the fastest mare in harness racing history, finished fourth tonight in her season's debut at Roosevelt Raceway, before a crowd of 26,306.

title: Carlene C. Harris Bride of Dr. Bonner
description: Dr. Thomas Neville Bonner, president of Union College, and Carlene Carey Harris, director of university relations for the State University of New York at Binghamton, were married in the Memorial Chapel on the Union campus in Schenectady, N. Y., yesterday evening. The Rev. Dr. Norman B. Johnson, a Dutch Reformed minister and emeritus chaplain at Union, performed the nondenominational ceremony. Previous marriages for the couple ended in divorce.

title: A Perky Planter For the Patio
description: Modern versions of the strawberry barrel are far less cumbersome than the oldfashioned kinds made out of a wooden cask or barrel.

title: City Parks Bracing for Busy Season
description: Edwin L. Weisl Jr. lit his fourth cigarette in an hour. It was sunny outside; but Mr. Weisl was sitting in a stuffy conference room at Flushing Meadow Park, listening to a torrent of employe complaints.

title: Article 11  No Title
Notes: Cruise Ships Chart Course for Suez
description: A JOURNEY through the Suez Canal was once the hallmark of the welltraveled. It used to take up to 17 hours for a large cruise ship to negotiate the 100mile long waterway between Port Said and the Gulf of Suez. The scenery, veterans recall, was mainly desert, although passengers did see the Egyptian barracks at Ismailia (a former British Army outpost), catch a glimpse on a clear day of Mount Ararat far to the east in Turkey and spot an occasional Bedouin camel driver. Yet tedious though it may have been, the trip through the canal was intriguing, too, for most voyagersand now it is going to be possible to sail it once again.

title: Miss Connors Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Connors of Phoenix, Ariz., formerly of Albertson, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Maureen Connors, to Thomas Michael O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul O'Brien of Rome, N. Y.

title: Avenue C Neighbors and Police Celebrate a Growing Friendship
description: Up until few years ago, people on the Lower East Side used to throw bottles at the police, William Gundersen, commanding officer of the Ninth Police Precinct on East Fifth Street said yesterday as he observed festive children and adults milling around a crimeprevention van and sawing to Latin music.

title: U.S. Funds to Aid Rockaway Stores
description: The city has allocated $1.3million of anticipated Federal community  development funds to upgrade the Far Rockaway shopping area in Queens, which in recent years has been steadily deteriorating.

title: THIRD LEFTIST KILLED IN ITALIAN VIOLENCE
description: ROME, April 19 (Reuters)Another young leftist was killed today as violence flared in major Italian cities for the fourth successive day.

title: In Saigon, It Is Every Man For Himself, Nobody for Thieu
description: SAIGONA South Vietnamese Army captain in a neatly pressed green uniform and polished boots stood by the side of Route 1 north of Saigon as thousands of refugees and fleeing soldiers pushed past him in panic. The captain had a motorbike loaded with rice and water in a large plastic bottle. He had come up from his office in Saigon, he said, to look for his parents, who had been trapped in the battle for Xuan Loc. He had brought the food and water in case he found them.

title: What's Doing in BRASILIA
description: BIRTHDAY  Brasilia celebrates its 15th birthday tomorrow with the conviction that it's here to stay. Most of the past decade and a half was spent inland Brazilians that this inland city is a fait accompli and getting them to leave the pleasures of Rio de Janeiro, the country's former capital. An Italian monk, Dom Bosco, is :credited with dreaming of a modern city, in the heart of the Brazilian bush three centuries ago, but nothing was done about it until another visionary, Juscelino Kubitschek, promised in 1955 that if he were elected President he would build a new capital during his fiveyear term, He was elected and he kept his promise.

title: North's Drive Defies Orthodoxy
description: North Vietnam's unorthodox strategy and tactics have made heavy gains over South Vietnam's poorly implemented military orthodoxy, United States analysts have concluded after preliminary stuaies of the fighting. The transfer of aircraft, equipment, munitions and headquarters from Bien Hoa to Saigon; the concentration of Communist' forces, including three fresh divisions, north, east and south of the capital; the increase in harassing actions on the edge of the cityall these indicate to the American analysts that the stage is being set for the final act.

title: Records Hint Paul Revere Got First Expense Account
description: BOSTON, April 19 (UPI)While there are no known records that Paul Revere was paid for his famous ride 200 years ago today, he may have filed the nation's first expense account with a Government agency.

title: Births
description: Abraham

title: U.S. Experts Predict a Good Grain Harvest in Soviet This Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Conditions appear to be very good for a large increase in Soviet grain production this year, United States experts on Soviet agricultural developments said this week.

title: Ohio an Has TwoSuit Job
description: TOLEDO, Ohio (AP)Byron Myler, a longtime employe of a motor inn here, is something of a quickchange artist. Mr. Myler wears a uniform as bell captain and often changes to a business suit to serve as a house detective.

title: Reta Shannon Is Bride Of Robert A. Laughlin
description: Reta Waid Shannon, daughter of Mrs. Walter M. Waid of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Mr. Waid, was married yesterday morning to Robert A. Laughlin, a partner in S. P. Cooper & Co., certified public accountants here. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laughlin of Commack, L. I.

title: The Kissinger Style: Less Panic, Not Squishy
description: WASHINGTONIf you write something friendly about him I'll never speak to you again. said the stenographer on the fifth floor of the State Department, who knew the man at close quarters.

title: Red Smith
description: There may in the past have been mention here of a day's fishing on. Lough Corrib in Ireland with a guide named Dick, who had been born in Galway and had always lived there except for three years in New York. The trout were not on the feed that day and Dick took it as a personal affront that they rejected every fly pattern offered. Never mind, said his client, to whom suffering skunkage was no new experience, I'm going to the Galway races next week and I'll have better luck there. I suppose you go every year?

title: Rep, Hebert Museum Plan Is Assailed
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 19A museum to house memorabilia of Representative F. Edward Hbert which President Ford plans to dedicate on a visit here Wednesdayis running into local opposition for taking public park land to honor a living politician.

title: Journalism Dean Named
description: TOPEKA, Kan; April 19 (AP) Paul Delbert Brinkman was named yesterday as dean of the William Allen White School of Journalism at the University of Kansas. Mr. Brinkman, 38 years old, has been acting dean since the resignation last December of Edward Bassett.

title: CHESS
description: Nowadays there are players who approach games with such a vast amount of memorized opening theory and practice buzzing around in their heads that they lose their poise in dealing with anything off the beaten track. One cannot fault opening studies as such; for tournament players to dispense with them in favor of a rough and unready attack is to court disaster.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Ten years ago this month, an associate professor of history at Rutgers University, Eugene D. Genovese, touched off a political uproar when he said at an antiwar campus teachin: I do not fear or regret the impending Vietcong victory in Vietnam. I welcome it.

title: As ever, Sol Yurick
description: Five years ago I learned, from the intricate patterns of his short stories in Someone Just Like Me, or almost 10 years ago from the complex designs of Fertig, how easy it always was to get into Sol Yurick's halfbeast, halfalltoohuman urban world, Once in there, I was caught ineluctably until the last labyrinthine wordstructure was given me. I was haunted by the strange reality of his cityscapes, the beguiling mazes he dragged me through, because his people were more than characters. They were creations of his subtle wordplay, his seemingly inescapable logorrhea.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: THE PEASANT SMOCK

title: Vietcong Hint That Saigon May Get Chance for Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19A senior Vietcong official hinted today that the Communist side might delay an expected military onslaught against Saigon to allow time for a possible peaceful conclusion of the war.

title: Comeback for Hair of the Camel
description: In the maelstrom of thousands of natural and synthetic fiber blends that make up the billions of yards of fabric used in the world of fashion every year, some of the oldest types will sometimes float to the top.

title: Judges Take a Hasty Tour of 2 Prisons
description: One hundred and sixty judges presiding over criminal cases in New York City were bustled through the corridors of the Rikers Island Detention Center and Ossining State Corrections facility yesterday in an unusual, and to some, unsatisfactory, visit to the institutions they can force people to live in.

title: PALAY SINGS CANIO IN CITY OPERA BOW
description: Elliot Palay, who made his debut with the New York City Opera on Friday night as Canio in Pagliacci, has had a career both familiar and unusual. A native of Milwaukee, he studied with Charles Kullman at Indiana University and then went on to sing in some of the smaller German opera houses at Lbeck and Freiburg. A year ago, when he was 25, he sang Tristan, which must make him one of the youngest tenors ever to tackle that formidable role.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Pittsburgh

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The American Revolution Bicentennial Administration has good news for collectors who want all of the official Mintstruck Bicentennial commemorative medals but who missed out on the A.R.B.A.'s earlier offerings (emphasis is placed on the words Mintstruck because many collectors feel that only those medals produced by the U.S. Mint are truly official.) The A.R.B.A. has discovered a small stockpile of several hundred pieces left over from the first two issuesdated 1972 and 1973in its Bicentennial medal series and is offering them for sale now on a first come, first served basis at original issue prices.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, April 19 (AP)The. champion Soviet Union hockey team overpowered Sweden, 134, today to complete play in the 1975 world ice hockey championships with a perfect 1000 wonlosttied record. Czechoslovakia, the silver medal winner, finished with an 82 recordthe two losses to the Soviet Unionby scoring four goals in the second period en route to a 51 victory over Finland. The loss by Finland guaranteed the bronze medal for Sweden. Both teams finished with 55 records, but Sweden earned the thirdplace finish because of a better goal count.

title: CAREY, BEAME AGREE ON AIRCODE MOVE
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame have both signed consent degrees that in effect order the city and state to adhere to a stepbystep program to clean the city's air over the next two years.

title: Students to Run Model Congress
description: POMONAThe introduction of bills, as well as hot debates and touches of lobbying and logrolling, are expected to take place here next Saturday, when more than 150 Senators and Representatives from 25 public and private secondary schools in the state convene for the sixth annual Model Congress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Frederick B. Tolles Dead; Teacher of Colonial History
description: Frederick B. Tolles, professor emeritus of Colonial history at Swarthmore College, died Friday at a nursing home in Wallingford, Pa., on his 60th birthday. His home was in Swarthmare.

title: 160,000 Mark Two 1775 Battles; Concord Protesters Jeer Ford
description: CONCORD, Mass., April 19More than 160,000 Americans here and in nearby Lexington celebrated today the anniversary of the battles that opened their Revolution. They celebrated in ways that sometimes reflected the differing strains that 200 years of the nation's history have brought.

title: FILM VIEW
description: As if he were a member of some privileged order, Michelangelo Antonioni is allowed to see things the rest of us cannot. In his stunning new film, The Passenger, he shares that privilege with us. His camera's eye is a laser that transforms everything it sees into a more precise definition of the thing representedobjects, people, movements, landscapes. Yet the definition of the thing representedand this is the rubbecomes increasingly ambiguous the closer Antonioni's camera gets. The same thing happens when you say the same word over and over again so often that finally only the sound is left. We return to essentials.

title: Town Hall Recital On Piano Is Given By Ian Shapinsky
description: Ian Shapinsky, the young American pianist who appeared in recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, could be called a pounder, but at least he pounds to mostly good effect.

title: Marston's Chow Chow Earns First Top Award
description: RESTON, Va., April 19Joel Martson, a television acOr from Sun Valley Calif., and his hombred chow chow, Ch. Starcrest Lemon Drop Kid, put on a great show today and triumphed at the Old Dominion Kennel Club of Northern Virginia event in rainsoaked Reston Park.

title: On the Hopelessness of Turning Good Books Into Films
description: I call myself a professional novelist, meaning an exhausted hack who tries to sell bookpacked dreams to the public, but increasingly I find I am not allowed to be a novelist, although my right to be a professional something is affirmed rather than contested. Put it that I am a sort of British man of letters living more or less in Rome, that Radiotelevisione Italiana and the, International Television Corporation of London are anxious to make telefilm epics and sell them to America, and then it will be easily understood why I am ceasing to be a novelist. There is work in the great demotic medium for an Inglese italianato, and, by God or Dio, I am doing it. I have already written the script for a series on Moses, which the American networks will show this year, and am working on Jesus Christ, Michelangelo and. Shakespeare. I call all this my televisual tetralogy on Great Men, and I would rather write novels.

title: Mrs. Knauer Asks Caution On Gas Mileage Gadgets
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)Consumers should be leery of gadgets promising better gas mileage because many of them are nearly useless, Virginia H. Knauer, President Ford's adviser on consumer affairs, said today.

title: I.R.S. Gives Guidelines For 5% Tax Credit
description: The Internal Revenue Service has issued guidelines clarifying the conditions under which buyers may qualify for a tax credit for the purchase of a new home.

title: Hawks and Doves Are Glad It's Ending
description: From hawk and dove alike there seems to he relief that the American involvement in Southeast Asia is at long last all but over.

title: Epilogue
description: Darwin CleanUp

title: Irate Pot Lobstermen Mapping Survival Strategy
description: BELFORD  New Jersey's pot lobstermen, beset by foreign trawlers, vastly increased competition and the threat of state regulations that they say would severely limit supplies of the crustaceans, are angry and fighting back.

title: Design
description: Lelia and Massimo Vignelli (she is an architect; he is a graphic and industrial designer) have contributed much to the roster of what now qualifies as classic design. Their boxlike sofa of lacquered wood and loose leather cushions, called the Saratoga and designed 11 years ago, was the first example of furniture that looks like part of the architecture of a room. Their line of stacking plastic dinnerware, which is in the permanent design collection of the Museum of Modern Art, won the Compasso D'Oro, Italy's highest award for design, in 1964. Their svelte Bloomingdale's logo, created in 1972, replaced the flowery script that had identified the store since the nineteenthirties.

title: A Vasectomy Camp, With Prizes for All, Is Set Up in Madras
description: MADRAS, IndiaThe community marriage hall of the Royapuram residential colony in a crowded section of this city has been given a new role. It is serving as a vasectomy camp to sterilize men who do not want more children.

title: EQUALITY SOUGHT BY JEWISH COEDS
description: Jewish women at more than a score of colleges are quietly seeking equality in religious ritual, the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundations report.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT dropped at an annual rate of more than 10 per tent in the first quarter of this year, the steepest dive in 29 years, but the price deflator showed inflation at an annual rate of 8 per cent, the lowest In almost two years.... The Labor Department said that an additional 31 major labor areas had been added to its list of areas with substantial unemployment in March, meaning unemployment was expected to continue at a seasonally adjusted rate of 6 per cent or more for at least two months. Industrial output slipped 1 per cent last month, the sixth monthly decline in a row but the smallest since October.

title: Las Vegas: How to Eat, Drink and Gamble on the House
description: THERE is no paper shortage in Las Vegas, Nev. The folk's who own or operate the less renowned motels and casinos are offering visitors free coupons, fun books, gift certificates, economy packets and all manner of other freebees in unprecedented numbers in an effort to, fill their airconditioned rooms, scatter sunburned bodies around their pools and crowd their gambling casinos.

title: Princess Nowedonah Dies; Lectured on Shinnecocks
description: SOUTHAMPTON, LI., April 19 (UPI)Princess Nowedonah, a Shinnecock Indian and a collage lecturer on the history and customs of her tribe, died yesterday in Southampton Flospital. She was 71 years old.

title: EUROPE IS LADEN WITH EXTRA FOOD
description: BRUSSELS, April 19 (AP)Western Europe is groaning under food surpluses and complaining about it.

title: COAST TRIAL TOLD OF DEATH ANGELS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 The chief prosecution witness against four young black men testified in the first week at the murder trial that they were members of a group called the Death Angels, and that the group's purpose was to start a rate war.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Sam Snead, hearing that Johnny Miller had caught a 12pound bass in a pond during the Masters tournament: Son, you never saw the day you could beat me fishing. You probably caught two sixes.

title: Wendy R. Weingarten Will Be Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Weingarten of New York, Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Rae Weingarten, to Laurence Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul I. Miller of Great Neck, L. I.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Washington's running energy policy debate, which started some two years ago, has recently moved into high gear as the Administration and Congress try to come up with legislation to reduce our dependence on highcost foreign oil. Some of the proposals are sensible, enforceable and well research, such as the plan to establish a strategic oil storage reserve and the recognition that the existing price control on old oil produced under secondary recovery methods acts as a disincentive to the installation of new secondary recovery projects or the maintenance of existing ones.

title: TOWN IN PORTUGAL OPPOSED TO REDS
description: OPORTO, Portugal, April 17This middleclass center of the textile and wine industries is preparing to give a large vote to nonCommunist forces in the elections April 25.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The Freedom of Information Act amendments that went into effect two months ago have given Americans access to Federal Government documents that once were difficult, and often impossible, to obtain. And many are making use of that access.

title: State Seeks To Purchase 2,600 Acres Of Wetlands
description: New York State is negotiating with the owners of 2,600 acres of Long Island wetlands to acquire the property Under the provisions of the 1972 Environmental Bond Act.

title: Shop Talk
description: FRANKLIN LAKES  For more than a century, the Roehrs family has come up with at least one distinguished horticulturist in every generation,

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Surprising as it may seem to many amateur photographers who have never tried it, making color prints in a home darkroom is not much more complicated than making black  and  white prints. It can be done in almost any darkroom already equipped for blackandwhite enlarging and at a fraction of the cost of having prints made by a professional lab.

title: Church Bells in Boston Swing While They Ring
description: BOSTON, April 19 (UPI)The 3ton brass bells of Christ Church were let free today to swing round and round in a chorus of sound rather than held fixed with just the clappers inside the bell doing all the work. At 11 A.M. the hells in towers all over Boston joined in a cityring in celebration of the Bicentennial.

title: Answers/Questions
description: TOMATO FERTILIZER (March 30)

title: N.B.A, Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Houston

title: REVISIONS SEEN IN LOBBYING LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Another report was issued today documenting the inadequacy of the Federal lobbying control law and lobbyists here are predicting a Congressional crackdown on their activities.

title: Tomlin Retrospective on Exhibit
description: HEMPSTEAD  Although Bradley Walker Tomlin is not a name as familiar to the art world as Adolph Gottlieb, Franz Kline and Robert Motherwell, he must be considered as one of the motivating forces and spiritual paladins of the abstract expressionist movement.

title: Davis Wins Firestone Bowling
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 19 (AP)Dave Davis won bowling's most lucrative event, the $125,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions, tonight when he posted a 201195 triumph over Barry Asher of Costa Mesa, Calif., in the title game. The '32yearold lefthander won $25,000.

title: Recruiting Revisited: Students' Moral Values Suffer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 3 Brooklyn Youths Accused Of a Kidnapping and Rape
description: Three Brooklyn youths were accused yesterday of kidnapping a young couple in the Coney Island section Friday night and raping the girl, who is 14 years old.

title: Popular Culture Specialists at Hofstra Take a Light Look at Anthropology for the Masses
description: The art director of Mad Magazine has white hair. Irving Howe the literary critic, speaks flawless Yiddish. The CocaCola sign is one of the world's most widely recognized symbols. The Hofstra University Student Center serves flavorless food. And Merle Miller's mother is talking to him again.

title: Carolina to Get Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The mothballed aircraft carrier Yorktown, the fighting lady of World War II fame, will be taken over by the State of South Caroina to become a navy museum at Charleston, the Pentagon announced yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S.Bred Group of Radical Leftists Vexes Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, April 19The tiny Mexican section of an obscure American radical  left group is provoking suspicion and irritation in Mexican political circles through a wellfinanced campaign against the Government.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Peter Allen Fiance Of Margaret Silver
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce Silver of Akron, Ohio and Point O'Woods, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Handy Silver, to Peter Kirby Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Allen of New York and Southampton, L.I.

title: Robyn R. Durrell, Thomas Geissler To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Durrell of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robyn Rae Durrell, to Thomas E. Geissler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Ernest Geissler of Willimantic, Conn.

title: National League
description: Chicago 4, New York 2.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayYonkers K.C. allbreed and obedience match, Tibbetts Brook Park, entries from 9:30 A.M.; judging noon.

title: She never cried over spilt milk
description: By Helen Lawrenson. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Random House. $8.95.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 20, 1975

title: Barbara Wyper Wed to Charlton Pettus
description: Barbara Wyper, a librarian, was married yesterday afternoon to Charlton Messick Pettus, a painter. Both are of Brookline, Mass., where the Rev. George Blackman performed the Episcopal ceremony in the bridegroom's home.

title: Judith McCabe Loutrel Is Wed To Robert Goodchild, a Banker
description: Judith McCabe Loutrel and Robert M. Goodohild were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Robert T. Kelsey in the chapel of Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N. J.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: DETROITThe domino theory is at work in American industry as well as in Southeast Asia, and the biggest domino of them all is Detroit. The collapse of the automobile industry over the past 18 months has knocked over rubber and glass and the national economy as well. Officials here say the auto industry affects 18 per cent of the gross national product.

title: N.Y. Jazz Repertory Company Surveys 75 Years of Changes
description: The New York Jazz Repertory Company's survey of 75 years or jazz on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall pointed up, among things, how much essential jazz territory the company's programs have covered in less than two seasons. A large part of all three segments of the programthe early traditional jazz, the swing period and the jazz of the last quarter of a centuryconsisted of excerpts from earlier programs by the jazz company.

title: It's Not Just Women's Work: Men Who Cook
description: About three times a week, Richard M. Kallman, the actor, sits down to a dinner he has prepared himself. The table is elaborately set with Baccarat crystal and vermeil flatware. The chances are, he shopped for the ingredients at about 5:30 P.M., welcomed his guests at 7:30 P.M. and had his meal on the table a halfhour later.

title: 5 Hurt After 2 Men Leave Burning Gas at Apartment
description: Two men left a burning bottle of gasoline outside an apartment door on the Lower East Side last night, causing a blaze that injured five residents of the building. One of the residentsa 4yearold girlwas injured seriously, the police reported.

title: Music Competition Invites Applicants
description: JERSEY CITY  Applications for the third annual New Jersey Audition Competition are now being accepted. The competition is sponsored by the Friends of Music and Art of Hudson County, and the winner will receive a cash award of $400.

title: A defense of five heretics
description: When a Dickens character wished that a vexatious sailing vessel might end up in Jonadge's belly, her creator observed that she appeared to confound the prophet with the whale. The proper distinction between the prophets and leviathan is maintained, however, in Ronald Radosh's timely study of defamed and neglected critics of United States global foreign policy. as the author struggles to rescue their ideas and reputations from oblivion in the belly of the beast. Unfortunately, the expedition takes place in some very murky waters, and the significance of what is delivered remains obscure.

title: Article 12  No Title
Communist Parties Especially Concerned
description: PARISNext week's Portuguese elections are provoking apprehension throughout Europe, and not the least, within the European left.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: GIRLS CAMPS

title: Article 9  No Title
description: A star trek in the theory of poetics

title: IncomeSharing Offer Is Believed Acceptable To Most W.F.L. Players.
description: Even if the World Football League, newly organized although still heavily saddled with debt, should fail, it could make a major contribution to professional sports in terms of player and management relations. The most significant feature of the organizational plan devised by the W.F.L. president, Chris Hemmeter, is an income sharing device whereby player salaries, above a $10,000 minimum, are to come out of net income.

title: The War Against the Jews 19331945
description: On October 4, 1943, Heinrich HimToler, head of the Nazi SS troops, spoke in confidence to his Gruppenfhrer (lieutenant generals). The plan for the extermination of the Jews, as he frankly labeled it, was well advanced, and despite some softhearted Germans who claimed to know an A1 Jew who ought to be spared, the Nazi elite forces would not be deflected from their course. They alone, he said, knew what it meant to see a hundred corpses lie side by side, or five hundred, or a thousand. In public we will never speak of it, but the destruction of the Jews would forever remain an unwritten and nevertobewritten page of glory.

title: Yunich Says the Transit Payroll Is Down and Will Fall Further
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the state's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last week that as a result of a vigorous costcutting program begun last August, there were 849 fewer persons on the payroll of the city's transit system. He said the agency hoped to increase the cutback to 2,000 by the end of 1975a 4 per cent cut in the work force.

title: Three More Carriers Put to Sea For Possible Use in Evacuation
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) Three United States aircraft carriers put to sea in the Western Pacific today for possible use in the evacuation of Americans from South Vietnam.

title: ASBESTOS IN RICE IS STUDIED HERE
description: Researchers at the Mount Sinai Medical Center have begun an investigation to determine if asbestos, a known cancercausing agent, is present in significant amounts in talccoated rice that has been consumed for years in large quantities by the Korean and Japanese population in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Food
description: Italian cooks have known for years that while veal may be the most expensive meat on the market, it is possible to make a very few slices go an admirably long way by stuffing them. There are as many Italian methods for stuffing veal as there are beans in a kettle of minestrone, but one of the best is offered here. The filling is made with a base of bread crumbs and prosciutto (or other ham), parsley, nutmeg, garlic, basil and oregano. To round out a menu there is also an excellent Italian shrimp appetizer made with oranges and anchovies.

title: Sandra C. Auchincloss Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Reginald Auchincloss Jr. of New York and Mrs. Carleton Putnam of McLean, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Cutting Auchincloss of Boston, to Eliot Wadsworth 2d, son of Mrs. Eliot M. Wadsworth of Beverly Farms, Mass., and the late Mr. Wadsworth.

title: First to Die In Vietnam Is Recalled
description: LIVINGSTON, Tenn., April 19Three days before Christinas in 1961, when American soldiers in South Vietnam were still called military advisers, Specialist 4 James Thomas Davis was killed by insurgents on a dusty road outside of Saigon.

title: Agenda for the Future
description: President Ford characterizes the setbacks to American policy, particularly the tragedy of Indochina, as selfinflicted problems. Though the description is quite accurate, the President's interpretation is not. The defeats of American policies were selfinflicted, not because of insufficient American military aid, as Mr. Ford implied, but rather because the United States has over the years succumbed to a serious distortion of its role as a major world power.

title: Seton Hall Victor in 3 Relays
description: Kevin Price of Adelphi again brought out the best in Seton Hall and himself yesterday during the QueensIona Relays.

title: Crimson Captures Stein, Biglin Trophies
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 19  With everyone in Boston inaugurating' the Bicentennial celebrations, the Charles River crews contributed their efforts to the event today by turning out a full flotilla of boats and staged the biggest regatta of the season.

title: Housing Demolition for Amsterdam Subway Stirs Opposition
description: AMSTERDAM  As this city of treelined canals and graceful old houses celebrates its 700th anniversary this spring, a fierce battle is raging over its future.

title: INTRIGUING DANCE BY JAN WODYNSKI
description: The trace of unexplainable irrationality at the base of Jan Wodynski's dances gives them their intriguing savor. Everything seems to make sense up to a point, and yet there is a time or tonal dislocation that gives resonance to her characters as they evolve through the labyrinth of her dances. Miss Wodynski showed a selection of her works from 1971 to date at the American Theater Laboratory Friday evening.

title: Environmental Test Planned in Hoboken
description: PRINCETON  Richard J. Sullivan, who served as New Jersey's first Commissioner of Environmental Protection, will be starting a new job in June that will enable him to apply environmental techniques in an urban setting.

title: Newsmen in Cambodia Reported to Be Safe
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19 (Reuters)The French Embassy in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, has reported that, to the best of its knowledge, no foreign journalists were killed or wounded when the city capitulated on Thursday to Communist forces, reliable sources said here tonight.

title: Bigness Defended
description: Small cars perform important functions in the transportation system. They meet the transportation needs of many single persons or young families with one or two children. For others, they make excellent second cars or commuting cars.

title: THE PRESIDENT
description: MONDAY

title: Seaver Beaten by Cubs, 42; Hunter Is. Routed by Tigers
Beame Counters P.B.A.
description: Mayor Beanie abruptly put off graduation ceremonies next week for 510 rookie police officers, charging Russian roulette by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in a dispute over an agreement aimed at saving the rookies' jobs by requiring officers to work five days free. Page 19.

title: Weddings
description: GillForgey

title: Five Appointed to Boards Of U.S. Service Academies
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) President Ford today named five persons to be members of the Boards of Visitors Lo the service academies, for terms expiring Dec. 30, 1977.

title: Ridership on Queens Subways Down
description: Queens subway stations have had a loss of one passenger in seven in the last decade, yet not all of the figures are downhill.

title: The World
description: The period of relative stability between oilconsuming and oilproducing countries has been jeopardized if not ended by the breakdown of talks in Paris being held to prepare for fullscale negotiations this summer. The collapse of the talks revives questions of oil supplies and prices and the disruptive effect that renewed antagonisms among consuming and producing nations might have on the world's economy.

title: CITY TO AUGMENT MONOXIDE GAUGES
description: The city plans to establish 45 new carbon monoxide monitoring stations by July, 1976, because it has concluded that the information it has compiled in the last 18 years is insufficient to determine whether the levels are rising or falling.

title: McAdoo Looming Over Bullets in 5th Game
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 19  Bob McAdoo, seemingly unstoppable, will lead the Buffalo Braves against the Washington Bullets at Capital Centre tomorrow afternoon in the fifth game of their fourofseven National Basketball Asociation playoff. The series is tied 22.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It was a week spent largely on the move. I found myself in Toronto to see John Neumeler's trilogy for the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, in Princeton to see Martha Graham's reconstruction, for her own company, of her great 40yearold solo, Frontier, in Boston for the world premiere, by the Boston Ballet, of a classic work by Agnes de Mille, Summer, and finally back home in New York for a triple bill by the Jos Limn Dance Company with a new work by Ruth Currier, Phantasmagoria 1975, and a couple of major Limn revivals. Well, at least it was a week with plenty of dance variety to it.

title: Future Social Events
description: Witchery in Stitchery April 2230Even if rich men have such a hard time getting past St. Peter, we're told that needlework enthusiasts, rich or poor, will find a little bit of heaven at the 19th biennial exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today in The Lighthouse. Nonenthusiasts may not reach such empyrean heights, but there are some remarkably fascinating embroidery and needlepoint works to be seen  a chessboard, for instance. The theme is AngloAmerican, and special displays include kneelers from the Winston Churchill Memorial in Fulton, Mo., and pieces worked by Lady Lindsay of Send. Nothing is for sale. Admission is $2.50, which goes to The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, and as services. The exhibition is closed Sunday, April 27. The Lighthouse's annual Treasure Ball takes place Wednesday, April 23, at the Plaza Hotel. Like last year, the theme is Western, and Western attire is suggested. $75.

title: Foolish Pleasure Captures Woodby Head
description: Foolish Pleasure contributed a performance packed through with drama yesterday as he raced to victory in the $121,400 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct.

title: S.B. Finch Jr. Is Fiance Of Ruth Louise Pinches
description: The engagement of Ruth Louise Pinches to Stephen Baker Finch Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Pinches of Lewiston, N. Y., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Finch of Lawrence, L. I., and New York.

title: Anne Phillips Is Bride Of E. H. McGehee Jr.
description: Anne Therese Phillips, daughter of Mrs. Henry Benning Spencer 2d of Chevy Chase, Md., was`married yesterday afternoon in Washington to Edward Henderson McGehee Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. McGehee of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square.

title: Carol White Bride of Stacy Wolfe
description: Carol Putnam White, who expects to graduate next month from Wheelock College in Boston, and Stacy Edson Wolfe, a graduate of the Akron University Law School, were married last evening in the Barrington (R.I.) Congregational Church. The Rev. James H. O'Brien Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Is the Bolshoi a Victim of Its Past?
description: Bolshoi is Russian for big, and for a good many years most people have been prepared to accept the proposition that the Bolshol Ballet is the greatest. During a London season last summer, however, that notion began to be questioned, and the same question is likely to arise during the company's fiveweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which opens this Tuesday.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Who is the world's greatest putter?

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: Child to Mrs. R. F. Cruise
description: A daughter was born April 4 in Paris to Mr. and Mrs. Roger F. Cruise of Paris, where Mr. Cruise is director of American stocks for the Banque de Neuflize, Schlumberger & Mallet. Mrs. Cruise is the former Vivian Eve Lester of Hartsdale, N.Y. The child has been named Caroline Rebecca.

title: Byrne Struggling for Tax Vote
description: TRENTON  As Governor Byrne took his campaign for a state income tax to the people this weekend, administration officials said that his program was still short of majority support in the Senate.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: A Mashed Potato on Ice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hypertension Tests for Young
description: PATERSON  A screening program designed to detect high blood pressure in youngsters is being conducted in the Paterson schools.

title: Ricki Mae Bernstein Is Betrothed to Dentist
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sidney C. Bernstein of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ricki Mae Bernstein, to Dr. Orrin Dwight Sokolof, a recent graduate of the New York University of Dentistry.

title: Pop Notes: The Sturm and Drang of the German Rock Invasion
description: Our success is going to make it easier for all of the other German bands who want to win acclaim in America: it also has Americans talking about a socalled German sound,  says Ralf Hutter, a vocalist in Kraftwerk, the German rockquartet that is currently topping the nation's pop music popularity charts. Over the years Americans have been introduced to many German rock bands but not until Kraftwerk has one met with major success. With another German group, Passport, and the Germanbased English group, Nektar, also climbing the pop charts, there is a sudden buzz about the German invasion, and the German sound.

title: 19 PRESUMED DEAD IN SINKING ON RHINE
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, April 19 (AP)A cruise ship carrying aged and crippled Dutch passengers caught fire and sank at its mooring early today, leaving 19 dead or presumed dead in the worst Rhine River disaster since World War II.

title: Veteran Railroader Tackles Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON  In the seven weeks that he has been in his new job as president of Amtrak, Paul H. Reistrup has ridden 21 of his trains on 11 railroad systems.

title: DISEASE IMPERILS WHOOPING CRANES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)Federal and state wildlife officials are trying to steer flocks of nearly extinct whooping cranes from a diseaseplagued resting spot in Nebraska. But some of the birds slipped in anyway.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Manhattan

title: Chris Evert, Mrs. King Set Stage for $50,000
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 19 (AP)  Billie Jean King and Chris Evert gained straightset victories today and advanced to the final of the $100,000. L'eggs World Series of women's tennis. The winner tomorrow gets $50,000, the biggest bonanza ever for women players, and the loser $25,000.

title: SUPPORT IS FOUND FOR A THIRD PARTY
description: A new third party, more conservative than the Republican party, could draw support from as many as onefourth of all voters in next year's Presidential race, according to a Gallup Poll made public today.

title: A Heart To the Hawks
description: There's a lot of lifesmall I and big Lin Don Moser's fine, funny and sensitive story of a boy's coming of age. There's so much growing and going on, in fact, that a little weeding would have made this very good book even better (one of the weeds being the book's loftily sappy title). But no matter.
