Consider the riches: Mike Harrington, 14, the protagonist, well on his way to becoming a brilliant naturalist; the unspoiled land around Mike's house on the outskirts of postWorld War II Cleveland, where Mike collects and studies everything that moves; Mike's father, a frustrated inventor; Mike's best friend, Corcoran, a budding genius with a test tube; Angeline, the budding girl next door; Angeline's quirky Old Country father; Dr. Oberman, the crusty museum biologist who spouts achs! and jas! and tales of tropic nights; the fierce redtail hawk that Mike captures and struggles to subdue; the men who arrive to develop Mike's precious countryside with bulldozer blades and blind eyes. Whew.

title: American Historians in an Iconoclastic Mood at Annual Meeting
description: BOSTON, April 19Viewing contemporary events and evaluating the nation's past, historians of the United States are in a markedly iconoclastic mood. Their strong skepticism and a willingness to topple old gods were reflected in scores of papers read and discussed at the 68th annual meeting of the Organization of American Historians, which concluded here today.

title: Red Hook Residents Critical of City on Relocation
description: City officials opened a second relocation office in Red Hook last week to aid 220 families who are to be displaced by construction of a new containerport in the South Brooklyn neighborhood. Neighborhood residents and community spokesmen have charged that they have not been able to get adequate information from city officials on relocation, or on promised new housing.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Sunday, April 20, 1975

title: The Constant Stardom of Ingrid Bergman
description: Here's looking at you, kid, Humphrey Bogart said, lifting his glass in a toast to Ingrid Bergman. That was in the movie Casablanca, back in 1942, and looking at Ingrid, Bergman remains a favorite international pastime even today. Thirtysix years after her first American film, Intermezzo, in which she sat at the piano and played Rustle of Spring to an enraptured Leslie Howard, Miss Bergman still commands the admiration of her peers and the enthusiasm of film and theater audiences.

title: Dance: Zero Movers
description: An experimental dance group called Zero Moving Company from Philadelphia came to town Friday night and bounced up and down on a giant white rubber mattress in the Washington Square Methodist Church.

title: Letters
description: Stefan Heym (Letter from East Germany, March 23) admits that living in the German Democratic Republic allows for little objectivity about the conditions in his homeland. Asking him to write such an essay is a little like asking H. R. Haldeman for an objective assessment of life in a Washington ghetto during the late nineteensixties.

title: Czechoslovaks' Campaign Against Dubcek Intensifies
description: PRAGUE April 19 (UPI)The Czechoslovak party daily Rude Pravo accused Alexander Dudcek today of taking part in an effort to remove Czechoslovakia from the Soviet bloc.

title: Encounter: Getting to Know Sung Ae Park
description: IT began on the ground at Haneda Airport, Tokyo. As Pan American World Airways flight 800 (New York via Fairbanks, Alaska) prepared to move out to the runway, the purser paced up and down the aisles of the wellfilled 707. Would anyone be willing to hold a baby during takeoff? Along with six or eight other passengersonly one other manI held up my hand. Almost instantly each of us was handed a Korean baby. Mine was a tiny girl screaming bloody murder.

title: Linda Shapiro to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Shapiro of Oswego, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda June Shapiro, to Robert M. Lichtenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lichtenstein of Bayside, Queens.

title: Solutions For the City Terrace Problems
description: Anyone who lives in a city apartment with a penthouse, a terrace, or roof space is indeed fortunate. Nowhere else is the relaxation and pleasure of tending a garden more valued. What a delight to step out of an apartment to cut fresh bouquets of cosmos and petunias, to snip parsley and tarragon while cooking dinner, to dine five or six months of the year at fresco with a view of the city, or to sunbathe in Complete privacy.

title: Lisbon in AntiCholera Drive
description: LISBON, April 19 (Reuters)Portugal today launched an anticholera campaign to guard against a repetition of last summer's outbreak, which seriously curtailed tourism.

title: Letters: Charlest onSubs and Sociability
description: To the Editor:

title: Janine A. Hart Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard William Hart of Woodbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janine Anne Hart, to Ens. Leonid Neboshynsky, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Neboshynsky of Jericho, L. I. The wedding is planned for May 24.

title: UNION RIFT BRINGS ARGENTINE CRISIS
description: VILLA CONSTITUCION, Argentina, April 12Three weeks ago, the Argentine Government said that it had uncovered a vast subversive terrorist operation aimed at paralyzing steel production in the industrial zones north of Buenos Aires and at assassinating labor leaders.

title: New Study On Tocks Emphasizes Recreation
description: TRENTON  Building the controversial Tocks Island dam across the Delaware River would satisfy a real need for recreation and flood control, according to a study being prepared for Congress.

title: How to Control Pests Without Pesticides
description: When a pair of woodchucks set up permanent residence in our cutting garden, we decided that drastic measures had to be taken. In keeping with New Earth morality, we set out to protect our garden organically without endangering assorted pets, rabbits, squirrels, birds, friendly bees and the woodchucks.

title: Diana M. Common Sets Bridal To Ernest Dempsey on May 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Common Jr. of Montreal, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Melanie Common, to Ernest Davis Dempsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dempsey 2d of Cleveland, and Murray Bay, Quebec, where the prospective bride's family also has a residence.

title: Article 4  No Title
The Campaign Law Discourages Big Contributors
description: WASHINGTON  Like most political reforms, the Federal campaign financing law of 1974 was dressed up for passage as Virtue herself. At a single stroke, said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, in an extravagant moment, we can drive the money lenders out of the temple of politics. But like all structural adjustments in politics, including notably Senator George McGovern's reform rules on the selection of delegates to the Democratic convention of 1972, the fund raising and spending reforms were pregnant with unseen political consequences.

title: The Fate of Reading
description: Georfrey Hartman is one of the most resourceful spokesmen for a recondite school of FrancoAmerican literary criticism. He is the author of centrally important studies of Wordsworth and, in The Unmediated Vision, of Hopkins, Rilke and Valry, and of a remarkably erudite number of essays collected in Beyond Formalism. Praise for his accomplishments is nearly presumptuous, especially when he implicitly asks that they be taken as part of a community enterprise meant to constitute the most significant challenge to literary studies since Northrop Frye and, before that, I. A. Richards. By conviction as well as temperament, Hartman wants to shine only in the company of others, some German and monumental, like Hegel and Nietzsche, some recent and French, like Jacques Derrida and Jacques Lacan, and some American and close to home, like his colleagues at Yale, two of whom have ecently written books prominently mentioned in this one: Harold Bloom's The Anxiety of Influence and Paul de Man's Blindness and Insight.

title: Voters Can Meet Candidates
description: Candidates' meetings will be held in most school districts to give voters a chance to meet the candidates and hear their views on school issues.

title: Kunstler Hit by Pie Daring Vanderbilt Talk
description: NASHVILLE, April 19 (UPI)Minutes after he said colloge students lacked revolutionary spirit, William M. Kunstler, the lawyer and civil rights activist, became Tennessee's lastest victim of a collegiate piethrower.

title: Wisconsin Bicentennial Blast
description: BELOIT, Wis., April 19 (UPI) Beloit opened its Bicentennial observance with a bang and two broken windows last night. After a reenactment of Paul Revere's ride, an artillery piece similar to one used at thattime was fired during a flagraising ceremony. The concussion broke two small windows in the municipal center. No injuries were reported.

title: 3 MUSICIANS OFFER CHAMBER PROGRAM
description: Anita Zia, mezzosoprano; Barbara Levy, cellist, and Natalie Goldberg, pianist, joined forces yesterday at Carnegie Recital Hall in a concert of vocal and instrumental chamber music. The program included songs by Brahms, Grieg and Toiva Duula, and works for cello and piano by Beethoven, Schumann and Britten. It also offered the first performance of Roger Rundle's Lunar Tunes for voice, cello, piano and clarinet. The guest clarinetist was Spencer Bruno.

title: The Bulge in Bank Profits
description: The banking industry is reporting dramatically higher profits for the, first quarter of 1975 at a time when the economy was deep into its worst decline since the Depression and most industrial companies are struggling to maintain profit levels  or even find them falling.

title: ROBIN TROWER PLAYS AT MUSIC ACADEMY
description: The problems of rock n roll; showbiz were quickly apparent for Robin Trower's Academy of Music appearance on Friday. Mr. Trower was announced over a dramatic undulaling carpet of dry ice. fumes that covered the stage. Alas, a fault developed in the sound system before note one had been heard and technicians fumbled around in the fog with flashlights looking for the loose wire. Eventually, after a long delay, connections were made and Mr. Trower's trio was off and running.

title: Any Used Boat Lying Around? Newport Has New Show for It
description: First there were the traditional indoor boat shows. Then came the inwater shows. And now the newest is an old one  a usedboat show. The Newport Yacht Bazaar, for sailboats only, will be held May 30, 31 and June 1 in Newport, R. I. Sailboats ranging in length from eight to 60 feet will be displayed, primarily in the water, at the Newport Harbor Treadway Inn.

title: Dozens Hurt In English Soccer Riot
description: LONDON, April 19 (AP)British soccer fans ripped wooden safety barriers apart with their hands and battled police with improvised clubs today.

title: Ironbridge: Where the World as Irrevocably Changed
description: THERE is a small brick chamber in the depths of rural Shropshire, England, where, one of the Most momentous revolutions in history was forged. Here, one winter's morning early in 1709, a dour Quaker piled ore and limestone on a bed of incandescent coke, blew air through the mass with waterwheel bellows, and, 16 hours later, tapped off a trickle of pure iron.

title: Into the Air,. Junior Birdmen!
description: It was bard to believeI was actually flying the airplane, arms and legs working the controls in a kind of mindless euphoria. Suddenly we started to climb and the nose of the plane obstructed my Vision to that I couldn't see ahead.

title: Inroads by TouristTrade Shops Troubling Fifth Ave.
description: Touristoriented camera and electronicproducts shops have accelerated their penetration of prime shopping areas along Fifth Avenue, causing dismay among those most committed to maintaining the avenue's fashionable tone.

title: On the Housatonic: Wilderness Canoeing
description: IT was a far cry from Deliverance. The three of us on a twoday canoe trip confronted nothing more menacing than a power dam or two. But we were embarked on a pioneering voyage of sortsdiscovering a kind of river wilderness amid the industrial reaches of southern Connecticut.

title: BOYCOTT BY ARABS AFFECTING ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, April 19Israeli manufacturers are beginning to feel the effects of Arab economic warfare.

title: Sunday Observer
description: A New York television station recently discovered that college students are taking pornographicmovie roles to work their way through cotlege. It is another instance of hard times changing the country.

title: First Chancellor Named By U. of New Hampshire
description: KEENE, N.H., April 19 (AP)Bruce Poulton, administrative assistant to Gov. James Longley of Maine, was named today the first chancellor of the University of New Hampshire system.

title: Article 6  No Title
Whose Risk?
description: When the Supreme Court recently declined to stay the ruling of a lower court in the Reserve Mining Company case, a dangerous gap was left in the protection of the public health. Senators Nelson of Wisconsin and Hart of Michigan now propose to fill that gap with reasonable legislation.

title: Ford Wins Monza Pole
description: MONZA, Italy, April 19 (UPI)  A Ford piloted by Jochen Mass of West Germany and Tim Schenken of Australia won the pole position today for the 1,000 kilometers of Monza auto race tomorrow. Arturo Merzario of Italy and Jacques Laffite of France, in an Alfa Romeo had the second best two day time.

title: Article 10  No Title
Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Book Ends
description: Scandal. This season seems to have had more than its share of controversyshrouded books. Among the current titles much in the public eye that have had their basic credibility put in doubt are The Last Testament of. Lucky Luciano and The Bermuda Triangle. Attacks on the latter seem not to have hurt sales, since it still rides atop the Best Seller List; however, Charles Berlitz's book was ignored by critics until it became a phenomenonrather like an offBroadway musical that keeps playing previews without formally opening to reviewers. Lawrence David Kusche's refutationThe Bermuda Triangle MysterySolved (which was not written as a specific attack on the Berlitz cook)did not appear until March. Of course there is some question as to whether the true believers care about opposing arguments anyhow. Another ex post facto attack was recently launched against Harry Browne, author of You Can Profit From a Monetary Crisis, a doomandgloom book advocating the buying of gold, silver, Swiss francs and a fortified rural retreat, which had a long run on the Best Seller List. It seems that Mr. Browne was collecting commissions from a coin company he touted in his booksa company that has also been charged with fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Meanwhile, in the Soviet Union, they have their scandals too. Roy Medvedev, a leading Russian dissenter and historian, has charged that Mikhail Sholokhov did not write And Quiet Flows the Don, a classic of the late twenties that made Mr. Sholokhov a Soviet literary establishment figure. In a 125page essay, Mr. Medvedev noted that Mr. Sholokhov was only 20 when he allegedly wrote the hook and lacked the necessary historical and literary sophistication. Mr. Medvedev's candidate is a Cossack scholar named Fyodor Kryukov, who died in 1920.

title: LETTERS
description: Two recent articles in the Arts and Leisure section which discussed elements of propaganda in current films have elicited an unusual number of letters from readers. A selection appears below.

title: Favorite Responds To Outside Chance
description: To win from the No. 15 post position going a mile and an eighth at Aqueduct, a horse has to be much, much better than anything else in the field.

title: In Texas, Anger Over the Oil Depletion Allowance
description: HOUSTON  The drastic changes in the controversial oil depletion allowance recently voted into law draw a highly emotional reaction in this part of the country.

title: TAX DISPUTE WON BY METZENBAUM
description: CLEVELAND, April 19Former United States Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum has won a twoyearold tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service that was widely credited with contributing toif not sealinghis defeat in the 1974 Democratic primary by John H. Glenn, the former astronaut who replaced him in the Senate.

title: CITY AIDE OPPOSES SST LANDING HERE
description: Robert A. Lowe, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, yesterday predicted a long court battle if the Federal Aviation Administration went ahead with its tentative plan to permit four daily flights by the Concorde supersonic transport in and out of Kennedy International Airport.

title: For Garden, a Celebration
description: Although the symbolic cherry blossoms were still frozen in hard little buds, spring came officially to the Japanese Garden of Brooklyn's Botanic Garden last week, as HarnMatsnrithe Japanese spring festivalwas celebrated in song, haiku, dance and, naturally, a garden tour.

title: Town Acts to Close Girls' Home
description: OYSTER BAY COVEThe village Board of Trustees here passed a resolution Wednesday night authorizing a Mineola law firm to institute proceedings seeking to force the closing of Harmony Heights, a 24room mansion housing 21 homeless girls.

title: Wood Finishing: Bleach Lightens, Stain Darkens
description: Although some types of wood have a natural tone or color that is so attractive and pleasing to the eye that no change in color or shading is desired, in the vast majority of cases a wood finishing or refinishing job involves either lightening, darkening or otherwise changing the original coloring of the wood (without hiding its natural grain pattern or texture).

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Maybe the New York City Opera production of Erich Korngold's Die tote Stadt is overproduced. Maybe Ronald Chase tried to get too much into his films and projections, ending up with hysteria rather than phantasmagoria. Maybe a lot of things. But Chase and his crew have taken the techniques of film/projections/montage a significant step from the state it had been when the Delius Koanga and Village Romeo and Juliet were done in Washington a few years back. I thought then, and the current Die tote Stadt reinforces the impression, that Chase, working with Frank Corsaro, the director, had worked out one of the most exciting developments in the history of operatic stage presentation.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Investors' growing belief that the worst of the recession is over enabled the stock market to advance last week in active trading.

title: Some Notes (Mostly Sour) On Singing Songs
description: What the world needs is a Society for the Promotion of Last Performances. This organization would dispense prizes to those artists who are the first to give the last hearings of the major works of Beethoven and Brahms. Since all living composers have a vested interest in discouraging standard programing, they should be recruited to draw up the rules of the contest.

title: Gerry & Ed & George & Hubert
description: RALEIGH, N. C.A State Senate committee has returned to a subcommittee the Housepassed bill that would eliminate North Carolina's Presidential primary. This was a delaying action to let passions cool after George Wallace came here to testify against the bill, but it probably works in favor of those who want to kill off the primary in order to keep Mr. Wallace from winning it as he did in 1972.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: To Our Amazement, We Built a House
description: BELMONT, Vt.  Anyone who has owned even a small piece of land has longed to build on it. My husband and I thought we were different four years ago, when we bought some lovely streamstudded woods adjoining Vermont's Green Mountain National Forest. We solemnly vowed to keep the wilderness unspoiled.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: The longest running drama in New York is not in the theater at all but in the galleries. Continual changes of cast insure that it will never stale. And it is played out in a wide variety of locations: so much so indeed that it is easy to get into a fight as to where the action is at any given time.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The walls of my house have no insulation at all and I am investigating having one of the following installed: Loose fill, pumpedin foam, or aluminum siding with a fiber insulating board on back. Which would you recommend?J.M.K., Rockville Center, N.Y.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 20, 1975

title: About the Mets....
description: Jerry Koosman joined the Mets' wounded brigade when he was struck on the left ankle while pitching batting practice. The culprit was Jesus Alou, whom the Mets signed last week to replace Cleon Jones and his ailing knee, and the weapon was a line drive. The outlook: bruise, not serious.... Rusty Staub, who missed the first three games of the season with aches and pains, reports that he feels quicker with the bat than at any time in the last two seasons: My hand and shoulder hurt sometimes when I'm tired, but otherwise I can stand over the plate and not give the pitcher anything. If the ball is out there, I can pop it now.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: Manhattan

title: Gallery Jottings Of a Spring Stroller
description: A special pleasure of New York City life is to pick a Saturday early in the spring and stroll along Madison Avenue, unbundled at last, observing the latest blooms of the uptown art scene. With SoHo also vigorously budding nowadays, the artgallery stroller has a choice of excursions, to be sure; but in both richness and diversity, no gallery district in the world comes close to matching what's on display in the 30odd blocks that go north from 57th Street. Herewith, the notes of a recent spring stroller.

title: INVESTING
description: There is considerable gloom in Wall Street about the elimination of the oil depletion allowance. It is universally predicted that fuel prices will go up and that investors will suffer until the new economics of expensive energy become a part of the formula.

title: Towns Act to End A Mixup on Names
description: NEW SHREWSBURY What's in a name? Confusion, If you happen to live in the Monmouth County community of New Shrewsbury (as distinguished from neighboring Shrewsbury Township and the Borough of Shrewsbury) or in the Ocean County community of Dover Township (as distinguished from, Dover, which is in Morris County, well to the north).

title: Since Attica, the Significant Changes Have Been Rhetorical
description: Three and a half years ago the Attica rebellion raised fundamental questions about the nature and purposes of incarceration in New York State and in other jurisdictions around the country. L. D. Barkley, an Attica inmate put the issue vividly in a speech in D Yard when the inmates held it. He said, We are men. We are not beasts and we do not intend to be beaten or driven as such.

title: Arson Conspiracy For Insurance Laid To 4 Detroit Men
description: DETROIT, April 19  The husband of Viola Liuzzothe civil rights worker who was shot to death during the march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., in 1965was arrested here this week and charged with seven counts of arson conspiracy.

title: An Ambitious West Side Story for Great Neck
description: A crowded school bus of Great Neck South Senior High School students learned a little about filmmaking last week, and something about brotherhood as well.

title: 2 Papers and a TV Station Win Negro College Awards
description: The New York Times, Station KPRC of Houston, Tex., and The Sacramento (Calif.) Observer are the recipients of the United Negro College Fund's 1975 National Media Appreciation Awards; the fund announced yesterday.

title: Barbara Vosburgh Married in Darien
description: Barbara Ellen Vosburgh and Dr. Dan Charles Omohundro were married yesterday afternoon in the United Methodist Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Earle Sanford. The Rev. Edward Howley of St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church, Darien, assisted.

title: Carole J. Uhlaner Is Engaged To Sandford Fredrick Borins
description: Dr. and Mrs. Julius E. Uhlaner of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Jean Uhlaner, to Sandford Fredrick Borins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Borins of Toronto. The wedding is planned for May 25.

title: Lucy S. Judson Plans Nuptials
description: Prof. and Mrs. Sheldon Judson of Princeton, N. J., and East River, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Sheldon Judson, to Craig Yager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Yager of Boulder, Colo.

title: 2 JUSTICES CITED ON PRECINCT BAIL
description: Two Brooklyn Supreme Court justices stepped in three times over a 15month period to set bail in police precincts for a convicted Staten Island gambler who the police say is a member of the Carlo Gambino organizedclime family.

title: Flyers Top Leafs for Sweep
description: TORONTO, April 19The frustrated Toronto Maple Leafs, who couldn't afford to lose, carried the lackadaisical Philadelphia Flyers into overtime tonight. But 1 minute 45 seconds later, Andre (Moose) Dupont scored, and the Flyers won, 43, to sweep the National Hockey League quarterfinal series in four games.

title: Memoirs
description: Cardinal Mindszenty, primate of Hungary, was convicted in February of 1949 of all the usual things you can convict somebody of if you torture him long enough, deploy skilled forgers, phony defense lawyers, paid and intimidated witnesses, and, for the sake of a little plausibility, if you succeed in sowing, abroad, just that hint of doubtnot about Mindszenty's innocence: that was quite widely taken for grantedbut about his guilt. When I subsequently went through foreign books, newspapers, and magazines that dealt with my case and commented on my confession, I realized, the ingenuous prelate tells us, that the public must have concluded that the confession had actually been composed by me.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly stated in last Sunday's Highlights of the Week that Joseph A. DeRose had resigned as senior vice president of the American Stock Exchange because of alleged violations of securities laws. According to the exchange, the resignation was for personal reasons, and was not related to any inquiry into securities trading.

title: 80% Work a 5Day Week; Trend to 4 Days Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)Five days is still the standard work week for more than eight out of 10 American workers but a study by the Department of Labor shows there is a slight trend toward a fourday workweek.

title: Brewers Triumph Over Indians, 30
description: CLEVELAND, April 19 (UPI) Bill Champion of Milwaukee shut out the Cleveland Indians with two hits today as the Brewers won, 30. Jim Perry was the losing pitcher.

title: The Market Unfixes French Gold
description: PARISLast winter the French thought they had a sure thing with gold. The price had approached $200 an ounce, and further galactic propulsion was expected when American citizens were given the right to buy and hold sold for themselves.

title: CRABIEL WITNESS TELLS OF PAYOFFS
description: A highway contractor who had been testifying at the bribery trial of J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State, has told the New Jersey Attorney General's office that he also made payoffs to the state police.

title: Allan Michael, Marine Biologist, To Wed Margaret Mills in June
description: Margaret Ann Mills, a research engineer with United Engineers and Constructors, Inc., in Philadelphia, plans to be married in June to Allan D. Michael, a marine biologist, of Woods Hole, Mass.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: PRINE NOT AT BEST IN CONCERT HERE
description: John Prine has composed many fine songs, and most of them were on display in his concert of nearly three hours at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night.

title: The World
description: Two venerable political figures have emerged as leaders of an opposition movement that is, potentially, a serious threat to the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. They have the support of all the opposition parties excepting the proMoscow Communist party and they have attracted many former Gandhi supporters alienated by the Prime Minister's economic and other policies.

title: Tender Bulbs For Planting
description: Dahlias, gladiolus, ismene and acidanthera are tender bulbs that can be counted on for color in summer and early autumn. They are planted each spring and dug and stored in a frostfree place over winter.

title: Josephine Baker Buried In Monaco Before 2,000
description: MONACO, April 19 (UPI)Josephine Baker was buried in Monaco today in a ceremony attended by 2,000 admirers.

title: PUBLIC CAN'T VIEW CITY H.I.P. REPORTS
description: For more than two years the city's Health Department has been sending inspectors, into the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York's centers to find out how well they are serving the plan's members, but the inspectors' reports cannot be seen by the members in general or by the public because of objections of H.I.P officers.

title: ROSS SOBEL, PIANIST AND GOLF PRO, DIES
description: MIAMI, April 19 (UPI)Ross Sobel, a jazz pianist who became a wellknown teaching pro in golf, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 84 years old.

title: STAMPS
description: The United Nations, accenting again its continuing endeavors to achieve changes in laws and traditions that discriminate against women throughout the world, has proclaimed 1975 as International Women's Year and is putting out four stamps to mark this year of effort.

title: Agriculture Department to Abandon Campaign Against the Fire Ant
description: The United States Department of Agriculture has decided to abandon its war against the fire ant, a tiny but aggressive and seemingly invincible pest to people and agriculture in the Southeast.

title: A Peripatetic Paul And a Portable Pad
description: JUST 200 years ago this weekend, Paul Revere made his gallop to glory. His object was a modest twostory dwelling in Lexington, Mass., the HancockClarke House, a national shrine that, in its small way, has been as peripatetic as Revere himself. The Douse will not be open to BIcentannial visitors on this historic weekend; the Lexington Historical Society is struggling manfully to get it in shape for tourists by June 1. The tale of their efforts has its anomalous elementsthough nothing to compare with the ride of Paul Revere.

title: Teen Registration Pressed in Bergen
description: HACKENSACK  As part of a continuing effort to register teenagers as soon as they become eligible to vote, the Bergen County Commisioner of Registration has appointed a volunteer deputy registrar in virtually every public and private high school in the county.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Of hijack stories there is no end. But John Miles and Tom Morris in OPERATION NIGHTFALL (BobbsMerrill, $6.95) have come up with some very Big Thinking and have in the process created a lively, suspenseful caper. Hijack an airplane? Kid stuff. Miles and Morris have a band of six crooked pilots hijack an airport.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: Manhattan

title: First Indian Satellite Is Orbited From Soviet on Russian Rocket
description: NEW DELHI, April 19The first Indian satellite was shot into space today from the Soviet Union atop a Soviet rockeL the Indian Government. announced tonight.

title: $50MILLION BUDGET BACKED AT BROWN U.
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 19 (AP)The advisory and Executive Committee of Brown University Corporation reported today its approval of the proposed 19751976 school budget.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Nurture of Poets
description: W. H. Auden once wrote: In the eyes of others a man is a poet if he has written one good poem. In his own he is only a poet at the moment when he is making his last revision to a new poem. The moment before, he was still only a potential poet; the moment after, he is a man who has ceased to write poetryperhans forever. Publishers cannot, and luckily need not, share this inner uncertainty, but they should take what pains they can to recognize and support the poets who have done their job. Since World War II, in fact, publishers have done more, though not necessarily better, things to recognize new poetry than ever before.

title: WoodRidge Has Pride and Problems
description: WOODRIDGE  Homeowners in this Bergen County community face a tax increase of more than 15 per cent in the coming fiscal year because the largest taxpayer, the Curtiss  Wright Corporation, has refused to meet its payments for the last two quarters and is charging that its property is assessed too high. The issue is before the courts now, but the local government has announced that it will have to raise the property tax to get the Money it needs to meet existing obligations.

title: College Age Is No Longer Just 1822
description: Not many years ago, college students like Richard Barker were an oddity. The idea of a 39yearold father of four going to school and taking on the burden of homework was something extraordinary. But no longer. Society and its attitudes toward higher education have changed.

title: Visitors Pack Museum For Scythians in Gold
description: The largest firstday attendance at any Metropolitan Museum of Art special exhibition was recorded yesterday as thousands of art lovers and the curious turned out to view From the Lands of the Scythians, a display of ancient treasure, the spokesman said, set the from the Hermitage in Leningrad.

title: Article 2  No Title
SEPARATE U.S. UNIT ON SCHOOLS URGED
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said here yesterday that the nation needed a separate national department of education, a national education trust fund and provision by the Federal Government of at least onethird of the nation's educational expenses.

title: Article 3  No Title
TV VIEW
description: Television is at its best when it allows the viewer to see the world with his own eyes, to witness important events and personalities. But not everything that matters can be captured on film, and The I.Q. Myth, which will be aired as an hourlong CBS Reports special this Tuesday evening at 8, demonstrates how extraordinarily difficult it is to present a complex, nonvisual controversy on television.

title: Communications Blackout Limits News of Cambodia
description: A virtually complete blackout on customary news channels wrapped developments in Cambodia in uncertainty yesterday.

title: Controversial Express Bus Lane Experiment for Queens Is Temporarily Halted
description: Traffic Department engineers retreated to their drawing boards last week after scores of taxis blocked the first day of a controversial express bus experiment eking Queens Boulevard, bringing it to.a halt within half an hour of its start. But the engineers have not given up.

title: Bomb Found in Ottawa
description: OTTAWA, April 19 (UPI)A time bomb, allegedly placed by the radical Weather Underground of the United States, was discovered last night outside National Defense Headquarters and was detonated by experts, a police spokesman said today.

title: Trumpeter Kept Busy in Europe
description: JERSEY CITYTed Curson packed his trumpet, his flugelhorn and the rest of his baggage a few days ago and took off for Europe for his annual sixmonth stay there. Vacation? Hardly, for Mr. Curson is In constant demand there for jazz festivals, concerts, clubs and such special events as a multimedia dance project in Zurich.

title: Miss Gamble Wed To Charles Flood
description: Kristin Gamble and Charles Andrew Flood of New York, both vice presidents of New Court Securities in the investment management division, were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lex N. Gamble of Chappaqua, N.Y., brother and sisterinlaw of the bride, by Brig. James G. Scott of the Salvation Army.

title: The Kissinger Substance: Power Permits Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTONNow, just a short year after Secretary of State Kissinger reached the zenith of his powers during the Watergate crisis, many reporters, Congressmen, diplomats and other officials in Washington are beginning to wonder in that cruel phrase of bureaucracy, whether he has outlived his usefulness.

title: Another Boston
description: BOSTONSince the start of this school year, busing in Boston has been a subject of nationwide attention. Just the other day, in the press elsewhere, a discussion of school busing in Buffalo reported that residents there feared Buffalo would become another Bostonthe grim catchword of defiance and despair. Unfortunately, grim catchwords neither inform the public nor explain the facts.

title: Airline Aides Grapple With the Improbable
description: THE radio message from the flight captain is urgent: Crabs in cabin. Confusion. Passengers need calming.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: Manhattan

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Vexilar, Inc., a Minneapolis electronics firm, now enjoys the distinction of having one of its sophisticated fishfinding units being considered for prohibition by a state legislature, presumably because it is too effective.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Hunter College has announced the creation of a new planning and research office to coordinate the college's various programs for the elderly and to study new methods to assist the aging socially, educationally and medically.

title: Japan Acts to Lend Egypt Funds to Enlarge Canal
description: TOKYO, April 19, (Reuters) Japan is moving ahead with plans to lend Egypt $1110million to finance the first stage or a sevenyear project to widen and deepen the Suez Canal for ships up to 250,000 tons.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time in appear in Section 2:

title: Miss Earley Bride Of Ophthalmologist
description: Kathleen Earley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Earley of Allentown, Pa., was married here yesterday morning to Dr. Richard Cornforth Lanning, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. McClure Lanning of Pittsburgh.

title: Essex Greets a New Stern's
description: WEST ORANGEStern's, the department store that began operations in New Jersey in 1957 end withdrew from New York City in 1969, opened its fifth store in this state last Thursday. It is in the Essex Green shopping center here.

title: SideSaddle Expert To Conduct a Clinic
description: RINGOESMrs. Donald Owen of County Kent in England, the world's foremost authority on the art of sidesaddle riding, will, conduct a threeday clinic here, starting Thursday. It will be held at the Knobby Knoll Farm on Wertsville Road, beginning at 8:30 A.M. each day. Food will be available on the grounds.

title: U.S. JOB SEEKERS LOOKING TO IRAN
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., April 19 Ron and Jill Stuber, who were married a short while ago, had hoped to travel to Iran for their honeymoon, but the reces sion forced him out of his job as a heavymachine technician, and her as a dental assistant. However, they plan to go there anywayto find employment.

title: Derby Goes To Diabolo On Coast
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 19 (AP)Laffit Pincay Jr. rode the 95 favorite, Diabolo, to a 4length victory in trackrecord time in the $100,000 California Derby at Golden Gate Fields today.

title: Teenagers Seeking Summer Jobs Are Urged to Try Volunteer Work
description: MORRISTOWN Teenagers, seeking volunteer Jobs this summer will find a wide assortment of opportunities at hand.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Terry Sue Kugler Has Nuptials
description: Terry Sue Kugler, a pediatric occupational therapist, and Dr. Michael Edward Makover, an internist and rheumatologist, who is medical director of the New York office of the J. C. Penney Company, were married yesterday evening at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I., by Rabbi Joseph Sternstein.

title: Looking For The Exit
description: A week of discussing 11thhour aid to South Vietnam has made plain that the Ford Administration, while rhetorically consistent with past policy, is actually in agreement with the Congress: Saigon is an already lost cause and the Americans there must be evacuated quickly and, if possible, discreetly.

title: U.S. to Reconsider Mitchel Field Plan
description: MINEOLAThe director of the Federal Office of Management and Budget will review the agency's decision not to build an $84million Federal office building at Mitchel Field, according to Representative John W. Wydler.

title: Primary Battles Likely for Surrogate Candidaies in Suffolk
description: BLUE POINTThe various candidates for Suffolk County Surrogate Court judge campaigned energetically last week amid indications that there would be primaries in the Republican and Conservative parties.

title: Supermarkets Dimming Lights, Recycling Heat
description: Supermarkets, once so brightly lit that some customers wore sunglasses, have dimmed their lights.

title: The French, They Are Hooked On La Tl
description: PARIS. The popular belief that the average Frenchman is a culture maven Is, alas, an illusion. The truth is that the average Frenchman is a TV addict. Here In France, television beats out all other cultural practices, according to a survey recently conducted by this country's Cultural Ministry.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONThe Assembly never has been noted for its legislative decorum, with members having described it as a zoo or a bedlam: Debates sometimes turn into partisan harangues, and parliamentary procedure has often given way to someone's capacity to outshout someone else.

title: Aksel Schiotz, Tenor, 68, Dies; Dane Was Symbol, of Resistance
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 19 (AP)Aksel Schiotz, the Danish tenor whose singing became a symbol of Danish resistance to the Nazi occupation during World War II, died today. He was 68 years old.

title: Getty Calls Fighting Tragedy for Those With Links to U.S.
description: LONDON, April 19J. Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire, making a rare appearance before the press, said today that the war in Indochina was tragic for all those who have been connected with Americans.

title: SEPARATE U.S. UNIT ON SCHOOLS URGED
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said here yesterday that the nation needed a separate national department of education, a national education trust fund and provision by the Federal Government of at least onethird of the nation's educational expenses.

title: Democrats Pressing to Unseat Purcell
description: MINEOLA  Buoyed by their successes in last year's local elections, Nassau County Democrats are preparing to wage a strong campaign to wrest control of the Town of Hempstead  the most populous town on Long Islandfrom the Republican party in the November elections.

title: The Nation
description: MONTGOMERYThe others who would be PresidentBensten, Carter, Jackson, Udallscurry about the country in frantic personal quest of prospective delegates, campaign money and a better standing in the polls.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodaySuburban Sports Car Club T.S.D. rally; start at rear parking lot, AcmeSuper Saver Market, Bloomfield at Passaic Avenues, West Caldwell, N. J. Registration: 12 P.M.

title: Meadows Depicted As Potential Slum Area
description: SECAUCUS  There are times when Philip J. Kieffer, the Town Administrator here, looks out the windows of the Town Hall and envisions the Hackensack Meadows being swallowed by a potential future slum.

title: Karen Greenspan Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Greenspan of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Barbara Greenspan, to Marc Alan Rosenbaum of Shaker Heights, Ohio, son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Rosenbaum of Lyndhurst, Ohio.

title: ROBERT ARON, 76, FRENCH HISTORIAN
description: PARIS, April 19 (UPI)Robert Aron, a writer on 20thcentury French history, died here today of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

title: Kim Il Sung Bids U.S. Get Out of Korea
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, April 20President Kim Il Sung of North Korea congratulated the Cambodian Communists last night on their victory and warned the United States to withdraw all its troops from South Korea if it really wants peace.

title: Carolyn Brooke Thomas Plans Marriage to Wyle Grigg Dold
description: Carolyn Brooke Thomas, a paralegal with Vinson, Elkins, Searis, Connally & Smith, a Houston law firm, and Wyle Grigg Dold, an appraiser with the Real Estate Corporation in Houston, will be married Aug, 16 in that city.

title: PLAN IS ADVANCED FOR CLEAN WALKS
description: The state's Charter Revision Commission for New York City recommended yesterday that all property owners be required to keep their sidewalks free of garbage, refuse, rubbish, litter and other offensive material.

title: 313 Seeking 108 School Posts
description: A number of strongly contested battles for control of local school boards in Brooklyn are developing as the dateMay 6nears for the new community school board elections. The citywide elections will be the third since the start of decentralized school operations, here in 1970, and, for the most part, will be influenced by local issues and concerns.

title: LEBANESE SHAKEN BY BEIRUT BATTLE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 19Beirut reassumed many aspects of normal life today after several days of death and violence, but the political situation remained badly shaken and uncertain.

title: Workers Reject Pact In Garden State Strike
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 19 (UPI)Garden State Park called off its ninerace card today after striking cleaners ignored their union's recommendation and rejected s proposed contract offer.

title: 8 Women of the Year Honored by Magazine
description: NEW YORK, April 19 (UPI) Eight women, each prominent in her own field, were named by The Ladies Home Journal tonight as women of the year. 1975.

title: WALL STREET ROUNDUP
description: Wall Street's vigorous diversification plan, sparked by the plummeting of stock market volume and prices during the last four years, is beginning to pay dividends.

title: Liberals Defend Open Classes Against BacktoBasics Forces
description: A counteroffensive to the back  to  basics movement is taking shape among educational liberals as they try to insure that the school reforms of the nineteen  sixties, particularly the open classroom, do not get swept aside in the rush to reemphasize fundamentals.

title: DR. DOROTHY LEE, ANTHROPOLOGIST
description: Dr. Dorothy Demetracapoulou Lee, a cultural anthropologist, wellknown as a teacher in many parts of the United States, died Friday in Cambridge, Mass. She was 69 years old and lived in West Cornwall, Conn., and Athens.

title: Christo's Art Exhibited in Princeton
description: PRINCETON  Christo Javacheff, a 39yearold Bulgarjanborn artist generally known only by his first name, is the subject of an exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum.

title: Drop Seen in College Rolls
description: Enrollments at the 16 institutions of higher education in Nassau and Suffolk Counties surpassed the 100,000 mark for the first time this year, a 5 per cent increase over last year, but declining student populations appeared on the college horizon.

title: Wendy Weiss, Judd S. Meltzer To Wed June 10
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Weiss of New York and Atlantic Beach, L. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Karen Weiss, to Judd S. Meltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elton Meltzer of New York.

title: 15 Months Before Games, Olympic Site Needs Big Effort
description: MONTREAL, April 19 (UPI)  What was the biggest snow bank in the city last month is now the biggest mud puddle. In a few months it even could resemble the site of the 1976 Summer Olympic Games.

title: Louisa Hough Engaged
description: Mrs. Charles Thacher Hough of Hingham, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Louisa Hough, to Robert M. Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Goldberg of Massapequa, L. I. Miss Hough, daughter also of the late Mr. Hough, is a senior at Fairleigh Dickinson University, from which her fianc graduated.

title: TALKS ON CUTTING FORCES IN RECESS
description: VIENNA, April 19After 18 months of negotiations on a mutual and balanced reduction of their forces in central Europe, the Western and Communist sides admit that they have made no significant progress toward their goal of starting to cut back this year.

title: Bills Sign Fullback
description: BUFFALO, April 19 (AP)The Buffalo Bills of the National Football League signed today a fullback, Torn Donchez of Penn State, the club's fourthround selection in the 1975 draft. Donchez, a 6foot2inch, 216pound power runner, will step into the position of No. 2 fullback behind Jim Braxton, whose backup last season, Larry Watkins, has been traded to the New York Giants.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: Staten Island

title: MASTER PLAN SET FOR BROOKHAVEN
description: PATCHOGUE, L.I.  Brookhaven, the largest of Suffolk County's 10 towns, has adopted a master plan to check residential growth, preserve open space for farming and discourage the kind of haphazard industrial development that has transformed this area from a rural region into yet another suburban zone.

title: The Nation
description: Former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally has been found not guilty of bribery, raising doubt about the claim of numerous defendants in Watergaterelated cases that they could not receive fair trials because of prejudicial publicity. The Connally verdict seems to have said otherwise: that a weak caseas the Government's was generally considered to beis a weak case, Watergate or no.

title: WaterPollution Control Effort to Be Extended to Urban Areas
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Environmental Protection plans to shift. the emphasis of its waterpollution control programs to New Jersey's cities, rather than concentrating them on largely rural areas.

title: Museum Names a Trustee
description: The controversy over representation on the board of the Queens Museum appears to have abated with the election of the president of the museum's volunteer group to a trustee seat on Tuesday.

title: Auto Worker is races for Pinch as Benefits Run Out
description: DETROIT, April 19Willie Harper was in elementary school then, but he remembers well the hard times of the late nineteenfifties, when his father was laid off his Job on the auto assembly line. There was no electricity in the house and sometimes no food, either.

title: BEAME COUNTERS P.B.A. LEGAL MOVE
description: Graduation ceremonies for 510 rookie police officers next week were abruptly put Off yesterday by a deeply distressed Mayor Beame, who charged that his hand had been forced In a game of Russian roulette perpetrated by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Harry B. Helmsley has turned back a Lower Manhattan office building and two loft buildings to their mortgage holders and indicated that he might take similar action with a couple more commerical properties.

title: ART VIEW
description: The American photographer Walker Evans, who died on April 10 at the age of 71, was one of the greatest artists of his generation. He was also, in my opinion, one of the most widely misunderstoodmisunderstood In the way that photography itself was so often misunderstood in his lifetime. Like many great artists, he was a difficult man, often indeed a devious man, and never more devious than at those momentsand they were not infrequentwhen he allowed his work to pass Into the world and be praised as something he knew it was not. He was an artist who traveled, as it were, incognito, sometimes amused, sometimes cynical, sometimes merely resigned to what the world had made of his accomplishments. He was very far from being immune to vanity or the appetite we all share for praise, recognition and preferment he certainly savored to the full his wellearned position as a classicbut he was disinclined by temperament and intelligence to mistake the world's word for the precise measure of his artistic worth. To no other figure of our time does Rilke's dictum about the paradox of celebritythat fame is but the sum of misunderstandings that accumulate around a wellknown nameapply with greater force.

title: Pollensa: Away From The Tourist's Majorca
description: THE town of Pollensa on the island of Majorca is said to antedate the birth of Christ. Its old plaza dozes in the Spanish sun, ringed with stunted plane trees and decorated with the town's medieval flags. Pollensa boasts a cathedral dating from the Moorish occupation, the Banco Agricolo and four bars.

title: A Little Boy's Day at Lexington Includes Presidential Greeting
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., April 19  As everybody knows, Saturdays are usually good days for little boys, but for David Drew Flaherty Jr., this one was special.

title: Lieut. Buchanan, Elizabeth Wilson Set June Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Ann Wilson, a senior at Mary Washington College, and Second Lieut. John Preston Buchanan, U.S.A., who received a B.A. degree in foreign affairs last year from the University of Virginia, will be married June 28.

title: Egyptian Aide Flies To Moscow in Move For Better Relations
description: CAIRO, April 19A month after the collapse of Secretary of State Kissinger's mediation mission in the Middle East, President Anwar elSadat is embarking on a campaign to improve relations with his fellow Arabs and with the Soviet Union.

title: The Region
description: It now seems certain that a serious hearing will be given to charges that possible police crimes against inmates during, the Attica State Prison uprising were covered up. Bernard S. Meyer, a former State Supreme Court justice, has been appointed to head the inquiry.

title: New Watchdog for Commodities
description: WASHINGTONA powerful new regulatory agencythe first for the securities industry since the midnineteenthirtieswill begin tomorrow trying to impose its will on trading in commodities futures, the fastest game in town.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTONA young and proper Bostonian is about to become at the age of 35 the greatest borrower in the history of the world.

title: Job Outlook: 400,000 More by 1980
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Labor and Industry projects an increase of 400,000 jobs in New Jersey between now and 1980. It concedes, however, that such growth is based on the assumption that the economy will make a dramatic recovery from its current doldrums.

title: Coast Inquiry on Oil Prices Shows No Illegal Activity
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP) The inquiry into possible illegal oil price rises during last year's Arab embargo has failed so far to turn up much illegal activity in California, investigators say.

title: Plant Now for FreshVegetables Spring Through Summer
description: Not since the Victory Garden era of the forties has there been such overwhelming national interest in vegetable gardening. Civic organizations, schools and garden. clubs are sponsoring supervised community gardens for those who do not have suitable growing areas. Individuals for whom gardening is a new adventure will be trying their hands at small backyard gardens to reduce their market basket costs.

title: Pages From a Cold Island
description: Alas, there are writers who no longer know what an honest memoir is, just the nonfiction novel. In an age of stampeding literary confession, suicides who leave completed novels about themselves, authoresses who turn every honest coupling into a feminist saga, it is easier to tell the dancer from the dance than it is to tell anybody's hard life from wouldbe fiction about it. Fiction is supposed to be at a low ebb, but when it comes to dissecting an individual rather than society, most anybody tries to be a noveliststill the easiest badge for creativity. Even among the more explicitly honest autobiographersMalcolm Muggeridge, Lillian Hellman  Sartre in Words stands out as wholly convincing personal history, an artist above all artifice.

title: ANGEL END AND TEXAN SING AT BOTTOM LINE
description: Pairing Shawn Phillips and Wendy Waldman at the Bottom Linethere through tonightis a most interesting idea.

title: Zambia Leader Explains Detentions
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia said here today that he had moved against radical guerrilla leaders operating from bases in his country against the white minority Government in Rhodesia.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Minnesota vs. New England

title: Policing Elections
description: The Federal Election Commission established by Congress last year is off to a belated and unpromising start. The campaign finance reform act was signed into law last Oct. 15 and the commission was supposed to file its first report to Congress by March 31, but the six members of the commission were not sworn into office until last week.

title: Nancy Gordon Walker Is Married
description: Nancy Gordon Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Axson Walker of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to George William Bynum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Turner Bynum of Sanford, N. C. The Rev. Robert Nelson Back performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Noroton, Conn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Teacher Describes Visit To Schools in North Vietnam
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 20  Every morning when we visited a school the students would he talking about how another province had been liberated the night before, Mrs. Sara Boyd said of her visit to North Vietnam. They were beaming and said they were so excited that we're going to be one country again.

title: 2 Montreal Shows Notable for Prizes and Length
description: It seemed like a preview of the coming Olympic Games in Montreal as thousands stormed the Place Bonaventure last weekend for the international shows of the United Kennel Club. There were 18,477 enthusiasts on Saturday and 25,991 on Sunday for a twoday paying total of 44,468, one of the greatest throngs in a decade to watch canine competition. And enthusiastic they were. The huge exhibition hall reverberated to the cheers, in French and English, for the champions.

title: The Firesign Comedians Are Hot Stuff
description: Pete and Phil here on latenight twoway callback radio, and were brought to you early this morning by Nose Brothers Coffee. Open it up . . . (pssss) . . . sniff . . . (ahhhhh!) . . . throw the can away. You've just had Nose Brothers Coffee. And remember, Nose Brothers and other fine products are featured all this week at all Giant Toad Supermarkets.

description: UNIONDALE, April 19What can you say about a penguin that caught pneumonia and died?

description: Kentucky vs. St. Louis
