description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Miss Howell Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur K. Howell Jr. of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Howell, to H. William Reisner Jr., son of Mrs. Herbert W. Reisner of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Reisner.

title: Tampering With Nature Perils Health, U.N. Environment Unit's Report Warns
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 19There is increasing evidence that, human beings, using the massive leverage which science and technology have made available, are creating serious risks to their own health and wellbeing, according to a report on the state of the world environment.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Spring is gradually righting itself and getting back on course for planting and seeding. . . Catch up and keep everything on schedule.

title: Stavisky Pushing For School Aid
description: ALBANYWhile vacationing state legislators basked in the Southern sun, or, working in their districts, experienced the warmth of constituents' opinions, Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky's staff sent some 1,300 questionnaires to school officials around the state.

title: LIST MAKING MOST OF SHOSTAKOVICH
description: MOSCOW, April 18Eugene List said today that he came here to play the First Piano Concerto of Dmitri Shostakovich for the 254th time for public consumption.

title: Headliners
description: A selfordained Fundamentalist minister, the Rev. Marvin Horan, has been convicted of conspiracy in the bombing of public schools during a text book controversy in West Virginia. He has been a leader in a protest campaign against what he and others allege are godless and dirty books used in the Kanawha County schools. Mr. Horan, a former truck driver, faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $10,000 fine. His righthand man, Larry Elmer Stevens, also was found guilty last week of conspiracy and other counts in connection with the bombings last fall. Several other defendants indicted after the wave of violence remain to be tried or sentenced.

title: Music in Review
description: Han de Vries, a Dutch oboist who plays with uncommon plasticity and expressivity, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, performing sonatas by Vivaldi and SaintSans, Schumann's Three Romances, Berio's Sequenza VII and shorter works by Bartk, Andriessen and Shinohara. His accompanist was Diane Walsh.

title: Music: Telemann Twist
description: A trumpet, a pair of oboes, a bassoon and a harpsichord were combined in an unusual work by Telemann that opened the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society Concert at Tully Hall on Friday night.

title: HOSTAGES FREED AT JAIL IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)After an 18hour holdout, maximum security inmates quietly surrendered the last of a dozen hostages today after they had been promised improvements at the decrepit 103yearold city jail and leniency for leaders of the revolt.

title: Marian Mitchell Wed to F. O. Nicholson
description: The marriage of Marian Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. MacNeil Mitchell of New York, to Frederick Ogden Nicholson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Nicholson of San Bernardino, and Laguna Beach, Calif., took place at noon yesterday in Newport Beach, Calif. The Rev. John Ashey performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Better Ties Up to Cairo
description: MOSCOW, April 19Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that an improvement in SovietEgyptian relations would depend upon Cairo's attitude toward Moscow.

title: Lack of Water Feared by '85
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Unless the 178 water companies in the northeastern and central sections of New Jersey are consolidated, two Rutgers University experts maintain, the area 4.5 million residents may be faced by a severe shortage of water by 1985.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Adherents of the nothingeverworks school are already busy ridiculing the possibility that anything sensible or rational will come out of the elaborate new Congressional procedures for review of the Federal budget.

title: The Boston Marathon: 3 Hours for the Race, But More Like a Lifetime for the Runners
description: James Joyce took the 10 years of Homer's Odyssey and compressed them into a Dublin day. He looked into the mind and heart and body of the hero Ulysses and created Leopold Bloom, who is everyman. And saw in the Lotuseaters, Cyclops, the gift of the Winds, Circe, Hades, the Sirens and even the nymph Calypso, those inner and outer events that happen to everyone, every day. And then he put all of it into the wakingtosleeping day of his Irish Jew. It takes 18 hours.

title: For Squad of U.S. Olympic Hopefuls, Road to Montreal Begins in Bermuda
description: The United States is one of 91 nations vying for the 14 vacant soccer spots in the Olympic Games in Montreal next summer. The United States squad opens its campaign toward that goal in Bermuda today with Julius Menendez as head coach. If the Americans beat Bermuda today and tie or defeat Bermuda in the second game of the series in San Francisco next Sunday, they will advance to the second round, where Mexico awaits them with open arms. A victory over Mexico would virtually guarantee a trip to Montreal and would gain Menendez the distinction of having coached Olympic teams in two sports.

title: What Greece's Policy Means
description: ATHENSGreece has begun withdrawing, from the direct alliance structure, units of its armed forces hitherto earmarked for NATO commands. This follows a long hesitation period during which Premier Constantine Caramanlis obviously tried to slow down a procedure that had been promised when the North Atlantic community, it was hoped, might do something concrete about Turkey's invasion of Cyprus.

title: Reconciliation Plea
description: CONCORD, Mass., April 19Standing at the foot of the Old North Bridge, where 200 years ago a small band of Minutemen turned back a column of British Regulars with their muskets, President Ford told a huge crowd, including some jeering protesters, today, that now is a time for reconciliation, not recrimination.

title: Foyt Returning to Trenton For World Series Finales
description: A. 3. Foyt will return to the scene of a career milestone next weekend. The event will be the World Series of Auto Racing at Trenton Speedway, and Foyt and 11 other United States Club drivers Motor will meet Sunday in a pair of 150mile racesone for stock cars and one for championship, or Indianapolistype, cars.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: What we need around here is endings. I don't mind sitting through shaky plays about terrorists holding actresses for ransom, or through preposterous plays about terrorists hijacking the theater in which we are all sitting, or through sneaky plays about burglars bent on seducing the extremely square man of the house. Sometimes there's a passing joke to be laughed at or a secondary performance to be admired, sometimes there's a line so unselfconsciously soupy that you want to store it away in your treasurechest of memories, to be trotted out at parties when people start comparing their favorite clinkers. It's a fare dog that doesn't leave with something to bat.

title: BRIDGE
description: It may be a shock to readers of this column to learn that I prefer vice, but let them be reassured the preference is strictly orthographic, not pornographic.

title: Temple Schedules Jewish Revivalist
description: CALDWELL  Esther Jungreis, a revivalist who has been called the Jewish Billy Graham, will speak at Congregation Agudath Israel of West Essex next Sunday. Mrs. Jungreis's goal is renewal of the Jewish faith. She is the founder and president of a nonprofit organization called HINENI (Here I Am), which connotes a readiness to serve God. She resides in North Woodmere, L. I., with her husband, an orthodox rabbi, and their four children.

title: In Cold Print: Thriving in Chains
description: Books are born free, yet they are everywhere in chains. Most people outside the business are probably only dimly aware that the chains exist. Yet anyone concerned about the fate of books, not to mention the condition of our culture, ignores the chains at his peril.

title: Burlington Offering Course in Fencing
description: PEMBERTONA noncredit course in fencing is now being offered at Burlington County College on Wednesday evenings.

title: DAN D. CHANDLER
description: Dan D. Chandler, vice president for operations for Pan American World Airways since May, 1974, died yesterday in Bermuda while on vacation. Be was 42 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Grants by Foundations Show Increase
description: The nation's major philanthropic foundations are giving out grants of more than $1.5billion a year in what has been a continuing increase since national records were compiled in 1958, the Foundation Center reported yesterday.

title: Miss Krupsak Denies Gamesmanship and Affirms GrassRoots Dedication
description: ALBANY, April 18Damn it, I'm not supposed to be a gamesman.

title: Field Harvest Work By Children 5 to 12 Is Backed in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) A bill making it legal for children aged 5 to 12 to do field harvest work by hand in areas authorized by the Secretary of Labor outside of school hours was approved yesterday by a House migrant labor subcommittee.

title: Linda Seifert Bride of Cleric
description: Linda Elaine Seifert was married in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., last evening to the Rev. Charles Randall Peyton. The ceremony took place at the Kirk in the Hills, Presbyterian, where the bridegroom is youth minister.

title: Baits in U.S. Fear American Policy Shift on Soviet Incorporation of Nations
description: WASHINGTON, April 19United States participation in the twoyearold EastWest European security conference has stirred apprehension among Americans of Baltic origin about the future of their ancestral homelands.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: French Hill Inn, French Hill Road and Alps Road, Wayne. (201) 6969440.

title: Critics Say Too Much More
description: WASHINGTONThe Internal Revenue Service expects 83,000,000 Americans to file their tax returns this year and pay their taxes. Because the service had received 63,000,000 returns by April 11, five days before the deadline presumably its expectations will again be fulfilled.

title: Arabic is Spoken (and Taught) in Commack
description: COMMACK  A teacher's gentle call of alsalamu alaykum! (Peace be with you') signals the start of a secondperiod class at Commack High School South here each morning.

title: Race Horses and Drugs: The Bettors Must Be Protected, Too
description: Ever since last fall's rash of drug cases at Belmont Park and Aqueduct the New York horsemen have been pressing the State Racing and Wagering Board for a new drug deal. What the horsemen want is the formal sanction td use Butazolidin (an analgesic painkiller) and Lasix (a multipurpose diuretic) on any horse in any race at any time. What the board decides will affect racing and the racing fan for many years to come.

title: Food News
description: MORRISTOWNThe butchers behind the counter at the Morristown Meats and Provisions market wear straw skimmers and, were it not for the cases full of fresh meats, poultry, and smoked sausages, they could almost pass for Princeton men a homecoming.

title: The Bee and the Crocus
description: The first bees out, these April afternoons that have been so much like March, have been the big golden bumblebees, and they have looked twice as big as the bumblebees we shall be seeing a month from now. They have been specially busy at the crocuses, which are generous with their pollen, carrying off load after load of the golden grains.

title: Family Dead in New Mexico
description: LOGAN, N.M. April 19 (UPI) Six members of a prominent family were killed tonight in what the polic said was an apparent multiple murder and suicide. Officers said Mr. and Mrs. Robert McFarland and their four children were found shot and stabbed to death in their fashionable home in this tiny community near the TexasNew Mexico border.

title: Morritown: Antiques Fair Is Slated
description: MORRISTOWN  Bigger than ever, the sixth annual Morristown Antiques Fair and Sale will get under way at the National Guard Armory here on Thursday. Newly recruited dealers with quality merchandise are helping to expand the show's horizons.

title: McGee Leads on 66 for 201
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Apr. 19 (AP)Jerry McGee, a nineyear player still looking for his first tour victory, shot a fiveunderpar 66 in the $125,000 Pensacola open today and took the lead with a 54hole total of 201.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: RCA's Bluebird label, which fluttered off into phonographic limbo 20 years ago, has come winging back as the imprimatur under which an ambitious number of old recordings will be reissued. The label has launched, a series of twodisk albums which will resurrect memorable works from RCA's Victor and Bluebird catalogues of the 78rpm era, drawing on everything except classical recordings but focusing primarily on blues, Jazz, country and pop music. The first five Bluebird releases (which, for added nostalgic, effect, carry a replica of the original buff and pale blue Bluebird label) seem to be representative of the intentions of the series  a mixture of both familiar and longneglected material from the four basic areas.

title: Nurses Will Discuss Nonmedical Healing
description: STONY BROOKHealing by touch and altered states of consciousness will be among the topics to be considered at a twoday conference on The Nature and Nurture of Life to be held at the Stony Brook Union of the State University here this Friday and Saturday.

title: Elevation of Dialogue on the Economy Is Urged
description: Participants in a community forum on the state economy agreed yesterday that it was bad, and warned against one group contending with another in the search for solutions.

title: No Evidence Found of Police Graft Rings
description: There is no longer any evidence of police corruption rings in the city, but individual allegations of extortion and other graftrelated charges increased slightly last year, according to the latest Police Department corruption surveys.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayBennett College, Route 44, Millbrook, N. Y. Regular, Limit and Junior Working Hunters: Open jumpers, Equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: On the Careful Art of Composting
description: Considerable interest in composting has developed with the increasing numbers of gardeners and the need to dispose of more waste on less land. Higher fertilizer prices, the usefulness of soil conditioners on unproductive infertile soil, and the desire to conserve plant nutrients have also stimulated interest.

title: Billboard Appeal Lost
description: ST. LOUIS, April 19 (UPI)A billboard company, fighting a $100 suburban tax for each of its billboards, has lost its case in the Missouri Court of Appeals. The court ruled last Wednesday that the Eller Outdoor Adevrtising Company must pay the tax to the city government in suburban Florissant. And the state Appeals Court reinstated a $25 fine imposed on the company by the Florissant Municipal Court. The Appeals Court upheld Florissant's right to impose such a tax and set no limit on the amount.

title: Carey Names D'Angelo To College Board Here
description: Governor Carey said yesterday he was nominating Armand D'Angelo to fill a vacancy on the New York City Board of Higher Education.

title: Journey For Three
description: Cynics may put down Alison Cairn as a latterday Little Orphan Annie, but the heroine of this new book by Isabelle Holland is sure to charm and captivate young readers. All of 11, the plucky Alison, who had helped out during floods, unfriendly attacks, fever epidemics, even, in a pinch, giving a hand at delivering one or two babies, has successfully negotiated a trip halfway around the world, from India to the Andes to the United States, seeking refuge for herself and two brothers, Fat Buttery, a plump blond 3yearold Anglo Saxon, almost housebroken, and San Ignacio, a brownskinned South American boy of 8, who makes beautiful tortillas and has already alienated some of Alison's relatives in Westchester with his color.

title: Elizabeth Woo Is Married to Aubrey Li
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Elay Woo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kyscang Woo of Hong Kong, to Aubrey Kwoksing Li, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fookwo Li, also of Hong Kong. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. Douglas Ousley.

title: Engineer Sculpts Contour Figures
description: HIGHLAND PARK  Ex pressing the human form in an effective, original way is perhaps the sculptor's greatest challenge. Centuries of artists have attempted and failed, but R. H. Karole, a fulltime civil engineer and part  time sculptor, has turned to his professional background for the insight and techniques for a new approach to sculpting the figure.

title: N.J. Currency
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Novel
description: Strong Wine Red as Blood

title: Alan Hertz to Wed Andrea Lee Berly
description: Andrea Lee Belly, who expects to graduate in May from Yale University, and Alan Lee Hertz, a Yale graduate now in the doctoral program in English literature at the University of Toronto, plan to be married May 25.

title: Article 1  No Title
Quaker Eight Beats Tigers, Columbia in Childs Cup
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 19 They say that at Princeton in the springtime, with the forsythia in bloom, it is easy to fall in love. But not when it rains, as it did today.

title: Council Sets Schedule Of Its Public Hearings
description: The following public hearings will be held by City Council committees this week:

title: Agricultural Society Will Honor Alampi
description: TRENTONSecretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi will receive the gold medallion of the New Jersey Agricultural Society at the organization's annual dinnermeeting on May 7. The affair will be held at the Cedar Garden Restaurant in Mercerville.

title: A Correction
description: Joyce Burland is seeking the Democratic nomination for the Suffolk County Legislature in the First District. where Norton W. Daniels is the Republican incumbent. It was erroneously reported in this section last Sunday that she would run in an adjacent district.

title: Ford, Lexington and Concord
description: WASHINGTON, April 19On the week when Cambodia surrendered and South Vietnam tottered, President Ford found time to preside over the crisis, address the D.A.R. and the American Society of Newspaper Editors, meet with the full membership of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, make a speech and hand out the prizes at the annual White House photographers' dinner, deliver the sermon at the opening of the Bicentennial celebration in the Old North Church in Boston, and visit Lexington and Concord.

title: Piscataway School To Hold Art Show
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELDPiscataway High School is holding its third annual art show and sale at the Middlesex Mall here Wednesday evening and again Thursday through Saturday.

title: Dave Anderson
description: She's so steady, so smooth, she probably could wear a tiara while she plays. And it wouldn't even tilt. Chris Evert is the queen of tennis, but at the age of 20 she prefers to think of herself as a crown princess.

title: Divorce Therapy Aids Children as Well as the Parents
description: As difficult as divorce is for the adult couple, it can be devastating for children, who must first cope with the bitterness at home, then with the severing of one parent and, finally, with building a new kind of life.

title: DOPE DEALER, WIFE ARE MURDER VICTIMS
description: The police yesterday identified a murdered couple found in an apartment on upper Broadway Friday night as a convicted narcotics dealer, 42yearold Jesus Manuel Diaz, and his wife, Gloria Uribe Diaz, 32.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Recent discoveries of fossils and tools in East Africa have done more than push back the accepted dates for the emergence of the precursors of modern man. A growing number of students of human evolution now believe the evidence demands that the traditional view of man's development be revised.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: GILJOSE LOPEZ on April 3, 1975. Beloved father et Virtor Manuel Luian. Loving grandfather et Rossana Luian. Mass Sungay, April 07, 1975 at 9 AM, Immaculate Conception Chanel, 20.16 21 Avnue, Astoria. All friends are invited to attend.

title: Music:
description: Benjamin Lees is a composer often played by the National Symphony, and yesterday afternoon the Washington orchestra brought his Concerto for String Quarte and Orchestra (1964) to Avery Fisher Hall.

title: T. M. KAVANAGH, MICHIGAN JURIST
description: LANSING, Mich., April 20Michigan Supreme Court Justice Thomas M. Kavanagh died last night of cancer in St. Lawrence Hospital here. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. POLICY CHANGE EXPECTED BY KAUNDA
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia strongly indicated today that he expected a change in the United States Government's African policy, with more understanding for the black liberation movement on that continent.

title: Conservative Rabbi Sees Women in the Pulpit Soon
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 20 The head of the Conservative rabbinical movement predicted today that women would be serving in his denomination's pulpits in the foreseeable future.

title: Jane Moore Bride of Andrew Avallone
description: Christ the Redeemer Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Jane Elizabeth Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis O. Moore of Pelham Manor, to Andrew John Avallone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Avallone of New Rochelle. N. Y.

title: Du Pont to Raise Prices Of Sulfamic Acid on May 1
description: A 17 per cent increase in the price of crystal and granular grades of sulfamic acid effective May 1, has been announced by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. The increase, which the company said was required because of rising raw materials costs, applies to open market sales and contract transactions. Sulfamic acid is used to remove scale and deposits from boilers, heat exchangers, condensers and evaporators.

title: Judicial Independence
description: In criticizing the reassignment last December of Judge Bruce McM. Wright from the Criminal Court to the Civil Court, the Association of the Bar for the City of New York has raised an important voice in favor of the integrity of the judiciary.

title: Assurances to Cambodia From Nixon Are Reported
description: President Richard M. Nixon gave the Cambodian Government private assurances last year that encouraged it to assume that the United States would come to its rescue, Time Imagazine reports in its current issue.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: POLYTECHNIC GETS GIFT OF $1MILLION
description: A gift of $1million has been made to the Polytechnic Institute of New York and $700,000 of the needed matching funds from trustees has alrady been raised, the institute's president announced yesterday.

title: Italy Accused of Laxity Amid Violence
description: ROME, April 20A wave of political violence throughout Italy during the last few days has suddenly heightened tension, while party leaders and newspapers are accusing Pre mier Aldo Moro's Governrnent of weakness and the police of incompetence.

title: PROPOSALS CLASH ON ENERGY POLICY
description: Two prominent organizations. Resources for the Future and the Commission on Critical Choices for Americans, have published studies offering diametrically opposed solutions to the energy problems of the United States.

title: REFUGEE AIRLIFT BUILDS UP QUICKLY
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philip pines, April 20  The flow of people leaving South Vietnam, which started with a trickle nearly two weeks ago, developed tonight into what military and diplomatic officials here considered the start of the major airlift sought by President Ford.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTJohn M. K., of Old Lyme, Conn., en April 17, age 75. Refired Vice President in charge of Public Relations, New York Life Insurance Company. Father 01 John S. Abbott of Orange Park, Fla., ens Mrs. Walter G. Fluter of St. Clair Shores, Micnigan. Brother of Ernest H. Abbott of Pittsfield, Mass and Lawrence Abbott or Coventry, Conn. Interment private. Me. rnorial services at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, May 3 at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Ms Lyme, Conn. Memorial contributions to National Audubon Society, 950 Third Ave., NYC 10022.

title: Fisher's N.A.S.L. Debut A Success Before 18,347
description: The eighth season of the North American Soccer League is only four days old, but the talk of the 20team league is already Terry Fisher, the 25yearold coach of the Los Angeles Aztecs.

title: FIRE IN BROOKLYN KILLS 4 IN FAMILY
description: Four members of a Brooklyn family were killed yesterday morning when an intense fire allegedly set by an arsonist roared through their threestory wooden apartment building.

title: Leveling Off of Rates Is Seen
description: Opinion is growing in Wall Street that the Federalfunds ratethe cutting edge that has trimmed all shortterm interest rates steadily since late last summerfinally has lost its

title: CHINA SEES A WAR FOR U.S. AND SOVIET
description: TOKYO, April 20 (AP) China charged today that the United States and the Soviet Union had stepped up their fight for influence over Europe and that it would lead to war.

title: Of Land and History
description: One is tempted to paraphrase Robert Frost and say: Something there is that doesn't love an island. The pressures are relentless to alter the natural character of the nation's few remaining undeveloped islands, to bulldoze their dunes, to fill in their marshes, to preempt the living space of marine birds and wild animals. And for what? To substitute yet another golf course, another marina, another colony of vacation cottages and luxury condominiums.

title: Lon Not Is Said to Plan To Buy Honolulu Home
description: HONOLULU, April 20 (AP) Marshal Lon Nol, the former Cambodian President, plans to buy a $103,000 house in a Honolulu subdivision, a realtor says.

title: Cool Tiant Defeats Orioles for Red Sox
description: Luis Tiant, one of major league baseball's senior citizens, doesn't like pitching in cold weather. But the 34yearold Boston righthander remained cool in the cold at Fenway Park and pitched a fourhitter yesterday.

title: Leaders in Albany Trim List of Major Legislation
description: ALBANY, April 20While the two chambers of legislators were still sowing bills last weekthe total of proposals was past 8,000 in the Assembly and 5,000 in the Senate  their leaders met pri

title: McGee Finally Scores in Golf
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 20 (AP)Jerry McGee, recovering from a collapse on the first nine, carded a 70 today and registered the first golf tour victory of his career. He Won the $125,000 Pensacola open by two strokes with a 14underpar 271.

title: U.of Southern California To Build a Nixon Library
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20Former President Richard M. Nixon and the University of Southern California said today that Mr. Nixon was giving papers and materials accumulated over his years in public office to a Presidential library to be established on the university's main campus. When completed, the library would be deeded to the Federal Govern

title: Eglevsky Ballet Company Gives Tasteful and Sane L.I. Program
description: The Eglevsky Ballet Company is a bastion of tasteful sanity in the general morass of ballet companies outside the major centers. Andre Eglevsky, the

title: Brazil Will Press Kissinger on Trade
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 20When Secretary of State Kissinger comes here Friday as part of a tour of Latin America, the Brazilians will undoubtedly want to talk primarily about United States trade policy, which the Brazilians see as a threat to their industrial progress.

title: Realtors Hold Clinic for Home Buyers
description: A panel of bankers, appraisers, accountants and real estate brokers yesterday tackled the job of explaining to more than 800 potential firsthome buyers Everything you wanted to know about home owning but were afraid to ask, at a sympositun held at Bergen Community College in Paramus.

title: WISCONSIN LONGS FOR KENNEDY RACE
description: MILWAUKEE, April 20An almost palpable longing by many for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts appears to be the main product of other Democrats Presidential campaigning here in one of the key primary states on the 1976 calendar.

title: OftenEmbattled Southern Judge Is Honored
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 20The tone of the gathering was a bit akin to that of a reunion of veterans of some long, grim military engagement that had somehow ended successfully despite great odds.

title: REDS MAKE MOVES TO CUT OFF SAIGON, BUT ATTACKS EBB
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 21Communist divisions were reported yesterday to be maneuvering rapidly near Saigon with the obvious intention of sealing off the capital from all approaches.

description: Michael Gold and William Warner have been named senior vice presidents of de Garmo, Inc.

title: Books of The Times
description: Look at it from the outside in for a moment. Ursa Corregidora, the protapnist and narrator of Gayl Jones's strong first novel, Corregidora, is a cafe blues singer in a nameless city not far from Bracktown, Ky., where she grew up. She has a hard kind of voice, as one listener tells her. You know, like callused hands. Strong and hard but gentle underneath. Hurt you and make you still want to listen. But Ursa's husband, Mutt Thomas, doesn't want her to sing in cafes. I don't like those mens messing with you, he tells her. Don't nobody mess with me, she

title: Latins Now Leaders Of HardDrug Trade
description: In the last two years. Latin America has become the major source of hard drugs entering the United States. Much of it is being supplied by rings controlled by businessmen and professionals who have grown so politically and economically powerful that they can operate with virtual immunity from arrest and prosecution.

title: 26 Journalists Safe In France's Embassy
description: Communications with Western correspondents in the Cambodian capital continued to be cut yesterday. But the French Foreign Ministry confirmed in Paris that 26 journalists were safe in the French Embassy in Phnom Penh.

title: Gloxinias:
description: Anyone who thought that people belonging to anything called the Gloxinia Society must be matrons from a New Yorker cartoon, or aging and eccentric bachelors, would have been confounded at a recent meeting of that plant society.

description: Passage Predicted

title: Feminists Decry the Role Of Women in Jewish Life
description: Young Jewish feminists and older women, less committed to the cause, met at the McAlpin Hotel on West 34th Street yesterday to consider what one speaker called the myth that women are honored and important in Jewish life.

title: Molin Captures Eastern Net Title
description: Jon Molin, following the oath blazed by juniors in previous years, captured the 12th annual Eastern men's indoor tennis championship yesterday by defeating Art Carrington in the final, 46, 61, 67, 76, 64, at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx.

title: Failure in Paris.
description: Given the deep differences among the participants, the breakdown of the preliminary meeting in Paris of oilexporting and oilimporting countries was at once more honest and more sensible than would have been a vaguely compromised agreement to stage a fullscale and highly publicized conference this summer. Such a conferencewhich the oil producers and their poor, thirdworld allies wanted to cover the vast range of topics appropriate to the creation of a new economic order would almost certainly have been doomed to failure.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: The kindest definition of mutton is, in dictionary terms, the flesh of grown sheep. Proper mutton has a flavor, unmistakably perfumed It is not for all palates, but neither are caviar and snails. Those who dote on it, and we do without apology, have at times what amounts to an actual cravine.

title: Bloomingdale's Sprightlier Image
description: Under the direction of its new communications chief, Bloomingdale's is about to change its advertising look.

description: Film

title: Israel Must Yield Territory To Win Peace, Percy Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, said today that thehre would be no peace or security for Israel until she withdraws from most of the lands she has occupied since the 1967 war.

title: JAZZ GROUP. SAMPLES ELLINGTONIAN STYLE
description: Duke Ellington provided the National Jazz Ensemble with the best moments of its program at the New School on Saturday evening. But not even Conga Brava, a Juan Tizol contribution to the Ellington repertory, or a superb performance of Ellington's Transblucency could overcome the sense of lethargy that settled over most of the concert.

title: Harlem Office Building Still in Chaos
description: The State Harlem Office Buildingborn in chaos, built in confusion and dedicated more than a year agois still in turmoil, with its recent problems brought on, in part, by the change in leadership in the state.

title: Pope Expresses Concern For People of Cambodia
description: ROME, April 20Pope Paul VI appealed today for moderation and clemency in Cambodia.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS SEE RECESSION END
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) Five business leaders predicted today that the recession would probably end by next fall and that 1976 would be a year of economic acceleration.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times Saturday, the winners of the New York Press Club's 1975 awards for radio feature stories should have been listed as Hill Edell of WABC and Mary K. Taylor of WCBS.

title: Chris Evert Conquers Mrs. King
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 20 (UPI)Chris Evert, benefiting from a controversial line call, rallied and tied the third set, then defeated Billie Jean King, 52, in a tiebreaker today for the $50,000 first prize in the L'eggs World Series of Women's tennis.

title: Advertising
description: Tonight the OffTrack Betting Corporation will make its dbut as a television advertiser, hoping to convert nonhorseplayers into members of the New York Bets.

Court to Hear Test Today On Death Penalty Return
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Two years and 10 months after the Supreme Court ruled that capital punishment as practiced in the United States was unconstitutional, 31 states have restored the death penalty and the trend appears to he continuing

title: Mass Transit Use of Road Fund Lags
description: Two years after Congress authorized the use of billions of dollars of Federal highway funds for mass transit projects, the results have proved bitterly disappointing to the advocates who hailed the Congressional action as a great victory.

title: Nixon Attributes His Survival to Wife
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Former President Richard M. Nixon might not have survived major surgery last year without the reassurances of his wife Pat, he said in a tribute to Mrs. Nixon made public today.

title: Jersey City Feels Effects of Brownstone Revival
description: JERSEY CITYThe brownstone revival that has been sweeping American cities is gradually taking hold here.

title: Jill Meredith Farren Wed to Robert Phelps
description: Jill Meredith Farren, an assistant on the production staff of the CBS television serial The Guiding Light, was married yesterday to Robert Phelps, an actor. Both are graduates of the theater department of CarnegieMellon University.

title: Internment Camp Visited
description: Tulelake, Calif., April 20 (UPI)JapaneseAmerican college students walked 10 miles in a pilgrimage to a deserted World War II interment camp today where more than 18,000 United States citizens of Japanese descent were imprisoned after the bombing of Pearl Harbor.

title: Klein Accused of Pressure In Suffolk Building Deal
description: ST. JAMES, L.I., April 20John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, and his political mentor, Nicholas Barbato, the Smithtown G.O.P. leader, were accused by fellow Republicans this weekend of having exerted strong pressures on county legislators to obtain their approval for a $5million rental arrangement with a developer. The deal subsequently led to the indictment last week of Suffolk's watchdog for real estate matters.

title: Brewing Industry Feels Mixed Effects of Recession
description: The recession has had a mixed effect on companies in the beer industry. Some are prospering, but others are faltering. Some are expanding or introducing new brands, while a few are dropping old products and closing plants.

title: M.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Houston

title: Heritage Museum Dedicated
description: LEXINGTON, Mass. April 20 (AP)Secretary of Air Force John L. McLucas helped dedicate today the $6millihn Museum of Our National Heritage built by the Masonic order. The museum, on a 22acre site, features exhibits tracing the growth and development of the United States.

title: Yanks'
description: DETROIT. April 20Not even when he was their manager did the Yankees applaud Ralph Houk's strategy as they applauded it today. That's because Houk's strategy worked about as successfully today as it frequently did when he managed the Yankees.

title: Olympic Standards Are Listed
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 20 (AP)  Qualifying standards for track and field events at the 1976 Montreal Olympic Games were announced today by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. In most cases they are much higher than those set for the 1972 Games at Munich, officials said.

title: ForeignLanguage TV Has Wide Range Here
description: Every Sunday night Lin Yu Ching, a young United States citizen of Chinese descent, tries the patience of her conservative grandfather, an elderly Taiwanese whom Lin Yu is visiting in Taipei.

title: Israeli Court Stays Expulsion of Arabs Pending a Hearing

title: High Joblessness Expected to Persist As a Condition of U. S. Through Decade
description: Relatively high unemployment has become a new characteristic of an affluent United States  a phenomenon that many experts think is likely to persist beyond the depths of the current recession and through the remaining years of this decade.

description: there were three new men in Lucia di Lammermoor's life Saturday night, two of them decided assets to the City Opera production.

title: Bridge:

The Bulls lead, three games to two, as the teams move toward the sixth game Wednesday night in Kansas City.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONZA, Italy, April 20 (UPI)Jacques Laffite of France and Arturo Merzario of Italy won the 1,000 kilometers of Monza auto race in an Alfa Romeo today. It was the second straight victory for the Alfa team in the World Manufacturers series and cut Porsche's lead in the standings to 7 points after four races. The Porsche team of an Italian, Mario Casoni, and a West German, Reinhold Joest, finished second. Gerard Larrousse and JeanPierre Jabouille of France were third in an Alpine Renault.

title: Hassan Cancels Cancels U.S. Trip

They said a major reason for the cancellation was the collapse of Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East peace efforts. An Amaerican Embassy spokesman said that the trip had been postponed at the king's request.

Gallagher Jr., suspended director of special education in the Albany school district, was sentenced today to three years in prison on his conviction for seconddegree grand larcency. Mr. Gallagher had been accused of taking more than $1,500 from the Albany Public School Teachers Credit Union. He had been treasurer of the credit union.

title: Some Treasury Issues At Lowest Prices of 75
description: Prices of Treasury coupon issues with maturities from two yeAs out to 25year bonds slipped yesterday to their lowest levels of 1975. Dealers said the pullback in prices, accompanied by simultaneous increases in yields, reflected two main fears in this market that is the most sensitive of all to interestrate developments.

title: A Whooping Crane Egg Produced in Captivity
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Describing it as a major event of scientific importance, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service reported today that its captive flock of whooping cranes had produced its first egg.

title: PROBE CONTINUING IN KENYA KILLING
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 21The Kenyan police have picked up and questioned a Member of Parliament who serves on a select committee investigating the murder last month of a leading politician. The murder has touched off a wave of anger in Kenya.

title: Pitt Gets Japanese Grant

title: Thieu's Wife Reported To Have Left Vietnam

Tran Thien Khiem, had left Vietnam following President Thieu's resignation last night. He declined to say where the two women had gone.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
Notes on People
description: Dr. Rocco Petrone, launching director for the first moon landing by Apollo 11 and later overall director of all the moon landings, is leaving the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to direct a program to reclaim solid wastes. In May he will become head of the Naticnal Center for Resource Recovery, a joint industrylabor effort to turn garbage into energy as well as usable materials. Dr. Petrone, with the space program since 1960, is 48 years old.

title: People and Business

Clifford, prominent Washington lawyer and a Presidential troubleshooter and adviser, to serve as counsel to a Honduran investigating commission. The commission is looking into charges that the United Brands Company bribed top Honduran officials.

description: OMAHA, April 21The Omaha City Council has endorsed what appears to be the first management lottery in the nation. It would be run by a nongovernment corporation headed by a downtown businessman.

title: Lawrence Keepnews, 50, Dies; State Insurance Superintendent
description: Lawrence W. Keepnews, who took office last month as State Superintendent of Insurance, was found dead yesterday in his hotel room, apparently of a heart attack, while attending a conference of insurance commissioners in Colorado Springs, Colo. He was 50 years old and lived in Pelham, N. Y.

description: PARIS, April 21The French Government appealed urgently today for a quick resumption of negotiations to carry out the 1973 Paris agreements on Vietnam, accompanied by a ceasefire covering all South Vietnam.

description: Residents of the Rikers Island Correctional Institution for Women and women from the Junior League of New York mingled yesterday at an afternoon reception at the facility.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Denouncing, the United States as untrustworthy, South Vietnam's President, Nguyen Van Thieu, has resigned after 10 years office. He appointed his Vice President, Tran Van Huong, to replace him and said President Huong would immediately press for an end to the war and a start of peace negotiations. In an impassioned address to his nation, Mr. Thieu defended his character and his regime's accomplishments. [Page 1, Column 8.]

description: UTICA, N. Y., April 21 (AP) John P. Gualtieri, who served as Presiding Judge of the state Court of Claims in the midnineteensixties, died today at a hospital here. He was 71 years old.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 22Communist gunners were heavily shelling two besieged provincial capitals last night on the northeastern and eastern approaches to Saigon.

title: Accident Rule Voted
description: The State Senate gave final approval yesterday to a major change in the tort law. It would permit a person who is partly at fault in an accident to collect damages for the part of the accident that is attributable to the other party. Page 72.

title: Warning to Prosecutor In Connally Trial Cited
description: DALLAS, April 21 (AP)The Watergate special prosecutor was advised not to plea bargain for the testimony of Jake Jacobsen, the milk lobbyist, against former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally, The Dallas Times Herald says. It said that a Justice Department memo in the records of the case warned that Mr. Jacobsen would not be a credible witness.

title: Moscow Seeks Short Geneva Session on the Mideast
description: MOSCOW, April 21The Soviet Union is proposing an abbreviated preliminary session of the Geneva conference on the Middle East. Soviet pans for the conference, official Soviet, and Arab sources said, are being explained to Arab officials at Kremlin meetings and through highlevel diplomatic channels. The United States and Israel, it was understood, are also being kept abreast of Soviet plans through diplomatic channels.

title: Borg Is Toppled In Sweden, 64, 64
description: STOCKHOLM, April 21 (AP)  Unheralded Tenny Svensson, who ranks fifth in Sweden, upset his countryman, Bjorn Borg, 64, 64, in the first round of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 21A mariner sailing the length of the 1,000mile coastline today might observe no conspicuous difference from many other stretches of the nation's shore.

title: THREAT TO HIGHWAY IN LAOS IS REPORTED
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 21 (UPI)Renewed Communist attacks today threatened to cut a highway linking Vientiane and the royal capital of Luang Prabang, Defense Minister Sishouk na Champassak reported.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Tuesday, April 22, 1975

title: Screen: Exciting 'Maids':American Film Theater Presents Genet Work
description: "Everything that comes out of the kitchen is spit," says Madame to Claire, her maid. "Get out and take your mucous with you."Madame is dressing for an evening on the town. She reviles Claire as she orders her about, fetching jewels and clothes. Madame insults Claire and Claire grovels with pleasure. When Claire has attempted to add a bit of polish to Madame's patent leather shoes, Madame sneers, "Do you think I find it pleasant to know that my foot is shrouded by veils of your saliva?" And Claire answers humbly, "I wish Madame to be lovely."When the alarm clock suddenly rings, the two women clutch each other. Madame says, "Hurry. Madame will be back . . . It's over already and you didn't get to the end."The end is the end of the ceremonial masquerade enacted by Claire and Solange, the title characters in Jean Genet's "The Maids."Whenever Madame is out of the posh apartment, Claire and her older sister Solange take over the premises for an elaborate ritual in which each takes turn playing Madame while the other sister plays the maid who is not herself: When Claire is Madame, Solange is Claire. The end they never get to is Madame's death by strangulation.This time, Solange (Glenda Jackson), who seems to be the stronger of the two, blames Claire (Susannah York), and Claire says rather wistfully, "We waste too much time with the preliminaries."The American Film Theater's film version of Mr. Genet's one-act play has been somewhat literalized by being "opened up" for the screen by Christopher Miles, the director. Madame's elegant digs now are recognizably across the Place Vendome from the Paris Ritz. Nothing much has been added by this information, nor by our being presented a sort of dumb-show behind the opening credits that tells us that Claire and Solange have written anonymous letters resulting in the arrest of Madame's young lover, a character who never is seen in the Genet play.Though nothing much has been added by this mildly cinematic treatment, it is more important that nothing has been lost. The film, which was shown at selected theaters yesterday and will be shown again today, is a fine, vivid recording of what seems to have been a smashing theater production of the play in London last year with Miss Jackson, Miss York and Vivien Merchant (as Madame).The film preserves the essential quality of the play, which is that of a series of performances designed not to tell a story or convince us of narrative truth, but to speculate on illusion, on the relationship between the looks of things and the reality. As is the inevitable case with Genet, illusion is the only reality, and reality is a lie or, you might say, an illusion.In his preface to the Grove Press paperback edition of "The Maids," Jean-Paul Sartre has a good deal of ponderous fun going over this conundrum, which, at this point in history, seems a little schoolboyish and suggests nothing of the very real excitement of "The Maids" in performance.It is the surface of things that makes "The Maids" spellbinding (even through an arbitrary intermission that has been stuck into the one-act play). The film is carried by the furious interplay between Miss Jackson's Solange and Miss York's Claire, when they are playing what they call their "scene," and then between the two maids and Madame, who renders Solange and Claire effectively impotent by her casual kindnesses, by her insistence on recognizing as tokens of love the presents they have given her in hatred.Although "The Maids" is composed of role-playing, it is not a drama of identity as Antonioni's "The Passenger" is. Solange. Claire and Madame do not possess hidden hearts to be uncovered as by peeling artichokes. Each is a reflection of the other's wishes. Solange and Claire exist only in terms of the sado-masochistic relationship that binds them to each other and to Madame, who is, in turn, their creation.The three actresses have a superb time giving life to this wild riddle, missing none of the sometimes caustic, sometimes matter-of-fact humor that Sartre never takes time to ponder in his preface, but which is essential to Genet's work and to this film.

title: FORD PESSIMISTIC ON BIG EVACUATION
description: President Ford saidrt last night that it would be virtually impossible to evacuate large numbers of South Vietnamese refugees under current conditions without a sizable military commitment by the United States.

title: Ford, in TV Interview, Cooler to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, April 21President Ford exhibiting coolness toward Israel, said tonight that his Administration was considering three options for new Middle East neogtiations.

title: Deaths

description: PHILADELPHIA, April. 21 (UPI)Officials of the Internal Revenue Service hid the tax returns of President Nixon when evidence was disclosed in late 1973 that he had underpaid his taxes, according to a former auditor for the revenue agency.

description: Dr. William Geller, an attending physician in the department of medicine at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases and a specialist in the treatment of Hodgkin's Disease, died Sunday in Lyme, Conn. He was 54 years old and had an office here at 215 East 68th Street,

title: New York Looking to London For a Lesson in Growing Old
description: LONDON, April 21Full of American faces, the tourist bus rolled past the massed red Victorian towers of St. Pancras StationWhat shame! And only five years old, muttered a sarcastic voice from the fifth rowup through a decayed section of the borough of Camden and onto Harmood Street.

description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)Officials today investigated the hanging death of a police informerprisoner in a maximum security cellblock taken over by rebellious prisoners for 17 hours during the weekend.

description: WASHINGTON, N.C., April 21 (AP)Joanne Little, a black accused of killing a white jailer while she was an inmate, appeared in court for the first time today as arguments continued on pretrial motions.

title: Test of Phone Bills In City Area Finds Most Have Errors
description: ALBANY, April 21  More than half of the telephone bills in the New York City area tested for accuracy by staff members of the State Public Service Commission contained one or more errors, a commission analyst said at a hearing here today.

description: The ScrippsHoward Foundation yesterday named an investigativereporting team in Milwaukee, newspapermen in Detroit, Miami and Lakewood, Fla., and a New York television station the top winners in four annual competitions.

title: Chess:
description: With 10 points out of 15 games, Lajos Portisch won this year's 37th running of the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijkaan Zee. The Hungarian grandmaster impartially won three games with White and three with Black while drawing the remaining nine to finish undefeated.

title: LITTON PRODS NAVY TO PAY MORE COSTS
description: Litton Industries disclosed yesterday that it had increased by almost $130  million its claims against the Navy for costs the company said it had incurred in building five LHA amphibiousassault ships.

title: DR. ANTHONY S. KING
description: Dr. Anthony S. King of Madison, N. J., a diplomate of the American Board of internal Medicine, died Saturday in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N. J. He was 43 years old.

title: TV Weighin Bail on Scales of Justice
description: Interfacea series of half hours exploring areas in which different cultures in America come together, stinggle for dominance, blend, interact and occasionally explodereturns at 10 this evening to public television. Despite the rather labored definition of its intentions, the series offers a standard mix of personal profiles, social essays and investigative reports. But with Tony Batten (formerly of Black Journal and Channel 13's The 51st State) as executive producer and host, the results frequently deliver beyond standard expectations.

title: Marathon Victor Dispels Myths In Event He's Not Sure He Likes
description: BOSTON, April 21Shortly after he had won the Boston Marathon with a record performance today, Will Rodgers spotted Ambrose Burfoot, his former college roommate and the 1968 champion, in the locker room.

title: WALLACE GREETS 19 SOVIET YOUTHS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 21  Gov. George C. Wallace, who in times past has suggested that Communists are involved in civil strife in America, warmly greeted today a delegation of 19 young party members from the Soviet Union his office.

title: Brown U. Students Return After a Week of Protests
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 21 (AP)Brown University students returned to classes today for the first time in a week, but boycott leaders indicated the students were still unhappy with cuts made in next year's school budget and may resume the protests.

title: Islanders: On the Brink Again
description: A lingering Ranger challenge was met by the New York Islanders last Sunday afternoon when they defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 3.1, for their first victory in the four  of  seven game quarterfinal series. Derek Sanderson's parting remark after the Rangers went down to defeat was a derisive statement that the Islanders would never win another game in the playoffs. Among the signs hanging in the Nassau Coliseum gallery Sunday was a simple retort, Derek Be Damned.

title: Connecticut Job Figures
description: HARTFORD, April 21 (AP)Despite an overall loss ofjobs in Connecticut in the last 12 months, nonmanufacturing areas  including health and legal services, banking, government, restaurants and hotelshave posted gains. Total nonmanufacturing jobs increased by 8,440, from 815,270 in midMarch 1974, to 823,710 last month. But in manufacturing, 40,290 jobs disappeared  a decline from 431,520 a year ago to 391,230 in March.

title: Plan to Kill Castro Cited
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The C.I.A.'s former head of dirty tricks told the Rockefeller Commission today that during the Kennedy Administration, highranking intelligence officials discussed plans to assassinate Cuban Premier Castro of Cuba.

title: CORRECTIONS

Mr. Clark, who is 75 years old and retired from the Supreme Court in 1967, lives in Washington, D.C. The Tines regrets the error.

From what has now been learned about former President Nixon's secret correspondence prior to South Vietnam's reluctant adherence to those accords, it is reasonable to conclude that his American allies did little to disabuse President Thieu of this conviction.

He will pack the leaves into bales, called tambors, and sell the 300 pounds he harvests for $250.

description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)  The House gave final Congressional approval today to a $638million appropriations measure that includes $500,000 to fund the newly created Federal Elections Commission. The measure, approved on a voice vote and sent to President Ford, basically funds the Veterans Administration to pay the increased costs of the extra two years eligibility period for veterans to take advantage of education benefits.

The price of gold also fell, but the dollar gained against most other currencies. Page 49.

title: N.&W. and Santa Fe Earnings Fell Sharply in First Quarter
description: Two of the nation's strongest railroads, the Norfolk & Western and the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe, reported yesterday sharp declines in their firstquarter earnings. A third big carrier, the Illinois Central Gulf, said it operated in the red.

title: Ely Chinoy, 53, Sociologist At Smith, Dies in Accident
description: Ely Chinoy, professor of sociology and anthropology at Smith College and a member of the graduate faculty of the University of Massachusetts, died yesterday in a car accident while returning to his home in Northampton, Mass., from a meeting of the social needs section of the Massachusetts Bicentennial Commission.

The agreement would reduce the number of patients at the facilityonce overcrowded and depicted as a place of horrorfrom a current 2,900 to 250 in six years.

title: GERALD K. LEVINE
description: Gerald K. Levine, a vice president of the Humbert & Jones advertising agency, died of a cardiovascular ailment Sunday in Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark. He was 50 years old and lived at 71 West Montrose Avenue, South Orange, N. J.

title: Ranieri Mazzili, 65, Dies; Once President of Brazil
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 21 (AP)Ranieri Mazzili, former interim President of Brazil, died today at a hospital where he had been treated for a kidney ailment. His age was 65.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 21  Approaching peak excitement in what has been an exceptionally successful season for each team, the Golden State Warriors and Seattle SuperSonics will attack each other again tomorow night at the Oakand Coliseum with their fourofsevengame National Basketball Association playoff series tied at 22.

description: There's the old story about the little boy who brings home two applesone perfect and the other badly bruised. His mother says that he must share them with his sister. When he offers the bruised apple, his mother reminds him that a gentleman would choose differently. Outraged, the little boy cries: Make her choose!

title: PLAN OF PAN AM AND IRAN GAINING
description: Negotiations on the deal by which the financial troubles of Pan Ameriean World Airways would be eased through Iranian loans and investments of about $300million are making steady progress, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Transfers Can Be for Better or Worse
description: Merely transferring retardates from the Willowbrook Developmental Center has not, of itself, improved the plight of those who were transferred or those who remained in the state institution. In some cases, the patients were no better off at the new place. In others, their situaation was considerably improved. And long after hundreds of patients had been transferred by court order from Willowbrook, conditions at the Staten Island institution were shown to be still bad, and the director was transferred.

title: Earl of Mar Is Dead at 60; 30th Holder of Scottish Title
description: LONDON, April 21The Earl of Mar, 30th holder of the 900yearold Scottish title, fell to his death today from the sixth floor of his London apartment in Knightsbridge, He was 60 years old.

title: Port Authority Trims Rise In Its CommuterRate Plan
description: The Port Authority of New Yorrk and New Jersey, at the insistence of the Governors of both states, yesterday modified its scheduled toll increase for Hudson River crossings by agreeing to retain monthly discount tickets, but at a higher rate.

title: Yankees Down Red Sox, 121, As White Leads 16Hit Attack
description: BOSTON, April 21Before the Patriots Day game, which began here at 11 o'clock this morning following tradition, the Minutemen from Concord, the official Massachusetts Bicentennial Militia, spread across Fenway Park's grass and staged a mock presentation of the battle of Concord and Lexington.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The inflow of savings into the nation's savings and loans associations reached a record $12.9billion in the first quarter of this year, the United States League of Savings Associations estimated today.

title: New York Looking to London For a Lesson in Growing Old
description: LONDON, April 21Full of American faces, the tourist bus rolled past the massed red Victorian towers of St. Pancras StationWhat shame! And only five years old, muttered a sarcastic voice from the fifth rowup through a decayed section of the borough of Camden and onto Harmood Street.

title: Colleges Will Share Data Through Computer Network
description: PRINCETON, April 21 (UPI) The development of a computer network that will allow colleges to share information resources is under way, a consortium of colleges announced today.

title: U.S. PLANES CARRY MANY VIETNAMESE
description: CLARK AIR BASE, The Philippines, April 21  Hundreds of Vietnamese, some of hem present or former military officers, began arriving at Clark Air Base today on the American airlift from Saigon.

title: Chrysler Omits Dividend
description: DETROIT, April 21  The Chrysler Corporation, the company hardest hit by the auto sales slump, is omitting its 35cent dividend for the second straight quarter because of continued losses.

title: Article 1  No Title
F.A.A. SAYS SECURITY AVERTED HIJACKINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (Reuters)Security procedures at commercial airports in the United States prevented about 25 potential hijackings last year, the Federal Aviation Administration reported today.

title: Newark, Jersey City, Trenton Mayors Hail Economist's Call for Aid to Cities
description: Three of New Jersey's Mayors had warm praise yesterday for Arthur M. Okun, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, who asserted that when the Federal Government mismanages the overall economy and the cities and states get the problems the cities ought to be reimbursed with revenue aid.

title: Mr. Thieu Tells His Side of It
description: President Thieu's emotional speech of resignation is, of course, only one version of events, and that of a man who obviously has much need to justify himself. Even so, it seems at first reading to support a few observations:

title: Rodgers Captures Marathon With CourseRecord 2:09:55
description: BOSTON, April 21In an area currently consumed by Bicentennial celebrations and reliving the Great American Dream, Will Rodgers won the 79th annual Boston Marathon today with a course record and the fastest marathon ever run by an American.

title: RETIRED MILITARY IN INCOME PINCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The economic pinch is hurting retired military personnel, like other people, but the ones who hung up their uniforms many years ago contend they are in worse condition because of a 1958 change in the method of figuring their income.

title: SILVER FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Silver futures drifted lower on the Commodity Exchange, and some brokers warned their customers away from positions in April and May. The reason is what one broker called the battle of the giants in the two nearby months.

title: Jefense Lawyer Discounts Evidence in Murder Trial
description: MORRISTOWN, April 21 (UPI)  The lawyer for Morristown man charged in the murder of a 40yearold man last November said in Superior Court today that there was little evidence to connect his client to the killing.

title: Parent Getting Lifetime Pact
description: The contract negotiations of two National Hockey League stars reached bizarre extremes yesterday.

title: Thieu: A Cautious Man Who Only Jumps When the Tide Mounts to His Toes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21Nguyen Van Thieu, who resigned the presidency of South Vietnam tonight, has had a reputation among fellow Vietnamese as an exceedingly cautious man who makes his move only at the last minute.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Dvorak's Rusalka will be staged by the Juilliard American Opera Center next Nov. 20 to 23 as its first presentation of the 197576 season. The work will be conducted by Peter Herman Adler, who led a concert version of it here in 1955. It will be sung in a new English translation by Ruth and Thomas Martin.

title: Money
SETON HALL SEEKS CAUSE OF CLASHES
description: SOUTH ORANGE, April 21The provost of Seton Hall University said today that the school was calm after a series of racial clashes on campus on Friday and Saturday.

title: Byrne Income Tax Drive Faltering in State Senate
description: TRENTON, April 21Governor Byrne's proposed income tax plan for New Jersey continued to lose ground in the State Senate today.

title: Sugar Exporters Seeking Policy On Prices as Cuba Joins Talks
description: PUERTO PLATA, Dominican Republic, April 21 Delegates from Latin American and Caribbean nations that control half the world's sugar exports met today in the first of a weeklong series of discussions aimed at formulating a common pricing policy for sugar.

title: Jobless a Year, He Wins State Lottery
description: It was 12:40 P.M. yesterday, and Bernard Leone, district supervisor of the New York State Lottery, was waiting nervously in his office, wondering what had happened to the winner of the weekly jackpot, who was already 40 minutes late for his appointment.

title: TORT LAW REVISED BY STATE SENATE
description: ALBANY, April 21The Senate today gave final legislative approval to a major change in the tort law that would permit a person woo is partly at fault in an accident to collect damages for the part of the accident that is attributable to the other party.

title: Kennedy Committee Set Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Massachusetts Democrat whose (term ends next year, has set up a reelection committee, according to records filed with the Secretary of State. However, in a letter authorizing creation of the committee Mr. Kennedy said, No decision has yet been made regarding a declaration of my candidacy for reelection.

title: Construction Workers Mass In Capital to Demand Jobs
description: WASHINGTON. April 21 (UPI) About 3,000 construction unionists massed here today to demand some government relief for the 18 per cent unemployment rate in their crippled industry.

title: Justices Bar Review of CitySuburban School Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Supreme Court declined today to review two decisions that could result in the merger of city and suburban school districts to achieve racial desegregation in an overall metropolitan area.

title: State Agrees to Transfer 2,650 Out of Willowbrook
description: Governor Carey announced an agreement yesterday settle a threeyear court fight over the state's Willowbrook Developmental Center for the mentally retarded. The agree ment would reduce the number of patients at the facilityonce overcrowded and depicted as a place of horrorfrom a current 2,900 to 250 in six years.

title: College Students Think Ahead, With Help From the Real World
description: PRINCETON, N. J.It was a sunny spring Sunday, the kind that many college students spend and tossing footballs and Frisbees to one another on the campus grounds. Or studying anatomy under the elms.

title: Many Hurt as Leftists Assault 2 Political Rallies in Portugal
description: LISBON, Tuesday, April 22The Social Democratic Center, the only conservative party competing in the election for a constituent assembly next Friday, came under physical attack last night for the second time in 24 hours in the northern area where it has its greatest following.

title: State Rests in Crabiel Trial's First Part
description: ELIZABETH, April 21The state rested its case today in the first phase of the trial of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel and the Franklin Contracting Company. TheY are charged with conspiring to rig highwayconstruction bids and pay kickbacks to public officials.

title: Florida Hospitals Struck
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 21 (UPI)  Anesthesiologists at 18 Broward County hospitals began a oneweek strike today to protest sharp increases in malpractice insurance costs and the threatened loss of coverage. The strike halted all but emergency surgery.

title: ROBERT J. M'CARTNEY, UNIVERSITY AIDE, 57
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 21 (AP)  Robert J. McCartney, assistant to the president of the University of Massachusetts, died yesterday at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Education Chief Back in School

title: N.J.Racing On Sundays Is Rejected
description: TRENTON, April 21A proposal to permit horse racing in New Jersey on Sundays, subject to public referendum, was defeated today by the State Assembly.

title: Prison Chairmn Admits Inaction on Key Reforms
description: ALBANY, April 21  In the face of charges of a disgraceful performance, the chairman of the state's Commission of Correction conceded today that The group's operations had stayed pretty much the same in the last 15 months despite a legislative mandate for more active investigation and reform of the state's orisons and jails.

title: British Soccer Standing
Dave Anderson
description: In recent years, this was always the best of times New York with the annual intensity of the basketball and hockey playoffs, the annual inception of the baseball season, the annual indifference toward Joe Namath's annual indecision about his future. But now it's the worst of times. Of the basketball and hockey teams, only the Islanders are breathing, barely. In baseball, Catfish Hunter inspired bumper stickers that read, The Yankees in '75  You Ain't Seen Nuthin' Yet. The bumper sticker is partly prophetic. Catfish's record is nuthin' and three. As for Joe Namath, only the Jets' owners appear indifferent. If their quarterback decides to play for the Chicago team of the World Football League in return for the stockyards and Lake Shore Drive, the Jets' line will be stronger. Not their offensive or defensive line, but their bottom line. In these worst of times, each of the New York teams deserves mention, but not necessarily consideration. Let the bad times roll.

title: Net of Public Service Electric Off 15c a Share in First Quarter
description: NEWARK, N.J., April 21The Public Service Electric and I Gas Company reported today that its earnings for the first quarter of the year dropped to 60 cents per common share, from 75 cents for the first Quarter of 1974.

title: SMITH IS NAMED IN 1.5BILLION SUIT
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21The trustees of the bankrupt Westgate  California Corporation accused C. Arnholt Smith, its deposed chairman, and others today of systematically looting the company and sought damages against them of more than $1.5billion.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company has received three Army and Air Force contracts, totaling $63.5million for tow and Maverick missiles and for tactical air control system equpment.

title: Colonels Take Onener, 112109
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 21 (AP)Louis Dampier pumped in 27 points tonight, helping the Kentucky Colonels beat the Spirits of St. Louis, 112109, in the first game of the American Basketball Association's semifinal playoffs.

title: Moonlight, Jasmine and Rickets
description: When one writes about India as a European and in English (as I do), inevitably one writes not for Indian but for Western readers. Problems of communication, present themselves: how to translate the idiom of one language into another, how to present scene to an audience unfamiliar with its most obvious ingredients (such as temples, bazaars, and motorcycle rickshaws).

title: Stores Scored on Use of Buying Talent
description: Retailstore buyers gathered here yesterday at an industry meeting heard themselves hailed as the critical factor in the success or failure of a retail venture.

title: POSTAL UNIONS OPEN DRIVE FOR PAY RISES
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)Representatives of the United States Postal Service and four postal unions held today a short organizational session and announced plans to meet again April 29 to resume negotiations likely to lead to higher postal pay and higher postal rates.

title: Defendants Seek to Shift Blame in Trial on '71
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 21 Lawyers for defendants who included H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff, agents of the Secret Service, White House advance men, local policemen and members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars sought in Federal court today to shift the blame from their own clients for any illegalities committed in roughing up and barring political demonstrators from a 1971 rally attended by President Nixon.

title: SUEZ CANAL OPENING IS HAILED BY DAY AN
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, April 21Moshe Dayan, the former Israeli Defense Minister, said tonight that Egyptian President Anwar elSadat's actions opening the Suez Canal and redeveloping the cities along the waterway were more important than any agreement that Secretary of State Kissinger might have achieved.

title: Plans Rethought for Old Buildings of Distinction
description: The city has decided, at least for the time being, not to devote any funds toward refurbishing two old, architecturally distinguished buildings it owns just north of City Hall.

title: Three Newsmen Sentenced On Refusal to Name Source
description: FRESNO, Calif., April 21 (Reuters)The managing editor and two reporters from The Fresno Bee received indefinite jail sentences today for refusing to disclose the source of a grand jury transcript.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: John L. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, lashed out yesterday at the Patrolmen's Benevolent Associaion and its leaders for attempting to break current wage relationships in the city and achieve higher pay scales. In an unusually sharp attack another city union, Mr. DeLury accused the P.B.A. being a cry baby union that had long ridden on the backs of the sanitationmen in labor negotiations.

title: J.W.T. Narrows Loss In the First Quarter
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company might not have made money in the first quarter, but at least it cut its losses. These days you have to make do with small favors.

title: Stage: Inge's Picnic Revived by W.P.A. Theater
description: One of the longest and best established of the Off Off Broadway companies is the W.P.A. Theater, which has been working in its pleasant home on the Bowery for seven years. It has now staged more than 100 productions, very many of them new plays, but some of them revivals. This year, perhaps just to get in front of the Bicentennial orgy about to engulf us, it has devoted its season entirely to American plays. At present it is performing William Inge's Picnic, and it is interesting to see how the play stands up after more than 20 years.

title: Wilkes Wins Rookie Poll In N.B.A.
description: Keith Wilkes of the Golden State Warriors, whose unorthodox overthehead release jump shot has been called almost laughable, was named yesterday theNational Basketball Association's rookie of the year. Shooting off balance, with elbows flying and body twisted, the 21yearold, 6foot6inch forward averaged 14.2 points a game, second best on the team. He also was the Warriors' second best rebounder (671), had 183 assists and 107 steals and played outstanding defense.

title: Phone Book Cover Unveiled
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The Bell System unveiled its bicentennial telephone book cover today at a ceremony in the National Geographic Explorers Hall. The colorful cover will be put on telephone books in more than 2,000 communities across the nation as they are issued in the next 14 months.

title: Town Orders Chemical Plant to Close
description: INDEPENDENCE TOWNSHIP, April 21The Mayor and the Township Committee have ordered the Ashland Chemical Company, which operates the largest industry in this rural Warren County Township, to cease operations by noon Wednesday because the company is causing pollution problems.

title: SIGNAL IS SEEKING UNIVERSAL OIL CO.
description: The Signal Companies, Inc., of Beverly Hills, Calif., announced yesterday that with the concurrence of the Universal Oil Products Company, Signal would make an offer for 5.8 million, or 50.5 per cent., of Universal's common shares at $21 a share. The offer includes payment of $31.5million for 1.5 million shares of unissued Universal common stock, and $90.3million for 4.3 million shares from Universal shareholders. The offer to shareholders is scheduled to dote at 5 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time, May 2.

title: Unser and Stearns Give Mets Fair Deal So Far
description: Yogi Berra had some good reasons to enjoy the Mets' day off yesterday. The manager's early headaches with his bull pen were soothed in Sunday's doubleheader sweep of the Chicago Cubs and Berra, speaking from his Montclair, N. J., home, could extoll the players received in the trade that, supposedly weakened the bull pen.

title: Kissinger Puts Off Trip Slated for Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Secretary of State Kissinger announced tonight that because of the Vietnam crisis he was being forced to postpone a threenation South American trip that was to have begun on Wednesday.

title: Events Today
Playing With History
description: We know we're not really making history, just sort of playing with it, said Dino Di Carlo, whose midday rerun of Paul Revere's midnight ride last week set the stage for the first act of America's Bicentennial celebration.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Thousands Gathering at the River for Hudson Cleanup
description: BEACON, N. Y.Hard by the brown, rolling waters of the Hudson and buffeted by a biting neargale from the west, a thousand or more spectators and participants gathered here last Sunday to take part in one of the several shad festivals planned fellow performers.

title: JOBLESS YOUTHS THRONG CITY UNIT
description: More than 1,000 highspirited teenagers overwhelmed the South Brooklyn Office of the Neighborhood Youth Corps yesterday morning, seeking applications for federally financed jobs.

title: Dr. Lawrence S. Robertson Of Academy of Osteopathy
description: Dr. Lawrence S. Robertson, a former president of the New York Academy of Osteopathy, died of a brain hemorrhages Sunday in University Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 500 East 83d Street.

title: L'ENSEMBLE PLAYS IN ROCOCO SETTING
description: There are probably few more elegant surroundings for a concert in New York City than the French rococo ballroom of the James E. Burden mansion on East 91st Street.
