description: WASHINGTON, April 24As fears rose here that time was running out on plans for an orderly evacuation of Americans and Vietnamese from Saigon, the director of President Ford's Refugee Task Force said today that he was trying to accelerate the outflow.

title: Governors Agree On Plan to Extradite Kallinger to Bergen
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 24, (AP)Joseph Kallinger will be handed over to New Jersey authorities, who have charged him with murder, after he is tried in Pennsylvania on other charges, Gov. Milton J. Shapp said today.

title: Appeal Issued in Paris
description: PARIS, April 24A Khmer Rouge communiqu issued here today appeared to confirm reports that fighting was continuing in several provincial areas of Cambodia.

title: A New Cast Gives Its All In Bolshoi's Spartacus
description: Commitment is a word that easily springs to mind in watching the Bolshoi Ballet's dancers in Yuri Grigorovich's epicstyle ballet, Spartacus. When a new leading cast took over Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the recurring thought was how much and with what consistency Yuri Vladimirov, Boris Atimov, Nina Sorokina and Tatiana Golikova gave their all at every moment of this threehour spectacle.

title: JORDAN AND SYRIA ARE SAID TO PLAN JOINT COMMANDS
description: PARIS, April 24Syria and Jordan have agreed to establish joint military commands for their land and air forces, according to official information reaching here from the Middle East. The accord was, said to have been reached under Soviet sponsorship.

title: DR. IVOR D. HORWICH
description: Dr. Ivor D. Horwich, a retired orthopedic surgeon, who had been on the staffs of the Hospital for Special Surgery and New York Hospital, died Wednesday in Northport Veterans Administration Hospital, Northport, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Sayville, L.I.

title: Dr. EDITH DOBIE
description: Dr. Edith Dobie, professor emeritus of American history at the University of Washington, Sea??, died there yesterday at the age of 87.

title: 4 Children Die in Blaze
description: GRIMESLAND, N. C., April 24 (UPI)  Four children, ranging in age from 5 to 8, were killed last night when fire swept through a rural frame house heated by wood stoves. Six other children and two adults sleeping in the sixroom structure escaped. The victims were identified as Rochelle Anderson, 5 years old; her brother, Ricky, 4, and her cousins, Veronica Moore, 6, and Tyrone Davis, 8.

title: Warning of Racial War
description: President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia used an unusual vehiclea toast to President Ford at a state dinner in the White House, which is excerpted on the opposite pageto underscore the message he had brought to Washington in behalf of black Africa: racial war lies ahead southern Africa and the United States must exert itself positively and energetically to help avert such a catastrophe.

title: Film: 7 From the Coast
description: The work of Western avantgarde movie makers, which has been appearing here seasonally over recent years, again is marked by vitality and independence, if not consistent effectiveness, in the program of seven short subjects that opened yesterday at the Film Forum.

title: U.S. Officials Voice Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Administration officials, voicing doubts about reports that Jordan and Syria had agreed on joint military commands, said today that they had no information to confirm such moves.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A physicians' group said yesterday that it would join the fight against a bill that would prohibit the use of Medicaid funds to finance abortions. The bill has passed both houses of the Legislature, and Governor Byrne has said would sign it. The physicians' organization, the Obstetrical and Gynecological Group of Perth AmboyEdison, noted that similar legislation had been declared unconstitutional by courts in eight states.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Olin Earnings Climb by 33.9% In the Quarter to $16.2Million
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 24 James F. Towey, chairman of the Olin Corporation, had bullish news for the more than 300 stockholders who came to the company's annual meeting here this morning: earnings rose by 33.9 per cent to new first quarter high of $16.[09]million, or $1.38 a share. This compared with the $12.1million, or $1.03 a share, reported a year earlier.

title: FOUR NEWS GROUPS BACK SHIELD BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 24;Legislation granting newsmen la qualified privilege to protect confidential sources by refusing to answer investigators' question won broad support today from television networks, writers and newspaper publishers.

title: Jobs Here Decline To Lowest Level In 7Year Period
description: In a continued decline, the number of jobs in the Newt YorkNortheastern New Jersey area in February reached the lowest level for any month since January, 968, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Texans Say Ship Channel Is Getting Cleaner
description: HOUSTON, April 20Capt. Ozro Sheppard eased the Port Authority's 95foot touring yacht, the Sam Houston, into the Houston Ship Channel and pointed out some of the highlights of what the city calls its fabulous 50 miles of wharves, refineries, grain elevators, steel and paper mills and petrochemical complexes.

title: Hondurans Pledge Move to Democracy
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, April 24The military officers who seized power here Tuesday say they may need five to 10 years in office to carry out the social and economic retorms necessary to lift Honduras out of her chronic backwardness.

title: Notes on People
description: Anatoly Karpov was applauded by 1,000 chess fans in Moscow yesterday when he received the laurel crown an enormous wreathand modest gold medal of the world chess championship. Leading chess players and officials from 15 countries were present, but not Bobby Fischer, who has played no public matches after winning his title three years ago from.

title: GEN. DAVID H. TULLEY OF ENGINEER CORPS
description: David H. Tulley, a retired major general who had commanded the Army's Engineer Center at Fort Belvoir, Va., died Monday of cancer at FitzSimons Army Medical Center in Denver. He was 70 years old and had been living in Aspen, Colo.

title: No Leakage From Crash
description: HUNTERSVILLE, N.C., April 24 (AP)A truck carrying radioactive material wrecked here today but the police said that there was no leakage and canceled evacuation orders they had issued for this town.

title: Celtics Put Out Rockets, 128115
description: BOSTON, April 24The only thing that has changed with the Boston Celtics is the names. The tradition and the ability to destroy an opponent in a few minutes the way they did in the days of Bill Russell, Bob Cousy and Bill Sharman remain.

title: William Hartnell, 67, Actor In British TV and Movies
description: LONDON, April 24 (AP)William Hartnell, a character actor best known for his role as the original Dr. Who in British television series for children, died today at the age of 67.

title: Allen F. Stokes, Designer For Architectural Firm, 77
description: Allen Frederick Stokes, a retired architect and a former partner and chief architectural designer for Alexander D. Crosett & Associates here, died Wednesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: To tell of life from a blue whale's point of view, and a whale that starts out in its mother's womb at thatit seems at first an absurd risk that the naturewriter Sally Carrighar has taken in The Twilight Seas: A Blue Whale's Journey. For the very exercise of shaping a whale's impression of the world into human language would seem to smack of anthropomorphism. And such phrases as How splendid to be blue whale! and Oh, this was terrible weather in which to be horn! would seem to evoke the sort of pipesmoking, oldbeforehistime leviathan one mightn't especially want to know even if whales could talk. Yet the risk that Miss Carrighar takes is a calculated one. For empathy is what she demands for the giant creatures she writes aboutcreatures that have been so beleaguered and harassed by human marauders that their numbers have diminished to the danger point and their very urge to reproduce themselves has begun to wane. And since human beings seem able to empathize only when they recognize themselves in the Other, Miss Carrighar has made her whales as human as scientifically possible.

title: State Law on Second Term For Wallace Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Justice Department said today that it had no objection to the constitutional amendment passed by the Alabama Legislature in 1967 to permit Gov. George C. Wallace to seek and hold office for a second consecutive term.

title: San Juan Phone Disruption
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. April 24 (AP)  More than 8,000 telephones in the San Juan metropolitan area were out of order today and at least eight communities were unable to place long distance calls, the Puerto Rico Telephone Company said. The disruption of service came on the third day of a strike against the company by a union contending that a number of employes were dismissed unnecessarily.

title: Hondurans Meet Executives
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 A sixmember Honduran Government commission gathering evidenced related to bribery charges against its deposed President met today with Edward Gelsthorpe, executive vice president and chief operating officer of United Brands, which was known until five years ago as the United Fruit Company.

title: Construction Men In Connecticut Get An Alert on Fossils
description: Science and industry are joining hands with the blessing of the State of Connecticut to make sure that the wave of the future does not arrive over someone's dead bodyparticularly if it is a dinosaur's.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCORD IS FADING ON MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY. April 24  The atempt to reach a mipartisan agreement on malpractice insurance for physicians deteriorated seriously today, with the Senate Republicans announcing they intended to pass their proposals unilaterally next week.

title: ROBERTA SHERWOOD GIVES TOUR OF SONG
description: For a performer who started in Miami Beach and blossomed in Las Vegas, Roberta Sherwood is remarkably free of the slick, surface qualities usually associated with those enter tainment centers. Making her first appearance in New York in eight years, at Upstairs at the Spindletop, 254 West 47th Street, she conducts what amounts to a tour of popmusical Americana, from the sentimental era of When My Old Wedding Ring Was New to the contemporary world of Carole King, Nashville and The Way We Were.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 25, 1975

title: Schtz Takes Oath In 3d Berlin Term; Coalition Formed
description: BERLIN, April 24  Mayor Klaus Schtz of West Berlin was. sworn in today for his third term, more than six weeks after his Social Democratic party lost its majority in city elections.

title: George Gillespie, 85, Dies: Navy Captain Was 16 Flier
description: CORONADO, Calif., April 24 (AP)George S. Gillespie, a retired Navy captain who earned his wings as a naval aviator in 1916, died Monday at the age of 85.

title: House Backs $1.12Billion For Amtrak Through '77
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)The House approved today $1.12billion in grants to Amtrak, the national passenger train network.

title: Byrne to Restrict Crabiel To His Ceremonial Duties
description: TRENTON, April 24Governor Byrne said today that Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel would be confined to the constitutional  and largely ceremonialduties of his office and would not reassume the sensitive and influential position he held before he was indicted last year on charges of highway bidrigging.

title: Bernard Newman, Officer Of City Criminal Court, 47
description: Bernard Newman, deputy chief executive officer of the New York City Criminal Court and of the Criminal Branch, First Judicial District, State Supreme Court, died of cancer yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Four Embassies Close
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 25About 5,000 Vietnamese left Saigon for Guam yesterday aboard United, States Air Force jet transports' as the evacuation of Americans and Vietnamese continued.

title: DOCTOR IS GUILTY OF MURDER PLOT
description: TRENTON, April 24  Dr. William R. King, the former chief psychiatrist at Trenton State Prison, was convicted last night of plotting the murder of his former wife and two of her relatives.

title: No Derby Worries For Stephens Now
description: A year after saddling the winner of the 100th Kentucky Derby, 60yearold Woody Stephens is letting other trainers do the worrying while he prepares for a $25,000 race the called the Paul Race Revere Stakes. My colt works Tracks Friday, Stephens was saying yesterday in the barn area at Belmont Park. Then he goes out on the van at noon. We'll walk him Saturday, gallop him Sunday morning. Let him take a look at the race track. a $25,000 race called the Paul Revere Stakes. My colt works Friday, Stephens was saying yesterday in the barn area at Belmont Park. Then he goes out on the van at noon. We'll walk him Saturday, gallop him Sunday morning. Let him take a look at the race track.

title: Aboard the QE2, 1,000 Admen
description: The Queen Elizabeth 2 pointed her graceful bow toward the open sea, a thin trail of blue smoke from her single stack rose against a starry sky and the lights of her superstructure merged with the lights of the Jersey Palisadesone of the greatest media junkets in the history of man had begun.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The deepening recession the economy further distorted the nation's productivity and labor cost figures in the first quarter of this year, Labor Department figures indicated today.

title: 26 Thais Reported Lost
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 24 (AP)A Burmese gunboat opened fire on three trawlers fishing in Thai coastal waters and 26 Thai fishermen are missing and believed dead, the Bangkok Post reported today.

title: Kilt Is Used to Skirt Dress Code
description: HACKENSACK, April 24When George Gallagher, a stationary engineer, woke from just a few hours of sleep this morning after working the late shift in the boiler room of the Bergen County administrative offices here, he found a note from his wife. It read:

title: Financial Details Snarl Gurney's Trial
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 24One afternoon this week during the extortion trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Judge Ben Krentzman sat impassively at his bench in Federal District Court here. His chin propped on his right hand, his eyes closed behind his glasses.

title: JORDAN AND SYRIA ARE SAID TO PLAN JOINT COMMANDS
description: PARIS, April 24Syria and Jordan have agreed to establish joint military commands for their land and air forces, according to official information reaching here from the Middle East. The accord was said to have been reached under Soviet sponsorship.

title: Review of Mideast Policy Avoids Basic Shifts So Far
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The much vaunted policy reassessment for the Middle East has thus far not led to a reevaluation of basic American interests in the area, and at most, to a shift in the nuances of rhetoric and perhaps aid levels, according to Administration officials. No dramatic change toward Israel has been indicated.

title: Board Chairman Retires At Philadelphia Bulletin
description: The retirement of Robert McLean as chairman of the board of The Philadelphia Bulletin after 61 years with the paper was announced yesterday at the annual meet of The Bulletin's stockholders.

title: WAYNE A. DRESSEL
description: Wayne A. Dressel, founder and president of Dressel, Dimmitt & Andrews, a national executive recruiting concern with headquarters here, died yesterday of cancer at his home, Riders Lane, Fairfield, Conn. He was 48 years old.

title: PEDDLERS' MALL IN BRONX IS VOTED
description: A group of 40 street merchants in the South Bronx was granted a city franchise yesterday to create a peddlers' mall in the middle of Westchester Avenue, the first of its kind in the five boroughs.

title: VIETCONG INDICATE THEY WANT MINH AS SAIGON LEADER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 25  The Vietcong strongly implied last night that only Gen. Duong Van Minh, a proponent of peace, neutrality and cooperation with the Communists, was acceptable to them at the head of the Saigon Government.

title: Israeli Scandal Raises Questions About Bureaucratic Corruption
description: JERUSALEM, April 24A major new scandal involving charges of bribery, fraud and embezzlement by Government officials and defense contractors is rocking Israel, raising questions among many Israelis about the extent of corruption In their bureaucracy.

title: Panel Urges a 5Year Plan Of State Capital Investment
description: TRENTON, April 24A special commission appointed by Governor Byrne recommended today in its final report a fiveyear, $9.1billion capital investment program for New Jersey. The panel also called for creation of a permanent capital budgeting and planning commission.

title: BERNSTEIN DISCUSSES ORCHESTRA RETURN
description: Leonard Bernstein concluded his concert last night with the New York Philharmonic by commenting to the audience that somehow and in some way I'm going to come back to the Philharmonic. The remark, described as emotional by several members of the audience, came after Mr. Bernstein had conducted a Tchailkovsky program that closed with the Symphony No. 4.

title: Quiet Debut Set for Met's Lehman Wing
description: The pictures are not quite hung; the objects of art and furniture not yet precisely placed. But by May 13 the Lehman Collection, the magnificent bequest of Western European art left to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by the late Robert Lehman, will be ready for viewing by Metropolitan members. Its opening to the public will occur on May 27.

title: Administration and Congressional Sources Say Legislative Action on Energy Cannot Meet Ford's Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Congress cannot satisfy President Ford's goal of major progress on energy legislation by the end of this week, key Administration and Congressional sources said today.

title: Jamie Zashin Is Wed to Bruce Dunlap
description: Jamie Ellen Zashin and Bruce Edward Dunlap were married yesterday evening in Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N. T. Rabbis Ely E. Pilchik and Barry H. Greene and Cantor Norman Summers officiated.

title: 25.8% Decline Is Listed
Panel Urges Cancellation Of Dr. Jacobson's License
description: ALBANY, April 24A subcommittee of the State Board of Regents has recommended to the board that it revoke and cancel the medical license of Dr. Max Jacobson, the 75yearold general practitioner in New York City who for years used powerful amphetamine stimulants to lift the moods of rich and famous patients.

title: Arson Suspect Was Success Back Home
description: SPENCERVILLE, Ohio, April 24The word was out by the time Jack Young, maintenance superintendent of Ohio Decorative Products, Inc., went to lunch at the Villager (beerfoodcarryout, says the sign).

title: Music: Songs by Crespin
description: Regine Crespin, the French dramatic soprano, came to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night to sing the most peculiar assortment of French songs and arias this listener has ever encountered. It included everybody's sentimental favorites by Chausson and Duparc, songs about animals by Ravel, Chabrier and Rosenthal, a bawdy chanson and two other minor items by Poulenc, an opening Debussy group consisting of La Grotte, Romance and La Chevelure and a closing selection of pieces from Offenbach operettas.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times last Friday, the Human Resources Administration stated incorrectly that specifications for new city Medicaid laboratory contracts had been drawn up by state lawyers. A corrective article appears today on Page 33.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Island Project
description: Reading one's mail i like beachcombing: every once in a while something of value emerges from the wrack of words.

title: Hospital Group Names Chief
description: Paul J. Connor Jr., director of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island, has been designated presidentelect of the Greater New York Hospital Association and will become the group's president next month.

title: Advertising
description: Gilbert Advertising. for 24 years the handiwork of Richard L. Gilbert, is expected to merge into Kameny, Solomon, Sherwood & Partners next Thursday to become Kameny, Solomon, Sherwood & Gilbert.

title: QUARTER NET DOWN FOR DELTA AIR LINES
description: With its traffic down 2 per cent and its operating expenses up by 21 per cent, Delta Air Lines reported yesterday sharply lower earnings for the three months to March 31, its third fiscal quarter.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS ON AMEX DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday as volume rose slightly but was still slow. Prices finished mixed in the overthecounter market.

title: Market Place
description: In three weeks American Telephone warrants to purchase 31.3 million telephone shares at $52 each are due to expire, and, with A.T. & T. stock at 48 it is widely believed that the warrants will prove to be worthless.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Pittsburgh

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOWCASE In a way, Jane Scheckter typifies the parade of talent at the Fallen Angel (6501081), an uptown supper club with nightly entertainment on Second Avenue at 84th Street. A young hopeful balladeer, she has also circulated, in midtown (at Improvisation and Gypsy's) and downtown (Village Gate, Bitter End, the Ballroom).

title: House Backs Revamping Of the Securities Industry
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The House of Representatives approved legislation today providing the most comprehensive revision of securities industry regulation in 40 years and laying the foundation for national market system. The vote was 376 to 13.

title: G. M. Rehiring
description: The General Motors Corporation says it will reduce the number of workers on indefinite layoff to 110,000 by April 30 from the present total of 130,000. Page 50.

title: Alcan Aluminium Cuts Its Dividend to 20 Cents
description: MONTREAL, April 24 (Reuters)Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., said today it was cutting its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share from 30 cents a share because of current economics and liquidity problems, including heavy accumulation of inventories. The dividend is payable June 5, to shareholders of record May 7.

title: Islanders Now 4th N.H.L. Team To Tie Series From 30 Deficit
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 24 As if to touch history, a hundred fans milled around the Islanders' dressing room tonight, an hour after the New Yorkers' had posted 41 victory to even their Stanley Cup series with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Bridge:
description: Most of the players who are prominent in the game nowadays developed their enthusiasm for it as students, when there was time and energy to study technique and argue about bidding sequences. There may be some stars of the future among the 16 pairs competing today and tomorrow in the finals of the North American Intercollegiate Bridge Championships in Chicago.

title: StateOwned Bank Urged As a Way to Help Economy
description: About a dozen speakers, including Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, and the economist Eliot Janeway, agreed yesterday that a stateowned bank would fill gaps in the state's economy that they said were not me tby the commercial banks and savings Institutions.

title: About the Mets ...
description: Manager Yogi Berra, in a happy mood because of the Mets' fourgame winning streak, received good news as he left early last night with his players for Montreal. The Mets are listed to face the Expos in three afternoon games starting today. The happy tidings came from Billy Connors, the Mets' minor league pitching coach. He phoned and reported that George Stone, a southpaw pitcher, and Cleon Jones, who have been ailing, had participated in a minor league farm system game yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla. Stone pitched three innings, allowed two hits and walked one, while throwing 29 pitches, said Connors. He also reported that Jones, recovering from surgery and a subsequent pulled muscle in a calf, also had played three innings and shown no sign of his ailment while running bases.

title: SMOKY IRT BLAZE TRAPS THOUSANDS
description: A smoky electrical fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel crippled service on four IRT lines at the height of the rush hour last night, trapping thousands of passengers aboard five trainssome for an hour and a half.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: At the final Federal Aviation Administration hearing on the agency's tentative plan to permit four daily flights of the BritishFrench supersonic Concorde airliner into and out of Kennedy International Airport, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz joined the opponents. His statement, presented by an assistant attorney general, James P. Corcoran, suggested a different way for the Federal Government to reduce travel time for airline passengersby providing funds for the needed rapidtransit rail link from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport. Charles R. Foster, the F.A.A.'s director of the Office of Environmental Quality, who conducted the hearing at the Fort Hamilton post theater in Brooklyn, said additional written comments would received through May 6. The City Council's Environmental Protection Committee, meanwhile, approved a resolution calling on the F.A.A. to reverse its tentative approval the Concorde flights.

title: Impact of Inventories
description: In almost every recession there comes a time when the tail wags the dog. For the current recession, the deepest in decades, that time is now. The tail, so far, is a $36billion swing in inventory levels. The enormous United States economy, with a gross national product of $1.4trillion, is the dog.

title: ACCORD LACKING ON WATER USAGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24A national conference on water resource policies ended three days of deliberations today after focusing on problems that have been unanswered thus far.

title: 3 Die as Guerrillas Seize and Blow Up West German Embassy in Stockholm
description: STOCKHOLM, Friday, April 25  Three persons were killed as terrorists shot their way into the West German Embassy here yesterday, took up to a dozen hostages and then blew up part of the building after their demands for the release of 26 anarchists jailed in West Germany had been refused.

title: 109 on Saigon Plane a Problem for U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24Last Monday night 294 Vietnamese refugees landed at Oakland Airport stuffed into an overloaded DC8. The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service still has not decided what to do with 109 of them.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 25, 1975

title: VIETNAMESE POUR INTO GUAM BASE
description: ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, April 24 (Reuters) Plane after plane landed here today bringing thousands of Vietnamese refugees to this base that was the home for many of the B52's that bombed Vietnam at the height of the war.

title: Beer Hall in Oregon Shelters Refugees
description: MOUNT ANGEL, Ore., April 24Numb from fatigue and a cold spring rain, lame children from Saigon and scores of other Vietnamese refugees settled today into their temporary Oregon shelter  a community beer hall  after traveling 10,000 miles in three days.

title: Fighting Slackens in Vietnam, Pressure on Saigon Keeps Up
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24 (Reuters)Fighting scaled down in South Vietnam in the past 24 hours, but Communist pressure was kept up on key Saigon defense points, a command spokesman said today.

title: Board Scores Beame Plan To Shut 43 Schools in '75
description: Reacting angrily to Mayor Beame's announced plan to close 43 underused schools at the end of this term, the Board of Education declared yesterday that under no circumstances would it permit City Hall to dictate educational decisions.

title: Seymour Shifrin Work Has Local Premiere
Indian Bureau Funds Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)President Ford has asked Congress for an additional $10.9million for the Interior Department for the fiscal year 1976 to provide for expansion and improvement in the Bureau of Indian Affairs' law enforcement program.

title: Rockefeller A pologizes to Senate Over 'Discourtesy' on Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Vice President Rockefeller apologized today for any discourtesy he showed the Senate when he presided over a change in the filibuster rule two months ago.

title: Byrne Drops Fight to Get An Income Tax in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 24Governor Byrne and the Democratic leaders in the Legislature said tonight that the Governor's plan for a state income tax was dead.

title: Jobs and Crime (cont.)
description: When the F.B.I. published sharply higher figures for the incidence of crime in 1974, Attorney General Edward Levi attributed part of the increase to rising unemployment, and it was remarked in this space that Americans might well ponder the implications of the apparent link between rising unemployment and rising crime.

title: C. STERLING CONOVER
description: Dr. C. Sterling Conover, who retired in 1963 as an orthodontist after 42 years of practice here, died Wednesday while on vacation in Venice, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Bay Head, N.J.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Portugal Voting Today, Forces Alert
description: LISBON, April 24  Portuguese ground forces were being placed on alert today in preparation for the election tomorrow of a constituent assembly.

title: LOANS DECREASE; MONEY EXPANDS
description: Business loans continued to decrease and the money supply continued to grow faster in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Douglas and the Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 24When the Supreme Court heard the final case of the current term argued yesterday afternoon, the highbacked leather chair at the right of Chief. Justice Warren E. Burger was empty, as it has been virtually all this year. Associate Justice

title: MRS. THOMAS GRACE
description: Ethel Glass Grace, widow of Thomas G. Grace, a lawyer and former New York State Director of the Federal Housing Administration, died Wednesday in Boca Raton, Fla., where she lived. Her age was 76.

title: Penn Relays' Mile Looms as Big Test for Wohlhuter
description: It's not the pressure that has heightened Rick Wohlhuter's interest in tomorrow's Ben Franklin Mile at the Penn Relays in Philadelphia.

title: BROWN UNIVERSITY IS SITE OP A SITIN
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 24Black students seized Brown University administration building early this morning in a running dispute here over the schol's budget cutbacks.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Kentucky vs. St. Louis

title: U.S. and E.E.C. Declare a Truce in the Cheese War
description: WASHINGTON, April 24A truce was declared today in the simmering cheese war between the United States and the European Common Market.

title: CAREY PICKS FOUR FOR U.D.C. BOARD
description: ALBANY, April 24Governor Carey nominated four directors of the Urmbban Development Corporation today, among them a former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman and a former New York City Finance Administrator.

title: Red Smith
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Trial of the John Mackey case, in which the National Football League players challenge the socalled Rozelle rule, is to be resumed Monday before Federal Judge Earl Larson in Minnesota. Meanwhile, collective bargaining between the players and their employers is proceeding at a halting pace, with one pair of subcommittees scheduled to begin work in New York on Tuesday and another pair due to meet here on Thursday. Finally, perhaps in early June after the Mackey case has been de cided, Joe Kapp's antitrust damage suit against the N.F.L. will go on trial.

title: NOAH FELDMAN
description: Noah Feldman, a Brooklyn lawyer specializing in realestate work, died Wednesday evening, in Caledonia Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old and lived at 90 Remsen Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: ATOM ARMS HELD A PERIL ON ROADS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)The Army and Navy have been moving nuclear warheads along the nation's highways in a manner that makes the weapons vulnerable to terrorist activities, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Master Derby, $4.60, Wins Muddy Blue Grass Stakes
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 Master Derby sped through the extremely sloppy going to score an impressive and expected victory today in the Blue Grass Stakes.

title: BREITEL RECEIVES NADJARI APOLOGY
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, apologized yesterday to the chief judge of the Court of Appeals for submitting a brief that challenged the honesty and integrity of the lower appeals court that dismissed the indictment of Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney.

title: The Screen
Automated Device Speeds Eyeglass Prescriptions
description: A computerized method of determining eyeglass prescriptions is being studied by eye specialists at Mount Sinai Medical Center as a means of screening large numbers of children who might otherwise go through years of school with their visual problems undetected.

title: LAOS RIGHT REPORTS RETAKING JUNCTION
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 24 (Reuters)Rightwing military sources said here today that they had regained control of an important road junction and an airfield north of here lost to proCommunist Pathet Lao troops earlier this week. The sources said that fighting, which broke out in the area Saturday evening and ended Tuesday night, resumed yesterday.

title: IRT Fire in Brooklyn
description: A smoky electrical fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel crippled service on four IRT lines at the height of the rush hour last night, trapping thousands of passengers and overcoming at least 15. Page 44.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn.Duane Bobick, 213 pounds, Bowlus, Minn., outpointed Raul Gorsito, 199, Argentina 10 rounds; Scott LeDoux Minneapolis, outpointed Rodney Bobick, Bowlus, Minn.

title: P.S.C. Staff Urges Phone Rise but Cut In HomeUse Rates
description: ALBANY, April 23In answer to the New York Telephone Company's request for a rate increase of $488.8million, the staff of the State Public Service Commission is recommending an increase of $237million, allocated in such a way that the cost of basic service to millions of residential customers would drop.

title: Moses Finds Things to Deplore
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., April 24Robert Moses surveyed the world scene today and found a variety of things to take a dim view of.

title: CAREY PICKS FOUR FOR U.D.C. BOARD
description: ALBANY, April 24Governor Carey nominated four directors of the Urmbban Development Corporation today, among them a former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman and a former New York City Finance Administrator.

title: Yemen May Cut Beirut Ties
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 24 (UPI)Yemen has decided to close her embassy in Beirut in protest over an attempt on the life of a Yemeni diplomat here Tuesday, Egypt's Middle East News Agency said today in dispatch from Sana, the Yemeni capital.

title: Chris Evert Advances To Semifinal, 62,60
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., April 24 (Reuters)  Topseeded Chris Evert, playing flawlessly, breezed past Franoise Durr of France, 62, 60, today and advanced to tomorrow's semifinals of the $150,000 Family Circle magazine cup tennis tournament.

title: GRAIN AND SOYBEANS SHOW LAG IN STOCKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (REUTERS)Stocks of grains and soybeans held around the nation on April 1, were less than officially projected, indicating that usageparticularly domesticallyhas picked up more than expected over the past three months.

title: Governor Concedes His Income Tax Plan For Jersey Is Dead
description: TRENTON, April 24Governor Byrne and the Democratic leaders in the Legislature said tonight that the Governor's plan for a state income tax was dead.

title: More Than Survival
description: When many of the nation's colleges and universities are understandably preoccupied with spiraling costs and gaping deficits, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching has issued a needed warning that fiscal survival alone is not enough. Though the financial projections are indeed gloomy on many campuses, no response could be more damaging to the institutions and to the nation than resigned adherence to the status quo as a means of muddling through.

title: Treasury Issues Continue to Advance
description: Treasury issues continued (their quiet but improving tone yesterday. This sector of the market apparently was helped by recent statistics showing a decline in the inflation growth rate, as well as the poor April showing of newcar sales. The rationale behind the latter development is that the economy remains exceedingly sluggish and, in view of this, the Federal Reserve will be loath to tighten credit conditions for some time.

title: 300 PLAN A PROTEST AT HOSPITAL CLOSING
description: About 300 perions, a dozen of them disabled patients in wheelchairs, filled a loud and angry meeting of Community Planning Board 8 last night to, protest Mayor Beame's announcement that the city would close Goldwater Hospital on Roosevelt Island because of its budget crisis.

title: Operetta: FirstRate Merry Widow
description: If anyone thinks operetta is dead, he or she should catch the Village Light Opera's production of The Merry Widow. The Lehar masterpiece is being given a very spirited, handsome revival at the Fashion Institute, and it can still be seen tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon.

title: Susan Saxe Trial Delayed
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP)Susan Saxe, who was on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 Most Wanted list for four years until her arrest last month, will go on trial June 9on Federal bank robbery charges, it was announced today. The trial earlier was scheduled to start May 12.

title: ... and the Future
description: What is happening in Saigon now is the collapse the policy that has guided South Vietnam through its years of disaster, and consequent disintegration of the ruling group that embraced that policy. The process not yet complete; as the proCommunist Provisional Revolutionary Government (Vietcong) recognized immediately, the replacement of President Thieu by the ineffectual Tran Van Huong was merely a shift within the same power structure, not a genuine new direction.

title: CHASE BANK CLOSES ITS SAIGON BRANCH
description: Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had suspended operations of its Saigon branch at the end of the business day.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Friday, April 25, 1975

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN; Gesell Institute: Still, the Work Goes On
description: NEW HAVENSitting in a bright and airy office of the Gesell Institute of Child Development here the other day, Dr. Frances IIg found herself thinking back to the forties, the glory years of her work with children.

title: CLEMENS E. BENDA, PSYCHIATRIST, 76
description: Dr. Clemens E. Benda, an internationally known authority on mental deficiency and mongolism, died last Friday in Munich, Germany. He was 76 years old and lived in Arlington, Mass.

title: I.C.C.UNIT TO ISSUE RAILPLAN CRITICISM
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)An agency within the Interstate Commerce Commission this weekend will issue a report strongly criticizing the United States Railway Association's plan for reorganizing Northeastern railroads, it was learned today.

title: Rockefeller Apologizes to Senate Over Discourtesy on Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Vice President Rockefeller apologized today for any discourtesy he showed the Senate when he presided over a change in the filibuster rule two months ago.

title: Catholic Church Charges Brazil With 100 Political Arrests in '75
description: RIO de JANEIRO, April 24Roman Catholic Church sources say Brazilian authorities have made more than 100 political arrests in So Paulo in the first three months of this year. Many cases of torture are said to have been involved.

title: ExPrison Psychiatrist Guilty of Murder Plot
description: TRENTON, April 24Dr. William R. King, former staff psychiatrist at Trenton State Prison, was found guilty today of plotting the murder of his wife and two of her relatives.

title: Phelps Unit Price Rise Set
description: The Phelps Dodge Cable & Wire Company announced yesterday new selling prices for most building wire products. Effective Monday, prices will be raised about 5 per cent. The company is a subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: COOK COLLEGE DEAN, FRUSTRATED, QUITS
description: Dr. Charles E. Hess, dean of Rutgers University's Cook College, announced his resignation today, citing frustration with the university's central administration and with the state's Chancellor of Higher Education.

title: Westgate Trustees File Suit Aganist Government
description: A suit, seeking over $10[09]million in compensation from the United Stales Governments was filed yesterday by the trustee of the WestgateCalifornia Corporation, Sin Diego, Calif.

title: Aaron Designated Sitter Tonight
description: Henry Aaron has played at Shea Stadium before, but not against the Yankees. Henry Aaron has played against the Yankees before, but not in a regularseason game. Henry Aaron might play at Shea Stadium against the Yankees in a regular season game tonight. Then again he might not.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: WASHINGTON, April 24, (Reuters)A nuclear test in the yield range of between 20 and 200 kilotons was conducted underground today at an atomic test site in Nevada, the Energy. Research and Development Administration announced. It Was the agency's fourth announced test this year.

title: People and Business
description: I believe it is time for all of uslegislators, regulators and bankers aliketo opt for fewer, not more, regulations, Vincent H. Crawford said yesterday in Washington on the occasion of his election as the new president of the Savings Banks Association of New York State.

title: SHAH BACKS EGYPT IN ISRAELI CONFLICT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 24Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi declared today that Iran supported the policies of Egypt 100 per cent in the ArabIsraeli conflict and other issues, and he predicted that those policies would prevail at the end.

title: Kaunda: Dismayed by America
description: We seek American understanding of Africa's objectives and America's fullest support in the attainment of these objectives.

title: Suspect  A Farm Boy Who Made Good
description: SPENCERVILLE, Ohio, April 24The word was out by the time Jack Young, maintenance superintendent of Ohio Decorative Products, Inc., went to lunch at the Villager (beerfoodcarryout, says the sign).

title: 3 Killed as Guerrillas Seize and Blast West German Embassy in Stockholm
description: STOCKHOLM, Friday, April 25  Three persons were killed as terrorists shot their way into the West German Embassy here yesterday, took up to a dozen hostages and then blew up part of the building after their demands for the release of 26 anarchists jailed in West Germany had been refused.

title: Sihanouk Looks to an Asia Without U. S.
description: PEKING, April 24  We did what they said we could never do, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia said here. We defeated the Americans.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON USE OF TROOPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24House and Senate conferees reached a tentative agreement today on legislation that would give President Ford limited authority to use armed forces to evacuate Americans and some South Vietnamese from Saigon.

title: UAL Pledges to Fight C.A.B. on Records
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24Officials of UAL, Inc., the parent company of United Air Lines, asserted today that the company could not accede to demands of a Federal inquiry on illegal campaign gifts because investigators had exceeded their authority by seeking unlimited access to all documents on the premises. unlimited access to all documents on the premises.

title: Our Schools, Yes
description: It's time for someone to Say something good about the New York City school system. You don't encounter very much good news about it in the newspapers or on television. Schools are the favorite whipping boy of a lot of people. It's the in thing to take a few swipes at the schools at any respectable cocktail party and, what's worse, even the educators themselves are beginning to do it.

title: Dellums Tells House Of Nephew's Slaying
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)Representative Ronald V. Dellums challenged the House to take the weapons of death and destruction from the hands of criminals after telling startled legislators today that his 17yearold nephew had been shot in a robbery.

title: P.S.C. Staff for Phone Rise With a Cut in Home Rates
description: ALBANY April 23In answer to the New York Telephone Company's request for rate increase of $488.8million, the staff of the State Public Service Commission is recommending an increase of $237million, allocated in such a way that the cost of basic service to millions of residential customers would drop.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Good food in generous quantities, well served in a sufficiently attractive room at $6.75 for a full dinner, is rare enough to make Le Muscadet, 987 Third Avenue at 59th Street (near all those movie houses), a pretty good bargaineven after you add tax, tip, and two bits for the checkroom for a total of $8.30.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Columbia to Refuse Soviet Exchanges; Visa Issue Is Cited
description: Dr. William J. McGill. president of Columbia University, said yesterday that he would not receive or deal with any visitors from the Soviet Union until the Soviet Government allowed Vitali Rubin, a Jewish specialist on Chinese philosophy, to accept a teaching position at Columbia.

title: Peril of Catalytic Devices Is Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)A study released today by manufacturers of emission control devices contends that the Environmental Protection Agency overestimated the potential danger of sulphate emissions from cars equipped with catalytic converters.

title: President's Power: Tonkin and Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Nearly 11 years ago, the House of Representatives, in 40 minutes, unanimously rushed through the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, giving the President broad authority to use American troops in Indochina.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Moses Deplores Variety of Things

title: The Eternal Optimist
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The news from Paris is that Jean Monnet, the architect of a united Europe, is finally retiring from his heroic labors, but this can't be true. Mr. Monnet never retires, even at bedtime. He never quit anything in his life and will go on preaching and fighting for unity until he himself is finally united with the soil of Europe.

title: Comment by Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (Reuters)The Defense Department acknowledged that United Statesmade bomb might have been used by the South Vietnamese to suffocate troops attacking Xuan Loc.

title: Politics in Saigon ...
description: The internal politics of South Vietnam have never been quite so clearcut as they appeared through the distorting prism of United States policy. What looks like a sudden end to South Vietnamese independence may beat least for the presentsomething less than that: a new political phase, and one that is likely involve a struggle among various factions of Hanoi's partisans as well as the nonCommunist nationalists of the south.

title: IRT Fire in Brooklyn
description: A smoky electrical fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel crippled service on four IRT lines at the height of the rush hour last night. trapping hundreds of passengers and overcoming at least 12. Page 44.

title: 10 ACCUSED IN FIRE THAT RAZED PLANT IN SHELTON, CONN.
description: Arson and conspiracy charges in the firebombing that destroyed a $10million spongerubberproducts plant in Shelton, Conn., last month were lodged yesterday against the plant's owner, his allegedly clairvoyant spiritual adviser and eight other men.

title: Saxbe Says U.S. and India Grow Apart
description: NEW DELHI, April 24  Ambassador William B. Saxbe says he fears that the United States and India are drifting apart and that a recent wave of antiAmerican comments could have an impact on Congress and the Ford Administration.

title: Simonetti Is Ordered Into Court In Inquiry on the Attica Defense
description: BUFFALO, April 24A State Supreme Court justice today ordered the chief Attica prosecutor to appear in court here next Monday in connection with an inquiry into whether the state prosecution received information concerning the Attica legal defense from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Medical Center Dedicated
description: FORT GORDON, Ga., April 24 (AP)  The $33million Dwight David Eisenhower Army Medical Center was dedicated toda yby military officers and civilians who gathered to eulogize the former President.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Looks as if there will be more designers making clothes meant to be worn inside the house. Donald Brooks, Stephen Burrows, Clovis Ruffin and Scott Barrie are among the Seventh Avenue habitus who have made the jump to Madison and Park Avenues, the home of the loungewear market.

title: Accused Minister Denies Any Role in Shelton Fire
description: MEMPHIS, April 24David Noble Bubar, 47yearold Bap tist minister, self  professed psychic and wellknown Memphis spiritual adviser, denied involvement in the firebombing of a Connecticut spongerubber plant at his arraignment on Federal conspiracy and other charges here today.

title: About Real Estate
description: YONKERSAs the builder Martin Ginsburg tells it, Westchester is now where New York City was five years ago.

title: Soviet Is Showing More Vigor Abroad
description: MOSCOW, April 24The Soviet Union has begun demonstrating greater assurance in its foreign policy as it seeks to explore the possibilities offered by the reverses suffered by the United States around the world.

title: G.M. IS REHIRING 20,000 WORKERS
description: DETROIT, April 24Despite a continued slump in sales of new cars, the number of General Motors Corporation workers on indefinite layoff will be down 20.000 by the middle of next week from current levels, a G.M. spokesman said today.

title: Islanders Beat Penguins, 41, Even Series at 3 Games Each
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 24The improbable came to pass in Nassau Coliseum tonight as the New York Islanders won their third straight game over the Pittsburg Penguins, 41. The victory evened the fourofsevengame National Hockey League quarterfinal series at three games apiece.

title: C. ARNHOLT SMITH IS FINED $10,000
description: SAN DIEGO, April 24 (UPI)A Federal Court judge imposed a maximum fine of $10,000 today on C. Arnholt Smith, the financier and longtime friend and financial supporter of former President Richard M. Nixon, for making illegal corporate campaign contributions.

title: MAYOR INDICTED IN MANCHESTER
description: TRENTON, April 24Mayor Joseph S. Portash of Manchester Township, a former Ocean County Freeholder, was indicted today on charges of misconduct in office and illegally accepting $31,730 from Robert Schmertz to obtain zoning approval for a $200million retirement billage. Mr. Schmertz is the principal owner of the Boston Celtics basketball team.

title: Russians Angered Over Sea Burial by the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)  Soviet diplomats are privately expressing indignation that the bodies or personal effects of Russian seamen brought up by the Central Intelligence Agency from a sunken submarine in the Pacific were not returned to the next of kin.

title: Indiana Standard Backs a Revised Bid To Pasco Property
description: Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) approved yesterday a revised cash offer for the Wyoming oil and gas properties owned by Pasco, Inc. The company raised its bid for the Wyoming properties to $225million or $5million more than it offered earlier this month. Under the revised offer. Standard will acquire two natural gasoline proc essing plants in addition to the seven oil and gas producing properties owned by Pasco, but the transaction does not include Pasco's refining, marketing and transportation facilities, and certain nonproducing acreage. It also provides for continued supply of crude oil to Pasco's Wyoming refinery from these fields.

title: 4 NEWSMEN AWAIT APPEAL ON SOURCES
description: FRESNO, Calif., April 24 (AP) Four Freno Bee staff members, including the managing editor and city editor, have until May 23 to appeal indefinite jail terms over their refusal to disclose a news source.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe Vancisin, Yale University basketball coach for 19 years, has resigned, effective July 1, to become executive secretary of the National Association of Basketball Coaches. His teams won 207 games and lost 241. Yale has had seven straight losing seasons. His record last season was 3 victories and 20 losses. Van cisin, 52 years old, produced two Ivy League championships and his teams finished in the first division 11 of his 19 years.

title: G.M. Aide Refuses to Disclose Details of 25 Dismissals on L.I.
description: DETROIT, April 24A vice president of General Motors refused again today to explain why the corporation had dismissed about 25 employes in its Chevrolet Division zone office for the New York area.

title: House Backs Revamping Of the Securities Industry
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The House of Representatives approved legislation today providing the most comprehensive revision of securities industry regulation in 40 years and laying the foundation for a national market system. The vote was 376 to 13.

title: Library of Congress: 75 Million Books Old
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Library at Congress, begun with just a few hundred books shipped from London, observed its 175th birthday today, its 320 miles of shelves groaning under the weight of 75 million books, photographs, musical scores, mars and microfilm.

title: Six Share Lead at 67
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 24 (AP)Six players, including Bob Shaw, the 1972 winner, shot fiveunderpar 67's today and shared the firstround lead in the $60,000 Tallahassee open.

title: About New York
description: Arthur C. Holden has a photograph in his office, taken when he was a child, of the view looking south from the house his family owned at 311 West 82d Street.

title: Anderson Says Carey Is Speeding Welfare Aid to Create Deficit
description: ALBANY, April 24Warren M. Anderson, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, today accused the Carey administration of deliberately speeding up stateaid payments to local welfare districts last month so the state could finish the fiscal year with a deficit instead of a surplus.

title: Harvester Bank Loan Set
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (Reuters) The International Harvester Company said today it had completed arrangements for a sevenyear term loan for $16[09]million with a group of United States banks for which the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York is the agent.

title: Agency Ruled Able To Curb Cigarettes That Are HighTar
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission had the authority to consider banning the interstate shipment of hightar cigarettes.

title: Four Embassies Close
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 25About 5,000 Vietnamese left Saigon for Guam yesterday aboard United States Air Force jet transports as the evacuation of Americans and Vietnamese continued.

title: Sugar Exporters Set Minimum Price Goal
description: PUERTO PLATA, Dominican Republic, April 24Sugar importing nations will be asked at a meeting with exporting countries next month to pay a minimum of 20 cents a pound for raw sugar in exchange for a promise from producers that prices will go no higher than 30 cents a pound.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON USE OF TROOPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24House and Senate conferees reached a tentative agreement today on legislation that would give President Ford limited authority to use armed forces to evacuate Americans and some South Vietnamese from Saigon.

title: Dow Stock Index Up 1.17, But Declines Exceed Gains
description: The stock market finished mixed yesterday in slower trading after a shaky start.

title: Harlem Troupe Opens Its 2d Season
description: The dance company that could never have happened keeps on happening. On Wednesday night at the Uris Theater, the Dance Theater of Harlem opened its second New York season. It is only seven years since its directors, Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook, began realizing their dream of a black classical ballet company. Now they have a rapidly developing ballet company with a growing international reputation.

title: Miss Hill Gains With Mrs. Oliver
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (AP)Cindy Hill, the National Amateur champion, defeated Connie Chillemi, 4 and 3, and Judy Oliver won a 19hole match when Nancy Roth Syms threeputted today in the semifinal round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: NURSE SHORTAGE FOUND FOR AGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The American nursing home industry has a critical shortage of nurses, which is a major factor in the low quality of care, according to a Senate report issued today.

title: A's Snap Tie in 7th And Top Royals, 32
description: The Oakland A's are back in their accustomed place in the American League's Western Division standingfirst. The defending world champions got there yesterday by scoring a 32 victory over the Kansas City Royals, the second straight triumph over the team that figured to give the A's a great deal of trouble this season.

title: Senate Votes to Protect the Mortgages of Unemployed Homeowners
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Senate voted today, 64 to 26, to protect the mortgages of jobless homeowners and to subsidize housing starts to build 400,000 new homes and create 800,000 jobs.

title: Warriors Win Game And Series
description: SEATTLE, April 24 (AP)Rick Barry snapped out of his slump and scored 31 points tonight to help the Golden State Warriors defeat the Seattle Supersonics, 10[09]96, and win the fourofseven game National Basketball Association playoff series, 4 games to 2.

title: Rumanian Pact Goes to Congress In Test of TradeEmigration Tie
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 President Ford submitted trade agreement with Rumania to Congress today that would provide an initial legislative test of the restrictions in the Trade Act linking trade benefits to freer emigration from Communist countries.

title: Unveilings
description: BROWNERFrances M. Dedication of mon??

title: TREASURY REJECTS PLEDGE ON CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Treasury has declined to pledge to a key member o! Congress to refrain entirely from borrowing in the longterm market in financing the impending huge budget deficits.

title: Beer Hall in Oregon Shelters Refugees
description: MOUNT ANGEL, Ore., April 24Numb from fatigue and a cold spring rain, lame children from Saigon and scores of other Vietnamese refugees settled today into their temporary Oregon shelter  a community beer hall  after traveling 10,000 miles in three days.

title: Colbert's 65 Sets Pace By 2 Shots
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., April 24With the big guns partly silenced, Jim Colbert shot a remarkable 65 a stroke off the course record today and led by two shots over Al Geiberger and four over young Tom Watson and veteran Gene (the Machine) Littler, thrice winner in this Tournament of Champions in the fifties.

title: Cambodian Leaders Celebrate Victory but Mourn War's Dead
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 24 (Reuters)The new Communist leaders of Cambodia today began three days of celebration of their capture of Phnom Penh and a week of mourning for those killed in five years of war.

title: Panel Urges Cancellation Of Dr. Jacobson's License
description: ALBANY, April 24A subcommittee of the State Board of Regents has recommended to the board that it revoke and cancel the medical license of Dr. Max Jacobson, the 75yearold general practitioner in New York City who for years used powerful amphetamine stimulants to lift the moods of rich Land famous patients.

title: For One, the Glitter Didn't Mean Gold
description: Harriett Fowler Waldron, age 68, is one of the less enthusiastic former Ziegfeld Girls. Known simply as Harriett when she was a $100aweek acrobatic dancer in the Ziegfeld Follies of 1923 and 1924, she went on to become a dancing sensation in Paris in the late nineteentwenties.

title: The Pop Life
description: The news that the New York Dolls had broken up came as a sad surprise. Actually, it wasn't so much of a surprise, I suppose. The Dolls owed a large part of their appeal to their image of reckless outrageousness: one got the impression, watching them perform, that they were just unstable enough to tip over the edge at any minute.

title: Spirits Turn Back Colonels
NEW CENTER TO AID THE MENTALLY ILL; Queens Building Is Designed ??or Rehabilitating Patients in Small Facilities
description: A rehabilitation center for mental patients, the first of its kind in the city, was opened here yesterday, with acclaim by the top mental health experts of the state and city and the enthusiastic backing of Governor Carey.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: $25 Award Settles Suit Over 2 Poodles' Virtues
description: HACKENSACK. April 25 (UP11  The owner of two pedigreed French poodles has accepted a $25 outofcourt settlement from the owner of two notsopedigreed dogs who made advances to the poodles.

title: ROYAL INNS FILES UNDER CHAPTER X
description: SAN DIEGO, April 25 (UPI)Royal Inns of America, Inc., has filed a bankruptcy petition in Federal court in a move aimed at protecting the nationwide corporation from creditors with claims estimated at $38million.

title: THIEU IS REPORTED ARRIVING IN TAIPEI
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, April 26 (AP)Former President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam and his wife were said to have arrived in Taipei early today.

title: Article 4  No Title
Volkswagen Posts $223Million Loss; No Dividend Slated
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, April 25 (Reuters)Wes, Germany's troubled Volks wagenwerk, A.G., reported to day a loss of nearly $223million for 1974, and said it did not intend to pay a dividend.

title: ARGUS OF CANADA FENDS OFF RIVAL
description: MONTREAL, April 25The Power Corporation of Canada Ltd., one, of this country's largest investment companies, conceded today that it had lost the first round in its battle to take over the Argus Corporation Ltd., its principal rival.

title: Butz Tells Hearing He Will Act To Support Income of Farmers
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz told a Congressional committee today that he would take administrative action to support farm income even though he continued to urge a Presidential veto of the farm bill sent to the White House this week.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A rehabilitation center for mental patients, the first of is kind in the city, opened with acclaim by top mental health officials in the city and state. They called it a model of cooperation among the city, state and voluntary agencies, and expressed hope that it would be the beginning of new era in handling mental patients who were discharged from institutions.

title: New Vice President in Egypt Playing a Key Role With Sadat
description: CAIRO, April 25A 47yearold air force general who became Egypt's Vice President only nine days ago is rapidly emerging as a major political figure.

title: NATOA Victim of Its Success
description: IZMIR, TurkeyAt the local headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here, officers wear a special patch that combines the flags of Greece and Turkey. Since 1952 these two countries have formed the bulwank of the alliance's southern flank, but today they are quarreling with their allies and each other, and even in an era of EastWest detente, NATO planners are deeply concerned.

title: Peter Paul to Restore Some of Candy Weight
description: The shrinkage of some now that cocoa, coconut and candy bars will be halted and their sizes increased by about 10 per cent.

title: Coffee Producers End Talks Without Reaching an Accord
description: LONDON, April 25A twoweek meeting of the International Coffee Organization ended here today without formation of a new International Coffee Agreement, to replace the one that technically expired in 1973.

title: Antiques: Roman Glass
description: Ray Winfield Smith's pursuit of some of the most fragile and exquisite glass ever blown in the ancient world has, for 45 years, charted courses from tombs to palaces, from exotic bazaars to the atomic research facilities of the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, from distant museums to his home in Dublin, N.H. ne cumulative results of this extraordinary odyssey of the 78yearold authority on ancient glass will be admired, argued and evaluated for years to come by scholars, historians, and collectors. For some that appreciation or debate begins today when 135 of the remaining pieces in Mr. Smith's collection go on view at Sotheby Parke Bernet prior to next Friday's auction.

title: 500 ARE LAID OFF AT U.S: STEEL PLANT
description: FAIRLESS, Pa., April 25 (UPI) About 500 employes at the United States Steel Corporation's Fairless Works were to be furloughed for seven days beginning tomorrow, the cornpany said today.

title: Attica Troopers Seek State Aid To Pay for Their Legal Counsel
description: ALBANY, April 25  Asserting that some people will not rest until a peace officer is indicted in the Attica prison insurrection, the State Police Benevolent Association today called on the state to provide legal funds for troopers.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF GRAMS UM
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, following the stocksonhand report issued by the Government after Thursday's close. It showed that inventories in farmers' hands, at grain elevators and at terminal markets were somewhat lower than expected.

title: More Money and Fast Action Asked for Crime Victims
description: Felipe Sanabria's wife was shot to death in 1973, and he gave up his two daughters because could not afford to take care of them, not aware that he was eligible to apply for compensation from the state's Crime Victims Compensation Board.

title: New Slogan in Hanoi: Everything for the South
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 25Everything for the South!: That is the new slogan in North Vietnam.

title: Government Witnesses in Peril Are Given New Lives
description: WASHINGTON, April 25That new family moving in down the street. Who are they?

title: Sony Ends Fair Trade
description: The Sony Corporation of America said yesterday it was discontinuing its fair trade program for consumer products in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Products affected are television sets, radios, compact stereo systems and highfidelity components.

title: Koch and Mrs. Abzug at Loggerheads
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Represenative Edward I. Koch has accused his colleague, Bella S. Abzug, of political sexism but she says it is he who is guilty of sexism. The exchange between the Manhattan Democra ts, long identified with the liberal wing of the party, stemmed from Mr. Koch's ardent espousal of Bess Myerson as the ideal candidate to win the Democratic nomination for United States Senator and to defeat Sena??or James L. Buckley, the ConservativeRepublican next year.

title: Pilgrim State Center Faces Loss of Its Accreditation
description: In a decision that could cut off from $16million to $23million a year in Federal money to the state, the Joint Commission on the Accreditation of Hospitals has moved to end its accreditation of Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in West Brentwood, L. I., a state mental hygiene official said yesterday.

title: Regents' Vote Unanimous
description: ALBANY, April 25The New York State Board of Regents revoked today the medical license of Dr. Max Jacobson for unprofessional conduct.

title: Bolding Sets Hurdle Mark In Relays
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 (UPI)Jim Bolding, a world recordholder, maintained his mastery over Ralph Mann today in the 440yard intermediate hurdles and turned in a recordsetting performance in the opening day of the 66th annual Drake Relays.

title: Import Cut Brings 1.3Billion Surplus In Quarterly Trade
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The United States rang up large surplus of exports over imports in the JanuaryMarch period, the first quarterly trade surplus in the last five quarters the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Canadians, Departing, Barred Pleading Vietnamese Staff Aides
description: OTTAWA, April 25  The Canadian Embassy in Saigon refused to take pleading Vietnamese employes on the plane that evacuated the embassy staff to Hong Kong Wednesday although two autos and crates of souvenir art work were put aboard.

title: Communists Mount Assault on a Town Northwest of Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 (Reuters)Some three battalions of Communist troops today attacked the town of Trang Bang, 30 miles from Saigon.

title: PROFIT IS REPORTED BY SHEARSON HAYDEN
description: Shearson Hayden Stone, inc., the brokerage house, reported yesterday that it had a profit for its third fiscal quarter ended March 31 of $1.9million, or 60 cents a share, in contract to a loss of $486,000 a year earlier. Revenues for the period advanced to $36.4million from $16.3million. For the nine months ended March 31, the company reported profits of $2.4million contrasted with a loss of $347,000 the prior year. Revenues rose to $87.2million from $51.3million.

title: SAIGON ASSEMBLY CONSIDERS GIVING MINH LEADERSHIP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 26President Tran Van Huong called on the National Assembly today to decide whether to make General Duong Van Minh president in his place to negotiate with the Communists.

title: Monsanto Is Expanding
description: The Monsanto Company announced plans yesterday for building a multimilliondollar, plant at Sauget, Ill., to produce, santicizer 160, a plasticizer that is used in making flooring products. The plant is expected to he in operation in the third quarter of 1977.

title: Landlord and Friend Held In Arson Attempt on House
description: A Bronx landlord was arrested yesterday and charged with trying to burn an occupied fivestory apartment house he owns at 1062 Faile Street.

title: BASQUE REGION PUT UNDER CRISIS RULE
description: MADRID, April 25 (AP)The Spanish Government declared a state of emergency today in the Basque provinces of Guipzcoa and Vizcaya in an effort to curb a wave of violence ascribed to the Basque guerrilla organization that seeks separation from Spain.

title: Imports Cut Brings $1.3Billion Surplus In Quarterly Trade
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The United States rang up large surplus of exports over imports in the JanuaryMarch period, the first quarterly trade surplus in the last five quarters the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WHEELING STEEL CITES HIGHER NET
description: The Wheeling  Pittsburgh Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its firstquarter net income had soared by 107.4 per cent over the 1974 period as sales rose by 16.2 per cent.

title: Girl, 13, Is Given 2 d Patent
description: WASHINGTON, April 25An inventor who is about to graduate from grade school was this week awarded her second patent. The document, issued to 13yearold

title: Karpov Still Wants Moral Satisfaction Despite Chess Title
description: MOSCOW, April 25Anatoly Karpov, the new world chess champion following Bobby Fischer's default earlier this month, asserted today that he still sought an unofficial match with Mr. Fischer but said that he had not yet been contacted directly by the United States grandmaster.

title: BROOKLYN LISTS FESTIVAL EVENTS
description: Indoors and outdoors, but mainly outdoors, Brooklyn's annual spring and summer cultural festival is about to blossom.

title: Lockheed and Creditors Reported Near Accord
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration and its creditors are reported close to agreement on restructuring the debt of the giant aerospace company to further the recent improvement of its still not robust financial health.

title: Judge Saves Hansen From Jail; Terms Representative Stupid
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  Terming Representative George Hansen stupid but not necessarily evil, United States Distric Judge George L. Hart Jr. set aside today his twomonth prison term and instead fined him $2,000 for violating campaign finance laws.

title: Market Place
description: Wall Streeters and investors alike have been somewhat baffled by the strength of the stock market in the context of the dismal prospects so apparent for many companies in the months ahead.

title: Peregrine Falcon Reintroduced To East in Ecology Experiment
description: The peregrine falcon, a 200mileanhour bird of prey, is being bred in captivity by Cornell University and reintroduced in several Eastern states from which it it had been eliminated by man and his poisons.

title: CAPT. S. H. BEATTIE, GEN. JOHN T. COLE, 78, LED ST. NAZAIRE RAID EQUESTRIANS' COACH
description: LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) Capt. Stephen Halden Beattie. British wartime hero, who won the Victoria Cross, the country's highest military decoration, for his part in the raid on the Frenchoccupied harbor of St. Nazaire, died yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times on April 21 on raising gloxinias, a typographical error changed the meaning of one instruction. The plant should not be cut back to the ground until after the buds stop forming.

title: U.S. IS CONCERNED OVER TIES IN ASIA
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Ford Administration, concerned about the possible impact of the Indochina situation on other Asian countries, hopes to bolster relations with Japan, South Korea, the Philippines and other Asian nations in coming weeks and months.

title: Mercy Hospital on L.I. to Work With Harvard Medical School
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 25The Harvard University Medical School and Mercy Hospital today announced the establishment of an affiliation to provide continuing education for physicians in the metropolitan areathe school's first such affiliation outside Massachusetts.

title: Avoid Cliches Like the Plague
description: THE DICTIONARY OF DO'S AND DONT'S. A Guide for Writers and Speakers. By Harry G. Nickles. 211 Pages. McGrawHill, $7.95.

title: Col. R. Ernest Dupuy, 88, Dead; Publicist and Military Historian
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Col. R. Ernest Dupuy, U.S.A., retired, soldier, newspaperman and military historian, died today at Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: State Officials Scored
description: Officials of national and New York medical societies said yesterday that the Board of Regents' revocation of Dr. Max Jacobson's medical license vividly illustrated the need for doctors to police themselves more effectively and for the profession to have broader disciplinary Powers.

title: BUCKLEY PREDICTS RETURN TO SENATE
description: COLONIE, N.Y., April 25 Senator James L. Buckley predicted today that he would get the Republican and Conservative party nominations next year without a primary and said that lie would love to run against Representative Bella S. Abzug.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 26, 1975

title: HIJACKING EFFORT FAILS IN ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, April 25A man carrying a bag that he said contained explosives attempted unsuccessfully tonight to hijack a Newarkbound United Airlines jet and divert it to Cuba.

title: CANCER UNIT GIVES CHEMICAL ALERT
description: A chemical widely used In the metal and clothing industries has been found in preliminary tests to cause cancers of the liver and other organs in mice, according to an internal Government memorandum of alert issued by the National Cancer Institute.

title: Five Seoul Newsmen Reported Held
description: SEOUL. South Korea, April 25 (Reuters)  South Korean journalists said today that five of their leaders were being held by the country's Central Intelligence Agency in a bid to crush their drive for a free press.

title: Jacques Duclos of France Dies; Communist Ran for Presidency
description: PARIS, April 25Jacques Duclos, a leading Communist party politician in France and a candidate against Georges Pompidou for the Presidency, in 1969, died here today. He was 78 years old.

title: SENATORS, 53 TO 14, VOTE $6.1BILLION FOR PUBLIC JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Senate passed today a $6.1billion appropriations bill aimed at either creating or continuing a million public service jobs both to stimulate the economy and to keep workers off unemployment insurance and welfare.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Saturday, April 26, 1975

title: In Memoriam
description: DEUTCHCatherine Nancy. Together foreverlittle one.

title: The Days They Used to Make
description: Have a nice day has replaced This Is a stickup as the most frequently spoken fourword sentence in the American language.

title: Henry St. Stage and Papp To Develop Plays Jointly
description: In an effort to spur black, Puerto Rican and other minority participation in the theater, Joseph Papp, director of the New York Shakespeare Festival, and Bertram Beck, executive director of the Henry Street Settlement, have agreed to develop plays that will be presented first at Henry Street and then at Lincoln Center or at the Public Theater, downtown.

title: WILTSHIRE C. CLAYTON
description: Wiltshire C. Clayton, a dentist here more than 50 years before his retirement in 1964, died Wednesday at his home in Madison, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: Alexander's Seeks Klein Unit
description: Alexander's, Inc., one of New York City's largest retail chains, is negotiating to acquire the Flushing, Queens, store site of S. Klein Department Stores. The effort is part of a plan by Alexander's eventually to expand its chain here and in the metropolitan area.

title: Enemies Number 1 & 2
description: The latest report on consumer prices demonstrates that unemployment has moved far out in front of inflation as the nation's most immediate problem.

title: Bronx Judge Says Brain Death Is the Legal End of Human Life
description: Brain death is the legal end of human life, Acting Justice Mary Johnson Lowe ruled yesterday in Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Beame and the Board
