description: The statements were public, but they aggravated the hidden agenda. An accidental assertion provoked a request for information. Municipal protocols were bypassed and political toes were stepped on. Of such factors are confrontations made, and this week's clash between Mayor Beame and the Board of Education was no exception. The Mayor had said on Tuesday that a $5.1million component of his budgetary trims for the next fiscal year would be the closing of 43 small, antiquated and underused schools.

title: and at City Hall
description: The pinch in Albany is bound to be felt at City Hall where Mayor Beanie has only begun to wrestle with deficit that remainsaccording to the Mayor's own figuresat a staggering $641.5 million after weeks pruning and manipulation.

title: State Advised to Overhaul Plans for Water Supplies
description: TRENTON, April 25  A sweeping overhaul of the management of New Jersey's limited water supply, including revised system of fees, was recommended today by the state's County and Municipal Government Study Commission and the Department of Environmental Protecion.

title: Church Assumes a Mission For Older Single Members
description: The 25 welldressed men and women arrived at Calvary Baptist Church at 123 West 57th Street, found their way to a cozy sideroom, and mingled quietly for a while. Then the Rev. Edwin Mitchell opened the proceedings.

title: Bernstein Discloses Decision to Return To the Philharmonic
description: Leonard Bernstein turned to the aduience after Thursday night's concert with the New York Philharmonic and said: I've just made a decision. I don't know how, I don't know when, but I'm going to come back to this orchestra.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus Is Barnstorming Here
description: It is 9 A.M. The lobby of the Navarro Hotel on Central Park South is quiet. A sense of calm and rectitude prevails. Abruptly a young man enters wearing the cap and overalls of a railroad man. To his chest is pinned half a plastic heart It's my heart, he explains pleasantly. It's broken.

title: Vietnam Airlift Goes On
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The United States Government continued its huge airlift today, aiming at the evacuation of more than 130,000 Americans and South Vietnamese from Saigon and confident of its technical abilities despite funding and logistical problems.

title: Trading Down in Albany
description: Consumers all over the country are reported to be coping with the impact of inflation and recession by trading down, settling for less expensive no frill itemsa compact instead of a Cadillac, nonbrandname appliances, meat substitutes and cheaper or patchedup clothing. In the process, many are discovering that the family budget had accumulated unnecessary layers fat.

title: At Hanover Fair, Mood Is Restrained
description: HANOVER, West Germany The annual Hanover industrial fair, said to be a barometer of the West German economy, got underway with the needle pointing to becalmed.

title: U.S. ASTRONAUTS RELYING ON SOVIET
description: ZVEZDNY GORODOK, U.S.S.R., April 25American astronauts said today that they werenot apprehensive about accidents that might occur in their joint space mission next July with Soviet astronauts.

title: DOW CLIMBS 8.14 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Encouraging economic and international news helped the stock market end higher yesterday in heavier trading.

title: Concert: Asian Talent
description: About 10 years ago it began to be plain that the shortage of firstclass string players, much noted and bemoaned, was about to be taken care of by a surge of extraordinary players out of Asia. At Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, one could look at the stage and see that promise realized. If you have hen lying awake nights worrying about the decline of the fiddle, forget it.

title: WOR to Honor Magazine with Readinas and Profiles
description: In honor of The New Yorker's 50th anniversary this year radio station WORAM will present a series of five special programs from May 12 to 16 with reminiscences of the magazine's contributors and readines of selections.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A high Transit Authority official said that the probable cause of the fire that halted service on four IRT lines Brooklyn on Thursday evening was a short circuit that set fire to discarded newspapers lying along the tracks. John Mombach, assistant general superintendent for power, told a panel of three authority board members that the blaze spread to a small splicing chamber housing cables under Rogers Avenue and Eastern Parkway. At least 15 persons were reportedly overcome by the dense smoke generated by the twoalarm fire.

title: 13 Suspected Guerrillas Freed by British in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 25 (AP)The British Government today released 13 suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas from detention in response to a guerrilla ceasefire.

title: Celtics Awesome, Conclude Rockets
description: Rudy Tomjanovich, the bruising, highscoring Houston Rockets' forward, offered perhaps the best explanation of how the Boston Celtics reached the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference final round, in which they will play the Washington Bullets.

title: Legal Services Delay
description: On July 25, 1974, President Nixon signed a bill creating the Legal Services Corporation which he had proposed three years earlier as a means of taking the poverty law program out of politics. As of this morning, a full nine months later, the Administration has not yet appointed the board required to bring the corporation to life.

title: STATE TO ALLOCATE MORE HEATING OIL
description: TRENTON, April 25 (AP)About 800,000 gallons of home heating oil will be distributed basis month on an emergency basis to meet increased demands caused by recent cold weather, an official of the State Energy Office said.

title: Byrne Beset by Mounting Woes
description: TRENTON, April 25It was just last week that Governor Byrne told his top administration aides that everything looked bad, but that things could get a lot worse. This week they did. At one end of the State House, the Democratic Governor was embarrassed by Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, who marched right back to work after he was cleared of charges that he had taken part in a highwayconstruction bidrigging conspiracy.

title: SAIGON IS MOVING TO SATISFY REDS ON A NEW REGIME
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 26President Tran Van Huong called on the National Assembly today to decide whether to make General Duong Van Minh President in his place to negotiate with the Communists.

title: Books of The Times
description: Every so often, important books come into print so quietly that they are not so much published as they are materialized. Then they lie around waiting to be discovered, which they sometimes are, if not by the public, then perhaps by academics or polemicists. Sex and Power in History is that kind of book. Itdeals with nothing less than the question of who is man and who is woman, or, what is male and what is female? This is SEX AND POWER IN HISTORY. By Amaury de Riencourt. 469 pages. McKay. $12.95. great question, touching on the mystery of life and the mechanics of civilization, and Mr. de Riencourt, a distinguished French historian, who has written books about Tibet, China, India and America, tries to answer it with a staggering amount of learning.

title: BURGLARY SUSPECT LINKED TO 85 THEFTS
description: An unemployed sign installer was arrested on burglary charges yesterday, and the police said later they believed he was the thief who had robbed at least 85 apartments since late last year along or off Ocean Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Jean Walling Dead of Cancer; East Brunswick Mayor Was 53
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 25 (AP)Mayor Jean Sears Walling died today after a battle with cancer that began several months ago. She was 153 years old.

title: Moderates Lead in Portuguese Vote
description: LISBON, Saturday, Apirl 26Moderate political forces took commanding lead over the Communist party yesterday and early today in returns from the election for a national constituent assembly.

title: DONALD SWAELENS
description: BRUSSELS, April 25 (AP)Donald Swaelens, a leading European golfer and five times winner of the Belgian Professional Golfers Association closed championship, died today after an operation for an undisclosed ailment. He was 39 years old.

title: Mrs. Hardwicke, Howard Oxenberg Wed
description: The marriage of Anne Hardwicke, a former fabric designer, to Howard Oxenberg, a former clothing manufacturer, took place in Mr. and Mrs. Keith Barish's Justice Manuel A. Gomez performed the ceremony in the apartment here yesterday afternoon. State Supreme Court presence of 200 guests.

title: Rights Amendment Rejected By Florida Senate 2d Time
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 25 (AP)The Florida Senate, ignoring appeals from the wife of the President, rejected today the proposed Equal Rights Amendment for the second year in a row, killing the issue for the 1475 session.

title: Lagging French Industry To Get Investment Spurs
description: PARIS, April 25For the first time in recent history a French government has moved to stimulate productive investment during an economic slump. The reaction was that it had still not done enough.

title: DR. ROBERT BLOCH, LUNG EXPERT, DIES
description: Dr. Robert G. Bloch, former chief of the pulmonarydisease division at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center, the Bronx, died there Thursday. He was 81 years old and lived in Yorktown Heights, N. Y., and GarmishPartenkirchen in his native Germany.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times on April 21 on raising gloxinias, a typographical error changed the meaning of one instruction. The plant should not he cut back to the ground until after the buds stop forming.

title: Mets Get 3 Singles, Win, 53
description: MONTREAL, April 25The New York Mets gained their fifth straight victory by beating the Expos, 53, today, but they did it with so feeble batting display that Manager Gene Mauch of Montreal found himself wondering about the futility of it all.

title: Relay Mark Broken by Villanova
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 It is one thing to sit around and ponder worldbest performances, the way Eamonn Goghlan, Ken Schappert and Tom Gregan did after an advanced public speaking class last night.

title: Canada to Recognize Regime
description: OTTAWA, April 25Canada will recognize the new Cambodian government as the legal one, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's office announced today.

title: $62Million Claim Filed in Fire That 10 Are Accused of Setting
description: A $62.6million insurance claim was filed yesterday by the Sponge Rubber Products Company for losses incurred in the firebombing of one of its plants in Shelton, Conn., on March 1, according to an insurance expert close to the proceeding.

title: HALD0EMAN REFUSAL TO TESTIFY REVEALED
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 25 (AP)H R. Haldeman, former White House aide, invoked the Fifth Amendment in refusing to answer all questions except ones on his name, age and employment when he gave deposition last year in a $1.2million damage suit.

title: Car Layoffs to Fall to 179,370, Lowest Since Week of Dec. 9
description: DETROIT, April 25Auto industry layoffs will drop to 179,370 next week, the lowest total since the week of Dec. 9, when 170.000 United States auto workers were off the job.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama confirmed yesterday that as of now he intends to seek the 1976 Democratic nomination for President.

title: Dollar Advances On Markets Abroad As Trade Data Gain
description: BRUSSELS, April 25 (UPI)The dollar got a lift today on all European money exchanges from surprisingly good United States trade figures for March.

title: COAST CHESS CONTEST IS WON BY AN ISRAELI
description: LONE PINE, Calif., April 25 (AP)  Vladimir Liberzon, leading Soviet grandmaster who emigrated to Israel last year, played strong, steady chess through 10 rounds to amass 7 points and win the first prize in the Louis D. Statham International Chess Tournament here.

title: Senate Confirms Morton As Commerce Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)The Senate confirmed the nomination of Rogers. B. Morton as Secretary of Commerce today. Mr. Morton, approved by voice vote and without dissent, succeeds Frederick B. Dent.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: Week ended April 25, 1975

title: Elizabeth Pie plow, Paul Wollstadt Wed
description: Elizabeth Peters Pieplow of Silver Spring, Md., was married, there yesterday evening in the Northwood Presbyterian Church to Paul Wollstadt, a vice president of the American Petroleum Institute in Washington. The Rev. Robert C. Angus performed the ceremony.

title: Journalist Is Honored
description: The American Association of Petroleum Geologists has presented its journalism award to William D. Smith of The New York Times for outstanding work in explaining the science of geology. The scientific association, whose 17,000 members make it the world's largest association of earth scientists, is made up of geologists and geophysicists from, universities, consulting concerns and business.

title: Johnson in '69 Suspected Foreign Ties With Oswald
description: Former president Lyndon B. Johnson indicated in an interview in 1969 that he felt international connections might have been involved in Lee Harvey Oswald's assassination of President Kennedy.

title: John Finklea Will Direct Occupational Safety Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Dr. John F. Finklea was appointed director of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health today by Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. He replaces Dr. Marcus Key, who resigned last August.

title: Makarios to Meet Kissinger
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus. April 25 (Reuters)President Makarios will meet Secretary of State Kissinger in Washington on May 5, it was announced today.

title: Israelis Dubious of SyrianJordanian Accord
description: TEL AVIV, April 25An Israeli official who closely watches developments in the Arab world said today that he was surprised by a Paris dispatch in The New York Times today reporting that the Soviet Union had promoted an agreement between Syria and Jordan for joint land and air military commands.

title: SANFORD BERGHOFFEN
description: Sanford Berghoffen, manager of traffic operations for the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network, died yesterday in Riverdell Hospital, Oradell, N.J. He was 42 years old and lived in Harrington Park, N.J.

title: NBC Gun Program, Never Shown, Attracts Letters
description: We can give you our opinion of your Sunday, March 2nd, special, Shooting Gallery Called America, in two short words: It Stunk!!! We found it nothing more than rehash of the same tired old theme: blame the instrument, not the criminal.

title: Art: The Mobiles Of George Rickey
description: In the history of constructwist scupture, the mobilea construction engineered in such a way that its separate parts are set in motion by natural air currents to form a pattern of kinetic imagery has long been identified with a single figure: Alexander Calder. To venture into Mr. Calder's preserve has apparently required a courage and a confidence that few artists have been able to muster, but at least one sculptorGeorge Rickeyhas faced this daunting task with remarkable equanimity. The result is a body of work that boasts a distinctand distinctly appealingesthetic profile of its own.

title: Shah and His Wife Planning State Visit In U.S. Next Month
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 25The Shah of Iran and his wife, Empress Farah, will begin state visit to the United States on May 15, the Minister of the Imperial Court announced here today.

title: Screen: 'Peter Proud'
description: "The Reincarnation of Peter Proud," which emerged on the screens of the Cinerama, 59th and 86th Street Twin Theaters yesterday, illustrates, perhaps more than anything else, that ghosts???even modern ones???needn't be convincing. Despite a sincere, polished treatment, this delving into the dark, sex-ridden??? tragic previous life of Peter Proud generates clouds of suspense but no solid solution to the riddle of reincarnation."Suppose you Knew who you had been in your previous life . . . what then?" the film's blurb enticingly asks. The answer, now that the results are in??? would be to let bygones be bygones.J. Lee Thompson, who directed in a properly moody style, and Max Ehrlich, who wrote the script from his novel, adhere to the trappings of current parapsychology, dream research and the like to give their mystery ??? scientific patina. But it isn't science as much as a persistent nightmare that drives Peter Proud, a young college professor, to seek surcease from his bad dream.The trip takes him from his California campus to an upper-class suburban Massachusetts town of his nocturnal??? frightening visions, where he discovers that??? in the nineteen-forties??? he had been Jeff Curtis, World War??? If hero, the father of an infant daughter, and who was murdered by his anguished wife for his callou???s indiscretions.It should be noted that Peter Proud is plagued enough to fall in love and have an affair with a now grown, beautiful daughter of the late, unlamented Jeff Curtis???a sort of incest, once removed???and to pursue his investigation to a macabre and fatal ending.Michael Sarrazin is fairly sensitive and generally subdued as Peter Proud, a name, he admits lightly, that sounds like a nursery jingle. Margot Kidder does well by the unlikely roles of the young wife and the anxiety-filled hard-drinking mother whose murderous secret is finally exposed. And Jennifer O'Neill, as the surviving daughter, and Cornelia Sharpe, as Mr. Sarrazin's college pal, are genuinely confused by the mystery that distracts their lover.Peter Proud, in short, utters a logical mouthful about this "reincarnation" when he tells the worried Miss O'Neill. "If I tried to explain, you'd think I was insane."

title: Nix Pix of Stix as Hix
description: GEORGETOWN, Conn.  Much of American history comes down to the people's erratic pursuit of equity in the face of obdurate privilege. During the nineteenthirties that pursuit was expressed largely in terms of class; in the nineteensixties, in terms of race. Now the time seems right to speak also of place, and of those Americans who by virtue of where they live are deprived of full participation in our political and economic system. sixty million Americans live in small towns and rural areasoutside what the Census Bureau calls Standard Metropolitan Statistical Areas. By and large, our national policy visvis these rural citizens has been one of ferocious eglect. Their voice has been drowned in the urban hubbub; their needs have been continually overlooked.

title: PENNZOIL NET OFF 12.8% IN QUARTER
Ford Asks Action to Insure Prison for Violent Crimes
description: NEW HAVEN, April 25Dedaring that violent crime obsesses America, President Ford tonight called for mandatory jail terms for those convicted of violent crimes.

title: Belts Are Tightened at the Harvard Club
description: The Harvard Club's eighttoone martini, a concoction that has befuddled some of the finest minds in the country, has apparently been shrunk.

title: Islanders Feel Capable Of Defeating Penguins
description: The green slate board in the Islanders' dressing room bore a chalked message for the team after Thursday night's 41 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins  The magic number is one.

title: Guam Finding Ways To House Refugees
description: ACIANA, Guam, Saturday, April 26In aircraft hangars, in churches, under stairways, in barracks and tents, on cots under the tropical sky and in former hospital annexes that once held wounded United States marines, thousands of refugees from South Vietnam are spending their first nights away from home.

title: Man Dies in Fall From Bridge
description: A lone driver of a pickup truck yesterday morning stopped the truck on the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge and then jumped to his death.

title: GURNEY TRIAL TOLD OF A SECRET DRIVE
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 25The Government's main witness in the extortion trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida'testified today that he was hired by Mr. Gurney as a special'aide in January, 1971, and almost immediately was given an assignment to raise reelection funds in secret and in cash.

title: Cambodians Designate Sihanouk as Chief for Life
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 25 (UPI)The new Cambodian Government announced today that Prince Norodom Sihanouk would be Cambodia's chief of state for life. It also said that all Cambodian diplomats serving abroad would be dismissed and replaced.

title: WOR to Honor Magazine With Readings and Profiles
description: In honor of The New Yorker's 150th anniversary this year, radio station WORAM will present a series of five special programs from May 12 to 16 with reminiscences of the magazine's contributors and readings of selections.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ON THE TOWN This weekend local activities are definitely on the upsurge, with a paradepierand sloop program shifting down the Hudson from Harlem to the South Street Seaport; a whalewatching event at the New York Aquarium; walking tours of the Murray Hill area and an inspection of landmarks and homes in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn.

title: To All Nations: Don't Have a Pack Mentality. Keep Antarctica Pure.
description: PRINCETON, N. J.It is not too early to speak up on behalf of a continent that has a reputation for being fiercely hostile to life and yet which, when the weather is quiet, impresses one with its gentleness, peacefulness, even innocencea place remote from other great land masses, different because it is so extreme, the sole continent that never harbored man, that can be thought of as being otherwordly and therefore possibly expendable.

title: Ana Maria Serralta Bride of Glen Howard
description: Ana Maria Serralta, a stewardess with Pan American World Airways, and Glen Howard, executive producer of college and consumer media for Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc., were married yesterday afternoon in the Church Center for the United Nations. Chaplain Melvin Hawthorne, the minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Bullets Win 7th Game, Routing Braves, 11596
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 25 Stung by suggestions in local newspapers that the team has a tendency to choke in the National Basketball Association playoffs, the Washington Bullets demolished the Buffalo Braves, 11596, tonight before a capacity crowd of 19,035 at Capital Centre.

title: Tiant of Red Sox Loses TwoHitter to Lolich, 1 to 0
description: Luis Tiant, picked up as free agent in 1971 by Boston, lost a bid for a perfect game in Tiger Stadium last night, and also lost the game, 10, to Detroit despite a twohit effort.

title: E. R. N. DOUGLASS
description: Edward R. N. Douglass, president of Regional Public Relations, Inc., of Newark, died Thursday of cancer at his home in Lebanon, N.J. He was 60 years old.

title: James T. Bryan Dies at 84; Retired Stockbroker Here
description: James T. Bryan, a retired stockbroker, died yesterday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L. I. He was 84 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Suffolk Makes OTB Debut; Resident Reaction Is Mixed
description: EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 25Danny Simmons was one person who couldn't place bets with the Suffolk Offtrack Betting Corporation when it opened its first parlor today because he was far behind in his workpainting the spacious premises.

title: Aaron Hitting .114; His Last Season?
description: Some aging baseball players, failing to see that their talents are behind them, cling to the hope of rejuvenationone more year here, one more year there. Maybe even a year or two in the minor leagues. Not Henry Aaron.

title: Article 3  No Title
G.I.'s, Long Deserters, Appear for Evacuation
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)An unspecified number of American military deserters, hidden in Saigon for years, have turned up to get on the evacuation planes, State Department officials said today.

title: Aetna Life Reports 41.7% Drop in Net For First Quarter
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company reported yesterday a drop of 41.7 per cent in firstquarter net income, while operating earnings fell 70 per cent from a year ago.

title: ExRep. Chester Gorski, 68, Buffalo Council President
description: BUFFALO, April 25 (AP)Chester C. Gorski, a former Democratic Representative in Congress and president of the Buffalo Common Council from 1960 to 1974, when he retired for reasons of health, died today. He was 68 years old.

title: Dance: Bolshoi's Giselle
description: It is now nearly 20 years since Leonid Lavrovsky's celebrated Bolshoi production of Gisellewith the equally celebrated Galina Ulanova in the title roleburst upon the Western world. On Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House it reappeared, with Madame Ulanova herself, now a coach and teacher with the company, sitting sedately in the audience.

title: Ford Asks Action to Insure Prison for Violent Crimes
description: NEW HAVEN, April 25Dedaring that violent crime obsesses America, President Ford tonight called for mandatory jail terms for those convicted of violent crimes.

title: Article 1  No Title
StateHeld North Dakota Bank Is Under Study as a Model Here
description: The Bank of North Dakota the only stateowned bank in the country, was pointed out yesterday as an example for New York to follow if it wished to create a publiclending institution as an alternative to the private banking establishment.

title: Weapons Seized in Office Of a Zionist Youth Group
description: Five rifles, two rifle barrels and 1,600 rounds of ammunition were seized yesterday afternoon in a police raid on the Manhattan headquarters of Betar, a militant Zionist youth organization, at 55 West 42d Street, the police reported.

title: CASH NEED CITED BY PENNSY LINE
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad said today if the Federal Government failed to provide more operating cash the railroad would have to cut service soon and furlough some 3,500 employes to stay in business into 1976.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)An agreement lifting many restrictions by the Bell System for its competitors interconnect with the system was accepted today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: People in Sports
description: Five and a half weeks after surgery for the removal or a small bursal sac from his back. Tug McGraw, the relief specialist, was restered to the active 1st by the Philadelpia Phillies, The 30yearold lefthanded pitcher who was obtained from the New York Alas in a sixplayer trade last. January has been throwing well for the last two weeks. However, he has not pitched a ball in league play for the Phillies far.

title: 2 AUTO EXECUTIVES ASSAIL DISMISSALS
description: DETROIT, April 25 (AP)Two former supervisors' in the General Motors Chevrolet Division accused the auto company today of dismissing them for conduct that had been permitted in the past.

title: AllAmerica Cities Awards To 12 Cities Are Announced
description: Twelve cities have received AllAmerica Cities Awards from the National Municipal League. A listing of them in The New York Times of April 14 contained several errors.

title: Schmidt Is Adamant
description: BONN, April 25Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, speaking of his Government's refusal to yield to the demands of the terrorists in Stockholm, said in Parliament today that future challenges will be met with the same firmness.

title: Newark Policeman Indicted in Killing During 1974 Hispanic Disturbances
description: NEWARK, April 25A member of the Newark Police Department's mounted patrol squad was charged with murder today in the death last September of a 36yearold man during disturbances in the downtown district.

title: Brown U. Students Win Concessions, End Their SitIn
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 25  Black and LatinAmerican students evacuated the main administration building at Brown University this evening after negotiating a compromise with the administration on their demands for more recruiting of minority applicants, higher minority enrollments and funding of minoritysupport services.

title: Belts Tightened at Harvard Club
description: The Harvard Cluh's eighttoone martini, a concoction that has befuddled some of the finest minds in the country, has apparently been shrunk.

title: Livingston College Opens Inquiry on Cafeteria Melee
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 25 The Rutgers University campus police are investigating an incident that occurred last night during which 50 students stormed the Livingston College cafeteria and pushed aside dean, two university policemen and three dininghall supervisors.

title: Regents' Vote Unanimous
description: ALBANY, April 25The New York State Board of Regents revoked today the medical license of Dr. Max Jacobson for unprofessional conduct.

title: W. NORMANBROWN, INDIA EXPERT, DIES
description: Dr. W. Norman Brown, an author and a leading scholar on India, died Tuesday at Friends Hall in West Chester, Pa. He was 82 years old and had lived in Moylan, Pa.

title: Orioles Off, Play 2 Today
description: BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)  The Baltimore Orioles' scheduled opener of a threegame series with the Cleveland Indians was rained out tonight. The game was rescheduled as part of a doubleheader tomorrow.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A subsection of North Bergen's rentleveling law that froze rents for the elderly last January has been declared unconstitutional and discriminatory.

title: Soviet Court Denies Appeal By 2 Jews Sent Into Exile
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (AP)The Russian Republic's Supreme Court today denied appeals of two Jews who were sentenced to five years in exile for having taken part in public demonstration, according to friends of the two, Mark Nashpits and Boris Tsetleyonok.

title: Prime Rate Unchanged
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it was keeping unchanged at 7 per cent the lowest interest rate it charges on loans to corporations. This prime rate, reconsidered every Friday morning, has now been in effect since March 31.

title: Senate Votes, 46 to 17, to Give Ford Authority to Use Troops in Vietnam Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Senate, by a vote of 46 to 17, gave its final approval today to legislation that would let President Ford use combat troops to evacuate Americans and, in limited circumstances, South Vietnameses from Saigon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EDUCATION BOARD AND MAYOR AGREE
description: The Board of Education assured Mayor Beame yesterday that it would live within his budgetary constraints and the Mayor said the board would decide which schools should be closed to meet the cutbacks.

title: Sawhill at N.Y.U.
description: When he assumes the presidency of New York University next September, John C. Sawhill will be expected do more than guide the fortunes of a single institution higher learning. The actions and policies of the, former Federal Energy Administrator will be closely watched indicators of the capacity of large privately endowed urban universities to survive and flourish. In plain words, Mr. Sawhill will be expected to find new ways of assuring N.Y.U.'s stability under conditions of competitive coexistence with the giant public universities of the city and the state.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The show is called a Potter's Garden for a reason: the Greenwich House Pottery sale, representing works by professional craftsmen associated with the artisans' school, will offer ceramic creations for the outdoors (hanging planters, vases, garden sculptures and other ornaments), as well as tableware that can be used al fresco.

title: Massachusetts U. Records Brought to Jury by the F.B.I.
description: BOSTON, April 25 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation today took records of the University of Massachusetts School of Education before a Federal grand jury.

title: Sweden to Deport 4 German Terrorists
description: STOCKHOLM, April 25 (Reuters)Sweden announced to night that she would deport four of the five West German terrorists captured after yesterday's siege at the West German Embassy here, in which part of the building was blown up.

title: City Closes Massage Parlor as Unfit
description: A new tactic was initiated yesterday in the continuing effort to close down midtown Massage parlors and places of prostitution as the Health Department ordered Caesar's Hamil, an Eighth Avenue massage parlor, to close within 48 hours ecause it was unfit for human habitation.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
State Officials Scored
description: Officials of national and New York medical societies said yesterday that the Board of Regents' revocation of Dr. Max Jacobson's medical license vividly illustrated the need for doctors to police themselves more effectively and for the profession to have broader disciplinary powers.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices advanced in slightly increased trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as those in the overthecounter market also increased.

title: Bridge:
description: The first day's play Thursday in the Long Island regional championships at Belmont Park Race Track, Elmont, L.I., was less like a horse race than a caucus race. This, as every reader of Lewis Carroll knows, is a curious event in which everyone rushes madly round in a circle, nobody gets anywhere, and everyone wins a prize.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: AT WEIGHIN FOR EXHIBITION: George Foreman, the heavyweight boxer, in Toronto with his opponents. From left: Jerry Judge, 195 pounds; Boone Kirkman, 208;

title: Final Drive Under Way To Keep Picatinny Open
description: TRENTON, April 25With the future of Picatinny Arsenal very much in doubt, the Byrne administration and the New Jersey Congressional delegation are engaged in a final effort to prevent the closing of the Morris County munitions facility.

title: MATT DENNIS SINGS IN EASY GOING MOOD
description: Matt Dennis's basic claim to fame is that he wrote a number of songs that became hits when Frank Sinatra sang them with Tommy Dorsey's orchestra in the early nineteenfortiesEverything Happens to Me, Violets for Her Furs and Let's Get Away From It All, among others. Mr. Dennis is still primarily a song writer, but he also is, and always has been, a singer and pianist with an easygoing voice and manner that are exceptionally well suited to his songs.

title: THOMAS J. McCARTHY
description: Thomas J. McCartily, a retired registered representative for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., member of the New York and other stock exchanges, died Thursday in Passaic (N. J.) General Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Passaic. Mr. McCarthy had been with Merrill Lynch for 26 years at his retirement in 1973.

title: SENATORS, 53 TO 44, VOTE $6.1BILLION FOR PUBLIC JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Senate passed today a $6.1billion appropriations bill aimed at either creating or continuing a million public service jobs both to stimulate the economy and to keep workers off unemployment insurance and welfare.

title: Left Behind by the Colonels
description: ATHENSGetting the army out of politics has been and still is perhaps the most difficult internal problem faced by Greece. For seven years the dictatorship of a military junta coddled officers and tried to mold them into new class entitled to special privileges. Now, under the democracy restored last July but still awaiting a permanent constitution, this favored position has ended.

title: 15 Are Killed in a Bank Robbery And Police Chase in Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, April 25 (AP) Bandits shot their way into hank with submachine guns today and escaped with $12,000, authorities said. At least 15 persons, including 10 policemen, were reported killed in the robbery and the chase that followed.

title: OKLAHOMA'S HALL GETS PRISON TERM
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 25 (UPI)Former Gov. David Hall was sentenced today to three years in prison on each of four counts in an interstate conspiracybribery scheme. The terms are to run concurrently.

title: Manila Moves to Change Defense Pacts
description: MANILA, April 25The Philippine Government has formally notified the United States that it wants to discuss changes in the longstanding security agreements between the two countries, especially those authorizing the existence of American bases here.

title: People and Business
description: Productivitythe concept itself as well as its pursuithas received another strong plug in Washington from John T. Dunlop, Secretary of Labor. Yesterday he called upon Congress to fund a productivity center in the United States.

title: Article 2  No Title
MOODY'S REVIVES RATING ON CON ED
description: Moody's Investors Service, Inc., announced yesterday that it has restored its Baa rating to the publicly held bonds of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.

title: Church Assumes a Mission For Older Single Members
description: The 25 welldressed men and women arrived at Calvary Baptist Church at 123 West 57th Street, found their way to a cozy sideroom, and mingled quietly for a while. Then the Rev. Edwin Mitchell opened the proceedings.

title: Speeding Evacuation
description: Whatever the reason, the city of Saigon has not yet been attacked by the North Vietnamese force to which it is so tragically exposed. The United States has been beneficiary of this fortunate delay, succeeding in the safe evacuation of many thousands of American citizens whose presence has constituted one of the most explosive elements in a tense situation.

title: Ford Asks for More Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Ford today hailed the $30.2billion general revenuesharing program as a resounding success and asked Congress to extend it through September, 1952.

title: ConnorsNewcombe Match: Showdown Within a Show
description: LAS VEGAS. Nev., April 25Because John Newcombe and Jimmy Connors are two of the best tennis players ever, their special match here tomorrow shapes up as a major world sports event, apart from the huge sum of money involved and despite the artificiality of the circumstances.

title: Miss Evert, Navratilova in Final
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., April 25 (Reuters)Topseeded Chris Evert and secondseeded Martina Navratilova of Czechoslovakia advanced today to the final of the $150,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup tennis tournament.

title: Diverse Balkan Mood Persists In Rumania's City of Timisoara
description: TIMISOARA, Rumania, April 20No city could he more Balkan than Timisoara, if the term is taken to mean a population of diverse nationalities and religions, a history of changing ruleand the general air of a polyglot border market even though the nearest border is about 25 miles away.

title: U.S.Backed Mortgage Rate Up to 8%
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today that maximum allowable interest rates for Governmentinsured mortgages would be raised to 8 per cent effective Monday, ending a threemonth downtrend.

title: MARATHON'S APPEAL ON PRICES DISMISSED
description: FINDLAY, Ohio, April 251 (AP)The Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals in Washington dismissed today for lack of jurisdiction the Marathon Oil Company's appeal from a lower court order that denied the company relief from the Government's old oil entitlements program, the company said.

title: FORD AIDE URGES PENSION RISE CUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)The Ford Administration said today that about 35 million Social Security and Supplemental Security income recipients were due to receive an 8 per cent benefit increase in July, an increase that would cost $5.7 billion in 1976.

title: U.S. IS CONCERNED OVER TIES IN ASIA
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Ford Administration, concerned about the possible impact of the Indochina situation on other Asian countries, hopes to bolster relations with Japan, South Korea, the Philippines and other Asian nations in coming weeks and months.

title: When the Rain Just Won't Go AwayCreations for Children
description: It was billed as a Rainy Day Workshopnot because of the torrential weather the night it was held, but rather to show mothers of small children how to brighten those terrible rainy hours when the sun seems gone forever. The twohour workshop at the 92d Street Y last week, which was attended by teachers as well as mothers, was taught by Emily Rosenthal, who was director of the Y's nursery school for 20 years, teaches crafts at The New School, and will be back at the Young Men's & Young Women's Hebrew Association next fall for longer version of this course.

title: New Hampshire's Vote Dispute Is Returned to Senate by Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) A divided Senate Rules Cornmittee returned to the Senate today, the issues it has been unable to resolve in last November's contested Senate election in New Hampshire.

title: DONALD CLYDE
description: HEBER CITY, Utah, April 25 (UPI)Donald Clyde, former; president of the National Wool Growers Association, died Tuesday in a Salt Lake City hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Kentucky vs. St. Louis

title: Workers Buy Textile Mill, Hoping to Revive Its Sales
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., April 25 (AP)In what one worker termed a great American adventure, 41 employes announced today that they had purchased the Van Raalte Company's textile plant here, hoping to revive lagging business.

title: Art: A Key Matisse Joins the Modern
description: In one way or another the Five Recent Acquisitions that are on view (through June 22) at the Museum of Modern Art have a lot to tell us about modern art, about the museum and about the people who run it.

title: Bruce Edwards, Catcher For '47 Brooklyn Dodgers
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 25 (UPI)Bruce Edwards, catcher for the 1947 National League champion Brooklyn Dodgers, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 51 years old.

title: Guam Finding Ways To House Refugees
description: AGANA, Guam, Saturday, April 26In aircraft hangars, in churches, under stairways, in barracks and tents, on cots under the tropical sky and in former hospital annexes that once held wounded United States marines, thousands of refugees from South Vietnam are spending their first nights away from home.

title: For the Islanders, Chico Is The Man
description: When the improbable New York Islanders try to complete their improbable Stanley Cup conquest of the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight, their most improbable performer will be an improbable goaltender with an improbable nickname. Glenn Resell might be the only hockey player ever to answer to Chico, which is usually associated in sports with shortstops and welterweights reared in the Caribbean sun. One of his Islander teammates noticed that Glenn Resch, with his dark hair and dark moustache and talkative manner, does slightly resemble Freddie Prinze, the Puerto Rican comedian with the title role in Chico and the Man, the popular television series. But the Penguins must think that Glenn Resch resembles that invisible shield in the TV commercials. The Penguins had won the first three games of the quarterfinal playoff series before Glenn Resch was inserted in the Islanders' net. He has permitted only 4 of 98 shots to elude him as the Islanders have won three in a row to create a decisive seventh game in Pittsburgh tonight. He has been hailed with the chant, Chico, Chico, Chico, in the Nassau Coliseum where a homemade sign proclaims, Chico Is The Man. The turning point of the series is obvious to everybody but Chico himself.

title: Bishop Loughlin Winner In Medley at Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25  Bishop Loughlin, which last won a schoolboy championship at the Penn Relays in 1952 but still holds the greatest number of victories here, captured its 21st crown today with a dramatic triumph in the distancemedley relay.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Democratic Dinner Raised $1Million for Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)The Democratic party took in an estimated $1million last night at a fundraising dinner for 1976 House and Senate campaigns, a spokesman said today.

title: Mailboat Odyssey: A Long Day's Journey Through the Grenadines
description: CARRYING its twice weekly load of mall 40 tons of food and hardware, 50 West Indians and a dozen tourists, the squat blackandwhite sea bus called the Seimstrand chugged into the aquamarine waters off the Grenadine island of Cannouan.

title: The World
description: The Communist party has been decisively defeated by moderate political elements in Portugal's election. The result was not unexpected, but it poses some difficult questions for the nation's military ruling council, which has moved the country leftward and now must contend with an expression of popular support for the moderates, the several nonCommunist parties that have ideologies ranging from Socialist to centrist.

title: Brother Stephen Sullivan Named at Manhattan College
description: The appointment of Brother Stephen Sullivan, executive vice president and provost at Manhattan College, as the 17th president of the 122yearold college, was announced yesterday.

title: COAST YOUTH SAYS HE KILLED SISTER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26The son of the late advertising executive, Howard Luck Gossage, has admitted to a jury here that he killed his sister, but in selfdefense.

title: Dog Show Awards
description: AT STANTON DELAWARE

title: Foreman, in Playful Mood, Defeats 5 Foes Handily
description: TORONTO, April 26In a carnival atmosphere that often was more comic than competitive, George Foreman registered secondround knockouts over Alonzo Johnson, Jerry Judge and Terry Daniels, then battered Charley Polite and Boone Kirkman today in threeround bouts of an unusual boxing exhibition.

title: CHRYSLER REBATES EXPECTED ON MAY 1
description: DETROIT, April 26  The Chrysler Corporation is expected to resume its price rebate program next Thursday, because new car sales have lagged badly since it stopped rebating on March 21.

title: Plans Another Comeback
description: DETROITA smaller, leaner Chrysler Corporation has adopted a strategy for riding out its present crisis that similar to the one it used when the company last had its back to the wall in 1970.

title: A New Marxist Opera by Nono
description: MILAN These are not easy times for the world's great opera houses. But La Scala of Milan the bastion of Italian opera for two centurieshas been beset by unusual difficulties in recent years. La Scala's problems are not merely economic. The old opera house has had to face up to social problems as well. These troubles may be traced back to those sumptuous Maria Callas galas of the fifties and early sixties, when the weight of jewelry and fur assembled in the great theater's boxes is said to have prompted the local tax collector to inquire how such a lavishly dressed audience was able to spend so large a proportion of its declared income on theater seats. True or not, the story says a lot about social conditions in the commercial capital of Italy; certainly Europe's largest and most sophisticated Communist party was not slow to comment on the flaunting of wealth that marked the Scala's great evenings.

title: Drivers End Revolt in Spain
description: BARCELONA, April 27Autoracing drivers, accustomed to danger, gave in to a threat and decided to hold a practice session today and compete in the Spanish Grand Prix tomorrow.

title: Jobless Up By 105,000 in a Year
description: TRENTONThe number of unemployed persons in New Jersey now totals 366,600, an increase of nearby 105,000 in a year's time, according to the latest economic survey of the state's Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Armchair Travel as Therapy
description: WHEN Dr. Jerome L. Singer, professor of psychology at Yale University, has his teeth filled, he daydreams. He lessens the discomfort of the drilling by imagining himself flying off to exotic islands, or even simply traveling to New York for a baseball game.

title: Kibbee Urges College President Be Forced to Quit Immediately
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the chancellor of the City University, who is trying to force Dr. Edgar J. Draper out of the presidency of Borough of Manhattan Community College, has strongly urged the Board of Higher Education to act without any further investigation.

title: A Radio Guide to Classical Music
description: When WNCN went off the air last fall, the uproar from music lovers suggested that classical music would now scarcely be heard on New York radio. Not so. The fact is that serious music is on the air almost 24 hours a dayalthough some dial switching is required to hear it all.

title: Communist Rule Will Be Disciplined, Moralistic
description: SAIGONI must get out of Vietnam. The Communists will kill me, said a young Vietnamese housewife as she stopped an American on the street. Please help me, I beg you!

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have rented an old apartment and the former tenants had apparently cemented down rubber strips in the bathtub to prevent slipping. They removed the strips but this left stains or marks in the bottom of the tub. Can you advise how to remove the remains of the glue that is left? Mrs. C.S., Bellerose, N.Y.

title: A little shimmer and glimmer: the gleam of glass
description: A. OVENTOTABLE SOUFFLES, 4.00 TO 8.00. Made of clear glass, they're delight to cook in and they add sparkling touch to your table setting. qt., 4.00 (3840) 1 qt., 5.00 (3841); 2 qt., 8.00 (3842)

title: ChildCare Certification Is Debated
description: TRENTONA proposal to eliminate the state certification requirement for teachers in childcare centers is the subject of a series of public hearings now being held throughout New Jersey.

title: 4Hour Tour May 7 To Cover 7 Houses
description: MONTCLAIR  Seven houses in Montclair and Glen Ridge will be open to the public on May 7 in a tour sponsored by the League of Women Voters. Cost of the tour is $5.

title: Imported floorcovering savings
description: ALTMAN'S OWN ROYAL KRISHNA RUGS 35 NOW 149.00 reg. 179.00. Ming design on rugs of magnificent pure wool hand woven in India. Ivory with gold color, dark green or gold color with ivory. D.91

title: U.S. Relations Could Be A Lot Better
description: Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda's official visit to Washington last weekend could mark a turning point in United StatesAfrican relations. His visit came at a time when relations between the United States and most black African states are possibly at their lowest point for over a decade.

title: Sale! White flower pots  for your green thumb
description: DELIGHTFUL CACHE POTS for all your pretty plants. By Whittier Potteries.

title: A Sorrow Beyond Dreams
description: Almost everything appears to separate Heinrich Bll and Peter Handke; age, experience, preoccupations. Bll is German and was born in 1917, Handke is Austrian and was born in 1942. Bll is an elder statesman of literature, winner of the Nobel Prize, and a moralist. Handke is an avantgarde playwright and a novelist whose work centers on a dishevelled amoral anxiety. Bll's brief new book is a decent, orderly, minor work of fiction. Handke's brief new book is non fiction at all, but a major memorial to a host of buried German and Austrian lives, the best piece of new writing I have seen in several years.

title: D. W Griffith, U. S. Film Pioneer
description: D. W. Griffith, whose innovative genius transformed the motion picture into high drama and great art, has been most aptly described by fellow movie directorsby Cecil B. DeMille who once called him the teacher of us all, and by Rene Clair who declared nothing essential has been added to the art of the motion picture since Griffith.

title: Sussex Seen Benefiting From Exclusionary Zoning Decision
description: NEWTONSussex County, New Jersey's last frontier, could benefit from the recent State Supreme Court decision striking down exclusionary zoning, according to Andrew S. Paszkowski, the county's Planning Director.

title: Smokey Robinson Comes Back to Sing
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26Smokey Robinson and the Miracles had their first big hit song with Shop Around in 1959. It impressed the Miracles name on teenage minds, provided a financial and emotional boost and national recognition to a small black record company in Detroit named Motown, and it announced the young Mr. Robinson to the country.

title: Baker Raises Possibility Of '76 White House Race
description: ALBUQUERQUE, April 26 (AP)Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. said today that he may seek the Republican nomination for President next year and would not rule out a primary election challenge to President Ford.

title: Unauthorized Sales Charged in Islip
description: ISLIPAn unauthorized group is apparently using, the name of the Islip Town Handicapped Services Division in promotion of the sale of products said to be produced for the benefit of the handicapped, Human Resources Commissioner Gregory W. Munton said last week.

title: LC at 175
description: In the shorthand of researchers all over the United States, LC stands for Library of Congress. As a symbol of scholarly attributes, LC is unrivaled even by the NYPL; but then the New York Public Library is actually a private library except for its branchesbut that's another story.

title: EightyNine Widows Of the Confederacy Get Army Benefits
description: ATLANTA, April 26 (UPI)Eightynine widows of Confederate Army soldiers still are receiving pensions 110 years after the end of the Civil War, with Alabama paying the most $335 a monthmore than the average Social Security or public welfare payment.

title: Remembrance Of Things Past
description: CESME, TurkeyNothing heightens contrasts between past and present more than visits to wellremembered spots after long absence. This Turkish town, only a few miles across the Aegean from the Greek island of Chios, is now a resort center with new hotels and welltended beaches. But I first knew it under different circumstances which, in their way, emphatically bespeak different times.

title: Good buys to keep your bath beautiful.
description: A. MARIPOSA SHOWER ENSEMBLE. Butterflies on a background of blossoms. Made of sheer polyester with a plastic liner in mint green, yellow, pink, blue, beige or white. By Ames.

title: Cost, Disposal Problems Delay Dredging Work
description: Jockey Creek in Southold, L.I., a pleasure boat inlet, is in danger of being shoaled in if it is not dredged within a few weeks, according to Louis W. Pinata, the Army Corps of Engineers' chief of operations for the New York region. Two marinas up Jockey Creek may be forced to close if they are cut off from boat traffic.

title: TV VIEW
description: Born last October as the. major character in an NBC special called The Law, Murray Stone has already departed televisionland. Or at least maybe. The cynical lawyer will not be getting his on regular series this fall, but he could be resurrected some day for another miniseries similar to the package of three onehour episodes recently concluded on NBC.

title: The Soviet Jews In Israel: Coping With Free Choices
description: Russian emigrants to Israel conventionally are seen as fugitives from totalitarianism seeking reunion with the mother nation. But many of the 100,000 Jews who have left the Soviet Union for Israel since 1967 represent a generation born and brought up under Communism and away from the traditions of Jewish society. The experience of what is probably the largest group of Soviet citizens ever to reject the regime demon strates the problem of weaning the individual from dependence on the state as much as it tests the Zionist premise that independence in the motherland brings a new life for the immigrant.

title: Miss Jarerna Has Nuptials
description: St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in Binghamton, N.Y., was the setting for the wedding yesterday afternoon of Lesley Elizabeth Jarema, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jarema of Binghamton, to Timothy Brown Hackman of New Rochelle, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Russel S. Hackman of Timonium, Md.

title: Voters Can Meet Candidates
description: Candidates' meetings will be held in most school districts to give voters a chance to meet the candidates and hear their views on school issues.

title: Fern Fronds Are Unfurling
description: Spring is a time of nature's uncurling. No plants better exemplify this awakening than the ferns, which send up their fiddleheads from buds that lie just beneath the soil surface.

title: Yale Will Honor 5 Leaving Staff
description: NEW HAVEN, April 26Five longtime members of the Yale Athletic Department will he honored next Tuesday at a retirement reception in Woolsey Hall.

title: Indian Legislators Back Statehood for Sikkim
description: NEW DELHI, April 26 (AP) The Indian Parliament gave its final approval today to bill making the Himalayan kingdom of Sikkin an Indian state.

title: Humphrey Feeling At Homein Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Remember Hubert H. Humphrey? The junior Democratic Senator from Minnesota. approaching his 64th birthday next month, is feeling young againan old Humphrey story. But, for the first time in decade, he is looking and sounding happy at home in the Senate. He is a man to be reckoned with again in the formulation of Democratic economic and foreign policy. He is a teacher, as ever, with some new Senate pupils, and is still as eager a student as there is in Congress.

title: What's Doing Around WILMINGTON
description: THE FAMILYNot everyone around Wilmington, Delaware's largest city, likes to have the northern part of the state thought of as a du Pont preserve, but it is a fact of life. It is impossible to drive far in any direction without passing streets, highways, schools, office buildings and museums named for or endowed by the oldest and biggest of American lionaire families. E. I. du Pont do Nemours & Co. is the world's largest chemical corporation and Delaware's largest employer. It owns Wilmington's newspapers, which blanket the state, and Delaware's only Congressman is Pierre S. du Pont 4th, a former du Pont Company official. State Route 52, which winds north out of Wilmington and through the countryside into Pennsylvania, is the main street for so many mansions of du Pont family members and company executives that the area is known as Chateau Country.

title: 1,100 Nassau Police Attending College
description: MINEOLALouis J. Frank, the Nassau County Police Commissioner, reported last week that more than 1,100 police officers will have acquired college degrees by the end of this spring semester.

title: Robinson's Work To Be Exhibited
description: Children's Day and an exhibition of Charles R. Robinson's marine paintings highlight May activities at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: ForeignDoctor Figure Rises
description: TRENTON  A study of New Jersey's licensed physicians shows that 75 per cent of the state's interns and residents are graduates of foreign medical schools. This is said to be the highest percentage of foreign medical graduates in training in the nation.

title: Pocahontas Honored
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)As a tribute to American Indians during the Bicentennial, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican of upstate New York, has introduced a bill that would allow the remains of Pocahontas to he returned to the United States from England.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: For a nine during Bette Midler's socalled C?ams on the HalfShell Revue (it's not really a revue, it's a camp concert) I blew hot and cold. Wild applause for the joke of the overture: what the pit was playing, with all the strings thrown away, was Oklahoma! (Okay, but a Ben Bagley Shoe String Revue of many a year ago beat her to this one by borrowing My Fair Latly's overture when that and the gag were new.) then, the curtains parting, a gaudyamusingly gaudyMississippi sidewheeler belching thunder clouds of Mack and white smoke while darkies in bandannas fanned themselves, smoked corn cobs, and sang a little something about totin dat barge. Tony Walton's fiery postcard design is just right here, and the stylized postures of the black ensemble make deadly comment, suggesting camp with a canker in it, garishness geared to clean, curt mockery.

title: Lon Nol and His Family Move to Honolulu Home
description: HONOLULU, April 26 (UPI)Marshal Lon Nol, the former Cambodian President, moved into his newly purchased $100,000 home yesterday in a fashionable suburb of Honolulu protected by community guards.

title: LAWYER IS CONVICTED IN ART SWINDLE HERE
description: A 41yearold lawyer was convicted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of mail fraud and receipt of stolen property for his part in a scheme to swindle a San Francisco art gallery out of three paintings worth $100,000.

title: District Judge Named by Caso
description: MINEOLA  Richard D. Furlong of Manhasset was named last week a judge of the Third District Court by Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive.

title: Tomahawk Home Opener Wednesday
description: A sport in which crosschecks are legal, goaltenders score and the ball crosses the goal line 30 times game, leaps into Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday when the National Lacrosse League makes its first appearance in the New York area.

title: Ann M. Gomprecht Bride in Bronxville
description: Ann Marie Gomprecht, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert F. Gomprecht of Bronxville, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to John Michael Skrzypczak, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Skrzypczak of Port Chester, N. Y.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Islanders Win Playoff

title: Claire Siegel Is Remarried on L. I.
description: Claire Lynn Fleet Siegel and Arnold S. Berkman, psychologists at Michigan State University, were married early yesterday evening at Temple BethEl in Great Neck, by Rabbi Jerome Davidson.

title: Women Among the Lions
description: LOS ANGELESFor the 57 years of its volunteer service history, the Lions Clubs have been an allmale pride, and proud of it. No lionesses admitted.

title: Duncan Wagner Becomes Fiance Of Anita Lembo
description: Anita Carole Lembo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lembo of Queens Village, Queens. plans to be married to Duncan Edwards Wagner, son of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York and the late Susan Edwards Wagner and brother of Robert F. Wagner Jr., City Councilmanatlarge for Manhattan.

title: Oil Companies Abandon Operations in Vietnam
description: The American oil industry, whose investment in South Vietnam is estimated at more than $100million, pulled out of Saigon last week.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Enrico Ferorelli

title: Oil Profits Slump Amid Debate on Their Adequacy
description: The oilindustry profit boom of the last two years ended last week as most of the nation's major oil companies reported sharply lower profits for the 1975 first quarter.

title: Crockett Is Disqualified For False Start in Dash
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26 (UPI)Eastern New Mexico and Western Kentucky, relying on foreignborn runners, dominated the final day of the 66th annual Drake Relays today, which were disrupted by a controversial disqualification in the special 100yard dash.

title: For Culver Shuttle Its's the 11th Hour
description: For a small band of Brooktynites, the longfeared demise of a venerable elevated railway link they use each workday the Culver shuttle in the Borough Park section is only two weeks away.

title: An ActionPacked Week
description: This week New York will offer another of those numismatic extravaganzas that have helped to make this city the big apple of the hobby for so many years. There will be three major auctions, one of them part of one of the city's biggest annual coin conventions. Actually, it is almost too much of a good thing, for two of the auctions will have overlapping sessions on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. But first, the convention:

title: A Creative Caterer Shows 6 Couples How He Does It
description: SPRINGFIELD  Any caterer who suggests a main course of striped bass en croute with a salmon mousse filling, or perhaps a Croquembouche (a pyramid of glazed cream puffs) for dessert, has a right to call himself creative. And any discriminating diners who pool their resources to hire Robert B. Wemischner of Springfield to cook dinner for them can call themselves just plain smart.

title: State Realty Unit Facing Crackdown
description: TRENTONThe Byrne administration is mounting an Mack on the operation of the state boards that regulate professions. Its first target is the New Jersey Real Esthe Commission, which is nominated by realestate broers.

title: The Beautiful Dandelion
description: There aren't many flowers prettier than a dandelion, if you can look at a dandelion as a blossom, not a weed. Its color is magnificent, one of the most richtoned yellows anywhere around. Its shape is the economical sphere, beautiful from every angle. It blooms early, and it keeps blooming until the first daisies appear.

title: THEFT BY SOVIET FOILED NAVY TEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A Soviet ship stole a United States Navy marker buoy from the midPacific in the fall of 1969, causing the failure of an important American oceanographic experiment codenamed Sea Spider.

title: Nixon Library Plan Hailed at U.S.C.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26Former President Richard M. Nixon's announcement that he will donate his papers and materials to a library to be constructed on the campus of the University of Southern California has delighted some and left others confused by the exact nature of the bequest.

title: Judith Ellen Morrill ?? Married To James Gordon Hanes 3d
description: Judith Ellen Morrill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manning C. Morrill, was married here yesterday afternoon to James Gordon Hanes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Hanes of WinstonSalem, N. C.

title: Kay M. Burger Wed to Thomas Scholl 3d
description: Kay Marschall Burger, a research assistant with Barclays Bank International, Ltd., and Thomas F. Scholl 3d, a stockbroker with Sterling Grace & Co., in Locust Valley, L.I., were married early yesterday evening.

title: List of Candidates
description: Following is the list of candidates in the May 6 school board elections for Districts 19 through 23 and 32 in Brooklyn, as supplied by the Board of Education. Some candidates are being challenged and may not be on the actual ballot. The list of candidates in other Brooklyn districts was printed last week and the names of candidates in Queens districts will be published next week.

title: U.S. and Soviet Discuss Corn Damage
description: MOSCOW, April 26Soviet and American farm experts will try to coordinate their qualitycontrol efforts following Soviet complaints that the Americans have been shipping some damaged corn.

title: Dr. J. of the Nets: The One and Only
description: Basketball players wear short pants. They wear no hats or helmets of any kind. You can see the hair on their legs. And you don't have to wait for a shaving commercial on TV to see their faces.

title: SeldomSeen Paintings On View in State Capitol
description: ALBANY, April 15  Indians in colorful dress stare from the corners. A tattered Confederate flag flutters low at Gettysburg. Bayonets gleam in the hands of World War I soldiers in their pieplate hats. There is even portrait entitled The Unknown Soldier.

title: Plan your summer around carefree knits
description: A. FORTREL NEAT PLEATER, 24.00. Softly defined box pleats kick out below the long, lean lines of our torso dress. This wellchilled houndstooth check by Lady Carol in Celanese  Fortrel  polyester. Sky blue or lettuce green. 1018. (4725).

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Robert F. R. Ballard, a vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., has won the 31st annual Most Ingenious Broker award of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc.

title: LAOTIAN LEFT SETS TERMS FOR PULLOUT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 26 (AP)The proCommunist Pathet Lao announced today that it would not withdraw its forces from seven strategic positions in northern Laos gained during recent fighting unless the royal Lao forces pulled their reinforcement units out of nearby areas.

title: Twixt and Capossela Score at Aqueduct
description: Twixt won the $55,400 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, but the day belonged to Fred Capossela.

title: ExPremier of Cambodia Criticizes Lon Nol's Rule
description: BANGKOK. Thailand. April 26 (AP)I don't understand why the Khmer Rouge want revenge on me, said In Tam, former Premier of Cambodia. I am only a rice farmer. I quit politics 16 months ago.

title: This Season's House Tours: From Log Cabin to Ultramodern
description: FOR the traditionalist, there are Victorian gingerbreads at Cape May and 18thcentury fieldstone houses in the Connecticut and New York countryside. For the trendy, there are angular beach houses on the Long Island shore. For the cultist, there is a Frank Lloyd Wright design. And for househunters, there are even homes that are for sale. In short, there's something for nearly everyone in the almost three dozen house tours, many of them annual events, being held in the metropolitan area from now until midAugust.

title: Ticket Man Takes N.J. Lottery Race
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 26 (AP)Ticket Man, ridden by Buck Thornburg, won the New Jersey Sweepstakes II race today at Garden State Park and netted $100,000 for holders of Sweepstake Lottery tickets numbered 649409.

title: Angel on Horseback
description: It's Wednesday, March 12, a rainy spring day Aqueduct, the New York supermarket of American race tracks, a $2 bettor's palace of dreams.

title: It's Time for a New W.P.A. for Artists
description: When I note the economic troubles besetting the men and women in the creative arts these days, I'm reminded of a JapaneseAmerican painter who, symbolically at least, expressed their current plight. On being asked to list his assets on a government form, under the heading Cash on hand, he wrote: 30 cents. Under Other assets, he wrote in bold letters: One billion dollars in unsold paintings.

title: Marietta Crew First
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, April 26 (AP)The Marietta College crew rode to victory in four of five races today against Georgetown University on the Muskingum River. In the main event between the varsity heavyweight eights, Marietta pulled from behind to win by half a length in 5 minutes 20.1 seconds for the 2,000 meters.

title: Afghan Named Best Dog Among 1,159 at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, April 26An apricotcolored Afghan, with a black mask, Ch. Mandith Pericles, C.D., owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr. of New York and Michael Wolf of .Christiana, Pa., went into the final in the Center of Progress Building on the New York State Fair Grounds today with a record of one best in show.

title: Save 50% off regular prices on reversible comforters
description: HALFPRICE SAVINGS ON DRAMATIC DYNASTY, TWIN, 17.00. Reg. 34.00. Turn it floral side up and its a mohair look. Reverse it to the solid side and it's smooth acetate/nylon tricot. Either way you'll find it a great comfort. Lightly fluffed with warm Kodel polyester fiberfill. Predominantly gold color. By Purotied.

title: Article 1  No Title
Federal Planners Use Computer System to Study L.I. Growth
description: UPTON, L. I.In an effort to pinpoint the energy needs of America's growing communities, the Federal Energy Administration is developing a computer system to assist planners and developers.

title: Epilogue
description: Vice. President Rockefeller and the conservatives in the Senate have made up, at least for the time being. The Vice President has apologized to the Senate for any discourtesy he showed last February when he failed to recognize Senator James B. Allen, an Alabama Democrat, during a Senate debate over a change in the filibuster rule. Mr. Rockefeller, as presiding Senate officer, alienated not only the conservatives, but also senators from both parties when he ignored calls from Senator Allen to be recognized. Senator Allen has been a leading defender of the old filibuster rule. Mr. Rockefeller was applauded and congratulated for his apology as he left the chamber. He commented afterward, If I made mistake I like to say so. I'm a very simple person.

title: Yearround blankets, most at savings
description: SALE. MACHINEWASHABLE WOOL, TWIN, NOW 25.00. Reg. 35.00. The patchwork blanket by Faribo is woven in a charming design, bound with nylon tricot velvet. Machine washable wool in an anyweather weight. Gold, brown, red or blue.

title: INVESTING
description: There's a joke about con vertibles that occasionally makes the rounds on Wall Street. Of course I know what a convertible is, (the fellow says. It'll kill you in a bad car wreck.

title: Restoration Aids a Hospital
description: PASSAICOne of the newest ways of raising funds for civic or social organizations the restoration of historic houseshas attracted more than 4,000 North Jersey residents to the hill section of this industrial city.

title: Brooklyn Will Hold 5Month Arts Series
description: A wideranging Festival of the Artsincluding theatrical performances, concerts, art shows, house tours, the official opening of Brooklyn's Bicentennial celebration, and an auction to benefit the borough's cultural institutions  was announced last week by Borough President Sebastian Leone.

title: State Shares of Federal Funds Depend on the Numbers
description: States, cities and counties, which used to compete with one another in luring industry through booster brochures extolling their high levels of properity, have been forced by the recession into a new type of competition. Now many political districts are accenting the negativecomplaining that the Federal Government undercounts their unemployed.

title: Truman's Yacht to Be Sold
description: SALEMHarry S Truman once described her as truly a sturdy shipshe served me well, and she was accustomed to sheltering the likes of Winston Churchill and Clement Atlee.

title: Working With Existing Light
description: There was a time when taking pictures for most amateur photographers was a matter of waiting for a sunny day and making certain that the sun was behind them (and shining on the subject) in order to insure proper exposure. However, today's modern films and cameras with fast lenses enable anyone to take pictures in almest any kind of lighteven by candlelight. In fact, with a little practice, and after becoming familiar with a few basic techniques, many beginning photographers soon find that it is actually lust as easy to take pictures by existing light as it is to provide some form of artificial lightin many cases even easier.

title: More Rabbis Leaning to Public Aid for Schools
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 22A growing element in the Conservative rabbinate is rethinking its movement's traditional opposition to the public financing of religious  sponsored schools.

title: Hope for a Classic Building
description: JERSEY CITY  In the basement of the old Hudson County Courthouse here, the headline of a tattered 1963 newspaper reads: SEE WHELAN COUNCIL'S PICK AS GANGEMI'S SUCCESSOR.

title: The new comic style of Richard Pryor
description: LOS ANGELES. The handwritten sign on the door of the modest Hollywood Hills cottage is literary and more than a little selfconscious: To avoid ill feeling and/or unpleasantness, the sign advises, please be aware of the fact that uninvited guests are not welcome at any time, whatsoever. To avoid rejection, please do not take the liberty of dropping by. Sincerely and Respectfully, Occupant. On one level of reality, the sign says a simple Go Away!

title: 10th Blackwell Cup Taken by Quakers
description: DERBY, Conn., April 26Pennsylvania's varsity crew won the Blackwell Cup today on the windswept Housatonic River, defeating St. Joseph's and Yale. The Red and Blues margin of victory was two lengths over the Hawks, with Yale one length farther back. The winning time was a fast 5 minutes 41.9 seconds, with the strong tailwind and the fastmoving spring waters of the river aiding the crews.

title: Coalition Formed to Rid Lake Hopatcong of Pollution
description: HOPATCONGThe glamour of the days when Lake Hopatcong and the towns surrounding it formed a fashionable resort area has virtually vanished. Instead of wealthy city people and elegant summer parties, the inhabitants or the four lake communities are largely middle  class families who have moved away from the metropolitan sprawl 30 miles to the east.

title: DR. JOHN C. PIERSON, SURGEON, 67, IS DEAD
description: Dr. John Clough Pierson, former assistant attending surgeon at Memorial Hospital and Lincoln Hospital and consultant in gastroenterology at Roosevelt Hospital, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 210 East 68th Street.

title: Letters
description: Unfairness

title: Career Day Is Set For Sociologists
description: NEW BRUNSWICKSeciologists seeking jobs outside of conventional academic employment may be able to obtain the help they need at a Career Day program here next Saturday.

title: Rustin to Address Upsala Colloquium
description: EAST ORANGEBusinessmen, labor leaders and educators will be among those who will gather at Upsala College next Sunday night for a colloquium on Equality vs. Equity: Affirmative Action and Equal Opportunity.

title: A Fresh Look at Early American Modernists
description: WILMINGTON, DEL We appear to be entering a period of intensive research into the achievements of the early American modernists. Names long forgotten are being revived with a sense of discovery and excitement, and even names long familiar among the firstgeneration modernistsJohn Marin, Marsden Hartley, Max Weber, et. al.are taking on new meaning as the era of their early endeavors comes more clearly into focus. Ten years hence, the entire history of American art in the 20th century is certain to look very different to us than it looked, say, 10 years ago. Which means, too, that some of our major museums will sooner later be obliged to alter their policies of condescension and indifference to this period in order to give us a more comprehensive account of its newly perceived accomplishments.

title: Revive summer furniture with fresh coverings
description: A. RECOVERS in heavyduty cotton duck. Yellow, tangerine, green or blue. For butterfly chair, 11.00 (3891). For director's chair, 6.00 (3892)

title: Guilford Area Is A Rewarding Cruise Stop
description: The Guilford (Conn.) Harbor doesn't look like much on the chart, but I think you'll find it a rewarding stop on your Long Island Sound cruise, an alternative port to busy, beautiful Branford, or picturesque Clinton Harbor.

title: WomanLed Cubs Ousted
description: JESSUP, Md., April 26 (AP)A Cub Scout pack in this community has been disenfranchised from the national scouting movement because its pack leader. Marjorie Ripple, was a woman.
