description: IZMIR, TurkeyBread, Turkey's basic food, used to cost about 7 cents for a standard loaf. A few months ago the price doubled and the loaf shrank slightly.

title: Canter Crashes in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 27 (AP)A helicopter crashed on top of South Side building and burned today while transporting concrete blocks, but the two men inside were unhurt, the authorities said. The helicopter was hovering about 15 feet above the roof of the five story Eastman Kodak Color Print PhotoGraph Laboratory to pick up concrete block weighing about 1.500 pounds, when the craft plummeted to the roof, according to. Fire Commissioner Robert J. Quinn.

title: Widow Is Running In California to Fill Seat Husband Held
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27A special election to fill California's 37th Congressional District seat, left vacant by the death of Representative Jerry L. Pettis, will take place Tuesday in Riverside and San Bernardino counties. Mr. Pettis's widow, Shirley, is a leading contender.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)  Robert J. McClosky, Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations, said today that about 130,000 Vietnamese refugees would be brought to the United States.

title: Bridge:
description: The result of the knockout team championship at the Long Island regional championships played at Belmont Park, Elmont, L. I., during the weekend demonstrated that a leading tournament director can also be a successful player, although the combination is a rare one. Henry Bethe of New York, who has directed many tournaments here in recent years, led a winning team that included Ronald Blau of Bellmore, L. I., Martin Ginsberg and Alan Truscott of New York.

title: Toward Peace in Vietnam
description: Messages dispatched from Hanoi to beleaguered Saigon during the past weekend amounted to a military ultimatum and hints of political promises. The rocket attack on the capital was clearly intended as the big sticka reminder that the attacking forces have the capacity to deal the final blow. Conciliatory broadcasts and a subtle shift away from the previously uncompromising antiAmerican rhetoric seemed to be the carrot, suggesting that Hanoi would like to avoid an assault on Saigon.

title: Queens College: Passport to the Middle Class
description: The other day, Queens College led the nation in the competition for the prestigious Lehman Graduate Fellowships with two winners and three alternates. To the longtrustrated partisans of the college this was just the latest proof that their school has become the jewel of the city's college system, surpassing City, Brooklyn and Hunter.

title: Black Rhodesians to Bar Talks Till Agreed Conditions Are Met
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 27 (Reuters)Black nationalist leaders said today that they would not resume constitutional talks with the Rhodesian Government until Salisbury fulfilled a number of conditions that nationalists said it agreed to in Lusaka, Zambia, last December.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State's Controller, Arthur Levitt, reported yesterday that millions of dollars in additional state personal income taxes could be collected from reluctant taxpayers by a more careful scrutiny of income tax returns with obvious errors and that additional revenues could be saved by the tightening of procedures in the tax bureau.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Led by their Primate, Archbishop Iakovos, and other prelates of the Greek Orthodox Church, members of Brooklyn's Three Hierarchs Church staged a colorful procession through the Kings Highway section yesterday, marking the Greek Palm Sunday and celebrating the groundbreaking for new church social center. With American and Greek flags and the banners of church organizations snapping in the spring breeze, the procession followed a circuitous route that began and ended at the church on Avenue P between East 17th and 18th Streets, where the new social center will also be built.

When should reporters cooperate with government officers? When should they cooperate with competing reporters? When should reporters keep information even from their editors?

title: Big Treasury Refunding To Guide Credit Market
description: On Thursday of this week the capital markets are due to learn the details of the Treasury's plan to refund, or refinance, $3.8billion of maturing debt. On those details will hinge the nearterm trading action of the Government securities market and, derivatively, the corporate bond market. The question uppermost in the minds of dealers, traders, economists and observersatlarge is whether the Treasury will include a longterm bond as part of its refunding operation.

title: CAMBODIAN QUEEN IS DEAD IN PEKING
description: PEKING, April 27 (Reuters)Queen Mother Kossamak of Cambodia, 71yearold mother of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, died here today with her son at her bedside, an official announcement said.

title: SummerWork Documents
description: Young people aged 14 to 21 hoping to be considered for the Summer Youth Employment program  formerly Neighborhood Youth Corps must have Social Security cards, and those under 18 need working papers, Nyrka Torrado, Commissioner of Youth Services, said yesterday. She said it took at least six weeks after applying to a local Social Security office to get a card. Information on working papers may be obtained by telephoning 4773980 in Manhattan 5837204 in the Bronx; 8753571 in Brooklyn; 6585680 in Queens and 4477040 in Richmond.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate's conventional wisdom is that a President's choice for Cabinet or other high administrative posts should not be rejected except for very compelling reasons questionable character, bad prior record in public office or manifest inexperience for the job. Consequently, confirmation hearings by Senate committees are usually pro forma affairs. Members' questions are usually soft; the nominee's replier are agreeable and cautious. Opposition witnesses are given polite but short shrift.

title: The Newmans: 2 Lives in the Movies
description: On May 5, Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward will be honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center at its fourth annual gala benefit. In previous years, tributes were paid to Charles Chaplin, Fred Astaire and Alfred Hitchcock. The fact that Mr. and Mrs. Newman are following such grand old masters makes them feel abashed, as if they were being enshrined before their time: Wasn't it just yesterday (actually it was 22 years ago) that they met while playing in Pionic on Sri:4dway?

description: WASHINGTON, April 27Lieut. Gen. Louis H. Wilson, the head of Pacific area operations for the Marine Corps, has been chosen by President Ford to succeed Gen. Robert E. Cushman as the Marine Corps Commandant, a Ford Administration source said today.

title: Foolish Pleasure's Derby Drill Pleases
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 Foolish Pleasure had a workout this morning with results that were hesitantly satisfactory to his trainer, moderately satisfactory to his jockey and almost exultantly satisfactory to his veterinarian. The formidable colt, owned by John Greer, went seven furlongs in 1:27 4/5 and galloped out the mile in 1:40 4/5. He went very nice, he said. He finished very well and he galloped out strong the last quarter of a mile. Well aware of the colt's disposition, since he has ridden him in almost all of his 11 races, Vasquez went on: He's a nice horse to be around. He runs so evenly. The only bad race he ever ran was in the Florida Derby.

title: 'Monty Python and the Holy Grail'
description: A foolish constancy is the hobgoblin of little minds and of some movie critics (who may or may not have little minds) when writing about the films of comedians.In his own day, poor old W. C. Fields was always being rapped for not making movies that were as funny, from start to finish, as his adoring critics found bits of them to be. I'm afraid that once or twice I've gone so far as to suggest that a certain film by Woody Allen or Mel Brooks hasn't been consistently funny, that is, that there were some parts that weren't as funny as other parts. However, as any surveyor of anything will tell you, you can't have a high spot unless you have a low one from which to survey it.All of which is a round about way of saying that "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" has some low spots but that anyone at all fond of the members of this brilliant British comedy groupwhich more or less justifies Sunday night television in New Yorkshouldn't care less."Monty Python and the Holy Grail," which opened yesterday at the Cinema 2, is a marvelously particular kind of lunatic endeavor. It's been collectively written by the Python troupe and jointly directed by two of them (Terry Gilliam and Terry Jones) so effectively that I'm beginning to suspect that there really aren't six of them but only one, a fellow with several dozen faces who knows a great deal about trick photography.Unlike "And Now for Something Completely Different," which was a collection of sketches from "Monty Python's Flying Circus," television show, "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" is what is known on Broadway as a "book show."It has a story with an approximate beginning, an approximate middle and it ends, or perhaps I should say that it stops after a while. To be more specific, it's the Python troupe's version of the legend of King Arthur and the search for the holy grail, with no apologies at all to Malory though it manages to send up the legend, courtly love, fidelity, bravery, costume movies, movie violence and ornithology.Graham Chapman plays Arthur, the film's major continuing character, with the earnest optimism of a 19th-century missionary, who's doomed to fail but refuses to acknowledge the fact. The other members of the Python team turn up in a variety of rolesRound Table knights, snobbish French aristocrats, irritable serfs, mythical monsters and, in one case, as a noble son named Alice who tries to turn the film into an operetta.The gags are nonstop, occasionally inspired and should not be divulged, though it's not giving away too much to say that I particularly liked a sequence in which the knights, to gain access to an enemy castle, come up with the idea of building a Trojan rabbit. When Arthur calls retreat, he simply yells: "Run away!" And the morale of Sir Robin, the least successful of the Round Table knights, isn't helped by a retinue of minstrels who insist on singing about his most embarrassing defeats.I have no idea whether Mr. Gilliam and Mr. Jones have seen Robert Bresson's rather more austere film, "Lancelot of the Lake," which was shown at last year's New York Film Festival, but there are times when "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" seems to be putting on Mr. Bresson unmercifully. The dour lighting and landscapes that are so important in the Bresson film are tossed into this comedy without apparent thought for the havoc they do "Lancelot." Mr. Bresson's emphasis on what you might call the sound of knighthood (clanking armor, horses' hoofs) is also hilariously parodied, as well as the violence of the age, on which the Python people have the last bleeding word.Everyone interested in Mr. Bresson would do well to stay away from "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" until after they see "Lancelot." The comparison, which may never have been intended, is nevertheless lethal to the work of the great French director.

He is a former underground starthe lead singer of the old Velvet Undergroundwho has won himself close to mass acceptance without too much obvious compromise of his seamy image. And he is an avantgardist who has had to wrestlewith only sporadic successwith the question of how far one can go in search of popularity before one can be said to have sold out.

Mr. Connally's friends hope the verdict is the start of a broad reaction against the socalled Watergate syndrome of public suspicion.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels, with Artis Gilmore hitting 29 points, trounced the Spirits of St. Louis, 123103, tonight and won the Eastern Division final playoffs in the American Basketball Association by four games to one.

title: Sparkman Asserts the U.S. Must Meet Israel's Needs
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Senator John J. Sparkman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today that despite the Ford Administration's current Middle East reassessment, the United States must assure as much as we can that Israel's security and economic needs are satisfied.

title: SCHOOL LUNCH BILL ADOPTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28After five weeks of argument, the House passed today a $3billion school lunch bill, but gave Republicans a partial victory by blunting proposals by the Democrats to increase the program's cost.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Gloria E. A. Toote of New York will leave her post tomorrow as Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for fair housing and equal opportunity. She will be replaced by James H. Blair, formerly head of New Jersey's Civil Rights Commission and now chairman of Michigan's Civil Rights Commission.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, April 28, 1975

title: DOLLAR OFF ABROAD; GOLD PRICE UP A BIT
description: BRUSSELS, April 28 (UPI)The dollar retreated on a broad front on European money markets today after opening substantially higher.

title: They're Learning How to SewBut Not Just to Save Money
description: That women will finally get out of jeans and pants and into dresses is a dream that Seventh Avenue has been living by. Now two rival industries  the manufacturers of patterns and the makers of woven fabrics for home sewingare hoping for the same thing.

title: Yankees Conquer Indians
Uninstitutional, Unrigid, Understanding
description: DETROITFor a year, beginning in September, 1970, I was a teacher at small private school in Cambridge, Mass. The student body of about fifty was made up of boys, black and white, who lived in the metropolitan Boston area. They were between the ages of twelve and seventeen and were classified as emotionally disturbed.

title: 32 Hurt as Blast Sets Off Fire on Upper West Side
description: An explosion in a West Side storefront last night started threealarm fire that heavily damaged two fivestory apartment buildings and left at least 32 persons hurt, authorities said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 29, 1975

title: Dance: Event No. 131
description: A dance performance is what Merce Cunningham says it is. With his dance company, Mr. Cunningham is proving this again in a new series of weekend concerts with guest musicians at his Westbeth studio through June 1.

title: SAN DIEGO LOSING MOTHBALL FLEET
description: SAN DIEGO, April 28Steve Anderson came down from Seattle over the weekend to say goodby to the cruiser Galveston, a trim and gallant ship when he sailed and fought aboard her but now a decrepit, helpless hulk consigned to the junk heap.

title: COURT OVERTURNS G.T.E. TRUST ORDER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (UPI)A Federal Appeals Court said today divestiture is not an available remedy in private antitrust actions and overturned an order that would have made the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation give up sever subsidiaries.

title: Memo on Fake Tickets Cited In Suit on '71 Nixon Speech
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 28 (UPI)  A White House memo outlining a plan to keep unfriendlies away when President Nixon was giving a speech in 1971 was introduced in evidence today in a $1.1million suit.

title: 200 in Westchester Tour Estate Full of Daffodils
description: HARRISON, N. Y., April 28More than 200 visitors, almost all of them suburban women, got a rare glimpse at the nation's largest daffodil display today as Mrs. Flagler Matthews opened her 100acre Brookside estate for a day.

title: KAYSEN RESIGNS AS INSTINTE HEAD
description: Two years after most of the faculty members of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton demanded the resignation of the director, Dr. Carl Kaysen, he has acceded to their wish.

title: U.S. High Court Rules Judge Is Subject to Trial by the State
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The United States Supreme Court ruled today that Edwin H. Helfant, a municipal court judge in New Jersey, was not entitled to a Federal Court hearing on his contention that he could not get a fair trial in the state courts on criminal charges against him.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A group of civil rights activists and political figures urged that the Legislature establish a panel to recommend steps to abolish housing discrimination allegedly practiced by many suburban localities through zoning requirements. Such requirements, the group said, often make it necessary build housing on large lots, or with unnecessarily large floor areas, thus raising costs and making it impossible for the poor, the minorities and even middleclass families afford the housing.

title: Suspect in Plane Hijacking Held Under $100.000 Bond
description: ATLANTA, April 28 (AP) A Richmond, Va., man with a history of psychiatric confinement was ordered held today under $100,000 bond pending a hearing on a Federal charge of attempted air piracy.

title: LongTerm Reactor Peril Is a Worry to Physicists
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A team of physicists, convened last year by the American Physical Society to assess the safety of American nuclear reactors, has found no reason for substantial shortterm concern, but is critical in terms of longrange prospects.

title: Close Soviet Links Leave Finns Secure but Careful
description: HELSINKI, FinlandWhen the Finnish publishers of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn decided last year not to publish The Gulag Archipelago: 19181956 because of its political sensitivity, the incident was cited abroad as another example of Soviet intimidation of this small country.

title: C.L. MARBURG, AIDED LEAGUE OF NATIONS
description: BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP)Charles L. Marburg, who had been active in the League of Nations, the United Nations and the English Speaking Union, collapsed in the arms of his daugnter Christine while dancing at the Hunt Ball yesterday. He was 69 years old.

title: Ford Weighs Evacuation Of Remaining Americans
description: WASHINGTON, April 28President Ford studied the deteriorating situation in South Vietnam at an emergency meeting of the National Security Council tonight but apparently put off a decision on evacuating all Americans still there.

title: Greenspan Sees. Recession Continuing
description: Although businessmen and economists continue to predict that the nation's deep recession will soon end, the President's chief economic adviser, Alan Greenspan, warned yesterday that the bottom of the slide has not yet been reached, despite a very dramatic slowing in the decline.

title: D.A. Digs Into a Hampton Town Hole
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., April 28  The Suffolk County District Attorney's office started investigating today why it cost $30,000 to dig a huge hole in the ground in this resort community when some officials believe it should have cost almost nothing at all.

title: SCHOOL LUNCH BILL ADOPTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28After five weeks of argument, the House passed today a $3billion school lunch bill, but gave Republicans a partial victory by blurting proposals by the Democrats to increase the program's cost.

title: Custom Tailoring:
description: Imagine everyone's surprise when Jean Bennett presented Elliot Paris with a homemade sport coat. It's a wellknown fact that Jean can't sew to save herself. Trouble with buttons, even.

title: Pigless Secaucus, 75, Points With Pride
description: These days in Secaucus, N. J., it's diamonds before swine.

title: Battle of Saigon
description: With the first light of dawn today came a Communist rocket barrage upon the airport of Saigon. The Vietnamese Communists have abruptly rejected the truce and negotiation proposal of the newly inaugurated President Duong Van Minh; instead of the orderly and gradual transfer of power which the Paris agreements designed for South Vietnam, the outlook now is for nothing less than a bloody and totally unnecessary battle for Saigon or surrender.

title: LongTerm Danger In Reactors Feared
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A team of physicists, convened last year by the American Physical Society to assess the safety of American nuclear reactors, has found no reason for substantial shortterm concern, but is critical in terms of longrange prospects.

title: Council Vote on Fuel Rent Rise Put Off
description: In the midst of a rollcall vote, a City Council committee abruptly decided last night to postpone further action on a bill that would permit landlords of rentcontrolled apart ments to collect special rent increases to help compensate them for higher fuel costs.

title: REDS ASSAULT SAIGON DEFENSES, RAKE AIRPORT WITH 150 ROCKETS; MINH REBUFFED ON TRUCE PLAN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 29Saigon's airport came under the heaviest rocket attack of the war early this morning as North Vietnamese troops assaulted parts of the city's suburbs.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: EFFECTIVE MAY 3, 1975

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: Minnesota vs. Quebec

title: DISPUTE STIRRED BY CRABIEL CASE
description: TRENTON, April 28The failure of the state's criminal prosecution of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel has among New Jersey's top aw enforcement authorities.

title: N.C.A.A. Seeking Way to Cut Budget
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is on the verge of facing up to the realities of economic life in the nineteenseventies long after most of its 687 member colleges and universities have made large cuts in their sports budgets. Follow ing a twoClay special meeting on economics in intercollegiate athletics at Kansas City last week, the N.C.A.A. Council has called for a special convention of the association in midAugust in order to enact moneysaving legislation. Tom Hansen, an assistant executive director of the N.C.A.A., said, Everyone at the special meeting seemed in agreement that there should not just be cosmetic type changes but there should be severe changes that don't just look good on paper.

title: Trial Opens in Dismissed Teacher's Suit
description: FREEHOLD, April 28Patricia Endress, who was dismissed as journalism professor and student newspaper adviser by Brookdale Community College last June, insisted in court today that she had never violated any of the college principles about academic freedom or philosophical platforms and goals and that she had not ordered the publication of material against the student editor's wishes.

title: PHYSICIAN APPEALS IN DEATH OF FETUS
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP)Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin is asking judge to declare him not guilty of manslaughter, despite his conviction last February in the death of an aborted fetus.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE OF 11.5% HIGHEST IN THREE DECADES
description: The unemployment rolls grew by 40,300 in the city in March, bringing the total of jobless people here to 372,600 and the unemployment rate to 11.5 per cent, a high for the threedecade postWorld War II period, the State Department of Labor renorted yesterday.

title: Earle Lister Named New Arts Director Of City College Unit
description: The Board of Higher Education yesterday approved the appointment of Earle R. Gister as director of the Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts at City College. The appointment described by a college official as a step toward transforming the center into a major metropolitan area theatertraining program.

title: President Minh's Inaugural Address in Saigon Palace
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 (UPI)Following is a transcript of the inaugural address today of President Duong Van Minh as translated by United Press International:

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 29, 1975

title: BEAME CUTS SCORED BY CITY U. STUDENTS
description: As 600 City University students demonstrated in front of the Board of Higher Education offices to protest Mayor, Beanie's proposed cuts in the university SEEK program, Alfred A. Giardino, chairman of the board, criticized the Mayor's efforts to dictate budgetbalancing procedures.

title: People in Sports
description: Now that Chris Evert has announced that she and Jimmy Connors expect to marry soon, plans for matrimony on the women's tennis tour are catching on. Evonne Goolagong, the former child prodigy of Australian tennis who is now 23 years old, became engaged yesterday to Roger Cawley, a British businessman. The engagement was announced by Caw ley's family in Canterbury, England.

title: Attica Prosecutor's Appearance On F.B.I. Issue Put Off by Court
description: BUFFALO, April 23  The court appearance of the chief Attica prosecutor was postponed for a day today after he turned over material to State Supreme Court justice Joseph Mattina, who questioned him briefly in his chambers.

title: 6 Hurt in Bank Blast
description: DENVER, April 28, (UPI)A bomb stuffed beneath a secondfloor stairwell of the American National Bank detonated today, injuring six employes and heavily damaging adjacent offices.

title: Advertising
description: Jane Maa??,, a vice president at Ogilvy & Mather, has been writing advertising copy for 10 years, usually for television and occasionally for print but never for radio.

title: Orchestra Makes Last Visit of Season
description: The orchestra season is drawing to an end, and last night in Avery Fisher Hall the Philadelphia Orchestra ended its New York visits until 197576.

title: FORECAST RULES OFFERED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today series of standards and guidelines intended to give all investors equal access to earnings projections of public companies.

title: EDWIN B. WILLIAMS, LEXICOGRAPHER.83
description: Dr. Edwin B. Williams, provost emeritus of the University of Pennsylvania who was an authority on Romance languages and in internationally known lexicographer, died yesterday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 83 years old.

title: Failure of State Prosecution of Crabiel Stirs Ire Among Hyland Aides Involved
description: TRENTON, April 28The failure of the state's criminal prosecution of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel has precipitated a bitter fallingout among New Jersey's top lawenforcement authorities.

title: Protecting Voters
description: The second extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is moving through Congress on the strength of a considerably greater consensus on the law's usefulness than was the case in 1970 when the Nixon Administration tried to dilute the force of the legislation.

title: People and Business
description: Henry C. Wallich, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve Bank, contends that the Fed must maintain its current policy of moderation in expanding money supply.

title: An Instant New Yorker Named Catfish
description: He has to order his chewing tobacco by the case and he has been hunting for a house instead of for deer but otherwise, Jim (Catfish) Hunter adjusted to life in New York quicker than his curveball did. Quietly, the Three Point Seven Million Dollar Man of the Yankees is living in midtown hotel not far from the Stage Delicatessen with all those photos of Broadway personalities in the window and all those slabs of pastrami on the counter. You can get some of the best food in the world there, he was saying: Anything you want. I like the turkey and bacon sandwich. There's so much turkey in it, one's enough. In other years, other Yankees lived differently. In his cap and camel's hair coat, Babe Ruth moved through the big city noisily, as if he were leading a parade. Joe DiMaggio moved gracefully. Mickey Mantle moved cautiously. Catfish Hunter moves easily, as if he were a tourist from Hertford, N.C., who has been here before.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: M.I.T. Researcher Studies Visible Scientists and Impact They Have on Public Issues
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 27 There are a handful of scientists today who always seem to be making headlines.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Flyfishing
description: A recent wire service dispatch said that this may be the year that the slowly growing interest in flyfishing makes a sudden upsurge.

title: Couples Are Set Aboil In Stage Meeting Place
description: Two men and two women dance a curious quadrille in Robert Lord's Meeting Place. They challenge one another and retreat, form sides (boys against the girls, girls against the boys), then assail their mates. They talk about other lovers, who may beprobably arethe characters in the play.

title: STEEL OUTPUT DOWN 0.1% IN LATEST WEEK
description: Steel production in the week ended April 26 dropped 0.1 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES MOW PRICE DROP
description: Aggressive Brazilian sales of soybeans and related products depresssed domestic prices for those key commodities yesterday, while seasonal weather factors created a ragged market in the grains.

title: Bombing Competition
description: SHREVEPORT, La., April 48 (AP)The Strategic Air Command's annual bombing competition has been canceled this year for economic reasons, officials at Barksdale Air Force Base said yesterday.

title: Dance: Juilliard Ensemble Presents 3 New Works
description: Always one or me more interesting annual events of the dance calendar is the series given by the Juilliard Dance Ensemble at the JuilHard Theater. The dancersgraduating or senior students are always of a high professional level, and usually pains have been taken to present an interesting program showing off their talents. This yearthe series took place Saturday, Sunday and yesterdaywas special, however, because Juilliard had commissioned three new works from established choreographers, Daniel Lewis, Kazuko Hirabayashi and Anna Sokolow.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Extradition proceedings for Joseph Kallinger, who wanted in New Jersey for the murder of a nurse in Leonia, were delayed by Judge William Caldwell in the Dauphin County Court in Harrisburg, Pa., until after Mr. Kallinger's trial there on robbery charges. The extradition hearing for Mr. Kallinger had originally been set for yesterday, but was delayed when he became ill during his transfer from a cell block in the court house to the courtroom.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Meyer Butensky, Trucker, Dead; Major ClothingTrade Carrier
description: Meyer J. Butensky, chairman of Branch Industries, Inc., which runs Branch Motor Express Company, a major carrier and terminal operator here, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami, where he had been living. He was 88 years old and had been active in the business until recently.

title: Man With 2 Hats: Lawyer and Pianist
description: Everyone has heard of physicians who play the violin for pleasure and of engineers who relax as Sunday painters, but Robert Miller is the only Wall Street lawyer around who is also a professional pianist acclaimed for performances of contemporary music.

title: Woman and Two Children Die in a Newark Fire
description: NEWARK, April 28  A young woman and two small children died early this morning when a fire of undetermined origin swept through their thirdfloor apartment in the city's East Ward.

title: Nicholas Soussanin, Actor In Russia and Hollywood
description: Nicholas Soussanin, an actor in his native Russia who came here in 1923 and had a successful career in Hollywood supporting roles, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 86 years old and had been visiting here from his home in District Heights. Md.

title: Albany Civil Service Union Studies Projected Contract
description: ALBANY, April 28A 6 per cent acrosstheboard raise for civil servants, which would take $119million from the strained state budget was studied by union officials at a private meeting here today.

title: Organizer of Airlift
description: When he retired a month ago as Deputy Under Secretary for Management in the State Department, Lewis Dean Brown may have envisioned himself as walking into a future of relative peace and quiet. But he could not have been more wrong.

title: I.B.M. Is Scored on South African Role
description: PITTSBURGH, April 28The issue of what a major American corporation should do to combat apartheid in South Africa dominated the annual stockholder meeting of the International Business Machines Corporation here today.

title: Levi Warns Against New Wiretap Restrictions
description: Attorney General Edward H. Levi warned here last night that a Congressional proposal to restrict the President's power to order foreignintelligence wiretaps would endanger national security.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Philadelphia

title: Index of Indicators of Economy Shows Drop of 0.5% for March
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Government's soontoberevised index of leading indicators of the economy showed a small decline in March after a small rise in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Thursday incorrectly listed the Islamic Center of Washington as one of the sponsors of a conference on Religion's Role in a Violent World convened by the Armenian Church of America. The center withdrew its cosponsorship of the conference several months ago.

title: Democrats Select Connecticut Chief: State Rep. O'Neill
description: HARTFORD, April 28The Democratic State Central Committee of Connecticut tonight unanimously elected William A. O'Neill of East Hampton, majority leader in the State House of Representatives, as the new nartv chairman.

title: Spender Edits Book on Auden the Man
description: Stephen Spender, distinguished in achievement (poet, essayist, critic), and in demeanor (a shock of white hair sets off his tall figure and ruddy, still youthful appearance) took time out the other day on a visit to this country to talk about his lifelong friend W. H. Auden and the book about him he has just finished editing; W. H. Auden: A Tribute.

title: Sentence Cut, McCord May Be Free in May
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) A Federal judge reduced today the sentence of James W. McCord Jr., to four months in prison. It means that Mr. McCord, the chief wiretapper on the Watergate burglary team, may be free next month.

title: Judge Backs Sale of Plant In Texas by American Beef
description: OMAHA, April 28 (UPI)A Federal bankruptcy judge approved today the $18million sale of the Dumas, Tex., plant of American Beef Packers, Inc., to Swift Fresh Meats. Inc.

title: San Diego Losing Last of Mothball Fleet
description: SAN DIEGO, April 28Steve Anderson came down from Seattle over the weekend to say goodby to the cruiser Galveston, a trim and gallant ship when he sailed and fought aboard her but now a decrepit, helpless hulk consigned to the junk heap.

title: James and Mollin Reach Round of 16
description: WOODBURY, L.I., April 28 John James of Australia, Harold Mollin of Great Neck, Willie Oropez of New York and Peter Marmureanu of Rumania advanced to the round of 16 in the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championships today at the Woodbury Country Club.

title: U.S. AIDES REVEAL DISCLOSURE RISKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 28To fake available to the public information that is truthful but damaging or embarrassing to the Government is often all that is needed to ruin a bureauamide career, a Senate subcommittee was told today by seven Federal employes who had done it and suffered.

title: Philippines Looking to Steam for Energy
description: MANILAAt the foot of one of the active volcanoes that dot the Philippine Islands, a Union Oil Company rig has struck major deposits of what may become one of Asia's newest and most important energy resources steam.

title: Airline Rate Changes Taking Effect Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)Coach class air fares will rise up to $4 on very short flights tomorrow and drop as much as $11 on long distance trips.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Tigers Get 3 in Ninth And Sink Orioles, 53
description: BALTIMORE. April 28 (AP) Mike Cuellar's basesloaded walk to Aurelio Rodriguez in the ninth inning forced home the tying run, then Gary Sutherland tagged Dave Johnson for a tworun single to give the Detroit Tigers a 53 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Washington

title: O'NEILL CONFIDENT KENNEDY'S IN RACE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Representative Thomas P. O'Neill, the House Democratic leader, said today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy is a candidate for the Presidency next year, despite continuing denials.

title: 5 Composers Hear Brooklyn Ensemble Play Their Works
description: Morris Lang preaches at Brooklyn College what he practices as a member of the New York Philharmonic, and the results were on impressive display Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall, with the first recital there by Mr. Lang's Brooklyn College Percussion Ensemble. The group's 12 student members played an astonishing ar ray of battery instruments in superb synchronization, with the confident individual and collective expertise of seasoned professionals.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Tuesday, April 29, 1975

title: POPE PAUL CHARGES DISTORTION OF NEWS
description: ROME, April 28Pope Paul VI warned the information media today against manipulating facts and audiences under the pretense of neutrality and independence.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Tomahawks Win First Time, 1917
description: BOSTON, April 28 The Long Island Tomahawks, after tying the game with 28 seconds to go in regulation time, defeated Boston, 1917, in overtime in the National Lacrosse League tonight before a crowd of 8,724 at Boston Garden.

title: EPISCOPAL COURT SUMMONS BISHOP
description: In a stern memoranduum, the ecclesiastical court of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington reaffirmed yesterday its call, to the church's Presiding Bishop, the Right Rev. John Maury to testify at the trial I of the Rev. William A. Wendt.

title: Cambodia Bars Foreign Bases; Move Believed Aimed at Hanoi
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 28The new Cambodian Government served notice today that no foreign military bases would be tolerated in Cambodia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders: 3d Round Begins Tonight
description: Euphoria and the 10day layoff will come to an end tonight when, the New York Islanders take their playoff bubble to Philadelphia where the National Hockey League champion Flyers have been pawing the ice for a week and a half waiting for semifinal opponent.

title: Dangerous School Cuts
description: Many of the painful austerity measures announced by Mayor Beanie are both overdue and necessary; but his call for larger school classes as a means of reducing teaching staffs is both undesirable and unnecessary. Particularly in the elementary schools, pupil achievement depends so directly on individual attention and the security of learning in small groups that any sacrifice these advantages would have totally unacceptable longterm effects.

title: March ChainStore Sales Up 7.6% on Early Easter
description: Chain stores, aided by an early Easter, achieved a gain of 7.6 per cent in sales volume in March, the biggest monthly gain so far this year, it was reported by Chain Store Age magazine.

title: Marcos Would Renegotiate Defense Accords With U.S.
description: MANILA, April 28 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that his Government would reassess and renegotiate all our relations with the United States in a spirit of friendship and caution.

title: Four Die in Baltimore Fire
description: BALTIMORE, April 28 (UPI) Fire burned through a threestory frame house in northwest Baltimore today killing four young persons and injuring six others.

title: NORTH KOREA GETS PEKING'S SUPPORT
description: PEKING, April 28 (Reuters) China today expressed resolute support for North Korean efforts to unite Korea but made clear that she did not want to see renewed conflict on the divided peninsula.

title: Children Warned On Risk of Riding On Backs of Buses
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday helped teach youngsters in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn about the dangers of hitching rides on the backs of city buses.

title: Mets Make Two Moves
description: The New York Mets took their sixgame winning streak to Chicago yesterday and made two player transactions as they prepared to defend it in a threegame series against the Cubs. They sold Jerry Moses, their No. 3 catcher, to the San Diego Padres, and they recalled Hank Webb from the minor leagues as their No. 5 pitcher.

title: A FINE MICAELA SUNG BY MISS MALFITANO
description: It's hard to see how a soprano can go wrong as Micaela, certainly one of the most gratefully written parts in the repertory. Catherine Malfitano sang the role for the first time with the New York City Opera in Sunday night's performance of Carmen and she was, not surprisingly, completely winning.

title: Housing Costs Found Hurting Middle Class
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)  Many middleclass families have been priced out of the housing market, ascording to a study prepared by the Library of Congress.

title: TV: ABC's Solid Returning Home
description: Returning Home (a miserable title), ABC's madeforTV movie at 8:30 tonight, is based on the film The Best Years of Our Lives. The film is a minor classic. Directed by William Wyler and written by Robert E. Sherwood, from a novel by MacKinlay Kantor, it carefully treads the thin line between realism and sentimentality in depicting the return to civilian life of three World War II veterans. This TV adaptation is not a classicmajor, minor or otherwise. It is a pilot for a possible series, and the possibilities for an endless soap opera are bubbling all over the opportunistic project.

title: Colon, Slighted in Mile, Makes Officials Wince
description: Tony Colon was bypassed for the Ben Franklin Mile at the Penn Relays last weekend in Philadelphia, which might have fired the enthusiasm that resulted in his best series of track performances this year.

title: Saudia Arabia Asks Tapline to Continue Supplies to Others
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 28 (AP)Saudi Arabia has asked the Americanowned TransArabian Pipeline (Tapline) to continue supplying oil to refineries in Lebanon and Jordan even though It is losing money, a Tapline spokesman announced today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 29, 1975

title: HUSSEIN WELCOMED IN CAPITAL FOR TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)King Hussein of Jordan, piloting a Boeing 707, landed at Andrews Air Force Base today and was met by Secretary of State Kissinger to.begin a private visit to Washington.

title: Saigon Defenses Attacked; Airport Under Rocket Fire
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 29Saigon's airport came under, the heaviest rocket attack of the war early this morning as North Vietnamese troops assaulted parts for the city's suburbs

title: MRS. JAMES, MAHONEY
description: Evelyn Flahive Mahoney, wife of James J. Mahoney, Former secretarytreasurer of the New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union, died yesterday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 12 Monroe Street.

title: 4 Architects Win U.D.C. Competition For Housing Designs for Roosevelt I.
description: Overwhelmed by what one member called evidence of a Wonderful direction for hoeshag, a sevenmember jury has selected not one, but four, winners for the Roosevelt Island Housing competition, an architectural event sponsored by the New York State Urban Development Corporation.

title: LINK FROM PARIS TO CAMBODIA CUT
description: PARIS, April 28 (Reuters)France has lost contact with her embassy in Phnom Penh and has appealed to the United Nations to intervene to rescue the French and foreign refugees who have been packed in there for 11 days, French officials said today.

title: Railroad Patchwork ...
description: The first official review of the preliminary plan for reorganizing the Penn Central and other bankrupt Northeast railroads raises monumental new doubts about the plan's practicality.

title: John Bull's Other Choice
description: LONDONVery strong opposition to continued British membership in the Common Market is going to be shown by a large section of the British public in the referendum, the first in British history, on June 5. It is vital that those outside Britain, particularly in the United States, should understand the deeply felt motives for this opposition.

title: TV Networks Lose Plea to Bar Trial
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Supreme Court refused today to block a second attempt by the Department of Justice to prosecute the three national television networks on a charge of violating the antitrust laws by monopolizing primetime entertainment programing.

title: Young Artists Cancels Final
description: The finals in the annual auditions conducted by the Young Concert Artists, which were to have been held at Hunter College tomorrow night, have been canceled. The auditions were to determine who would appear on the organization's concert series next season. This year, the judges decided that no one in the semifinals was eligible for the finals.

title: Youngsters Warned by Beame Not to Hitch Rides on Buses
description: Mayor Beame yesterday helped teach youngsters in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn about the dangers of hitching rides on the backs of city buses.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Vietcong's Reply to Mirth Denounces U.S. Policies
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 29Gen. Duong Van Minh assumed the Presidency of South Vietnam yesterday to seek peace with the Communists, but they rejected his initial declaration. Attacks continued around Saigon and a rocket barrage struck the capital's airport.

title: EDWIN T. ASPLUNDH
description: BRYN ATHYN, Pa., April 28 Edwin T. Asplundh, who retired in 1962 after five years as board chairman of PPG Industries, died here today at a nursing home. He was 86 years old.

title: Lockhart, Athas Wait To Be Free
description: Two days before they are eligible to become free agents, Pete Athas and Carl (Spider) Lockhart are waiting for the New York Giants to make the next move in their stalled contract negotiations.

title: Chess:
DR. GRACE GOLDSMITH
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 28 (AP)Dr. Grace A. Goldsmith, dean emerita of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at Tulane University and a nutritionist, died today. She was 71 years old.

title: Superport Plans Suspended
description: MORRO BAY, Calif. April 28 (UPI)Sttandard Oil Company of California said today it was suspending indefinitely plans to build an offshore superport that would have handled huge tankers bringing crude oil from the Alaska pipeline and foreign countries to the West Coast. Factors contributing to the situation included rapidly escalating costs, growing uncertainties about crude oil requirements and supply, and lack of Federal direction as to allowtariffs, said Jules Mayer, the project manager.

title: Pigless Secaueus, 75 Points With Pride
description: These days in Secaucus, N. J., it's diamonds before swine.

title: A Middle Course
description: New York State Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve has asked Gov. Hugh Carey to grant full amnesty to everyone who might be charged with a crime committed during the 1971 Attica prison riot, and says he will introduce legislation to provide such an amnesty if the Governor doesn't act.

title: Guam Faces Human Traffic Jam
description: OROTE POINT, Guam, Tuesday, April 29  Almost 6,000 more South Vietnamese refugees reached this United States territory in the last 24 hours as evidence began to mount that lengthy immigration clearance procedures, combined with a shortage of aircraft to carry evacuees on to the United States, would soon cause a major human traffic jam here.

title: Article 1  No Title
Compromise Tax Package Faces Strong Resistance
description: TRENTON, April 28Legislative leaders reported here today that the $750million compromise incometax package was facing strong resistance in the Senate and that the outlook was even more pessimistic in the Assembly.

title: STUDY IS PLANNED ON RESOURCE USE
description: Formation of a citizens commission to study the extent to which Americans are ready to adjust their lifestyle to larger sharing of world resources with other peoples was announced yesterday by Robert O. Anderson, chairman of the Aspen Institute of Humanistic Studies.

title: Two Cyprus Leaders Agree to New Panel
description: VIENNA, April 28Leaders of the Turkish and Greek Cypriote communities met here today with Secretary General Waldheim and came to an unexpectedly swift agreement to set up a committee to study proposals for a future government of Cyprus.

title: U.S. Youth Population Likely to Peak in 1980
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The nation's youth population will peak in 1980 and then decline, the Census Bureau said today.

title: EMERGENCY STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, April 29President Ford ordered the emergency evacuation today of all Americans remaininz in South Vietnam.

title: Miss Schwarzkopf in Stately Farewell
description: Retirement parties are seldom happy affairs. Although they can be boisterous, and all concerned put the best possible face on the matter, the villian named time is always there in the background trying to dampen everyone's spirits. Nevertheless Sunday night's song recital by Elisabeth Schwarzkopf at Carnegie Hall, billed as her Farewell United States Appearance, managed to make one forget its valedictory purpose much of the time.

title: Mansfield Warns Ford on Oil Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Senate Democratic leadership urged President Ford today to refrain from unilateral action on energy matters.

title: More Federal Grants and Fewer Loans to Students Are Urged by 23, Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Consortium of Higher Education Financing, a group of 23 of the nation's most prestigious colleges and universities, proposed today a revision in Federal student aid programs that would provide more grants and fewer loans to the country's poorer collene students.

title: Police Ask a Witness In Slaying to Phone
description: The police yesterday urged a witness to the fatal shooting of a Brooklyn resident to call them at 4497200. They said the witness's identity woud be kept confidential.

title: Dow Falls 1.80 to 810 As Trading Pace Slows
Derby Trial Spotlight on Round Stake
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 The Kentucky Derby lineup was nearcompletion today, with about a dozen horses likely to run in the annual race on Saturday. One step remained before the field could be clearly determinedthe running of the Derby Trial tomorrow.

title: Church Council and Blacks Join In Fighting School Union at Polls
description: In an effort to counter the United Federation of Teachers' campaign in the local school board elections next month, the antiracism division of the Council of Churches here has joined in a coalition with two lack church groups and the Alliance for Childrenan education lobby organizationand donated $1.000 to the coalition.

title: Helms Terms Newsman Killer For Hint of Murders by C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) Richard M. Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence, denounced a newsman today for reporting charges that the Central Intelligence Agency carried out the assassination of foreign leaders.

title: Judge Refuses to Remove Joanne Little's Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, N. C., April 28 (AP)Superior Court Judge Henry McKinnon denied a defense motion today to remove a special prosecutor from the Joanne Little murder case.

title: WEEKEND BOXING
description: TORONTO  Clyde Gray, 149 pounds, Toronto, knocked out Sammy Rookart, 149, Spartanburg, N. Y., 3 rounds.

title: ARAFAT ARRIVES FOR SOVIET TALK
description: MOSCOW, April 28Soviet efforts to arrange a new session of the Geneva conference on the Middle East reached new phase today as Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived for talks.

title: Books of The Times
description: 1. The Looming Shadow

title: CHICAGO PUT FIRST IN FIRE FATALITIES
description: CHICAGO, April 28 Chicago's fatality rate due to fires is the highest of the nation's 10 largest cities, according to a fourmonth study conducted by The Chicago Reporter, a monthly publication dealing with the city's racial matters.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES SEXCRIMES BILL
description: ALBANY, April 28A bill that would limit the admmis sibility of evidence of a victim's past sexual conduct and elimi nate much of the demeanig crossexamination in rape cases and other sex crimes was passed by the Assembly today 140 to 2.

title: 2 Times Reporters Chosen as Winners Of the Polk Awards
description: Two New York Times reporters, Seymour M. Hersh and Richard Severo, were among the winners of 1975 George Polk Memorial Awards for outstanding journalistic achievement announced here yesterday.

title: H. Kauffman Marks Century as Saddlery
description: The air at H. Kauffman & Sons was redolent with saddle soap and nostalgia yesterday as Mayor Beame presented the city's Citation of Business Merit to the saddlery that has catered, to New York's horsey set for 100 years.

title: TV Networks Lose. Plea to Bar Trial
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Supreme Court refused today to block a second attempt by the Department of Justice to prosecute the three national television networks on a charge of Violating the antitrust laws by monopolizing primetime entertainment programing.

title: BOND PRICES FALL ON BROAD FRONT
description: Bond prices were lower across a broad front yesterday as the investment community awaited details of Treasury plans on Thursday to refund $3.8billion of maturing debt and to raise perhaps an additional $2billion in net new cash early next month. It was a classic case of prerefunding jitters, one analyst declared.

title: U.S. Study Predicts 23% Price Decline On '75 Wheat Crop
description: WASHINGTON. April 28 (UPI)Farmers may see average 1975 crop wheat prices dipping 23 per cent, from 1974 and corn prices slumping 27 per cent if production reaches currently forecast levels, a Government study shows.

title: Dillon to Jordan and Crawford
description: BBDO International, the parent company of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, held its annual meeting yesterday morning and then its board of directors departed the scene and elected Bruce Crawford president of the parent and James J. Jordan president of the subsidiary, which is its major operating unit.

title: Vietcong's Reply to Minh Denounces U.S. Policies
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 29Gen. Duong Van Minh assumed the Presidency of South Vietnam yesterday to seek peace with the Communists, but they rejected his initial declaration. Attacks continued around Saigon and rocket barrage struck the capital's airport.

title: U.S. Post Office Halts Mail to South Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  The United States Postal Service announced today that it had temporarily suspended delivery of civilian mail destined for South Vietnam.

title: Former Gurney Aide Testifies F.H.A. Officials Raised Money
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 28A onetime aide to former Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida testified today in Mr. Gurney's trial that most Federal Housing Administration officials in Florida were eager to help raise money for Mr. Gurney by in effect selling commitments to home builders for F.H.A. insurance and F.H.A. grants.

title: Stringent Federal Law Backed To Halt Black Market in Babies
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)  The executive director of the Child Welfare League called today for tough penalties against persons who sell babies for profit as well as for couples who pay exorbitant fees for black market children.

title: Military Bases in Arkansas, Florida, California to House Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Large numbers of South Vietnamese refugees will be flown to three military bases in Arkansas, Florida and California for temporary housing in the United States, the Defense Department announced today.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE OF 11.5% HIGHEST IN THREE DECADES
description: The unemployment rolls grew by 40,300 in the city in March, bringing the total of jobless people here to 372,600 and the unemployment rate to 11.5 per cent, a high for the threedecade postWorld War II period, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: Blacks Fighting to Save a Part of Their Army History
description: JUNCTION CITY, Kan., April 28To some people in this small Kansas city, a part of black history will disappear if plans to redevelop East Ninth Street are carried out.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX FINISH DAY MIXED
description: After a strong opening, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterady in slackened trading as prices in the overthecounter market finished lower and volume also decreased.

title: Laurents's Scream Is Set
description: Arthur Laurents's latest play, Scream, will be produced on Broadway in the fall by Fritz Holt and Barry M. Brown. The drama is in two acts and calls for five major characters. It takes place a generation after World War II. The principal charatter is described as an ageless, invincible survivor of Auschwitz, a woman with a mordant sense of humor. The author will direct.

title: State Aide Admits Failure of Albany Jail Inquiry
description: ALBANY, April 28A leading official of the State Commission of Correction conceded today the commission had failed to investigate numerous reports of incidents at the Albany County Jail, including the smuggling of hacksaw blades, an escape, and charges that more than a dozen guards were homosexually involved with prisoners at the jail.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States will sponsor a nationwide family mixed doubles tennis tournament that will have its final rounds in conjunction with the United States Open at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. It hopes to attract as many as 100,000 entrants to Family Tennis Challenge.

title: Killanin Sure Games Will Open
description: MONTREAL, April 28Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that he was entirely certain that the Summer Games would take place here next year as planned.

title: N.B.A. Picks O'Brien As New Commissioner O'Brien to Head N.B.A
description: Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will be the new commissioner of the perience, were voted on by ciation. The 18 N.B.A. owners ended a long search for a successor to Walter Kennedy Friday in Chicago by electing O'Brien unanimously.

title: Funeral Services Held on Town Hall. Lawn for East Brunswick Mayor
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, April 28More than 5,000 people paid tribute to Mayor Jean Walling here today as she lay in state in the township's municipal building and later during her funeral.

title: Johns Hopkins No. 1 On Lacrosse Ballot
description: The Johns Hopkins lacrosse squad is blazing its way toward another national championship. For the seventh week in a row the undefeated Blue Jays top the coaches' poll, released by the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

title: Rightists Fighting to Retake Strategic Laos Crossroads
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 28 (Reuters)  Rightist forces fought today to retake the strategic Sala Phou Khoun crossroads that they abandoned under Pathet Lao artillery bombardment earlier, military sources said.

title: A Patient Is Found Dead At New Lisbon State School
description: TRENTON, April 28 (UPI)A severely retarted patient, at the New Lisbon State School was found suffocated with styro foam and tied in a strait jacket officials said today.

title: NIXON FILES REPLY TO HALPERIN SUIT
description: Richard M. Nixon has submitted a court statement that he authorized wiretaps on the telephone of Morton H. Halperin, former assistant to Henry A. Kissinger, to protect national security information against foreign intelligence activities.

title: Ford Aides Hint Campaign Sabotage
description: WASHINGTON, April 28President Ford definitely plans to run for election next year and some of his aides believe that someone is trying to sabotage his candidacy with reports he may not run, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Carey's Veto Threat on New Spending Is a Big Political Gamble
description: ALBANY, April 27With his promise last week to veto any new spending programs the Legislature passes without the corresponding taxes to pay for them. Governor Carey embarked on the biggest gamble of his fourmonth old administration. In some ways, he looked like a man consigned to tossing a coin according to the rules of heads you win, tails I lose.

title: SOARES TERMS VOTE BIG DEFEAT FOR REDS
description: LISBON, April 28 (Reuters) The Socialist party's leader, Mario Soares, said today that his party's victory in Friday's elections was an immense defeat for the Communists.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: 81ST BLOW MARKS WNET FUND DRIVE
description: The television premiere of the Israelimade documentary The 81st Blow will be the focal special program In the spring membership drive of WNET/13, which has taken the thematic title of A Time to Remember in devoting itself to a commemoration of the 30th anniversary of VE Day.

title: THIEU WILL REMAIN IN TAIWAN FOR WEEK
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 28 (AP)Former President Nguyen Van Thieu plans to stay in Taiwan for at least another week before deciding whether to fly to another country, the South Vietnamese ??bassy said today.

title: MRS. ROBERT C. BARR
description: Judith Cunningham Barr, wife of Robert C. Barr, magazinegroup executive for Time Inc., died Sunday at her home in Darien, Conn., at the age of 58. Mrs. Barr had been active in the Stamford Rehabilitation Center and was a member of the Junior League of New York. She was a graduate of the University of Chicago.

title: Allied Chemical Optimistic On Oil and Gas Exploration
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 28 (Reuters)  The Allied Chemical Corporation's Longrange program for oil and gas exploration should soon start making a favorable impact on earnings, the company's chairman, John T. Connor, said at its annual meeting here today.

title: Market Place
description: The bid of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation for 38 per cent of the shares of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., has turned into a real donny brook that has important accounting, conflictofinterest and stock market implications.

title: Chrysler Planning Rebates Of $200 on 2 Lines of Cars
description: DETROIT, April 28The Chrysler Corporation confirmed today that it would offer rebates on two lines of cars and some of its trucks during May.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Eastern railroads, except for the Chessie System, and the Western railroads, filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to raise freight rates in 45 days by 5 per cent.

title: TESORO AMENDS BID FOR REFINER
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had amended its tenderoffer statement for the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company as required by the Federal Court here. Tesoro has extended its tender offer for 5.5 million shares of Commonwealth at $11.50 a share un til 10:30 A.M. May 9. The offer was to have expired tomorrow.

title: Rumanians Tighten Emigration Curbs
description: BUCHAREST, April 22 When the Soviet Union renounced its trade agreement with the United States last January because it would not accept the American requirement linking trading advantages to freer emigration, Bulgaria, Hungary and Czechoslovakia quickly aligned themselves with the Soviet position.

title: David L. Stevenson Dies at 64; Led Hunter English Department
description: David L. Stevenson, chairman of the English department at Hunter College, died yesterday at his home on Puddler's Lane In Falls Village, Conn., of causes undetermined pending an autopsy. He was 64 years old.

title: Pan Am Has 59Million Loss
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a first quarter consolidated net loss of $59million, after a tax credit of $5.2million. This compared with a net loss of $24.4million, after a tax credit of $24.1million, reported for the yearago quarter.

title: Shah Arrives in Saudi Arabia For 2Day Visit With King
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 28 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran arrived in Saudi Arabia today for a twoday state visit that could set guidelines for future relations between the Middle Eastern gulf states.

title: Health Department Cites 21 Concerns As Food Violators
description: The Health Department has named 21 more foodhandling establishments that, it said, failed to pass a second Health Code inspection and warned that failure to pass a final inspection could result in closing orders.

title: Upheaval in Honduras
description: The admission that United Brands Company paid a $1.25million bribe to an official of the Government of Honduras to obtain a cut in the export tax on bananas will damage the standing of multinational corporations everywhere and bolster demands for more stringent control over their operations.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Kentucky vs. St. Louis

title: H. Kauffman Marks Century as Saddlery
description: The air at H. Kauffman & Sons was redolent with saddle soap and nostalgia yesterday as Mayor Beame presented the city's Citation of Business Merit to the saddlery that has catered to New York's horsey set for 100 years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Thursday incorrectly listed the Islamic Center of Washington as one of the sponsors of a conference on Religion's Role in a Violent World convened by the Armenian Church of America. The center withdrew its cosponsorship of the conference several months ago.

title: Council Group Backs Bill For GasStorage Rules
description: A bill that would set up an 11member board to set standards for the storage and transportation of liquefied natural gas in the city was approved yesterday by the City Council's Public Safety Committee.

title: JOINT RAIL SERVICE BACKED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)The Senate passed a hill today to permit one railroad to operate the services of another in an emergency.

title: King Plans AliFrazier In Honolulu
description: Don King, who has lost money for promoters in Zaire and Cleveland, said yesterday he would bring Muhammad All to Honolulu to fight Joe Frazier next September.

title: ...vs. National System
description: Far more substantial outlays are involved, however, in the fundamental task envisaged by the planning office the upgrading of track and equipment on a national basis, along with comparable improvements in efficiency and service quality for other forms of transportation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The office of the New York State Welfare Inspector General said an investigation of the Hempstead Medical Services on Long Island had disclosed abuses in the health care provided to Medicail and Medicare patients. Among the charges was that allergy testing was done improperly and that the taking of Xrays was done by unlicensed personnel, and that the facility was operated by a nonprofessional. The proprietor denied any wrongdoing.

title: College and School Results
Cambodia Bars Foreign Bases; Move Believed Aimed at Hanoi
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 28The new Cambodian Government served notice today that no foreign military bases would be tolerated in Cambodia.

title: TAIWAN PARTY GIVES KEY POST TO CHIANG
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 28Premier Chiang Chingkuo's dominant political position was reinforced today when he was named head of the governing Nationalist party, or Kuomintang, at a special conference of the party leadership. He will hold the concurrent titles of chairman of the Central Committee and of the Central Standing Committee, with express authority over all party affairs.

title: Red Defeat in Lisbon
description: LISBON, April 28  Before Portugal's election last weekend, the general prediction had been that the Communist party would trail, and that its voting strength would come nowhere near matching its organization and its apparent influence in public life. But few Portuguese or foreign ers ventured to put the Communist figure as low as it turned out to be.

title: EXBERGMAN AIDE DECLINES TO TALK
description: A former administrator of the Towers Nursing Home, owned by Bernard Bergman, has invoked what she called Talmudic law in refusing to testify before a special grand jury investigating nursing homes here.

title: G.M. Quarter Profit Off 50.8% From Depressed 1974 Periop
description: DETROIT, April 29The General Motors Corporation reported today firstquarter net income of $59million, or 20 cents a share, a decline of 50.8 per cent from the depressed first quarter of 1974 when the company earned $120million, or 41 cents a share.

title: Tesoro Tender Bid For Commonwealth Shortened by Court
description: Federal Judge John M. Cannella ruled here yesterday that the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation's cender offer to purchase 38 per cent of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company would be valid until 5 P.M. on May 6. An amended tender offer had called for an extension of the offer to May 9. Judge Cannella also ordered Commonwealth to make available to Tesoro its list of shareholders.

title: Council Grapples With RentRise Bill
description: After a full day of intensive bargaining involving the Beame administration, the City Council leadership and recalcitrant Councilmen, Council leaders gave up the effort last night to obtain immediate agreement on a bill that would permit special rent increases in many of the 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments here.

title: 74 Saigon Planes Fly 2,000 to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 29At least 74 South Vietnamese Air Force planes fleeing the country streamed into U Taphao air base in southern Thailand without warning this afternoon.

title: City Hall Protest Staged By Goldwater's Patients
description: Quadriplegics in motorized chairs and wrapped in blankets against a chilly breeze were among the 500 patients and employes at Goldwater Hospital who gathered in City Hall Park yesterday to protest Mayor Beame's proposed closing of the hospital as an economy move.

title: Mild Tremor Shakes Luzon
description: MANILA, April 29 (AP)A mild earthquake shook the Philippines' main island of Luzon at 4:42 P.M. today [4:42 A.M. Tuesday New York time], officials reported. They said the tremor had lasted four to five seconds and had an epicenter 80 miles southeast of here. There was no immediate report of damage.

title: Saigon Copter Lands on Another In Stampede to U.S. Ship's Deck
description: ABOARD U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE, in South China Sea, April 29Scores of South Vietnamese helicopters filled with military men and civilians fled Saigon today and headed out to sea to search for the carriers of the United States Seventh Fleet.

title: G.M.'s Profits Fall
description: Firstquarter profits of General Motors declined 50.8 per cent from the depressed 1974 quarter. Page 53.

title: Cuba Weighs Castro Plan To Decentralize Power
description: HAVANA, April 29 (Reuters) Cuba is discussing Premier Fidel Castro's plan to inject some democracy into the Communist oneparty system here and to decentralize the state apparatus by electing provincial assemblies.

title: CAMBODIA ORDERS FOREIGNERS OUT
description: PARIS, April 29The French Government said today that the people who have been isolated in its Phnom Penh embassy since the Cambodian Communists took over two weeks ago had been ordered expelled in the worst possible conditions.

title: RIGHTS HELD ISSUE IN COLLEGE OUSTER
description: FREEHOLD, April 29  A longtime newspaperman and, professor of journalism contended in State Superior Court today that the dismissal of Patricia Endress from the journalism faculty of Brookdale Community College was a violation of academic freedom and freedom of the Dress.

title: Antipornography Center Losing U. S. Aid
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., April 29Faced with mounting academfc and legal criticism, the Department of Justice has canceled its subsidized operation of a national clearing house for the prosecution of pornography cases, set up two years ago on the campus of a small sectarian college here.

title: ULASEWICZ CITED ON TAX CHARGES
description: Anthony I. Ulasewicz, the White House intermediary who secretly distributed more than $200,000 in cash to the Watergate burglars to keep them quiet, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having filed false and fraudulent income tax returns for 1971 and 1972.

title: U. S. ASTRONAUTS VISIT SOVIET BASE
EvenHanded Injustice
description: The Special Prosecutor and the courts have failed see that justice is done in the widespread violation of the law by major corporations which have maintained secret political slush funds. The prosecutors have settled for gentlemanly negotiated pleas. Judges have imposed trivial fines that barely amounted to taps on the wrist.

title: General Dynamics Planning No Shift of Tanker Orders
description: QUINCY, Mass, Aprl 20 (AP) The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it had no plans of transfer construction work on any liquefied natural gas tankers from the Quincy shipyards to builders in Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: Mets, With Seaver, Crush Cubs for 7th Straight, 9 to 1
description: CHICAGO, April 29Ecstasy in Snoopy terms is to go out to pitch the second inning against the Cubs on a sunny spring afternoon in Wrigley Field with an 80 lead. Thus ecstasy came to George Thomas Seaver today as the New York Mets buffeted Chicago, 91.

title: Youth, 17, Is Electrocuted
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., April 29 (AP)A 17yearold Plymouth youth was killed today when he touched a 12,000volt high tension wire. The police said Brian P. Arnold was eleltcocuted when he and a companion apparently climbed some high tension girders 40 to 50 feet above ground.

title: Lawyer Convicted Of Bribing Leuci Denied New Trial
description: An attempt to obtain a new trial for Edmund A. Rosner, a Manhattan lawyer convicted of bribery, was rejected yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: LIBERIAN OFFICIAL DIES IN AIR CRASH
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 29 (Reuters)  Liberia's finance minister, Stephen A. Tolbert, and five other people were killed when their aircraft crashed in the sea just after takeoff at Greenville, 203 miles south of here, reports from rescuers said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three inmates of Rikers Island prison, held on minor robbery charges, were indicted yesterday for homicide in the April 1 strangulation of a fourth inmate who had twice tried to commit suicide and then asked fellow inmates to help him, Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola announced.

title: BOMB BLASTS HOME OF A C.I.A. OFFICIAL
description: DENVER, April 29 (UPI)A pipe bomb explosion outside the suburban home of a Central Intelligence Agency official may have been caused by radicals inspired by the bombing of a bank hours earlier, or may have been the work of a crackpot, the police said today.

title: The Americans Depart
description: The United States left Vietnam with the same confusion and lack of direction that took this country there in the first place. The scenes of agony and tumult Saigon yesterday, as the helicopters lifted American diplomats and panicstricken Vietnamese away, add up to one more sorrowful episode at the conclusion of an Americanand Vietnamesetragedy.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed in order of Post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Pittston's Profits Soar 276%
People in Sports
description: I was a luxury and not in their plans, said Sonny Jurgensen yesterday. The National Football Conference's leading passer last season was alluding to the threehour contract meeting he had with Washington's head coach and general manager, George Allen, last week. The 41yearold Jurgensen, who feels the Redskins have dropped him, played out his option at $120,000 last season and will become a free agent tomorrow if not signed.

title: VW to Have Six Plants On Short Hours in May
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, April 29 (Reuters)  Volkswagenwerk, A.G., said today further period of shorttime workingthe sixth this yearwould be in effect at four of its six domestic plants next month.

title: College, School Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Thomson's Pleasing Nonsense Cantata
description: With the exception of his film scores, Virgil Thomson's two operas have remained his most successful, characteristic and original works. There is nothing comparable to the alliance of the Gertrude Stein librettos with the composer's extraordinarily sensitive settings. Mr. Thomson has now turned to somewhat similar material for his latest work to be given its premiere here, and the results are equally felicitous. for his latest work to be given its premiere here, and the results are equally felicitous.

title: Phone Company Gets No Answer in Saigon
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said in New York yesterday that calls to South Vietnam were no longer getting through.

title: Saigon's Surrender Texts
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Following are the texts, in unofficial translation, of President Duong Van Minh's address on the surrender of South Vietnam and of the General Staff's order to South Vietnamese forces:

title: President's Statement
description: WASHINGTON, April 29Following is the text President Ford's statement today on Vietnam:

title: DAMAGES BACKED FOR MALPRACTICE
description: TRENTON, April 29  The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a medical mal practice victim was entitled to damages even though none of the individual defendants in the case has been found guilty of negligence. Rather, the. state's highest court said, each defendant must prove his innocence.

title: SAMUEL WEBSTER
description: Samuel W. Webster, a retired certified public accountant, died at his home here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: U.S. Defenses Abroad
description: BRUSSELSThe annual defense budget debate now under way in Congressional committees in Washington is being watched at NATO headquarters here as a crucial indicator of American foreign policy in the postVietnam era.

title: U.S., GREECE AGREE TO END HOME PORT FOR THE 6TH FLEET
description: ATHENS, April 29United States and Greek officials announced today the termination of the homeport arrangement for Sixth Fleet ships at the port of Eleusis near Athens and the closing of the American air base at Athens airport.
